review_text:
"I wanted to be brave for these girls": Sunshine is on the verge of joining the national gymnastics team and going to the Olympics, when she loses focus, careens off balance, and falters. Dreams nearly in her grasp shift to distant phantoms as she realizes she is pregnant. Shaken, fearful, desperate, and determined not to lose her rightful place on the national team, Sunshine searches the underground of the city for abortifacients. Abortion and even divorce are illegal in the Philippines, so Sunshine has few options and few people she can trust. Just then a mysterious young girl appears in the darkness and crowded streets with knowledge of Sunshine's heart that surprises her and touches her deeply.

"I wanted to be brave for these girls," said Maris Racal (Sunshine) "who have no one else to turn to." Racal is intrinsically believable in her role. In the conservative religious culture of the Philippines and with the lack of access to reproductive support, many girls are in crisis. The issue is relatable and timely not just in the Philippines, but in many other countries including, unfortunately, our own.

At this world premiere screening at the Toronto International Film Festival, director Antoinette Jadaone said she got the idea for an imaginary friend from the film Jojo Rabbit. As part of her film research Jadaone interviewed girls who had abortions. She hopes the film sparks conversations and change, that it is part of the solution for the country, and helps girls in such situations make their own decisions.

An honest, genuine and raw moving story!: I've seen this movie at the cinema alone last night and truly I can say that this is absolutely a genuine heartfelt cinematic experience movie. The story is really an eye opening for everyone especially for the young teenage women out there. It was really sad and heartbreaking story for a young athlete who had a dream to do good in gymnastics in the olympics but struggled in the process because of getting pregnant and doing an abortion in order to do so. One of the best part in the movie wherein I cried and felt bad for the main lead actress was her motel scene, where there is quietness of being alone but all you can hear is the noise of the train running in the background. This scene was very raw and sad to watch especially the time when she struggled so hard to abort her baby just to make sure that she can continue with her dream in the gymnastics. Overall this movie, definitely can be a great contender at the Oscars International Film Feature especially by how cinematic, and compelling the story was. I love how the movie tackled a controversial topic that everyone needs to hear and be open about. Maris Racal and her eyes in this movie is seriously a gem, such an amazing and effective best actress of this generation.

This is the sunshine the country needs in today's climate.: This is the sunshine the country needs in today's climate.

It was Jadaone's courage that popped in my head when the title card flashed, a very Filipina name that connotes brightness and warmth - two things the film was not intended for, two things the titular character deprived of.

Sunshine is a story of every Sunshine, a Filipino woman vulnerable to systemic injustice and oppression; a story no one could have been told better than a Filipino woman herself - and a fearless and intelligent one at that. From reproductive health and general health care system to conservatism, Jadaone's care and spirit championed. Her personification of one's conscience was beautifully done. I sobbed through the last 15 minutes.

True-to-life darkness in the country executed from the literal streets to the contexts of quality of life through Orendain's realism. There's a harrowing frame in the movie that ticked all my boxes as a fan of dark cinematography. I bled in the dark with Sunshine right there.

This film boasts a talented bundle of actresses: Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, Jennica Garcia, with Maris Racal tying the ribbon, flexing her acting muscles across different tones and needs. Well-written and well-directed performances with standouts coming from Garcia, Co, and Racal. Ah, women.

Malalim. Matapang. Mahalaga. Hindi ako babae pero gets na gets kita, Sunshine.

Nice movie.: It follows a young gymnast who discovers she is pregnant on the week of the national team tryouts. On her way to a seller of illegal abortion drugs, she meets a mysterious girl who eerily talks and thinks like her.

Dude the cinematography and camera angles in this trailer is what I have been wishing Philippine Cinema would have already been by now. Not the disappointing films they keep hyping and giving fake accolade.

Finally, a realistic story, not about kabit, poor/rich love story, badings. This is a realistic struggle of teen pregnancy in the Phil.

Sobrang deserve ni Maris makakuha ng maraming awards sa acting! Ang ganda! Ang galing!

Perfect execution: Directed by: Antoinette Jadaone Written by: Antoinette Jadaone

SUMMARY

A teenage gymnast, training to compete in the Olympics, is derailed when she discovers she's pregnant. In the Philipppines, where abortion is illegal, she risks everything to end the pregnancy. After surviving a near-fatal scam abortion pill, she finally succeeds and finds closure in a vision of her future child giving her her blessing.

RATING

S

Sunshine is absolutely perfect filmmaking. A simple plot - so simple that it risks being stale, but isn't! - that is executed with perfection and nuance. Sometimes the hardest things to get right are those that are the simplest. Superb casting.

A Powerful 10/10 Film That Tells the Truth: This 2024 Filipino film follows a teenage gymnast, Sunshine, whose Olympic dreams are suddenly derailed when she finds out she's pregnant. What unfolds is a raw, deeply emotional journey through shame, societal pressure, and the painful reality of having no legal access to abortion-something many women across Asia still face today.

The film doesn't sugarcoat anything. It shows exactly what's wrong with restrictive abortion laws in many Asian countries-how they silence girls, punish ambition, and force life-changing decisions on those who are still children themselves.

The movie itself is honest, hard-hitting, and emotionally devastating in the best way.

Maris Racal's performance was absolutely stunning. She carries the entire film with a performance that is real, raw, and unforgettable.

Sunshine should be shown in classrooms, government offices, and households. It's that important. It sparks urgent conversations about women's rights, bodily autonomy, and the price of silence.

Sunshine is one of the most courageous and necessary films to come out of Southeast Asia in recent years. It holds up a mirror to society and forces viewers to face uncomfortable truths. Anyone who thinks film can't change minds hasn't seen this one yet.

This is not just a good movie-this is essential cinema.

10/10. A masterpiece.

One of the most important Filipino films: "Sunshine" is not just the greatest Filipino movie I've seen but one of the most important Filipino films of all-time! This film deals with controversial topics in our society, abortion and teen pregnancy.

A week of national tryout for the gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal) finds out that she's pregnant. Conflicts arise as she has to decide what to do next. In between life and dreams, what's the most significant between the two?

The film is unconventional at best. This is not your usual and average Filipino drama you'll see. It's a character study about a teenager who is on the down side of her life. We follow her journey through this life and see a glimpse of her life dealing with her problem.

Maris Racal defines this film as Sunshine. Her acting here is brilliant. She's perfect for this role. Jennica Garcia surprised me. Her character as Sunshine's sister marks! What she said to Sunshine near the ending, though it's common, is like a punch to tears! I ended up loving her character. Jennica Garcia deserves an award for being the best supporting actress for this role. Another cast that standout is Rhed Bustamante and Xyriel Manabat both deserve a recognition for their role.

Blurring between reality and fantasy, mostly this film is realistic in portraying the whole theme thanks to Direk Antoinette Jadaone directions. Also, the cinematography is the best!

Overall, "Sunshine" is a women's movie. It's timely, affecting and brave to its theme. It doesn't spoon feed. It will make you immersed and think. It's worth an experience. This is a rare Filipino movie I've seen! I'm glad and proud watching this in cinema. After watching "Sunshine", it leaves me with a question, "Is abortion a choice if your greatest dream will compromise?"

Sunshine is the collective experience of many Filipina: We watched Sunshine yesterday, July 24, during the block screening at SM Megamall. I had seen the trailer beforehand, so I knew we were in for something bold, something necessary. But I wasn't prepared for how deeply it would sit with me long after the credits rolled.

I didn't cry while watching the film, but once it ended, I found myself overwhelmed. The weight of Sunshine doesn't hit all at once - it lingers, it settles. And it stays.

At its core, Sunshine is the story of a woman taking control of her body in a society that keeps telling her she isn't allowed to. It's not simply about one choice, one moment, or one woman. It's about the collective experience of many Filipinas who navigate a system that consistently fails to hear them.

Antoinette Jadaone's direction doesn't shy away from discomfort. She faces it head-on, inviting the audience to confront the silences we've learned to live with - about abortion, reproductive rights, the stigma around sexuality, and the lack of access to informed sex education in the Philippines.

Sunshine is timely, urgent, and painfully real. It gives voice to the cry of our generation, echoing the need for progressive reforms that protect women and children. The film challenges its viewers not just to empathize, but to act.

As a viewer, I left the cinema not only moved, but also awakened. Sunshine isn't here to entertain. It's here to disturb, to provoke, and to push us into uncomfortable yet necessary conversations.

To my fellow Filipinos: let's not turn away. Let's create spaces where women can speak freely, where choices about their bodies are met with compassion, not judgment. Let's demand that our lawmakers stop treating reproductive health as taboo.

To filmmakers and storytellers: keep telling these stories. We need more films like Sunshine-bold, unapologetic, and grounded in truth. The personal is political, and cinema has the power to move both heart and policy.

Let Sunshine be a beginning. Let it be a spark. And let's keep the conversation going.

Sunshine - A Raw and Eye-Opening Film: Sunshine is truly an eye-opener. It bravely tackles real issues that so many young adults-and even kids who are just stepping into their teenage years-are silently going through. The film dives deep into the realities of early pregnancy, abortion, and the emotional and social weight that comes with them.

What I really hope is that parents take the time to watch this film. Not just to be aware, but to feel that urgency-the need to guide and talk to their children about these sensitive but important topics. It's a conversation that can't be delayed anymore.

What stood out to me the most was how real and raw everything felt. I didn't leave the cinema feeling happy, but I did feel relieved. I felt the pain, the heartache, and the struggle that Sunshine went through-but I also saw the strength in her journey. The story is complete. It gives you everything from beginning to end, no shortcuts, no sugar-coating.

I loved the film. I honestly want to watch it again-not just for the story, but for the emotions it stirred up and the awareness it brings. This film matters.

Perfect, Very Relevant: Will keep this short, but I can't due to the minimum characters. It perfectly captures and delivers the message it intends to relay. Just beautiful! Loved it!

Very, very relevant. Moves you even if you yourself cannot directly relate, and that is where the magic proves itself!

Great acting as well by almost everyone in the cast!

Sunshine: The performances are outstanding, with the lead actress delivering a raw and emotional portrayal of Sunshine's struggles. The supporting cast adds depth to the story, particularly the little girl, who brings a sense of wonder and curiosity to the film.

One of the most striking aspects of "Sunshine" is its refusal to provide easy answers. The film presents a realistic portrayal of the complexities surrounding reproductive choices, leaving viewers to ponder the moral implications.

Still processing. This film stays with you.: Maris Racal delivers an incredibly raw and grounded performance. You feel her tension, her fear, her hope and the heartbreak that comes from making an impossible decision. She doesn't ask you to agree with her character. She just asks you to understand. And that's powerful.

Direk Tonet Jadaone has once again proven her gift for telling stories that cut deep. This film doesn't shout, but it lingers. It haunts you in the quiet moments. It reflects a reality many would rather not see one where shame is louder than support, and judgment comes faster than help.

Responsibility is Also a Choice: The film Sunshine, directed by Antoinette Jadaone, presents a deeply emotional and socially relevant story that challenges how Filipinos view teenage pregnancy, abortion, and womanhood. It is a complex and sensitive topic, especially in a country that is deeply rooted in religion and traditional values. As a viewer and as someone who is pro-abortion, I strongly believe that abortion should be legalized-not to promote recklessness, but to ensure safe healthcare for women who are placed in impossible situations.

What makes Sunshine powerful is how quietly but painfully it reflects reality. The film does not exaggerate emotions; instead, it shows how fear, confusion, and pressure from society weigh heavily on young women. It highlights how judgment often speaks louder than understanding. In many cases, the girl is seen as the only one responsible for what happened, while the systems meant to protect her fail.

In the Philippines, many people argue that illegalizing abortion teaches responsibility. But isn't choosing abortion also a form of responsibility? Knowing that you are not ready-emotionally, financially, or mentally-to raise a child can already be an act of maturity. We openly preach safe sex, yet we deny women access to safe abortion. This contradiction puts women's lives at risk.

For me, this issue is not about the rights of a fetus alone-it is also about the rights of a living woman. In my own view, if my mother had gotten pregnant in her teenage years while still chasing her dreams, I would rather not be born than be the reason her future was taken away. I would not remember it, I would not suffer from that decision-but at least she would have lived the life she wanted. That, too, is a form of love and sacrifice.

Another harsh reality the film touches on is how society treats teenagers who experience early pregnancy. Many say, "They enjoyed it," or "They wanted it." But a child or a teenager needs guidance from responsible adults, not condemnation. Blaming them does not fix the problem. This is not about tolerating impulsive behavior-it is about educating both girls and boys, teaching accountability, protection, and respect.

Sunshine makes you realize that judgment is easy, but compassion is rare. The film reminds us that behind every controversial situation is a scared, confused young girl who still deserves empathy and protection.

Overall, Sunshine is a brave and emotionally heavy film that forces us to confront one of the most uncomfortable issues in Filipino society. It does not give easy answers, but it asks the right questions. For me, the film strengthens the belief that abortion should be legalized-not to promote irresponsibility, but to protect women, save lives, and give them the freedom to choose their own future. True responsibility does not come from punishment and shame, but from understanding, education, and safe choices. Sunshine is not just a movie-it is a mirror of our society and a challenge to our beliefs.

A Missed Opportunity to Stick the Landing: I had been waiting a long time to watch Sunshine, especially since I never got the chance to see it on the big screen. So, when it finally arrived on Netflix, I was so excited, only for that excitement to fade the longer I watched.

The premise is undeniably compelling: a young gymnast discovers she's pregnant just as her lifelong dream of reaching the Olympics is within reach. It's a setup filled with emotional stakes and potential for a powerful, character-driven story.

But instead of exploring her dedication to the sport, the film shifts almost entirely to her pregnancy and her attempts to deal with it. I kept waiting for scenes that would show her fighting for her dream, intense training, the pressure of competition, the physical and emotional toll of gymnastics, but those moments never really come. The narrative focuses more on side characters and subplots that feel unnecessary and, frankly, uninteresting.

I couldn't help comparing this film to other international athlete biopics that portray the grit, passion, and relentless work behind the journey. Sunshine had all the ingredients to deliver that kind of inspiring story, but it simply doesn't stick the landing.

Overall, I'm disappointed. With a stronger focus on the athletic journey and the challenges of balancing an unexpected pregnancy with Olympic ambitions, this could have been a much more compelling and memorable film.

This film truly highlights how anti abortion is violence against women: While the subject is powerful and brave and the acting excellent, the execution and cinematography are weak, marring what could have been an excellent film.

What it does well is highlight how anti abortion is violence against women. It shows how the anti abortion crowd destroys the lives of young women through lack of sex education and lack of health care combined with horrid anti women propaganda.

The hospital scene where the evil "Jesus" Dr. Berates the propagandist for attempting an abortion absolutely enraged me because it is so accurate as to how women are treated.

I think the film would have been better if it has put more emphasis on Sunshine's sister who supported and helped her. I wanted more of that.

All that said, this is a powerful and timely film about an important subject. I applaud all those involved for having the courage to show the evil at the heart of Filipino culture, and for daring to stand up against the "pro life" machine.

TIFF 2024 #41: Centrepiece (World Premiere)Gripping, distressing - among many things that can be said to describe the experience of a woman who could just as easily lose everything she ever knew with as much as a single unplanned pregnancy. But perhaps the added stress to watching Sunshine is only exacerbated by the environment in which our title character is inhabiting, where the conservative religious and social norms of the Philippines are infringing on her own rights as a human being too.Really liked this one a whole lot.
So was that girl a personified version of her fetus or was she literally just stalking her?

World Premiere at TIFF 2024! Maris is magnetic. She makes the movie. I also wanna commend Jennica Garcia! I was deeply moved by her. The storytelling I wanna say is quite…unexpected. It added to the layers of the movie and I just know this will totally ruffle feathers when it finally gets shown in the Philippines. Even on the Q&A Director Antoinette Jadaone mentioned she wanted to spark the conversation on this, to which I hope people don’t take for granted. Also, the cameos! I live for them.
TIFF 2024 - World Premiere. I really enjoyed this one—happy to see more creative and bold films being made in the Philippines.  Protect our women.

TIFF film #2 (World Premiere) I had no idea what I was getting myself into, but damn, what a pleasant surprise. I felt so hard for the lead character, with an solid performance from Maris Racal. She carried the movie, alone, brilliantly. It really show how decisions made by men (that doesn't have a lot of screen time in this movie) can impact the lives of women and girls. This movie really opened up conversations after the screening (for my friends and I) and I hope it will do the same after it open in the Philippines. I'm glad I saw that movie and I learned a lot, still processing things.

TIFF film #4 – a simple, straightforward piece about women's sexual and reproductive health and rights in the Philippines, and a portrait into the country's politics, faith, societal pressures and expectations, and gender roles. the film is carried both by its message and by Maris Racal's great performance (there is also very few supporting characters – honorable mention to Sunshine's ate). i enjoyed the cinematography and the boldness in the telling of this story. looking forward to the conversations + reception of this film, especially within the Filipinx diaspora.

TIFF Film #14: Well received in Toronto but I expect this to be divisive in PH and will spark conversations. Probably the film by which the audiences are too eager to attend the Q&A (as handfuls only left after the credits of the world premiere screening). A very important film which is very timely to be told and the Jojo Rabbit inspired reference gives lighter touch to the dark subject. The Piolo Pascual cameo is noteworthy and unsettling (I Am aloof to any forms of pastors lol).

i watched the world premiere for this film for tiff 2024. maris racal’s performance in this film is ABSOLUTELY amazing. she embodies the character so well and its a lot of pressure to carry being that her screen time is 90% of the film.the pacing of the film was pretty good in the 2nd half. I found the first part to be repetitive and didnt contribute to the characters development nor the storyline.overall, since the directors main intention is to spark a conversation, i will be looking forward to the reception of this movie once it is released to a wider audience. the subject matter is a very sensitive topic especially in the ph. different religious, political, and cultural perspectives regarding abortion are depicted in the movie and i have no doubt that it will receive strong criticism but perhaps thats only the start.

The film allows an audience to wrestle with their own understanding of body autonomy, while bearing witness to the strength of a mother and daughter bond.I’m so happy I took a chance on this.

Ortalama bir arthouse&gişe ayarında bir film izledik, kürtaj ve hamilelik gibi konuları irdeleyip “Never Rarely Sometimes Always” gibi bir filmin anlatmak istediğini deneyip pek de beceremeyen bi film olmuş.2024 Toronto Film Festival

really three and a half stars in my books, but a well-deserved extra half star for the experience seeing a movie from my home country in one of the biggest film festivals in the world and for the film’s powerful message that will unfortunately get censored in the philippines (i hope not though) because a numbee of the people over there are brainwashed by the greatest scammers in the history of the world - the catholic church.

TIFF '24 Very solid, entertaining, funny, and emotional, with a thoughtful script. Truly wonderful performance from Racal. The director clearly has a good grasp on both comedic timing and the more emotional beats, and I really loved how clearly this story was told. I imagine this would really strike a chord with Filipino women, or Filipinos in general if the Q&A is any indication.

Maris Racal delivers a beautifully nuanced performance as Antionette Jadaone's titular Sunshine. It's about an Olympic aspirant seeking an abortion in The Philippines, where it is illegal. The subject is handled with so much empathy and compassion. Loved it.
Another solid entry in the "critiquing society by showing women just trying to live normal lives" genre.
Fantastic film, unfortunately had to miss the Q&A with the director to sprint full speed to see K-pops but this movie made me angry and that's a compliment.Watched at TIFF

Strong message to the policymakers and people in power over in the Philippines. Hopefully this is widely seen and acknowledged. Necessary to make positive change in a land long held back by some traditions. TIFF2024

KAZAKHSTAN mentioned!!!!! (Our flag was there for half a second)So glad she had an abortion!!!!! It’s unclear which direction the film leans into more throughout the film.Last tiff film)Edit: the director showed up and explained that it was ambiguous due to censorships in Philippines

TIFF 2024 #40Beautiful, beautiful movie that speaks about such an important subject. A devastating and often bleak glimpse into the reality of reproductive rights in the Philippines, which is sadly so universal in this day and age. The movie is honest and doesn’t pull back, which I appreciate. Stunning lead performance, she carried this movie on her back.
such a beautiful film about such a sensitive topic, so happy to end my tiff film festival season on such a high emotional feminine note
#SEATED
Direk Tonet does it again. This movie is a triumph. Maris Racal at her best.

well crafted and tackles the main issue with sensitivity. both antoinette jadaone and maris racal did such a fantastic job evoking sunshine's anxiety amid all of the stigma. ends perfectly too. i really appreciate the neutrality and seeing both sides of the abortion argument leading up to the actual stance of the film - during the q&a jadaone talked about doing interviews and research with women with the different viewpoints and that's awesome to hear. love how philippine society is portrayed here, in all of its hyper-religious and patriarchal ways, because even though it isn't pretty, it's reality

tiff 24 maris racal was so so great as sunshine. this film did a great job portraying the horrors a woman has to go through without access to safe abortions. it’ll definitely spark a conversation as intended by direk jadaone, which i think is necessary for the development of women’s reproductive rights in the philippines

Hard for me to comment when I have the wrong plumbing to really understand the main characters pain. But I know it's something that should be addressed and for whatever reason the laws are going backwards.
Censorship in the Philippines shapes the film’s narrative. I understand its ambiguity at first but overall the film is a solid critique of the country’s reproductive healthcare system. #TIFF
Uy philippines!Im so happy this is on tiff first tiff experience and im so happy it is. I hope this reach big audiences and talk about more.

A Filipino drama that feels gritty and grounded, offering an interesting glimpse at life in the Philippines from a perspective that I hadn’t really seen before. Maybe a touch heavy-handed in places, but still a pretty nuanced and even-keeled exploration of its tough subject matter.Full Review

a very important film with such a precise and well thought out look into the real conditions of young filipina women in PH.honestly what i rlly loved about the movie, besides the themes and messages it portrays, is its efficient uses of every single scene in the movie. there's no unnecessary scene in this movie that doesn't forward the character's arc, the pace of the movie and it's messages. everyone's performances are top notch and every beat hits very hard emotionally. nd it rlly is such a realistic portrayal of what folks go through in the philippines when it comes to reproduction rights. i love how this movie covers every part of this issue without it feeling hamfisted and blatant, such as not only the stigmatization, but also the economic conditions of every day filipinos (u can argue the kids might be that, but honestly it was a good narrative tool in what otherwise be on insight we might not be able to obtain). i sincerely hope this movie gets distributed widely nd ESPECIALLY in the philippines.great way to end tiff 2024!!!

I had the honour of having this movie be the first ever Filipino movie I’ve watched on the big screen. I walked into the theatre not knowing anything about the movie and man it really hit me hard.The way it tackled body autonomy and womanhood while living in a very religious community felt so real (And especially since it’s set in the Philippines).
Expected nothing less from direk Tonet. Filipino cinema Renaissance TIFF 2024 ScreeningScotiabank Theatre, Toronto

tive o prazer de conhecer a diretora e um dos produtores do filme e aprender um pouco sobre a cultura nas Filipinas. o filme foi estranhamente bom e torturante ao mesmo tempo, doía assistir algumas cenas e como mulher acho necessário que o assunto seja discutido de forma clara e real. o filme foi só um pedaço da dor que é viver como uma mulher no mundo atual.

Sunshine is on the verge of joining the national gymnastics team and going to the Olympics, when she loses focus, careens off balance, and falters. Dreams nearly in her grasp shift to distant phantoms as she realizes she is pregnant. Shaken, fearful, desperate, and determined not to lose her rightful place on the national team, Sunshine searches the underground of the city for abortifacients. Abortion and even divorce are illegal in the Philippines, so Sunshine has few options and few people she can trust. Just then a mysterious young girl appears in the darkness and crowded streets with knowledge of Sunshine’s heart that surprises her and touches her deeply.“I wanted to be brave for these girls,” said Maris Racal (Sunshine) “who have no one else to turn to.” Racal is intrinsically believable in her role. In the conservative religious culture of the Philippines and with the lack of access to reproductive support, many girls are in crisis. The issue is relatable and timely not just in the Philippines, but in many other countries including, unfortunately, our own.At this world premiere screening at the Toronto International Film Festival, director Antoinette Jadaone said she got the idea for an imaginary friend from the film Jojo Rabbit. sunshine: ma, buntis akomama niya: padayon

This is a film of two parts. This film is part compelling drama, with a strong lead performance from the young actor and a powerful examination of the treatment of women in the Phillipines. This film is also part surrealist, but in a way that I feel undermines the strengths of the film. There is a young girl who appears at various points throughout the film; her identity is left to interpretation. However I feel that this apparition weakens every scene she's in. You'll have this powerful understated drama and then this wise-cracking girl appears to swear at you. It is clear that they couldn't even make her fit throughout the film because she disappears for at least half an hour in the middle. The filmmaker said this was the original core concept of the film and I understand that, but I feel that the film moved beyond the need for this character. I will say that I found the final interaction between the girl and our protagonist quite touching. Maybe if the girl was more understated it could have worked better. I do want to mention that it was really lovely to be in the TIFF audience for this one; the Filipino community was so passionate about this film and it was the longest and most involved Q&A I'd ever seen. It's really inspiring to see how beloved it was.

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichés and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines — which is prohibited in the constitution itself — Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge. Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy. With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (it’s obvious when no one else interacts!). While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of women’s rights in the Philippines, Jadaone’s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message.Part of our Berlinale Generation coverage
a masterclass in utilizing film to create pure empathy - overcoming all social beliefs along the way.

quite graphic and visceral at times without failing to be ever-so-gentle with the delicate subject matter it handles. through the blood, sweat and tears, the resilience of its young heroine rarely wavers. though it may not promise a better future for its women viewers gone/going through similar experiences, i sure as hope it makes them feel seen and held for a little while.
MARIS RACAL LANG MALAKAS!

First time watching a Berlinale film and it’s by my fave Filipino director  saw this trailer a couple of months ago and hoped I’d get to see it at some point so this was a pleasant surprise. Important and powerful storytelling, great balance of heavy drama and sprinkles of humor and an emotional journey into the main character’s inner struggles and point of view. Maris Racal’s performance was so good!I truly hope this will be released in Philippine cinemas.
didn't walk into this expecting to cry this much but the berlinale generation section just gets me everytime

A brave movie produced in a country where abortion is illegal. This is what filmmaking as a form of expressing real life issues in a creative way should be like.Haven’t seen so many well written female characters in a while!

Totally engrossed me and I cried a bunch. Beautiful film and loved the message and insight into the catholic Filipino culture. Hope this film sparks conversations and change in the Philippines and Southeast Asia. The director made great creative choices in the film and captured the audience.

Watched at Haus der Kulturen der Welt.A touching film about an ever-topical subject from a country we don't know much about here in Central Europe. Garnished with a little comedy to give some hope to the viewer, director Antoinette Jadaone succeeds in portraying the importance of the discourse on abortion and entertaining with many clever ideas at the same time.

Deuxième séance GenerationPlus14 et plus JAMAIS. Moi présidente de la Berlinale j’organise des screenings réservés pour les classes. Déjà pour Only On Earth ça a fait que bla-bla-bla mais alors là ?? Entre en haut à gauche un groupe de racistes qui se moquent ouvertement du film en imitant les personnages et en haut à droite un autre groupe qui n’a pas arrêté de discuter littéralement pendant plus de la moitié du film ?? Les profs par pitié servez à quelque chose et contenez vous élèves ?Bref le film est important, tellement important qu’il n’a pas encore été montré en Philippines à cause du contexte politique là-bas. Tout le monde joue bien c’est sûr. Maintenant au niveau de la réalisation askip la réal a plutôt l’habitude tourner des rom-com et ça se sent ? Mais ce qui m’a le plus gênée et qui me gêne tout le temps anyway c’est la personification d’unborn child. Le film est 10000% pro avortement mais je sais pas, je suis toujours embêtée qu’on personnifie des personnes qui n’existent pas et n’existeront jamais ? Pour nous faire ressentir quoi exactement ? Parce que ok, dans le contexte de ce film ça donne une autre dimension et une sorte de profondeur au sujet mais still ? Je comprends pas trop.

Tiff Catchup cause I'm racing to log 2024 movies watched #5This and Queer are not just the best movies I saw at TIFF, but both are experiences that have stuck with me throughout the last year. Just like how Queer paved an honest way of portraying gay men, Sunshine isn't like an abortion movie I've seen before. I'm always excited to watch a Filipino movie that breaks out into a critically praised festival run. As a Filipino who grew up in a family that owned a lot of Filipino movies, I was never a fan to be quite real with you. Filipino movies ranged from Hallmark style romances, repetitive action movies and cheesy low budget horror (although Shake, Rattle and Roll did slap). But every once in a blue moon there comes an ambitious director who tells an honest Filipino story that is both intimate in its narrative and expansive in its political themes. Sunshine doesn't hold your hand the way mainstream Filipino cinema does. It takes you on this journey of this ambitious woman who has to make the toughest choice of her life in order to determine her future. Surreal manifestations of her consciousness is brought out by imaginary characters in a way I never saw in abortion centred stories. Its so powerful. Want to watch this again with my parents. I met the director at Tiff too! :D the only person I met at the festival. While everyone else I knew wanted to get into the big films I patiently waited with my friend to see this hidden gem.
A film that "delivers" and unfortunately does not much else with a rich world it hints at almost constantly.

In the Philippines, Catholicism is the predominant religion comprising around 80% of the population. Because of the church’s influence, the country’s policy is restrictive and conservative, especially regarding family planning. Considering the social context, Jadaone’s attempt to address the topic of abortion is certainly admirable, but the simplistic and tear-jerking way it is done leaves much to be desired.asianmoviepulse.com/2025/02/film-review-sunshine-2024-by-antoinette-jadaone/

Very moving. Very emotional. Sunshine's story is probably one of many young women in the Philippines and it is important that every single one counts. The film shows more than clearly the difficulties and impossibilities that are placed in the way of young women (or far too often children) and that sometimes there is no way out when everyone really is against you. The film shows that you can be strong on your own, but that your environment is also so essential. A really important film!

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichés and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines — which is prohibited in the constitution itself — Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge. Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy. With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (it’s obvious when no one else interacts!). While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of women’s rights in the Philippines, Jadaone’s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message.Reviewed as part of our Berlinale Generation coverage

Antes que nada he de decir que la la cinematografía de Pao Orendain en Sunshine es un deleite: sus planos capturan la ciudad de manera natural, con un lenguaje de cámara preciso que da vida a la historia con una sencillez bella y efectiva. A través de una mirada profundamente realista, Antoinette Jadaone narra la historia de una adolescente atrapada en una sociedad que niega la libertad de la mujer sobre su cuerpo.La película muestra de manera sutil pero poderosa el conflicto interno de la protagonista, atrapada entre sus deseos, su futuro y las estrictas normas y creencias impuestas por su entorno.El guion, que entrelaza la historia con la presencia de una misteriosa niña pequeña que persigue a Sunshine, ofrece una reflexión sobre cómo las cargas y creencias sociales se transmiten de generación en generación; subrayando la continuidad de esas presiones a lo largo del tiempo.

"In SUNSHINE verwebt die philippinische Regisseurin Antoinette Jadaone ökonomische, soziale und politische Umstände, die Sunshine navigieren muss. Dabei dient das immer tumultartige Manila, das nahezu wie ein Labyrinth erscheint, als Hintergrund, der das beunruhigende Chaos von Sunshines Suche nach Wegen der körperlichen Selbstbestimmung optisch wie akustisch mitformt."Die vollständige Kurzkritik lest ihr auf unserer Webseite: filmloewin.de/ifff-2025-sunshine-kurzkritik/

What sets ‘Sunshine’ apart is how writer-director Antoinette Jadaone roots the film in the Philippines’ conservative culture, shaped by Catholicism and its influence on public policies. While some moments may feel a bit heavy-handed, Jadaone delivers an earnest take on the tension between religious values and societal realities, while occasionally poking fun at certain hypocrisies. Another unique aspect of ‘Sunshine’ is how it weaves in magic realism. This creative approach, which is like a mix of Taika Waititi’s ‘Jojo Rabbit’ and Celine Sciamma’s ‘Petite Maman’, might not be for everyone; nevertheless, it enriches the discourse and keeps the narrative from feeling simplistic. (Watch my full film review on video.)

The script never shines for true brilliance or originality but tackles its central theme with genuine nuance and sincerity, confronting both the emotional and physical horror of an unwanted pregnancy AND the delicate hopes of a new life about to flourish. This honesty gives even the clumsiest and most ham-fisted parts of Sunshine, which are not rare (found myself rolling my eyes whenever the "imaginary children" showed up and the film tried to make it comically clear that you understood what they represented), a nice emotional weight.

Far East Film Festival 27 - In Competition‎ A slice-of-life portrait of womanhood set in a country — the Philippines — that still has a long way to go in terms of individual rights and freedoms. Beautiful, delicate, engaging, and carried by a young actress who is truly talented and convincing.‎ Uno spaccato di quotidianità al femminile ambientato in un paese - le Filippine - che ha ancora grandi passi in avanti da fare dal punto di vista dei diritti e delle libertà individuali. Bello, delicato, coinvolgente e interpretato da una giovane attrice davvero brava e credibile.

A beautifully devastating film about female reproductive rights and self-agency in the Philippines, Sunshine follows a young gymnast who discovered she is pregnant right before the Olympics qualifiers. It explores what being a woman is like in a society that does not see you as a human being with your own thoughts and aspirations. Although my stint as a trampolinist did not lead me to the success that she has achieved, I felt personally acquainted to the title character and her experience and struggle really resonated with me.

I was at an exclusive screening for this film, and there was a girl dressed in all-pink, and I thought to myself "Why is she dressed like Glinda from Wicked?"... I later learned this was Xyriel Manabat.

Early in this coming-of-age sports drama from Antoinette Jadaone, we see Maris Racal as the titular character, twisting and turning her body gracefully like a professional who's been doing this routine all her life. Right there and then, I told myself silently that this is going to be the best and most unforgettable performance of her career. In the film, she plays Sunshine, a dedicated young gymnast preparing for her team’s upcoming tryouts for the Olympics. But days before their tryouts, she discovers that she is pregnant. Now she must embark on a desperate and risky journey to fight for her dream.Penned and directed by Antoinette Jadaone, this is definitely one of her strongest works and one that truly stands out amongst all the films in her sprawling filmography, thanks to its solid script paired with equally confident direction. Her works, which are reminiscent of the late Marilou Diaz-Abaya, albeit with a more modern flair, are always centered around fully fleshed-out female characters who, while at times flawed, go through a transformative journey (case in point: directing That Thing Called Tadhana, Beauty in a Bottle (2014), Never Not Love You (2018), Alone/Together (2019), and Fan Girl (2020)). And this latest one is no different. Here, we follow a young woman faced with the burden of her unplanned pregnancy in a country like the Philippines, where abortion is illegal under all circumstances and has no exceptions, even in cases of rape, incest, or when the woman's life is at risk.It's honestly a pretty daunting task to write a story like this given its themes, let alone actually make one and release it in a highly conservative, mostly Catholic country like the Philippines. Yet Jadaone successfully completed the film without sacrificing her vision. The film manages to bravely portray the burden brought by unwanted pregnancies to women while men get a free pass in this patriarchal society designed by and controlled by men. It also paints how religious people can't help but keep shoving their beliefs on others instead of minding their own business. Most importantly, the film discusses the importance of a proper health care system in a third-world country like ours, which is run by capitalism and corrupt government officials. Instead of providing safe and accessible procedures like safe abortion for women, we have a country forcing them to find unsafe means on their own, endangering their lives in the process.Performance-wise, the film is packed with numerous talents, so not a single shot in the film is put to waste. Both Meryll Soriano as Sunshine's coach, Eden, and Xyriel Manabat as her best friend, Thea, are effective. Elijah Canlas nails the gaslighting asshole of a boyfriend, Miggy, while Jennica Garcia is simply brilliant as Sunshine's sister, Geleen. Other noteworthy turns include Rhed Bustamante, Juan Miguel Garcia, Angeli Bayani, and Piolo Pascual in a cameo role as Miggy's father. A young Annika Co also shines with her role as the young girl constantly nagging Sunshine.But the film will definitely not work if not for the career-best portrayal from its lead, Maris Racal, who delivers a tour-de-force performance as Sunshine herself. One can really feel and see the dedication she had for such a demanding role, physically and emotionally. Her performance really pulls you into the film and won't let go until the emotionally charged third act, making it one of the best local female performances I've seen this year so far.The film also boasts some great visuals thanks to Pao Orendain's slick camerawork and incredible music courtesy of Rico Blanco—a first for the singer-songwriter.Overall, this latest film from Antoinette Jadaone is one rollercoaster of emotions that is buoyed by a daring and electrifying performance from Maris Racal. It's a poignant, gripping and thought-provoking journey of a woman coming to terms with her own inner conflicts. It's already halfway through the year, but this is already the best Filipino film of 2025 in my opinion.Trust me, you will not be prepared for how powerful this film is.

This is the best Filipino film I've seen so far. It follows a gymnast whose dreams are challenged by an unexpected pregnancy. Because the Philippines are incredibly Catholic, abortion is illegal and hard to execute. Will she give in to the pressure of keeping the child, will she seek medically unadvised procedures, or will she get help from others who understand her situation?The film explores the pressures that religion and misogyny place on young women - pressures that unfortunately appear to still be widespread in today's world.

Watched as a representative of UP Cinema. It's a brave take on one of the most controversial issues in Philippine society ever. Maris Racal is soooo good. Direk Tonet is on Fan Girl mode: things get quite tense and harrowing.

Claustrophobic, not just in how the frame is composed in several scenes, but in how it shows the extent in which the malignant structure of self-righteous patriarchal conservatism has done palpable harm to women and children everywhere. The film uses its central plotline to weave a rich tapestry of people and places that paint a picture of how this corrupted structure affects the titular protagonist, as well as the people around her. The tone possesses a gradually ratcheting anger at the oppressive status quo, going for the throats of its targets with at times bleak satire, or crushing nightmarish realities. This indignation, however, is ultimately fueled out of immense compassion. The film never really downs itself in hopelessness as it actively claws for hope, and never loses sight of Sunshine's agency through it all. Maris Racal's humane, scrappy performance is the total anchor of this film, carrying the heaviness with determination impressively.Although the breadth of the screenplay's scope is the film's biggest strength, there is some messiness in terms of scene-by-scene progression, and the more metaphorical/allegorical stuff doesn't fully coalesce with the film's more tangible arcs. Still, its willingness to take an approach both upfront and delicate to its central topic proves to be a burning, driving core towards a cathartic final endpoint. Meaningful, impassionate stuff.

I am averse to making comparisons to Brocka, but here we are. You see it in this film's Manila, a hysterically cruel city that somehow maintains its kindness in its edges. Here we are, at the claws of light, a sliver of sunshine cutting through the darkness. Sunshine makes a lot of bad decisions, but that's all she has. This is a nation of bad decisions, especially when it comes to the plight of young women. And she has to weave through these apathetic streets to find the kindness that exists in spite of the cruelty.The film uses a device that I found tenuous at points, though I do think it works out in the end. It's just that the film is so good at depicting the casual reality of these characters and the city that surrounds them that I found the break from it a little distracting. The film is transcendent when it just shows us what this city is: a place where a churchyard is where you go to find abortion drugs, a city where a motel is hesitant to give you a room if you're alone, a place where a person charged with caring for you might also take it as an opportunity to shame you for your choices.At the heart of this is Maris Racal, who delivers what might be the performance of a lifetime. A lot is asked of the young actress, who is made to mask the rage of generations of women and put on the facade of someone who is pretending that all this will pass without incident. It is sadness and worry, but also the prevailing need to show the world that everything is okay. She gets ample support from the rest of the cast, with Jennica Garcia in particular embodying the spirit of this film in its most crucial moments.There were several moments watching Sunshine where I find myself saying, "yes." Yes, because I was agreeing with what the movie was saying. Yes, because it was showing me a Manila that felt right. Yes, because Racal was really nailing something. Yes, because the music just swelled at just the right moment. There will be much talk about what the movie says, what it argues in the face of a society that often feels immovable. But here we are. Here it is. All I can say is yes.

“Mahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas.”No matter how matriarchal, modern, or progressive we claim to be, women here are still shackled by outdated norms, patriarchal laws, and the belief that their bodies and their choices are not truly their own.Sunshine confronts these hard truths with unflinching honesty. The quiet desperation of having limited options. The shame bred by religious and societal expectations. The resilience women are forced to summon simply to survive.Maris Racal delivers a tour-de-force performance. I’ve loved her since Marupok AF, but here, she transcends. She carries the film with depth and vulnerability, her portrayal of Sunshine equal parts fragile and fierce.She’s matched beautifully by Jennica Garcia, whose turn as her older sister is quietly powerful. In her hands, sisterhood becomes a form of motherhood, a reminder that parenting can come from places we least expect.Sunshine hopes to be a catalyst for reproductive rights, choice, and change. And at its core, it’s a love letter to every Filipina who has ever had to fight for her rights and a light in the dark.Go see it.

Cinemaster FJ Calvario says:In 2022, the government of Cuba had undertaken a bold move. It ratified a revision of its Family Code which redefined the “family”. It was no longer defined by only biological ties but also by relationships based on love and mutual support. This revised code is a radical piece of legislation, expanding the rights of women and children and recognizing same-sex marriages and adoption. It is a watershed moment for a country once colonized by Catholic Spain whose religious policies defined what was and wasn't allowed in society. In another corner of the world, the government of the Philippines continues to enforce the same religious norms set by Spain. Unlike Cuba, the Philippines has a long road ahead of itself in dismantling colonial legacy. A road perhaps may be paved by radical films such as Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine. A pioneer of the dialogue-driven hugot films of the 2010s, Jadaone is best known for her screenplays that blended comedy and romance. However, beginning with 2020’s haunting thriller Fan Girl which tackled male idolatry in the Duterte era, she seems to be on a sociopolitical streak in her directorial efforts. Her latest drama Sunshine now examines a woman’s decision to abort her pregnancy in a country where it is illegal and heavily stigmatized by the influential Catholic Church. At the heart of the film is the eponymous protagonist Sunshine (played by Maris Racal), a gymnast who dreams to compete for the Olympics. We first see Sunshine practice her routine in a stunningly directed scene showcasing well-paced editing and choreography. The pulsating electronic score by Rico Blanco is the cherry on top. He embodies his inner Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross who coincidentally scored another sports film released the same year as this one. Her character’s Olympic ambitions remind me of the great women athletes in our country who have been making waves for their international achievements. I see in her the Olympic gold-winning weightlifter Hidlyn Diaz and the Wimbledon-competing tennis player Alexa Eala. But this dream of Olympic glory and national pride may not be realized if Sunshine decides to continue her pregnancy. We spend much of the film following her as she navigates through her personal relationships with her family and friends, her boyfriend, her gymnastics coach, and a mysterious girl who questions her decision to abort. It’s quite a cast really. Maris Racal makes the film as Sunshine; she plays her with steadfast determination. Bubbling behind Racal's eyes is great fear and tragedy. Xyriel Manabat does a lot with silent glances as Sunshine’s best friend Thea who begins to distance herself from her pregnant friend. Elijah Canlas epitomizes the upper class douchebag as Miggy the boyfriend, frequently speaking in straight English and hilariously offloading responsibility to his girlfriend. Annika Co as the mysterious nagging girl manages to be cute, annoying, and threatening in the same scene (although her character’s inclusion in the film is questionable and counter-intuitive, well intentioned as it is).Jadaone’s dense screenplay is riveting in its timeliness, empathy and boldness. The struggle of Sunshine in choosing between her career and an unwanted pregnancy recalls last year’s controversy around another athlete the Olympic gold winner Carlos Yulo who feuded with his mother over the latter’s misappropriation of his hard earned money. The discourse around the Yulo issue saw the clashing of cultures, the divide between conservatives (who viewed the athlete as an ungrateful son) and progressives (who championed Carlos’s autonomy). I expect the same discourse around Sunshine’s decision in choosing herself to unfold in Facebook comments sections once the film gets widely released in the country. It takes a cold heart not to be moved by Sunshine’s struggle for bodily autonomy. Jadaone situates her protagonist in the working class environs of Manila. It is a landscape defined by neglect and economic difficulties. Sunshine’s mother and father are nowhere to be seen, leaving only Sunshine and her siblings to fend for themselves. Sunshine meets a young girl who is also in need of money for her own abortion, having been raped by her own family member. Miggy refuses to share the burden of Sunshine’s pregnancy and keeps his distance. Beyond her words, Jadaone’s images (courtesy of cinematographer Pao Orendain) strikingly capture urban oppression. There is a great shot of Sunshine praying behind the grills of a church, visualizing the struggle between Catholic faith and personal freedom. There’s another great shot where a lone Sunshine is again framed behind a window of a motel beside a train line, highlighting how isolating her struggle can be. Who would want to give birth to a child into a world of constant struggle amidst economic hardship and social stigma? The screenplay brilliantly reimagines what a family and society could be. In the place of a mother and a father, Sunshine has two mother figures: her sister Geleen (played by Jennica Garcia) and her coach Eden (played by Meryll Soriano). Where other films would fixate on the familial tension between a parent and a child, this film is refreshingly optimistic in envisioning a family that supports and respects each other in their decisions, even with a decision as controversial as abortion. Sunshine’s supportive, orphaned family challenges the dominant Filipino imagination of the family (a father, a mother, and children). There is a wryly funny dialogue exchange in a Catholic hospital scene between Geleen and a conservative doctor where the former defends Sunshine by pointing out the doctor’s religious hypocrisy. Jadaone’s screenplay beautifully emphasizes the solidarity between women. Beyond interactions within her family, we see Sunshine helped by a kind doctor (played by Angeli Bayani) and, in turn, she helps a young pregnant girl (played by Rhed Bustamante). Even in an unjust male-dominated world, the film shows hope in the kindness among women. I have read reviews comparing this film to works of Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya. Perhaps, they are not far off. What Jadaone achieves in this film is the start of an honest conversation about women’s bodily autonomy in our society, much like what Brocka and Abaya have done in their social dramas during the Second Golden Age of Philippine Cinema. Time will tell how impactful Sunshine will be on legislation regarding abortion and other aspects of women’s rights. The Philippines, society and state, has a long way ahead to embrace progressive ideas, unlike for our fellow ex-Spanish colony Cuba. I suspect this film will trigger backlash among conservative audiences. God, imagine the online discourse and private message chains from concerned parents. But I do hope that close minded people would be moved by a film as empathetic as Sunshine.Watch Sunshine exclusively in SM Cinemas starting July 23

Very backlogged review but hey, to have a star such as Maris (who is great in this film) lead in a controversial topic in this day and age is a breath of fresh air. Antoinette Jadaone steps out of her comfort zone yet again to bring out one of her bolder works. I am happy that something like this is out there, don't get me wrong, but there is something so off and odd about representing their struggles with hallucinatory unborn children. Feels almost counterproductive. In the talkback, direk says that she was inspired by Jojo Rabbit with this style of narrative and I wish she went deeper in explaining her reasoning. Edit: I strongly urge everyone to read my friend Mac’s review on this here. Perfectly captures the qualms with the film.Watched the premiere in SM Aura.Thanks for the opportunity UP Cinema!

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is a powerful, intimate portrait of a young gymnast who discovers she’s pregnant just days before her Olympic tryouts. Rather than using the pregnancy as a dramatic twist, the film treats it as a deeply human moment—one that forces Sunshine to confront her identity, future, and agency as a young woman. Jadaone’s direction is sensitive and grounded, allowing the story to unfold with quiet urgency and emotional truth.The film bravely highlights the invisible struggles women face when ambition and reality collide. Through layered characters and subtle symbolism, Sunshine reveals how choices—especially for women—are rarely simple, often shaped by expectations and silent pressures.Maris Racal delivers a standout performance, capturing Sunshine’s vulnerability and strength with nuance. The final scene is restrained yet powerful, offering a deeply satisfying end. Sunshine is a brave, necessary film that speaks volumes about the difficult choices women must make in a world that rarely makes space for them.
Di ko pa napapanuod pero si maris na yan kaya 5 stars agad i love u forever maris racal

What do you mean Sunshine walked from Quiapo Church to Siena College? I’d recognize that street corner anywhere. As in Fan Girl, the best thing about Jadaone’s filmmaking here is how she leverages unreality to create an immersive, tactile, and real subjective experience. The film is not just set in Manila, but Sunshine’s Manila, at times hypocritically prim and tragically seedy, both just different modes of alienation borne from the conservative milieu that devalues and abandons the marginalized among us, here particularly young women. It’s a potent text not because it presents clear answers—although its allegiance to its protagonist is never uncertain—but because it paints the sort of full and rich portrait of a woman’s life that the society it portrays cannot seem to imagine for the women in it. Very good.

Sunshine is a powerful, empathetic, and important film that bravely confronts a topic still considered taboo in the Philippines. As someone born and raised in the country, I found it both courageous and deeply resonant. It’s not just what the film is trying to say, but how it says it and, that stands out. They did it with care, nuance, and emotional clarity rarely seen in local cinema.Premiering internationally was also a smart and strategic move. It speaks to how difficult it still is to have open conversations around abortion back home. The truth is, stories that challenge long-held cultural or moral beliefs often need recognition from abroad before they’re embraced locally, a reflection of our lingering colonial mindset and deeply rooted conservatism.I truly hope Sunshine finds its audience in the Philippines. It deserves to, it needs to. Until we confront the systems that silence stories like these. Film this bold will remain the exception, not the norm. And for that alone, I commend Jadaone. We need films like Sunshine—not just to provoke, but to create space for real change.

Gets na gets ko na. During the film's duration, I felt like I was drowning. I was drowning with Sunshine in the chaos of Manila's unsafe milieu. As she traverse the limited and unfair choices, the feeling of helplessness associated with the ticking time bomb inside her is tactile. I felt restrained from the very beginning until the penultimate scene because every obstacle she goes through, she can't show weakness; she has to show up with a brave face because of the programmed noise in her head; which was generated by the years of social norms put upon every woman's shoulder.One of the most profound and sensitive moments I found deeply moving was when Sunshine said, "Hindi po ako buntis, coach", yet her eyes was swelling with tears. She can't believe that this is the only truth she is forced to deal with, that everything she has worked for will end in a whim, and that the choice wasn't even deliberately made by her; mirroring the many women in the Philippines who undergo teenage pregnancy, who also don't have a safe choice for their bodies, and for their dreams. As I sit and bask in her story in the cinema, my tears kept falling even in the most simplistic emotions. Maybe that's what happens when you feel like you've already lost the battle even if you haven't started to face it it yet. Maybe that's how it feels to be in the losing end of the decisions made by the very society that should be protecting you. Maybe this is how it is to step in the shoes of every woman in the Philippines, and at the very least, it's only a feeling I can imagine.Honestly hought this film wouldn't make a willful statement. But it takes a stand, and at the core of it is Maris Racal; supported by a riveting ensemble just as honest as her. Direk Antoinette Jadaone weaved the story with compassion through the lens of real stories of real women. She made a deliberate choice to conceive this film, and this time, it was made by her.

a young gymnast, days away from national team tryouts, finds out she's pregnant - a truth that threatens everything she's trained for. in search of a way to undo it, she crosses paths with a strange girl who mirrors her fears, thoughts, and silence. what follows is a quiet unraveling of control, shame, and choice.maris racal is exceptional. every look, every movement feels lived-in. you can tell how much she trained - not just physically, but emotionally - to bring sunshine to life. it’s a performance that doesn't ask for attention but demands it anyway. jennica garcia also delivers a quiet but aching presence that stays with you.the film isn’t without its flaws. some parts felt rushed, others too drawn out. and the mysterious girl character, while symbolic, didn’t fully land. but still, this is jadaone’s boldest and most important film. raw, intimate, and unafraid to touch topics we’ve long kept in the dark.akala ko sapat na ang pagiging pro-women ko but this film reminded me how far we still have to go. i'll never fully know the weight women carry - lalo na sa bansa nating punong-puno ng limitasyon. and that’s the power of this film. it doesn’t lecture, it just quietly shows you the truth.mahirap maging babae. mas lalo sa pilipinas. and this film makes that heartbreakingly clear.

Philippines is still a conservative country and, honestly, I'm shocked that this got a wide release thanks to SM Cinemas. I don't know how hard it must've been to make this release work given how abortion is still illegal in this country and the stigma surrounding it. Such an empathetic film that's filled with so much heart despite how other people make it seem like an immoral decision. As Direk Tonet said in the Q and A screening I went to, as a writer, she sides with her characters whether people think the decisions that her character makes is right or wrong. In other words, she doesn't give a fuck what other people thinks about abortion. As for Maris, damn, what a performance. She's known to be more expressive and she admits as well that the hardest thing for her is leveling that down that she has to unlearn even the small nuances that she does. Such a vulnerable performance. Give her the recognition she deserves.We have been behind as a country when it comes to talking about reproductive health and women's rights but I hope given how widely this film is being seen right now that it sparks the necessary conversation not only in our society but also in our government that at the very least, decriminalize abortion.Side note: what a complete 180 when I saw this after watching Fantastic Four

Sa Pilipinas, ang mga tulad ni Sunshine ay pinipilit habulin ang liwanag kahit paulit-ulit silang nilulunod sa dilim.Alam naman nating lahat: illegal ang aborsyon sa bansang ito. Pero kailanman, hindi ito makakapigil sa aborsyon. Ang nagagawa lang nito ay itulak ang mga babae sa delikado, hindi ligtas, at hindi kontroladong paraan. At ipinakita sa atin ng pelikulang ito kung gaano ka-mapanganib iyon. Mula sa pagbebenta ng pamparegla sa mga black market hanggang sa mga hilot na hindi naman ginagawa ng propesyonal—lahat ‘yan ay repleksyon ng desperasyong hindi nila ginusto, kundi bunga ng sistemang patuloy silang pinapabayaan.Pero hindi lang aborsyon ang laman ng pelikulang ito. Binuksan nito ang mas malawak na usapin—bulok na healthcare system, paniniwalang relihiyoso na ginagamit panlaban sa kababaihan, incest, rape, teenage pregnancy, pressure bilang atleta, takot sa kahihiyan, at moralidad na tila laging nakasandal sa pananakit ng babae. Pinakita ng pelikula ang buong paligid ni Sunshine—pamilya, paaralan, simbahan, coach, kaibigan, doktor—at kung paano sila naging bahagi ng problema o ng solusyon.At sobrang tamang-tama lang na sa Maynila ito kinunan. Sa Morayta, Recto, at Quiapo—mga lugar na malapit sa University Belt, kung saan maraming estudyante ang nakakaranas ng hindi planadong pagbubuntis. Mga lugar rin ito na kilala sa underground na kalakaran—mula sa pekeng dokumento hanggang sa black market na pampalaglag. Realidad ito ng maraming kabataan, at pinili ng pelikula na hindi ito pagtakpan.Wala itong pa-plot twist. Walang engrandeng eksena. Pero ramdam mo ang bigat. At naipaabot niya ang mensahe nang malinaw sa masa, sa bawat Pilipinong kailangang mamulat. Hindi para mangumbinsi, kundi para magpasimula ng pag-uusap. Pag-uusap na maaaring maging tulay tungo sa legalisasyon—o kahit dekriminalisasyon—ng aborsyon sa bansa natin.Sobrang husay ni Maris Racal. Para siyang talagang gymnast. Lahat ng galaw may kahulugan. Lahat ng tahimik na sandali, may sigaw. Kudos sa choreographers—dahil bawat routine, may sariling kwento.Si Sunshine ay isa lang. Pero napakarami pang katulad niya. Iba-iba man ang dahilan, iisa ang dapat malinaw: ang desisyon ay dapat laging nasa babae. Sa katawan nila. Sa buhay nila.Hindi kailangan ng pelikula ng sagot. Pero may lakas ito para magtanong. At sa isang bansang takot harapin ang tanong, sapat na iyon para tawaging rebolusyonaryo.Sana ang Sunshine na ito, maging sinag ng panibagong simula. #LegalizeAbortion

essay ka saken mamaya sunshine pero for now MAHAL KO TONG PELIKULA NA TOedit: eto na ako. woke up too early today and thought…bat di ko simulan ang araw! to talk about sunshine! first of all, maris? hands down. gets mo bat sya nasabihan na haggard nung nakakita sa kanya habang nagshoshoot. ganto ang mukha ng bawat batang babaeng naghahanap ng tulong sa mga sulok-sulok ng quiapo, hilutan, at twitter. wala eh, saan ba pwede humingi ng tulong ang isang babae kung isang buong relihiyon, gobyerno, at bansa ang humuhusga sayo? ganda ng cinematography, kuhang kuha yung pakiramdam ng manila; yung sulasok, yung ingay, yung mga dasal, pati na rin yung desperasyon. para sa mga nakakaangat-angat at hindi naranasang maglakad sa kahabaan ng quiapo habang nasa harap ang bag (dahil baka manakaw), mga hindi napadpad sa lugar dahil may kakayahang magpa-hospital, madaling husgahan ang mga nagtitinda sa quiapo o mga kustomer dito. pero di niyo alam ang pag-asang bitbit ng mga ale at langis at gamot at booklet na may instructions kung paano magpalaglag para sa mga taong kagaya ni sunshine. mga taong pinagkaitan ng karapatan sa katawan at accessible healthcare. mga kababaihan. mga kagaya namin.maaaring nakakadisorient yung existence ni annika dito, pero sobrang importante na andito siya. mahirap pag-usapan ang aborsyon sa pilipinas dahil sa predominantly catholic country tayo. mabigat ang pagkakaangkla ng mga batas natin, maging ang moralidad at paniniwala natin bilang indibidwal, sa mga turo ng simbahan. kaya kahit ako, bilang babae at pro-choice, nahihirapan pag-usapan ang aborsyon nang hindi nakakaramdam ng guilt (catholic guilt!). pakiramdam kasi ng mga tao, walang impact sa mga babae ang pagpapaabort. madalas din kasi sa mga video galing sa western countries, they can joke about it na cells lang yan….kasi totoo naman. pero iba kasi pag lumaki ka sa bansang kagaya ng pilipinas na sobrang taas ng pagpapahalaga sa pamilya at diyos. mas iba yung bigat. iba yung konsensya. kaya nga dumaan muna si sunshine sa simbahan para humingi ng tawad (ARGH SOBRANG GANDA I LOVE IT) kasi ganon tayo lumaki dito. at oo cells lang, laman lang, pero laman mo. parang personification nito si annika…sa madaling salita, sya yung anak that sunshine could have had, yung what if, paniguradong sasagi sa isip ni sunshine from time to time. Sunshine is Direk Tonet Jadaone’s softest scream yet. A quietly radical film that says: women shouldn’t have to bleed in silence to be forgiven.We need more films like this. More filmmakers like Direk Tonet who aren’t afraid to tell stories that actually matter. Stories that sit in the grey area. That show the truth without sugarcoating it.Maris Racal delivers a performance that’s tender, haunted, and furious beneath the surface. The film doesn’t beg for sympathy—it demands dignity.This isn’t about regret.It’s about agency.It’s about how in this country, your body is never really yours.And still—she tries to heal.

Hindi ko gets kung bakit ang dami pa ring hindi nakaka-gets.Sunshine is a film about noise— ingay ng Maynila, ingay ng judgement ng iba, ingay ng kaguluhan, ingay ng mga maling desisyon. At sa gitna ng lahat ng ingay, ay isang babaeng may pangarap— tumatakbo, lumalaban.I have so many to say about the political nature of this film but I think at its core, Sunshine is about understanding. Hindi natin kailangan baguhin ang paniniwala natin, kailangan lang natin matutong umintindi sa kalagayan at sitwasyon ng iba.If you don’t believe in abortion, don’t get one. Same goes with the idea of divorce and same sex unions. Why limit the choices of others? The screenplay works so well along with its perfect casting. Lahat bagay na bagay sa role lalo na si Maris as Sunshine. I also love the cinematography lalo na sa Quiapo scenes. I felt the chaos through that. We know our country is fucked up when women can’t make choices for themselves. We know we’re fucked up when we’ don’t have safe and accessible abortions. We know we’re fucked up when we can’t pass laws like the divorce bill and the sogie bill. So what do we do after this? Hindi sapat ang isang pelikula upang baguhin ang sistema. Hindi dapat ganito— pero madami pa tayong kailangan paliwanagan upang maka-gets. Kailangan ng kolektibong aksyon upang i-push ang progressive bills into legislation. Malayo pa tayo.

The best Filipino film I’ve seen so far this year.Raw, relevant, and worth talking about.Set in Manila: masikip, mainit, mabaho. The film captures it so well that you can almost smell and feel it. Beneath that heat and heaviness is a quiet story of sacrifice. It powerfully portrays the struggles of women in a deeply patriarchal society. Young women are expected to give way, to carry the weight, to make the harder choice. While men are often free to walk away, women are left at the crossroads, torn between duty and ambition, between what they want and what they are told they should become. Its honest portrayal of everyday hardship, mixed with strong feminist themes, feels like it is channeling both Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya.The film also reflects the quiet hypocrisy we see in everyday life. No one is truly exempt. People speak of values, yet live with contradictions. The film shows us these double standards in a way that makes you reflect.Maris Racal is so, so good as Sunshine. The rest of the cast is just as strong. Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Rhed Bustamante and the rest of the casts are all remarkable. I also appreciate how even the crowd and background extras were credited at the end. It speaks volumes about how everyone involved was valued.And what a story it is. Raw, relevant, and worth talking about. Sunshine is not just the best Filipino film I have seen this year. It is one that dares to ask difficult questions and sit with uncomfortable truths. Brave and thought-provoking, it will likely spark conversation after the ending credits. Some of the choices in the film may feel morally difficult, and not everyone will agree with them. But the real question is, who are we to decide what is right for someone else? Are we even in their place to judge?More than anything, Sunshine reminds us to be kind. To live with empathy. To listen, to pause, and to try to understand before we judge.Just like these past few days, the rain has not stopped. For some, it is a blessing. For others, it feels like a never-ending trial. But in the middle of it all, we wait for the same thing: Sunshine.Sunshine that reminds us that after the storm, healing begins. And slowly, we rise.

ChoicesSunshine makes mistakes and will make mistakes. People will question why she is pregnant at a very young age. And it was clearly hers and her boyfriend’s choice to be unprotected. And when she decided to tell him she was pregnant, both of them had to make choices. But when legal options run out for Sunshine and the only choice she can make is to abort through illegal means, she puts her own life at risk. But it is also in making a choice that Sunshine finds herself.God’s Gift Sunshine leaves a jeepney with the words God’s Gift. She walks towards Quiapo church and asks for forgiveness, and outside the church there is a market selling religious things, but also potions that “induce menstruation”. A medical professional preaches God at Sunshine’s bedside after her “medicine” fails her. And it says a lot about the structures surrounding young women with unwanted pregnancies. Later on in the film, we see the impact of these structures on them. They are forced to make decisions that risk their lives.Full of GraceMaris Racal is perfect at portraying Sunshine’s physicality and character. Her performance will make you believe she’s an Olympian who can take the spotlight and get everyone’s attention, a sister who learns how important it is to make her family proud, but most importantly, a dreamer who understands her young age is the right opportunity to change the world around her. I will never feel the exact same way as Sunshine experienced, but as a male audience, the film still allows me to put myself in Sunshine’s hard and difficult situation. The film is able to open eyes, and hopefully the audience willingly opens their eyes to Sunshine.
