"Naiintindihan mo ba 'ko?"Has the grit and guts of showing how women haven't had it easy when it comes to body agency in this patriarchal and faith-bound country. The part where the kid was used as a metaphor just seemed self-defeating to the movie for me. But as far as performances go, Maris sticks her landing here.

It’s so odd to see Jadaone out of her box—or perhaps returning to her old form. If Fan Girl leaned into the dark, Sunshine veers into the gritty. The clever use of environment makes Maris Racal’s performance feel grounded and central, without overly commenting on political allegories like in Jadaone’s previous work. Orendain’s shots don’t try to elevate the story—they move hand-in-hand with it, gripping tightly to the isolation of being a young woman in the Philippines.I haven’t seen any Filipino film tackle abortion quite like this. The nuance of setting it in a deeply religious country is compelling. It opens the conversation, but perhaps plays a little too safe—maybe to appeal to a broader audience. I was hoping for a stronger push, but it chooses to be understated: a film beaming with quiet urgency and an accurate reflection of the current climate surrounding women’s reproductive rights.

There’s a lot to unpack in Sunshine, but let me begin by saying this: Maris Racal owns this character. There’s no other actress who could have pulled off Sunshine the way she did. She embodied every bit of the character so completely that Maris disappears—you’re not watching Maris as Sunshine; you’re watching Sunshine herself. Her performance is quietly powerful and emotionally charged, grounded in rawness and empathy.But this film isn't just carried by Maris alone. Alongside her are Annika Co, Jennica Garcia,and Rhed Bustamante, who play pivotal roles in deepening Sunshine’s story. In many ways, their characters are Sunshine—reflected through different lenses. Through themes of mental health and teen pregnancy, the film constructs a layered portrait of girlhood under pressure. It's raw, empathetic, bold, and unafraid. It doesn’t flinch from the truth, nor does it romanticize the pain.What Sunshine does best is handle a very sensitive subject in our country with sincerity and urgency: the ongoing struggle for bodily autonomy. It quietly and firmly illustrates the emotional toll of being a young woman in a society that refuses to let her decide for herself. And worse, how these conversations remain taboo.Every silence in the film is so loud. The pauses, the stillness, the unspoken—Sunshine knows that some of the loudest screams come from what isn’t said. The film allows space for emotion to breathe, for truths to sink in, and for viewers to truly feel the weight these girls carry.The producers behind Sunshine had to fight to get this film seen—not for profit, but because these are stories that matter. They pushed forward to open a much-needed conversation on bodily autonomy and reproductive rights. And it’s 2025—yet these issues are still being dismissed, invalidated, or worse, treated like they’re myths. In truth, they are not up for debate. They are basic rights that every woman deserves.I only hope that in the years to come, we won’t need another Sunshine just to get people to listen.Panoorin ang Sunshine, hindi lang dahil gusto n'yo, kundi dahil kailangan. Napapanahon, mahalaga, at dapat pag-usapan.Gets ko na.

When I was in grade school, I wrote a feature editorial piece about abortion. I took the point-of-view of an unborn child narrating all his aspirations and would have been's in life had he had the chance to live, but I did not give voice to his mother, or at least I chose not to. 16 years later and here comes Sunshine.In the middle of this storming weather in the metro, Sunshine is haunting. It brings you to the darkest alleys of Manila where hope feels nowhere to be found, especially in a political climate where a woman is at a disadvantage, for the lack of a better term.Sunshine is disturbing in such a way that a woman, in this modern age, is still left with limited options, or the lack thereof, and has no autonomy in doing informed decisions on her own body amidst retribution of a patriarchal society.Sunshine is moving. It kicks. It punches. Five months after its Berlinale win, Sunshine comes home, and it needs traction. It is high time to make the conversation going until, for some divine intervention, it reaches the people that should be of utmost concerned about the plight of women.Sigh. Going back to the essay I wrote years ago, I guess I no longer need to rewrite nor revise that piece, kasi ngayon, mas gets ko na ang buong kwento.

2:30pm AWKP Screening @ SM North with Direk Tonet Jadaone & Maris Racal We live in a nation of choices & contradictions where women are the ones who are burdened with most of its unwanted consequences. Abortion? Illegal. Teenage pregnancy? Immoral. Contraceptives? Taboo. Elders look down on women who have pre-marital sex, unwanted pregnancy, and even an ounce of body autonomy.Beneath clouds of apathy & judgment, SUNSHINE reminds us to choose empathy & compassion.Nora Aunor was Bona. Hilda Koronel was Insiang. Today, Maris Racal is SUNSHINE.To bring up Lino Brocka is a heavy statement itself, but the Crystal Bear winning-SUNSHINE has also memorized Manila, and all its aches and decays. In her background are the familiar veins of Avenida & Quiapo. The heaviness of everyday life, religion and culture all add to her already buzzing headspace. She tries and must drown out the noise.With this award-worthy role, Maris might just have earned her place among the revered women in Philippine cinema who have embodied the honesty and rawness of the Filipina experience—in their respective era, each still under the same problematic patriarchal society.There's an all-timer hospital scene that stayed with me the most. As a medical student, what we're taught often align with Catholic teachings, even if our personal beliefs say otherwise. Our hope is that the next generation of health professionals will be provided with aligned legislation and protection that will help them become more compassionate, empathetic, and sensitive to women's autonomy over their bodies. These conversations should start not just in household discussions but in our social institutions as well.Elijah Canlas nails the recklessness of a young boy scared to man up. Xyriel Manabat's eyes speak for themselves. Jennica Garcia is simply luminous and embodies the 'Ate' in our lives. Her tough love exterior melts whenever Sunshine needs her genuine guidance. Meryll Soriano's presence is calming and reassuring. Piolo Pascual delivers friction and captures the high and mighty men in our society who assume to know all about everything and everyone, especially women’s needs. This is Direk Antoinette Jadaone's career-best work, yet. And at the heart of it all is Maris Racal, delivering a thrilling performance that will catapult her to superstardom.
Sometimes a raw no-frills straightforward piece is all you need to convey a powerful message.

Uuwi kang maraming napagtanto—na ito ang kasalukuyang lagay ng lipunan.Mahusay si Maris. Sobrang husay. Hindi siya ang napanood, kundi si Sunshine.Totoong si Jennica ang magpapakurot sa puso ng bawat isa. Ngayon, mas lalo niya akong napahanga, at umaasang marami pa siyang proyektong ihahain para sa lahat.Pagkalabas ng sinehan, may nagtanong sa akin: “Gagawin mo ba ang ginawa ni Sunshine?”Sabi ko, “Kung may p*ke lang ako, bakit hindi? How can you drown out the noise when even the silence starts to echo your doubts?Direk @tonetjadaone’s pragmatic approach to storytelling moves the soul.Although far from being perfect, the film delivered where it mattered most - clarity in messaging and a vision compelling enough to leave emotional resonance to spectators.

This film on female reproductive health boldly centers the female gaze, offering a fresh and unflinching take on the realities that many Filipinas face. It attempts to break the glass ceiling of deeply rooted Filipino norms and challenges the culture shaped by religion, stigma, and silence around topics like abortion, sex education, and women’s health.Direk Tonet Jadaone masterfully captures the struggles of the protagonist, whose aspirations are put on hold after she discovers she’s pregnant. The film follows her journey, portraying how a woman navigates the weight of societal expectations in a culture that often leaves little room for personal agency.Cinematically, it’s far from your typical Filipino cliché. The pacing is tight, the cinematography is visually compelling, and each scene is deliberate, drawing the viewer into the emotional and social turmoil the character endures. The film allows us to witness how Sunshine finds resilience amidst adversity, all while shedding light on the layers of deprivation and injustice a Filipina can experience in a patriarchal society.More than just a narrative, the film leaves an impact. It sparks important conversations about our broken systems—the stigma surrounding reproductive health, the taboo nature of sex education, the inaccessibility of contraceptives, and the criminalization of abortion. It confronts how society often reduces women to objects of pleasure or vessels of reproduction, without regard for their mental or physical well-being.Ultimately, this is a film about empowerment. It’s a powerful reminder that women can dream for themselves, stand their ground, and rise above a system designed to keep them down. Thought-provoking and timely, it’s a testament to Direk Tonet Jadaone’s bold storytelling and her commitment to stories that matter.

This movie is arguably one of the best films of the year. It feels incredibly real because it reflects life in the Philippines, where women's rights are acknowledged but often support a male-dominated system and the patriarchy."Sunshine" tells the story of many women living in the Philippines. In this country, discussions about sex and sex education are frequently considered taboo. Many people talk about sex negatively, treating it as something sinful rather than educational. As a result, issues like teenage pregnancy are primarily viewed as public health problems. Furthermore, while there is a law aimed at protecting women from violence, it forces victims of sexual abuse to carry any resulting pregnancy to term, even in tragic circumstances such as r4p3.With abortion being illegal in the Philippines, many women find themselves in difficult situations. Those facing unplanned and unwanted pregnancies may have to consider unsafe options, which can threaten their lives.Women's rights must prioritize the well-being and choices of women, not men. The self-righteousness and views of certain religious groups should not dictate whether abortion is legalized. Women must have the power to make choices about their bodies."Sunshine" is a story of hope, second chances, and pursuing dreams. It hopes for a better society where women are not scrutinized for claiming rights over their bodies. This movie is a bold and significant step for film in the Philippines, as it represents the experiences of many women in the country. We must continue the conversation and let this film be a part of the movement advocating for better women's rights.Without a doubt, Maris Racal brought life to her character, Sunshine. Her outstanding performance solidifies her status as one of the best actresses of this generation.

“gets ko na”the physical representation of sunshine making peace, letting go of her guilt, and getting complete reassurance in her decision, all in the form of the child she once detested, but in the end, loved, was honestly beautiful. there is so much love and strength with the child in understanding sunshine’s dreams and circumstances, and how society was truly set against them; two females who were young girls at the end of the day. in a way, it reminded me of the popular thought prompt, “if my mother didn’t have me, what kind of life would she have had?” it’s a bittersweet thought at first, but there is such genuine love and understanding in seeing your mother past her caregiving responsibilities and wanting to witness her thrive as an independent woman with goals and ambitions, even if it meant losing your existence. however, there is also so much love and strength with sunshine deciding what would be best for both her and for the child, even if it hurt. sunshine loved the child enough to recognize that she didn’t deserve to be brought into such a cruel world, not when her own mother was still navigating through it, barely managing to survive the horrors she was dealt with. she knew she wasn’t ready at all and she didn’t want her child to bear the brunt of it, given what she herself has went through. there is love and strength in choosing yourself, recognizing your weaknesses, and acknowledging that both you and your child deserve the best version of yourself; one that has wholeheartedly lived her dreams and life despite societal expectations and harsh realities and one that is ready to help her child to do just the same.despite all odds, naintindihan nila yung isa’t isa. and out of love, for both themselves and for each other, they both let go.

every time sunshine makes a decision, i just find myself nodding, quietly saying, “gets ko.” because i do. i was shaped by the streets of metro manila, grew up near churches where pampalaglag or pamparegla are sold right outside. i've had my own sunshines— close friends, a relative, a classmate — people i care about who’ve gone through the same thing. and watching this film, i saw myself in geleen, thea, the kid, and ariana. you just want your sunshine…

Sunshine is an aspiring Olympian. She is two weeks away from performing in the qualifying round. She has won numerous gold medals in local and Asian competitions, making her an ideal candidate for an Olympic gold. But everything changes when she discovers an unwanted pregnancy. In a male-dominated, conservative, church-leaning country, who can help Sunshine achieve her dreams?Jadaone's latest picture is a gritty coming-of-age sports drama that tackles a sensitive yet realistic portrayal of the struggles women face when the government and society turn their backs on them. It is a claustrophobic journey that dims the shine of its lead character even before she sees the end of the tunnel. The film offers a timely and relevant discussion on gender roles, sex education, the health care system, body autonomy, female rage, and empowerment.At its center is Maris Racal, who plays the titular character with grace, bareness, and nuance. She embodies the sunshine amidst a dirty, hypocritical, careless, and immovable society that becomes a character of its own. This is supported by the film’s striking eye for cinematic framing of the ragged city of Manila.I love how the film handles the core of its subject: should Sunshine get an abortion and continue chasing her dreams, or take the baby and live a life she is not prepared for? I love how the women characters come together to help each other against the oppressive weight of our patriarchal society.And when Sunshine finally makes a decision, I don’t think the film wants you to agree or disagree with her. It wants you to ask why she had to be in this position in the first place. It wants us to notice the shoulder-to-shoulder crowding in public maternity wards. It wants us to see the hypocrisy of a society where black markets for abortion operate in the shadows of churches, and why a woman still cannot make a decision about her own body without judgment from everyone around her.Pero gets kita, Sunshine. Gets na gets.

Gets ko na.Hinding hindi ko malilimutan kung paanong pagkatapos ng lahat, hindi binitawan ni Sunshine ang pangarap niya. Kitang kita kung paanong ang gintong bola ng pag-asa sa loob niya ay patuloy na kuminang sa kabila ng kadiliman ng Maynila. Sa kabila ng lipunang hindi handa sa isang babaeng may paninindigan at pangarap sa sarili niya. Gets ko na.Ito ay sulat para sa akin. Hindi dahil isa rin akong gymnast na gustong maging Olympian. Ito ay sulat para sa akin at sa munting “iha” na ang tanging kakampi lang sa kadiliman ng mundo ay ang tingkad ng pangarap niya. Gets na gets ko na. Gets na gets ko na kung bakit kahit hindi ako buntis, hindi ako gymnast, o kahit hindi ko pangarap maging olympian, ako si Sunshine. Dahil kahit anumang magyari, sigurado akong patuloy na mananaig at pipiliin kong yakapin ang pangarap at pagmamahal ng munting “iha” sa akin.

Sunshine is a statement. Raw, delicate, and bold. It presents a social commentary on themes rarely explored yet deeply prevalent in the Philippine context. It dares to be radical. It dares to draw the line. When does the sun finally shine in a morally gray cloud of social disapproval?As linear and straightforward as the film appears, beneath it lies a complex character study — fearlessly told, thematically sharp, and emotionally unsettling. Antoinette Jadaone writes for women, and in a cinematic landscape like ours, we need more voices like hers. I was initially worried about where the story would go, but it was brave enough to take the harder path.This is Maris Racal's best performance yet — nuanced and quietly powerful. But it was Jennica Garcia who stole every scene she was in. She was the emotional anchor, the tearjerker. Some casting choices outside the leads, however, fell short. Certain scenes and narrative decisions could have landed harder with stronger performances or more fitting direction.That said, the editing needs work. The presence of a stunt double in certain scenes is obvious, breaking immersion. While the film’s visuals hauntingly capture a side of Manila we rarely see on screen, the sound design lacks polish. These flaws are noticeable but not deal-breaking.Still, this film succeeds in doing what few others do: it makes you ask what is ethical and what is not. It invites reflection. And when a film draws that line clearly for society to see, perhaps that’s when the sun truly begins to shine.

Sa bawat eksena ng pelikula ni Antoinette Jadaone, iisa ang tinig na umaalingawngaw — tinig ng babae. Hindi lang basta karakter ang mga babae, gaya ni Coach Eden mapa hanggang kay Doc Helena; sila’y haligi, saksi, at sandigan. Maging ang mga ina sa maternal ward, tahimik man o may tinig, ay larawan ng kababaihang nagtutulungan, nagkakapit-bisig sa gitna ng unos.Sa mundong kinahon ng patriyarka, binubuksan ng pelikula ang mata natin sa lakas ng kababaihan — lakas na hindi lang para sa tahanan o pamayanan, kundi para sa paghubog ng mas makatarungan at pantay na lipunan. Sa mata ng kamera, dama ang panawagan: bigyang saysay ang katawan at karapatan ng kababaihan.Dahil sa mundong nararapat, walang Sunshine, walang Menggay, ang kailangang manahimik sa sakit. Walang babaeng kailangang dumaan sa dilim ng unsafe practices para lamang maramdaman ang kontrol sa sariling buhay. Sa mundong nararapat, ang babae’y hindi takas, kundi ganap — may tinig, may kapangyarihan, may laya.
deserve mo 'yan tito bobot

As someone who doesn’t have a womb, watching this film was eye-opening. It showed me a side of the issue that I’ll never fully experience, it’s about recognizing that these decisions aren’t mine to make, but they are mine to respect.I thought this kind of filmmaking about women’s welfare will never exist. Thank you, Maris did a great job bringing a powerful story to life.Gets ka namin, Sunshine!*brb crying atm*But to all boys out there…Use protection. Educate yourself. Communicate openly. Respect women.If you’re not ready for the consequences then you’re not ready to take the risk.We should be responsible not reckless. Please!

by women, for women.so many social issues tackled in more than an hour of runtime. shows how harsh it is to be a young woman in the poverty line of a third world country that does not prioritize your reproductive health.

Obviously im not a woman so I will never fully understand the lived experience of a woman but just like sunshine, I am someone who made regrettable decisions in the past. Someone who’s also eager to make it right. At least for me. But sometimes it’s hard to do the right thing when you have so many people telling you what to do, or when you don’t have the resources to do so. It’s hard to drown out the noise in your head when everything around you is so loud. Sometimes you don’t even need someone to tell you what to do at all, because you already know. Sometimes all you need is someone to be by your side. Something to make you feel like youre not alone. A text message from a friend. A hug from a sister. A pair of compassionate eyes of a stranger. Despite feeling alone in her whole ordeal, Sunshine was held together by the women she encounters. From the child, her sister, the cashier at the motel, the doctor at the hospital.I was lucky enough to have my own community lift me up at a time when I thought i was done for. It’s because of them that I’m still here, and that I still keep going. “Mahalin mo si sunshine, kahit ano pa siya, kahit ano pang nagawa niya”, said my friend. Indeed, we are all just people in need of community to get us through. In need of compassion. In need of empathy. Someone to say “kakampi mo ko dito”. Sometimes having someone sit through it with you is enough. And yes, gets kita, Sunshine.

The film has a sense of urgency about it, presenting the drama with so much eagerness, firm convictions, and intense sentiments nearly to the point where it devolves into cheap propaganda for a cause with which I happen to agree ideologically. It was too on the nose and constantly going for shock value that it was draining to follow, brazenly provoking the audience to feel for a horrible social reality but instead of pointing it out with a nod and a commentary, it was trying so hard to make them feel bad about those situations. Not in a good way because it is one of those things that breeds frustration rather than empathy for the protagonist. At some point, Sunshine simply disappeared, becoming a vessel for the audience to put their shoes on since she is subjected to so much oppression, losing any semblance of agency as it is all about how messed up her social reality has become. It's the same problem I had with war films and other poverty porn, where it ignores developing the protagonist in favor of escalating the situations in front of her and throwing every miserable conflicts imaginable at her. To be fair, the protagonist as a vessel had an aspiration, a threatened dream that was about to be broken, and the idea of her interacting with all these women, smoothly transitioning from the one who needed help to the one who provided help, clearly distinguished the film from those with a typical point-of-view character. Those moments of empowerment and camaraderie with other women may have eased the tension and made it feel more hopeful than the premise implies, but it also falls into the trap of caricaturing other characters for the sake of cheap sensationalism. It also felt betraying that so many things transpired that the gymnastics was set aside for so long, and I would hope that it was more of an escape than a hardship because no joy was displayed during those routines except for the last act. I would say that the sport was not seamlessly wedded to the character, since it could have been any sport or dream, and the film would still be effective. The magical realism element is essentially what I detest about the film, because it could have lingered in the loneliness and allowed the audience to connect with the character through subtlety, but it had to be filled with hypothetical conversation that hits the audience on the head to explain the themes and demonstrate the unspoken dilemmas in the present predicament. It could be interpreted as a mean to communicate guilt, a process of forgiving oneself and empathizing with other women, or as humanizing the fetus inside the body, which I'm not sure how to feel about that ideologically. It's also tonally odd, which is a Philippine cinema branding at this point, but it's always convenient to use a child for humor, and it reduces the overall tone of what's happening to the main character. It was just too telegraphed at times, and I was hoping to let the sequences play out and use more silence because those are the scenes I enjoy when the protagonist is alone and burdened by her situation. The upward momentum of a film that begins bleakly will always impede any form of storytelling because it must outdo itself, building emotions that are overwhelming every ten minutes to the point of monotony. In fact, I can't recall the chronology of the film even though I saw it yesterday, but I do remember every segments and the emotions it was going for. It actually came to the point of absurdity in the third act, when one character emerged, followed by a terrible circumstances, followed by even more bleak information and an unsettling confrontation, which would undoubtedly disturb anyone. And then there was a cameo in which the small theater collectively whisper and giggle a bit as a result of being taken off guard, which again felt awkward because it always has to make a joke after every other miserably effective scene. Not letting the moments breathe for a while. It can even be tonally confusing at times, with scenes that is either attempting to be comical or unsettling as some of the dialogue was just satirical and they incorporate some triggering monologue ala Vincentiments, but they also made the film lighthearted, which I am not sure is a good thing. I suppose I want my abortion movies to be more thought-provoking and full of sociological nuances rather than funny and emotional, because it can be too loose for its sensitive subject matter, but it was heartfelt and that was good. I'm making it seem like I hate this film when than I don't because it was terrific and entertaining, but it's just that I'm not sure if those are the things I want to take away from this film. I have to say though that it had a very good filmmaking mechanics. I heard they tried to hide the camera in public scenes to make the setting appear more authentic, and I was expecting long takes because it was another Filipino film about a protagonist wandering around which they did not employ at all, but I kind of like what they did here, from the shot composition and coverages to the way they were edited together. The only criticism I had regarding the filmmaking was the noticeable stunt double in the gymnastic routines, as well as how the emotions in the close-ups did not match those in the wide shots whenever they intercut them together. I suspect no one grins when doing gymnastics since it is a serious performance by meticulous athletes rather than by an exuberant victorious person, as the film claims at the conclusion. It's just a little quibble, but I commend the filmmaking overall and even the rough cuts were fantastic. Definitely the best-directed Filipino film I've seen in quite some time, I can say that with confidence.

Ung after niya ikuwento ung kuwento niya in the most perfect way and in a language na she knows best, she asks (dares, almost) "Naiintindihan mo naman ako di ba?" tapos ako… ako na walang matres, ako na hindi nireregla, ako na hindi mabubuntis, mapapasabi din na: oo, "gets ko na"Gets kita, Sunshine.

Sunshine— a pretty ironic title for a film consumed by darkness, where religion and men are suffocating women’s rights, holding them accountable for circumstances they never chose.

Sa lipunang hindi progresibo, paano natin malulutasan ang mga problemang nangangailangan ng napapanahong solusyon?It's a film that attacks the inaccessibility to safe and accessible abortion and the rampant patriarchy in the country. And it does so with its magnificent cinematography. From wide shots symbolizing that her mind is still free, to tight composure, symbolizing that her world is closing in.Yes, abortion is not ideal, and the film shows Sunshine's struggle to decide what to do with the pregnancy. But what about those who are taken advantage of, harassed, and even r@ped?A film is not enough to change society. However, I know this film will touch the lives, and hopefully the minds of many.

made me feel a lot of emotions and had me crying over various reasons but mainly from frustration that what Sunshine went through wasn't just a story but a lived reality for a lot of Filipina women in our society where they still have no full autonomy over their own bodies! Ang daming layers—religion, power dynamics, healthcare system, our own Constitution—na nagtatagpi-tagpi for this delicate but important topic that always seems to get pushed aside. And I hope this film is one way for all of us to finally start having these conversations. Sobrang galing! Gets ka namin, Sunshine!

this film is close to my heart…i really believe that women should be given a choice when it comes to their body and reproductive health. bringing life into this world should also not be disguised as a “blessing”, especially when the means to raise the child is little to none. maawa kayo sa mga batang walang makain, walang matinong tirahan, hindi makapag-aral, at hindi masulit ang pagiging bata. ang pagiging magulang ay hindi natatapos sa pagluwal sa bata at hindi dapat iasa sa iba ang responsibilidad mo bilang magulang.tangina rin ng mga mapang-abusong lalaki sa loob at labas ng bahay. pati na rin ang gobyernong patuloy na pinipigilan ang pagkakaroon ng access to better healthcare, hindi lang para sa mga babae, ngunit para rin sa lahat ng pilipinong may kailangan nito.maraming salamat direk tonet para sa pelikulang ito. maraming salamat sa napakahusay na pagganap nina maris, jennica, rhed, at xyriel. nawa’y mas marami pang pelikula gaya nito ang maibahagi sa masa at nawa’y maraming makapanood nito.

breathtaking kse di ako makahinga sa iyak at sakit. maris the actress you are. the film left me in a fetal position in my seat. a very important piece of work, a film that hugs women that dream and fear. i love this.

“Start strong, stay strong. You can do this.” But what happens when life throws you off balance? Sunshine is a powerful, no-frills story set in the gritty, chaotic streets of Manila. It follows a young gymnast whose future gets shaken when she finds out she’s pregnant. Antoinette Jadaone tells this story the way she does best—letting silence, glances, and small gestures speak louder than words. No drama for drama’s sake. Just raw, real moments. Maris Racal delivers a stunning performance.…

This film tackles numerous points that need to be discussed. It provides a comprehensive overview of the different systemic issues that our country is not addressing, ranging from the double standards imposed on women to the societal barriers that make it difficult for women to meet these standards. It is an irony between what society wants for women and how society sets up women to fail to meet these standards.That's where the "bullsht-ery" comes in, as this film successfully sends it to its audience. I want to say a lot of things about this film, on how it provides a good argument, on how it provides a good piece of reality that is not glorified nor romanticized and on how it gave us something that will not just be left on the cinema, but to be talked about in the streets and on the media.I really understand the fear of the production of showing this in the Philippines, but I believe that strong and brave films like this are what we need, to not just start conversations but to challenge the views we have as individuals and as a collective. This is the kind of film that everyone needs to watch, as it will definitely afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted. No words, but pure awe of everything about this film. Definitely the best work of both director Antoinette Jadaone and actress Maris Racal. And it's weird for me to have a good rewatch feeling on these kinds of movies, but I believe I will be rewatching this film again (once the storm settles and subsides).Mabuhay ang pelikulang Pilipino!

Sa wakas, may nakadiskubre at nakagawa na rin kung paano gamitin nang maayos si Racal. Sa labas ng maliliit (at ilang malalaking mga) na mga butas sa detalye, at naratibong pagpili na hindi ko masakyan, maayos ang pelikulang 'to. Matino ang mga pangalawang aktor, may tamang balanse ng kritikang panlipunan—ng mga gagong biktima ng sistema (at sadyang gago lang) at mga gustong maging mabuti sa gitna nito—at may gustong sabihin, ipaunawa. Nakakapag-isip ka, nakakapili. Ito si Jadaone kapag nasa labas ng dikta ng studio, kapag malaya—tulad noong bago pa siya gumawa (o kapag hindi gumagawa) ng mga nakakautang romcom na ginawa nang hubugan ng mga sumunod sa kaniya.

I have no words, but this film really moved me. Nakakagalit. Matapang ang pelikula not because of the topic, naging matapang ang pelikula nang dahil sa kung paano ito kinuwento. Ang galing-galing mo, Maris! We deserve proper healthcare, particularly for women. The ending of the film proves how I really rooted for Sunshine and her dreams as an Olympian.#GetsKoNa

Interviewer: Pabor po ba kayo sa aborsyon?Interviewee: Hindi. Labag 'yan sa batas ng Diyos. Kahit hindi mo ginusto, biyaya pa rin 'yan.Interviewer: Paano kung bunga ng panggagahasa, hindi handa, walang kakayahang magpalaki, o delikado sa buhay ng ina?Interviewee: Tanggapin na lang. Panindigan mo.Bakit nga ba ganito ang kultura natin sa Pilipinas? Tanggapin. Tiisin. Kimkimin at ituring na “blessing” ang trauma at paghihirap.Bunga ba ito ng mapagkunwaring pagsabuhay ng relihiyon? Imbes na maging mabuting tao, nagiging mapanguhsga, sunod-sunuran sa mga itaas, at manhid sa damdamin ng iba. Ang tanging gusto ay makapunta sa langit at hindi maging sandalan ng kapwa niyang umiiyak sa hinagpis.Nakokontrol na nga ba tayo ng relihiyon at kultura kung saan ang mga lalaki ang palaging namumuno? Katulad ng conclave na puro lalaki ang bumoboto, nagtatalaga ng pinakamakapangyarihang lider ng simbahan. Samantala, ang babae'y itinutulak na maging ina: tungkulin daw niya ang isakripisyo ang kanyang pangarap, ang kanyang tinig.Hanggang kailan natin ituturing na banal ang pananahimik?Kung ang pananampalataya ay pinapatahimik ang naaapi sa ngalan ng “kalooban ng Diyos,” anong klaseng pananampalataya ito?Panahon na para tanungin, hindi lang ang ating mga prinsipyo, kundi ang mga sistemang kinukupkop nito. Kaya siguro, hanggang ngayon, narito pa rin tayo. Bansang walang pinagbago.Sex. Reproductive Health. Abortion. Teenage/Child Pregnancy. Mental Health. Iilan lang yan sa taboo topics na ayaw pag-usapan ng gobyerno at simbahan. Laging sinasabi na sumunod na lang sa “kung ano ang batas ng Diyos.” Pero hanggang kailan natin patatahimikin ang mga kwento ng kababaihan, kabataan, at mga taong naghihirap sa katahimikan? Hanggang kailan ikukubli ang realidad sa likod ng doktrina?Na may mga taong humihingi ng tulong: hindi ng dasal lang, kundi ng konkretong solusyon.Ang pananahimik ay hindi kabanalan.Ang pagtugon sa tunay na pangangailangan : iyan ang may malasakit.Panahon na para pag-usapan ang mga ayaw nilang pag-usapan.
Log ko lang muna kasi I can't write right now. I'm at Gong Cha and I might cry af!!!

Powerful. Authentic. Bold.Ang ganda ng film. Ang gustong ipakita ng pelikula? Ang realidad ng mga kabataang babae na hindi madalas marinig. Ang galing ni Maris. Kahit na wala siyang binabanggit na mga linya, damang dama ko yung emotion. Ramdam ko yung sakit, guilty and takot ni Shine. Yung simpleng pagtitig, paghinga, and pagbitaw ng mga linya niya ay napakasolid. Hindi pang-arte lang. Totoo. Ito na yung pinakamahusay na role ni Maris. Yung kwento, well narrated. Kakaiba siya and kailangan talaga siyang pagusapan. Ineexpose ng film na ito yung real life issues tulad ng abortion, teenage pregnancy, and stigma. Hindi pinilit ang morality, pinakita ang reality and hinayan ako na makapagdecide kung anong mafefeel ko. Ang ganda ganda ng cinematography. Super totoong totoo bawat eksena. Yung color grading, grabe ang galing. Bawat kulay saktong sakto sa bawat eksena.Super galing ni Jennica. Bilang ate hindi niya pinagalitan si Shine. Kinampihan niya kasi alam niya yung nararamdaman ng kapatid niya. Ang galing din ni Elijah. Kuha niya gigil ko. Aside from Maris, ang galing ni Annika and yung isa pang bata. Speechless lang sa performance ni Annika. Si Annika ang manifestation ng konsensiya, guilt and innocence. Nasasabi niya ang lahat ng ayaw aminin ni Sunshine sa sarili niya.Grabe yung eksena sa motel. Ang powerful. Pero grabe ang ending. Walang dramatic confrontation, walang resolution, at walang solusyon sa mga problema ni Sunshine. Pero isang bagay lang ang ginawa niya, pinili niyang magpatuloy.
Naiintindihan mo ba ako? Gets ko na. Gets ko na.

Antoinette Jadaone has always been one of the few Filipino filmmakers I deeply admire, not just for her craft, but for the way she tells women’s stories with empathy and nuance. Her work has always felt personal, films like Alone/Together, Fan Girl and now Sunshine, might just be my favorite Filipino film released this year so far.I remember seeing the trailer last year and wondering if it would even get a proper release here. It tackles such a taboo topic, one that many in this country still refuse to even speak about. That’s why I admire Jadaone so much. She’s chosen to talk about what others won’t. In a predominantly Catholic nation where abortion is criminalized, even in cases of rape or incest, Sunshine feels like an act of courage.I’ve always been pro-choice. I grew up surrounded by the whole “abortion is murder” narrative, from relatives, from my old Catholic school run by nuns. But even as a kid, it never sat right with me. I never saw it as a sin. And now that I’m studying to become a doctor, that belief matters even more to me, because women deserve healthcare that doesn’t judge or shame them. Sunshine affected me on a personal level because of that. It reminded me why I want to do this.It’s not a perfect film. Some might find the pacing fast or feel like it didn’t say enough. But to me, the point isn’t perfection. What matters is that it exists. It dares. It’s a film that opens doors, uncomfortable ones, sure, but necessary. I really hope it’s not the last of its kind.
Gets ko na.

Maris plays Sunshine with so much empathy that it permeates outside the screen, her win is our win, her disappointment is our disappointment. Through the streets of Manila to the corners of her room, we get to hold hands with her and be a confidant. I like how it positions the audience as part of this journey, not as the usual bystander. One sequence that stood out is the one from the inn to the hospital - Maris lets herself be consumed by Sunshine, almost as if the creeping is part of the routine itself. The messaging gets confusing in the middle but ultimately ends in a tender moment of acceptance and determination. I’m just happy films like this finally exist in our country.
Gets ko na
shuta ang galing ni Maris

I knew Sunshine was a good film even before watching it because Antoinette Jadaone has consistently delivered satisfying work throughout her career. I had the chance to watch it in a cinema in Cebu, surrounded by fellow film enthusiasts, including Maris Racal and Antoinette Jadaone in the audience. I teared up multiple times.This is a woman’s story, one that powerfully captures her control over her body and her choices. The film's use of magical realism elevated the narrative, turning what could have been dull internal monologues into vibrant, engaging character portrayals by the actors.It’s no surprise the film has already received international recognition. It absolutely deserves it, and even more.

Hindi ako nahihiya. Ayokong maging nanay Needless to say dahil expected na, pero ang galing ni Maris at Jennica. That leaning-on-shoulder scene nila sa taxi ang fave kong ganung moment in Asian cinema.Natuwa ako na nandito si Angeli Bayani, bilang isang compassionate na doctor.

gets ko na. gosh what a powerful one-liner to end and encapsulate the entire progression of the film. sobrang powerful that the child gets it; she understands and respects the reasons behind Sunshine's choices, even at the expense of her own life. sobrang powerful din ng scene before the last routine, with jennica and maris, na kahit anong desisyon ni Sunshine, mage-gets ng ate niya. at ganoon din yung goal ng pelikula—na ma-gets nating lahat why people resort to abortion,…

for as many times as we sit and talk about unwanted pregnancies and abortion, there is a woman out there na katulad ni sunshine na dala-dala ang bigat ng desisyong siya lang ang pwedeng gumawa. conversations regarding this matter often talk about the cause and consequences, but never once did we talk about the process women have to endure— the grief, the confusion, the isolation. it was never just in black and white. hindi lang siya basta nabuntis at mas lalong hindi lang siya basta nagdesisyon. this film showed everything in between. it was an honest attempt to potray the realities women go through, a reminder that we are free to dream and we are free to live life the way we choose to.

In a Q&A with writer-director Antoinette Jadaone that I was lucky to attend, she was asked how she braced for the potential backlash of this film from Filipino audiences given our mostly conservative background. Her answer resonated with me deeply: As a writer, Jadaone believes her primary duty is to stay loyal to her characters. If her character's arc demands visiting unnerving and controversial depths, she is not afraid to take the plunge - regardless of how viewers might perceive it. Her earlier work, Fan Girl (2020), already painted a similar picture, albeit a bit spottily.Jadaone takes her boldest steps yet in her latest work, Sunshine (2024), by tackling abortion, a highly contentious subject in the country, with both sensitivity and grit. This entry is unflinching in its commentary, taking us to the most harrowing places women can be in a nation where sexual abuse is prevalent, abortion is illegal, and healthcare fails the underprivileged . Sunshine, our protagonist, is a skilled gymnast, but even she can't leap over patriarchy, tumble past outdated laws, or cartwheel her way out of the conservative society and system. In one scene, Sunshine waits along a street choked with tricycles, behind the railing of a pharmacy counter - she is jailed in and by this wretched city, made a criminal for wanting to make a choice that should be her right. But this film's Manila is more than just Sunshine's prison. It's a breathing character, trailing her around from scene to scene. Always in the backdrop but never invisible. Never speaking but always loud. A passing MRT train rattles the windows of a shabby motel. A crammed jeepney bounces to the bass of a local rap song. Grimy streets teem with hustling vendors and weary residents. Sunshine makes her choices, but her choices are only as good as this bleak, brutal city allows . Maris Racal delivers a phenomenal performance, portraying our protagonist with nuance and raw intensity. She is backed by a stellar ensemble - Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, and Elijah Canlas - each breathing life into characters that are authentic and vital to the film's message. The sequences are daring, the story beats sometimes violent, but always necessary. The music elevates it all, with a standout Challengers-esque score underscoring the gymnastic scenes. This film is not without its faults though, with excessive cursing (seriously, again in a Project 8 work?), somewhat awkward acting, and some unpolished plot points, but these are forgivable given how effective the complete work is.Sunshine may very well be Direk Tonet's finest work yet - and rightly so. It stands as one of the most important Filipino films in the modern times.

first time watching a screening at a cinema with the star herself (ANG GANDA MO SA PERSONAL MARIS WTF)! such a great film with brilliant creative choices all throughout. so emotional and so so real. only a female director could masterfully tell this story!edit: after the second watch, i realized how empowering and important it was to portray this story using sports as a metaphor to her bodily autonomy. everybody loves her when she uses her body to look beautiful for the world, but when mishap occurs, she is shamed for it. yet, in the end, i noticed that the last thing she declares about her pregnancy is a statement that is so bold and firm: “Ayoko maging nanay.” right in front of the men who tried to control her decisions. which maybe leaves the audience to think: “what happened after that?” but the point is that her decision, her body, and her passion, are all unshakably hers until the end. and we see that because after that scene with miggy and his dad, she practices her routine again. and then it was so perfect-had tears in my eyes the whole time. in that gymnasium, Sunshine “drowns out the noise.” what remains is her unwavering bond with her body, both as a woman and as a gymnast.
Let women do what they want to do with their bodies!

i was deeply moved and inspired by sunshine. what a gem of philippine cinema. you know a film is good when it makes you want to create again. however, while undeniable in its prowess and relevance, its potency and impact dwindles in its struggle to pinpoint with conviction who its target audience is. it seems to want to pander to both liberal and conservative audiences, but this muddles its message. who is this film really for? who is it in dialogue with? i thought that the choice to portray the unborn fetus as a grown, conscious being was counterintuitive at first, but then i realized the film was only trying to meet its conservative audiences halfway in their beliefs. then i thought it was a stroke of genius: of course, the only way to convince someone to change their mind is by explaining it in the terms they understand, through their perspective of the world. but then it also alienates this very audience by demonizing them in the film. while it successfully empathizes with the horrors of being a woman in the philippines, there is a lack of nuance, a dichotomy of good vs. evil, that might be more harmful than helpful in the grander scheme of things.(there are also so many scenes where maris racal’s quiet yet powerful performance should have been enough, but the beauty of the moment is ruined by the “child” voicing out sunshine’s thoughts, spoon-feeding the audience.)only particularly critical because i think sunshine is an exciting step in the right direction for ph cinema. i loved it and i think everyone should still watch it in spite of its flaws.

The tone set by Sunshine over Jadaone's previous film, Fangirl, is way different. The urgency of survival is apparent and how it clashes with the film's thematic journey, like Paul Soriano's Thelma. Though Sunshine tends to get the feel of guerrilla direction, it is a combination of the director's experiences in mainstream and her indie roots. Meaning, we get to see well-lighted scenes and less usage of shake cam.Sunshine unpacks a lot of society's ills and inequalities. Patriarchy, discrimination in the medical field, inhumane laws, and glaring social class issues that don't benefit those without that much. In a country where religion reigns, or so they say, the film easily relays problems with well-made sequences and heartbreaking results. Jadaone knows the voices of her characters, and it tells a distinct topic with passion and wit, giving the audiences a rollercoaster of emotions.One thing that makes this film unique is the inclusion of a fantastic element. It somehow references, or a styling of, what they had in Death Note anime or Big Mouth to make it more accurate. And such symbolism as Sunshine's conscience made it relatively easier to tell the film's narrative. It was smartly added, and it didn't make the audience unintelligent.The technical are overwhelmingly great. The use of lighting in urban areas, especially those scenes shot at night, is worthy of a picturesque view of the marginalized reality. We rarely see such strong shots in film. The options to use close-ups for intensity of emotions and certain decisions to make the scenes with Mariz Racal's gymnastic performance were made with careful efficiency. And the sound editing was just on point. It is technically the protagonist's in-ear audio being shared with the viewers.Jadaone's casting is really one for the books. An appreciation to Mariz Racal's graceful bookend performance. The representation is exactly what we need to see from young adults, especially in the situation of what is happening to her character. The conflict-bearers really made the sequences memorable, and it made you think of the situations presented. These aren't farfetched ideas shown in the film. Most of them are realistically sound and Piolo Pascual's short stint really is just something for us to gasp about. And we also get to see Jennica Garcia and Elijah Canlas' supporting roles to complete the ensemble.Les we forget Annika Co's strong personality. I guess we have another star made by the director. And regarding Meryll Soriano being part of the film. It made me remember how she did a similar role back in 2010, as Lizette in the Mark Meily film, Donor.Sunshine displays what needs to be said in a society when abortion is considered a taboo topic. A possible eye-opener to the current status quo. .:smcityeastortigas>>

Sunshine Francisco played by Maris Racal, is a teenage gymnast dreaming of getting in the Olympics, got pregnant by accident, and must face the moral dilemma of choosing between her dreams and keeping the baby.Maris Racal carried the film to pitch perfection and rawness. She takes you in and makes you feel her struggles. Her facial nuances and physical vigor makes her the right choice to play the titular role, in what could be a role of a lifetime. Director Antoinette Jadaone's never been more sure and absolute of her vision here. The film stands as an audacious statement in a country full of naysayers when it comes to the sensitive and controversial subject matter: abortion. The ending really made me shed a tear, in response to understanding why women do what they do. Though the film is not without its flaws. I sometimes felt the script and characters could have been more seamlessly sewn, and not just coming out of nowhere, making it feel a bit unnatural. Nevertheless, this is an essential film that needs to be seen by a wide audience. It didn't provide the answers, but this is what a filmmaker does best: to start conversations, to challenge the status quo and make us reflect our own beliefs and morals.ps. support local films, local music, local products, and local boys. eme

Some people will never understand what it feels like to be a woman.Some will never understand what it feels like to be poor.Some will never understand what it feels like to have no choice—and to only be left with the harmful one.This film carries the burden of making you feel something about these topics and it does, effectively.It does not shy away from addressing these themes. Yet at the same time, the film never forces them down the audience’s throat. These issues are real. The depiction of Manila is painfully real. The horror of what Sunshine is going through feels immediate and heavy.Gorgeously shot. Gorgeously written. Gorgeously acted. This is Tonette at her bravest. I’m excited for what comes next.

naiintindihan mo ba ako? gets ko na. gets ko na.bawled my eyes out during the last scene when she was doing her routine. kuhang-kuha ako ni Maris. ramdam na ramdam mo ang bawat emosyon na pinapakita niya. this film is beautifully executed and cuts deep. it's the kind of story no one’s ready to talk about but we need to. it speaks for the silenced, for every woman forced to carry pain quietly.also—ang realistic din ng pagkakuha ng relationship ni Maris with her coach. grabe ang flashbacks ko as a former gymnast sa mga “pa-drown the noise” moments ni coach, ramdam na ramdam.

This was honestly just a sad movie. Even though you should be at least happy for Racal's character at the end. She went through hell and back just for the sake of her dream. It was a poignant (POIGNANT?!) commentary on a person's instinct to pursue one's dream and how it can lead to decisions and sacrifices to avoid compromise or delay. The other commentary is definitely about teen pregnancy/sex education/family planning in the Philippines. Despite having dramatized scenes, the burden that tolls on the characters is easily felt. Direk Tonet's writing, cinematography, directing, and overall vision really had a strong impact with this movie. Grabe talaga, its one of those films na babalikan mo in the future. I was really hoping this movie wouldn't end in a tragedy the way so much media in the Philippines has portrayed abortion in the past. I was hoping Sunshine would live a good life and thankfully, Antoinette Jadaone did just that. Sunshine shows an important and timely message. That scene when Sunshine speaks up against her pathetic boyfriend Miggy and his pastor dad that she is not ready to be a mother means so much to me. To be able to say no, I choose when this will happen to me and it is not going to happen today. Jennica Garcia's character as Sunshine's older sister is also a powerful performance. The fact that Sunshine had women helping her in her struggles gave hope that in the midst of a very religious and conservative society in the Philippines, there are women who believe that we should have the freedom and power to choose what happens to our bodies.

Every time I visit Quiapo Church, I’m always amused by the chaos outside its gates. Right beside vendors selling rosaries, crucifixes, candles, and bottles of holy water, there are stalls hawking pamparegla and other herbal concoctions said to “regulate” missed periods. The juxtaposition is striking. Sacred and taboo, salvation and cycle, side by side like it’s the most natural thing in the world. It’s absurd, hilarious, and deeply Filipino. I always find myself thinking, someone should write a story, play, or movie out of this contradiction. With Sunshine, it finally feels like someone did. Fearlessly and with heart.It’s not exactly about Quiapo, but it carries the same beautiful mess of contradictions. Faith and survival, morality and body, dream and disappointment. It dares to talk about reproductive health care in the Philippines without flinching, but it’s also about more than that. It’s about the right to choose. Not just over one’s body, but over one’s future. It’s about women tired of being told to wait, to settle, to stay silent. And finally daring to want more. What makes it powerful is its quiet grace. It doesn’t preach. It listens. To the unspoken shame carried by women. To the whispers exchanged in tricycle/jeepney rides and neighborhood clinics. To the dreams that keep getting deferred by the weight of economy, expectation, and morality. Sunshine is a film that sees women. Not as symbols or martyrs, but as people.Technically, it’s a marvel. The cinematography captures the real Manila. Not the sepia-toned or shadow-drenched “poverty porn” we’re so used to. No extra lighting or artificial grime smeared on walls for the sake of grittiness. No “designing poverty.” The production design feels lived in, never overworked. Every detail feels honest. If I have only one criticism, it's that the magical realism elements could have been woven in more seamlessly. But even that doesn’t take away from the film’s quiet power.Then there’s the acting. Maris Racal delivers the role of a lifetime. Raw, honest, and quietly devastating. Jennica Garcia, whenever she’s on screen, shines. Her presence is magnetic, and together, their chemistry feels lived-in and true.In every sense, Sunshine is a landmark film. It should be our Oscar submission for next year. And if there’s any justice, it should sweep every local award. It’s not just a movie. It’s a mirror. One we’ve long needed in a country as patriarchal and hypocritical as ours. The kind of mirror that’s often hard for Filipinos to look into, but impossible to ignore.

Some films entertain you. Sunshine confronts you.When the credits rolled, no one moved. No one spoke. It was that rare kind of silence. Not awkward, but sacred. As if we had all just witnessed something painfully true and didn’t quite know what to do with ourselves.Because Sunshine isn’t just a movie. It’s a question. A confrontation. Directed with clarity and deep compassion by Direk Tonet Jadaone, Sunshine doesn’t soften its message or try to make it more palatable.. It’s brave. It’s loud in its honesty. It doesn’t ask for permission to be angry or tired or vulnerable. It simply is, and that’s why it hits the way it does. And yet, somehow, even with all its emotional weight, Direk Tonet’s signature humor still finds its way through. There are moments—unexpected but perfectly timed—when the entire cinema bursts into laughter. It’s sharp, it’s honest, and it never feels out of place. Maybe Direk Tonet makes us laugh because she knows we’ll cry eventually. Or maybe that’s just how we are as Filipinos, finding humor even in the heaviest moments, because sometimes, it’s the only way we know how to carry the pain.What makes this film even more powerful is how it gives voice to things we often overlook. As someone who isn’t a woman, I know I can’t fully grasp the weight of that experience. But this film opened a window for me. A clear, honest glimpse into a reality I will never live, but need to see. Much of that power comes from the performances. Maris Racal, as Sunshine, delivers the most vulnerable and grounded work of her career. Her pain is quiet, but it radiates. You feel it in the way she holds her breath between words, in the weight behind her gaze. Jennica Garcia, as her sister, is just as affecting. Her stillness, her softness, the way she listens. She becomes a reflection of what the film asks of us: to pause, to witness, to respond with care. There’s a moment near the end that stuck with me. Sunshine asks, “Gets mo na ba ako?”And while it’s said to the person in the room, it felt like she was looking straight through the screen, asking us, the viewers. And like that person beside her, I hope we all have the courage to say: Yes. We see you. We understand.Please, Direk Tonet, keep making films like this (inutusan pa nga). Keep telling stories that hold space for women to be everything—loud and quiet, strong and hurting, tired and brave. Stories that make people feel seen.Gets kita, Sunshine.

what does it mean to want something just for yourself, when everyone else thinks they know better?sunshine is about what happens when a girl becomes a symbol— of shame, of failure, of something to fix. it’s about how the world will rally for gold medals but stay silent when a young woman says, i’m not ready.this isn’t just a film about abortion or teenage pregnancy. it’s about the grief of losing the life you fought for before you ever got to live it.all throughout the film i kept thinking: would i have chosen differently if i were in her place?well, that's the point. the choice should be mine. even if it haunts me. even if no one else understands what that could mean.and sunshine, with all her fears and defiance, she reminds us: there is no right way to fight for your life.only your way.

Gets ko na. I am studying MA Women and Development. I always mention yan dahil di naman ako pinanganak na babae. Pero I feel feminine enough to be a woman. Sa tanan ng pagaaral ko ng kurso ko, andami ko na ring mga babaeng nakasalamuha. Yung feeling ko dito sa pelikulang to ay parang nakausap at nakaharap ko na si Sunshine. Sa mga babaeng nakausap ko, nakadaupang palad ko, natulungan ko, andun si Sunshine. Sa mga babaeng nagtuturo sa akin kung paano maging mas mabuting tao at mas mabuting babae o binabae, andun yung ate ni Sunshine, andun si Mary Grace, andun yung tricycle driver, andun yung hotel receptionist, nasa atin lang silang lahat. Sa buong sinehan sa Sta. Mesa, ako lang ata ang mugto ang mata na lumabas sa sinehan, di ko alam dahil siguro ramdam ko ang danas nila, dahil siguro yung mga nababasa ko sa klase ay totoo nga, at dahil siguro, yung pagkabigo ko sa bawat hakbang or lecture or recitation na naranasan ko sa loob ng dalawang taong pagbabagong hubog ko ay nagkaroon na ng isang imahe. Siguro yung iyak ko dahil sa tapang rin na sana meron ako, na sana meron tayong lahat, kasi yung laban natin, maraming maraming pagsubok pa na dadanasin, taong kukutya, at mga lalaking gagapi, pero sa kabilang dako, alam nating tayo tayo lang rin ang magkakakampi. Ako si Sunshine, tayo si Sunshine. Kaya naiintindihan ko na.

kung gagawan ng hirarkiya ang mga karapatan ng tao sa pilipinas, mula sa laging nabibigyang atensyon sa madalas naisasantabi, kasama sa laylayan ang kababaihan—baka hindi lang sa pilipinas, malamang sa buong mundo.isa sa sentro ng pelikula ang reproductive health at aborsyon. isang maselang usapin sa isang bansang ilang siglo nang sadlak sa ideolohiya ng katolisismo, isang bagay na pilit pumipiit sa mga batas na dapat ay nagsisilbi sa lahat ng pilipino at hindi sa iilan lamang. sobrang pait makita ang depiksyon ng mga batang babaeng nais lamang kumawala sa tanikalang hindi naman sila lamang ang may gawa, ngunit sila lamang ang nagdurusa. nanliliit na sila sa lipunang mababa ang tingin sa mga batang ina, nanliliit pa sila sa sistemang iniwanan silang mag-isa—sabi nga sa pelikula, krimen ang aborsyo.hugas-kamay pa ang doktor, na nangakong sumagip ng buhay nang matanggap ang kanyang lisensya—isang bagay na dinahilan para hindi tulungan ang nag-aagaw-buhay na si mary grace. naiintindihan ko na sistematiko ang pagkukulang, pero hindi ba may mali pa rin? hindi ko masisi ang doktor—mahirap mawalan ng trabaho sa pilipinas. lalong hahaba ang listahan ng biktima ng kahirapan. pasalamat na lang sa mga doktor na tulad ni doktor helena. hindi ko maisantabi ang subtext na babae din siya. sino pa ba ang tutulong sa kapwa babae kundi babae rin? habang umaagos ang luha ko sa sinehan, pinagdarasal ko ang mga totoong taong nagbubuntis ngayon at nagnanais ng kalayaan. sana ligtas sila. sana makamit nila ang buhay na kanilang inaasam-asam.nasa puso ng istorya, para sa akin, ang pangarap. simula't sapul, sa pagbubukas ng kwento, pambungad na ang pangarap ni sunshine na maging isang olympian. ubos-lakas at buong tapang niyang linalakbay ang daan patungo dito. sa likod niya ang kaniyang pamilya, coach, at matalik na kaibigan. sa salaysay ng kwento, halos hindi mahalagang bahagi ng buhay niya ang ama ng kaniyang dinadala—nagkataon na lang na naging bahagi siya ng kwento. isang gabing pagkakamali na naiwasan sana kung mayroon matibay na reproductive health education sa bansa. isa sa mga pagkukulang ng mga institusyong nagsisilbi dapat sa nakararami, hindi ng mga bata. pero sa kanila pa rin ang sisi—sabi nga ng tindera sa botika, kung anu-ano na ang ginagawa ng mga bata ngayon. kilala ba niya si sunshine? hindi. alam ba niya na atleta si sunshine? hindi. pero pambungad pa rin ang panghuhusga.isa pang bahagi ng opresyon ni sunshine ang pagiging bata. nabanggit ko kamakailan ang isa sa mga agam-agam ko na marahil ay hindi natin napapansin masyado, pero marahil ay nagagawa din natin paminsan. ang mga micro-aggression sa mga bata—kesyo maingay sila, kesyo hindi pa nila alam ang ginagawa nila, kesyo bakit kayo nandito? pero huminto man lang ba tayo para isipin kung ano ang lagay nila? simula ng pandemya, lalong lumiit ang espasyong ginagalawan nila kung saan dapat silang makihalubilo at matuto kasama ang mga kaedad nila. saan ba sila dapat lumugar? nasaan ang pamilya nila? nasaan ang komunidad na dapat kumalinga sa kanila?sanga-sanga ang problemang pilit inilahad ng sunshine, pero hindi ko na palalayuin pa. pakiwari ko, alam naman ng lahat kung gaano kalalim ang mga isyu sa pilipinas. hindi lang natin alam paano magsisimulang solusyonan ito.ibabalik ko sa pangarap. lahat ng tao: minsan, hanggang ngayon, lagi’t-lagi, ay may tangan-tangang pangarap—maliit man o malaki. isa itong krus na boluntaryo nating binibitbit hanggang sa makamit natin ang patimpalak o kaya naman ay pansamantalang binibitawan para sa iba pang mga pangarap.puso ng pelikula si sunshine na nais maging olympian. nakakatuwang makita ang paninindigan niyang makamit ito anuman ang mangyari. kanya-kanya tayong may mga isinakripisyo para sa pangarap. nakakatuwang hindi niya isinakripisyo ang sarili para lamang sa iisipin ng iba—para sa ano ang 'tama' sa tingin ng tao at ng 'diyos'. naiintindihan ng 'diyos' niya kung bakit niya kinailangang gawin ang mga bagay na ginawa niya. mapagpatawad ito. nakapagpatawad na rin ang bata sa imahinasyon niya. naiintindihan niya na para maging olympian sila ni sunshine, dapat siyang magpaalam. isang malalim na pagmamahal ang pinakita ni sunshine sa pelikula, sa kabila ng lahat—pagmamahal sa sarili, pagmamahal sa pangarap, at pagmamahal sa buhay, sa buhay na nais niyang buuin para sa kanya.sa loob ng isang oras at kalahati, napakalalim at napakagandang nailatag ng pelikula ang mga tunay na kwentong ito. napakagaling ng bawat aktor na nagbigay-buhay sa mga karakter na base sa mga totoong tao. kulang ang isang beses na panonood para makuha pati maliliit na detalye na sigurado ay mahalaga. kailangang panoorin. kailangang panoorin uli. kailangan natin ng mas marami pang gantong kwento sa pelikula. bigyang-boses muna sila hanggang marinig na din natin ang kanilang totoong mga tinig.

Ganito yung mga paborito kong genre, binibigyan ng pagkakataon yung audience nila para maging matalinong manonood. Maris’ performance was stellar. The casting was perfect, like?? i still need time to process after watching this in the cinema tonight and after waiting for this for so long :") but as a young woman with big dreams as well as an older sister like sunshine, i am sooo so so emotional over this film. it made me cry, it surprisingly made me laugh, and it made me ponder. still thinking about how i feel about annika co's character, but regardless, i am grateful direk tonet and the entire team behind this really fought for this film to be produced and screened in the philippines and across the world.

Ang ganda ng film na ‘to. Ang ganda ng cinematography—ramdam mo kung gaano kagulo sa Metro Manila. Ang galing ni Maris. I think she solidified her place as one of, if not the best, Filipina actress in her age group right now (wag nyo lang panoorin ang Sosyal Climbers). Solid ng range niya sa pag-arte. May mga eksena ditong ramdam na randam mo talaga yung sakit na pinapasan nya (emotionally at physically).Gayunpaman, may mga detalye pa ring medyo di nag-klik para sa’kin. May mga creative choices sa plot na questionable depende sa kung saang spectrum ka sa abortion debate. If pro-abortion ka tulad ko, magigets mo ‘to.Overall, a very timely film considering na sobrang conservative nga ng Pilipinas pagdating sa issue na ‘to. Brings to light the unfair challenges women must face just to have autonomy over their own bodies.Feeling great. Andami kong napanood na Filipino films lately!

Sunshine (2024) would be a perfect double feature with Eliza Hittman's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) as they both tackle similar topics but with a stark difference in privilege and access.where the latter becomes a story of sisterhood and compassion, as two girls cross state lines to get access to healthcare, Sunshine offers no such respite to our eponymous protagonist.in here, what Sunshine wants is not even a matter of choice, it is something that she is forced to bear. all alone as her confidants succumb to the stigma of her dilemma, Sunshine takes to the streets of Manila in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy.the plot moves along while the audience is served scenes of what i believe to be one of the better cinematic depictions of modern Manila. the first few minutes almost feel like an entirely different film (one i would have particularly liked more) until the plot takes a peculiar detour.in all of its realism and poignancy i found a particular element in its storytelling very out of place and oftentimes distracting. while the ending made me understand why those choices were made i just don't think a semblance of Magical Realism is the perfect vehicle for a message as heavy as this one.while i think the point that: "an entire generation of Filipino women being forced to reckon with their unborn children as if the choice of abortion is something that has to be explained, and in turn, be understood." is a step in the right direction for this nation's pro-choice discourse, the delivery just felt like it was bordering into Diary of an Unborn Child territory. with that being said, i still thoroughly enjoyed Sunshine and i would still highly recommend it. despite some of my grievances with the film, the unblemished ray of sunshine known as Maris Racal delivers a stellar performance in the titular role. perhaps even a mariesteller one. *wink* *wink*

This is my first film in FOUR months?! It’s horrible for my cinephile ass out here…This is the Happening of Filipino cinema, except it’s less thrilling and more aligned with the traditional storytelling of Filipino drama.Perhaps my favorite element of this new project from Antoinette Jadaone is the contrast between morality and sin as personified by the hawker who sells abortion pills behind figures of saints beside Quiapo Church, which is arguably the most popular place of veneration among Catholic Filipinos throughout the country.Beyond that, I’m struggling to seek nuance and proper closure. What sets this work, aside from the palpable gentleness toward the female main character, apart from the many stories about abortion out there?It’s worth noting, however, that stories about women are told by women, just like what Jadaone manages to deliver here. I believe (cis) male filmmakers, no matter how genuine their intent is, cannot tell stories about women because women’s danas, the distinct Filipino word for experience, is not men’s danas.[Watched at SM Mall of Asia Cinema 1]

Sunshine is going to be an eye-opener for a lot of people here in the Philippines. It doesn't just raise awareness, it confronts the daily injustices Filipino women face just for being women. This should kickstart long-overdue conversations about reproductive rights, no matter how uncomfortable they may be.Maris Racal gives a career-defining performance as Sunshine. She fully captures the vulnerability, resilience, and quiet strength of her character. She feels heartbreakingly real. The supporting cast also pulls its weight, with Jennica Garcia standing out in a big way.What I really appreciated is how the film frames everything through the lens of a deeply Catholic country. The Sto. Niño statues being sold next to illegal abortion pills and the Christmas lights in the maternity ward stick with you. They are not just background details, they feel like commentary. Birth and suffering are made sacred here, even when they come with pain, even when they are not wanted.Sometimes it feels like the film is about to lean into pro-life messaging, with "what if" hypotheticals and future-president guilt trips. But instead of reinforcing those ideas, it pulls them apart. I didn't expect it to handle such a taboo subject with this much care. Subtlety is completely thrown out the window at times, with some characters written like Facebook comment sections come to life. They are loud, caricature-like, and clearly meant to provoke. But the sad truth is that people like that exist.Without getting into spoilers, the film isn’t trying to decide what’s right or wrong. It’s more interested in what it means to be understood.Heavy-handed? Sometimes. Necessary? Absolutely.So with that, we thank God for Sunshine.

The moments when our titular character, Sunshine, was hopeless and lost, the first thought that came to mind was: Thank God I’m not a woman. And as soon as I thought it, I recognized how privileged it was to even have such a thought. How easy it is to be a cis man. And because of that, I’ll never truly understand how a woman feels.But this is precisely what the film accomplished—it made me feel.Direk Tonet’s writing and direction are potent and hard-hitting, while Maris’ performance is just as powerful. For a film that exudes a seemingly hopeless atmosphere, with no end in sight to the world’s harshness, Maris’ Sunshine shone like a light at the end of the tunnel.I hope the future is kinder to women, and I hope I get to contribute to paving the way for that future to become a reality.

No filters. No lies. An honest, no-holds-barred glimpse of women's societal struggles.‎Pro-woman movie. Sunshine is a bold and timely film that opens up vital conversations around abortion and a woman's right to choose. It challenges traditional views by asserting that motherhood is a decision, not a duty—and that bringing a child into the world should be an intentional, compassionate act.‎The film’s message is powerfully delivered through impeccable cinematography and emotionally grounded storytelling. Sunshine which was played by Maris Racal gives a standout performance, capturing the complexities of her role with sincerity and strength. The ensemble cast also deserves praise for their nuanced portrayals, collectively bringing depth to a narrative that is both personal and political.

I still remember when Direk Tonet shared the concept of Sunshine back in 2021 at a workshop I attended. Everyone knew it was risky, yet the story had to be told. It wasn’t a question of “how” but “when?”Fast forward to today, Sunshine finally lives and receives its well-deserved spotlight. It’s easy for some to dismiss it as “just a film about abortion”. When in reality, it’s a gritty portrayal of thousands of Filipinas—all the dreams and lives lost, the could haves and what ifs. The fact that this film exists (in this political and social climate) is already a miracle. It being one of Direk Tonet’s masterpieces is just a bonus.

My experience with this film didn’t end when the credits started rolling. Walking out of the cinema and into the crowded floors of a large mall, I began to watch people with a weighted heart. The children playing. The mothers of different ages. It left me reeling and in silence for quite a bit, to the point I felt a little sorry to the company I watched the film with. That was the moment I knew this film would leave an impact for a lot of people, and could even be divisive among most of its Filipino audiences.Sunshine leaves a mark. A film that paints a very real, raw, uncomfortable, and deeply moving picture on what it is like to be a Filipino woman with a dream, a mistake, and an agency that is being challenged by those around her—even by herself. It does this through depicting scenes all pointing towards the state of reproductive healthcare in the Philippines, and all those who are affected by it.Its characters are what makes the film so moving. Of course, Maris Racal does a stunning job portraying Sunshine and the character’s emotional complexity. Every character, though, has a purpose and reflects Filipino realities accurately. Perhaps the most special characters are what the film uses as a device to move the story along. At first, I felt unsure of it, but by the end of the film, it was very effective.This is a type of story that I feel, and hope, most Filipinos get to see. It is highly relevant as much as it is good. The narrative, linear structure of the film lends to the experience of the casual spectator; it builds up and comes crashing down. The scene of Sunshine being alone in the gymnasium.. is one that will stick with me for a while.I love this film. Go see it. It is so worth the ₱270.

Smart, funny, emotional, and heartbreakingly raw and real in showing the state of women's access to, or lack thereof, reproductive healthcare options in the Philippines.MARIS RACAL, THE ACTRESS THAT YOU ARE!! Also, much flowers to the incredibly talented supporting cast!

Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers in your chest long after the credits roll. It’s raw, urgent, and quietly devastating. Maris Racal gives such a gripping performance—her portrayal of a young gymnast grappling with an impossible choice feels painfully real. The way the film contrasts the clean, structured world of gymnastics with the chaos of Manila's underground makes everything hit harder. There’s so much weight in the silence, the stares, the quiet desperation. It doesn’t hold your hand or tie things up neatly, but that’s what makes it so powerful. Antoinette Jadaone tells Sunshine’s story with empathy and fire, shedding light on the terrifying realities young girls face in a country that offers them no choices. Unflinching and necessary.
