For a couple of years, I've lived and roamed in the kind of Manila Tonet has painted for us: busy and dirty streets of Recto and Carriedo overflowing with people trying to make ends meet, the filthy motels of Avenida filled with horny, exploitative men who need them, and the whispering neighborhood all around the tight grid-like system such as Tondo, Blumentritt, San Lazaro, Laon-Laan or Dapitan watching, staring, looking for something to make time pass.Under the watchful eyes of this condemnatory city stands a rather bright-eyed Sunshine, a young female student-gymnast trying to secure her spot in athletic competitions such as the Olympics and SEA Games. Her hard work and dedication have reflected in her routine, and her coach is confident in her skill in making it to the national team. But all of her dreams of soaring global recognition have been put to risk when one day, she discovers she is with child.What's heartbreaking about this piece is that this film is about a young woman working day and night fighting for a country who doesn't fight for her. This is a country where a woman needs to make unnecessarily drastic measures just to live a life she works hard on achieving. This is a country built on guilt and shame, yet a country proudly branded for its resilience. This is a country that veiled its dirt and its scum with the cloak of catholic morals and self-righteousness. This is no place for a sun to shine on.It's easy for me to believe in this film, because it is a true story. This is a biography, not of Sunshine and not of Tonet. This is a biography of Philippines in modern day, and for decades this has been told time and time again from the works of Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Brillante Mendoza, to works of Kip Oebanda, Ramona Diaz, and now Antoinette Jadaone. For years filmmakers like them have hoped for a brighter future, hoped for people to open their eyes and unveil what is hidden in plain sight, and Tonet, in this incredible feat, making the movie ticket as cheap and as accessible as it can be, is reaching out to us saying "This is my country. Look and see."

The moment Sunshine opened, I felt like I was already there in her world. That’s one of the things I’ve always admired about Direk Tonet Jadaone: how she builds these quiet, lived-in spaces that don’t just exist for her characters, but completely pull you in. You don’t just watch the story unfold, you feel it with Sunshine.What stuck with me the most is the way the film builds this deeply uncomfortable paradox: a country that loudly declares abortion is murder, yet leaves no room for safe options, quietly allowing dangerous pills to be sold under the table. The contradiction isn’t even subtle, it’s the whole point. Being a Filipino is already hard, but being a woman in the Philippines? It's brutal. The film doesn’t sugarcoat anything, it throws you straight into the brokenness of it all, from healthcare to shame culture to just… surviving.As the story unfolds, you’re taken on this intense ride with Sunshine, a girl trying to make sense of what she’s going through while the world around her offers no real answers. It forces you to confront your own biases. You start to ask yourself: what would I do in her place? What’s the “right” choice, really, when you’re trapped in a society that only ever gives you wrong ones?Menggay’s story hit like a gut punch. It’s the kind of pain that’s so real, but we never talk about because we’re scared to. Menggay isn't just another casualty, at the end of it all -- she's still a kid.What I love most about the storytelling is that it doesn’t preach. It makes you think, it makes you question -- but in the end, it reminds you that it should all boil down to what Sunshine feels is right. What she knows is best. It gives her that agency, that voice, something this world so often tries to take from girls like her.I've always been a fan of Maris Racal, and I agree that this is her best project yet. She didn’t need to go big; her silence already said everything. And I loved how the film used gymnastics as this quiet metaphor of control, performance, and discipline all while her personal life spirals into uncertainty. It’s so smart.And I have to say: the cinematography? Stunning. Of course, the gym scenes were beautifully shot, we all expected that - but it was the motel scenes that floored me. There was something about how those moments were framed that just hit harder. Like everything was raw, exposed, still. And what really stayed with me, long after the credits rolled, was this one feeling: at the end of it all, our dreams, they’re always for the younger versions of ourselves. We fight, we keep going, because we hope they’d understand. That if we ever had to explain why we chose what we chose, they’d look at us and say, “gets kita.”But the question that lingers is: are we, is this world ready for a story as brave as Sunshine?

i love how sunshine stood her ground and said she didn’t want to be a mother, even when her boyfriend’s dad offered help and support. it really showed how sure she was about what she wanted for her life. abortion should be legalized not because people are being careless, but because women should have the right to decide for themselves.and let’s not ignore the elephant in the room: the philippine healthcare system is so messed up. women like sunshine don’t get the care they need. and for what? so the budget can go to another pointless msproject or billboardsized face of some politician? like, please… put the money into actual healthcare. NO ONE SHOULD HAVE TO CHOOSE BETWEEN DYING IN SECRET AND LIVING IN SHAME. I cried because it’s painfully relateable and also bc I know women like her. I’ve been that friend who hears the secret. The details are so specific and real. From the moment she bought the pregnancy kit with shame in her eyes and afraid of judgement — to checking that test in a cramped public restroom where two cubicles exist but only one works. Lalo kay Maris at Sunshine sa pagdala ng kwento at pagbitbit ng bigat na totoo sa buhay ng maraming kababaihan.

There’s no denying Sunshine matters - it speaks to harsh truths and tackles its themes with care and emotional honesty. The film had a timely subject, sincere writing, and phenomenal acting - Maris Racal was stellar, while Jennica Garcia delivered with quiet power. But I struggled with certain elements, particularly its attempt at magical realism. The presence of the imaginary child felt clunky, tonally jarring, and out of sync with the otherwise grounded narrative. Frankly, the character felt unnecessary - the film had already evolved past the need for her. The story had power, and I wish it had trusted its own strength without the added flourish. Ultimately, I admired its purpose more than loving its execution.

Sunshine sheds light on a topic many still avoid, the abortion and women's choices. It's not just a Philippine issue, but a global one. Sensitive as it is, this film proves it's a conversation worth having, especially with the youth. Sex education needs attention, lalo na mula sa mga nasa pwesto. The government should support this by pushing for proper education and open dialogue.Kudos to the whole Sunshine team for bringing a story like this to light, something we should be openly discussing in this day and age.

The premise was simple but the message was hard. It did not just amplify a young girl's struggle with how to handle a life-changing conflict, but it also showed how the external actors play a huge role on how things must go. The film aimed to magnify how conservative the culture of the Philippines is, in which in this modern age, some of it could be considered obsolete.Coming from someone with a short attention span, I found myself staring at the cinema screen for the whole time, even after the film ended. There were no dull parts of the film, all scenes were necessary to how the story flows.Maris Racal's portrayal was exemplary. It was a different flavor from what she was known for, and this might be the turning point to her career. I would also have to give some flowers to Jennica Garcia, even with minimal participation in the scenes, her eyes and her minimal actions spoke volumes.

In a deep personal level, saying that I like this film is an understatement. This is a well crafted story that follows a gymnast enroute of becoming an Olympian. Antoinette Jadaone is really clever in tackling a stigma with boldness and sensitivity at the same time. I really appreciate that the movie also depicts the reality and scenarios of living in Manila on a daily basis. I also appreciate the shots where the busy streets of Manila is in the backdrop. This may be an overstatement but Lino Brocka will be proud. I do not want to compare but when I was watching this movie, I remembered the late Gil Portes' classic High School Scandal starring Gina Alajar and Sandy Andolong. Its a proof that we need movies like this to be informed and educated.Maris Racal, the entire heart of the movie, humbly carried the story in her back - a teenager who got pregnant in a very religious and conservative country. This is her best one yet - humble, raw and precise. The supporting cast are great, too. Jennica Garcia's eyes are really captivating on those crucial moments. And Anika? Bruuuh, we really need to watch for that little one in the years to come.One of the best Filipino films in recent memory, Sunshine is bold, thought-provoking and relevant. Sunshine deserved all the hype and that f*cking Crystal Bear award. I am waiting for the movie's release since last year and finally, Sunshine is home! And hopefully, this will be a strong contender for the Oscars next year!Mabuhay ang pelikulang Pilipino!

Play "Perpektong Tao" by Maris Racal.Oh Diyos ko po, mapapatawad N’yo pa ba ako!!!I walked into the cinema with so much expectation—and Sunshine delivered more than my expectations. This is a landmark film. A humanizing, soul-stirring, and bold piece of cinema that dares to speak truth in a country that often prefers silence and compliance.In a nation as conservative and deeply religious as the Philippines, Sunshine dives headfirst into the conversations we often whisper about, especially around the elderly and religious individuals—abortion, reproductive health, sexual abuse (WITHIN the family), and the religious hypocrisy that surrounds them. One of the most powerful moments for me was when she prays to God in the middle of an abortion attempt: “Lord, tanggalin Mo lang ’to, babawi ako sa lahat-lahat.” That line alone—honest and devastating—is a statement that cuts deep into the Filipino moral paradox.Napakagaling. Maris Racal carried this film on her own, brilliantly. No awkward or cringey moments—just pure, intentional acting that hits you right in the gut. This is easily her most brilliant and mature performance to date, and I am hungry for more.Also, just to share my theory: I don’t think the kids she sees represent a “mother figure” version of herself. To me, they were the babies’ little angels, quietly watching over their mothers, protecting them, forgiving them.I laughed, I wept, I cursed out loud inside the cinema. PUTANGINANG PILIPINAS TO. We need to see this. Sunshine deserves every bit of international acclaim it’s been getting—and more. And most of all: the Philippines is ready. Filipinos are ready for this conversation, for this kind of truth-telling, for this kind of art. More than a film, it’s also a wake-up call. Never doubted you, Maris Racal.

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is a powerful and unflinching examination of the ongoing issue of teenage pregnancy in the Philippines, anchored by a stunning breakout performance from Maris Racal. The film transcends a simple narrative, offering a poignant and necessary critique of a society grappling with deeply entrenched religious and political views that often leave young women isolated and without agency. Through its raw and unapologetic storytelling, Sunshine doesn’t just present a problem. It takes a stand and demands that we, the viewers, confront it alongside its protagonist.Where the film truly excels is in its unflinching depiction of the societal and systemic failures that trap young women like Sunshine. The Philippines has the second-highest rate of teenage pregnancy in Southeast Asia, and a 2023 survey by Save the Children Philippines revealed that more than 500 adolescents become mothers each day, some as young as ten years old. Sunshine masterfully illustrates the intense personal isolation behind these numbers by using the accessible medium of sports. Read my full review here.

I have a love-hate relationship with the Philippines.My country has it all, a strong historical background and culture, beautiful agricultural sights. The Philippines shines in so many ways. This country is easy to love, but it’s also easy to hate. On the other side of the spectrum, the Philippines is plagued with corruption, deeply oppressive religious standards, and many more hateful traditions and mindsets that continue to affect the Filipino people. The bare minimum is oftentimes glorified as the best that society could do for itself in the Philippines, but is to settle for less to settle for enough? This is the question that Sunshine raises. In a country that struggles to stand for its women, Sunshine did what many movies could not, it fearlessly depicted what was real and happening in our country. It showed the pure, unfiltered realities of a young, adolescent woman facing an unwanted pregnancy. The film doesn’t hold back. From the infamous ‘motel scene’ to the different women we follow in the film, direk Antoinette Jadaone fearlessly portrays the dangers a woman has to go through just to gain autonomy over their body, hopes, and dreams.Upon a second watch (this time with my mom and my cousin), I noticed something about the way Sunshine (Maris Racal) progresses in the film. She starts off as quiet. When she finds out she is pregnant, she only tells her boyfriend and her best friend. When she’s worried or angry, she conceals her emotions. She is held back. She is chained. As the film progresses, she slowly finds her footing, first through the infamous ‘basag windshield’ scene, and then through the numerous situations she finds herself stuck in. There is a scene near the end of the film. Sunshine is practicing her routine. She is emotional, and she’s made up her mind. As she ends her routine, the ribbon falls around her body, chaining her. She has a heartfelt conversation with ‘bata’ and she breaks free from her chains, which directly leads to the ending. Nothing is holding her back, she won’t settle for less, she has had enough.There is a scene in the film between Thea (Xyriel Manabat) and Sunshine. They are at a school canteen, eating separately from each other, but through their eyes, through the way they are looking at each other, you know that they are in support of one another. In a country that fails its women, they are forced to support each other in silence.Listening to my mom’s thoughts and reaction to Sunshine was the best part of my experience with this film. A woman who is somewhat religious, understanding why someone would want an abortion. An emphatic moment between my mom, me, and all the Sunshines in our country. The irony of watching a film entitled Sunshine during tag-ulan season is an irony that’s hard to look past, but I think this film couldn’t have come at a better time. We are settling for less. The streets are flooding, and the women in our country struggle to find the healthcare they deserve. We are chained and we are held back. When will we break free? When will we have enough? For all the Sunshines out theregets kita Sunshine, kakampi mo ako palagi.

"Sunshine" is one of the most important Filipino films of all time as it sheds light on the struggles of women in a conservative country that shames them for not embracing motherhood in any circumstance. It's a powerful story that teaches viewers about empathy, bravely tackling a sensitive topic about women's rights and the dangers women like Sunshine face when a country punishes them for making choices about their future instead of giving them the proper care and support they need.Director Antoinette Jadaone is a creative genius. She masterfully tells the story of "Sunshine" in a manner that opens hearts and minds. Hopefully, this movie achieves its dual purpose: To spark healthy conversations about women's health & rights and to encourage people to show kindness and understanding to the "Sunshines" of the world. Sana pagkatapos ng pelikula, mas marami ang magsasabi ng mga salitang: "gets ko na."Meanwhile, this outstanding story comes alive beautifully on screen also because of Maris Racal's strong performance. Maris slays as Sunshine especially in the quiet times she tries to mask her anxiety and appear calm when her reality is chaotic.Manifesting that this movie becomes the Philippines' entry to the 2026 Oscars.

I really admire Direk Tonet’s bravery. Sunshine was not just about the system failing women and their needs, but also tackles the sad reality that Filipinos are still entangled with the conservative and traditional principles they hold. It wasn’t just Sunshine who was being forced to adapt to the system, it was most of the women in Sunshine’s life. I love how the film was almost depicted like it was a horror movie. Unfortunately, it wasn’t a coincidence that I noticed this detail. It was meant to be like that—Manila being a horrible and disgusting place to live, day or night. With that being said, you couldn’t blame those who would draw parallels with Lino Brocka’s Maynila.I feel like each character was written purposely for each actor. The way Direk Tonet writes each character in her stories is always in detail and intentional. Lemme add this film to the ‘Haggard Maris Racal motion-picture’MARIS RACAL TRUTHER SINCE DAY 1!!!

Sunshine overflows with strong political commentary, dissecting how a society steeped in flawed systems, conservatism, and the double standards of religion and morality profoundly impacts our personal and rational choices.While some abrupt jumps between sequences occasionally pulled me out of the experience, the film was largely immersive. The casting is perfect, from Maris Racal as the titular lead, up to the pastor, whose towering arrogance embodies a patriarchal mindset, believing women are inherently reliant on men.The film allows us to fully realize the power of having a choice and making one in a world we wish were kind and harmonious. Antoinette Jadaone's best film to date, Sunshine is thought-provoking, yearning for a time when we can fully embrace and realize our choices once they're made.

The film doesn’t try to impress, it just tells the truth, and that’s what makes it hit. Sunshine had real depth, and her portrayal felt raw and grounded. The supporting characters did what they were meant to - help tell her story without stealing the spotlight.What stood out to me visually was how natural everything felt. The cinematography wasn’t overly stylized, but it matched the tone and mood perfectly. Set against the harsh backdrop of Manila, the film captured that mix of grit, morality, and religion in a way that felt all too real. It opens up an important conversation about sex education, teenage pregnancy, and abortion - topics we often shy away from, but ones that need to be talked about.More than anything, Sunshine shows how hard it is to be a woman in a world that’s stuck and unforgiving. It doesn’t scream its message, but it stays with you. If there really is such a thing as a “best,” this might just be one of Jadaone’s strongest works and definitely Maris Racal’s best performance yet.

Unflinchingly raw and emotional, the film captures the quiet defiance and inner turmoil of women who dare to pursue their dreams in a society that remains indifferent, or even hostile, to those who choose ambition over expectation and personal truth over misplaced morality.

We are in a limbo. So much of Philippine cinema, especially that which makes the rounds in local and international film festivals, is stuck churning out “groundbreaking” firsts. Because our cultural discourse is so behind, our filmmakers are tasked not only with telling stories, but also with inventing the stories to be told. They’re required to stake out new thematic ground, not in service of aesthetic evolution, but simply to keep up with the global conversation. The cost of this is a cinema that often feels overburdened with didactic intent and undernourished in emotional and formal rigor.In a particularly polarizing gesture, Jadaone introduces a hallucinated child character, a device that indirectly echoes Jojo Rabbit (2019). But this choice results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the film’s emotional center. What was perhaps intended as farce to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. It’s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the film’s pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old “when does life begin?” debate—a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesn’t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, literalizes it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. What’s more revealing than the film itself is the discourse surrounding it: a ubiquity of gender-essentialist and bioessentialist defenses, as if any critique of any form is automatically a threat to representation. That instinct: to guard a film’s cause rather than evaluate its craft just proves how far behind we are as a nation in talking about gender politics in filmmaking. The refusal to embrace genuinely revolutionary tactics, whether in politics or art, has kept us coasting on the optics of progress ever since.Full review for the Kinoise Substack published here

Sunshine isn't afraid to show what it truly means to be a woman in the modern world. In a society where your choices are often shamed, imposed, or forced into the very core of your identity, Sunshine remains steadfast in her decisions. We are too unforgiving towards women—too critical, too much of everything. And for a 19-year-old girl simply wanted to chase her dream, who are we to shame her for the choices she takes pride in?The film is heavy, filled with thrilling sequences and beautiful picturesque cinema that adds an insightful edge to its narrative. It doesn't shy away from the realities of living in Manila, where everything is muddy, dreary, and dried in irony. It reminded me at different tangents of Black Swan and Manila in the Claws of Light—a woman haunted by the consequences of her actions while navigating Manila's streets with weary kindness and understanding.All I can say is, "Gets ko na." Sobrang gets ko. Each of our choices is valid and every human experience is nuanced. Puno't dulo ng pelikula ay kababaihan, at sana mas marami pa makapanood nito.
Ang tunay na pelikula ay matapang.

In a country where a uterus can feel like a prison, Sunshine breaks through the silence with a scream.This is not just a film—it’s a rebellion against a system that punishes Filipinas for daring to survive.What a fearless and necessary filmz Sunshine dares to confront a brutal reality in a country where abortion remains illegal and where women’s rights are often reduced to whispers—silenced by false morality and systemic neglect.Antoinette Jadaone’s storytelling isn’t just intimate; it is a searing indictment of how the state and even the healthcare system fail Filipinas. This film reminds us that every choice a woman makes is shaped by power structures that shame her, control her body, and turn compassion into judgment. Through Sunshine’s journey, we see how being a woman in the Philippines means living in a constant struggle for autonomy—ang hirap maging babae, pero mas triple ang hirap ng mga babae dito sa Pilipinas.Sunshine is not just a movie; it is a mirror held up to a society that polices women’s bodies while abandoning them in their most vulnerable moments. It’s a rallying cry for the Sunshines, Theas, Helenas, Geleens, and Edens of this country—voices we must hear, stories we must protect.May this film be the turning point for our generation: progressive, pro-women, and unapologetically pro-choice.Thank you to the entire Sunshine team and SM Cinemas for making this powerful narrative accessible by lowering ticket prices. This is cinema with a purpose.

Maris Racal is astonishing as she gives a star-making performance in Antoinette Jadaone's finest film yet. Sunshine takes us by the hand in a bustling Quiapo that's full of hypocrisy, contradiction, and a brutal system on women and their bodies. It's a random odyssey of a woman trying to take back what is her's in an unforgiving conservative society. In the film's opening moments, we see an ambitious athlete confused and paralyzed with the news of her untimely pregnancy. She's scared and she's prolonging the agony of confronting the inevitable. One thing that some people may ask is, why doesn't she immediately ask anyone for help? Doesn't she have a family? Why is she trying to deal with such a serious problem on her own? Is this the society that we've grown into? Where a young woman is so afraid and paralyzed to get any help that she risks her life trying to deal with it on her own? The answer is a resounding YES. We are living in a country where dominant beliefs and religion are shoved down in women's throats even if it means giving up their dreams. Where young women are scorned and defined by their mistakes instead of being educated and getting a strong support system. Most egregiously, we live in a society that stigmatizes and punishes women but tolerates the very system, and actions that led to their unwanted pregnancies. That is the society that Jadaone perfectly paints in this harrowing film. Jadaone uses Quiapo as the backdrop to tell this story as she blends elements of neorealism and magic realism. This film has a great sense of place as Sunshine roams around a Quiapo that hides hypocrisy underneath its Catholic cathedral. Jadaone goes full Brocka mode through these scenes as she showcases different communities and people through a neorealist lens. That's why I found the film's surrealist tendencies to be a little bit jarring. Sunshine encounters a kid that appears only through her consciousness and it really makes you wonder if this type of storytelling fits the themes that Jadaone is exploring. It just runs the risk of making it too melodramatic and undercutting its authenticity. But what keeps it from going off the rails is her unwavering compassion and understanding of Sunshine's plight. Direk Tonet did mention in the Q&A session after that she swore that she was gonna hold Sunshine's hands and be by her side through every turbulence she'll face while writing this movie. In the film's third act, the neorealist and magic realist narratives just blend into a powerful, poignant, and profound moment while Sunshine practices her routine one last time. I think this is a film that our country desperately needs right now. It's bound to spark debates and fruitful discussions about abortion, reproductive health, and women's right. Some may disagree with what Sunshine ended up doing, but at least this is a film that ignites a discussion for these taboo topics. I will never know how it feels to be a woman in an unfairly conservative country. But this film rings with so much vitality, bravery, and honesty that I just cried by the end of it. This is so damn close to being a masterpiece. Gets ko na!

Maybe most ingenious about Sunshine is its willingness to accept the decision to abort likely also involves a negotiation with the unborn child, maybe even a plea for forgiveness—less from God, because getting that would be easy, and in fact Sunshine gets it out of the way early on, but more from who the child would have been. For the film indeed that is the longer battle, and it affords Sunshine a long array of events that could make the explaining easier. She sees her dilemma reflected in the city's decay, her choice—which she readily makes—put into perspective, rounded out, by another girl's inaccess to that choice. Very carefully, and backed by research, Jadaone dissects what that choice may mean for women like Sunshine in a developing city like Manila, where dreams are scarce and their fulfillment even rarer. Sunshine's choice is an act of self-determination, in a world where that's seen as vulgar, irreverent: that is clear. But to what should reverence be owed, in any case? Sunshine argues it's simply a matter of priority. When Sunshine chooses her dream—which she's been carrying in her womb longer than she's known her unborn child's ghost—we empathize with her, as does the ghost. That shows the film’s executed its heavy work.

If there’s anything that is uniquely Filipino in terms of interior design, it’s the green walls. It generally evokes feelings of tranquility and harmony, but Jadaone’s latest film flips it around to signify chaos and dysfunction. The color is almost everywhere, it’s inescapable: the walls of the protagonist’s home, the sterile and hostile clinic spaces, even the motel where the film’s lead almost died, comparable to the grip Catholicism has on the Philippines. While they say there’s a separation between the church and the state, it’s barely upheld in practice, as they hinder human rights that could save thousands of lives. And yes, I am talking about abortion laws, or the lack thereof here in my country. Jadaone’s Sunshine addresses the huge elephant in the senate, as it depicts the life of its titular lead (Maris Racal), whose life is turned upside down due to a sudden news of her own pregnancy. It’s easy to blame women like Sunshine for getting pregnant. After all, she’s presented as a domineering figure in her sport, even bound to compete in the Olympics, and she technically practiced unsafe sex, but not every case of unwanted pregnancy is like that.There are multiple shots where Sunshine is physically separated by a fence-like barrier: be it the metal gates in the church, the ever-stretching horizontal jeepney rails, or the cold and black window frames, that subtly signal how Filipinas are imprisoned by their surroundings. Almost every gratingly infuriating, thought-provoking, and ludicrous dialogue circles back to one simple question: why is it that women are the ones penalized and restricted on matters that could jeopardize their own health and safety, especially in pregnancies caused by rape and incest?While watching, I was constantly reminded of a film with similar thematic points, that of Hittman’s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, and how women need to be discreet, travel thousands of miles, and suffer in silence over matters that should be openly discussed and not considered taboo or immoral. If anything, I think this film is being highly censored in the Philippines, as the movie review board slapped an R-16 rating on a film that should be watched by teenagers. How can we avoid teenage pregnancies when our government avoids talking about practicing safe sex to the right demographic? Not everyone gets a happy conclusion like Sunshine did, so I hope that this film sparks a necessary conversation about women’s rights outside of the walls of movie theaters. Jadaone’s Sunshine is truly one of the Philippines’ best releases of the year so far, in both its themes and execution, and a must-watch for all types, especially men and the religious-alike. Written immediately after screening, Journal app, revised, and posted, July 25th. —SEE MORE:My Philippine Film Journal Entry Database – CLICK HERE.

We watched Sunshine yesterday, July 24, during the block screening at SM Megamall. I had seen the trailer beforehand, so I knew we were in for something bold, something necessary. But I wasn’t prepared for how deeply it would sit with me long after the credits rolled.I didn’t cry while watching the film, but once it ended, I found myself overwhelmed. The weight of Sunshine doesn’t hit all at once — it lingers, it settles. And it stays.At its core, Sunshine is the story of a woman taking control of her body in a society that keeps telling her she isn’t allowed to. It’s not simply about one choice, one moment, or one woman. It’s about the collective experience of many Filipinas who navigate a system that consistently fails to hear them.Antoinette Jadaone’s direction doesn’t shy away from discomfort. She faces it head-on, inviting the audience to confront the silences we’ve learned to live with - about abortion, reproductive rights, the stigma around sexuality, and the lack of access to informed sex education in the Philippines.Sunshine is timely, urgent, and painfully real. It gives voice to the cry of our generation, echoing the need for progressive reforms that protect women and children. The film challenges its viewers not just to empathize, but to act.As a viewer, I left the cinema not only moved, but also awakened. Sunshine isn’t here to entertain. It’s here to disturb, to provoke, and to push us into uncomfortable yet necessary conversations.To my fellow Filipinos: let’s not turn away. Let’s create spaces where women can speak freely, where choices about their bodies are met with compassion, not judgment. Let’s demand that our lawmakers stop treating reproductive health as taboo.To filmmakers and storytellers: keep telling these stories. We need more films like Sunshine—bold, unapologetic, and grounded in truth. The personal is political, and cinema has the power to move both heart and policy.Let Sunshine be a beginning. Let it be a spark. And let’s keep the conversation going.

Walang Sunshine sa mundong patas.Hindi ko mapigilang ihalintulad ang Maynilang ipinapakita ng Sunshine sa Maynila na kung saan nakilala si Lino Brocka. Amoy mo ang malamayang usok ng mga sasakyan at hindi mo na ito kailanman malabas sa iyong sistema. Mahapdi ang tirik ng araw sa balat. Ramdam mo ang pawis sa balikat ng bawat kasalubong na para bang ramdam mo na rin ang bitbit nilang bigat. Rinig mo ang ingay ng mga umiiyak na sanggol sa kapitbahay at pati ang nakabibinging busina ng tren na dumadaan sa Avenida. In a Quiapo churchyard, abortion pills are sold right across the “abortion is a sin” signages. In a cramped hospital, the doctor who preaches their kind and merciful God is the same one who will shame you until you are forced to say I’m sorry, God, repenting a thousand times not to a benevolent being, but to a woman in a coat. Four women, round bellies squeezing against each other, share only two small hospital beds. Hundreds more in that one tiny room, some whose dreams never saw the light of day. I’ve had two girls already. You’re so lucky that your child is a boy. The horrifying realization that 13 isn’t even the youngest of them.Hindi mabait ang mundo, at mas lalong hindi sayo mabait ang mundo kung babae ka. But sometimes, it takes just a sliver of warmth to remind you that you are not alone. The kind that comes from the ate sa botika who hands you a pregnancy test without judgement. The kind that comes from your best friend texting they love you right when you don’t know if you’re making the right choice. Or the kind that comes from the gentle caress of a young girl bleeding out, telling you she does not want to die in the back of a police car. How you can sense that the fear in her voice is also the one that crept up on you days before, as the motel lady put you in tricycle telling the driver to hurry to the hospital. I’ve always found the word “ate” to be a strong signifier of the tight the bonds between Filipina women. We may not know each other, but we know that we carry similar burdens. Call a woman ate and their heads turn with instinct. The film does not only show you the grim, unrelenting, cruel Manila that takes (and claws) more than it gives. Nor does it exclusively show you the girlhood that was stolen from you by the capitalistic and patriarchal structures so deeply embedded in society.Yes, it shows you that. It does not hold back from showing you how tiresome it is to clean the poo of a newborn or how much more easy it is to find empathy in illegal markets than it is in public institutions. Yet, what it also shows you is that whenever you feel like a lone speck of light in the dark, just call an ate. Ask them for help. Rest on their shoulders. You are all each of you has. The film itself does its job of telling an important story beautifully. One of the key narrative devices may be a bit too on the nose for some viewers, but I find that it adds a sort of tangibility and gravity to the story that otherwise would have been missing some heart and soul without it. Tonet’s directing is sharp and focused on such visceral and visual contradictions. Racal is bursting with passion and rage…vulnerable…and stellar. Everyone from her coach and older sister down to the younger kids our titular character meets held so much weight in their portrayals. Noong pinapanood ko, ang nasa isip ko, tunay na tao ‘tong mga pinapanood ko. Walang Sunshine sa mundong patas. Ngunit, hindi patas ang mundo natin. Kaya mabuti nalang at may pelikulang ganito (in a country where abortion is illegal, at that). Mabuti nalang na sa bawat lalaking kagaya ni Miggy at Bobot na nagdidesisyon para sa buhay ng kababaihan, may mga katulad ni Sunshine na hindi takot i-reclaim ang kababaihan niya. Walang sino man ang makakapagdikta kung ano ang pagiging babae para sa atin. Higit tayo sa mga desisyong pinili para sa atin.Pangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, Sunshine.

At sa mga pelikula ni Direk @tonetjadaone, ramdam na ramdam ko 'yan!I’ve recently been staying in Manila for a few months now. Bakit? Nanay ba kita? Gut-wrenching and brave, Sunshine speaks truth with honesty and feminine rage in a heartbreaking story of womanhood, a character study that puts a young woman, an aspiring Olympian in the most harrowing ordeal — pursue her dreams or let go of it, continue her pregnancy or terminate it. In a country where traditions and conservatism plague our sociopolitical landscape, and at a time where the world at large is being corrupted by right-wing fundamentalists, Sunshine stands with a strong pro-choice message; that women should have the rights to bodily autonomy despite the patriarchal structures that harp on religious preachings in which our women have to pay social costs or worse, their own lives and safety. At the center of it is Sunshine, played by the brilliant Maris Racal whose tenacious yet delicate character work put so much layers to a heartfelt protagonist. In the first 10 minutes alone, Racal delivered a string of unbridled emotions, from being flushed with regret, anger and desperation, she grew with intensity, defiance and vulnerability. Her resolve is one of strength and a moving emotional core that’s unshakeable while being present in every turn in Sunshine’s dilemma in which we met the most colorful and textured cast of unusual characters. Even with Racal’s stellar lead performance, every supporting actor also put on a remarkable stamp that not only served their scenes but also the entire story. From Jennica Garcia to Annika Co to Elijah Canlas to Meryl Soriano to Xyriel Manabat to Angeli Bayani to Rhed Bustamante to Piolo Pascual, it’s perfectly casted and Jadaone made sure that they deliver a well-calibrated turn for Sunshine’s story. A chilling and entrancing dissection of womanhood, the film shifts gears as a sports movie to a melodrama injected with some satire, absurdity, and a mystical element, it’s full of inspired creative choices that are in full concerto. With its spectacular cinematography and production design from drab and somber interiors with a hint of natural light or sometimes depressing fluorescent light, to neon-tinged urban areas where chaos lingers just around the corner while also capturing Sunshine’s extraordinary close-ups behind window railings that cage her or framed by her vibrant pink ribbon; its outstanding sound design that puts Sunshine’s inner turmoil at the center of a noisy Manila and blends a surrealist element to its heart; and a formidable original music that juxtaposes Sunshine’s personality from her life as an gymnast to her personal life. Sunshine is an urgent film that needs to be seen and heard, there’s power in its universality and Tonet Jadaone’s feminist voice soars with an elevated storytelling. Beaming with Filipino sensibilities and humour, its melodrama is used with beautiful intent while being grounded and playing with raw emotional reactions from the cast, and levity and grit in its screenplay. And as cliche as it sounds, it’s a totally different Jadaone that made this movie. There’s maturity that put her titular character at the center of a well-crafted film but there’s this restraint we haven’t seen before that refined the story’s message without ever being didactic. Undoubtedly, her best film yet, an opus that cements her place as an important voice in Philippine cinema but also a landmark film that tackles subject matters that only a handful of Filipino filmmakers have touched on. An absolute achievement in today’s climate of Filipino cinema, there’s power in its tone and its themes — a protest that exposes controlling hypocritical men and medical professionals, and an interrogation of a systemic inequality full of government’s shortcomings in giving proper care and support for unwanted pregnancies, in a place where poverty and overpopulation have been a decade-long problem. But also in Sunshine, we found hope and her light in confronting her reality while finding women who helped and listened to her, a kind of feminism that celebrates sisterhood even in the most horrifying circumstance in a woman’s life. With high hopes, this should spark a conversation about women’s struggles and rights. In light of the overturning of Roe v Wade in the US, akin to Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Sunshine’s story is real and rampant in the PH, and as disturbing as it sounds, unsafe abortion have been killing 1 in 3 Filipinas each day. —————This reminded me of a podcast conversation I once listened to about a woman talking to her mother at a time she’s getting to know her more as an adult. She’s learning about her mom’s history and asked her if her mother ever wondered about living that life instead of having her. Of course the mother responded that she’s happy that she’s born and she’s her child. To which she replied with, “if I didn’t happen, YOU would have been born.”I think motherhood is beautiful but do you ever wonder what kind of woman your mother would have been if society gave them the rights to choose or their religion didn’t make them to aspire to fit into a mold of a woman? Maybe she could have been a president or she could have invented the cure to HIV/AIDS? Who knows?
that inn room scene ... SHET

Too often, films about abortion fall into the trap of emotional manipulation, when they push a specific agenda, reducing a complex issue to a simplistic, black-and-white narrative. But Sunshine rises above that pattern.Instead, the film offers a nuanced portrayal of the struggles (and even rage) experienced by women who are denied access to reproductive healthcare - told with such compassion and delicacy that you cannot help but empathize with and root for Sunshine because the conservative society has failed her. I hope many people get to watch the film because it is both a deeply personal and universal story that casts a light on one of the most pressing crises in the country: teenage pregnancy. And I also hope Sunshine ushers in a healthy and open conversation because women deserve the right to make decisions for themselves. This is the kind of film I’ll be thinking for days kasi ang bigat pero napaka-cathartic panoorin. And it features a talented (and reliable) ensemble of actors - napakahuhusay ng lahat, lalo na ng mga kababaihan.

I'm seeing posts on Reddit from people who have been through some of the same or similar situations. I hope it keeps people talking until the things that need changing finally change for the better.Beautiful work. Powerful message.Thank you for telling these stories.

Direk Tonet Jadaone holds a mirror up in the middle of Quiapo and asks the question: what is the proper protocol to take control of your life? Does the prayer come before or after the abortifacient? Does the boyfriend have to take it too? Sunshine, as a film and as a character, is bold and unwavering. She doesn't preach or ask for pity. She doesn't beg for the forgiveness of her boyfriend or the religious. The story is clear all through out -- Sunshine has made her decision, and while she seeks understanding, she seeks it only from those who matter, not from the audience and definitely not from the holier-than-thou.While Sunshine embarks on her journey to find answers, we never forget what she is -- a young girl in the Philippines, left to deal with the consequences of an unplanned pregnancy alone. It is so easy to put the blame on women or on impulsive, lustful teenagers, but the film reminds us that in a country where religious biases trump teenage pregnancy and maternal mortality rates, pointing fingers helps no one. The film reminds us that for women and other marginalized sectors, the first line of defense against systemic neglect is community.Brave and unfiltered, I can easily see Sunshine becoming a Filipino classic. What a beautifully written, directed, and acted film. This is Direk Tonet's best so far, and definitely a career-defining performance for Maris Racal. Gets ko na. Gets na gets.

Heavy raindrops were like meteorites landing on the pockmarked pavements of Manila when we braved two storms to catch the screening of Sunshine. Our tuktuk carried only three passengers: me, my partner, and another man—seven people short of the usual full ride as it had been a week of rain with flooding which meant classes and government work were cancelled. When it rained harder, our driver couldn’t help but mutter Tama na. Gutom na kami.It’s hunger borne out of poverty that limits, if not entirely removes, the access of ordinary Filipinos to watch important films such as Sunshine. Like any other works of art attempting to feature parts and parcels of Philippine society, etched on its tapestry is the signature Manila mayhem: masikip, mabaho, maingay and magulo.But the structure of the film is far from chaotic despite the complicated and challenging subject Direk Antoinette Jadaone took upon herself to flesh out. The stakes were high and indeed pushed the protagonist to do what she thought needs to be done. Her point was clear and warranted no further elaboration. Maris Racal was stellar in her portrayal of an aspiring Olympian who got pregnant at the blossoming of her career as a young athlete. The same can be said about the equally astounding young actress Annika Co who was a perfect foil to Racal’s character.The film, with its shorter than usual run time of barely an hour and a half minutes, didn’t hold back in driving its message, leaving nothing open for interpretation. Towards the end where Sunshine was performing her routine, I thought for a moment that her beaming towards the camera with her majestic ribbon would be the final shot of the film. But when the young Annika was shown watching Sunshine finish gracefully finishing her performance and embracing her when it ended, that was when I realized, gets ko na, that in this narrative, she would have a choice, one that's entirely her own.Direk Tonet has managed to make such a compact film about choice. While choice for women is such a privilege in a conservative country like ours, there’s something powerful in showing that Sunshine made a choice, one that goes against the conventional. While other films of the same topic would leave it to the audience to ponder whether or not the protagonist would choose the controversial choice, Sunshine showed us that yes, she did that!After the end credits have rolled, we were left staring at the black screen, perhaps, feeling fulfilled, weighed upon, or hungrier than ever for films of the same caliber. Sunshine is so monumental for Philippine cinema that it reaffirms one of my aspirations, that one day, Filipinos can have the choice about what films to watch in the cinema every weekend, not choose just either one—satisfying their physiological hunger or fulfilling the hunger of the soul.

“GETS KO NA.”First things first, thank you Direk Antoinette Jadaone for being so brave. Our country badly needs films that dare to confront the cries and injustices our society (esp women) continue to face. Sunshine is a soft, aching plea for change. It’s a quiet but urgent cry for body autonomy, for choice, for justice. And it’s not just about one woman’s pain — it’s rooted in something deeper: a system that has long failed us, most esp women, in this country.

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine begins with control. With poise, with the perfect arabesque, and with the precision of a gymnast that is ready for the next move. But as the film moves along, the tension in the stillness builds up and begins to show. Behind the clean flow and rhythm of theribbon, the rehearsed elegance of the body is still pushed to their limit. Sunshine feels like a cruel misdirection, but the contrast is exactly the point that womanhood needs.In a country where abortion is still illegal without exceptions, Sunshine doesn’t just tell the story of a young woman’s crisis. It captures a quiet violence of expectation, the pressure to remain graceful even when they are under a system that does not allow women to fail, to choose, or even to speak freely. In the Philippines, the Revised Penal Code punishes abortion with imprisonment, while access to safe and legal procedures remains out of reach for most women, especially those who are young and unfortunate. Punishment because of abortion with imprisonment, and this legal stance is reinforced by deeply rooted religious conservatism. It is not just illegal—it is unthinkable. The stigma runs deep, and the silence surrounding it is even deeper.According to the Center for Reproductive Rights (2023), thousands of women are forced into this silence every year. Estimated around 1.1 million Filipino women induce abortion annually. About 1,000 of Filipinas die each year from abortion-related complications, and over 100,000are hospitalized due to unsafe procedures. These numbers are not just statistics, they are lives of the young, scared, and the unheard. Sunshine puts that reality front and center, but does so without shouting. It doesn’t force emotion, it lets it build naturally. This film follows Sunshine as she navigates through the aftermath of a missed period, a distracted boyfriend, and a society that offers no legal, safe, or accessible options. She’s left to carry the weight of a decision she didn’t choose, in a system that treats her body like public property.Sunshine (played by Maris Racal) is a kind character with stillness that feels like a resistance. Her performance is tight, contained, and filled with the kind of fear that is quiet and does not seek and beg for sympathy. A character with a facade that represents many generations of women where they mask all of their feelings and hold on to the thought that “this too shall pass”.She is not trying to explain herself, she is simply trying to breathe and move in a world that keeps on closing in. Racal does not rely on big breakdowns or dramatic lines. She holds her ground even when that ground is crumbling beneath her. Every look, every breath, feels calibrated. Like someone preparing for a landing they know they might not even survive. What makes the performance even more powerful is how familiar Sunshine feels. She is notwritten as an extraordinary character. She is a regular young woman, navigating school, relationships, and the uncertainty of early adulthood. She could be any girl from any province, any city, any university. That ordinariness is important. Because it reminds us that this story isnot rare. It is not fiction. It is the quiet, constant reality of so many young women in this country who are forced to navigate the consequences of a decision they didn’t even get to make.Jadaone doesn’t push for spectacle. The film sits with silence and discomfort. No overdramatization and overexplanation. Her braveness has a place in Philippine Cinema as this take and storytelling of hers about abortion in a world where systems and institutions are fallingshort, the quiet resistance of Sunshine speaks volume. Instead of turning the film into a message movie, Jadaone chooses to linger. She doesn’t try to solve anything. She doesn’t pretend that resolution is possible. And that’s what makes Sunshine hit even harder. The film doesn’t just show the problem, it lets us sit in it. It allows discomfort to stretch across the screen without rushing to ease it. That discomfort mirrors what many women feel in real life. The shame. The fear. The confusion. The silence that comes not from peace, but from pressure.It also explores the feelings through visuals. Pao Orendain, the Cinematographer of the film captures the feel of the City of Manila. How it is familiar inside the streets, but also how suffocating it is. The noise pollution that is made by the vehicles, the streets filled with conversations, and the trains rattling as it passes by. The way they captured it, Manila is just another place where it forces the characters to move carefully, just like any other people who lives, visits, and goes to Manila to reclaim life. The streets hum with life, but not always with warmth. The camera observes from a distance, never forcing perspective but always aware of the space Sunshine must navigate.What makes Sunshine stand out is that it never asks permission to tell this story. It does not frame abortion as a debate, or as an issue that needs to be justified. It centers the experience without apology. In doing so, it offers a kind of cinematic resistance that feels rare in Philippine cinema. Jadaone’s choice to tell this story without moralizing, without preaching, without forcing catharsis, gives it more weight than any dramatic scene ever could.And in a country that still debates whether women should have that right, Sunshine lands, not perfectly, but with all the force of someone who has had enough. Someone who knows she deserves more. And that is enough to shake the ground beneath her, even if no one else is watching. Like a gymnast mid-tumble, it shows how much strength it takes just to survive a fall.And sometimes, survival is the bravest routine of all.Gets na gets kita, Sunshine.

This review features some spoilers.In local cinema, as with mainstream media, there’s a dearth of films tackling abortion. 12 Weeks, Anna Isabelle Matutina’s Cinemalaya feature debut, was the latest attempt I could recall, or at least one that had something useful to say. At the same time, a comprehensive sexuality education integrated at all education levels (separate from the education department’s sex ed order), as proposed in the anti-teenage pregnancy bill, has been under fire from the country’s conservative population.Into this frantic context emerges Sunshine, the latest indie darling from writer-director Antoinette Jadaone. The sole Philippine entry in the Centrepiece section of the 2024 Toronto International Film Festival, the film finally comes home. It’s making its local premiere exclusively at SM cinemas, after touring the international film fest circuit to critical renown, including the Crystal Bear for Best Film at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival.But make no mistake, as the picture refuses to be singled out as an “abortion film,” a descriptor so sweeping and limiting that it is seen only vis-à-vis morality. Jadaone finds new ammo with which to make sense of the polarizing topic: gymnastics. (The film’s TIFF world premiere, in fact, came at the heels of gymnast Carlos Yulo’s double Olympic gold in Paris.)The sports drama unfolds through the title character, played by Maris Racal, a young gymnast whose preparation for national tryouts is upended after discovering she’s pregnant. Refusing to compromise her shot at Olympic glory, with her useless boyfriend (Elijah Canlas) almost instantly ditching her, Sunshine resorts to illegal abortifacients offered by Manila’s underbelly, where she runs into an enigmatic young girl (Annika Go) bent on tracking her every move and policing her every decision. Soon, she internalizes biblical shame.Sunshine follows Jadaone’s feminist inclinations. Her directorial debut Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay (2011), is a raw mockumentary that doubles as a compelling paean to the titular screen bit actress, whose name is nearly synonymous with Philippine horror but has largely remained underappreciated. In Never Not Love You (2018), Nadine Lustre’s Joanne is a breadwinner who trades a long-awaited job promotion in Manila for a fraught chance to begin anew and dream together with her privileged boyfriend in London, only to wrestle with the punishing economics of romance. Fan Girl (2020) explores the dark side of being a superfan through a female character who’s a proxy for the film’s articulation about the psychology of idle worship in a nation forever beholden to it.Shortcomings of these movies aside, Jadaone insists on narratives that do not treat and present the female gaze as though it’s self-explanatory. The director often edges toward gray areas and destabilizing standpoints, whether or not they wind up humorous, fascinating, schmaltzy, or troubling.Whereas Jadaone’s previous movies are attuned to the conventions of their respective genres, Sunshine offers something new to the director’s dramaturgical defaults. The film is an intersection of neorealism and magical realism. It trains the camera on Manila’s grime, decay, and nonstop noise, embracing its outcasts and harsh truths (the Lino Brocka comparisons are inevitable), just as it punctuates the gritty reality with a magical invocation via the imaginary friend that trails Sunshine.“Media literacy” would tell you that the spectral presence is a representation of the internal-external friction the heroine deals with; fetus in the flesh and the body that refuses to carry it; the back-and-forth between morality and pragmatism. (Jadaone, in an interview with Filmmaker Magazine, revealed she was inspired by the imaginary character in Taika Waititi’s 2019 satirical drama Jojo Rabbit.) But beyond this, the make-believe figure is a surrogate for the conservative, pro-life fraction of the audience, with the director opting to engage in the subject matter’s complexity instead of comfortably locating the film in an echo chamber. While the narrative device could prove as an apparent play at sympathy, indulging in a “will she, won’t she” kind of thinking (surface-level reading could also suggest that women seeking abortion are deluded, ridiculous as that implication might sound), it also offers access to the broader violence disguised as “conscience” that puts women, regardless of gender identities, at a disadvantage.If anything, Sunshine is less about the act of abortion itself than about the systems that encourage women to settle for dehumanizing rights already decided for them by a patriarchal few, systems that prohibit them from dreaming, and tell them that to dream only means more labor, nothing more.Sunshine, like Petersen Vargas’ Some Nights I Feel Like Walking (which made its Philippine premiere in June), harnesses the metropolis as a character of its own, instead of reducing it to a mere symbolic backdrop. Whereas Some Nights steeps its urban tale in neon erotica, completely absent of daylight, Sunshine shifts between the city’s diurnal and nocturnal environments.Pao Orendain’s camerawork here chiefly reaps magic from close-ups and interior shots, often framed from the window and dotted by a shaft of light (hence the Brocka sentiments), locating the viewer into the heroine’s intimate yet anxious state. The self-induced abortion scene in the sketchy motel, a sight casually interrupted by frantic railway noise, is particularly visceral that you can almost feel the texture of the image.The camera also draws focus to the irony that permeates Manila’s streets, particularly around the vicinity of Quiapo Church, where makeshift stalls selling figurines, scapulars, and all sorts of religious paraphernalia also offer abortion drugs and quack treatments, just as banners declaring “abortion is murder” remain a typical sighting. In other scenes where Sunshine traverses the cityscape, the visuals are more straightforward. Accompanying the images is a soundscape that immersively mirrors the congestion, exhaustion, and urban din that form part of the DNA of the country’s capital.Jadaone’s script nearly leans on the miserablist. When Sunshine finds an opportunity to pull herself out of the vexing situation, poverty immediately gets in the way, leaving her with no choice but to ask her boyfriend for a meager P5,000 to secure the abortion drug and a cheap motel room to perform the deed herself. Yet even in Manila’s hospitals, the conditions are dire; patients are forced to share beds, and hallways are turned into makeshift wards, crowded by people in need of attention beyond the medical. Rape and casual prostitution also get in the way, as in the case of Menggay (Rhed Bustamante), the pregnant 13-year-old Sunshine comes across in Quiapo.In a highlight moment, Sunshine, livid upon meeting her friend’s abuser, suddenly picks up a beer bottle and whacks it over the man’s head, before sprinting to escape the scene. (Curiously, Jadaone plumbs the politics of self-determination by contrasting Sunshine’s ability to decide for herself with Menggay’s distance from that very sense of agency.) Even the Quiapo vendors selling abortifacients, who some might think merely exploit the desperation of their customers, are also victims who simply don’t earn enough.Unflattering as these depictions are, it’s hard to deny that these aren’t routine realities in the social inferno that is the Philippines. Still, there is humor, whether in a scene that involves a knife interrupting a silly argument, or in another that sees a self-righteous doctor preaching the goodness of the divine.As Sunshine, Racal delivers a performance that would be a disservice to reduce to neat superlatives. It’s a physical portrayal that required the actor to undergo training with national gymnastics coaches for nearly a year. It’s a role that might put her in the center of another controversy after barely surviving the previous one. But just as Sunshine is asked to “drown out the noise” whenever she steps on the mat, Racal distills every layer and emotion into a character that’s simply life-like, almost free from the veil of performance-making. Jadaone once told me that her ideal lead performance is one that “is part of something bigger than herself.” There has not been a more worthy portrayal in local cinema this year.At the same time, the movie functions as a reintroduction to the boundless talent of Jennica Garcia, who plays Sunshine’s elder sister, a single mother trying to keep everything intact. Her portrayal expertly captures what a supporting performance should be—one that has enough screentime to be an emotional anchor for the lead but also generates her own moment. There’s a kind of invisible labor informing the character that Garcia encapsulates with an onscreen presence that always feels grounded and never incidental.Sunshine is hardly a social exposé. What ripples throughout this partly winding urban tale is a ready, fatal fact about the place of women in this eternally eroded nation that we’d rather dismiss as “controversial” or “divisive” because we refuse to listen. The film’s visuals might be artful, but they don’t always convey a pretty picture. It’s no coincidence that the movie’s narrative throughline is the community that Sunshine finds in the women around her: her elder sister, her best friend (Xyriel Manabat), despite her initial inhibitions, her coach (Meryll Soriano), the young Menggay, the compassionate doctor (Angeli Bayani), and even the imaginary friend. Though this sense of solidarity comes at varying degrees, it keeps Sunshine afloat and does not let her think of herself as a monster for terminating an unwanted pregnancy.Once Sunshine nears its final shot, I keep thinking of Fan Girl’s insular ending that succeeds its heroine’s already exhausting journey. I’m glad to learn that our heroine this time does not succumb to sheer epiphany. Here, hope actually feels like a tangible possibility instead of an unwarranted emotional wallop.Sunshine is perhaps not Jadaone’s most definitive work; That Thing Called Tadhana (2014) or Never Not Love You might claim that distinction. But it is her sharpest creation yet. It took a whole lot of research and lived experiences to put this story on the screen. It took a bit of time for the film to make its way back to where it started. It’s a miracle that it even got the go signal to be screened publicly. I can already sense all the hot takes and thinkpieces it will generate. And I can only hope that it will be as meaningful as this.This review appears on PhilSTAR Life in a slightly different version.

Last year, I saw High School Scandal. Both films share the same throughline that Philippine health care sucks when it comes to pregnancy and sex education. High School Scandal was made in the 80s. The difference being is that Sunshine made me feel hopeful, while High School Scandal made me feel depressed.Here's the thing. Sunshine is a very heavy film, but what makes Sunshine such a heartlifting film to watch is that she had the proper support system whether she decides to keep the child or not. She gets to choose if she wants to carry the baby or not. She has a sister that cares about her well being, a best friend who will do everything for her, and strangely enough, a manifestation of what her child will be. The film shows that women should at the end of the day, have the final choice in matters related to childbirth.Oh and with heavy topic such as this, let women be the major voice in the storytelling. Maris Racal is a powerhouse actress. Antoinette Jadoane is a great writer and director and deserves all the praise in handling such a tough topic.

“Gets ko na.”In this film, we follow Sunshine, a rhythmic gymnast and an Olympic hopeful, as she travels through Manila’s dark, narrow, grimy, and crowded streets and alleys in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal. There are few parts of this film that really stood out to me because they made elevated the movie and made it more compelling.The first part that I really liked is how the city became a living representation of this country’s oppressive stance against anything pro-abortion. The city allowed us to have something tangible, to be able to relate to Sunshine’s struggles even more. Second, the magical realism aspect is also a highlight for me. Once it finally clicked what Ariana and Annika Co’s characters represented, I was blown away. One common argument of those against abortion is that you are going to kill someone who’s probably gonna be a very important person. And yet, we get Annika Co’s character. Through a very powerful performance we end up caring for this kid. But once you start to realize who she us and who she represents, you start to realize that she’s not just an extension of Sunshine but a representative of all babies born to mothers forced to carry a child. She and these babies are vessels forced to carry the unfulfilled dreams of their mothers. She said something like, “Ang pangarap niya ay ang pangarap ko.” And that line broke me. The argument is always, “We are not fulfilling someone’s potential if we abort them.” but there’s always a failure to acknowledge that forcing someone to bear a child is also not allowing them to fulfill their potential.The last part that stood out to me is Maris Racal’s great performance. She is the movie. Without that performance, this film will fall apart and she delivers. What this film did is humanize a debate that’s usually so contentious it ends up being too one dimensional. It made the debate more accessible to every one. The movie is unflinching and raw. A harsh criticism of a society and culture who despite being always proud of their women, continues to fail them by continuing to enabling oppressive systems that mostly targets women. A big middle finger to a society that still strongly reeks of misogyny. It also an exploration of the country’s broken healthcare system. This film is a celebration of female friendships and sisterhood. The people who helped Sunshine in her journey are women. It forces you to be uncomfortable. It forces you to think and have empathy. This film is highly relevant and should be a required watching for everyone. Probably one of the most important Filipino films ever made. Hope it gets an even wider release.

we meet sunshine through her battle of being an olympian. armored by her well-worn asian games shirt and her head held high, she shines the brightest among her peers who also look up to her and what more she can become. her coach knows this too, along with her family and lifelong friend, who would all do everything to make sure she achieves them.perhaps its in the nuance of a story that is deeply feminist and human, but antoinette's jadaone's sunshine is the strongest in its ability to capture the realities of adolescent pregnancy with both gentleness and fierce. portraying (albeit sometimes preaching about, but deservingly so) the world of a filipina girl navigating the weight of expectations and the silence surrounding sexual and reproductive health, the story unfolds as a reflection of what we lack and suffer from. this flaw persists in the lesson of consent that was never taught, contraception never offered, the judgment of clinical service providers, the terrifying possibility of dying alone, and the unbearable strength it takes to push forward anyway, not because you’re fearless, but because you must. as a youth. as a woman. as a human with dreams and rights.the reality today is rough: the philippine government failed to pass its version of the adolescent pregnancy prevention bill in the recent senate, the current curriculum and implementation of the comprehensive sexuality education is in question, and more and more right-wing (ish) groups are mobilizing their funds to hinder the fight even more. but hopefully, with these kind of films made accessible to the public, we will be reminded that abortion happens not just because teenagers are risky or that they have been abuse hence it's justified, but because they have the right to decide for themselves.after all, sunshine's every step and every twirl, carries not just her own hope, but the collective dreams of those who raised her, and fought for her to have this. and in watching her take the mat, we are reminded of every girl who dreams of olympic gold, of becoming president, of curing AIDS, and how urgent it is that we believe in them first before some blob of blood. that we talk to them about things that matter. that we care.because when we do, they shine.

A film full of images of ironies: The jeepney with God’s Gift sign, the abortifacients sold next to religious figures, sunshine being named one when her life seemed to be dark, and words of encouragement that made the burden heavier. In a country that is driven by morals, Sunshine begs to question and reassess our morales. What is moral? What is acceptable? Are we accountable? Aside from ourselves, who are accountable?Strong performances and storytelling, Jadaone and Racal hits a homerun.

In a country where abortion remains criminalized, Sunshine is both a risk and a revelation. It speaks directly to the young women whose stories are erased, stigmatized, or left in the shadows. It exposes the hypocrisy of a system that forces women to choose between their futures and their autonomy, between silence and survival.This film does not simply ask whether abortion is right or wrong, it asks us why we’ve made it so dangerous to even ask the question.Decriminalize abortion now!!!!!!!

Time and time again watching films and sharing my appreciation for the art form always felt one-dimensional. But there was a gut feeling that Sunshine was gonna be different.Watching this with my religious mom, laughing through the hypocrisies of it all and finally tearing up toward its third act felt intriguing. As we walked down to a nearby coffee shop, she shared her miscarriage story; she was just as scared as Sunshine, a story on what-ifs and what could’ve been, a thought they both pondered on.This time my mom didn’t.She went for her thirdAnd gave birth to whomshe’s sharing the story to.The comparisons with Brocka aren’t an exaggeration. Sunshine is arguably direk Tonet’s best and most important piece, bar none.Watch in theaters while it’s out.

“Gets ko na.”Madalas, hindi pinapakinggan ang kababaihan sa lipunan, kasingingay ng mga busina ngunit pilit pa ring hindi pinapansin katulad ng mga namamalimos sa kalye. “Drown out the noise,” ika nga ng coach ni Sunshine. Gayunpaman, salamat sa mga pelikulang kagaya nito ay nabibigyan sila ng boses. Ito na yata ang isa sa pinakapaborito kong pelikulang napanood ko ngayong taon. Sa mahusay na direksyon ni Direk Tonet ay naipakita ang lahat ng lungkot, saya, at galit ng istorya. Sa tulong din ng iba pang aktor ay mas nagningning ang performance ni Maris Racal bilang Sunshine. Bawat ngiti, sigaw, at iyak ay ramdam ng lahat ng manonood at siguradong dadalhin din nila ito paglabas ng sinehan.Marami pang Sunshine na hindi nabibigyan ng boses at sana sa pagkakataong makasalamuha natin sila, tayo naman ang maka-gets.Makinig. Umintindi. Umanawa.

Gets ko na, sana gets na din ng iba Five hours later, and I’m still thinking about it. Hindi ko pa rin alam kung galit ba ako o masaya para sa kanya. Parang may kurot sa dibdib na hindi mo maipaliwanag. That’s the kind of effect this film has—it stays with you, makes you uncomfortable in all the necessary ways, and forces you to confront questions we often avoid. Ganito dapat ang pelikula—hindi lang basta kwento, kundi karanasan. Something real, something that makes you feel and, more importantly, makes you think.

sobrang totoo at #danas yung pagganap ng mga aktor at lente ni jadaone rito. lapat sa reyalidad ng pagiging babaeng pilipinong maralita yung pelikula at pinaka nagustuhan ko na hindi lang ito nagmitsa ng simula ng diskurso tungkol sa reproductive health ng kababaihan at usapin ng legalidad at moralidad ng aborsyon sa bansa, tumindig ito— sa katauhan ng bata, ni menggay, ni dra. helen, ni geleen, at ni sunshine.para sa'kin, doon mo lang makikita yung pananda na nagtagumpay yung layunin ng ganitong uri ng pelukula e. hindi sapat na ibato mo lang yung tanong o ilatag sa mga manonood yung hamon na bumoses sa isyung tikom ang karamihan. gustong gusto ko na sa huli, pinili ni sunshine yung pangarap niya at nang maabot niya yung buo at perpektong routine para sa qualifiers, tahimik at walang script yung eksena pero doon ko pinaka rinig na rinig yung puso ni niya. takot, ngunit buo ang loob, at napaka tapang ni sunshine hanggang sa huling segundo ng pelikula. para sa'kin, sobrang halaga na ipakita kung gaano kalaking bahagi ng buhay ng kababaihan yung nakasugal sa tuwing nalalagay sa panganib ng unwanted pregnancy. at yung suporta mula, unang una, sa pamilya, at higit, mula sa gobyerno— upang matamasa ng mga menggay at sunshine ng bansa yung kaligtasan at pagkakataon na mabuhay nang para sa sarili at pangarap—ay hindi dapat ipanawagan kundi ipagkaloob nang kusa at maging mandato.kitang kita ko yung paglago ni maris racal bilang aktor dito. iba rin ang kinang ni jennica garcia at annica co, sobrang deserve na makita pa sa mas maraming proyekto.

“drown out the noise”and yet, no matter how hard Sunshine tries to ignore these noises, what she endures is a different kind of restraint, pain, and mess—the kind she can’t forcibly silence, even if she tries.hindi ako babae, pero gets ko si Sunshine. it’s been so long since a film has impacted and triggered something in me. to a point where a line gets stuck in your head. kumbaga sa kanta, na-lss ako sa linyang ‘to ni Coach Eden.without a doubt, Sunshine holds a special place in my heart. maybe it’s because of how timely and relevant its message is, or because of Maris Racal’s powerful performance, or how it portrays the real noise and mess of Manila. i don’t know. but, what i do know is that i am deeply in love with this film, and i’ll never get tired of talking about it. imagine, from the moment i first saw the trailer last year, to the moment i’m writing this review, i’ve loved sunshine. i’ve loved all the people in charge of making it. and i’ve loved Direk Tonet even more.Ang Husay Husay Husay.

Sunshine is a victim of her poor choice. She is a victim to the patriarchal system of the country. It perfectly encapsulates the intersectionality of being impoverished and a woman in the predominantly catholic setting. It is a bold statement to the cruel realities women face, especially the ones at the bottom. She is caged by the system. Jadaone has given justice in telling the plight women face.Sunshine’s character is imperfect and flawed, but real which makes you root for her character. This was emphasized by the camerawork which maintains a certain intimacy with the character that makes you see Sunshine’s vulnerability. Racal portrayal of Sunshine makes you want to empathize with the character because amidst of all the imperfections, there is this young dreamer. Her poor decisions are the consequence of the society she exists in, wherein there is no other choice— leaving her to opt for desperate methods.This film is so personal bilang isang babae.
