Wow. Galing. Pinagisipan. It reminds me, yet again, of the society we live in. In this film, just like any other woman, Sunshine is a sunshine of her own—a woman with dreams, goals and stories to tell. A story that is too scary to talk, yet need to be heard and seen. I hope this film will not just become a story of its own, but a way for us to be strong enough to discuss these kinds of issues.

Sunshine Is Every Woman Who Dreams Beyond Her CircumstancesSunshine was not created for the sake of making a statement, nor just triggering a conversation; it was meant to make people feel and understand why abortion happens and how our current system makes them dangerous for women. Sunshine did not need to be pitied or root for, she needed to be understood.The film opens and immediately solidifies Sunshine’s ambition. It is anchored on Sunshine’s eagerness to excel, to achieve, to succeed, to be the best, to be an Olympian. And this ambition is not going anywhere. With every tiptoe that Sunshine stands on—as she throws her pink ribbons and gives in to impulse—she stands tall again, catching the ribbons as if they were always meant to fall in the right places… until they don't. Sunshine’s perfect harmony gets disturbed by her sudden realization that she is pregnant. Antoinette Jadaone’s intentional direction on making some scenes too loud, too chaotic, and far too overwhelming added to the personification of Sunshine’s mind; scrambling, panicking, terrored. It was not just Quiapo’s busy streets, it was also Sunshine’s trembling heart. But in between the anxiety and fear, Sunshine gathers the courage to try making a choice—even amidst the confusion. Sunshine finds out in the harshest way possible that a choice is not an option. She is put in a situation where the only way out is to give in to ‘sinful’ acts, dangerous pills, and death-defying abortion attempts. For a young teenager whose dreams seem too far from where she is, this is the only way. While many expect this decision to become the climax of the movie, Sunshine’s story is far from over. In my understanding, the film explored her conscience through Annika Co’s beautifully done character. It reminded the audience that while women consent to abortion, they are still carrying its moral burden. Annika’s character became an instrument to make women who seek abortion feel human, with human conscience and sensibilities. But it was done with such care, careful enough not to make it counterproductive but rather stuck in the ideology of the system that she grew up in.However, Annika’s character is only a personification of Sunshine’s chaotic mind, making Sunshine her own companion to her dawning journey. This character becomes Sunshine’s comfort in the dangers of her abortion attempts, showing the deeply awful and tragic realities many women face; alone in rotting walls of the city, drowning out the noise, and daring to dream bigger than the spaces they are subjected in.But what makes this movie even more special is that it did not let Sunshine go through it alone. While the movie was an avenue for telling the reality, it also became a source of hope for many women, especially for young ones who will watch it. There will be other women supporting them in their decision, other women who will not judge them for their choices, and other women who will create a safe space for them—at least in ways that they can, in the rotting system we have. Finally, Sunshine does not just urge the system to give women the rights to their own body; it explicitly explains what women go through in the struggles that we speak of. It does not undermine the calls for a systemic change, but it brings you the stories behind why a choice is necessary. It opens you to a narrative that does not just agree to progressive actions, but puts the heart in it. And in between those narratives, the movie reminds us that women are more, that they deserve to take up more space. Women are dreamers, they have ambition, they are complex, cohesive, and compassionate. Women are more than their mistakes, their stories go beyond. And that is the essence of a choice; to let them dream. To free them from the shackles of an already oppressing society. To not dim their light and let them shine, like Sunshine herself.To all the Sunshines out there, you are not alone. Be steadfast on your ambition and dare to dream big. And you take up space even bigger.

Sunshine is a brave and powerful film—one that confronts a deeply taboo subject with grace, nuance, and emotional weight, especially within the context of the Philippines’ heavily religious culture. Tonet Jadaone doesn’t pull punches, but she doesn’t sensationalize either. It’s an honest, grounded portrayal of something often swept under the rug.Maris Racal shines in a career-defining performance—raw, vulnerable, and fully committed. This isn’t an easy watch, but it’s a necessary one. And for those who stay with it, it’s deeply rewarding.Easily one of the best local films I’ve seen this year.

In many known movies, abortion is commonly narrated as a quest with so much comedic acts, plus some forced shallow arguments to inject drama.But for Sunshine — How the movie depicted purchasing a pregnancy test kit in the Philippines = an act to get humiliated. Sunshine, a teenage Filipina athlete forged to be an Olympian who had an unwanted pregnancy, was the sacrificial being for a story to be told.Sunshine happened in the Philippines, where access to reproductive health services is way harder to have compared to other countries, like in the US and Europe. The country has been enclosed with regressive conservatism, causing talks about sex to still be taboos. Abortion is still illegal as well. The movie happened right smack in the heart of Manila City — Quiapo. It is an area known for a well-known Catholic Church and the surrounding kubols or booths of herbal medicines and potions for all uses — from seducing someone, cursing someone, to inducing abortion (or in Filipino, “pampawala ng kapit ng bata.”) The story, its darkness, and some women’s resort to the said harmful options would not have happened if only proper education and healthcare are available, to be honest.Sunshine was very telling of the struggles of Filipinas. But I think it’s globally reflective as well because it told the following things:1.) Unfair treatment on female athletes: Remember Venus Williams’ pregnancy? She almost died after giving birth, and she was kicked out of the top ranks because she cannot play during recovery. The WNBA players? They just wore shirts last All-Star weekend saying “Pay Us What You Owe Us.” And here, Sunshine, an aspiring Olympian, unintentionally risking her passion and potential bread and butter just because proper help is nowhere in sight.2.) Violence against women and children: Catcalling, predatory stares, and rape were parts of this movie. The movie did as much as it could to raise awareness that these actions are still apparent and are unfortunate enablers of all things that went downhill for the female characters. Sunshine mirrored reality, especially for us, Filipinas. I hate writing that sentence, but, it’s the truth. ————————Technical items I liked:• Rico Blanco’s Challengers-esque film score! The music was so immersive. • Rhetorical characters (which are pretty difficult to execute and usually come out as trying-hard, but they weren’t)• Piolo Pascual and his presence. The audience just gasped as soon as he entered the frame!• Most of all — Maris Racal. Her future is so bright. Pain, so much pain, was expressed by her character. And she did more than enough that the audience would want to stop whatever’s causing her agony.• Gusto Ko Sakin Ka Lang is a banger in a tugstugs jeep ↕If you’re in the Philippines, watch this in any SM Cinema. If you’re outside the Philippines, watch out for more future film festivals. Sunshine has been shown in the Toronto International Film Festival, Berlin International Film Festival, Palm Springs International Film Festival, and many more.

Sunshine is more than a film about a teenage gymnast reaching for her olympic dreams. it reflects the struggles, hopes, and quiet battles of countless young girls trying to find light in a world that often dims their shine. Sunshine isn’t just an athlete wearing an asian games shirt holding a pink crane—she is a woman, a sister, a student, a friend, and someone younger girls look up to. set in the noisy, smoggy, and congested streets of Manila, the film doesn’t shy away from the uncomfortable realities many Filipino girls face: teenage pregnancy, poverty, lack of access to healthcare and education, judgment from professionals, and the systemic neglect of women’s rights. it's not just Sunshine's story—it’s the story of so many young women who are silenced, dismissed, and left to figure things out on their own. Antoinette Jadaone once again directed a story that is not meant to be questioned, but understood. it's in movies like this that we uncomfortably see how and why women resort to abortion-simply because they are forced by circumstances. pregnant teens do not need to be told how reckless they were; they already know it, and they're already bearing the consequences of their actions. what they actually need is someone they can seek help from, someone who can give them the support they need.lest we forget it's the government that continuously denies women their right to a safe society free from the shackles of abuse and neglect.Maris Racal, you are one hell of an artist—and seeing you and Jennica Garcia in an Antoinette Jadaone film was something i didn't know i needed.

SUNSHINE: THE REVOLUTION!Lost for words after watching tbh, like fr!!Usa sa ni tatak jud nako ani na film kay ang thought na I HAVE NEVER, AS IN NEVER SEEN MS. MERYLL SORIANO THIS RAW, LOUD AND CLEAR EVEN WITH NO-ACTING ACTING STYLE WITH POIGNANT ROLE AS SEEN IN THIS MOVIE. Grabeee, kuhang kuha kaayo niya ang no-acting acting na pinakagusto nako with independent films. If wala lang jud ko kaila niya, i could say na siya gyud ang trainer ni Sunshine like ana siya kamaayo na wala nako nakita iyaang pagka Mama Meme or any other characters she portrayed but THE COACH OF SUNSHINE. Hands up Ms. Meryll! Inay Maria must be proud of you! I hope you'll bag an acting award on this film, you deserve it!Second, gets man na nakafocus pud ang ending sa role ni Ms. Jennica Garcia cause siya nga lang naman nagtiwala at nakakaintindi kay Sunshine, but I would have love to see the change of tone on Ms. Meryll Soriano's character (kulang po yung exposure emz) — she has been one of the dynamic characters in this film and I want to see her sa ending more, now that Sunshine has done what she really loves to do, and parte rin naman siya ng success ni Sunshine. She, in the first place, confronted Sunshine about the "rumors" but in the end, in her quiet strength, sinuportahan man pud niya.Third, TAYO ANG CHARACTER NI ANNIKA CO. Ang character ni Annika Co reminds me of the character ni Joven sa Goyo: Batang Heneral. Annika Co doesn't just represent "Sunshine's child", she represents how Pinoy see and interpret in their own narratives ang mga personal decisions ni Sunshine. Kumbaga ing-ana ang most judgments sa mga tawo sa mga personal decisions ni Sunshine. She was taken lightly kay ang character naglalaro thru a child actor pero katong part sa falling action na ni ana si Annika ug "ngayon gets ko na..." with full of love and a hint of conviction. That's the cue, mao na ang gusto ni Sunshine mahitabo sa nation na magets siya na women should always have the right with their bodies, and what to do with their bodies. I was ugly crying sa whole falling action-resolution because of that freaking satisfaction makita sa nawong ni Sunshine while gracefully performing sa iyaang practice. Ing-ana ang gusto nato makita sa mga babaye if they choose themselves and could become as selfish as these men or even more. Basta gahilak rako ani na part kay heartfelt kaayo ang whole scene with Annika plus giatay dalang dala kaayo ko sa musical scoring ani na scene even without dialogues, just pure execution.Andami ko pang gustong sabihin, but mao ra sa ni ang nitatak sa ako while watching.This is not just a reflection of what's happening sa mga kababaihan, cause this is also a call for action na kailangan na mulihok ang mga lawmakers na ma-Decriminalize ang Abortion sa Pinas to give chance to all women who are not ready to become mothers kasi may mga pangarap pa na mas dapat unahin. Let women be selfish for once. Hindi lahat pwede maging ina; hindi lahat gustong maging isang ina.

In a deeply religious country, I understand why Director Jadaone found it necessary to use symbolism through the characters of the child and Ariana in order to present the film Sunshine in a way that would allow it to be shown and appreciated by a wider Filipino audience.

The film conveys a strong message and opens discussion on a pressing (yet not widely discussed) issue in the Philippines: teenage pregnancy.There were scenes that made me cry, but that’s because it’s where it really makes me empathize with Sunshine. Maris does not just play Sunshine. Maris is Sunshine. I love that for her.

Woooooooh!!!!!!ADDENDUM CHAR (i just can’t stop thinking about this movie after like a week) Sunshine is a story of hope entangled in reality’s shadow.I’ve seen this film before—many times. As a student, learning the theoretical aspects of medicine. As an intern, having actual encounters through interviews with women like Sunshine. And as a practicing physician, who trained to become an OB-GYN, completing many incomplete miscarriages—induced or not—removing what’s left of what we call products of conception. Sometimes people call it products of misconception when they’re trying to be funny.This movie didn’t just slap us with the sensitive issue of abortion. It dissected so many layers of issues we need to talk about more often—and pondering them in reality is a mental and moral gymnastics at play.I would love to discuss all of them one by one, but this is a movie review after all, not an essay on the dangers of lacking a solid law to protect our young women from the societal pressures of patriarchy and religion—pressures that push them into life-threatening situations, only to be blamed for doing something they had no real choice about. In short, fuck the system.It’s always been a mental gymnastics for me to decide how to approach situations like this. And this movie is telling me exactly how. Jennica Garcia’s character deeply resonated with me—from the way she calls Sunshine’s name so tenderly, to the way she assures her that she’ll be there no matter what. She reminds us that we all need at least one ate around us who looks after us despite everything. (She literally said, shouted even, BE KIND!)Another character who lingered in my mind was the 14-year-old teenage mother. Shoutout to the team for dressing her in something colorful—a subtle clue to her identity, only revealed later. She was one small character representing thousands of teenage mothers, who are becoming younger as the years go by. She also represented the vulnerable group prone to sexual abuse—the group we have somehow failed to protect.I’d love to dissect each of the characters, but I’ll leave that to you. Instead, I’ll talk about Sunshine (last na, promise). Maris Racal’s portrayal was a masterclass in character acting. Sunshine is a fearless dreamer, full of dedication and passion to make that dream come true. She perseveres despite her family’s circumstances. She’s also a believer, kind, and someone who truly cares. You see it in the small things—like the way she makes the sign of the cross before her performance, or when she prays fervently in Quiapo Church to ask for guidance or forgiveness on the thing she’s about to do or not to do. And that’s the beauty of this film—it tells you so many things without saying so much. It urges its viewers to talk about them because these are urgent matters. Maybe we’re still far from legalizing abortion, but this movie isn’t just about that. It’s telling us we have so many other issues to tackle.In short, we need to protect the Sunshines—or this world will become darker than it already is.

I’m fairly easy to please when it comes to films. Give me a solid plot, a bit of laughter, a love story I can root for, and a strong ensemble, and I’m happy. Sunshine delivers all of these, but more importantly, it delivers a quiet, aching kind of truth. The trailer already sets up the premise: an aspiring Olympic gymnast finds herself two months away from the qualifiers, and pregnant. What unfolds is not a cautionary tale, but a necessary, grounded story about the private cost of dreams and the impossible decisions women are often forced to make.This is not a conventional film. At several moments, I found myself crying with Sunshine—because I know there are many women like her. Women who have been in the same position, or still are. In a country where laws continue to deny women the right to make choices about their own bodies, Sunshine handles its subject matter with a kind of restraint and realism that does not demand pity, but insists on empathy. Even if you haven’t experienced what she has, you feel it—because you are human, and perhaps more deeply, because you are a woman. When the credits rolled, it took a while before anyone in the cinema, including myself to get up and leave. There was a heaviness in the room. Everyone sat in silence, letting the weight of the film settle in.Some have described the film as Brocka-esque, and I find that comparison apt. This is Tonette Jadaone’s most powerful work to date. A film that is necessary, timely, and deserving of all our support. I hope more people watch Sunshine and understand this side of womanhood, one that is constantly sidelined in the name of morality and ethics. There is truth, and power, in giving women the right to choose. In letting them take ownership of their own bodies. Always.

As a Filipino woman, this movie hits so close to home. So many moments in this movie that made me realize that I might have been too jaded to comprehend just how common unwanted and taboo pregnancies are. I feel a sense of pride over the protagonist’s choices, for being “kontra-agos” in a society and industry that perpetuates ownership over a woman’s body and future. Maris shined, but Jennica Garcia’s performance as the firm yet nurturing older sister really stuck with me. Lastly, this movie brought to light just how much we need progressive reproductive health policies in the country, and just how much we have to fight for it. I would have wished for the movie to be straightforward about what happened after Maris’ decision, but there’s a certain charm about it being sort of open-ended.

There’s a quiet power in Sunshine, one that doesn’t shout its message but lets it settle in your bones. This film is many things: a coming-of-age story, a critique of a broken system, a glimpse into the intimate pain of being a girl in a country where your choices are limited before you’re even allowed to make them.It focuses on the deeply human moments of fear, frustration, and quiet strength as Sunshine navigates an impossible decision in a society that offers her no safe options. Maris Racal delivers her best performance yet, as there’s a stillness to it that makes it all the more heartbreaking.What I really loved is how it doesn’t feel like it’s trying to explain itself and it just presents the reality where religion, poverty, and patriarchy intersect in deeply personal ways. It’s a whole world closing in on a girl who’s just trying to breathe, fighting for her freedom to choose and a right to dream.Seen at SM City Dasmariñas

It’s a revelation to see how Jadaone’s point of view has evolved over the years through her filmography. From Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay to Alone/Together, from Fan Girl to Sunshine, she consistently shows us what it means to be a woman in our patriarchal society.As a homosexual queer man, I don’t know what it feels like to be a woman sa lipunang ginagalawan natin—but this film gave me a glimpse of just how difficult it is. Plus, I always love the ending. If this isn’t cinema, I don’t know what is.When Annika Co said, “‘Yung pangarap ko, kung anong pangarap n’ya,”I felt that.

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine listens. It listens to the silence of shame, the dissonance of faith, and the quiet, aching resolve of a girl who simply wants to choose. It’s the kind of film that our deeply Catholic country isn’t ready for, but desperately needs. That it’s showing in nationwide cinemas—not just tucked in the corners of a progressive film festival—feels like a small act of rebellion in itself.Like Eliza Hittman’s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, a film I often return to when thinking about stories of quiet resistance, Sunshine unfolds with restraint and tenderness, never sensationalizing what is already unbearable. But where Hittman’s film relies on cold urban detachment, Jadaone’s world breathes with a Filipino kind of chaos: loud horns, dim chapels, vendors selling herbal “solutions” beside icons of the Virgin Mary. It’s all there. The hypocrisy, the hush-hush remedies, the weight of sin pressed upon young women’s shoulders before they even understand the language of their own bodies.Maris Racal is astonishing. She carries the film with a performance so grounded, so lived-in, that she often feels less like a character and more like someone we know. A friend. A cousin. A girl on the jeep beside us, clutching a bag, hiding her fear behind a tight grip and a brave face. Her Sunshine is not loud, but she is brave. And perhaps bravery today looks exactly like this: choosing to take control of your life, even when the world tries to stop you.Jadaone’s direction is both intimate and distant, borrowing from the gaze of Brocka but infused with a distinctly feminine grief. We see Sunshine from behind glass, from across alleys, as if we too are complicit in watching but not speaking up. Yet the film never loses its tenderness, even in its political anger.Sunshine is not an easy watch. But it is essential. In a country where reproductive rights are still cloaked in rosaries and stigma, this film asks us not just to look, but to sit, to stay, to listen. It doesn’t beg for permission. It asserts presence. And sometimes, in a nation deafened by doctrine, that’s more than enough.

i’ve already seen so many pro-choice films that greatly explore the difficulties of going through an abortion (never rarely something always, happening, etc) but i must say that it feels really different to watch a film like it made in your country.. because in the pro-choice films i’ve watched before, they’re usually either set in the old times where abortion was still illegal in their countries or set in a modern setting whereas the female lead needs to travel in other places/states to undergo abortion legally… but in sunshine, it’s set in the modern times or the living conditions of filipino people right now yet there’s still no place to go where abortion is accepted… which speaks a lot about the real life situation for women in our country. women anywhere have to go through a lot to apply *the choice* that they’ve decided on.. however, it is much much worse in the philippines as it’s a complete taboo and sometimes it feels like we’ll never see in our lifetime where abortion will finally be legal in the country…… so, it truly is a remarkable feat that we got a pro-choice filipino film now. not only that because it’s directed by one of the most well-known directors, released nationwide, and promoted in mainstream shows and platforms. this film shedded some light to everyone and it was very much needed for every filipino woman out there.thank you direk antoinette, maris racal, and all the amazing women here for sharing the story of sunshine.

This film is, at its core, a well-intentioned and emotionally resonant film. It tackles difficult subject matter with sincerity, and for the most part, it does so with grace. However, I found that the inclusion of fantastical or imaginary elements occasionally detracted from the weight of its core issues. While I understand the metaphorical ambition behind these stylistic choices as well as their function in softening the emotional blows with humor or levity, I believe the film is at its most powerful when it forgoes embellishment and leans fully into the raw intensity of its subject matter. In those moments, when it embraces the chaos, the pain, and the emotional urgency it really becomes something far more affecting and memorable, allowing the simplicity it strives for to emerge, though it’s often overshadowed. At times, the dialogue veers into overtly inspirational or didactic terrain, feeling more like affirmations meant to uplift than naturalistic exchanges between characters. It’s clear that the film doesn’t only aim to tell a story, it wants to educate, to empower, to stir social consciousness. Yet in doing so, it sometimes edges closer to the tone of an educational TV movie than a fully realized work of cinema. That’s not a critique of its moral imperative, it’s a film that should be shown in schools but rather an observation about its limitations as a piece of narrative storytelling. The emotional and ideological weight it seeks to carry isn’t always supported by the nuance or complexity that cinematic storytelling demands.What grounds the film and gives it its most enduring power is its emotional core. Maris Racal delivers a performance of quiet strength and vulnerability, anchoring the film with remarkable consistency. Especially compelling is the subplot involving Rhed Bustamante’s character. Without revealing too much, her arc resonated with me more deeply than the central storyline. It was heartbreakingly authentic, subtle, restrained, and profoundly human. In that thread, the film touches something honest and unflinching.I also admired Antoinette Jadaone’s formal restraint in certain key scenes, particularly her choice to mute the sound. In a film so concerned with voice and expression, those pockets of silence carried tremendous weight. They allowed the viewer a moment of stillness, a space for reflection and imbued the film with a haunting quietude that deepened the emotional stakes.That said, the film’s message doesn’t always land with clarity. After a pivotal hospital scene, I overheard two audience members blame the protagonist for her choices, siding with the doctor who confronts her. That reaction, while anecdotal, reveals a significant shortcoming: the narrative may not have sufficiently challenged ingrained prejudices or prompted the kind of empathy it aspired to cultivate. It bravely addresses urgent topics- reproductive rights, bodily autonomy, the realities of being a young woman navigating unjust systems but the film doesn’t always sharpen these into a coherent or persuasive argument. In trying to reach everyone, it occasionally loses the sharpness needed to truly confront.Still, “Sunshine” is a valuable film, one with earnestness, compassion, and purpose. Its flaws are born of ambition: the desire to inspire, to uplift, and to inform all at once. But perhaps empowerment doesn’t always need to be accompanied by joy. Sometimes, it is in the unvarnished confrontation of pain without fantasy, without consolation that we discover our deepest strength. I don’t mean to suggest the film ought to have ended in despair, but rather that its final act, which shifts into metaphor and closes with a success story, might have benefitted from something more grounded, more unresolved or ambiguous . Real life rarely provides a clean arc, and in a film so rooted in truth, the ending felt almost too easy, too neat.

hindi pa ako nakakaupo sa aking assigned seat sa sinehan ay gets ko na si sunshine. ngunit mas na-gets ko siya paglabas ko ng sinehan. ang bigat panoorin, pero ito ang realidad, masalimuot na realidad ng mga kababaihang gaya ni sunshine. isa ito sa mga usaping hindi masyadong napaguusapan—should i say iniiwasang pagusapan, ang women’s reproductive health and rights. nawa’y maging daan ang pelikulang ito upang mas mabuksan ang isipan ng bawat isa at maisali ang paksang ito sa mga diskurso nang maintindihan ito ng mas nakararami pa—mula sa root causes hanggang sa mga sanga na konektado sa nasabing usapin.hindi lamang ito isang pelikula—ito ay sumasalamin sa patuloy na pakikipaglaban ng kababaihan para sa kanyang layang pumili, mangarap, at mabuhay sa kanyang ninanais na paraan.salamat po papa god dahil may pelikulang ganito.

I really commend and loove the creative choices of Jadaone in this film from power casting, relevant script, unpredictable turn of events, and conflicts in between. All of it TRULY just makes sense.

it is so powerful to see stories that center a woman’s right to choose, to live life on her own terms, without being forced into roles she never asked for. as i always say, a woman’s body is hers alone. only she should decide what to do with it. no one, especially not men, should dictate what a woman should or should not be.i am glad we are finally seeing more of these narratives here in the philippines. they are necessary, they are overdue, and they are real.

A random review ***it may contain spoilers*** I was in awe after seeing the first 10mins or more of this film. How perfectly shot, how each Sunshine’s flow, movement and forms were perfectly calculated in graceful manner, it may translate to her goals as a national athlete. I like the raw and realistic on the situation where she had an idea if she might be pregnant, from the varsity clinic, how she react, getting a pregnancy kit to a local pharmacy, how she search online on how to get rid or literally “mawala sa sarili” in the moment she found out, i may say if i were in that age I probably be acting the same thing Sunshine did.It very direct, light and eye opening to different perspectives in abortion, from the pro life views, to views of men who is not ready fathered or accept responsibilities, to the views of her friends and colleagues/societal norms, in the perspectives of her coach and to her lifelong dream, to the views of some unwanted pregnant women who dealt from complicated situations, to view of her own family, for Sunshine and to her unborn child. We all have out own biases when it comes to this topic; abortion but at the end it still in the capacity of the woman, the beholder to take choice on what choices she want to take… I was too happy how her family especially her eldest sister Geleen support Sunshine in what decision she may lead to. Its a gemIn silver screen seeing that moment, that scene that is so comforting, q moment that most of us longing in a situation like this. It’s not about taking responsibilities but owning and accepting mistakes and making peace to yourself. We know what is good and what's right but in the end of the day we are the not the right one to decide for someone else fate and choices especially we are not in that situation, where they are coming from.I want to commend Maris Racal for casting as Sunshine. I can’t think anyone else to portray for the role of Sunshine. Flawless acting, she really Sunshine. Also Jennica Garcia too and Meryl Soriano, superb performance. *i love the Aryanna scene. Speaks reality!*the scene with Angeli Bayani /Dr. Helena. After Mary Grace rushed to the hospital and Dr. Helena offer her service after a male doctor rejected Mary grace and Sunshine, only women understands women… period say it all. God, it’s life and death situation, would you still judge a person of her crime that saving her life?*the Tito Bobot scene- Sunshine gives Justice, p*tang-ina nya. Hayop!
Powerful. Visceral. Captures how religious conservatism in Philippine society continues to triumph over women’s bodily autonomy.

drown out the noise. you’re sunshine.ang sunshine ay isang matapang at tapat na paglalarawan ng realidad ng kababaihan—lalo na ng mga kabataang hindi pa handa, pero pinilit ng pagkakataon. hindi ito pelikulang magpapagaan ng loob mo; ito ang pelikulang magbubukas ng mata mo sa bigat ng mga pasaning hindi nila pinili, pero kailangan nilang dalhin.hindi natakot ang pelikula ipakita ang buong karanasan—kasama ang kahihiyan, sakit, panghuhusga, at mga desisyong hindi madaling tanggapin. pero higit sa lahat, ipinakita nito ang kapangyarihan ng babae na pumili para sa sarili, kahit hindi siya maintindihan ng iba.sunshine ay hindi lang kwento ng isang tao—isa itong sulyap sa katotohanang matagal nang sinisigaw pero paulit-ulit na binabaliwala.at alam kong hindi pa handa ang pilipinas sa ganitong pelikula. pero sana dumating ang panahon na mas piliin nating makinig kaysa manghusga. sana’y magkaroon tayo ng sapat na tapang at bukas na isipan para panoorin ito—baka sakaling mas maintindihan natin kung bakit may mga sunshine sa paligid natin.

yung number 1 reason kung bakit nagustuhan ko ang sunshine ay dahil si sunshine ang bida. that was a conscious and bold choice for the film. kasi ang mindset ng mga tao, okay lang ang abortion kapag nabuntis ang babae dahil sa rape.pero malinaw ang gustong ipa-realize satin ng pelikula, na si menggay ka man o si sunshine, na-rape ka man o hindi, may option at access ka dapat sa safe abortion. kwento ito ng maraming kababaihan sa bansa, ang iba’y mga ina tulad ni susan (The Barber’s Tales).dapat i-decriminalize ang abortion sa pilipinas and discussions about it must be more about the social reality than morality. naalala ko ang statement noon ng gabriela women’s party:“Whether we see abortion as a moral decision or not, we cannot turn a blind eye to the reality that poor women resort to unsafe abortion as they do not have the resources to raise a child amid the economic crisis, aside from the alarming cases of pregnancies arising from rape.”

ang iniisip ko lang talaga while watching ay, who would have thought na isang pbb housemate ang magiging one of the best actresses of her generation? no shade, pero hindi kasi talaga talent search ang pbb for me, pero shet, maybe ok lang pala dahil kung hindi walang maris racal?! performance of a lifetime. ilalagay ko sya sa roster of actresses na sasalagan ko ng bala kung sakaling may mamaril sa kanila. ganda ng trajectory ng karera ni bakla! multimedia ang atake! I’m so sorry pero hindi ko mapigilan i-compare si maris kay angelica panganiban. equally talented. it was uphill for angelica after santa santita, and this is maris’ santa santita. an actress na kayang-kaya tumawid between mainstream and profound roles. at sobrang powerful ‘nun kasi konting-konti lang ang nakakagawa ‘nun na kinakagat ng mga tao. husay din nung chuwariwap sunshine. si annika, meryll soriano, and lalong-lalo na si jennica garcia. sa konting eksena nya, para bang binigay nya yung buong pagkatao nya? kung papanoorin nyo palang, abangan nyo yung scenes ni jennica. pag hindi kayo napukaw, kakain ako ng tae!tell me something about mothering without being a mother ang atake ni tonet at sunshine. gets na gets ko ang mensahe na gustong iparating kahit wala akong uterus. at yung pagpapadala ng mensahe, sing-graceful ng rhythmic gymnastics ni sunshine.who was she talking to? her younger self? her dream? her baby? or her conscience? kanya-kanyang interpreration nalang, pero dun ako sa latter. yung tipong, ito yung societal standards na kinalakihan mo, to the point na naging konsensya mo. ang konsensya ba, napapalaglag? that is the question.nung 2020 after ko mapanood ang fangirl, nasabi ko talaga na this is the new age of tonet jadaone. after sunshine, indeed totoo nga. ganda rin talaga ng mga bond nya sa actresses nya for them to spill this hard.this film is not glorifying abortion; it glorifies the women’s choices, because their body, their choice. pinakita ang struggle, the weighing in, and most importantly, the strength on making a firm stand for yourself.

What I truly admired about this film is how Sunshine stayed committed to her decision from the very beginning. There are moments where you think she might waver, that she might choose differently, but she doesn’t. And I’m so glad direk Tonet stayed firm in writing it that way. As a Filipino film that bravely tackles the topic of abortion (a subject still considered taboo in our country), I really appreciated the way Sunshine and Mary Grace’s stories were presented.…

Sunshine is a film that proves time and time again that art matters. This is unrelated to the film but Ethan Hawke best explains it when he said that human art is a sustenance that lets us make sense of the things that we have no understanding of. And Sunshine exceeds in that very criteria because of how delicate the plot is yet it puts so much faith on its viewers by challenging them into understanding the struggles explored in the film, and it cleverly succeeds in such a way that does not make it intrusive. The viewer is allowed to draw their own opinions without the film ever forcing them to side with it. Sunshine is Antoinette Jadaone's magnum opus, and the film further shines as Maris Racal delivers a performance of a lifetime. I cannot stress enough how important this film is to the Philippines, and how it is a step forward to everything it stands for. Manila is unforgiving, relentless, and dark, but even the streets can feel like home with even just a little light.

Gets na gets ko na.To be honest, Sunshine may follow the story of a gymnast, but it's really about the quiet, impossible contortions many women are forced to make just to keep going—physically, emotionally, morally. It’s about the weight of carrying something you didn’t choose, in a world that offers you no real way out.It asks the kind of questions that linger long after the credits roll: How do you hold on to your dreams when your body no longer feels like your own? How do you choose anything at all when every choice comes with shame, fear, or punishment?In a country where abortion is completely outlawed—even in cases of rape or danger to the mother—and where women are taught to suffer silently for the sake of appearances or faith, Sunshine hits differently. It doesn't shout. It doesn't try to shock. It simply tells the truth as it is lived: with quiet pain, with small acts of defiance, and with the kind of strength that often goes unnoticed.This film doesn’t just resist—it listens, it aches, and above all, it stays with you.July 26, 2025SM Mall of Asia

in a country where abortion is still criminalized & still buried deeply beneath shame and fear, im glad that this film dares to say what so many are too afraid to: that we simply need to talk about this and that this silence is not a safety but just a mere violence in a very very slow motion.upon watching, i just noticed such apparent layers: desperation, love, pain, and so frustratingly impossible choices. and such never fit neatly into laws written without compassion. im really just so glad that they made a film about care, about womens autonomy, and about the dignity of choosing what to do with ones body, especially in a country like ours, where so many are denied that choice, where morality is frustratingly weaponized and healthcare is gatekept. im really hoping this sparks more than the praise. rage, conversation, and ofc solidarity. and im sure this is already starting to become one of those local films that are not afraid at all to confront our truths no matter how this disturbs the comfortable. we need to legalize abortion. not only simply bc of efficiency, but bc of necessity. bc everyone deserves the right to choose, to be safe, and to be seen.

To hell with these topics being taboo in the Philippines - Jadaone says LET’S TALK ABOUT IT and this film did that. Definitely a film that will start conversations and something that will linger in thought even hours after watching it.This film - for starters, was really well-shot and well-edited. That was my first takeaway. Second, well-scored. And when that credits rolled and I saw that Rico Blanco did it? The dots were connecting and with Maris Racal as the protagonist? Wow that was definitely personal maybe that’s why it was done so good.As a man, who actually didn’t know anything about this topic - THIS WAS EYE-OPENING EDUCATIONAL FOR ME. I didn’t know how self-abortion works, I didn’t know how much it cost, I didn’t know what it looks like, I didn’t know how treatment is done after, I didn’t even know that doctors refused service for this! Imagine my fuming anger when that scene happened. For me, this was information overload.I appreciate how this was not Maris Racal anymore. This was Sunshine. Sunshine was a real person. It borderline made me forget that this was a film, it felt like reenactment of something, or maybe unintentionally, it was.Also, scriptwriting and editing masterclass - How you make people laugh with subtle punchlines with great timing, but not cutting off the momentum and emotion you feel for the scene, and also not lightening off the topic at hand. The way that that were balanced? Hats off to Jadaone and the editor, Ben Tolentino (THE GOAT)Performances were topnotch as well! I love that you feel the cast, from lead to support, not one-upping each other. You felt them read the script and read the room and operate on that energy. They were supporting each others’ performances and maybe that’s why it became more effective as a script. The execution was phenomenal.Personally, I would have loved some bit more fleshing out by the third act, because I feel like the un-accustomed or laymen movie audience may not get it immediately with the execution of it and it would’ve been better with the topic at hand to be spoonfed a bit more (but not too much). But yeah this is more of a personal nitpick at this point.Either way - BEAUTIFUL FILM! Is this my favorite Jadaone? I’m not sure yet. But is this objectively the best Maris Racal? TO DATE YES!

So so so much empathy in Jadaone’s lens and Racal’s performance — in many scenes I found myself sharing Sunshine’s pain, so when she finds peace in her decision, I couldn’t help but beam with pride too.

Sunshine isn’t just a film—it’s a quiet cry from someone who feels stuck, trying to move forward in a world that keeps pulling her back. Tonet Jadaone tells the story with gentle honesty, never shouting, but always making you feel.Maris Racal plays a young gymnast chasing her dream. But life throws her a twist: an unexpected pregnancy. Suddenly, her body—once her source of power—feels like it no longer belongs to her. She’s scared, tired, and unsure what choice feels right.The setting isn’t just Manila—it’s its soul. Busy, sacred, messy. In one scene, she’s buying abortion pills from a street stall, while church bells ring nearby. The contrast is sharp, but real. Sunshine doesn’t tell you what’s right or wrong. It just shows you what’s true.What stayed with me most is how the film feels personal. Like every time I’ve had to choose myself, even when others didn’t understand. It reminded me that courage isn’t loud—it’s the quiet strength to keep going.If you’ve ever felt like you were drowning in expectations, Sunshine reminds you that even in the darkest alleys, there’s a sliver of light. Not because the world is kind—but because you choose to keep walking.

Yesterday, I stumbled upon a Twitter post pointing out parallelisms between Jadaone's Sunshine and Brocka's Insiang with how both films' main characters, in at least one scene, were framed behind bars, mirroring their metaphorical imprisonment within gendered norms of their respective social milieus. Indeed, although almost 50 years have passed between the two films, it's an unfortunate reality that women's rights in the Philippines still have a long way to go, with conservative Catholic values hindering its advancement. Both Jadaone and Brocka present us with their titular characters' fractured psyches, trying everything within their limited power to achieve some kind of self-emancipation. Another Twitter post, however, posits that while Jadaone echoes Brocka in some ways, she ultimately diverges from him by virtue of her "woman's instinct" that also augments her narratives with an "added layer." Obvious gender essentialism and identity politics aside, this is a sentiment that I'm keen on interrogating: what does it actually mean to have a female directorial sensibility, particularly in the vein of Antoinette Jadaone?An easy answer would be to look at the central conflict of Sunshine, that is, unwanted pregnancy, and that Jadaone opts for a female teenager as its main focalizer. I'm pointing this out because trans men and intersex people can also get pregnant hence a pregnancy plot point would not inherently be women-specific (although there would surely be many overlaps), so it's Jadaone's directorial decision to create a female protagonist that imbues the film with intricacies of the female experience---how proceeding with motherhood would be career suicide for an athlete aiming for the Olympics, how Sunshine is constantly berated by self-righteous people she encounters, how society itself was built against female self-determination, and despite all these, how Sunshine finds small pockets of refuge in other women---a friend, a mentor, an inn receptionist, a doctor, an abused prepubescent, a sister---who are empathetic enough to understand her pain and conviction, and to whom she's equally compelled to reciprocate kindness whenever the situation permits.Further, Jadaone digs deeper and finds the Catholic religious institution, itself a remnant of feudalism, as an underlying hegemonic force against women empowerment, so culturally embedded in Philippine society that Sunshine finds it wherever she goes, be it in the drugstore, in the hospital, in the university, in the sport that she loves, even in the man who got her pregnant. Unfortunately, here is also where Jadaone's supposed female sensibility loses steam: religious guilt is so ubiquitous that even she is not aware that it limits her perspective, that instead of finding multiple angles of inquiry she instead chooses to hammer in the same anti-religious (therefore anti-patriarchal) talking point over and over and over again, even to the point of physicalizing the unborn children, a weirdly pro-life creative decision in a film that self-categorizes as pro-choice. Heck, the film just assumes that the audience already knows about the economic facets of being a Filipino athlete so it makes no effort in examining it, nor is it concerned with how Sunshine and her family earn their money (nobody seems to be working!). No, those aren't important; just focus on the fact that Sunshine is a woman and that she's oppressed because of it. "Drown out the noise," her coach tells her, but is it really necessary to drown it out if the noise is as repetitively monotonous (albeit still imminently threatening) as Jadaone presented it?My argument is that uncritical admiration for "female sensibility" is as dangerous as the patriarchy it contends with, and that it's the same liberal narrow-sightedness that applauds Jadaone's bravery for tackling taboo gender topics and turns a blind eye to her cowardice in heeding the pro-Palestine boycott of the Berlinale film festival in the same breath; what's the point of female sensibility if it is devoid of anti-fascist solidarity? Perhaps Sunshine is actually a self-surrogate for the lengths Jadaone is willing to go through in pursuit of her career, and we're all just supposed to root for her because it's great that Philippine cinema is acknowledged and praised internationally, everything else be damned.And maybe I'm expecting too much from Jadaone, that I should just accept that her films are self-contained texts that will never reach the same kind of radicalism and depth as Brocka's (which is admittedly a high standard to reach), but deep inside I want to believe that she's capable of bolder, stronger filmic statements.

Ganito pala sa Maynila—maingay, mausok, at puno ng pangarap. Sunshine holds up a mirror to Manila's contradictions. There is a sketchy motel that asks for your ID before handing over the keys, as if the system needs to know if you are old enough to make your own decisions. A crowded hospital where pregnant women share beds in the maternity ward, almost as if they are only given a small space in a world they live in. A religious landmark for those seeking miracles, but just outside are street markets selling religious paraphernalia and illegal abortion pills.Maris Racal gives an outstanding performance as Sunshine, a young rhythmic gymnast whose Olympic aspirations are upended by unexpected pregnancy during tryouts. One of the film's striking choices is the inclusion of this magical presence played by Annika Co. To me this character felt like a reflection of the conservative audience inserted into the narrative, a constant presence, watching, whispering, and trying to make sense of Sunshine's decisions.The film closes with the hope that Sunshine, and others like her, might still get the chance to finish their routine and maybe, even become champions of their own lives.

Set against the relentless rhythm of Manila, the film captures how the world keeps moving—often without mercy—especially for those society has pushed to the margins. Yet, in the middle of all the noise and indifference, it reminds us that even the smallest act of empathy can mean everything to someone, not only for Sunshines out there but also to Mary Graces alike. There should be a choice. Always.

"Naiintindihan mo ba 'ko?""Gets ko na."Aside from the usapan between Jennica and Maris, dito talaga ako naiyak. Naisip ko tuloy bigla 'yung lyrics sa Indak na "makikinig nga ba sa isipan na alam ang wasto, ngunit pipigilan ang pag-ibig niya na totoo." Kudos to Sunshine for choosing what she feels right for her. Kung sa kwento at paraan ng pagkwento nitong pelikula, sa totoo lang. Kung ano talaga nangyayari sa lipunan. Walang labis, hindi nagkulang, kaya malakas ang impact. For me, iba talaga ang gawa ng direktor na nagmula sa Indie then pinapasok ang mundo ng mainstream. May pag-asa ang Pelikulang Pilipino.

Sunshine is a charming film. Beautifully directed, well-acted, and elevated by a great score and gorgeous cinematography (ang ganda ng Maynila kahit gritty). The pacing is tight and purposeful (walang fillers, or at least I didn't feel it), and honestly, I loved every minute of it. It’s the best Filipino film I’ve seen this year.What stood out most was how it tackled the lack of body autonomy that women face in this country. We reaaaalllyyy need a legal avenue for abortion, and I hope this film helps spark that conversation. Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas!I also liked that it showcased the real Manila without falling into poverty porn (great shots of Quiapo). It celebrated female friendships and relationships without centering men, and it showed the complexities of family without resorting to toxic tropes(supportive ate yes! Jennica Garcia was amaaaazing). I loved the inclusion of sports too; we definitely need more athlete-centered films.Pero, at the heart of it all is a strong, well-developed main character — flawed, impulsive, but deeply likeable and easy to root for (even during her chaotic, violent outbursts!!! I loved those moments, geh girl go lang!!!).Maris Racal was phenomenal. She captured Sunshine’s stress and anxiety with so much nuance — it never felt overacted. Grabe, I really felt her frustration, and by the end, I felt her relief too.I don’t usually write movie reviews, but this film was so phenomenaaaaal I couldn’t help but put my thoughts into words. Ayan tuloy, nakapagsulat ako ng ilang paragraphs! I really hope it gets the support it deserves and that more people catch it in cinemas before Tuesday so that it gets extended and marinig ni Direk yung now on it's 3rd week — ganern!Thank you, Papa God para sa movie na to!!!

Ang tapang!Not only is this Jadaone's bravest and best film yet, it's also arguably the most important local film in recent years. And the fact that it got past the Movie and Television Review and Christians Board and is now showing in the most mainstream cinemas in the country, is already a big win in itself.Sunshine joins Joanne and Jane as Jadaone's women trapped but still dreaming, living, and surviving in a world by and of weak men.And much like what she was able to get out of then-up-and-comers Nadine Lustre and Charlie Dizon, Jadaone gives birth to another star in Maris Racal. And like her big sisters, she SHINES.Jennica Garcia MOTHERED;Maris Racal MURDERED! (oops!)[SM Marikina] < Ang Ranking: Antoinette Jadaone >

Seconds after the credits started rolling, I blankly stared at the ceiling, pondering a lot of questions. Ganitong-ganito yung mga film na gustong-gusto ko may talkback not because I want to know the process but rather I want to learn more about the topic. As they say, “Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable” at sa tingin ko matagumpay na nagawa yun ng Sunshine. And that “Gets kita” scene crumpled my heart so bad (kahit hindi ako babae).From Maris to the supporting actors, everyone truly gave their all. They genuinely breathed life into their characters. My Direk Tonet’s fave alongside with That Thing Called Tadhana and Never Not Love You. Sana marami pa ang makapanood nito at maging paraan upang mas magkaroon pa ng nga diskusyon patungkol dito.

Usually, when a film claims to challenge a societal norm, it ends up being either too preachy or barely scratching the surface. But sometimes, a film like Sunshine comes along and delivers on its promise—clear, direct, and most importantly, brave.Not only is this Jadaone’s best film to date, but it’s also her most important. It’s a feminist masterclass in storytelling, evident in how every significant character in the film that supports Sunshine is a woman. And to top it all off, the ending was written to give the character what she truly deserves—even if the harsh realities of our country don't always allow a woman to have that.Even the casting was perfect and clearly intentional—from Maris’s embodiment of Sunshine to Elijah’s portrayal of the privileged Miggy (perfect choice of name, by the way). Setting the story against the raw backdrop of Manila adds just the right weight to the film’s intention.Minsan lang dumating ang isang pelikulang pwedeng magbukas ng mata ng mas marami pang tao. Sana dumating ang araw na hindi na mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Sana maintindihan ng kung sino man ang nasa taas. Sana masabi nilang, “Gets ko na."

[SPOILERS!]Ang pinakapaborito kong detalye sa movie nato ay ang fact na “wala lang ang pera sa buhay ni Miggy”.Binasag ni Sunshine ang windshield ng kotse nya? No problem, sa sunod na shot with the car, intentionally mag-ga-glide ang shot sa harap at makikitang napalitan na ang windshield at wala nang confrontation about it. It is just fixed.Kailangan ni Sunshine ng pera para magpalaglag ng bata? Walang intro-intro, dumukot sa bulsa si Miggy, binigyan nya si Sunshine ng 5k. 5000 pesos!Nalaman ng tatay ni Miggy na nakabuntis sya? Edi sige, sasagutin nila lahat ng hospital bills nya. Susustentuhan nila ang magiging bata until mag-18 ito. Pag-aaralin nila sa Ateneo, La Salle, you name it.Money is not an issue for them.The runners up are:2. Gift of God ang pangalan ng jeep na sinakyan ni Sunshine papunta sa Quiapo for the first time.3. I think (and maybe this is a reach), deliberate ang decision na pink and yellow ang official colors ng movie nato.I am a mark for this film. I have no distance from it. It is a match between Jun Robles Lana and Direk Tonet as my favorite active Filipino filmmaker right now tapos crush ko na si Maris PBB days nya pa lang. Of course I’m gonna love it.

Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a record-breaking national athlete, but the film fails to show the weight of that achievement.She wears a tank top marked “Asian Games 2018,” and her coach (Meryll Soriano) warns her against complacency: “Balewala lahat ng gold mo sa Asian Games.”Since the Asian Games are held every four years, and Sunshine is about 19 or 20, this suggests she won multiple golds in 2018 — a rare feat. She would be gymnastics royalty, a media darling, likely the most successful Filipina rhythmic gymnast in history.Yet the film doesn’t show her as a public figure. No news clippings, no media buzz, no crowds—just a few kids asking for a selfie. It also focuses mostly on her ribbon routine, barely showing the hoop, ball, or clubs—all key to establishing her as Olympic-level.Sunshine’s decision to abort is quick, and her fears and ambitions are underexplored. The Olympics, in fact, feel more like her coach’s dream—the film tells us this but doesn’t show it.There’s no pressure from a country rooting for her, nor from sponsors who presumably funded her expensive training (which we’re left to assume, since rhythmic gymnastics is an elite sport). No rival gymnast, no sense of competition, no major stakes, and no real glimpse into the demanding world of elite sport.All this undercuts the tension around her unwanted pregnancy.Jadaone instead spends a chunk of screen time on soapy magical realism. An imaginary, foul-mouthed child follows Sunshine around, mocking her decisions. But instead of adding insight, this character becomes repetitive and irritating.Rhed Bustamante plays another pregnant teen, awkwardly inserted into the plot in an effort to cover too many sides of the abortion debate. But Rhed’s more serious situation makes Sunshine’s dilemma feel shallow—like a story about a girl careless with sex and unwilling to face the consequences.Some visuals in Sunshine hit hard: abortifacients sold beside religious icons outside Quiapo Church—a jab at how the Catholic Church, in practice, is more ritual than moral compass. There’s also a grim motel scene. But these moments can’t save the film.Set in the predominantly Catholic Philippines, where abortion is illegal, Sunshine tries to raise issues around teen pregnancy and reproductive rights, like overcrowded maternity wards. True enough, the Philippines has one of the highest teenage pregnancy rates in Southeast Asia, especially among the poor.But if a film brings this up, it must give some context. The Reproductive Health Law, passed only in 2012, was meant to help—but the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) continues to fight tooth and nail against sex education and birth control.The film ignores all this. Instead, it gives us a cartoonish, Bible-thumping doctor and a patriarchal pastor—villains standing in for real problems. We don’t expect to be spoon-fed, but when a film enters controversial ground and hints at bigger issues, it has a duty to avoid shallow symbols.In the end, Sunshine parrots Western slogans like “My body, my choice” without anchoring its stance in the Philippine context. The message feels imported and emotionally flat.READ FULL REVIEW (DAILY TRIBUNE): https://tribune.net.ph/2025/07/26/sunshine-review-abortion-tale-misses-the-mark

In a world full of questions like “Naiintindihan mo ba ako?”, dare to be the one who says, “Gets ko na.”The social relevance of this film lies in its powerful commentary on how women should be given the right to own their bodies. I’m in awe of how socially conscious the film is, and how realistically it depicts the struggles of women living in a conservative and non-progressive world.I truly hope people will be moved by this film and realize that it’s not just about faith and beliefs—it’s about giving women an equal chance at life by listening to them, understanding where they come from, and supporting where they want to go.This film should be seen, heard, and felt.At dahil diyan, oo sunshine—naiintindihan na kita.P.S. This film is not just about abortion. It’s deeper than that. It’s also about our healthcare system, and so much more. I won’t spoil anything else—just go watch it.

Ang lungkot.The credits started rolling and I sat there, dazed and tear-stained. I wanted to sing my praises to the movie (and I do!) pero mas nangibabaw sa akin ang sakit.Marami akong gustong punahin. Mga detalyeng mas lalong binigyan ng laman ang buhay ni Sunshine. Like how she was always framed between rails. Clearly an artistic choice, but to me, she was caged throughout the film. By judgment. By society's cruelty. By this country's refusal to grant women autonomy over their own bodies.Wherever she goes, the spaces are as narrow as her choices. Masikip sa bahay kung saan nakikita mo kung paano natapos ang pangarap ng ate niya. Masikip sa paaralan kung saan mag-isa niyang nilalabanan ang mga mapangmatang titig at pandidiri. Masikip sa Quiapo kung saan siya laging tumatakbo at naghahanap ng paraan para makalaya.Masikip sa ospital—ospital kung saan nilalarawan ang kakulangan sa magandang serbisyo. Ospital kung saan nahuhusgahan ang maraming kababaihan.The only time Sunshine's world seems to widen and glow is when she's inside the training center. Doon lang siya malaya. Doon lang may ngiti sa kanyang mga labi. At sana doon din natin maintindihan kung anong pinaglalaban ng pelikula. Sana gets mo na.Masaya akong may pelikulang ganito. Pero nangingibabaw ang lungkot. What if this is another film on the big screen that will be forgotten soon? I remember watching Brocka's Manila sa Kuko nang Liwanag and saw how many of its harsh truths are still prevalent today. Walang pagbabago. Walang usad. Mahirap pa rin.The real pain of the movie is when we watch it years later and the truth remains: women still have to bleed to fight for their rights.Sana hindi.

Layunin ng Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) na magkaroon ng kamalayan ang kabataan sa mga isyu ng seksuwalidad lalo pa na nasa yugto sila na tinutuklas ito. Sa kabilang banda, kontrobersiyal ito sa ating bansang Katolisismo ang pinakalaganap na relihiyon. Gayundin ang usapin ng aborsiyon. Sa panulat at direksiyon ni Antoinette Jadaone, isa itong pelikulang sports drama na umiikot kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na kailangan magpasiya kung ipagpapatuloy o hindi ang pagbubuntis habang papalapit ang kaniyang paglahok sa pambansang paligsahan sa rhythmic gymnastics. Walang tapon sa bawat kuha ng mga eksena, kahit na sa mga background audio nito, sapagkat sumisimbolo ito sa kalagayan ng Pilipina sa ating patriyarkal na lipunan. Nagustuhan ko ang panulat at direksiyon nito dahil sang-ayon sa sinabi ng aking kaibigan, naiparanas nito ang pakiramdam na may isa kang kakilala na kahalintulad ni Sunshine. Bukod dito, naiparamdam nito na kasama ka sa pelikula. Iyong tipong sinubaybayan mo rin ang paglalakbay ni Sunshine sa saanmang sulok ng Maynila. Kaya, makakaugnay at mailalagay mo ang sarili sa kalagayan ng pangunahing tauhan o sa sinuman. Malinis din ang pagkaka-edit ng pelikula sapagkat malinaw sa direktor kung ano ang nais niyang mangyari kay Sunshine. Piling-pili ang mga eksena kaya ang hirap pumili ng pinakamaganda o pinakanagustuhan. Hangang-hanga rin ako disenyong pamproduksyon nito dahil bukod sa ginalugad talaga ang madidilim na espasyo ng Maynila, iniisip ko kung paano sila nakapag-shooting sa ganoong karaming tao. Grabeng blockings niyon. Karapat-dapat talaga na papurihan si Racal sa kaniyang pagganap dito. Tama lamang ang timpla ng iba't ibang emosyon ang ipinamalas niya rito. Ngunit ang pinakanakabibilib sa lahat, magaling din ang mga pantulong na tauhan kaya napalitaw nito ang husay ng pangunahing artista. Ang tinginan nila ni Thea (Xyriel Manabat). Ang coach na tila pangalawang nanay na si Eden (Meryll Soriano). Ang misterysong batang babae (Annika Co). Ang kakampi na si Geleen (Jennica Garcia). Kahit na ang lokong si Miguel (Elijah Canlas). May ambag silang lahat upang mapagtibay ang karakterisasyon ni Sunshine at ang husay ni Racal. Ang ganitong pelikula ang nagbibigay ng dahilan kung bakit mahalaga na mayroong CSE at kung bakit kailangan mapag-usapan at mapag-isipan muli ang legal at siyentipikong pagpapalaglag. Babae man o lalaki, kahit na ang LGBTQIA+, binibigyan tayo nito ng awtoridad sa ating katawan. Sa kabuuan, nagustuhan ko ang "Fangirl" (2020) ni Direk Tonet na naglarawan ng estado ng babae sa rehimeng Duterte. Higit pa sa debate ng aborsiyon, napaibig ako sa "Sunshine" dahil sa pagpapakita nito ng tunay na ideya ng feminismo - ang pagkakaroon ng kalayaang pumili at ng kakampi.
Gets ko na.

If I’m being honest, Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine floored me. There is something in this film that’s raw and authentic. It’s devastatingly human. Sunshine addresses the women’s act of choosing (their dilemma) and the outcome of that act. Jadaone’s direction was fearless for depicting women’s struggles, reproductive rights and vulnerability, especially in the context of abortion (which is considered taboo here in the Philippines), while focusing on the titular character’s dream—was commendable. Its narrative structure, themes, relevance and layers were handled…

i rarely rave about indie films that tackle societal issues because the ones i've watched either sound too preachy or abstract that it's difficult to grasp. but sunshine proved to be different and that's why i loved it so much. it never tells you whether abortion is right or wrong. instead, it shows you a genuine depiction of the lived realities of girls like sunshine and mary grace and gets you thinking about the many other girls/women like them long after you leave the theater. ang hirap maging babae sa mundo, lalo na rito sa pilipinas pero pinaalala sa akin ni sunshine na kailangan kong tapangan at lumaban di lang para sa akin kundi para sa iba pang kababaihang kasama ko sa araw-araw na laban.

Sunshine presents a two-pronged takeoff on putting forth a controversial subject it aims to transfigure into a discourse. It’s gritty yet poignant, a dichotomy facilitated by careful restraint in its direction, intricate cinematography, and Maris Racal’s stellar performance.The film deflects clichés observed in Filipino melodramas that often rely on overly oppressive emotional tropes and techniques. Most notably, it veers away from positioning religion or the Church as a central source of female agency. Instead, it presents it as an androcentric institution where permission for a woman’s reproductive health decisions must be sought, implying a strong assertion of control and dominance over women’s bodies.Set against the backdrop of bustling, grunge-textured Manila, the camera takes a remarkable grasp on the parallelisms and minutiae of everyday life in the cruel city: a crowded train moving across the metro juxtaposed against a dreary room in Avenida; an abortifacient vendor sitting by a display of Mary Magdalene busts she sells in Quiapo; a tight-knit community devoid of love and empathy for a child.The film refuses to paint the gaps and seams of a faulty society in broad strokes. Sunshine is delicately crafted and measured. It deeply delves into the nuances and detailed complexities of living in a Christian society that has, ironically and deliberately, chosen to position women’s rights on the periphery.It taps into female solidarity as a form of agency and collective resistance, offering both an idealistic and pragmatic antithesis to the marginalization they have long been experiencing.Reminiscent of Antoinette Jadaone’s pre-studio works such as Plano (2004) and Saling Pusa (2006), Sunshine feels like a beautiful work of personal musings. It is honest, outrageous, yet tender—marking one of her greatest directorial masterpieces.
a narrative film that tackles relevant issues in the philippines: reproductive health, abortion, poverty, misogyny, etc.
Perfect casting. Beautifully written. Relevant.

I think it's safe to say by now that Antoinette Jadaone is one of the greats of Philippine Cinema. And not just of now, but of all time. The still-young filmmaker, who cut her teeth on quirky indie comedies ( Six Degrees of Lilya Cuntapay, Beauty in a Bottle) soon became the new queen of Pinoy Romantic Comedies, resulting in an 8-films-in-5-years streak that included classics like That Thing Called Tadhana, Never Not Love You and Alone/Together. Then in 2020, something changed. At the height of the pandemic, Tonet released Fan Girl -- an unflinching, searing commentary on celebrity worship, toxic masculinity and patriarchal oppression in the Philippines. It not only won all the major awards during that year's MMFF, but was also the highest-grossing film for that year. This makes Tonet somewhat of a unicorn: a writer/director who can make socially relevant, intelligent cinema but at the same time kill it at the box office. This feat is especially astounding in a year when zero films have actually made money. And so that six-year streak turned into a five-year absence, and wisely so. Tonet channeled her creative juices towards other roles and mediums: television, streaming, producing. I'm a big believer in taking care of one's filmography, and she's doing just that. And as fans we have finally been rewarded. Hello, Sunshine. Sunshine follows a slew of, and there's no non-blunt way to put it, abortion movies that have come to the fore in the 2020s. You have the US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always and France's L'Événement. All films follow the internal struggle and loneliness that women face when going through the abortion process. Of the three, Sunshine is the most powerful for one simple reason: it's set in the Philippines. And while it hits home because it is home, the oppression, hypocrisy and outright strangeness of the system makes this abortion story unique. It's a country where you can find ads for abortives just buy typing in "abortion" in your instagram search terms, where a vendor of Catholic paraphernalia situated outside a church will also peddle Cytotec, where a doctor who saves your life will also give you a 5-minute telling-to once you're well enough to listen. It's a country where self-righteous sanctimonium has endangered millions of young women's lives. Sunshine is pro-choice, but it's also pro-life. It never tries to turn away from the consequences and the trauma women go through when making this decision. And it shows us what could have been, never cheapening the lives that were lost. These layers, the emotional depth with which Tonet imbues Sunshine, are what sets it apart. It's a very thought provoking film, but it aims straight for the heart. I've spent all this time singing Tonet's praises, but of course Sunshine wouldn't be Sunshine without the brilliant Maris Racal. I meant it when I said that Maris is a generational talent: a true actress with genuine love for the craft who just also happens to be incredibly popular. She breathes so much life and attitude into Sunshine that she really feels like a friend. Someone you're rooting for, someone whose pain you understand.It's a very important film, but don't let its importance weigh you down. End of the day, like all of Tonet's films, it's a story well told with characters you genuinely care about. Sunshine is now showing in all SM Malls. Please do go out and catch it right away.

WOMEN INDEED HAVE THE MOST AUTONOMY OVER THEIR BODIES! PERIOD! Malinaw ang mensahe ng pelikula at napakaganda ng pagkakahabi ng istorya at kung paano ang repleksyon nito sa lipunan. Progresibo ang atake and it has the power to spark meaningful conversation and eventually i-glorify ang karapatan ng mga kababaihan sa kanilang sariling desisyon sa napakaraming bagay kabilang na ang kanilang katawan.The moment I heard about Sunshine, alam kong hindi ito basta-bastang pelikula. Worth it ang paghihintay. Para kay Maris ang film na ‘to. Walang ibang artista na dapat gumanap kundi si Maris lang, she perfectly owned this film. Grabe braincells ni Direk Tonet, napakahusay! Technicality speaking, grabe iba ang Pao Orendain walang tapon na cinematography shots grabe ang pulido. Screenplay, grabe sobrang husay ni Direk Tonet nangungusap ang bawat salita sa masa — malinaw ang mensahe at may pinaglalaban.Isa lamang to sad and painful reality ng mga kababaihan. Yung film na ‘to hindi lang siya kwento ng aborsyon, kwento rin ito ng mga taong handang sumuporta sa desisyon ng mga kababaihan — ate, kaibagan, coach etc. Grabe yung scene ni Jennica and Maris sa kama, it hit me so bad! Ultimately, these stories are real. These realities exist. Kaya ang isyu ng aborsyon ay importanteng pag-usapan, unawain, at huwag ipagsawalang bahala lamang. Totoo ang dinaranas ng napakaraming Sunshines sa Pilipinas. Salamat sa buhay at istorya mo, Sunshine! Gets ko na! Kuhang-kuha mo ang respeto at pagmamahal ko sa mga kababaihan, Sunshine! Pagbati sa buong produksyon. OSCAR WORTHY ANG ATAKE!!!!

Sunshine explores the balance beam of morality, tipping between the push to reclaim bodily autonomy and the pull of Catholic guilt. It’s interesting how the film’s key scenes are set in the dark, sketchy streets of Quiapo — a reflection of how young Filipinas navigate the lifelong, generational burden of taking control of our own bodies, while still trying to stay in line with the same dark and sketchy standards set by the very society that claims to protect us from it.

Another point is how much I love her sister’s character — sinuportahan niya kung anong gusto ng kapatid niya, without judgment.

This is the sunshine the country needs in today’s climate.It was Jadaone’s courage that popped in my head when the title card flashed, a very Filipina name that connotes brightness and warmth — two things the film was not intended for, two things the titular character was deprived of. Sunshine is a story of every Sunshine, a Filipino woman vulnerable to systemic injustice and oppression; a story no one could have been told better than a Filipino woman herself — and a fearless and intelligent one at that. From reproductive health and general health care system to conservatism, Jadaone’s care and spirit championed. Her personification of one’s conscience was beautifully done. I sobbed through the last 15 minutes.True-to-life darkness in the country executed from the literal streets to the contexts of quality of life through Orendain’s realism. There’s a harrowing frame in the movie that ticked all my boxes as a fan of dark cinematography. I bled in the dark with Sunshine right there.This film boasts a talented bundle of actresses: Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, Jennica Garcia, with Maris Racal tying the ribbon, flexing her acting muscles across different tones and needs. Well-written and well-directed performances with standouts coming from Garcia, Co, and Racal. Ah, women.Malalim. Matapang. Mahalaga. Hindi ako babae pero gets na gets kita, Sunshine.

Another masterpiece by Antoinette Jadaone.Sunshine is more than just a sports story. It's more than just an abortion as a movie subject. Sunshine is a long-overdue conversation, especially in the Philippines. A message that conveys abortion as health care, women's rights, and autonomy over their bodies and their lives. Sana gets niyo na—because in a system and a society with a twisted and blinded morals, kapwa mga babae lamang ang nag-sa-sakripisyo para protektahan ang isa't isa.Sunshine, mahirap man sa ngayon, pero gets kita. Gets ka namin. We got your back.

This movie encourages the discussion about reproductive health and how it harms more than it protects those who are directly involved the longer this societal taboo regarding topics like abortion and sex education gets ignored.Sobrang gets ko si Sunshine, magmula doon sa guilt, sa despair, hanggang sa acceptance niya na may karapatan siyang pumili ng nararapat para sa sarili niya. She did it not for anyone else but for herself. Sana mas dumami pa ang makaintindi hindi lang sa naging sitwasyon niya, sa sitwasyon ni Menggay, pero maging sa marami pang kwento ng bawat babae sa mundo.Movie wise, para sa akin, maganda ang pacing. Maayos na naihayag ang kwento ni Sunshine na hindi minadali. Sakto lang para maintindihan pero bibigyan ka pa rin ng karapatan bilang manonood na mag isip. Patawa-tawa lang madalas si Direk Tonet sa AWKP pero ang bawat kwento na inihahayag niya sa mga pelikula niya ay may kirot, may substance, may relevance. Talk about versatility, eme!

There is much to commend about the film and it could have been even more impactful had it fully leaned into its intention of confronting the realities surrounding abortion and calling out institutions to respond with compassion and accountability. While it could have been stronger had it fully explored the idea of safe abortion and pushed institutions to respond, the film’s restraint is understandable given the legal and cultural context. It opens the door for more Filipino films that reflect the lived experiences of many, especially women whose struggles have long been sidelined. Sunshine is deeply human, and in that honesty lies its strength.
Gets kita, Sunshine.

Within the streets live the busiest minds of pain and anguish that are continuously being punished by a conservative system. Totoong tapang, totoong kuwento, totoong bigat, at totoong pagpapakasakit na sana ay tumawid sa lakas na bumago sa kakulangan. This film vividly speaks that Sunshine's story of courage should not be romanticized or praised, but her womanhood and choice must be liberated.

“Bakit ka ba takbo nang takbo? Mahirap yan. Tumatakbo tapos di alam kung saan pupunta.”i faintly remember this video explaining the absence of young prodigies in the film industry. because unlike athletes, the field doesn’t merely rely on one’s prime to succeed. instead, it honors the individual’s maturity, discernment, and time spent in understanding life. this is what i felt in Direk Tonet’s recent slew of films. since Fan Girl (2020), it feels like she’s found her voice¹. informed, empowered, and deeply understanding. with her latest offering, Sunshine, i have to applaud her for having the guts to tell such a delicate story, a sensitive subject matter—in a predominantly Catholic country where abortion is illegal, no less.Sunshine’s charm lies in showing the grim reality of the city, the sheer obliviousness of the night, the secret alliance of the system and culture continually perpetuating harsh conditions for women and their bodies. it’s an incisive picture for us to empathize with the Sunshines of this world, with their dreams at the palm of their hands but their backs against the wall—deprived of freedom, options, and utmost support. and don’t you find it endearing that the ensemble that helped Sunshine’s reckoning are all women? from her gymnastics coach, the motel receptionist, her estranged bestfriend, the healthcare professional, and, of course, her loving sister².watching Sunshine is important to open the discussion and continue the conversation on women’s bodily autonomy. and maybe it all starts with an understanding, a mutual agreement, and someone who will say “Gets kita.” like a heartfelt acknowledgment.___¹ one could argue it’s already burgeoning since Never Not Love You (2018)² Jennica Garcia the artist that you are
