"Sunshine" is not just the greatest Filipino movie I've seen but one of the most important Filipino films of all-time! This film deals with controversial topics in our society, abortion and teen pregnancy. A week of national tryout for the gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal) finds out that she's pregnant. Conflicts arise as she has to decide what to do next. In between life and dreams, what's the most significant between the two?The film is unconventional at best. This is not your usual and average Filipino drama you'll see. It's a character study about a teenager who is on the down side of her life. We follow her journey through this life and see a glimpse of her life dealing with her problem. Maris Racal defines this film as Sunshine. Her acting here is brilliant. She's perfect for this role. Jennica Garcia surprised me. Her character as Sunshine 's sister marks! What she said to Sunshine near the ending, though it's common, is like a punch to tears! I ended up loving her character. Jennica Garcia deserves an award for being the best supporting actress for this role. Another cast that standout is Rhed Bustamante and Xyriel Manabat both deserve a recognition for their role.Blurring between reality and fantasy, mostly this film is realistic in portraying the whole theme thanks to Direk Antoinette Jadaone directions. Also, the cinematography is the best! Overall, "Sunshine" is a women's movie. It's timely, affecting and brave to its theme. It doesn't spoon feed. It will make you immersed and think. It's worth an experience. This is a rare Filipino movie I've seen! I'm glad and proud watching this in cinema. After watching "Sunshine", it leaves me with a question, "Is abortion a choice if your greatest dream will compromise?"

Antoinette Jadaone's most polished work yet since NEVER NOT LOVE YOU. With a very strong social commentary on unwanted pregnancy and abortion, Jadaone navigates the pain and heartbreak of a woman in the person of Maris Racal as SUNSHINE. A gymnast aiming for Olympics but the conflict arise when she got pregnant. With her electrifying performance a shoo-in already for the next award derby Maris is deserving of all the future trophies that will be bestowed to her.Maris Racal and Annika Co are both fantastic!SUNSHINE is what we need during bad times.

i mean before anything else: maris racal is RIDICULOUSLY good in this. like, she's really one of the greats we got in the philippines right now. i seriously need to tap into her other work.but wow. what a film. it never really tries to pull back with handling the topic of abortion and how taboo it is here. and it doesn't make it some overdramatic thing at points too because... it's all real, once we pull back one surreal element the film has. the way the people treat it, talk down on it, that near total disregard for the pregnant person. it's heartbreaking. watching this just made me think of how much people act like men and women are wholly equal under the eyes of the law in the philippines. but with incidents like what's seen in the film still happening, is that really the case?a real shame that this will be in like three theaters by the time wednesday rolls around. even then, i'm glad a film that handles a difficult topic was able to screen nationwide. i seriously hope this film resonates with people this opens up more minds.

MARIS RACAL IS JUST THE DAMN QUEEN!!!  thats my pbb bias right there bro  iyak ako hard cheee idk if what i'll say will do any justice to how i feel pero 1st things 1st..... that scene sa umpisa nung nalaman ni maris na buntis siya tas sumakay siyang jeep na nakapinturang "GIFT OF GOD" sa harap GODDAMN!!!! tas bumaba siya nun sa quiapo church para magsorry kay Hesus fak!!! that was so simple yet so poignant to me. that & the rest of the catholic imagery throughout!! how we view mga anak sa sapupunan as biyaya ng Diyos na di dapat tanggihan... so much deliberateness & intention... tas ang ganda nung dalawang frame na nasa kwarto si maris (nag-eensayo sa kwarto niya/nagttake nung gamot sa inn) tas kita yung kalye/kalsada. yung busina ng tren habang sinusubukan ni sunshine na magpalaglag, etc etc. tatak talaga siya sakin. the film never fails to let us know na tagarito si maris—ito ang syudad, ito ang sistema na bumibigo sa kanya at sa mga babaeng tulad niya. love how the message is clear without being too on the nose about it, the ugly state of the maternity ward, the doctors that serve the system vs those that TRULY serve the people, the kids that that teeter on magical realism and shatter the illusion of a fetus' seeming otherworldly potential once let out and born.
A thought-provoking perspective for those who are pro-life.

“gusto ko maging presidente!”“pano ka magiging presidente?”“magaartista muna ko” gets ko na, gets ko na gotta be one of the best, if not the best Filipino film I’ve ever seen! it tackled a taboo topic very well. they successfully showed different reactions to abortion—the supportive pro-choicers to the people who stigmatize it (even medical practitioners). in the context of the Filipino society and religion, throughout the film, religion has been prominent. from sunshine’s rituals when she performs, the quiapo setting, the hospital scene, and the scene with Miggy’s dad… it all had religious dialogue which makes it so realistic, so Filipino. The film successfully captured the nuances of a teenage girl in a college setting. Walang moments na napa-huh? ako because it was so well made (or maybe I’m just used to Filipino films [that i’ve seen] making me huh) Maris was phenomenal. Jennica was outstanding. Rhed Bustamante’s role was a wake up call, a disgusting wake up call about the reality some Filipino women and children live in.
dare to say movie of the year.gets ko na.

Interesting na rhythmic gymnastics ang sports ni Sunshine (Maris Racal). Hindi ito kilala sa ating bansa pero kitang-kita sa sports na ito na kailangan ng marinading determinasyon at disiplina hindi lamang sa larangan ng sports dito sa Pilipinas pati na rin sa paghahanda sa paglaban sa Olympics. Kaya naman ng mabuntis si Sunshine ay naharap siya sa isang desisyong babago sa kanyang buhay at sa mga tao sa paligid niya. Ilan sa mga isyu na nilatag ng pelikula ay ang kakulangan ng sex education at accessibility ng legal abortion sa Pilipinas dahil na rin sa konserbatibong paniniwala. Idagdag pa ang kulang na suporta ng gobyerno pagdating sa ating atleta tulad na lamang sa eksenang sila pa mismo ng pamilya niya ang naghanda ng kanyang isusuot sa Olympics. Religious hypocrisy din ang kinokompronta ng pelikula tulad sa eksenang giniguilt trip ng isang sarado Katoliko na OB GYNE at muli ring pang-guilt trip sa kanya ng pastor na ama ni Miggy kay Sunshine. Si Miggy ay pastor kid na nakabuntis sa dalaga. Hindi na rin naman bago ang pagtalakay ng abortion sa Pilipinas sa pelikulang Pilipino dahil nariyan ang "High School Scandal" (1982) sa direksyon ni Gil Portes at "Hinugot sa Langit" (1985) na pinagbidahan ni Maricel Soriano at dinirek ni Ishmael Bernal. Ang kagandahan ng pelikula ay babaeng filmmaker ang lumikha at alam niya ang nadarama at pinagdadaanan mapa-pisikal, emosyonal at sikolohikal ng kapwa babae. Napakahusay ni Maris Racal sa pelikulang ito. Ang laking tulong ng cinematog kasi 'yun ang nag-set ng tone at mood ng pelikula over-all. Somewhat reminded of "Gusto kita with all my hypothalamus" pagdating sa cinematog. Regarding sa discussion of abortion, medyo closer sa controversial indie film na "Call Jane".

sunshine enlightened me on so many aspects of my womanhood that i feel like i haven't been able to sit down and reflect on yet. sunshine and i are different but i felt her struggle with not knowing what to do with what was going on in her body, and not wanting to disappoint the women and family who have built her up to reach her dream that is now at risk. i knew how it felt to have female friendships i turned to for support and strength, and how heartbreaking it is to lose them. so many scenes made me tear up because of how much it felt like it could really happen and how much it does happen. there are relatives that talk like that and there are doctors that have to risk their license to do exactly what a doctor should do. each theme and character was so intentionally and realistically portrayed that it all made sense, even to the part of my mind that plays devil's advocate when it comes to films like this.sunshine really is a must-watch for everyone para ma-gets mo na.ang galing tlga ng cast bruh

SUNSHINE (2024)3.8/5 SAME, ARIANA… She’s a main biàtch!! HAHAHAHA GETS KO NA!! Isa sa mga pinakapulidong gawa ni Direk Tonet. Ka-EME represent, alongside “Never Not Love You” & the iconic “Beauty In A Bottle” and “That Thing Called Tadhana.” Maris Racal literally emanated Sunshine!! She’s a ray of sunshine. This film is really for her. I didn’t know who else can bring Sunshine to life than her. & ANNIKA CO & JENNICA GARCIA…. ACTING MASTERCLASS!! MY FAVES IN ONE FRAME!! THE Xyriel Manabat could’ve been maximized more kasi halimaw sa actingan masterclass, but I think she had a proper exit. It is a delight to see Ms. Angeli Bayani’s presence contrary to her former portrayals. Her character only appeared for how many seconds, BUT THE IMPACT OF HER EXPOSURE IS OVER THE TOP!! Ang nagpalaylay sa storyline is not the open ending, but a rushed conclusion of the problem. Nasagot nga ba ang problema? Anong nangyari kina Miggy at Sunshine? Is ‘Ari-yun-uh’ also a personification that Sunshine only imagine, like Annika’s character? Hindi ko maramdaman ang father and son dynamic nina Elijah Canlas and Mr. Piolo Pascual. However, Piolo’s character, as Pastor Jaime could’ve been explained and discovered more, and not pressed in a few minute exposure. What stood out in the film were Maris, Jennica, Annika, and “Ariana”‘s portrayal. Also, Sunshine, due to her juvenile age, can be prone to misconception and misinformation. In a predominantly Catholic country wherein proper sex education and proper healthcare system are nowhere to be found, and practices are dictated by religion and morality, relying on social media platforms as search engines would mean that she’s susceptible to wrong notions of her reality, which may lead her to resort to the sudden decisions that she make. The debate between religion and choice is long-going in the Philippine context. If the international audiences accepted this film with open arms, it’s about time that the Philippines does the same, and the film’s message would transgress to those without an open mind and for those who are unawakened with the harsh realities that most “Sunshine” faces.

Manila in its rawest form. I was teary eyed through the whole movie but something in the scenes always felt lacking. And then I remembered some actual close friends who were once in the same situation, who once asked for my help and company. That what they actually needed was people who would understand and hear them and not who would feel bad for them. This did not intend to resolve anything, cos we have been seeing this in real life and in the news. But this was a good reminder that after all these headlines, after all the movies that tackled the same story, and after all the social media awareness, IS IT’S STILL A PERSISTING PROBLEM FOR MANY FILIPINO CHILDREN AND WOMEN. That we have still yet to save these women, that our authorities still don’t care, and these women are still in danger. MALALA ANG HEALTHCARE, MALALA RIN ANG JUDGMENT! I’m pro-choice because I advocate for a world where children could be children and play freely and grow old and love the life that’s ahead of them. I LOVE YOU SUNSHINE FRIENDS! Your reasons will die with me <3

Ito ang ibig kong sabihin kapag sinasabi kong may problematic pattern sa ilang pelikula. Layunin nito ay marahil ipakita ang pinakamasalimuot na kalagayan ng ating lipunan, subalit nauuwi lagi sa paggamit ng trauma at karahasan bilang device lamang. Sa paraang ito, yumuyugto ang kawalan ng respeto sa lived experiences ng mga biktima. Sunshine, however, is not that kind of film.Sa halip na pagsamantalahan ang lunan ng karanasan ng mga kababaihan, pinili ng pelikula na maging mapanagot. It is a story about women, in a world that constantly tries to pin them and to deny them full autonomy and diginity for themselves. Naging maingat at makatao si Direk Tonet sa treatment niya rito sa Sunshine. Hindi niya sinensationalize ang karahasan, bagkus ginawa ito nang may paggalang. Inilantad ang katotohanan pero hindi iniwan sa dulo ang mga biktima at maging ang mga manonood. In this film, we see a woman who is brave. A woman who insists on choosing for herself. A woman who, despite everything, claims her shine. To Sunshine, and to many sunshines out there: ang sinag ninyo ay magmumula sa inyo lamang. Hindi ito hinihiram, hindi ito ibinibigay, sa inyo ito at sa inyo lamang. Kasi gaano man kadilim ang lipunan sa atin, women will always be the brightest.

the film's message is very clear.3.5 for now, since we missed the first few scenes which might have included the entire plot build up -- will definitely rewatch, so i am hoping for the best thaat the universe finds a way to add more show dates... or i'll just have to wait for it to become available on a streaming platform.definitely felt the authenticity of sunshine. i know for sure that sunshine is a character woven from real-life experiences of women in our society. and if one day we cross paths with a sunshine in our lives, i truly hope we meet her with compassion and empathy. nawa'y magawa natin siyang intindihin, yakapin, suportahan, at samahan siya nang walang halong pag-aalinlangan—lalo na ang mga biktim ng mga tarantadong kalalakihan na punong-puno ng libido at kasinungalan sa katawan. tototo ang mga sunshine at ang kanilang mga karanasan.let women decide for themselves.let women speak for themselves.let women be heard.let women express themselves.women deserve choices and options.women should help women.men are trash. let's take down the patriarchy.gets din kita, shine. just like your siblings and best friend stayed with you until the very end, no matter what you chose, i am with you, sunshine. you will never be alone.

“Ang pangarap niya ay pangarap ko rin”Habang pinapanuod ko ‘to di ko maiwasan maalala yung mga students ko babae na maaga nabuntis. Magkakaiba ng kwento pero pinagkapareho nila ay babae ang laging talo sa kwento. Higit sa pasanin nila sa buhay dahil sa pagbubuntis. Dala rin nila yung panghuhusga ng mga tao. Lalabas na malaki ang tyan e, masasabihan ng malandi, mapusok o disgrayada. Dala rin ng babae yung hirap na pisikal, mental at pinansyal ng pagbubuntis. Habang ang nakabuntis sa kanila - madalas buhay binata na. Walang dalang kahit anong bakas ng kahihiyan. Isa rin sa pinaka nalulungkot ako, ay pansamatalang hihinto ang buhay ng mga pangarap ng batang ito para magbigay daan sa dinadala niya. Hindi lahat ng babae ay may privilege na makapag aral muli o mapursige ang pangarap nila pagkatapos magkaanak.Hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Hirap maging babae.Laging talo sa mundo di tayo kinakampihan.Sana mapanuod pa ng mas madami. Safe and accessible option for abortion sa Pinas isulong na.

one thing i loved with sunshine is that it really makes you feel her struggle and her dilemma.i'm a guy, i could never really personally go through what sunshine experienced in the movie, but i could still feel what she felt. the struggle between putting your dreams to a halt because of one setback and pushing through despite it all.i was a bit worried that the movie would somehow swerve in the middle with its message, and i'm glad it didn't. it really committed the whole time and it tackled such a sensitive topic with seriousness and grace.the movie showed us how difficult simply living as a woman in the philippines could be, so much so that the only characters seen helping sunshine are women for the most part.maris racal is a generational talent, and sunshine is proof that she is and always will last in this industry if she is just given scripts where she can shine.(p.s. piolo pascual is just the spitting image of my dad at this point that it took me out of the movie for a while)(p.p.s. who decided to hire rico blanco for the score and what was their thought process behind the whole thing)

Nauso na sa mga Pinoy viewers na hihintayin na lang nila sa Netflix yung mga pelikulang Pilipino. Para raw makatipid. Pero karamihan sa kanila, willing gumastos kapag Western superhero movie ang papanoorin. Gets naman din kasi nga may escapism kapag sinasalba ni Superman o ng Fantastic Four ang New York City kumpara sa mga realist stories sa Pilipinas. Bat nga naman kailangan ng malaking screen para lang makitang nag-aaway si Dingdong Dantes at Charo Santos?Pero please, panoorin niyo ang mga pelikulang Pilipino sa big screen, lalo na yung may magandang istorya na maaaring magbigay-linaw pa sa mga isyu. Tulad na lang ng Sunshine ni Antoinette Jadaone. Tungkol ito kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na naghahanap ng paaran na magpa-abort dahil sa napakaraming rason: hindi planado ang kanyang pagbubuntis, ayaw siyang panagutan ng nakabuntis sa kanya, ayaw na siyang samahan ng kanyang kaibigan, pagtsi-tsismisan siya, at mauudlot ang kanyang pangarap na maging Olympian. Sa dami ng kanyang rason, simple lang naman ang kanyang dahilan: ayaw pa niya maging nanay.Ito ang unang Pinoy film na napanood ko na talagang sinusulong ang karapatan ng babae para sa kanyang katawan. At sa dami ng pinagdaanan ni Sunshine, kahit na may reservations ka sa isyu ng abortion, gugustuhin mong matupad ang gusto ng ating bida. Ramdam na ramdam ko kay Maris ang mga dinadalang problema ni Sunshine hindi lamang bilang isang aspiring Olympian kundi ang isang pagiging babae sa Pilipinas kung saan malakas ang impluwensya ng Catholic values sa ating mga batas.Intersectional din ang pagtalakay ni Jadaone sa isyu ng abortion sa Sunshine. Hindi ito basta-bastang women's rights na nakita natin sa Western media tulad ng Barbie (2024) at Sex Education (2019-2023). Hindi itinanggi o dinemonize ng pelikula ang Catholic guilt pero hinimay ito sa pamamagitan ng pag-humanize nito sa anyo ng batang babae na sumusunod kay Sunshine (Annika Co). Ang ganda ng chemistry nina Maris at Annika at ramdam mong iisa lang talaga sila.So, bakit nga ba dapat panoorin ang Sunshine sa sinehan imbes na hintayin sa Netflix o ano mang streaming service? Napakalalim ng isyu ng aborsyon at women's rights na dapat bigyan ito ng full attention. Pag naman nanonood tayo sa streaming service, may tendency tayong mag-check ng phone. Pero hindi dapat tayo ma-distract habang pinapanood natin si Sunshine. Pag naman sobrang intimidating yung scene, pwede nating i-pause. Pero sa mga ganitong storya, dapat hindi ito pina-pause. Ma-disturb dapat tayo sa ganitong kwento.

iba ka talaga, maris! sobrang hanga ako sa buong screenplay, walang unnecessary details. i am so so sooo delighted with the execution until the end. naramdaman ko ang hagupit ng pagiging babae. at mas nag-alab pa ang apoy sa aking puso upang ipaglaban ang ating karapatan nang aking lubusang masaksihan na ang mga pangyayari sa pelikula ay nangyayari sa totoong buhay at mas malala pa sa iba na walang akses sa sex education.tayong mga babae ay may pangarap, ngunit ang pag-asam nito ay may kaakibat na balakid na hindi madarama ng mga lalake. this is such an important film in our culture. ilang beses ako napa-“tangina” sa mga diyalogo ng mga relihiyosong tao at ng mga putanging mga lalaking walang bayag at konsensiya pero putok nang putok. kababaihan na nga ang nagdadala ng buhay, tapos sila pa lagi ang nakukutya. nasaan ang hustisya?reproductive rights are human rights and decriminalizing abortion will save a lot of women, lalo na ang mga batang babaeng walang kamuwang-muwang. hindi natatapos ang pakikibaka sa pelikula lamang kundi sa paghingi ng accountability sa gobyerno at pagbago sa kaisipan ng mga patriyarkal at konserbatibong tao. i hope many people would watch this and say, “gets ko na.” kasi gets na gets ko. sobra.

this isn’t a story about sunshine, it’s a story about women — and it’s a poignant, well-told story about filipino women at that. sunshine lays all its cards on the table during the first 15-30ish mins of the film. i thought that was its weakness, then it turned out to be its greatest strength. and its clear that direk tonet does her job with so much thoughtfulness and care. there’s some storytelling choices i questioned at first — but when i held on it was worth it.and of course, this is maris racal’s magnum opus… she will always be famous idgaf!

GETS KO NA.I cried so much during this film. I just wanted to hug Sunshine. This story speaks about abortion, rape and the difficult choices women are forced to make. It’s heavy but it’s also a raw portrayal of reality that many experience but few talk about. The musical score and sound design are so natural, perfectly complementing the story. I literally got chills and cried when she entered the Inn.What struck me the most is how the film doesn’t romanticize pain it shows the truth as it is. Sunshine’s journey feels real and vulnerable and it makes you think about how every decision carries weight and responsibility. The use of her future child as a reminder of her choices was powerful and emotional.The film speaks about rights, life and the struggles of women how society pressures them while they’re just trying to survive and live freely. It’s a story that stays with you long after the credits roll. The best ka, Maris Racal!

This film touched me in ways I could never have imagined.It truly reflected the struggles of women seeking to abort their unborn children. In a country where Catholicism dominates, even in law, abortion is viewed as taboo and a sin against the Lord Almighty, rather than as a procedure that can preserve someone's mental health and offer a way to escape the endless economic hardships we face.It’s heartbreaking how inaccessible abortion is here. So many people end up resorting to dangerous methods just to find the peace they desperately need.The plot twists kept me on the edge of my seat—I absolutely loved this film.

Antoinette Jadaone, gets ko na. Took me a minute to pause, reflect, and absorb the film with all of it. The power of the film is the way it presents and tackles about womanhood and abortion. How Jadaone, shows, and you get it without needing the tell part.Every woman in the film is amazingly presented. From the coach, doctor, sister, and teenager. I’m giving injustice and lackluster narrative of how powerful, impactful, and lustrous the film is. Each frame is enthralling, given Maris’ powerful performance and how raw Manila is portrayed. You take it as it is. The mess, powering through the noise, and living it all every single day.The film also presents a huge middle finger to the hypocrisy of abortion and religion and how the only time Sunshine (Maris) felt free from her prison, which I must say is visually and creatively presented in the film is through her passion as a gymnast. Will try and revise this to write a cohesive review, but definitely glad I got the opportunity to watch this at the cinema.

either may kakilala kang parang si sunshine, or muntik nang maging si sunshine, or baka muntik ka nang maging si sunshine, or ikaw mismo si sunshine. or, you know, nanood ka lang at may naramdaman. at okay lang rin yun.yung gusto ko na ginawa ng pelikula ay na-explore niya yung delusyon ng unborn child ng isang babae. para sa akin ay innate feminine thing ito-- nagpapakita sila minsan sa panaginip. nagpakita yung akin sa isang panaginip. natakot ako. to have that fear manifest itself as this metaphysical, illusionary child that follows you around when faced with an unwanted pregnancy is so poignant and sickening. pasan talaga ng babae ang mundo dahil ang sarili niyang pag-iisip ay kinakalaban ng katawan niya. ng utak niya. and maybe that's why na-appreciate ko yung approach ng pelikula at ng writer-director na gamitin yung speaking-unborn-child motif na favorite ng mga pro-lyfers because to make someone see or understand something, you have to speak their language. may constant negotiation ang pelikula with its audience. take me seriously, pls, hear me out. wag mong tatanggalin ang mata mo sa screen. umiyak ka. sabing umiyak ka! and you know what, it closed the deal come the final show. i just wish it didn't end with that "gets ko na" line. nitpicky lang ako pero feel ko talaga mas maganda kung sa isang tanong siya nag end tapos final bow niya. wala naman kasi talagang makakaintindi sa buong sitwasyon mo, sunshine. matapang ka. nahihirapan ka. nararamdaman namin yun. but no one will ever understand how it feels until you are in that position.

for once there's no film that quite match what Sunshine did to me, emotionally. an absolute knockout in terms of its concept of bringing controversial topics about abortion and the struggle women face in search for accessible healthcare in the philippines on screen. it's rare to find films that touch most of the pressing issues in our culture, society, politics, and even in reproductive health. this was by far the most distressing and deeply harrowing depiction of teenage pregnancy i've watched since never rarely sometimes always. i'm on the edge of my seat the whole time. sobrang ganda na halos ako nakilabutan at napaiyak sa sudden escalation of events. must watch huhu.Ang tunay na sining ay nagsasalamin sa totoong pangyayari sa buhay, at ang pelikulang ito, ang pelikulang Sunshine, ay nagsisilbing patunay na buhay na buhay ang sining nating mga Pilipino.
A HORROR FILM FOR FILIPINAS AS WE WATCH THE PORTRAYAL OF OUR HELPLESSNESS AND LACK OF CHOICES REGARDING OUR BODIES, OUR LIVES!!!

Women are frequently placed in situations where they feel they have no choices due to the regressive and harsh judgment of society regarding our rights, particularly our right to safe healthcare. Sunshine, as a whole, has stood firm in its mission, showing why such story is important, as women continue to endure the repercussions of societal choices that place us in jeopardy. This film is undoubtedly one of those that was treated with so much care, showing little to no romanticization of the anger and struggles the characters faced, and most importantly, it did not conform to conservative ideologies.Maris Racal is definitely an actress to keep an eye on; her artistry and commitment to her craft shine through in this film. She certainly delivered one of the most valiant depictions of women in cinema, and it felt just right for her to bring the character of Sunshine to life.And of course, Antoinette Jadaone, who consistently brings depth and authenticity to her female characters, has done it again. As many have said, while anyone can create sociopolitical films, having women write and direct them adds a special touch that connects us to our shared struggles. Jadaone knows exactly how to write her female characters, and there’s nothing more beautiful than a woman who values the lives, journeys, successes, and struggles of her fellow women. Ultimately, as the film shows, it’s women who always end up caring for one another. May we live in a lifetime where abortion is decriminalized and seen as a fundamental aspect of healthcare for every woman, ensuring that no woman ever has to confront death or risk her life due to circumstances that leave her with no choice.
ABANTE BABAE!

it feels like watching social media debates on abortion come to life. it covers familiar arguments, from “what if the baby could be a future president” to real situations like abuse, unplanned pregnancies, and women not ready for motherhood. seeing it unfold makes the issue hit harder than words alone.it also calls out how both religion and close minded people can push views that ignore lived experiences. i loved how the possible future children were portrayed, like the little girl who acts just like sunshine, or the “tomboy’s” child being gay. the scenes felt real yet creative, and maris’s acting was excellent.

took me some time to process that a filipino movie about a stigmatized issue was watched by a full theater (that included gen x/boomers!) even when 2 big hollywood films were screening too. this almost never happens to our indie films. props to the team for carefully crafting this. it won’t easily change people’s minds, sure, but it opens up conversations about long-hidden stories of struggle. that’s better than nothing.

Wala akong sapat na karanasan para makipagdiskusyon ukol sa screenplay, sa directing, sa musical scoring, o sa writing ng pelikulang 'to. Pero dahil matapang na inilahad ni Direk Tonet ang kwento ng sangkababaihan, naiparamdam niya sa akin na sapat ang kaalaman ko para maintindihan ang gusto niyang iparating. Nasaksihan ko ang pelikulang isinulat hindi para mamilit, ngunit para magkwento.Para ito sa lahat ng naging ate, coach, menggay, doc helen, at iba pang kababaihan sa pelikula na nagpapatatag ng isang pagkatao sa mapanghusgang mundo. Mga babaeng nagpapadali sa mga karanasan ng kapwa kababaihan. Higit sa lahat, para ito sa iba pang mga Sunshine na piniling makawala sa pinaghalo-halong boses ng prinsipyo, moralidad, paniniwala, at kristiyanismo, para piliin ang pangarap niya.Kung iisipin, iisang Maynila ang nilalakaran, nasasaksihan, dinarasalan, at pinupuntahan natin. Pero iba’t-ibang buhay at konsepto ang pinaniniwalaan ng bawat kaluluwang minsan nang nanatili dito.Sa pagkilala ng mga babaeng piniling ialis ang kapit niya sa limitado at panandaliang kalayaan na ibinibigay ng sistemang ito, at sa panonood ng pelikula kahit hindi ikaw si Sunshine, sana maintindihan mo.

Tumatak sakin yung laging sinasabi ni coach kay sunshine, drown out the noise.Kaya sa tuwing may scene na tumatahimik, walang music, walang background noise, walang dialogue, di ko mapigilan maging emotional.Pati yung mga ibang cast, si jennica, xyriel, meryll, si doc elena. Di makakaya ni sunshine pag wala sila, kapwa babae lang makakaintindi sa problema niya.And si Maris? Gago tangina ang galing.

Dreams carry a powerful force—one that can drive people beyond the bounds of their morals. In the film Sunshine, this force is embodied by a young gymnast, whose ambition, fueled by society’s expectations of fame, pushes her to the edge—physically, psychologically, and morally—as she struggles with the weight of success and an unplanned pregnancy. Surrounding her are characters who reflect and intensify this tension: a doctor torn between personal ethics and the responsibility of helping an abortion patient; a street vendor selling both faith and death, caught in her own contradictions; a friend navigating the rift between her parents’ choices and her own agency; and a coach who, in relentlessly pushing her to break physical limits, unknowingly drives her toward moral collapse. The film offers a counterpoint through the voice of a child—a quiet yet powerful presence that serves as both an echo of the gymnast’s inner conscience and a projection of the expectations society imposes on her. This voice becomes a haunting reminder of who she is and who she is expected to be, grounding her in an innate moral compass even as she’s pulled deeper into chaos, anxiety, and confusion.Sunshine presents a world where the pursuit of dreams comes at a cost, and where ambition blurs the lines between resilience and ruin.

Usually, yung mga movie reviews ko nasa FB/IG stories ko lang but this movie deserves space on my feed.Relevant. Truthful. Brave.Simply the best Pinoy film of 2025 so far. To think na Marvel's Fantastic Four ang kasabay na pelikula nito sa sinehan, nagulat ako na puno yung sinehan na pinanuoran namin sa SM City North EDSA. Buti nalang, wala sya nung classic "Pinoy 3rd act curse" like Kathryn Bernardo's A Very Good Girl. Actually, the last act pa nga ang strongest part of the film.This is the kind of conversation na kailangan talaga natin pag usapan -- reproductive rights, lack of access to quality healthcare, and so much more.I hope mas marami pa ang makapanuod nitong movie na 'to.

pramis gusto ko talaga magsulat ng makabuluhang review tungkol sa pelikulang ‘to kaso puro “tangina” lang nasabi ko sa sinehan, at hanggang ngayon tangina pa rin.saka ilang movie review na rin ang dumaan sa feed ko na nabasa ko, feeling ko influenced na ang thoughts ko.basta…gets naman ng halos lahat kung ano mensahe nung pelikula di ba?ang bigat bigat lang talaga niya. agree ako sa isang review na nabasa ko dito—na sa sobrang realistic ng mundo na ipinakita ng pelikula, medyo naligaw ako ako dun sa element na apparition na bata (na at this point, parang wala nang may pake kung sino ba talaga siya). pero inenterpret ko na lang siya bilang bata na magiging anak sana ni sunshine… nung nakita ko naman na dinudugo rin siya sa hita kasabay ni sunshine, naisip ko na baka batang sunshine pala siya. pero kung ano man ang totoo (kung may totoo in the first place) i would say it all worked out for me, lalo na with the ending of the film.ang galing galing ni maris racal. tangina. i believe walang ibang makakagawa nito kundi siya at si direk tonet jadaone. saludo!!!sana makagawa rin ako ng gantong pelikula tangina

Mga kabataan ngayon di makapagpigil.Sabi ng bantay sa botika na buntis.I like any movie that utilizes metaphors to emphasize the severity of a situation. I think Annika's character was such an important part of the movie—despite others saying it downplayed the severity of the situation since it was a whimsical concept—since it brought contrast as well as a different but important point of view in such a controversial topic.

4.5/5I think this is one of those films that I will not just 100% get—not because it was badly written or executed—rather, it is such a lived experience (even phenomenological) that is scathing, intense, and too real.But Jadaone & Maris Racal (and the whole ensemble!) made this film so empathetic, bold, and brave to actually tackle and make you realize what the social reality is. The collective Filipino religious trauma, poverty, crime, the lack of accessible healthcare—it's all encompassing with Sunshine's experience (and to all Filipinas as well).Gets kita, Sunshine. Ang pangarap mo ay pangarap ko rin.

i find it hard to explain the experience of watching Sunshine it left me with a heavy heart, a quiet kind of ache, and a deep reflection. pero isang bagay ang malinaw, mahirap maging babae lalo na sa mundong paulit-ulit kinukuwestyon ang iyong mga desisyon, ang iyong halaga, at ang iyong tinig.kaya i have so much admiration for Direk Tonet and the entire team behind Sunshine for their boldness and honesty. it takes real courage to create a film that confronts the silences, the shame, and the societal fears around topics we often push aside especially in a country like ours where conservatism still tries to drown out stories like these. despite the progress we’ve made as a society, there are still so many walls around conversations that women desperately need to have.as a woman, i felt seen. i felt understood. and more importantly, i felt less alone. Sunshine gives voice to the quiet suffering that many Filipinas carry stories of pain, confusion, guilt, and survival. it doesn’t offer simple answers, but it offers empathy. and that’s powerful.i hope more Filipinos get to watch this film, not just to be entertained, but to really listen. to open their hearts and minds to the struggles of women they may not fully understand. i hope it challenges them to reflect, to unlearn, and to care more deeply about the rights and realities of women.sana magets niyo rin

How does a young woman endure a life filled with “faithfuls” who feel morally superior to judge and ridicule her choices in a society riddled with antiquated beliefs, further magnified by patriarchal politics where men can walk away without responsibilities and consequences? How do you thrive when institutions that are supposed to protect you are trying to pin you down? Maris Racal shines as the titular character Sunshine, hindi sumosobra o kinukulang, raw, honest, perfectly capturing a young woman in turmoil while trying to show a facade that everything is okay. She is supported by an amazing cast: Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Xyrel Manabat, Piolo Pascual, Rhed Bustamante, and the most affecting performance of Jennica Garcia.This film captures the gritty essence of Manila without being patronizing or didactic. Each frame is filled with ironies: abortion drugs sold beside a church, a repeated shot of split windows showing dreams, chaos, judgement, and slivers of kindness. One shot in particular shows Sunshine rehearsing at home, on the split side are young people probably coming home from a fun night, kasi bata lang naman si Sunshine and she is willing to sacrifice everything for her dreams, at napakarami pang tulad niya, lahat sila hindi napapakinggan. Listen, read, learn, resist until every woman has autonomy over her body.Drown out the noises, lift your head, close your eyes, and let your light pull you through.

“gets mo na ‘ko?” id like to believe that the kid was a depiction of sunshine’s conscience and its such a powerful statement to put out there — that sunshine didnt have anyone to convince but herself. that its okay as long as the choice was hers and not anyone else’s, especially in a society that often robs women the decision to make a choice in the first place.and despite the loud and often guilt-ridden noises that paralleled the packed and polluted streets of manila, it contested the catholic and cis-heteropatriarchal belief that the sole purpose of womanhood is motherhood and to choose to become someone else is to sin. but sunshine wouldn’t have come through all odds if it weren’t also for the women in her life that chose to show up for her. the only thing more powerful than the dangers that women are constantly subjected to, are the embrace of fellow women who just understand it. sunshine didn’t even have to utter a single word, her silence, both in her vulnerable and fearless moments, was heard. the quiet glances between her and thea, reassuring her that she is seen. her sister’s arms reaching out to her in bed, making her presence known and reminding sunshine that she’d never be alone, the gentle squeeze of menggay’s hands to let her know she’s safe. they all heard and seen each other, and having someone who’s willing to carry and share your burden with is enough for everything else to be bearable. gets na gets kita Sunshine, at sana mas marami pang mga pilipino ang makarinig at makaintindi sa’yo at sa kuwento mo.

Sunshine tells the story of a 19-year-old gymnast pursuing her dream of making it to the national team to compete in the SEA Games and eventually, the Olympics until a life-altering event changes everything.Ito marahil ang isa sa pinakamahalagang pelikulang Pilipino ngayong taon, o baka pati na rin sa buong dekada. Hindi ito nagpaligoy-ligoy sa layunin nitong maglahad ng katotohanan masakit man ito o hindi.Unang tumatak sa akin ang pangalang Antonette Jadaone noong napanood ko ang That Thing Called Tadhana. Mula noon, sinusubaybayan ko na ang kanyang mga pelikula maging ito man ay romcom, crime, psychological, o political. Siya at si Direk Dan Villegas ay palaging may tatak: may kirot, may kurot, at higit sa lahat, may lalim.Ang Sunshine ay isang napapanahong pelikula na nagsisilbing mitsa para sa mahahalagang diskusyon: ang kalagayan ng mga atleta sa bansa, ang sistemang pangkalusugan at pang-edukasyon, pananampalataya, gender roles, at higit sa lahat, ang karapatan ng kababaihan sa sariling katawan.Madalas nating marinig: “Ang anak ay biyaya.” Pero kailan nga ba ito nagiging biyaya? Kailan naman ito nagiging pasanin? Ang isang pagbubuntis ba sa murang edad ay dapat tawaging biyaya, lalo na kung ito ay dumating sa panahong hindi pa handa ang isang babae? O isa itong uri ng sumpa, bunga ng sistemang mapanghusga?Hindi laging pisikal ang pang-aabuso sa kababaihan. Minsan, ito ay nasa anyo ng mga ideolohiyang pinipilit ipalunok sa kanila. Kapag inagaw mo ang kakayahan nilang magdesisyon para sa sarili nilang katawan, para sa kinabukasan nila, para sa mga pangarap nila, iyon ay anyo ng pang-aabuso.Wala nang mas akmang gumanap bilang Sunshine kundi si Maris Racal. Ang kanyang pagganap ay puno ng puso’t tapang mula sa kanyang mga sulyap, bawat paghinga, hanggang sa mga katahimikan niya sa ilang eksena. Nararamdaman mo ang kanyang sakit, pangarap, at takot. Isa ito sa mga pinakamahusay na performance ng isang aktres sa kasalukuyang panahon.Ang buong ensemble cast ay maingat na pinili mula kina Elijah Canlas, Meryll Soriano, Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Rhed Bustamante, Xyriel Manabat hanggang sa mga may limitadong eksena ngunit tumatak: Juan Miguel Garcia, Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, at Piolo Pascual. Bawat karakter ay may silbi sa masalimuot ngunit malinaw na salaysay ni Sunshine.Ang pelikulang ito ay malakas, matapang, at mapanghamon. Hindi ito madaling kalimutan. Hindi kami agad nakatayo matapos ang closing credits hindi dahil baka may post-credit scene kundi dahil ninanamnam pa namin ang bigat ng mensahe nito.Sa huli, isang malaking saludo kay Direk Tonet Jadaone. Maraming salamat sa liwanag at lakas ng Sunshine. Sa panahong maraming gustong manahimik, pinili mong magsalita. Mabuhay ka, Direk!Rating:  (5/5 - unanimous)

God forbid a woman chooses herself.Sunshine is a film I recommend every woman in my life to see—yes, also those who belong to the earlier generations. How I wish a film like this existed when I was around Sunshine's age. This film isn't just about teenage pregnancy and women's reproductive rights. It's also about courage and knowing oneself better than anyone can. I wish any girl who's forced to choose between herself and other people's plans for her—no matter how more reasonable they are—gets to realize it's not a sin to pick the former, especially if it leads to a more purposeful life for her. And with this, I also hope that the girls who do so, gets to have the same support system Sunshine has. I am a woman.I get to choose the life I want for me.I am not a baby-making machine.I am more than my womanly traits.Mahal kita, Sunshine, at gets kita.

Sunshine (2025, Project 8 Projects)I acknowledge that there are a lot of things in life I take for granted as a cisgender man. In Antoinette Jadaone’s new film, Sunshine, she presents a flawed yet heartbreaking tale on the female cost of pregnancy.In the film, we follow nineteen-year-old Sunshine, who has dedicated most of her life, along with the support of her sister who was also a former gymnast, in rhythmic gymnastics and her pursuit to enter the Philippine team for the Olympics. However, several weeks before the National tryouts, Sunshine discovers that she got pregnant after a recent sexual encounter with her boyfriend.Stepping out of the theater, I realized how it’s so hard to be a woman, not just in the Philippines but in general. And pregnancy, one of the human experiences that only a cisgender woman can experience, and how much it impacts on their health, emotions, and even their dreams or aspirations - especially when it happens completely unplanned. All of these are further amplified in the situation here in the Philippines where sexual education is still not a priority, access to quality maternal care is expensive, and role of religion to beset unfair expectations towards women.Despite having a strong message, there are things in Sunshine that I wish had been improved on. I must admit I felt a bit cheated out because the movie was initially hyped as a sports movie focusing on gymnastics - the same way Rookie did for volleyball, but in the end was more of a character drama that whose lead character is a gymnast. I wish that Jadaone delved deeper on Sunshine’s motivations on why gymnastics is important to her because at how the story was written, Sunshine could’ve played any sport and the story would remain the same. Before I get called out, I know the movie’s true intention is a commentary on the state of female reproductive health in the Philippines, but I felt like it was just a missed opportunity to highlight the state of female sports in the Philippines, particularly gymnastics because Filipino sports movies are so rare. I also felt like that the script could’ve been tightened up a bit as the elements of magical realism introduced in the story (without going too much in spoiler territory) didn’t land as much in terms of story logic.As a follow-up to her lead starring role in 2023 movie Marupok AF, Maris Racal continues to be one of the promising actresses of her generation. And in Sunshine, she delivers one of her career best performances so far, especially at lengths her character goes through and in the dedication to train of the gymnastics segments of the story.Overall, Sunshine is not an easy watch because it doesn’t mince the hard truths of how it is living as a woman in the Philippines. And now with with the ongoing female reproductive health and sexual education discussion in the Philippines, Antoinette Jadaone offers a strong message on why it is imperative that protections for women’s health should be passed, and why the movie Sunshine deserves your time and your attention.However, irony that this movie can only be seen by a limited number of people because of its R16 rating as well as the unfair cinema practices in the Philippines, makes this even more frustrating.

first, i’m so happy of the featured sport. since the achievements of carlos yulo, gymnastics has been rising in the country. i think we need explorations of the fields in which we actually excel, even much more from the perspective of a woman.second, this film has a scent of lino brocka’s—the journey, the road, the streets, the jeep, the buildings, the motel, the church, the stalls and stores, the hospital, the government, the people—the social realism of it all. but different to his, sunshine has its own rhythm—a never-ending going back and forth, a push and pull, a dilemma that only athletes know, only pregnants know, only women know—a jadaone rhythm.third, everything about this film is brave. sunshine is brave. women in this film are brave. the writer is brave. the director is brave. it carefully touches a taboo topic that a lot of filipinos tend to talk about in shallow means, or even a lot also do avoidance of it. but this film just keeps on going and it’s not even apologizing for it. unapologetic but with care. and that is why THIS FILM IS IMPORTANT.maris, you are indeed a sunshine.

This film was grounded and felt real with every relatable action and reaction. I felt the pain and the fear, the uncertainty and the anxiety, the fervor and doubt. At no point did I feel the scene overstayed its welcome, it lasted just right amount of time to cause discomfort for the comfortable and comfort the uncomfortable. Sunshine stands to be a symbol for what is wrong with Philippine society (healthcare, religion, etc.) and what is right (truly loving and caring family) and could be a source of courage for the many who undergo similar situations but whose voices are drowned out and left unheard. Personally, I was moved to guilt for the parts I played in perpetuating the same problems the film emphasized.

ANIMA ceased to exist last July 31, 2024, and this film is the last project that was ever produced by the company to be released.I’ve spent the past year trying to find meaning in such a swift demise — after all, most people prefer to go out with a bang; and I felt like we went out with the most sad, unceremonious accordion noise. But I’m glad that, a year later, Sunshine came out, a film that all things considered, is so bold and so loud and so strong in what it wants to say. Leave it to Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal not only to craft such a severe, yet truthful and empathetic tale, but also to rally a community to see this film. It makes me feel like we went out with a bellow, and all of our pains, struggles, and heartache with our sudden departure was heard somewhere, somehow.ANIMA was where I really grew into my own as a marketer, a coworker, and as a person. I’ll miss it dearly, but will cherish the memories forever. I’m happy Sunshine is shining brightly for us.

Maris Racal delivers her most visceral performance to date — raw, quiet, devastating, Annika Co brings subtle intensity as Sunshine’s confidante, brimming with quiet guilt and Jennica Garcia anchors the story with maternal grit and emotional weight. Courage bleeds through every performance; this film demands to be seen a brutal, unflinching portrayal of abortion, rape, and systemic neglect in Philippine society every silence in the film speaks louder than dialogue; breath and ambient sound shape the mood Jadaone’s direction refuses easy comfort — every frame dares you to feel gritty visuals and handheld camera work ground the story in realism Sunshine isn’t just a movie — it’s a mirror, a gut-punch, a reckoningfavorite scene: the "mata-mata" scene of xyril and maris.. soundless but full of emotionsleast-liked: this is like a hard pill toswallow, theme is very heavy, but needs tobe seen to spark the conversationverdict: highly recommended, a very important film

A gripping and sensitive depiction of the struggles faced by many young Filipino women, Sunshine portrays the reality in the Philippines regarding women's bodily autonomy, a reality marked by irony, hypocrisy, and misplaced conservatism. Maris Racal and Jennica Garcia delivered strong performances. The film is disturbing, and rightfully so.

Katahimikan at pagkatulala. Napakaingay ng utak ko kanina, pero walang namutawi sa aking bibig pagkatapos kong masaksihan ang pelikulang ‘to. Kulang ang isang oras para magbalik-tanaw sa kwento mo, Sunshine.Isa lamang ang tiyak kong masasabi: Ang hirap maging babae. Ang hirap galawan ng isang lipunang ikinukulong ka sa ideya na ang puwang mo sa mundo ay nakabase sa iyong sinapupunan—sa pagluluwal mo ng bata.Kapag babae ka, hindi ka pwede mangarap nang mataas. Hindi ka pwede maghangad ng magandang career. Kapag babae ka, hindi mo pwedeng piliin ang sarili mo. Kailangan ang timeline ng buhay mo ay nakaangkla sa pagbubuo ng pamilya.Hindi lahat handang maging nanay. Hindi lahat kayang maging nanay. Hindi lahat ng babae ay pipiliin maging nanay.Balang araw, nawa’y makita ng lipunang ito ang kababaihan bilang isang pwersa, bilang isang lakas. Bigyan sana ng lipunang ito ang mga kababaihan ng kalayaang lumipad at kumawala sa mga rehas na pumipigil sa pamumukadkad ng kanyang pakpak.Maraming salamat, Sunshine, sa matapang at mahusay na pagbabahagi ng iyong danas. Isa ka mang kathang-isip, ang buhay mo ay hindi nalalayo sa kasalukuyang tinatahak ng isang babae sa bansang ito.Hindi rito nagtatapos ang kwento mo. Magpapatuloy tayo, at bitbit ka ng bawat kababaihang kagaya ko—saksi sa paraan mo ng pakikibaka sa mapang-aping lipunan.Papaburan din tayo ng mundo.

The storytelling is straightforward yet impactful, shedding light on the truths many Filipinos face every day. I now understand why the director chose Maris Racal — not because she is a seasoned actress, but because her raw, unfiltered talent brings a striking authenticity to the role.

The fact this got to even show in SM nationwide makes me amazed and is a testament to what this film symbolizes and argues for in our society. Even if I didn’t really care for a certain plot device used in the movie and in fact took my enjoyment at certain points from a very grounded and compelling story, the highs of this film is extraordinary and something I will always praise. The way the camera and direction paints the complex feelings of Sunshine, the usage of Manila as both familiar yet alienating in its loudness and chaos, the rage and social commentary that is extremely brave in our current societyGiving tons of flowers for this film, I would even say that taking away the campier/comedic aspects of the film would have made this a masterpiece in my eyes! Maybe in another rewatch, this would get a higher score!If you liked the direction Direk Tonet took in Fangirl and wanted to see it taken to a different level, this film will be for you!

Really nice. Brava  Nakakatunaw ng puso. Also shot in Manila, My Manila. So you know how I feel about it haha. What can I say man. Tonette Jadaone. Napakalinis magkwento. Really nice placemaking; finally for a long time, an honest-feeling Manila. A motel in Avenida you could hear the banging of rail tracks? Gusto ko rin yan mapuntuhan! Haha. Favorite ko rito yung little transgressions. Madalas ang pekilula tungkol sa shame, kumporme sa shame. That is to say parang laging uphill battle. Pero dito ni minsan hindi ako kinabahan para kay Sunshine. Panatag na panatag ako, nakakatuwang panoorin ang deliryo ng biyahe niya mula Quiapo-Avenida-Paco. Wala akong awa, naluluha lang ako sa lungkot. Bitin na bitin lang ako sa last sequence which looking back looked like an Aronofsky reference but contrivedHere is Maris Racal, who I’ve told my friends has a Mona Lisa face. Minsan 'di ko mawari kung anong nararamdaman niya, but with her command on-screen you could tell what she wants. Desperado. That is an actor you want to play Sunshine.Because Sunshine only has her mistakes to prop her up to dreams, which is a tricky proposition in the city, but nonetheless possible. And is often the case. Kailangang gustong-gustong-gustuhin mo lang talaga. Some kneel for a quarter-mile in Quiapo. Ang iba, pumapatay. Nevermind if your conscience is (literally) following you, you just have to make it work. Ito ang ibig sabihin kung mabingit ka sa mga kuko ng liwanag. To be a woman…. to be a mother. Gets mo na?

ang tagal ko bago isulat yung review ko sa SUNSHINE. sa pangkalahatan, walang duda—maganda at matapang ang pelikula. hindi lang maganda sa produksyon, kundi nakakanginig din ng laman. ang galing ng mga aktor, mula sa mga beteranong sina meryll soriano, xyriel manabat, elijah canlas, hanggang sa mga mas batang bituin na sina annika at julius. at higit sa lahat, si maris, na may malalim at matalim na hugot. simple pero malinaw ang paraan niya ng paghahatid ng mensahe: ang mga babae ang gulugod ng lipunan. nag-iiwan ‘to ng tanong na bakit sa kabila ng bigat ng responsibilidad na iyon, mailap pa rin ang mundo sa kanila? representasyon ang pelikulang ito na kulang pa ang mga diskusyon patungkol sa mga karapatan ng mga babae sa pilipinas. sa pelikulang ito, hindi ko kayang maging kritikal dahil alam kong hindi ko hawak ang karapatang humusga sa kwento ni sunshine. HINDI KO ITO KWENTO, at siguro iyon ang pinakamahalagang bagay na kailangang kong maunawaan. ako ay taganood lamang, at bilang manonood, ang tanging sigurado ako ay kung paano pinaigting ng pelikulang ito ang pagmamahal ko para sa kababaihan.habang pinapanood ko, parang unti-unting lumalalim ang pagkakaunawa ko na hindi pa rin patas ang batas sa mga kababaihan. mas nagkaroon ako ng lakas na sumandig sa tabi nila, sa pakikibaka para sa maayos, pantay, at respetadong pagtrato. hindi ko kailanman lubos mauunawaan ang bawat sakit, takot, at pag-aalinlangan na kaakibat ng pagiging babae pero dahil sa pelikulang ito, mas malinaw na sa akin: sila ang sentro ng komunidad. at kung may dapat magbago, hindi sila iyon ngunit ang sistema, paniniwala, at pagtingin ng komunidad sa kanila.

an underrated beauty of cinema is how it can invite one into a suspended state of reality. for a brief and borrowed hour or two, our story pauses to make space for someone else’s. sunshine (2024) is one of those rare films that honors the lending of time not with surprise and spectacle, but with empathy as its goal and medium for exploration.and the language of empathy in sunshine settles in slowly, almost bodily. aptly named, the movie seeps through the senses like the quiet force of nature: it casts a harsh light on the grayed and shadowed alleys of manila, where sins and prayers blur into one cruel cacophony. it burns with familiarity when we recognize sunshine, the girl, in our own world.she sits beside us in overcrowded jeepneys, gets scolded like us in hospital beds, walks among us on streets of quiapo that shame and steal a strip of dignity. with the same light, the film reaches for the sunshine within us - the ones who dream and persist, who dare hold our potential as promises. there are sunshines among us held tightly by sisters, while some sunshines are held up only as stubborns who flicker through the dark. yet herein lands the most transcendent part of the film: it peddles no moral lesson or pedantic sermon. all that it offers is an invitation to bear witness to sunshine, as she moves to the rhythm of a music only she can hear and pushes against the gravity of choices forced upon her. the film doesn’t seek answers; it simply asks for understanding. in its own sober way, it holds out hope that when the borrowed time is up, may we not only remember every sunshine who flies and rises, but also the ones who fall and return, until we see how every ground that meets her, holds her, or traps her, as she labors to birth her becoming, is also the same one we own.

Si Sunshine ay ako.Hindi man ako rhythmic gymnast, pero may pangarap din ako. Gaya ng maraming babae at dalaga na dumaan sa unwanted pregnancy o pregnancy scare, ramdam ko ang takot ni Sunshine. Yung pagkabalisa at pag-ukit ng konsensya kapag nakahiga sa kama. Yung konsensyang lalong lumalalim kapag may mahinang katok sa pinto. Ito na siguro ang pelikula na kung ang younger self ko ang makakapanood, hindi niya magugustuhan na nakakarelate ako kay Sunshine. Pero ganito talaga, personal na ito sa akin. Naiintindihan ko si Sunshine. Damang dama ko yung galit. Yung takot. Yung tapang, na bahala na nga basta wag lang mapurnada ang mga plano. Ramdam ko at alam ko kung saan hinugot ni Sunshine yung tapang na 'yon. Ang karakter ni Sunshine ay nakaangkla sa batang pasulpot-sulpot. Para sa akin, inner child niya ‘yon. Pero may kasama akong nanood na nagsabing baka konsensya niya raw 'yon. Pwede rin.Tingin ko inner child niya 'yon, dahil sa tricycle scene, duguan rin ang hita ng bata. Na para bang sinasabi na kung iniinda ni Sunshine ang sakit at pilipit ng puson, dama rin yon ng inner child niya. Nasasaktan. Naaawa. Maliban doon, gusto ko rin i-emphasize kung gaano ka poetic ng eksena. Naka higa sa hita ng bata si Sunshine na nag-aagaw-buhay. Hinihinging lumaban siya. Hindi ba't magandang pagnilayan na sa lowest points ng buhay, ang boses na naririnig mo ay ang boses ng munting ikaw? Maliit, oo, pero may bigat, may bagahe.Ang rason naman kung bakit daw konsensya ni Sunshine ang bata, ay dahil sa eksena sa ospital. Galit na galit ang bata kay Sunshine at hinahanap niya si Ariana, isa ring batang pasulpot-sulpot. Ineexplain ni Sunshine na okay na si Mary Grace pero ang importante para sa kanya ay si Ariana, na nawawala. Nawala na ba si Ariana dahil nawala na rin ang dinadala ni Mary Grace?Pero sa kabila ng lahat, matapang si Sunshine. Doon sa unang hospital scene, kita mong may hiyang nararamdaman si Sunshine. Pero dahil sa trauma at pagkalito, sunod lang siya sa pinagsasabi ng overly righteous na doktora. Hanggang sa napuno si Sunshine. Isa sa pinaka-paborito kong linya niya ay nang tanungin niya ang doktora: "Para saan?" Na para bang may panghuhusga rin si Sunshine sa kanya. Ang daming layers ng pelikulang ‘to. Hindi lang siya tungkol sa isang babae. Kwento ito ng pinagdadaanan ng isang babae sa isang bansa na binigo at binibigo ang mga kababaihan na magkaroon ng karapatan na magdesisyon para sa katawan nila. Nagbabago na ang panahon. Hindi na dapat taboo ang usapin ng sex at sex education. Higit sa lahat, ang mga batang gaya ni Mary Grace ang pinaka bulnerable sa lahat. Ramdam ko rin si Mary Grace. Ano ang laban ng isang 13-year-old sa isang Uncle Bobot? Alam nating maraming Uncle Bobot. At dapat lang na basagan ng bote sa ulo ang mga kagaya nila. Maraming kagaya ni Mary Grace, nananahimik lang, natatakot. Kaya nga ang pelikula at kwentong ito ay magandang halimbawa ng quote na:“Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable.” Mahusay. Napakahusay. Truly a landmark film.

We are introduced to Sunshine through her warming up with other student-athletes and performing her routine for the upcoming Olympic team tryouts. Viewers can tell that her prowess and national team member status is a mix of talent and hard work, that even when she messes up halfway through, it doesn't make her any less of a great gymnast.When she first finds out that she is pregnant, the camera focuses on her hands tremble. But she immediately acts on it – searching for suspicious dealers for pills, telling the boy that knocked her up, and going to church to pray that the Lord takes away the being forming in her womb – even when we see glimpses of her trying not to lose her composure in the humid streets of Manila.The film shows and justifies Sunshine's reasons for wanting an abortion, even if the means available in the Philippines will harm her. She has dreams that can't be put on hold, and she clearly is a young girl with mannerisms and tendencies deemed "immature" – factors that do not make her fit to be a mother.But in a scene wherein she talks to a pastor (played by Piolo Pascual, who made everyone in my cinema gasp) that promises financial support throughout her pregnancy and motherhood, she rejects it. "Ayoko maging nanay," she says, plain and simple.That was my favorite part of the film, because it felt cathartic to hear it. Although Sunshine had good reasons for the choices she makes, we must not need to have justified, valid, and layered reasons for wanting an abortion. Some of us do not want to be mothers and undergo the medical complications that come with carrying a child, just because.I hope that it has more time to stay in cinemas. I hope that more people see it, and by the time the credits roll, sana ma-gets niyo na kami.

The body of the story may be about Sunshine, but its soul revolves around Menggay.From the moment the official trailer dropped, Sunshine instantly captured my interest. I’ve been waiting ever since for the chance to see it and after months of anticipation, I finally did. And now, I can say this without hesitation: I have nothing but praises for the film.More than just well-made, Sunshine is a brave and necessary work. It’s a film that demands to be seen — not only because of Maris Racal’s powerful performance, but because of how urgent and relevant its message is in today’s world.Unlike other films that leave you in feel-good state when the credits roll, Sunshine leaves you with questions — difficult, uncomfortable questions that deserve to be brought into the open.What if women had better options?What if men received the same public scrutiny when it comes to unwanted pregnancies?What if we had a healthcare and justice system that actually protects girls like Menggay?What if we dared to talk about abortion in a way that invites honest, compassionate, and informed discussion?This is where the film finds its power. When Menggay’s story arc unfolds, that’s when Sunshine cements its message, it stops being just a film and starts becoming a mirror to reality.Because this is for the countless Menggays out there — young girls with no real choices. Mga batang gaya niya. Isang 13-anyos na tinanggalan ng karapatan ng mismong sariling pamilya.And the painful truth is: there are far too many Menggays in our country. Uneducated. Deprived of opportunities. Denied the chance to choose a safer path forward.Watching this film taught me to become more open-minded. It urged me to weigh both the pros and cons of abortion more critically, and to consider how we can use art as a tool for education and awareness.In the end, Sunshine is not just a film — it’s a challenge. A challenge to our government to craft better, more inclusive campaigns. Ones that don’t just resonate with the intellectuals but reach the grassroots, where change is most needed. #Sunshine

After two decades in the industry, Antoinette Jadaone has cemented her capacity to bend, direct, and write with different genres — the deconstruction of ekstras with Lilia Cuntapay, the ironic and hilarious takedown of cosmetic surgery industry with Belo-approved meta-comedy “Beauty in a Bottle,” and the dialogue-driven romantic hugot dramas with ‘Tadhana.” Without a doubt, Jadaone stands as one of the most vital voices in Philippine filmmaking today, consistently challenging conventions and pushing Filipino Cinema forward. In all her films, one thing that’s notable she's put women's voices at the forefront. She has since taken a pandemic pause after Fan Girl, but this has also led to her researching and diving deep into her most recent film, Sunshine. The film follows a student gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal), who discovers she’s pregnant just as she’s about to compete for the SEA Games. The film takes a surreal turn when she encounters a kid/ alter ego appears in crisis moments, reflecting her inner turmoil as she faces societal judgment.Throughout the film, Sunshine’s emotional arc—marked by anguish, desperation, and vulnerability—lays bare the reality where women’s access to safe choices is morally questioned and legally denied. This taboo isolates her: abandoned by friends and her partner, judged by doctors, and pressured by her coach to give up her dreams. Social stigma is one, but the films also highlights how poverty and consequently, sexual miseducation put into question the dignity of women. To be able to choose freely, is too high of a cost for Sunshine who has to deal with its social, financial, and legal repercussions. The film understands how for women in the fringes there’s little to no choice.The film is not without hope. Her sister, who’s a single mother, grounds Sunshine. Her alter ego serves as emotional salve during her many crises. And she also chances upon an underaged girl months into her pregnancy who reflects and echoes her experiences. In each of them, Jadaone realizes Sunshine’s future: to be a single mother, carry her pregnancy to term, and have a daughter. The film effectively wrestles with the nuances of her situation: to choose her dreams or be with a child. Ironically, Sunshine occasionally stumbles under the weight of its many themes: its surreal elements and side characters threaten to overshadow Sunshine’s emotional arc. It makes one wonder how better the film would have been had it just been, as the film title suggested, about Sunshine. Nevertheless, the film is a showcase of Jadaone’s confident vision.There’s this wonderful scene in the film of a maternity ward that just for brief moment became a community for pregnant women and mothers helping and supporting one another. It epitomizes the warmth that carries Sunshine forward: from isolation to solidarity, and from uncertainty to self-understanding. Parting with her past, she talks to her alter ego hoping she’d understand. They hug. To be understood that’s just what Sunshine needed.

Sana gets na rin ng PilipinasSunshine directly and unapologetically shows and conveys its initial and main purpose and advocacy. There’s no need for deep analysis or interpretation, no hidden meanings or figurative scenes that require thorough discourse. It’s direct, like a slap in the face, exposing the reality of teenage pregnancy, women’s health and rights, and the importance of abortion, especially in the Philippines. Alam kong napakahalaga ng pelikulang ito sa kababaihan pero ang hiling ko ay sana mas maraming kalalakihan ang makapanood nito.Ang misogyny at patriyarka ay mga problemang dulot naming mga lalaki. Matibay ang paniniwala kong kami ang dapat may pinakamalaking ambag sa pagbubuwag ng mga ito. Dapat kami ang nagpepenitensya. Pero hindi ganito ang realidad. Mga babae tulad ni Sunshine, Menggay, at ang maraming babae sa pelikulang ito ang bumabaka at nagdurusa sa ilalim ng huwad na sistema. Tila habambuhay silang nagpepenitensya para sa isang kasalanang hindi matubos-tubos kahit pa anong gawin nila—ang kasalanan ng pagiging babae.Mahusay ang pagpapakita ng Sunshine sa iba't ibang impyernong dinaranas ng kababaihan: personal, panlipunan, pisikal, mental, pinansyal, sekswal, at, higit sa lahat, pulitikal. Ramdam ito sa bawat eksena kung saan galit, pag-aalala, at pagod ang namamayagpag sa mga linya, ekspresyon, imahe, at tunog. Pati nga mismo ang kalagayan nito bilang pelikula ay isang impyerno rin: ang masalimuot na danas nina Direk Tonet sa paghahanap ng distributor, ang katotohanang madalang abutin ng mga ganitong pelikula ang mainstream consciousness ng mga Pilipno, ang mabilis na pagliit ng bilang ng mga sinehan na nagpapalabas nito, at ang nagbabadyang diskurso na tiyak na magiging mapaghati. Samakatuwid, ang pelikula mismo ay dumaan at patuloy na dadaan sa impyernong ginawa ng patriyarka.Ipinapakita ng Sunshine na mula noon hanggang ngayon, kababaihan ang umaako sa responsibilidad na hamunin at buwagin ang patriyarka. Kaya sana mapanood ito ng mas marami pang lalaki, lalo na kung hindi pa sila mulat sa realidad ng kababaihan, mga batang ina, at mga biktima ng sekswal na karahasan. Tayong mga lalaki ang nag-imbento at nakikinabang sa patriyarka. Tayo ang may kasalanan, tayo ang dapat magpenitensya.

i knew i had to watch this before this film disappears off the face of the earth like gitling did. no regrets because this might be antoinette jadaone’s magnum opus yet. sunshine (2025) had no metaphors and subtle parallelisms: it screams that a woman’s autonomy is her own. a very straight-forward, well-thought of, and a passionate piece about how a woman was made to struggle the moment she was born by the system and how it’s designed to take away her ownnes. this is true for everywhere else in the world; but much more significant in the context of a third world country such as the philippines. abortion is a controversial topic in the country, to say the least. it is seen as a violation to the sanctity of life—a sin to remove a clump of cell in a human body. swayed by the biblical texts and the catholic church, abortion is illegal in the country. but for women like sunshine and mary grace, the law does little to stop the reality: it only pushes them to do the act in shadows, where the only option is unsafe and risky. the religious references throughout the film were palpable: from the jeepney that sunshine rode to quiapo bearing the sign that says “gift of God” to sunshine’s physical manifestation of her conscience in the form of her would-be child—which shows an inner conflict between her faith and survival. these references do not seem disrespectful but rather an emphasis on how deeply stitched sunshine’s struggle to catholicism is. it’s a critique on how the bible is weaponized to police a woman’s choices and her bodily autonomy. i want to make a point on the healthcare system too which the film really did a good job criticizing: with all its faults, the healthcare system is biased against women. the lack of access to safe procedures, institutional neglect, and moral policing (made by professionals, mind you) leave women like sunshine and mary grace with nowhere to turn. the lack of quality healthcare in the country is so normalized that it leaves everyone no dignified options to address even their basic needs. a perfect film that paints intersectionality so well: women from different sectors, despite having the same oppressor, face different realities. it did not sensationalize abortion but it gave the audience another angle to look at it from; in a perspective that’s raw and honest. i was crying at the end (#that scene) because in spite all this, she prevailed. a woman, in a system that set her up to fail, survived and lived to achieve her dreams.overall, sunshine (2025) was hopeful, important, and full of courage. an important film that must be seen by everyone (and more importantly, by women). maris racal, you are a generational talent, you deserve all the flowers AND jennica garcia, this piece’s hidden gem, you have mothered on a scale no one has ever had before.
it is easy to get drowned in the noise. thank you, sunshine, for believing in your dreams and being loud about them.

Few films manage to hold intensity, tenderness, and truth all at once-but Sunshine does.It was a brave story of strength, love, and kindness. Yet it was also sharp, honest in its portrayal of the harsh realities young Filipina women often endure: the limits imposed on their bodies, their choices, their futures.And still, it was warm. It never allowed you to drown in despair. Instead, it held you with care, gently reminding you that even in the most shadowed and uncertain places, light still finds its way in.Just like its title, Sunshine felt like light breaking through, like a quiet kind of hope that chooses to stay.

Sunshine’s strength lies on its strong messaging. It confronts the audience— yes, what you heard was right. Maternity wards are in terrible conditions. A lot of R*pe and incest victims are of that age. Bigotry and victim-blaming play a huge part in our society. Antoinette Jadaone doesn’t tiptoe or walk around with her message: she is loud, angry, and knows where she stands. Her direction is both observational and sympathetic, allowing the audience to feel for Sunshine and feel helpless in situations out of our control. Despite all of these, it’s an incredibly hopeful movie about choice. Maris Racal is radiant and fantastic, and Jennica Garcia is the heart of the film.

Sabi nila, kapag ang isang pelikula ay tumatak sa damdamin at isipan ng manonood, naiparating nito ang mensahe nais ipaabot. Kapag dala mo pa rin ito hanggang sa pagtulog mo, ibig sabihin ay maganda ang pagkakagawa. At kung pagising mo'y ito pa rin ang laman ng isip mo, isa itong tunay na obra maestra.Naalala ko pa noong una kong mapanood ang That Thing Called Tadhana. Alam kong iba si Direk Tonet. Para niyang binago ang pormula ng mga pelikulang Pilipino. Simula noon, naging tagahanga na ako ng kaniyang mga gawa. Walang tapon sa kaniyang filmography. May lalim ang bawat karakter na nililikha niya. Naiipakita niya ang mga struggle at kahinaan naming mga babae, pero kasabay nito, naipapakita rin niya kung paanong buong tapang naming niyayakap ang aming pagkababae.At sa pelikulang ito, mas lalo niyang pinatunayan kung gaano siya kagaling bilang direktor. Alam ko nang magiging maganda ito, mula pa lang sa premise at trailer, kuhang-kuha na niya ako. Pero nang mapanood ko na ito nang buo, mas lalo akong humanga. Panahon na, sa tingin ko, para kilalanin si Direk Tonet bilang isa sa mga haligi ng pelikulang Pilipino. Ang pelikulang ito ang magbubukas ng daan para mas mapansin siya hindi lang bilang direktor ng rom-com, kundi bilang isang seryoso at malalim na haligi ng sining at dakilang manunulat.Bawat shot, pinag-isipan. Hindi lang basta kinuha para lang sa aesthetic. Bawat karakter, may saysay at mahalagang ambag sa buhay ni Sunshine, hindi lang basta comic relief o pandagdag lang sa cast. Mahusay ang bawat isa, lalong-lalo na si Jennica Garcia, kada eksena niya, tagos sa puso. Napakahusay rin ng batang si Annika Co, kaya niyang makipagsabayan sa mga beterano. Siya ang nagmistulang liwanag, ang "sunshine" sa kabuuan ng pelikula.At si Maris Racal—kung hindi siya mananalo ng mga acting awards, ewan ko na lang. Para siyang isinilang para sa papel na ito. Bitbit niya ako sa bawat eksena. Bawat ngiti, bawat pikit ng mata, bawat hinga, ramdam na ramdam ko si Sunshine. Ang lalim ng koneksiyon ko sa kaniya. Wala akong ibang hiniling kundi matapos na ang paghihirap niya. Dahil 'yon sa galing ng pag-arte ni Maris. Nagawa niyang kumonekta sa kaluluwa ng mga manonood hanggang magroll ang credits.Hindi na kinailangang i-detalye pa ang mahabang backstory para makilala si Sunshine. Ang galing ng pagkakasulat. Walang patay na eksena, lahat mahalaga, lahat may emosyon. Mararamdaman mo ang lahat: awa, inis, galit, tawa, lungkot, takot, pag-asa, at saya.Ito ay nagsilbing tinig ng mga kababaihan. GETS NA GETS tayo ng pelikulang ito. Hindi lang nito binunyag ang mapait na realidad ng mga kababaihan, pero ipinakita rin nito kung paanong ang mga babae ay kayang maging unapologetically passionate sa mga gusto namin sa buhay, sa mga pangarap namin. Dagdag na rin ang pasilip kung gaano kahirap na itinatawid ng mga atletang Pilipino ang buhay sa loob at labas ng pagsasanay.Hindi perpekto si Sunshine, pero kahanga-hanga ang pagkakabuo ng kaniyang pagkatao. Ang ganda ng paghubog sa kaniyang karakter. Lagi na lang nagtatanong ang kalalakihan: “Bakit ang mga babae na lang ang laging maingay? Bakit sila ang laging humihingi ng karapatan?” Para bang pakiramdam nila’y binabalewala na sila sa modernong panahon. Sana mapanood nila ito. Sana makita nila kung gaano unfair ang mundo para sa kababaihan. Sa aspetong pisikal pa lang, talo na kami. Kaya kung maaari, bigyan man lang sana ng puwang ang aming mga karapatan na matagal na namin hinihiling na pagbigyan. Ang dali-daling talikuran ng lalaki ang responsibilidad, pero sa babae? Kami ang nagdadala ng lahat ng iniwan na pinsala mapa-mental, pinansyal, emosyonal, sosyal, at lalong lalo na sa pisikal.Ang pelikulang ito ay isang mahigpit na yakap para sa kababaihan, at isang mata na bumubulaga sa mga nananatiling bulag sa mga hinaing at karapatang matagal na naming ipinaglalaban. Ito ang klase ng mga pelikulang minsan lang dumating sa ating buhay at siguradong mananatiling relevant sa mga susunod pang taon.

Sunshine Hindi ako madalas mag-share ng thoughts ko tungkol sa mga pelikula — kasi naniniwala ako na iba-iba ang tama ng kwento sa bawat tao.Pero iba si Sunshine. Isang pelikulang binigyang kulay ang isang usapin na matagal nang pinapadilim — ang karapatan ng kababaihan. Hindi ito pag-romanticize ng abortion. Ito ay pagtindig sa matagal nang pinapatay na diskurso tungkol sa maling ideolohiya, diskriminasyon, at ang paulit-ulit na pagkundena sa kakayahan ng babae na magdesisyon para sa sarili.Ang bigat ng mga eksena, pero ang galing — kasi ang gaan nitong naipaintindi. Gets ko na.Salamat, Direk Antonette, sa tapang at galing mong magkwento. Kay Maris, na sa loob ng higit isang oras at kalahati, ay naging si Sunshine — at naging kaibigan ko. Sa buong cast, salamat sa pagbuo ng mundong hindi namin kayang talikuran, dahil ito ang totoo.Kung may oras ka, panoorin mo Sunshine. Alam kong kasabay nito ang Fantastic Four at iba pang malalaking pelikula — at okay lang naman ’yon. Pero sana, bigyan mo ng pagkakataon si Sunshine. Pramis, walang sisihan.

Maris Racal turned into a drama actress in this movie. She played the role so well, from the gymnast to an early teen, pregnant, soon-to-be mother, not ready yet for the responsibility. She gave it all for this. The movie is full of different emotions. You will laugh, become angry, and be inspired. It is a story of a struggling athlete and the reality of different social issues in the country. The cinematography was superb, showing the different scenes in a way that made you get hooked and feel the emotion. The dialogue was natural and sublime and not filtered to show the actuality of what would happen. WHAT I LOVE THE MOST IS THE TWIST ABOUT THE CHARACTER OF ANNIKA AS “BATA”. It sealed the deal.
