A film about abortion that is so beautiful that it makes me proud to recommend this film to anyone regardless of their stance in abortion, most especially in a very catholic-dominated society. It spoke so loudly to me of how a woman's life could change from bearing a child in your womb. it could shatter your dreams, make your life critical, or give you a life you have always wanted- to become a mother. Annika, the bata, as a narrative device to signify conscience of Sunshine was Jadaone's wonderful choice to gently discuss a sensitive topic such as abortion without deafening the fetus inside of a pregnant woman. Sunshine was a cinematic storytelling of coming to a decision, with never-ending to contradictions with your conscience and peeking through jalousies of other people's similar but different narratives, to come to a choice for yourself, as a woman.

a film about special people who live a rather normal life, amidst the chaotic yet beautiful, neon-lit street life of manila, filled with a heartwarming sense of humanity. having only seen 'six degrees of separation from lilia cuntapay', i think i can say that direk tonet gets it, she treats her characters in a way that makes us care and relate with them in one way or another; i may not be pregnant like sunshine, but i very much live in the same society as her. the director doesn't glorify or romanticize the world in which sunshine, and we, live in—it is depicted in an achingly honest way, and therefore brutal. and maris racal is able to assimilate (?) in this world built around her character, she was phenomenal in portraying this character in such a manner that is raw and tender; most notable in scenes depending on non-verbal dialogue. although, said scenes are probably my favorite among the entire film, most of them fall short on an emotional level—just as the emotions are about to hit a gut punch, the scene is cut off. by all means, this is not a perfect film. still, it doesn't take away from the very real and grounded moving story that is sunshine.

watched this through the lens of the gay friend who's walked beside many sunshines in his life. it breaks my heart how familiar everything feels. how hard it is for sunshines to go through something like this in a country where it's still illegal, unsafe, and almost impossible to talk about.this is a movie for the masses. for the women who are left with no choice but to carry the burden quietly. for the world that needs to stop looking away.(fuck men)i hope one day we wake up in a philippines where no one has to suffer just to survive. where people are given real choices, not pushed to desperate corners.the film makes you feel it; how sunshine's world gets smaller the longer she hides her truth. you see it in the tight streets of manila, where every corner feels like it's closing in on her. her fear and panic so loud even when she says nothing. then you see her walk through the chaotic streets of quiapo, where she disappears into the crowd, holding onto the little control she has left. she's not sure if what she's doing is right, but she does it anyway, because no one's there to guide her. she does it alone, hoping that somehow it works. that somehow it saves her.this is a film that deserves to be seen for generations. and i hope that when they do, they can say, "ay, ganito pala noon" because by then, we’ve already made things better.to all the sunshines: you are not alone. ps: this is now my top fave antoinete jadaone film!!! also, they can never make me hate you maris racal!

The chaotic rhythm of life.Spoilers ahead.Bold and controversial, writer-director Antoinette Jadaone continues her non-romantic-comedy streak with another compelling and dark subject matter through "SUNSHINE". Gracing the screen is the titular character, played by Maris Racal in her career-best performance, who finds out she's pregnant while she prepares for her Olympic-qualifying event. Trouble ensues, dream and ambition crash.Teenage pregnancy and women conditions take front and center as the film gives voice to the usual silenced of the society. Jadaone may have placed rhythmic gymnastics in the background but it excellently serves as a metaphorical tool to describe the ebb and flow of Sunshine's life. We see her struggles pitted against conservativism and arguable morality in a country where religion and patriarchy rule and shackle. Through magic realism where we are introduced to two young players who abruptly show up mid-scenes, the film gets a rich layer on how our lead navigates her perilous journey. They channel the moral compass though at times their appearances and comedic flair tend to be uneven and out of timing. Racal, with her sharp strength and vulnerability, is utterly commendable but so is her supporting cast - Jennica Garcia and Meryl Soriano as her strong-willed yet nurturing older sister and coach respectively, Annika Co as her unborn child manifestation (an unpredictable plot twist that eventually made sense), and even the cameos from Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, Angie Castrence, Elijah Canlas, and Piolo Pascual fulfill their impressive character actor repertoire. Some arcs and scenes could have been fleshed out because it's got a premise worth exploring but the Philippine censorship may have played its upper hand to prevent the film's full bloom. In the same vein of "4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days", "Never Rarely Sometimes Always", and "Happening", it may not be everyone's cup of tea due to its hefty topic and open-endedness but it's a delight to see an important Filipino film that fearlessly opens the conversation to empower women more on making their own reproductive choices, even with the deafening noise and outdated discourse.Quiapo. Geleen. Ribbon. 4.5/5, folks!Winner of The Crystal Bear Award in the Generation 14plus category at the 75th Berlinale - Berlin International Film Festival, "SUNSHINE" is now exclusively playing in SM Cinemas, rated R-16 without cuts.Tangkilikin natin ang makabuluhang Pelikulang Pilipino!#MovieMadness #PinoyIndieSpirit#TheRoadToTheOscars2026

Been eyeing this film since last year. Fortunately enough, I was able to watch this yesterday with my Mom. In the midst of darkness and rain, we looked for Sunshine.It adds surrealism without sacrificing its groundedness. Remember crying in a few scenes just because of how real it felt and then that sudden realization hits me, and I remember — nangyayari talaga siya sa totoong buhay yet it's inadequately addressed. Alienated, discriminated, and hidden behind idols and symbols stained with shame like the Sunshines and Menggays who are forced to comply with the rules set by a patriarchal, hypocritical, conservative society. I think this film won't force you to agree with its message but it challenges our morals and belief system. Above all, it only asks to be understood. There's multiple shades of womanhood that's not confined within a black and white backdrop. And it's good that we start and continue to talk about it. Overall, this film isn't just about abortion — it's a critique on society, politics, and feminism. As well as a call for women's accessible reproductive healthcare.Ps. Grabe gets ko na bat sya award winning.Before I even entered the cinema, prepared na aq mag cry cry. I saw the trailer, the interviews, and the podcasts so I was bracing myself for emotional confrontations and intense family drama pero wala so what really made me cry was how real everything felt. The way Sunshine just tried to carry on, the way Jennica quietly supported her, and the way the story showed how painfully human this situation is. There was so much honesty in how it was told. Pogi din ni Papa P.As a woman who has experienced a teen pregnancy scare before, I saw parts of myself in Sunshine. That helpless feeling, the fear of not knowing what to do, the shame, and the silence around it… It was all too familiar. I also have friends who’ve gone through it for real. They shared their stories, and as I watched the film, I could see their experiences mirrored by Sunshine.Maris Racal is amazing as Sunshine. Everything about her performance was convincing, from the way she moved to the way she spoke (pero direk kita yung face ng double ni Sunshine ha ). She really looked like a young athlete from a struggling family, someone whose life revolved around discipline and dreams until it all came crashing down. I’ve seen Maris in different roles before, like in Incognito, where she played this aircon ex-military girly na mukhang ginagawang pangbahay ang gucci, it’s rlly impressive how she completely transforms into Kanal Sunshine bc she doesn’t just act the part, she becomes it.Jennica also stood out for me. As Sunshine’s Ate, her presence was comforting throughout the film. She had this motherly vibe that felt very natural. I liked how the film gave her character depth without spelling everything out. You could tell that her love for Sunshine came from a place of experience, like she had her own quiet struggles too. Galing din ni Annika.Even the supporting casts delivered. The manghihilot, the abortion pill seller, the doctors and the people Sunshine met along the way weren’t just fillers. Their performances felt soooooo real, and they matched the tone of the film so well. I didn’t feel like I was watching actors, I felt like I was watching people actually living through these moments.Sa ibang indie films, I cringe when I hear characters cursing because it feels like the writers are just slapping random tangina words trying too hard to sound edgy or cool. But here, everything made sense. The dialogue flowed naturally. The curse words weren’t just for shock, they felt earned u know. One of the scenes that stayed with me was in the motel. It was quiet, then the sound of a train passing by filled the background. That sound stuck with me. It gave the scene so much weight. It felt like the world outside was moving forward, while Sunshine was stuck in a moment where everything felt uncertain. That kind of sound detail is the kind of thing I really appreciate.As someone na working din sa field, I couldn’t help but notice the small design details. Sunshine’s costumes were on point, from her jerseys na may ibat ibang year (aminin, pambahay natin mga intrams shirt ) to the athletic tapes on her body, to her bag full of pins and cute hair clips. Those little choices made feel convincing talaga. She looked like an actual teen athlete, not just someone pretending to be one.The scene in the church was another standout. She didn’t even go inside. She stayed outside and prayed, and that choice said so much. It was symbolic. It showed how distant she probably felt from her faith or how unworthy she thought she was in that moment. That kind of framing really hit me.I also appreciated the sound design. Instead of dramatic bg music, they focused ambient sounds. It gave everything a grounded feeling. It was like I was right there with her, experiencing everything in real time.The pacing was perfect. There were no awkward pauses, no scenes that felt unnecessary. Sa ibang movies, may moments na napapa-phone lang ako hahahah Every second mattered. Every moment added layers to the story. Even the locations were smartly chosen. They weren’t overly stylized. They felt like real places people actually live in and go through things in.Award ka talaga Sunshine.

Sobrang fitting na sunshine ang title ng pelikulang ito dahil katulad ni sunshine, may tapang, puso, at pagkakakilanlan ang pelikula. Matapang dahil bilang predominantly catholic country na sobrang na ka-angkla ang paniniwala, mga desisyon, at disposisyon sa buhay sa kung ano ang tama at mali sa bibliya, isang malaking hakbang ang ipakitang tumaliwas sa nakaugalian at kinalakihang ideya ng kung ano ang “tama”. Matapang dahil sa mundo at sa bansang sobrang patriyarkal na nag c-cater lamang sa kalalakihan, walang pag-uubling pinakita na wala dapat may ibang may karapatan sa katawan at kapakanan ng isang babae kung hindi sila lamang. Matapang kasi ilegal ang aborsyon sa pilipinas at imoral ang tingin sa mga taong gustong gawin ‘to pero walang tako’t na ipinakita na katulad ni sunshine, may mga babeng hindi ginusto at gustong maging ina at dapat ay may karapatan silang mamili. May puso kasi naguumapaw sa pagmamahal ang pelikula. Pagmamahal ng kapatid, kaibigan, mentor. At higit sa lahat ang pagmamahal sa kapwa babae. Ang pagmamahal na ipinakita ni sunshine kay menggay, ang pagmamahal na pinakita ni doctora helena sa kanilang dalawa. Masakit in a way pero sobrang gandang isipin na women will always have each other’s back at the end of the day. Walang titindig para sa isang babae nang lubos kung hindi babae lamang rin. Ngunit ang nangibabaw rito ay ang pagmamahal ni sunshine sa sarili niya at sa kanyang mga pangarap. May doubts si sunshine bilang isang babae, bilang isang katoliko. Kaya nga ilang beses natin siya nakitang nagdasal eh at kaya na rin nag e-exist ang karakter ni annika co. Siya yung nagsilbing physical form ng nagsalong upbringing at inhibitions ni sunshine pero at the end of the day, nanaig pa rin ang pagmamahal niya sa pangarap niya. Ang ganda, sobrang ganda. May pagkakakilanlan kasi sobrang pinoy na pinoy ‘tong pelikulang ito. Mula sa kung paano pinakita yung ingay at gulo ng maynila, hanggang sa dynamics ng magkakapatid sa pamilyang pilipino. Pati kung paano nabubuhay ang mga babae sa bansang bulok ang reproductive health system at hindi tanggap ang pagiging sexual nila. Sunshine is now my favorite maris racal performance which was previously held by peachy of Pamilya Ko. I know it’s the bare minimum and literally the point of acting but you can really tell she’s a good actress kasi walang bahid ng kung sino si maris racal sa totoong buhay sa mga karakter na ginagampanan niya. Sobrang believable niya as an actress. In my opinion, this is direk tonet’s best work to date. Her magnum opus so far. Also, jennica garcia is truly a fucking star. She owned every scene she had. P.S. tangina mo miggs at bobot i hope you both rot in hell!!!

Sunshine. Athlete. Student. Sister. Teenager. Since childhood, she has dreamed of qualifying for the Olympics. But now, she faces a life-changing dilemma: she’s pregnant. Antoinette Jadaone’s film follows Sunshine’s journey by reflecting her through the women around her. There’s the little girl who silently follows her in the streets, questioning her every decision. There’s her older sister Geleen, once an athlete too, whose own dreams were interrupted by an early pregnancy. There’s Coach Eden, who’s trained her since she was…

sa mga pelikulang lokal, mga kwento tungkol sa urban poor ang pinaka-dama ko dahil buhay ko ito at buhay ito ng mga mahal at kilala ko. naiintindihan ko ang paghahalintulad nito sa Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, not only because of its messaging but in the way it presents itself — with so much bitterness yet so much heart. napakaimportanteng pelikula ni Sunshine. napaka-espesyal at sobrang lapit sa puso ko. and, unsurprisingly, this is direk jadaone best work yet, as well as maris racal.

sobrang raw ng pagkagawa ng pelikula. walang background music para lang mas may "impact" yung isang senaryo. mararamdaman mo na lang yung bigat na nararamdaman ni sunshine: sa bigat ng pressure na maabot yung pangarap (considering it's for the whole country), pressure na pag nag-decide siya for herself and for her loved ones dream for her, eh labag naman sa norms and belief ng mga nasa paligid, dito papasok yung bata na feeling ko "konsensya" nya. nung naintindihan na ng "konsensya" yung "logic" bakit dapat gawin yung isang bagay, naabot ni sunshine pangarap nya. sarap din makita na hindi pamilya nya yung nagco-command ng dapat paniwalaan, hinayaan nilang si sunshine yung pumili. basta andami ko pang gustong sabihin, sobrang galing mo direk at maris.

Drown out the noisenapakahirap maging babae lalo na sa isang lipunan na labis mapanghusga sa mga kababaihan. Mula sa isang kulturang lubhang konserbatibo na pinanday ng mga relihiyosong paniniwala hanggang sa mga magulang na nagpabaya sa tungkulin nilang protektahan ang kanilang mga anak. Dagdag pa rito ang mga kalalakihang hindi kayang akuin ang responsibilidad ng kanilang mabibigat na kasalanan-- gaya ni Miggs, na nagsabing natatakot siya sa sitwasyon nila sa harap ng kanyang paring ama, pagkatapos niyang murahin si Sunshine dahil hindi niya naayos ang kanilang problema. Sa kanila, napakabilis tumalikod, na para bang ang lahat ng bigat ay kayang dalhin ng nag-iisang tao.sa ilalim ng ingay ng Maynila, ipinapakita ng pelikulang ito ang katahimikan-- isang uri ng pananahimik na nagtatago ng isang mabigat na katotohanan mula sa lahat. Gaya noong nanood ako ng insiang narealize ko na may mga bagay talaga na babae lang ang makakaintindi =]

mabigat siya. buong pelikula, ’yung luha ko andun na, pinipilan lang kaunti. pero bumigay na talaga ako sa “gets ko na,” at tuloy-tuloy na hanggang dulo.sa bawat likha ni direk tonet, totoo ang pagkakasulat ng mga babae. lahat may angking kahinaan, pero hindi mahina. lahat may gustong sabihin, at lahat may kailangang sabihin.at hindi naiiba si sunshine.hindi nangaral ang pelikula. hindi isang woke agenda. hindi rin nagpaka-edgy, just for the sake of. pero alam mong may hangad at nais ang pelikula, habang pinapakita ang totoo.ano nga ba ang lagay ng healthcare sa pinas? ng healthcare para sa kababaihan?kailangan pa ba ng sex education talaga, o hayaan na lang maniwala ang mga bata na puwede na basta iputok sa labas?ang daming nais buksang dayalogo ng sunshine. mga dapat nating pinag-uusapan at pinag-iisipan. pero alam nating marami ring nais isara kaagad ang mga usaping ganito.ang hirap maging babae. sa mundo. sa pilipinas.at mas lalong humihirap dahil hinahayaan nating may isang sunshine, na tumatahak sa maynila. nang gabi. nang mag-isa—mag-isang humaharap sa problema. mag-isang nag-iisip ng kapakan n'ya.

THISSS IS CINEMAAAA U GUYS (YAS, edited w/ a short commentary)what i love about sunshine is it never tries to sell the idea that motherhood is innate, pure, or noble. instead, it asks the real question paano kung ayaw talaga? and it’s so bold to center that lalo na sa context ng pilipinas where everything about being a woman is reduced to sacrifice.we’re raised to believe na ang katawan natin ay para sa pamilya, para sa pananampalataya, para sa kinabukasan ng iba. never para sa sarili. kaya sobrang rare and sobrang radical makakita ng pelikula na nagsasabing "hindi mo kailangang gustuhin. hindi mo kailangang magpaka-martir.”sunshine understands na abortion is not some abstract “debate” about morality. it’s lived. it’s embodied. it’s desperate. and it doesn’t look away from that. it shows us what women are actually left with when they’re denied safe and legal options. instructions sa papel, gamot na walang label, pangambang baka mamatay ka sa proseso. it doesn’t sensationalize it, but it doesn’t sanitize it either. and that’s where the power lies.the film knows the violence doesn’t start when a woman decides to abort. it starts when the state tells her she can’t. when even in the face of trauma, poverty, or kahit simpleng “hindi ko kaya" o "ayoko," the answer is always “wala tayong magagawa." sunshine sits with that anger. nire-recognize niya na ang lack of choice ay isa lang sa napakaraming anyo o mukha ng systemic violence. patunay ito of how the law protects an imagined morality while punishing the actual living woman.and yes, this film is very aware that class makes all the difference. hindi lahat may access to private clinics or doctors willing to take the risk. karamihan, kung hindi lahat, gaya sa pelikula ay sa quiapo ang bagsak. o kaya naman hilot. 'yung iba wala talagang means & are forced to be victims of the way laws, culture, and religion collude to trap women into roles they never asked for. and that matters. because the way we talk about abortion in this country is always so detached from those realities. laging hypothetical. laging abstract. laging nakadikit sa spiritual na paniniwala. but sunshine shows that for many women, hindi lang siya tungkol sa pagkakaroon ng choice o sa moralidad kundi buhay at kaligtasan din nila mismo. literal na tinatanggalan sila ng basic human rights. ang sarap himayin ng pelikulaaa especially 'yung subplot tungkol doon sa 13-yr old girl tapos isampal 'yun sa mukha ng mga taong hindi magawang ilabas ang sarili nila sa personal nilang mga baluktot na paninindigan.ig the best part for me is how sunshine never tries to justify. likeee it doesn’t go “look, she had no choice,” or “she’s a victim, kaya understandable.” no. it says na kahit may support ka, kahit privilege ka, kahit hindi ka biktima, may karapatan kang pumili. and that, for me, is what makes it a GREAT feminist film. hindi siya nakikiusap sa audience na intindihin si sunshine. it tells you, plainly, na she owes you nothing.and maybe the most haunting part of this film is how it visualizes the weight of that decision. hindi bilang guilt or punishment but as memory. the film doesn’t erase the what-if. it shows you that even when a choice is right, it doesn’t come clean or easy. and that doesn’t make it wrong.FKK SOBRANG GALING LANG !!

A sunshine of hope in the dark, conservative alleys of Manila.This is a film that tackles what we Filipinos mostly shame women for: abortion. In this film, we see how the patriarchal society has a chokehold on our women. Men continue to crush the dreams of women, whether through abandoning them (ehem Miggy), ruining them (ehem Bobot), and deciding for their future (ehem Pastor Jaime).But not Sunshine.Despite everything, she persisted. She never gave up. Her trials and eventual triumphs gave a nice contrast to the setting: the dark alleyways of Quiapo. In the desolate streets, there she is continuing to shine. And can I just say, sobrang galing ni Maris! She really did justice in portraying the character. Additionally, I’d also like to commend Annika Co in her portrayal of the bata. Superb, she has potential! Her character is like an annoying voice of reason for Sunshine. Pero grabe, naluha ako in the end sa scene nilang dalawa.And Rhed Bustamante too as Mary Grace. Despite a short screen time, I felt that she was the soul of the movie. Through her, we saw how Sunshine comes to realize her fight for her dreams. Mary Grace was the bridge that Sunshine crossed to eventually come to her decision of persisting with her goals. I also liked how the women in the film supported each other. Thea, despite her mother not allowing her to hang out with Sunshine, showed up in the end. Coach Eden, who helped Sunshine realize her dreams. Her sister Geleen, who strongly supported her in every way. This film is an ode to women, and tackles an issue that should really be talked about more.

PEAK PHILIPPINE CINEMA! peak storytelling. peak everything. sunshine is loud and clear. this film talks deeply about women and women’s rights, especially in reproductive healthcare. in this country, there are countless individuals like sunshine, someone who will do everything for her dreams at all costs.
Alam mo yung nakaka-putangina? Miggy walks away with his future intact. Sunshine, meanwhile, has to carry the grief, the fear, the consequences, and still be expected to rise from it “with grace.”
That's my girl!

Sunshine tried to open a discussion about a topic rarely talked about in the Philippines -- and in that aspect, I think it was already a success.For it to be played in Philippine cinemas is already a win for the film, on top of the other awards it has received abroad. In terms of the technical aspects, I liked how the film showed the beauty of Manila despite its flaws, how graceful rhythmic gymnastics look like despite being a tough sport, and how the venues mostly used in the film had enough space needed despite being cramped.Story-wise, I like how it tackled the problems of the Philippines in terms of reproductive health, but also showed the pro of being a mother -- or at least having a mother figure by your side. However, while I understand why Sunshine made that decision, I think it somehow lacked that oomph on why she was eventually convinced to do IT. What happened after THE TALK? Still, I believe Sunshine should be watched by many. Sunshine shows that one may be in a dark situation, but if you stand your ground and believe in what's best for you, then you know how or where to find the light.

major major edit kasi walang laman yung una kong review ditoSunshine is such a progressive film in my opinion, which is crazy kasi bare minimum palang 'to ng dapat na malaman ng mga tao, na pinagdadaanan ng mga babae on a daily basis. sobrang natakot ako dito to be honest, sa reaction ng mga manonood; especially men. it's heavily emphasized sa pelikula kung ano yung gusto nitong iparating, sobraaaang laking factor nito na kung isa lang liberal na close-minded at misogynist pa—baka nagwala ka na kung nagbayad ka ng 350 para mapanood 'to sa sine ganon mwahahahaang hirap mamili ng favorite kong scene rito, siguro kasi nga bihira ako makanood ng ganito na local film with this kind of concept. so beautiful, so feminine, and so brave. pero siguro, yung papel ni Anika dito yung isa sa pinaka importante. siya yung what if ni Sunshine, "what if nanganak ako?" siya 'yon, and nakakapanibago na hindi makain ng guilt sa ganitong istorya, instead—i was uplifted. naintindihan niya si Sunshine. walang tapon sa cast din; si Xy, si Rhed Bustamante na favorite ko rin yung papel, kahit si Elijah.tip of the iceberg palang ito, and hopefully next time wala nang holding back kasi women deserve to be heard even in the most gruesome circumstances.

"Thankyou po...para saan?"- MarisRacalB4dB1tcH2k25Sa totoo lang, this is the first Pinoy film that I GENUINELY enjoyed, as an avid international film watcher, I guess that set a standard for me.Pero itong pelikula? Gago solid. Unang-una kong nanotice yung husay ng scriptwriters, ang wi-witty! Bawat kuda ng mga aktres at aktor, hahagalpak ka talaga ng tawa, at sa mga times man ng seriousness, ramdam mo ang bigat at poot all from those lines and words alone! Hindi cringe, kundi effortless at natural!But it would've not been that good if it weren't for the actress/actors, of course. Ang huhusay! Lalong lalo na si Maris, the dedication, the talent?! Mga bitawan ng lines, grabe sapul na sapul ka. Manilang-manila, pinoy na pinoy, along with its cinematography!Now, sa totoo lang, I thought this film would end in a cliché and pro-life way. Yung tipong sa huli she will choose to raise the child nalang and give up her dreams? God knows how I was sooo relieved when it did not end like that! I think and I hope this would be the start of the normalization of pro-choice Pinoy films! This is revolutionary in Philippine film landscape! It's something new and look where this movie went? T'was excellent overall, goosebumps ka for sure in some scenes. In our cinema, halos lahat parang nagcontemplate right after the film. A lot has already been said about this film—timely, important, brave. Sunshine is not great just because it tackles abortion, it welcomely invites us to be with its titular character. Every scene we are with her, and no scene is wasted. We know she got big dreams, and it's all she's ever known. We feel her despair, anger, and the facade through her smile. We see her make bad choices, but we understand why.I've seen a similar film in 2020, US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always. What sets Sunshine apart is it is set in the Philippines, a predominantly Catholic country. From the moment Sunshines wants to know about her status, judgment has already been cast upon her. People around her treat her as if she's some sort of contagious disease. Institutions, who are supposed to provide help, condemns her and gives a long-ass speech as if they're god. Yet, she finds a glimpse of hope in the most unlikely of places.Direk Tonet has proven to be one of the most versatile and essential modern directors in the Philippines. From her indie roots to her modern take of romcoms, she consistently has made semi-blockbuster memorable Filipino films. In her shift to sociopolitical drama, which already started in Fan Girl (2020), her voice as a female writer-director is clearer than ever. Hearing the germ of idea for this film got me intrigued, inspired from Jojo Rabbit (2019). At first, I was skeptical of this borrowed plot device, but it completely won me over and elevated the film in the end. Manila is captured as pure as it is. The score is played at the right moments, and so did pure silence.And of course, Maris Racal, the heart of this film. A year of training and research for the character paid off. She is Sunshine through and through! Her in that motel scene is raw and chilling to say the least. All the supporting actors and bit roles are just as great and gives life to Sunshine's world. Jennica Garcia may have a few lines, but her performance especially in that scene with Maris is one to be remembered for, especially for teenage mothers. A surprising yet worthy appearance comes from Rhed Bustamante, whose minor role made a huge impact on me—I cried!Sunshine is such a lightning in a bottle kind of Filipino film. Who would have thought that a great indie pinoy film about abortion is getting this high amount of traction and success? One's hope is for this to create discussion among us and to move the needle systemically for girls like Sunshine. (And as a cinephile, I hope more films like this get produced and be seen by Filipinos, because Philippine Cinema has always been alive!)

Courageous. This is how I would describe the film. The way it speaks to and for society, portrays women's experiences, and challenges the pre-existing notions— the societal pressures, religious guilt, patriarchal norms—all were executed perfectly.One thing that I can't seem to stop thinking about is the personification of Sunshine's troubles. Some said it could be her conscience, maybe her guilt, maybe it's also the pressures society had brought upon women experiencing the same struggle, but I personally saw it as the personification of the child inside her. Kasi as a pregnant woman, one of the top things that she's probably considering the most would be the child (since it has been embeded into us that the child has a life as soon as it's formed). Ang galing lang kasi talaga ng portrayal na 'to and it keeps my mind gears churning. And that 'gets ko na'… I BAWLED.Sunshine is also one of the movies na mayroong ibang level of understanding yung mga babae, e no? A man could watch this and empathize, pero iba yung dating ng pelikulang ito lalo na sa mga babae sa Pilipinas. I would really only trust movies about women to women. It is refreshing to see such a brave filmmaker like Antoinette Jadaone take on such a taboo topic as this, and despite its obvious flaws, there is so much to be celebrated about "Sunshine". Her depiction of realist Manila within a predominantly Catholic albeit judgmental Philippines is strikingly affecting, and the first half of this in particular is a worthy showcase of great filmmaking. The plot device did take me out of the film from time to time, and I do not think it was necessary nor was it effective. Yet, what more can you ask for when you have such a riveting turn from Maris Racal, who puts forward a performance for the ages. Those around her are also excellent, particularly Jennica Garcia, who embodies so much heart and emotion in the little scenes that she is in. Could this have been a better film? Yes. But is it one that is worth seeing? Absolutely.[Watched at SM Mall of Asia cinemas]

“drown out the noise.”easier said than done when the noise is everything.the streets of Maynila. the train. the coach. the prayers. the stares. the guilt.Sunshine isn’t just a film about a girl with Olympic dreams and an unplanned pregnancy. it’s about how loud the world gets when you’re no longer allowed to dream. the kind of noise that follows you into cramped maternity wards, judgmental glances, and conversations that aren’t even about you, but your body.it’s claustrophobic — not just visually, but emotionally. the tight shots mimic how it feels to be backed into a corner: by family, religion, institutions, and the echo of “what will people say?” that never stops ringing. there’s no space to move. no time to think. just pressure.this is a strong film. one that dares to confront the Philippines’ obsession with purity, shame, and control. it pulls back the curtain on a country where reproductive health is taboo. it also shows the quiet fear around abortion — how it’s never really said out loud, but always there, hiding under the surface. a real choice that girls are never allowed to make. where the system will preach “life is sacred,” but give you a plastic chair in an overcrowded ward and leave you to figure it out alone.sure, it plays it safe sometimes — there are parts where you wish it pushed a little more. but it still says a lot, even in quiet moments.Sunshine doesn’t claim to have all the answers. but it knows the questions that need to be asked.about bodily autonomy. about access to care. about what it really means to grow up in a place that punishes girls for being girls.APAKAHUSAY NYO MS TONET AT MARIS!

the world is unforgiving to womenlike the corners of manila that bore witness to sunshine and her quiet struggle, like the santo niños in quiapo that hide fatality, a risk to escape a life that was never theirs to carry. like the church that stands in the midst of relentless shame.the world is unforgiving to women, where desire is almost always consequence for who were born to bear its fruit yet never a sliver of guilt from those who took part in it.the world is unforgiving to women yet it expects so much. so much burden to carry. so much life to spend carrying. with only sisters, other women, to carry it with, to lighten the load.rarely has a film induced so much crying from me. it’s not perfect, but it hit a part of me that mourns for our women, for the lives that have forever been altered by the lack of knowledge and autonomy and conversation. and still, everywhere there are quiet ways that we hold each other through it all.

Watching Sunshine wasn’t just watching a movie. Parang I was sitting beside a woman, listening to her story ng tahimik lang, pero sobrang bigat. It’s not easy to watch, but that’s exactly why it felt so real. What hit me the most was how the film didn’t try to be loud or preachy. The film doesn’t try to romanticize or a free promotion for abortion. It just let the silence do the work. Minsan iyak lang, minsan wala talagang salita. That makes it more powerful. Hindi ito simpleng kwento. It’s about pain, dreams, and mga choices na hindi talaga madaling pagpilian.Pero I have to say, may parts na medyo kulang for me. Sana mas dark yung cinematography, like Khalel 15 — gritty and raw. Lastly, hindi ito movie para sa lahat. But still, Sunshine gives us something real. And if you’re willing to sit with it and really listen, then you’ll see a side of womanhood na madalas tinatago.
A woman who refuses to ruled by their own body, choices and dreams is something powerful and bravery. !!!!

Mula pa lang sa trailer, alam ko na—hindi ko puwedeng palampasin ang pelikulang ito. Direk Tonet ‘yan, eh. May tiwala ako sa kakayahan niyang gawing matula ang trahedya, at gawing tahimik pero mabigat ang mga sigaw ng kababaihan sa lipunang laging inuuna ang hiya kaysa sa hustisya.Isa sa mga personal na dahilan kung bakit ako nanood ay dahil gusto kong unawain—hindi man buo, pero kahit konti—kung ano ang dinadala ng isang babaeng katulad ni Sunshine. Bilang isang assigned male at birth, pero hindi ganap na komportable sa label na iyon, alam kong may distansya sa pagitan namin ni Sunshine. Pero iyon mismo ang dahilan kung bakit ako nanahimik sa sinehan. Tumigil akong mag-analisa, at hayaan ang pelikula na magsalita para sa sarili nito. Hindi ko kailangang maging babae para makiramay. Pero gusto kong makiramdam. At dito, sa pelikulang ito, nagtagumpay akong maramdaman si Sunshine—ang kanyang pagkalito, galit, at takot—na para bang sarili kong laman-loob ang kinikiskis ng eksena.At sa prosesong iyon, nadama ko si Sunshine—ang pagkalito niya na hindi simpleng pagkaligaw, kundi paglalakad sa isang landas na sinabihan siyang bawal. Ang galit niyang hindi mapagsigawan, at ang takot niyang hindi inamin, pero nandoon sa bawat kumpas ng katawan niya. Maris Racal didn’t just play Sunshine—she inhabited her. She carried her, as if every scene weighed heavily on her spine, even when she stood upright. May mga eksena na walang dialogue pero mas mabigat pa sa sigawan. At doon ko nakita ang mastery ni Maris bilang aktres: ang kakayahang magsalita gamit ang pananahimik.Nakakatawang may nagsabi raw sa likod ng kamera na “haggard” siya habang nagsu-shoot. I laughed—not because it’s funny, but because it’s too real. Ganito talaga ang hitsura ng kabataang babae na araw-araw tinatanggihan ang mundo, pero hindi puwedeng mapagod. May mga Sunshine sa Quiapo, sa mga post sa Reddit, sa mga comments na deleted, sa mga babae sa jeep na tahimik lang pero may bitbit na kwento. And it takes a film like Sunshine to remind us: they are not voiceless. We just haven’t been listening.Unang tingin kay Annika, iisipin mong comic relief siya. Isang batang gumugulo sa eksena, parang pang-balanse sa bigat ng naratibo. Pero habang tumatagal, na-realize kong siya pala ang pinakamatining sa lahat. Hindi siya ordinaryong karakter—siya ang konsensya ni Sunshine. Hindi ang moralistic kind, but the invasive kind. Yung konsensyang hindi laging tama o mali, kundi nagtatanong: “Nasaan ka na?” “Handa ka ba?” “Ito ba ang gusto mong piliin?” At dahil hindi laging consistent ang paglitaw niya—minsan parang guni-guni, minsan parang totoo—mas naging epektibo siya. Kasi hindi ba ganoon din ang konsensya? It creeps in when you're alone. It arrives uninvited. In a country where abortion is taboo, Annika becomes more than a person—she’s a presence. A question. A symbol of possibility and loss, but not in a way that condemns. She’s not there to judge Sunshine, but to make us feel what it means to carry a choice you can’t share with anyone. Sa isang bansang ang moralidad ay naka-template mula sa pulpito, ang pagkakaroon ng karakter tulad ni Annika is radical. Hindi siya plot device. Isa siyang reimaginasyon ng konsensya—hindi para ipahiya ang babae, kundi ipaalala kung gaano kabigat ang dalahin sa lipunang pilit silang pinatatahimik..Ang Sunshine ay hindi pelikulang pro-choice dahil gusto nitong makipagtalo. Hindi rin ito pelikula tungkol sa abortion dahil gusto nitong mag-skandalo. Ito ay pelikula tungkol sa karapatan. Sa kakayahang pumili, kahit pa masakit ang pagpiling iyon. Sunshine doesn’t celebrate abortion—it honors the courage to face it. Sa lipunang ang kababaihan ay kailangang laging malinis, laging mabait, laging matino, heto ang isang pelikulang nagsasabing: ang katawan mo ay hindi kasalanan. Ang pagpili mo ay hindi dapat katumbas ng pagkapako.Maraming salamat, Direk Tonet. Salamat sa hindi pag-ikot sa ligtas na naratibo. Salamat sa pagbibigay ng boses sa katahimikan. Salamat sa paghubog ng pelikulang hindi lang para sa kababaihan, kundi para sa lahat ng gustong matutong makinig.Bilang isang lalaki na walang MATRES, pero may malasakit sa mga may isa, ramdam ko ang urgency ng kwento. Sunshine is not a perfect film—but it is a vital one. And in a country that rarely gives women room to speak, a film like this doesn’t just feel brave. It feels necessary.

" Drown out the noise."This line in the Sunshine struck me after watching the film. Noise is considered as a plot device in the film literally and figuratively. I like how the background music or the noise from the background is used to set the tone and mood of the film especially in scenes where Sunshine is walking or riding a jeep home. Noise in the film can also represent the doubts that fill her while practicing and self-righteous religious people who judge her actions throughout the film.The film is about a gymnast who plans to join the tryouts for the Olympics. However, she receives a result that is unexpectedly pregnant which can hinder her chances in getting in. Maris Racal is great in her role as Sunshine and I think that she embodies the role of a gymnast especially since she tried gymnastics to prepare for her role. There were scenes that were remarkable for me such as when she tries to hit a the mirror of a car after her boyfriend (played by Elijah Canlas) doesn't take responsibility for her pregnancy. I also loved the supporting characters as well. Despite their small roles, they made a mark for me. For instance, Jennica Garcia was impressive in her scenes with Maris Racal as her older sister. You can feel that she defends and protects her sister and stay by her side especially during her revelation that she is pregnant. Xyriel Manabat is no surprise for me since I admire her acting skills since she was a child actress. She is great as Sunshine's best friend. Annika Co, an upcoming child actress, is a scene stealer where she acts as a conscience to Sunshine. She is charming and witty in her role and I think the twist made sense to me in one scene.In addition to it being a sports drama, this film also tackled the themes of women's choice and abortion. These topics are considered sensitive and taboo in a dominant Catholic and conservative society. As a man, this film moved me and realize how hard it is to be a woman in a society wherethey are judged for having an autonomy in their body. In a third world country, healthcare is considered a privilege especially for the poor. Because of abortion being considered illegal and immoral, women are forced to resort to unsafe practices which can endanger them. It is shown in the film and I think it's interesting that it depicted two doctors: one which discriminates women because of her religious bias and one which tried to understand and helped another character in the film who turned to abortion. It's a sad reality, but I'm glad that this film will open conversations about themes like these.Overall, I find Sunshine an impressive film. I think this is Antonette Jadaone's best film so far. It's my second film that I've seen in cinemas and I'm grateful to witness it in the big screen because it is worth the watch there with its immersive experience. I was definitely looking forward to it since it's rare to watch a sports film which centers around gymnastics and it has been shown in film festivals abroad. I was worried that it won't be shown here because of how controversial it would be because of the stand of the Catholic Church and other religious sectors regarding abortion. I guess more people are more open-minded towards the topics unlike before. Aside from the acting, what I found compelling in the film is the cinematography and scoring which adds tension and mood to the it. Despite its limited release and pitted against two superhero films during its premiere, I really hope more people will get a chance to watch this movie. Even if it shows the harsh realities of life and in sports, I agree with other film critics that it also shows hope. There is Sunshine after the rain.

No doubt my favorite Jadaone film, Sunshine is not only an important work of art in a cultural context, but an objectively beautiful, clean and concise narrative work. What I mean is not a single frame is wasted, or given up for style points - every decision of performance, framing and pace is made to serve the story, to make us empathize with Sunshine, to feel what she feels.Woman vs the institution - the clarity of this theme is just so powerful, yet we’re brought into Sunshine’s world through masterful camerawork that just feels honest. There’s a shot I love, where Sunshine is framed inside a window (in her room then in a motel), and the chaos of the city goes on about her, uncaring and apathetic to her situation. That’s the whole movie - the slow-burning horror that she is being shunned by society, cramped into tiny spaces trying to survive. It made me cringe to hear the chants of “Pilipinas” by the crowd in her performance at the end (the sad reality of Filipino athletes, unsupported in training yet celebrated in victory)Maris Racal’s best performance. The care and dedication she brought to the role should be applauded. Everyone else in the movie is so dialed in too, a subtle superpower of Direk Tonet’s ear for relatable acting and dialogue. Also love the Pastor P appearance, who brings such an important discussion into the public consciousness. The ultimate boss level: God & practicality vs the woman’s decision.Instant classic!

“Sunshine” gripped my soul and left me hollow with unease. the first ten minutes we follow Sunshine as she drifts aimlessly through the restless streets of Manila, and that’s how the entire film feels. yes, it’s sending a message, but watching her spiral felt almost voyeuristic, as if we were witnessing something intimate and illegal. no propaganda, just raw, heartbreaking truth.and as much as i hate comparing directors, the rawness of each frame felt deeply “Brocka” but captured through the tenderness and gaze of a woman. at the film’s core is Maris Racal, exceptional in her quiet nuance, supported beautifully by Jennica Garcia.this film will linger with me for days. it’s about the cruelty of the world, the ache of aspirations, the fragile hope for a better life, and, ultimately, a woman’s choice.And at the center of it all, I love when a woman chooses herself.
OMEYAK LANG AKO

sobrang halaga sa akin ng sunshine dahil hindi lang karapatan ng kababaihan ang buhat nitong adbokasiya, kung hindi pati na rin ang karapatan ng kabataan na madalas isinasantabi lang sa usapin ng reproductive health. kung ang tema ay tungkol sa pagiging pro-choice lang, magwowork pa rin naman yung kwento kung young adult o di kaya’y isang full grown woman si sunshine. pero siya ay isang teenager—bata sa mata ng batas at babae sa mata ng lipunan. eventually, titignan na rin siya bilang isang babae na lang dulot ng kanyang pagkabuntis, na para bang nawawala agad ang pagkabata porket may dinadalang bata.doble ang pasan ng teenage pregnancy, dahil bilang bata o babae man, wala silang say sa sarili nilang katawan. kulang pa ang impormasyon at rekurso kapag kailangan na nila, making them even more vulnerable sa panganib. tulad ni sunshine, marami ang natutukso sa mga ilegal at nakamamatay na paraan para lang ipaglaban ang karapatan nila sa sariling katawan, dahil wala silang natatanggap na anumang uri ng suporta. mas pinahahalagahan ng lipunan ang buhay na namumuo pa lang sa sinapupunan kesa ang buhay na nariyan na. kaya bukod sa panawagan para sa legal na proteksyon sa autonomy ng kababaihan at dekalidad na healthcare system, lumilitaw rin sa pelikula ang agarang pangangailangan natin para sa comprehensive sex education na siyang magpoprovide ng necessary and appropriate resources sa mga bata tungkol sa sex, contraception, consent, at iba pang mga kaugnay na bagay na gagabay sa kanila para tahakin ito nang ligtas at malay.sana ipalabas pa ito sa mas malawak na audience huhu kelangan to ipakilala at idiin sa consciousness ng mga pilipino ngayon din!!!

Solid pa rin sa pangalawang nood. Mas nag-focus ako sa details this time. At mas kasama ko si Sunshine this time, sa buong pagtakbo niya at sa lahat ng ingay.my FIRST rewatch of Sunshine at the cinemas. with my friends + pa-talkback din with direk Tonet and Inah. what a day!

"gets ko na"a moment in this film that really struck me was the last scene with sunshine and her almost child — that could've been me to my mom. my parents were teenagers when they had me, and my mom told me na she tried buying pamparegla from quiapo before, but her parents stopped her saying it was a horrendous sin kay Lord. if she had chosen to live her life without me existing, i would thank her for it. gets na gets ko siya. i hope this film will successfully convey its message to the viewers, and serve as an eye-opener for those who believe that a woman doesn't have a choice.rhed bustamante's character as a 13-year old who was sa'd by her tito reflects the reality of a lot of women — girls even, cause she's not even an adult yet. abortion being illegal in the philippines doesn't stop people from doing it, hence it leads them to doing it in a horrifying and deadly way. pamparegla pills and hilot are ways people resort to because of abortion being inaccessible here in our country. tapos nung na-ospital siya hindi pa ginamot? tangina talaga ng mga lalaki! thank you dra. helena for your life!to all anti-abortion out there, i hope this film reaches you. if it's not convenient for you, then okay, but at least think about those who really need it. overall, this film is such a great commentary on how women aren't always meant to be mothers, and that one failure won't ever stop you from reaching your dreams. to all sunshine's out there, kapit lang :))
salamat sa buhay mo, direk tonet!

“Sunshine” is more than a film, it is a visceral, unflinching portrait of womanhood in the Philippines. It gives voice not only to the silenced narratives about teenage pregnancy and abortion, but also to the layered realities of how Filipinas live, dream, suffer, and survive amid the relentless chaos of urban life. It dares to confront uncomfortable truths.The cinematography is superb! Every shot is meticulously composed to convey the oppressive density of Manila. The stress is not just seen, it is felt. Salamat, direk Tonet! This is a big contribution to the success of Philippine cinema.

many reasons why i absolutely loved this movie: 1) watched it w someone who is very dear to me (hi angel if you’re seeing this)2) the actors3) the story it tells 4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHok now lets go point by point starting at no. 2. hoping the people reading this dont think im intellectualizing my review or whatever bc i just have a lot of thoughts and i couldnt sleep so im writing this now…2) actorsits lined up with amazing, talented actors so it’s absolutely a no-brainer that they would all deliver their lines stunningly. however, each character brought out such vivid emotions that i believe only their respective actor/actress could bring out. props to the casting director and direk jadaone for this. i first give my flowers to elijah canlas and piolo pascual. honestly believe that no other pair of actors could portray this father-son, catholic tandem better. elijah weirdly embodies the annoying, conyo, gago actor really well, while piolo is no stranger to playing a overt Catholic. i also am all praise for xyriel, meryll, and jennica. the women in the film who, in a world that is cruel, chose to be kind, especially to Sunshine. i praise jennica especially because with every line recited, you can feel her character’s exhaustion of having to give up their dreams and forcing themselves to accept their reality in an unforgiving society, as if she had a choice. of course, annika co is also a standout star here. though a rookie in the industry, i loved seeing her on the big screen. lastly, maris. no one can play Sunshine but Maris Racal. i fear i have to make a separate review on her solely. i hope she bags many, many awards because she deserves it. 3) the story it tellsthe story of Sunshine is one that I, as a woman, have encountered many times. while post-debrief, i recounted the amount of times i was told a former schoolmate of mine became a teenage mother, and i thought about all of the dreams they had to give up simply because they had no choice. even in this film, Sunshine’s reality painted her to have little to no choice at all. while it’s not a new narrative, it’s a narrative that’s stuck in the past—in traditional, old, conservative Philippine society, which is why movies like Sunshine feel so refreshing. it strives to go beyond what society is now. 4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHthe fact that a film like this was produced and is being shown during a time where, globally, conservatism is on the rise and the Philippines is nowhere close to even considering the decriminalization of abortion, is already something revolutionary in itself. hopefully, this movie opens more doors to more discussions on abortion and bodily autonomy. i really have lots of respect for direk tonette and Maris for being at the forefront of what could be the beginning of the creation of a bigger platform for many women across the country to speak about autonomy and choice.

it’s worth mentioning that other than the discussion of women’s bodily autonomy, there is also solidarity observed with the female characters within the story. and i like how it is handled not in a romanticized or villainized manner, but of compassion and empathy. i like that. i hope this movie opens the minds of those who wish or are curious to watch the film. :)

manila in its barest, philippine societal system in its most oppressive on women, patriarchy in its sharpest teeth clenched tightly on women leaving them bloody (literally and figuratively), long held religious beliefs in its firmest grip leaving many more regressive, and most of all love and support system in its purest and most tender. i keep wondering by the end about the women who weren’t given the privilege to choose, those like mary grace, those who never had the support they needed when faced with the same dilemma, those who’ve braved the use of unconventional means of abortion and may have almost died or indeed died. i wonder of their dreams, of their autonomy, of the life they have to face. and this is a reality lived by many women in the philippines, that despite the film leaving on a positive note, i just cant help but think: this world isn’t built for women to thrive, instead it’s a world where they have to fight tooth and nail just to survive, and in the film, to just get the basic need of a choice over their body. a world crafted where men’s needs and wants are at the forefront, and where women would have to beg to even be considered.

first ever review!! new lang sa letterboxd xDD i enjoy being here! AND it really calls me to put some review sa film:_)truly every movie we watched leaves a mark but this cut deeper. mahirap maging babae sa sistemang dini-dismiss ka. hirap. sobrang ganda ng lahat, pati personality ng quiapo, na kahit gabi sa maynila, maingay pa rin. sa public hospital na halos tabi-tabi at yung mga pasyente na lang din nag tutulungan. ito kasi yung realidad na hindi alam ng karamihan, na hindi maintindihan ng ilan na walang ginawa kundi magsimba at maging komportable sa buhay.and i was wishing that it reaches those people, i hope they sit with the same uncomfortable feeling that the characters had. i hope it twisted their minds, to make them think. i hope it bleeds them just as how their "beliefs" put women in danger by denying abortion.lahat ng bida sa pelikula ay babae :'DD i have no intention to romanticize their circumstances, and it aches and comfort that there is warmth against all of it, na assurance na kasama pa rin ng mga kababaihan, natin, yung isa't isa.

the very experience of breaking down on public transportation while hev abi blasts through the speakers lol. kidding aside—hay, grabe. this film feels like being punched in the gut, only to be offered a warm hug right after.growing up as a woman means being taught to feel shame about everything. liking sex. not liking sex.getting pregnant too early. getting pregnant too late.being too submissive to men. not being submissive enough.getting married. not getting married.prioritizing your career. choosing to be a stay-at-home mom.and the list goes on. just full of contradictions.that's why i cannot emphasize enough how much i love the film's concept: a woman saving a woman saving another woman. sunshine’s sister standing up for her. her saving mary grace. her friend. her coach. the doctor. even the pregnant women na nagpapaypay sa kanya while she’s unconscious. just women looking out for each other.i watched this in the cinema, and when i went to the ladies' comfort room after the credits rolled, lahat kami mugto ang mata. i think we had all seen parts of ourselves reflected back at us. and it hurt. but it also healed.i hope more stories like this are told. i hope more women continue to take up space, hold each other close, and do whatever the hell they want. without apology, without SHAME.p.s. it couldn't have been anyone else but maris <33

beautifully acted and well written. there’s a sharp, dark humor threaded in its dialogues on sex, childbirth, & dreams, an unflinching tone that never really leaves u, and a quiet reality of sunshine that mirrors so much of what we rarely say out loud. a combination that truly amplifies the much needed conversation that this film advocates—one that gently but firmly questions our sense of life, morality, and the cost of it all. also, i’m a big fan of the jadaone-racal duo like shet ang galing potaena sana gets niyo! #marisracalapologist

“drown out the noise.”sunshine tramples on both internal and external noises—judgment, fear, catholic guilt, and desperate prayers; the chaos that quietly unfolds in the dark streets of manila, and the ironies existing at the heart of folk-catholicism as underground, unsafe abortion exists steps away from a sacred ground. it’s impossible for sunshine—for women—to drown out the noise. My favorite detail in this movie is the portrayal of different women, each with her own turmoil, resources, and stage in life, struggling in a deeply patriarchal and faith-bound society, while still finding the strength to stand for each other. wala nang ibang makakaunawa at dadamay sa paghihirap ng pagiging babae kundi kapwa mga babae.this film is dark, heavy, and uncomfortable to watch (as it should) but necessary. it shatters your core and makes you question how far can religious ideas go in a hostile and punishing society. A BIG CLAP TO DIREK JADAONE’S STRONG FEMALE CHARACTERS WHO NAVIGATE THE COMPLEXITIES THAT COME WITH BEING A WOMAN!

we need to open up a conversation. stat.about manila. about how quiapo has its own pulse.about commuting. about the air in your ponytail in the jeepney.about motel rooms. about pleasure in the darkness, for cheap, coerced, manipulative f*cks.about the repercussions of said f*cks. about how shameful it is to live with it in a place with ever-pointing fingers and watchful eyes.about motherhood. about how it isn't as glam when you're not as ready for it.about sports. about how athletes stand on their own two feet, sans government support.about the sunshines in our own circle. about the decisions you never really made but lived with anyway. about the dreams you chased with a sprained ankle.the ribbons you twirled and ripped.the jerseys you wore until they were worn out.the maternity clothes in your shopping cart.but what choice do you have?the answer is none.because how do you live in a country that is against you?in a system that is made for you to break, slowly, agonizingly?in places of pity and shame, how do you rise?in breaking glass windows and cages, who cheers you on?in places where the sun is scarce and the skies are dark, who forges your shine?

I love my mother so much. For me, she’s the best woman in the world - the only woman I love with all my heart. I enjoy Filipino films because of her influence - she loved classic Filipino films. She loved Sharon Cuneta. She loved Aldub. But I recently learned that she once dreamed of becoming a flight stewardess - a dream I never knew she had.I only learned about this and other stories of the woman I thought I knew when her sister shared them with us during a visit this year. That’s when the realization sank in, I knew my mom, but not the little girl she used to be - the one with so many dreams. A probinsyana with this dream of going around the world. But she had me (I'm the eldest) when she was eighteen. Unplanned. She said she never regretted itBut I remember when I was young, she drowned herself with alcohol almost every day. Now, I understand. She never had a choice. I'm happy that she is my mother. But it also hurts me to know that she could be in a better place -pursuing her dreams, seeing the world - if not because of me. This film got me because I hope my mom had a choice at that time. I loved her so much, but I hope in her next life, she chooses her dreams.

SUNSHINE advances itself as a film about bodily autonomy in a nation that denies its very terminology, yet it does so through the insulated idiom of psychological realism rather than the concretised mapping of the material conditions that make autonomy, abortion, and girlhood existentially precarious. We are immersed in affect, but the structure underpinning these sensations is left either ambient or altogether unrendered. Yes, the pharmacy exists as a moral space and the hospital as carceral, but where is the livelihood? Who funds the training? What does it mean, materially, to be a 19-year-old athlete—and an international one, at that—with no visible labouring parent and no bread line to back it up?Abortion is outlawed in the Philippines because it preserves state-church power and results in the reproductive labour of the poor as exploitable and their agency criminal, but to bracket class from the narrative—in a context where economic vulnerability is the foremost determinant of reproductive injustice—is consequential. Instead, the endless deferral into mood, while expressive, is in itself a seductive alibi for political disengagement. I understand that this is a film of interiority—that the point is to reflect Sunshine’s constrained perceptual field—but her interiority is a response to economic realities that the film chooses to elude, and when the audience is asked to interpolate systemic weight from ambience without any clear depiction of how deprivation functions, what we get is an abstraction that parades as empathy, and from that abstraction, other evasions proliferate: the neoliberal myth of the meritocratic athlete, whose suffering must be understood as psychological strain rather than as infrastructural abandonment; the convenient fiction that ambition alone propels a body through state-sponsored regimes without subsidy or the material realities the film forgoes. To abstract oppression into psychic distress then, while refusing its logistical origins, is to risk reproducing the same symbolic economy the Church relies upon: one in which the body is meaningful only as a metaphor and a vessel onto which morality is projected.This aesthetic disposition of interiority is of course obviously a structure inherited from the exportable idiom of European festival realism where the trauma of the Filipina is depicted legibly for the global North. From this perspective, it would make sense that the institutions that manufacture her precarity are rendered as emotional rather than historical, inviting the audience to feel with her but never to account—but by doing so, what emerges is not so much a Filipino film but a Filipino offering: an artefact of pain rendered in tones familiar to jurors abroad, a choice that aligns seamlessly with both (1) Jadaone’s career pivot into the international circuit, having premiered the film at Berlinale and TIFF, and (2) the film’s own final sequence: Sunshine performing her routine at the SEA games before a panel of foreign adjudicators, body taut and calibrated for approval by those who will never understand the weight of what she forfeited to arrive there. By naming these two parallels do we metabolise the rage of a system into something palatable and interpretable, and since both Jadaone and Sunshine must contort to be seen, in being seen, they are asked to become less what they mean. Perhaps the question is not whether SUNSHINE fails as a film or recedes as an offering, but whether it was ever permitted the autonomy to be anything else—whether within the landscape of Philippine cinema, where funding is precarious, distribution systems anaemic, and state culture support present only for the films that do not threaten it, a film like SUNSHINE must already enter the frame pre-legibilised and pre-digested, its rage ironed out for export. This is, after all, by the admission of its own producer Bianca Balbuena, a film that delayed its domestic release in order ‘to premiere in top festivals [around] the world to create noise and curiosity’, with the implication that only through international approval could the film attain enough value to justify its own existence at home. Thus, to resist the very circuit that enables its existence is impossible, but recognising this sharpens our understanding of the conditions under which those evasions occur. What we must ask, then, is what kind of complicity we are willing to forgive in a nation that punishes truth so severely that even its cinema must contort just to be heard.

Quiapo has always felt like a contradiction. It's a district that thrives on both holiness and hustle, tradition and survival, all crammed into claustrophobic, identical alleyways. At its heart stands a towering church, surrounded by vendors selling everything: street food, religious images, herbal medicines, fake documents, sex toys, and abortion kits – pamparegla. The irony writes itself. And yet, that's where people are forced to go when they're desperate. Like Sunshine.Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a gymnast on the rise who discovers she's pregnant before a major competition – just as her future starts to tighten around her. The plot is simple, but never small. What unfolds is a slow, steady panic of a young woman trying to figure things out in a country that offers her no real choices. You feel the weight that she's carrying, not just in her silence, but in her body. She's holding so much in, almost willing it all to be a fever dream. But beneath that restraint is a quiet rage — in her posture, in her breath, in the way she fights to keep it all together.The movie doesn't try to frame anything as heroic or tragic, and that's what makes it powerful. What stood out most to me was how angry, how fearless, it allows itself to be. It simmers. Controlled, but with crushing intensity. This is Direk Tonet's best work to date. It's her most honest and her most focused. And you can tell she did this with immense care. The love is in the details.

DI AKO NANGHINAYANG SA BINAYAD KO.Sobrang napukaw ng atensyon ko kung gaano ka realistic ang bawat eksena, ang ingay at lagkitan sa maynila, ang mga deboto ng quiapo church, ang mga ale na nagtitinda ng pamparegla at pampalaglag sa harap ng simbahan, ang kahirapan, ang unwanted pregnancy, ang krisis sa healthcare system, ang aborsyon at ang konsensya ni sunshine na hinahabol sya bawat minuto ng kanyang araw. it really captured every struggles ng pagiging babae sa bansang to. Sobrang raw, sobrang totoo at sobrang tapang ni direk tonet sa paggawa ng gantong pelikula na sana marami pa ang makapanood. Also, the performance of THE Maris Racal. Dalang dala nya ang emosyon ng manonood, the rage, pain, and bravery of Sunshine. Isa sa talagang nagpa agos ng luha ko ay ang eksena na sumasayaw sya, nakangiti pero ramdam mo ang bawat emosyon. Grabe ang scene na yun, walang dialogue pero tagos sa puso!! It was really indeed the best performance of her. And that ending, i love how direk tonet didnt show what happens to the unborn child, and pinakita na lang na nakaabot sya sa competition, it just shows na ang pagkakaroon ng choice ay magsasalba sa mga pangarap na minsan ng kinain ng sistema ng bansang ito. Gets na gets kita, Sunshine bago ko pa ito panoorin at sana magets ka na rin nila.Ginawa ang pelikula na to hindi lang para sa mga babae, ginawa ito para ipakita sa mga taong hindi nakakaintindi ang reyalidad ni Sunshine. Mahal kita direk tonet sobra!!!

This film gives you the opportunity to judge Sunshine & her decision-making as she deals with the consequences of an act she did not commit alone yet had to face entirely by herself. Dahil sa sistema at mga paniniwalang hindi pabor sa mga kababaihan.After watching, you might say “gets ko na” as you start to understand how they feel & where they’re coming from. Unfortunately, that’s only the tip of the iceberg. You must also imagine the lives of all other Sunshines out there whose stories remain unheard and unseen. In the real world setting, you no longer have access to every woman’s story. But through Sunshine, you gain something just as important: empathy and understanding. And maybe— just maybe— hindi naman matatapakan ang pagkatao mo if you simply allow women the freedom to decide for their own lives. Kudos to Maris Racal for beautifully executing the role of Sunshine and to Direk Jadaone for passionately pushing this brave and controversial work of art!

It takes a village, but that village needs to be better, especially for women. Whether that’s here in the Philippines or in the rest of the world. I hope people from all facets of our society can watch this movie and leave with a more compassionate attitude towards women with unwanted pregnancies. I can only hope the message of this can resonate and make us consider more material support for them, beyond the compassion we ought to show them. Oh, and legalize abortion now. #prochoice

[4:46AM] iba yung alam mo lang, sa naiintindihan mo talaga. staying informed is one thing, but feeling it? letting it crack something open in you? ibang usapan ‘yon.alam kong masama ang aborsyon sa mata ng simbahan. lumaki akong alam 'yon; itinuro, inulit, pinaniwalaan. alam ko rin kung paano siya tinitignan ng lipunan, ng batas, ng sistemang matagal nang hindi pumapanig sa kababaihan. isang sistemang feudal, patriyarkal, mapanghusga. pinalaki tayo rito, pinalo, pinatahimik.pero alam ko rin ito: may karapatan ang babae. sa sarili niyang katawan. sa sarili niyang desisyon. at sa healthcare na hindi dapat ipinagmamakaawa, kundi kusang ibinibigay. alam ko rin na hindi dapat tinitingnan ang aborsyon sa lente ng kasalanan o krimen, na para bang awtomatikong mali ang pagpili, at masama ang pumipili. pero ang hindi ko alam, ang hindi ko kailanman mararanasan sa ganap na paraan, ay kung ano ang pakiramdam. ang bumangon araw-araw dala ang bigat ng isang desisyong walang tama sa paningin ng lahat. ang labanan hindi lang ang sarili mong konsensya, kundi ang mundong hindi kailanman kinilala ang pinagdadaanan mo, ang takot mo, ang dahilan mo.yun ang hindi ko alam. at yun ang pinaramdam sa akin ng Sunshine.and i think that's where Sunshine really succeeds. it doesn’t glorify. it doesn’t argue. it simply shows. it gives us a glimpse. into a life of a young woman, into her choice, into her pain, and the kind of quiet strength we rarely talk about. gusto lang talaga ng pelikula magkuwento tungkol sa isang babae. ang dami kong gustong himayin. but if there’s one thing that stayed with me, it’s this: Sunshine gives voice to stories we rarely hear. and maybe we avoid them kasi nga masakit. mabigat. kasi hindi tanggap ng kultura at sistemang kinalakihan natin. uncomfortable. but that’s exactly why they need to be told.what makes the film powerful is how intentional it is. every frame, every silence, every turn it didn’t take. lahat may dahilan. it could’ve been more clever. it could’ve been more dramatic. pero hindi siya nagpakitang gilas. instead, ginamit niya ‘yung simplicity para tumama. para magpa-reflect. para magpa-isip.what i appreciated most was that it didn’t force me to take a side. it didn’t try to tell me which choice was right, no matter what sunshine ended up deciding. it just asked me to listen. to sit with sunshine. to be there with her. even when things were loud & messy, even when she herself didn’t know what to do. and sometimes, that’s all people need. not answers. just space. and empathy. maraming empathy. Sunshine moved me to empathize in ways i didn’t expect i could.gusto ko rin pala i-highlight kung paano naging karakter ang maynila rito. magulo ang maynila. marumi. maingay. minsan bitag, pero minsan daan palabas. minsan parang impyerno, pero minsan parang tanging lugar na may pag-asa. sunshine moved through its chaos looking for clarity, and somehow the city mirrored her confusion. klaustro ang mga eskinita pero may mga puwang. noisy yet full of silences. manila is hysterically cruel, yes. brutal sa babae, sa mahirap, sa pagod. pero sa likod ng lahat ng ‘yon, may mga sulok na mabait. tahimik. marunong makinig. may tenderness na hindi nagpapakita, pero nandiyan; in the people who care quietly, in the moments of stillness in between the noise.and god, maris. maris fucking racal. this is hers. this is every woman’s story. she is a woman in every way that matters. alam kong magaling na siya dati pa. nakita ko na rin naman ang ibang trabaho niya. but this time, iba. masarap sa pakiramdam na makita ang isang magaling na babae na hindi nakakabit sa loveteam, walang lalaking bitbit sa screen para lang matawag na lead. walang kilig, walang branding. sakanya lang talaga ito. and that felt right. that felt important.the way she portrayed sunshine’s pain and stillness and quiet strength, it just hit. hindi siya umaarte. she wasn’t trying to convince anyone. she just was. may mga eksena na wala siyang sinasabi, pero ramdam mo lahat. nakakaiyak siya, pero hindi dahil may music o linyang mabigat. nakakaiyak kasi totoo. kasi hindi mo alam kung saan ka huhugot ng ginhawa sa pinagdadaanan niya.totoong haggard nga siya buong palabas hahaha, and it just made so much sense. ganun talaga ang itsura ng babae na napagod na. sa sarili. sa mundo. sa kakaisip ng tama. sa sistema na walang binibigay na sagot. and yet she kept going. and yet she was still trying. that look—the mess, the confusion, the exhaustion, that’s what a woman in the middle of a fight looks like. not dramatic. just human.maris, sa’yo talaga ito. no one else could’ve done it this way. no one can take this away from you. and i hope alam mo kung gaano kahalaga ang binigay mo sa pelikulang ‘to.and the women around sunshine, sila rin ang puso ng kwento. sa mata pa lang ng bawat isa, kita mo agad. hindi sila filler. hindi sila background. si jennica garcia, si annika co, si xyriel manabat, atbp. pati yung mga sandaling lumitaw lang, ang doktor, ang bantay sa motel, yung pharmacist sa botika, yung babae sa quiapo, maski yung mga babae sa maternity ward. lahat sila may dala. lahat sila may pinanggagalingan. and they all stood with sunshine in one way or another. iba-iba sila, pero iisa ng tinig. kababaihan ang nagdala ng pelikula. kababaihan ang gumising sa kwento.Sunshine isn’t easy to watch, especially if you're a woman in this country— but maybe it’s not meant to be. kasi tunay na kwento siya. and real stories don’t always comfort. they challenge. they disturb. they demand something from you. and that’s what this film did. it made me feel. it made me think.sobrang ganda napasulat tlg ako ng review. i had to sit with it for an hour or two. ang husay mo direk tonet!

May nag-uusap kanina sa likod ko habang nanonood ako pero hinayaan ko nalang kasi nasanay na ako, tapos sakto yung scene na sumunod is yung sinabihan si Sunshine na “drown out the noise”. Okay lang sana eh kasi may libreng commentary ako, pero nung nalaman na ni Sunshine na buntis na siya, yung lalaki sa likod ko sinabi na “tatanga-tanga” siya. Medyo nawalan ako ng focus sa panonood dahil sa narinig ko kaya lumipat nalang ako ng pwesto maya-maya.Sobrang ganda ng paghandle ng movie na ‘to sa topic niya, lalo na sa bansang ‘to na sobrang sensitibo ng mga ganitong usapan kahit na hindi na naman sa ibang bansa, kaya malakas yung respeto ko sa lahat ng involved sa paggawa nito, lalo na si direk Jadaone, kasi kailangan natin ng mga pelikula katulad nito para makasimula ng pag-uusap at pagbabago sa bansang ‘to. Ang daming taong tumutol at humamon sa konsensya ni Sunshine sa iba’t ibang paraan, pagkontra sa kanya gamit ang relihiyon, ang batas, ang pera, ang kalalakihan, at iba pa. Kada sulok ng Pilipinas may matatamaan, kasama na yung nakaupo sa likod ko, at dapat lang.

Ang pelikulang ito ay tunay na isang sikat ng araw. Nakakasilaw. Tumatagos ang sinag. Totoo siya sa pakiramdam.Dahil totoo nga siya. Totoo si Sunshine.Matatanaw mo lang siya kapag binigyan mo ng oras ang sarili mong huminto at pansinin ang paligid. Saka mo mapagtatanto: kasama natin siya sa bawat hakbang ng kasalukuyan. Kahit sa gabi. Kahit pa sa gitna ng unos.Isa siyang payak na reyalidad—nararamdaman sa dulo ng mga daliri. Parang singaw sa paligid; halos masamyo mo sa hangin. Ganyan siya kasinsid. Ganyan siya humihingi ng pansin. Patuloy siyang lumulusot kahit sa pinakamasisikip at pinakatahimik na puwang ng kaingayan. Siya ang bumabati sa bawat umaga. At kahit sa gabi’t hapon, may iniwang peklat—mga bakas na, sa paglaon, bumubuo ng mas malaking larawan. Larawang pumupukaw sa atin tungkol sa mga madalas itinatanggi, pinatatahimik, isinasantabi. Mga bagay na totoo, at tunay namang nangyayari—ngunit ikinukubli. Tila bawal. Tila tabu. Ngunit sila pala ang tunay na bumubuo sa bilog, ngunit nananatiling hindi kinikilala sa tatsulok ng lipunan.At ang tanging hangarin ni Sunshine: na maging isa ka sa “atin.”Ako? Gets ko si Sunshine. Gets namin siya.Sana, gets din siya ng iba.

“My body, my choice.” But is it really when your options of what you can do with it is stuck in a country overtaken by religion and politics stuck in the medieval times? Sunshine falls under one of my most favorite genres: social commentary by simply showing girls just trying to live. You can see throughout the film that she’s just a girl. Asking Miggy for money, asking for help when she needs, acts on her impulse, has dreams and goals, using twitter and Reddit for research (#real), etc. She knows she can’t take care of a whole ass child right now, all she can (and she should) do is to chase her dreams and make a career out of it.Though you can also see that Sunshine doesn’t really hate the kid. She takes care of her the way she can– giving her money to get home, looking for her when she’s lost, protects her from adult themes (drinking, abortion, etc). So her decision at the end, it’s not because she hates the kid, it’s because she loves herself. With the limited choices she had, she made the most out of her youth And what’s so wrong with that? With being just a girl?

women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born 'no? a woman that chooses herself has a lot of implications that makes them look selfish.this film is consistently tight, not making moments linger a second longer than it should be. it places urgency to sunshine's situation and i just love how sunshine has full autonomy and gets right to it the moment that she knew. admittedly, a certain plot device employed here might've become a burden in the long run, there's a moment where it felt like the film doesn't know what to do with it, but in the end it still landed pretty well. jadaone throws a lot of anger in this film. an exasperation to the tito bubots of this world, to the judgmental people who's supposed to make you feel safe, to the system that prohibits women to have safer options, but never to sunshine. what might this film's great achievement is that you feel it too, the film carefully takes you on a walk to make you understand and feel its anger, to understand sunshine, just how much important her dreams are and how she doesn't aspire to be a mother in this time of her life. women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born, but people like sunshine makes it feel that choosing themselves is an act to be truly selfless and for once be free
