Para akong naglalakad sa bubog habang pinapanood ‘to, damang-dama ang esensya ng isang sining: nambubulahaw ng mga komportable. Sa madaling salita, sobrang epektibo ng pag-arte, sobrang authentic ng bawat eksena. Lumabas ako ng sinehan nang ikinakahiya ang pagiging lalaki. Hindi ko masisisi ang mga nagsasabing may kulang sa mensahe, pero para sa akin ay isang malaking hakbang na ang paglikha ng ganitong uri ng pelikula para mapag-usapan at maipaglaban pa lalo ang reproduktibong karapatan ng mga kababaihan. Idagdag mo pa ang kahusayan nina Maris Racal at Jennica Garcia, doon pa lámang ay deserve nang maipagmalaki ang pelikulang ito.

Direk Tonet knows exactly when to let silence speak, when to drown out the noise, and when to let emotions simmer. In Sunshine, she invites us into Sunshine’s mental and bodily struggles, but leaves just enough space for the character’s autonomy and our own. While some films impose what should or shouldn’t be, Sunshine deliberately resists the impulse to moralize— and does so with intention. Instead, it evokes. It urges us to feel and think through its subtlety. Jadaone’s placement of Sunshine’s body within the harshness of Manila is a political act. To know Sunshine, then, is to know the spaces that both suffocate and shelter her.The film doesn’t offer easy answers (or any at all), but that’s precisely what makes it resonate and linger.

A damning portrait of a misogynistic society and how the smallest acts of kindness become beacons of hope. Antoinette Jadaone's empathetic direction and writing is precise, harrowing, and sensitive, capturing its protagonist's defiant spirit against all odds.Maris Racal is flawless as the titular character, portraying Sunshine's turmoil - both internal and external - with stirring rawness. Jennica Garcia is likewise deeply moving as Sunshine's ally and compass, a performance rich with history and life. Shout-out to Paolo Orendain's austere cinematography, Eero Yves Francisco's oppressive production design, Benjamin Tolentino's laser-sharp editing, and Vincent Villa's absorbing sound design. This film is fully realized from top to bottom and you feel it in every moment.P.S. This better be the Philippines' official submission for Best International Feature Film at the #Oscars.

GETS KO NA.sunshine is full of light and resilience, stands against the grim, decaying backdrop of manila drowned in chaos and darkness. as her journey unfolds, it becomes clear how personal this film is, especially for filipino women. sunshine set in a country under a deeply patriarchal system, while she embodies the struggle of being a woman. as we all know, abortion remains taboo in the philippines and can be criminalized under the revised penal code of 1930. yup, laws written nearly a century ago still control our bodies as this outdated system should be reformed, as it reflects on deeply rooted cultural norms that often affect the struggles faced by the majority of women. AND THE PERFORMANCE?? BITCH, I’M GOOPED AND GAGGED. maris racal devoured this role (kumbaga kinain at walang itinira na mumo!! GOD ATAKE NIYAH!)

Ang daming bawal, kahit katawan mo, pagmamay-ari ng pamahalaan at nang simbahan.Anyways, Ariana is my bitch too!Salamat Direk Dan and Direk Tonette sa magandang pagpagan! <3

The film confronts the harsh realities of teenage pregnancy, abortion, and even the challenges faced by athletes in the Philippines. With abortion being illegal here in the Philippines, many women resort to dangerous methods that put their lives at risk. The movie also highlights how men often evade accountability for such situations, leaving women to bear the heavy burden alone. It sheds light on the prevalent issue of unwanted pregnancies, a reality that is sadly common here. The film emphasizes the powerful influence of religion in shaping societal norms. Overall, it’s a bold and honest portrayal of women's struggles, particularly in a country deeply shaped by religion and patriarchal values. Kudos to Maris Racal and Antoinette Jadaone! Truly a well-deserved win.

Hindi lamang ito pag-uusapan dahil sa kontrobersyal nitong paksa—humihikayat din siyang mapag-usapan. Nasa isang lipunan tayo na sobrang layo pa sa usaping abortion, at ang isang pelikulang katulad ng Sunshine (2025) ay paniguradong magbibigay liwanag—hindi lang sa usaping abortion—kundi sa usapin din kung paano gamitin ng lipunan ang relihiyon at pulitika para diktahan kung ano ang dapat at hindi dapat gawin ng kababaihan sa sari-sarili nilang mga katawan. Baka maging susunod na presidente ng pilipinas o baka makahanap ng gamot sa aids, oo. Pero paano naman si Sunshine, na isinasang tabi ang karapatan, na para bang pinuputulan niyo ng pakpak makalipad. Paano naman si Sunshine, na mas mataas ang potensyal—National teams, SEA Games, kahit maging sa Olympics pa.Lumabas ako sa sinehan at naririnig ko ang kanya-kanyang diskurso ng mga nanood. Positibo at negatibo. Kesyo gino-glorify ang abortion, kesyo sumusuporta sa mga desisyon ni Sunshine. Ano man ang reaksyon at opinyon nila patungkol sa pelikulang ito, malaking hakbang pa rin yung mailagay siya sa lamesa para mapag-usapan. Hindi na dapat natin ito pinag-uusapan ng patago, na para bang malaking kasalanan. Buhay at kinabukasan ng babae ang nakasalalay.Kaunting spoiler: sobrang halaga sa akin nung eksena na dumaan muna si Sunshine sa simbahan para humingi ng tawad sa mga desisyong gagawin niya pa lamang. Pinapahalagahan ng pelikula ang usaping abortion pero hindi nito binubura ang aspetong moral ng ganoong gawain. Saka, mahalagang detalye rin sa akin yung naroon lamang siya sa labas ng simbahan at hindi siya pumasok—dahil sa tingin niya ay hindi siya karapat-dapat, dahil iba ang catholic guilt ng bagay na gagawin niya.

I was lucky enough to be an extra for this film prior to knowing what it was about, upon seeing the trailer, I knew this was going to be special.Maris Racal truly gives one of the best performances I’ve seen in a long time. She is able to express pain (both physical and internal) in ways that make me writhe with her. I don’t think I’ve wanted to hug a woman through my screen like this in a while.And wow!!! Annika is a star in the making. She impressed me so much in this, especially in the scene where they head to the hospital. It’s definitely a scene that will stick with me for a long time. Jennica’s performance also stuck with me (as a panganay~)Manila is presented so cruel, yet so kind in those moments where Sunshine finds help. I’ve seen a couple of other films talking about abortion in the Philippines (Hinugot sa Langit and 12 Weeks specifically), but I think this one struck me the most. I found this to be extremely nuanced, the presence of the kids and their roles in Sunshine’s life really made me think. I’m still not a hundred percent sure how I feel about their presence, but I appreciate that it made Sunshine’s plight something to really think about.I also appreciated the ending, I think we often see a remorseful side post-abortion for female characters here. But I’m glad we get to see someone who gets to move on and continue to dream, to live.I also thought about the other women I’ve heard about going through similar situations. With how much the world seems to be going backwards, I really hope this piece makes people think about women’s right more here. No one should have to suffer.

Not gonna lie, when I first saw the trailer I wasn't sure how this would tackle the topic of teenage pregnancy and abortion, knowing how hard it is to talk about the latter outside of hushed circles without getting a stern lecturing or some weird looks. For most of the movie I was thinking about how in the world this got past MTRCB, CBCP, and literally every old-headed person out there; I'm so glad it did, btw, because it's an important story to tell, and so bravely told at that. Im not sure of the other devices used in this movie but I'm glad we have media that bravely shows a side society tries to push aside. Ang hirap maging babae!!!! We should have better legislation that supports women and children's health and welfare. Whether you choose to be a mom or not, you should be able to carry that out freely and safely. You should be able to be a girl freely. (Such a sorry state of public health honestly hay!!!!!!) Also reminds me of Happening by Annie Ernaux, one of my first brushes with this topic.

watched this movie at a new cinema. new environment & new everything. no connection to the movie at all but i really felt the need to watch this masterpiece asap! so i got out, alone & motivated to push through everything i had set out for the day.my expectations were not disappointed as the movie delivers such a strong message towards the harsh audience which is the Filipino society. everything about the Philippines' secular practices to its contradictions that are laid by the patriarchal nature of the country—it was cruelly portrayed in the movie transparently. that's what i loved about everything that had transpired in the hour and hour-half time i sat in my seat. everything was in color too—something our country is quite known for; though maris racal had played the role of Sunshine, her character had pretty much went through the storms of what seemed to be an unplanned pregnancy that would become her hindrance in achieving her dreams. dreams. something women would always give up once motherhood would grip them by the toes. sad but true, tragic but a reality. yet this film assures women all around that carrying a child—or not, should not be something that would hinder us from reaching for the stars. every scene reminds us, the audience, how motherhood is a gift (unplanned or not), and its something we should carefully discern of before accepting such a blessing. sunshine knows this, she knows it too well to give her baby the life she does not deserve, if they was born with a mother not mature enough to handle the challenges of maternity. moreover, sunshine knew her dreams. her lifetime dream. God knows how much she desired the big stage. as said by Doc Helena, our God is a forgiving god; the statement echoes towards the ending as sunshine weighed out her choices. it was not a matter of letting something go, it was a matter of reaching for something that was always there. ika nga, talent is equally distributed, but opportunity is not; and for sunshine, she grabbed the chance. gripped it hard. never letting it out of her touch. and ceased it like it was her last chance—it was. i loved this movie too much. social class, reproductive rights, healthcare, religion, mixed with the right amount of comedy all married into one thought-provoking film. mabuhay ang pelikulang pilipino!

fuck the patriarchy fuck the government and (i would) fuck piolo pascualbut jokes aside, the movie really showed the harsh realities women have to face in this god forsaken country,, with our deeply embedded religious roots to how society is geared towards men, leaving women to fend for themselves. naramdaman ko yung lungkot pero mas lalo na ang galit mula sa pelikulang ito. direk tonet and maris completely deserve their flowers.

mamaya ka sakin may gagawin lang ako saglet Most likely born from Carlos Yulo's gold win in the olympics and the emergence of recent abortion films such as Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Jadaone presents how teenage pregnancies ruins lives and dreams and how the lack of freedom for women in a religion oppressed third world country is a problem as alarming as any other. Although clearly being influenced by recent films tackling similar subject matter 'Sunshine' separates itself from the pack simply because it's set in a country where abortion is illegal. With no abortion clinics and only shady abortion pills how is a teenage woman chasing her dreams let alone a 13 yr old girl raped by her own uncle supposed to reclaim the life that was supposed to be ahead of them. Portraying Manila as a neverending,never resting street filled with people desperate to find whatever they are looking for. How it is a city filled with the kindest people stuck in the most cruel of circumstances. Contradictory to its title the film never shows us a sun that is shining but rather a moon desperate to try and shine on its own despite the world telling her she can never do so alone.

SUNSHINE—a film that is made to be felt. This film should have been created ages ago. WHERE DO I START? 1. Antoinette Jadaone is genius. This is her best work so far. Her artistry made me feel uncomfortable—that is how good she is! 2. Maris Racal is the perfect artist for this. More than her physique, she is 100% THE SUNSHINE. She is made to portray this role. 3. PUTANGIN—— mo Bobot, at lahat ng taong nire-represent niya. It's about time we talk about the "FAMILY/FRIEND/ATE/KUYA/TEACHER" rape culture that is happening in the country. 4. This is socially and politically timed. More than the abortion per se, it is about time we talk about women and everything they go through. 5. Ang sarap magkaroon ng Ate, yung mahal ka lang kahit ano pa ang mangyari (i know this for sure )6. Be kind. Not everything should be relevant to you. You do not have to comprehend or understand everything. People go through stuff you do not understand. Just be kind.

likes:- made use of scenes very efficiently which meant i didn’t notice that the movie was pretty short because it was packed with necessary ones - made me think of its relevance towards gymnastics in the middle only to bring me back to it once i did- gave the audience enough time for the characters to grow on them without it feeling forced - stuck to it its message with conviction and without diversion unlike other films trying to include as much social commentary as they could - muntik na ako pumalakpak sa gymnastics ni maris- magaling ramdam na ramdam at amoy na amoy ko yung baho at dugyot ng maynila dislikes:- sobrang dilim medyo masakit sa mataremarks:- it was amusing to see the similarity in cinematography of the quiapo scenes of maris and the ones taken of yas in our film for ethics with the same theme

Expectation ko dito sa film na ‘to is super high because it’s all about abortion— a sensitive topic and an important one that really needs to be addressed with care and it didn’t disappoint.I couldn’t stop clapping when the credits rolled, hands down to Direct Toinette, She is so brave. A few directors can only pull off a film about social justice, names like Lino Brocka and Lav Diaz come to my mindAlso handsdown to Maris Racal and Rhed Bustamante. MVPSunshine doesn’t just focus on Reproductive Justice, it also exposes the hypocrisy of religious people, the poor healthcare system in the philippines, how men can be trash. Sunshine delivers the message so beautifully, carefully and flawlessly. I cried so many times… and laughed too.This film isn’t just important, it’s necessary. If you care about truth, justice, and real stories that hit where it hurts (and heals), Sunshine is essential viewing.

As a man, watching Sunshine felt odd. As much as I wanted to believe that I am a feminist, I cannot fully connect with what Sunshine was going through. My girlfriend on the other hand, had very visceral reactions throughout the movie. Sunshine is a film that fully encapsulates the social subjugation of young women and their rage. Although I might have implied that only women are capable of understanding and appreciating it, there is still much to learn when you watch it.

what makes this film even more bothering is that it happens in real life. bitbit ni sunshine ang kwento ng bawat babaeng pinagkaitan ng pagkakataon para mamili. hindi ideal yung naging sitwasyon niya pero nararanasan to ng mga milyun-milyong babae sa mundo.sobrang tapang ng film to discuss about abortion, catholicism, incest, lack of accessible quality healthcare, lack of sexual education AT IBA PA in a country na deeply rooted ang sense of religion. that scene na dumaan muna si sunshine sa church para humingi ng tawad? SOBRANG TALINO! kitang kita sa mata niya yung guilt of even thinking of doing her plans !!! hirap siya to decide between doing what society thinks is right and doing what she thinks is right for herself. her choosing to do the latter does not mean the guilt felt lighter,,, kaya sobrang importante ng personification ni bata dito. for us to see how she’s conflicted with the decision she’s about to make!!! na kahit alam niya what she wans to do, she’s still hindered by the views and beliefs she grew up with!!!ang ganda ng last few minutes ng film. sobrang makatao. sobrang “ahh gets na gets ko siya.” i love na nalet go niya yung guilt, and she chose herself. gets ko si sunshine kasi hindi ko rin kayang ilet go yung pangarap ko, lalo na if pinanghawakan ko na siya simula nung bata ako. yung smile niya nung nilelet go na niya yung guilt felt so heartwarming! kaya sana we’re not too quick to judge other people who is (or has been) in the same situation!!

It's decent to say the least, it's a Jadaone movie for Jadaone fans. But that's the thing, it's myopic that it themes and logic of the narrative presented is as only limited as the filmmaker's worldview to say the least, or rather it is limited to how Jadaone sees the subject matter in regards to abortion and having an agency which is told in such a simplistic way, lacking that empathy and how objective it is. However, I commend the script to call out against the prejudiced perception but that's how it is, it did not hold accountable to it, and while Sunshine had conviction to make her decision in the end, and matters in her own hands, it didn't feel unearned to be honest. Like who is Sunshine to the audience, as a main character? Why do the audience should root for her, I think the screenplay failed to make its audience care and thank god Maris Racal made it somehow work because she did put effort to act in those dramatic scenes and it shows she's into that role, kudos for putting an extra work on gymnastic scenes.But in some light hearted scenes, it felt like she didn't convey those emotions that at times it felt monotone. She could've shown a more human and relatable side of Sunshine.It didn't helped that the runtime could've expanded or improve some things that were lacking, but overall the film did ok. Lastly, I have a message to those who are invoking Brocka's name or likening it to the film or the filmmaker: "keep his name out of your mouth."

“pasalamat ka kay Papa God.” pasalamat ka para sa sining ng pagpepelikula.madali lang naman mahalin ang pelikulang ito. tulad ng pagmamahal sa mga bagay na pinaniniwalaan at pinaninindigan mo: madali, simple, at walang pag-aalinlangan.there is no doubt that i would love this film effortlessly because the direk tonet jadaone formula never fails in empowering women in their strongest moments; and even more so in their struggles in the fucked up reality of living in a third world country where they are robbed of their freedom to choose.i loved all the little details in sunshine’s home; the subtle reference to problematic people supporting fascists and corrupt politicians; and the way the city of manila is captured in all of its colors, filth, and beauty—showing us familiar roads and alleyways, reminding us of the vibrancy and dullness of the thousands of lives that passed us by.but what struck me the most is the irony of abortion pills being illegally sold where you can buy a statue of Sto. Niño, an image of the Child Jesus who was born from an unplanned pregnancy (albeit God-willed and wholeheartedly accepted by Mary if you’re Catholic). because much like this visual, i do believe that devotion to God and the right to choose for yourself are not mutually exclusive. if you’re using your belief to shun others instead of understanding them, then you’re not living up to your faith.i’ve said it before in past movie reviews—to me, unsafe abortions are the most horrific thing you can show your audience and i’ve seen two other films before, one more vivid than the other. but this one in sunshine is the most painful and depressing. hihilingin mo talaga na sana walang babae sa mundo ang makaranas nito. how can something regarded as the source of life drain the life out of a woman? ang pinakamahirap lunukin na katotohanan ay mayroon at mayroong mga babaeng makakaranas nito kung hindi magkakaroon ng maayos na sex education sa ating mga paaralan at hanggat walang access ang lahat sa reproductive health at safe abortions sa bansa. saludo ako sa tapang mo, direk tonet, to show something no other director of today is not afraid to do so.naniniwala akong ang kababaihan ang pinagmulan ng mundo. quite literally, babae ang nagdala at nagluwal sa ating lahat. kaya maraming salamat sa pelikulang ito dahil nabigyan ng spotlight hindi lang ang mga babaeng tulad ni sunshine at ni mary grace, pero pati na rin ang mga babaeng tulad ng ate ni sunshine, kaibigan niyang si thea, ang kanyang coach eden, si doctor helena, at pati na rin ang babaeng bantay sa avenida inn na walang pag-aatubiling tumulong sa kanya. this is womanhood, ika nga. marahil para sa’yo, ang mga babaeng ito ay iyong ina, ate, kapatid, pinsan, kaibigan o kasintahan. pero isa lang ang sigurado, may mga babae sa buhay nating nagsisilbing kakampi natin sa araw-araw at dapat lang silang bigyang-pugay at pasalamatan.(please stop reading at this point if you don’t want spoilers for the ending!)at first, i thought annika’s character is sunshine’s manifestation of her younger self or her inner child that serves as her conscience in every decision she makes. but when we’re introduced to ariana, it’s finally clear to me that they were sunshine’s manifestation of the unborn babies from her and mary grace’s unwanted pregnancies. this is why that “gets ko na” scene is so powerful! because after relentlessly asking for forgiveness from God for reasons she couldn’t fully understand, she finally forgives herself for choosing herself and her dreams. minsan ay may ni-repost si direk sa twitter and it is all about the paths our mothers did not take when they chose to love us instead. when i read that, i just cried. obviously, i am thankful my mama chose me but honestly, i would’ve understood if she didn’t.i am glad i chose to watch this spontaneously on a work night (thank you, biancake, sa biglaang aya!) kahit nakipagsapalaran ako mula makati hanggang sta. mesa, tumakbo sa extension sa pagitan ng estasyon ng doroteo jose at recto para mahabol ang simula, at naglakad sa madilim at mataong lugar sa harap ng isetann para sumakay sa jeep pa-españa. dama ko ang maynila sa hangin sa daan at nasisilayan ko ang buhay nito sa mga taong nagsisiuwian. hiling ko lang na sa bawat tahanang nalalagpasan ng aking sinasakyan, may mga babaeng naaabot ang pangarap nang hindi nahihirapan.thank you, Papa God. thank you, para sa Sunshine.
what the fuck.

unsa sa lahat, putang*na ng mga lalaki talaga! kung ayaw niyo naman palang panagutan yung babae, mag condom kayo o di kaya putulin niyo na lang itet niyo. pero on a serious note, this film is truly a masterpiece, capturing the horrors of unsafe abortion in the philippines. maris’ role reflects the struggles of women’s access to genuine healthcare! kaya sana ipasa na ang abortion bill! it’s a woman’s body and all the things they do about it, abay labas na tayo don (lalo na kapag lalaki ka). finally, ang pogi ni papa p ha. thanks sa special appearance or something blabla!

gets ko na.tangina napakaganda, napakahusay, nakakaiyak, nakakagigil, nakakainis kasi sobrang totoo ng lahat ng nangyayari. thank you so much direk tonet and team for this film, holy fuck, easily the best filipino film of the year! please, panoorin sana ng lahat sa sinehan hanggat may chance pa, it's such a wonderful experience. all aspects of this film are soooo good!! what a film. i don't have enough words to properly review this because it did left me speechless. this is so painfully real to many women—young and not. i got out of that cinema still in dazed because it's that beautifully raw and brave. i can't help but to think of my mom and her internal struggle with herself getting pregnant as a young woman when at that time, she was also dreaming the life she wanted just as much Sunshine did in this film. we all dreamed and are still dreaming. this film gives me so much hope in everything good, despite the unfortunate events. what a film indeed.

I can already imagine the discourse once marelease to sa VOD. First of all, I think it is so bold of Jadaone to come up with a concept that is so simplistic yet so real and full of grit despite the subject’s thematic weight. Abortion remains to be a debatable matter in the Philippines and opinions are always highly polarized among liberals and conservatives. Despite the country’s right-wing political ideologies, there are still calls from progressive groups urging the government to legislate better constitutions on health and reproductive rights for the benefit of those who need it most. Sunshine happens to be one of these people.Sunshine is a dedicated gymnast and an aspiring Olympian. With only a few weeks left to polish and brush up on her routine, she suddenly found herself in a bind that put her faith, morals, and self-worth to the test. The film doesn’t let us stay in a hopeful frame of mind; rather, it propels us to empathize with the character and question whatever is wrong and fucked up with the system. When Sunshine found out she was pregnant, her first instinct was to get rid of it. Pray it away. End it even if it means drowning in a cycle of self-destructive behaviors. It was clear from the very start she didn’t want to push through and she held onto that. I guess that’s as far as I can go for now so as to not give away too much of the plot.I watched this alone sa sinehan kanina and as soon as the credits rolled, i overheard someone sa likod ko saying na ‘bitin’ daw, and i totally get the sentiment that maybe for some people medyo half-baked or kulang ang storya. But sometimes, films don’t have to be loud in order to hit the right spots. With its very straightforward premise and message, I think Sunshine deserves the amount of hype it’s getting.The sports industry is already overwhelmingly taxing and having to face added burdens brought about by unwanted pregnancy can be way more damaging than one can fathom. Sunshine is not a film that will convince you to change your moral and political convictions; rather, it clings to the little hope of making the audience understand that the dilemma Sunshine had to face isn’t something that exists only in the reel world, but something that is very much present in the real world—in a society where bodily autonomy often comes at a social cost.Above all else, one thing’s clear is we really need better and safer reproductive laws in the Philippines so women wouldn’t have to go through under-the-table practices that put their lives on the brink of death. However, with the current political climate, i guess it’s realistic to assume we’re still a little far off. But with films like Sunshine, I’d like to think there’s still an ounce of hope for our country to perhaps embrace ideals that give primacy to women’s autonomy and rights, at the very least.

“Gets ko na.”I think Sunshine is Direk Tonet’s best work yet. It is simplistic, raw, and bothering but it is wrapped in a cute pink ribbons that seeks to hide the harsh truths women in our society face. The bits of humor at times give audiences a space to laugh and forget how heavy the message of the film is and then it just hits you with its narrative and the core message behind it. My favorite scene was the conversation between Ariana and Bata, it was both pro life and pro choice which may be a hard thing to pull off but the team did it effortlessly. I loved how raw and unfiltered it is and how it became a eureka moment for the other audiences. I am in no way fit to write a long ass review about the them of the film because stories like these are rooted in everyday struggles of women in such violent and patriarchal society. I loved the film but I would love more hearing how women react and talk about this film, sila ang tanging nararapat na magexpound lalo nito at naka supporta lang ako.

Habang nasa kalagitnaan ng pelikula, nasabi ko na lamang sa sarili ko, “Para saan ba talaga ‘tong pelikula na ‘to? Ano bang point nito?” Yun pala, ako lang ang hindi agad naka-gets.Ang fucked up lang kasi isipin kung yung bata ay literal na physical manifestation ng nasa tiyan ni Sunshine, parang anim na taong gulang na anyo ng dapat sana’y magiging anak. Mas fucked up pa kasi kinokonsensya niya si Sunshine (tinawag siyang murderer). Pero later on na-realize ko: hindi siya totoong bata, kundi visual representation lang ng internal conflict ni Sunshine. Siya yung konsensya. Siya yung maliit na boses sa loob. Siya rin si Sunshine.Kaya hindi talaga tungkol sa journey ni Sunshine sa pag-abot ng mga pangarap niya ang pelikula. Mas tungkol ito sa batang karakter—na hindi rin pala talaga bata—at sa mas malawak na karanasang pangkababaihan. Kasi sa totoo lang, ang kwento ng abortion ay hindi tungkol sa bata. Ito ay tungkol kay Sunshine. Sa mga babae. Sa mga may katawan. Sa mga may kakayahang magdesisyon para sa sarili nila.Maganda naman ang ending. Medyo parang Modess commercial nga lang (charot). Pero kung tatanungin ako, feeling ko may kulang. Bilang manonood, hindi ko gaanong naramdaman ang bigat ng emosyon. Kulang sa lalim. Kulang sa hugot. Pero nabawi naman sa pagganap ng mga aktor—walang tapon, mahusay ang lahat.Isang halimbawa ng kakulangan sa emotional connection para sa akin ay yung eksenang umiiyak si Sunshine sa loob ng inn habang isinasagawa ang abortion. Malapit na akong bumigay nun, ramdam na ramdam ko na, pero biglang nag-cut to a shot from outside the window of her emoting and yung maingay na traffic. Aesthetic, oo. Maganda, pero di ko gusto. Parang sinampal ako pabalik sa reyalidad na, “Hoy, hindi ka kasama sa kwento.” Saksi ka lang. I don’t know about you guys, but I don’t like that.Favorite scene ko siguro ay yung early scene sa pelikula, yung umiiyak si Sunshine sa jeep. Maingay sa simula, tapos unti-unting tumahimik habang nakatutok lang ang lente sa kanya. Ang galing nun. Ang ganda. In addition, siksik sa intensyon ang mga detalye—katulad ng painting sa unahan ng jeep na may nakasulat na “Gift from God.” Hala siya, eh di ikaw na ang tumanggap. (charot)Anyways, ang dami kong nasabi. Pero ngayon na lang naman ‘to. Ang galing ni Maris. At isang malaking middle finger sa mga mahilig makialam sa buhay ng iba—lalo na’t hindi naman hinihingi ang opinyon nila. Wala rin namang ambag. Oo, may ambagan!+0.5 star kasi super ganda ng official poster!!
hindi enough yung tagal ng credits para i-digest yung pelikula, ang ganda !!

Beyond how brilliant Sunshine is, this film reminded me once again why cinema matters in shaping and inspiring a better society. It has the power to connect, to spark meaningful conversations, and to heal.The film doesn't ask you to take a side or change your stance, instead it offers perspective. It doesn't scream any agenda on you, instead it quietly holds your hand and asks you to listen. This film made me realize just how unfair this world can be to women. It is hard enough to be a woman, even more so to be a woman in the Philippines. As a man, it opened my eyes around struggles I'm privileged not to face, but must learn to understand.Sunshine champions women with deep care and honesty, and Tonet Jadaone continues to be one of the most important voices in Philippine cinema today. I can't wait to see what she creates next.Maris Racal portrayed Sunshine with such precision and depth. Her fears and pain simmer just beneath the surface, yet she keeps moving-focused, trying to hold herself together-trying to drown out the noise as she fights to choose what's best for her.Top 3 scenes that stirred the audience at our local theater:1. The preachy doctor scene 2. Rhed Bustamante’s pregnancy reveal 3. The “Ate” scene between Jennica and Maris
I love it when directors and writers put certain meanings into their works!!!

gets ko na.isang mahigpit na yakap sa lahat ng sunshine! hindi lang ito basta pelikula—ito'y pag-amin na ang sistema ay hindi para sa mga kababaihan. matapang pero may puso. sensitibo ngunit madaling unawain. at sana, mapanood pa ito nang mas nakararami.we need more films like this! mabuhay ang pelikulang pilipino!

A perspective from a young woman's struggle towards her dreams in Urban Manila. Handle delicate and sensitive timely issues-abortion and #ProChoice. The juxtaposition of society and women's struggle. How each scenes will straight out of reality. Your social support will vary and how public space are intermingle of ideas. Each realities matter yet beliefs they hurt-from a Conservative Christian Obgyne female doctor who cannot fathom how a young woman would not want to give birth, to a female Quiapo vendor selling abortifacients in front of a Church, to a dear sister who raised her both siblings who will love her no matter what (Jennica's performance here is so superb, I almost cry), to a 13 year old girl who been raped because by a family member, and finally Maris Racal's Sunshine who undergo making a decision, a choice--that is so hard and required ethics, but understandably absorbed into her role, how every woman in the Philippines simply existing is so exhausting. But also how the patriarchy compels women as their biggest supporter draping the country's public health that hurt and judge women for their choice, to the point of penalizing them as criminals.Sunshine is realism, carefully managed and lay out how women needs always to advocate for their own choice and bodily autonomy.
Maris Racal I never doubted you my cancelled sister! YOU ATE THIS AWP!

after months of waiting, i was finally able to watch sunshine! and the waiting game was worth it :)sunshine delivers a strong message while keeping things concise. with its 92-minute runtime, the film strongly conveyed a clangorous noise which could spark discussions regarding women's reproductive health as well as the overall state of healthcare in the country. the jokes are so subtle it made the whole cinema burst out laughing except the two boomers in our row. sobrang nabadtrip sila dun sa joke ni jennica garcia sa ospital hahahaha. the film connected so well with its audience, and with this i meant CONNECT! ramdam na ramdam ko yung pain ni sunshine sa isang eksena na 'yon, grabe. at bawat eksena ay tear-inducing dahil grabe 'yung pamumuo ng luha sa mata ko sa halos kalahati ng dulong part ng film. the hospital scenes were so painful to watch in a way that it reflects reality so much. nakalulungkot isipin na ganito ang estado ng public hospitals sa bansa, hindi matamasa kung ano ba ang dapat mayroon tayo. more than that, this film also shows how women do not have a safer option to terminate pregnancy when they choose to do so. kailangan bang mag agaw-buhay ang isang babae para lang maalis sa kanya ang 'buhay' na hindi naman niya hiniling?sobrang kirot sa puso panoorin tangina. pero napakaganda rin talaga jusko. but yeahhh! beautiful shots by pau orendain andddd jadaone has outdone herself here after fan girl (2020)! halimaw! gusto ko magtrabaho sa project8 projects pagka-graduate ko. This kind of film is what the whole Philippines has to watch. It is an eye-opener that sparks significant discussion in terms of how Filipinos perceive situations in a traditional and conservative way.I definitely loved how it tackled this controversy while focusing on Sunshine’s dream, which represents many teenage girls that suffered from unwanted pregnancies. In this hour-and-a-half film, it did highlight the majority belief yet also countered it in different narratives. Despite being so interested in pre-watching the film, I still didn’t expect how the film has featured many symbols and situations that Filipinos have to realize. I get so emotional about how the storyline has approached this issue, and I hope to see more of this in our country.Maris Racal is the right actress for the role. The way she played Sunshine was so natural and raw. Her delivery of lines, the body language, the expressions—everything was on point. She made Sunshine as the character that many can easily relate to. The casting was amazing, as were the cinematography, color grading, music scoring, and the flow.Definitely Direk Antoinette Jadaone’s best.
when imagining her unborn daughter wasn't enough, sunshine began to imagine another teenager's unborn child. justice for mary grace... she didn't get any...

sobrang aktres mo, Maris, at napakahusay mo, direkTonet!hindi lang basta pelikulang pinangunahan ng mga babae ito; ang tapang. ang tapang ng pelikulang humugot sa mga paksa na matagal nang itinuturing na bawal pag-usapan. lahat ng matagal nang tinitiis at pinapasan ng kababaihan, inilatag sa liwanag para mapag-usapan, maintindihan, at matanggap.grabe.mula sa pagtutok ng lente sa malayo, hanggang sa marahang paglapit ng kamera sa mga mata ni Maris Racal— ramdam mo lahat. hindi pilit, hindi sobra pero tama. parang gusto mo siyang yakapin, buhatin ang bigat nya sabihing hindi siya nag-iisa.lahat ng karakter may kinakatawan. may girls' girl, may tradisyonal, lalong mas may hipokrito. lahat sila, totoo. kilala natin sila sa totoong buhay, pero minsan ay (baka) tayo sila.pinakapaborito kong eksena siguro yong parte na nalaman na ng ate ni Sunshine ang kalagayan niya. walang sigawan, walang sumbat, kundi yakap, pag-unawa, at respeto sa desisyong mahirap man ay personal dahil galing na rin siya mismo doon. proof ito na hindi nagkulang si Jennica Garcia sa pagbibigay-lalim sa karakter niya— tahimik man ang portrayal, pero talagang mabigat ang tama.gets na gets kita, Sunshine :)

Antoinette Jadaone unleashes a kind of ferocity in this film that's very much needed from a mainstream voice in our sociopolitical age. The choices made throughout the narrative leave a powerful message that stay with you long after you walk out of the theater. It demands your attention, and it demands that you listen. Sunshine feels like a film that will define a new age in Philippine cinema, not for its technical marvel, but for ushering in a bravery in writing that may just be what's missing from our industry's identity. I might even reckon it to the likes of the Brockas, Bernals, de Leons, or the Diaz-Abayas of the world.Please, catch it in cinemas if you can.

i am angry at the church for instilling deep-seated catholic guilt that permeates thru all levels of our society, at the government for blatantly anti-women policies that lead to unsafe abortions, at medical professionals that push shame on patients, and unfortunately at my parents for not teaching me about contraceptives when i was younger. the film rly captures the loneliness and desperation of googling options for sexual health, not knowing who to turn to, calculating probabilities for pregnancy, mitigating risk of judgment and humiliation. hay naq even the experience of getting an iud made me feel some type of way about my womb. when will women be able to feel like their bodies belong to them w/o guilt or shame???

Naiintindihan mo ba ‘ko?raw. simple. true.hindi na kailangan pa ng mas maraming diyalogo para iparating sa mga tao ang mensahe nito: malinaw, maingay, malakas. tama sila, tao ang nasa pelikulang ito. hindi ito basta-bastang pelikula, ito ang reyalidad na dapat hamunin. napakahusay. napakatapang. ang ganda ng cinematography, kuhang-kuha yung dumi, sulasok, at pakiramdam ng manirahan sa maynila, lalong-lalo na para sa isang babaeng puno ng pangarap. pagdating sa characters, napakagaling. mahusay ang pagkakagawa ng bawat isa. napaluha ako sa karakter ni Mary Grace at ng ate ni Sunshine.sa pagpili nating mamulat at makinig, paglabas natin sa sinehan, alalahanin natin ang tanong ni Sunshine: “Naiintindihan mo ba ‘ko?” PS. Thank you Papa God for Sunshine!!!!! Mag-thank you kayo kay Papa God.

I have faith in this film's capacity for becoming a beloved classic in Filipino cinema given enough time. An unmelodramatic (if you found it melodramatic, I personally feel that may say more about you than the film!) and unflinching portrayal of the Hell that the Philippines is for girls and women. Somehow, even in all its white-hot rage, Sunshine approaches its controversial topic most of all with kindness, empathy, and understanding. I am overcome by an urge to watch every other previous Antoinette Jadaone film ASAP.Maris Racal, with this single performance, cements herself as our most talented actor from her generation. She's seriously in her FAMAS, Cannes Best Actress, Volpi Cup bag here!

“gets ko na.”sobrang powerful ng last 10 minutes na hanggang ngayon iniiyakan ko pa rin. halo-halong emosyon. ‘di ko alam kung nakailang type then delete ako rito kasi sa tuwing mabubuo ko na ‘yung mga salitang gustong sabihin, biglang mapapalitan ng “grabe”, “wtf”, at iyak yung nasa utak ko. andami kong gustong sabihin pero nai-speechless ako.sana marami pang maka-gets.

i don’t know if i could properly translate into words what this made me feel cause i was literally speechless after pero ito susubukan ko. sabi nila, hindi mo pwede husgahan ang isang tao hangga’t hindi mo nararanasan maglakad ng milya sa sapatos niya, at naniniwala ako do’n kasi habang sinasamahan ko si sunshine sa paglalakbay niya, nakita ko ang masalimuot na reyalidad ng maraming kababaihan na walang karapatan pumili. bawat isa, iba’t iba ang pinapasan, magkakaiba ang pinanggalingan, pare-parehas nakataya ang buhay. kaya sino tayo para manghusga?grabe ang husay ni maris at annika!! pati supporting, wala akong masabi. ang ganda ng temang pinili ni direk tonet, nagustuhan ko na hindi siya nagpokus kung pro-abortion ka ba o pro-life. instead, tumambay siya sa karanasan para manuot sayo yung hinaharap ng mga katulad ni sunshine.pag pangarap ang nakasalalay, titibayan mo talaga loob mo.gets kita sunshine, kakampi mo ‘ko.
i love you sunshine gets na gets kita!!!!
welcome back maris racal
HANDS DOWN TALAGA MARIS RACAL

if only i was able to document how i looked when i realized what kind of roles annika and ariyuhna were trying to portray. i was.. blown away. conflicted. i felt sorry, but i genuinely understand. i also just want to commend ms jennica garcia’s performance!!!!!!! as an Ate myself, i feel like despite the <intense> reactions that people around me think i’ll be like if in any case i end up being in that same position, i think i would react like sunshine’s Ate. it’s already a cruel reality, people like sunshine just needs a pair of understanding ears, a heart, and a warm embrace. i feel like i really broke down when jennica repeatedly said ‘i love you.’ with the most sincere and most genuine tone. i really really loved how sunshine’s performance for the competition ended with a face shot or whatever you call it. i like how it ended without seeing how the competition she worked and sacrificed so much went. for me, her actual performance was the one with annika watching it. that “gets ko na” carried so much SO MUCH emotions in it that you really just have to agree na oo, gets mo rin.it has been a magical experience to be able to watch this film on the big screen. i can’t believe i only paid 230 pesos to feel THAT much. thank you, sunshine. i offer you so much love and respect.

so much has been said about the bravery to tackle an important but still quite taboo issue in the country but it just cannot be overstated!!! i left the cinema today with a lot of heavy thoughts and feelings that i cant perfectly explain but i think a lot of that is rooted in sadness and anger.sadness over the realization that as a woman i see myself in more ways than one in sunshine. i may not have gone through a similarly tumultuous experience but there are bits and pieces of her character that i see myself in. at times it felt jarring to recognize those. as a healthcare worker myself, i can say that a lot of the scenes in this movie arent far from reality. they’re sometimes even worse. and it’s just. idk. this film heightened the anger i have… directed at.. i dont know. the society? the government? myself?my emotions about this are still all over the place really.what i do know is that this film will stick with me for years.

i love how this film showed na nasa babae lagi ang bigat when it comes to unplanned pregnancies—walang proper support; lahat ay tutol sa desisyon na gustuhin magka abortion ang babae, walang proper sex education para maiwasan ito at higit sa lahat, walang proper healthcare for it

This movie is brave in tackling a very delicate issue, but at times, it tries too hard to deliver its message. It needed more grit and heart, and less aesthetics and preachiness. The bit with the pregnant teenage girl felt like a random device, which is unfortunate given the weight it carried on the film's plot.Still, I like how it tried to take on subjects like incest, poor maternal health, Catholic guilt. It works well when it shows its heart -- the tender moments between sisters, the heartbreaking text message to a friend before a risky decision. Maris Racal is good, and the supporting cast also deserves a lot of praise (the Quiapo vendor was great).

Ang bigat wow.Paborito kong parte dito si annika. Sabi ng iba konsensya nya si annika, o way to cope, o di kaya ung unborn child nya.Buong buo ung loob ni sunshine na ayaw nya pa maging nanay, hindi nya pa kaya, tuwing hihingi ng pera sakanya si annika, “Umalis ka nga wala akong pera”. Pero nagaalala pa rin sya, pero binigyan nya ng pang tricyle, 100 para special, para ligtas si annika. Pero hindi sumagi sa isip nya buhayin nalang ung bata. ayaw pa ni sunshine, buhay nya yung gymnastics. Ang gandang representation nito sa bawat babaeng pinili ang abortion. Kahit gaano ka-desidido, kahit piliin mo yung sarili mo, hindj mawawala ung guilt, ung takot, ung sakit. Kasi tao lang si sunshine, napapaligiran ng mapanghusga, ng mga taong tinuturing na krimen ang abortion. Ang gandang representation na bukod sa physical pain na pagdadaanan ng babae sakin unsafe abortion choices, meron pa syang internal battle sa guilt at konsensya nya.. Nung nawala si Annika, takot na takot si sunshine, nakakapagtaka kasi e ayaw nya naman talaga si Annika in the first place. Pero parte parin sya ni annika. Something in me healed sa last part nung sinabi nya na “Gets ko na”. Ang perfect ng scene na to. I interpret is as making peace, and forgiving herself, na she chooses this and this is what she knows is best.
The silence in Sunshine is so loud. Deafening even. A masterful play on choices.

i have so many thoughts and feelings for this film. but it’s just a great film, hands down. throughout, we see sunshine behind and through bars and whenever we see her beyond it, her choices feel cathartic (like dasurv masiraan ng kotse! dasurv mabasagan ng beer sa ulo!) i found the hospital scenes to be the hard-hitting ones since there are so much to unpack. like either way, you’re trapped—trapped alongside the many other women who are forced to share hospital beds in public health centers/clinics/hospitals or either, you end up fighting for your life when the abortifacients don’t work. given the structures around us, the choices we are given do not serve us nor empower us, which then make these other options more enticing. despite this dreary reality, i found myself being emotional during the final sequence. sunshine finds herself free in gymnastics and that’s what she gets to do and she gets to drown out the noise. and that’s all what we’re advocating for, for women to have the choice. GOD i love this film sm. i do think it’s a good first step in addressing abortion in contemporary PH cinema. we are doing this film a disservice if we expect it to fully encompass the extent of nuances of this experience. what we can hope for, perhaps, is the exploration of more nuanced stories like sunshine’s to be seen and heard.

the movie was very raw and what saddens me the most is this is someone’s experience and it’s not impossible because in society lalo na sa ph na very religious centered instilled w/ such shame and discrimination among other ppl — women & abortion should not sit on the same table that’s why it’s very stigmatized kaya ive always been a pro-choice and never did and never will shame women who went through that — i embrace them with so compassion and empathy

The movie that will haunt you after watching. Sunshine isn’t loud, but it leaves a lasting echo. Her silence feel heavier than words. As she searches the streets of Manila for a way out, we feel every step, the desperation, the shame, the unbearable weight of decisions no one should face alone.What haunts you isn’t what’s said, but what isn’t. The film never preaches, but it unsettles. You don’t just watch it, you carry it with you. Sunshine doesn’t end with answers. It ends with a breath held in your chest.

gets ko na. sunshine sheds light on the complexities yet unity within the different relationships that girls have with other women. sobrang daming expectations na hinihingi sa atin at iba rin ang pagod dahil dito. maris perfectly embodies the character of sunshine, who stayed true to her dreams until the end, despite the multiple challenges she faced to get there. this film was very, very raw and the execution perfectly delivered the message it wanted to reach the audience. it will forever be in my heart!!! i love you sunshine <3

the irony of the super christian ob-gyne treating sunshine like a child (say thank you papa jesus) while also expecting her to carry a child full term.there are lots of ironies in this movie, especially in how sunshine—a girl, barely a woman herself—is treated. “what if the child you’re carrying is the next president of the philippines?” but what about sunshine’s dreams? must those dreams end when motherhood begins? whose dreams and potential are more important? sunshine the movie doesn’t answer these questions outright, leaving you to chew on them instead and come to your own conclusions. at the start, i found the narrative device of the child as a manifestation of sunshine’s guilt a little too on-the-nose, but the pay-off in the ending made it worth it. as the ending says: gets ko nabut the best parts of sunshine are when it dwells on the almost fantastical ridiculousness of manila—not just the place, but also the people. details like the abortifacient vendor using the money sunshine gave her to “bless” her holy figurines or the santo niños looming over their whole transaction or dangerous illegal abortions followed by scenes of overflowing maternity wards. the movie passes no judgement on these scenes but merely offers them up for observation: here is manila in all it’s messy glory. it’s the perfect backdrop for sunshine’s series of bad choices. (and also reminiscent of lino brocka’s film style which i absolutely ate up)

ABSOLUTE CINEMAwhat i love abt this movie is its soooo honest. it tackles abortion, a topic thats still seen as taboo in a conservative country. this movie DOESNT glorify abortion. what it does is offer a different perspective into the lives of women who go through this experience.i love how determined and full sunshine is. full of dreams, full of courage. she is the kind of woman who chooses her own path and fights for it, kahit gaano kahirap. her story is not just about abortion, its about freedom, choice, and dignity.women should have the right to decide for their own bodies. after all, kami ang makakaranas ng lahat, physically, emotionally, mentally. mo one else should dictate what we can or cannot do with our own life.i love how the film doesnt try to force an opinion on the viewers. instead, it invites you to listen and understand. it shows us why some women make this choice, not because they want to, but because sometimes, they have to. kudos!!!! sobrang ganda

10/10 tangina napakaganda! napakahusay mo maris racal! as usual, direk tonet did not disappoint! putangina nyong mga sexual abusers at anti abortion! let women decide on their own bodies. no vagina, no comment!!!

Siguro nasabi na ang halos lahat ng magagandang aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine, pero may isang bagay talaga ang tumatak sa akin: ang ilaw.Hindi ko alam kung sinadya man ito, pero napansin ko kung paanong ginagamit ang ilaw upang i-spot si Sunshine. Sa bawat eksenang naggi-gymnastics siya, ramdam mo ang goals at motivation ng karakter niya. Tunay nga na siya si Sunshine, siya ang liwanag. Ang bawat eksena sa loob ng training court ay nagmistulang higaan ng dilaw na liwanag, puno ng pangarap, dedikasyon, at pag-asa.Pero sa tuwing lalabas siya ng gym, sa tuwing aalis siya sa mundo ng gymnastics, unti-unting dumidilim ang paligid. Ang bahay nila, na nasa gitna ng nakakasulasok na usok ng Maynila. Ang pampublikong ospital na kalunos-lunos ang itsura. Ang mga kalsada ay madilim, makulimlim, nakakalunod ang ilaw. Habang bumabalot ang dilim, makikita sa mukha ni Sunshine, lalo na sa kanyang mga mata, ang pagnanais niyang kumawala. Parang sinasabi ng mga mata niya, ayaw ko ng ganito. Ayaw niya ng dilim. Ayaw niyang masakal ng mundong nasa labas ng kanyang pangarap.Siguro ang pelikulang ito ay hindi lang tungkol sa abortion. Isa rin itong kwento ng mga batang babaeng may pangarap. Kung paanong nililimitahan ng lipunan ang kakayahan nilang abutin ang mga pangarap nila. Kung paanong pinangungunahan at dinidiktahan ang mga desisyon nila kung ano ang “tama” o “mali” habang sabay na pinipigilan silang lumipad nang malaya.Ang dami ko nang nasabi, pero grabe, wala talaga akong masabi sa galing mo, Maris. Ang husay mo, sobra. At ikaw naman, Direk Tonet, ang tindi mo. Dati, pinapakinggan ko lang yung opinyion mo tungkol sa abortion sa AWKP, tapos ngayon, pelikula na siya. Kwento na siya. At hindi lang basta kwento, kwentong siguradong magpapasimula ng usapan, diskurso, at ingay.

Sa dami ng opinyon ng mga tao lalo na kapag tungkol sa katawan ng babae, iba ang ginawa ng Sunshine. Hindi ito dumaan sa maingay na diskusyon o pakikipagtalo. Tahimik lang siya, dala dala ang katotohanang hindi kayang ipaliwanag ng statistics, relihiyon o moralidad. Hindi siya ginawa para kumbinsihin ka o pasayahin ka. Ginawa siya para ipakita kung ano talaga ang nangyayari, at maramdaman mo kung gaano ito kabigat.Kwento sya ng libo-libong babae na tahimik lang, pero araw-araw may dalang mabigat na desisyon. Yung tipong kahit gusto mong may makausap, mas nauuna pa rin yung kaba kasi madalas, ang sumasalubong hindi pag-unawa kundi panghuhusga.Ang Sunshine ay paalala na hindi lahat ng sakit ay may eksenang iyakan.. minsan, nasa katahimikan ng paglalakad pauwi, sa paghawak sa tiyan, sa pag-iwas ng tingin, sa pagbitbit ng bigat na hindi mo pwedeng ibahagi kahit kanino.Hindi ito pelikulang dapat lang mapanood, pelikula ito na dapat pakinggan. Dahil sa mundo kung saan ang babae’y madalas pinagdidiskitahan, ang Sunshine ay isang matapang na bulong: ‘Pakinggan mo naman kami.'

I LOVE THIS SO MUCH  two things: (1) you already know my gripe with movies nowadays being too self-aware, esp when making commentary on social issues (e.g. through infodump dialogues and/or in-your-face monologues). given the themes of this movie, i was initially scared that this'll end up having the same issue— but THANK GOD that wasn't the case here. this one actually took the effort to situate us in Sunshine's shoes. it knew how to convey Sunshine's story by fleshing out the world that she lives in, by showing how she relates to others, by showing us the things she does not do and does not say. this movie knows how to practice restraint! that's how it managed to really make Sunshine shine :D(2) i love that this movie makes a very decisive stance on abortion, without having uhhhh such a cold attitude towards children. like, never once did Sunshine change her mind about having an abortion, and this movie also made several strong cases about how motherhood disadvantages/endangers women— but it also makes it clear that the problem is not... the babies/children? in fact the children are also victims here, as shown in Ariana's case. instead of being shown as ~the problem~ pa nga, this movie instead shows us that children may symbolize hope and companionship and possibilities. the unwanted pregnancy made life difficult for both Menggay and Ariana— but wasn't it Ariana, still, who stood up for Menggay? what Sunshine went through throughout the entire film was difficult and isolating— but she wasn't exactly alone, was she? hindi man niya gusto 'yung bata, there was a part of her that sought comfort from the possibility of the child's companionship. i think it's just human nature, yenno, to seek connections from others when going through a difficult time. and when you live in a society where you can't disclose all these troubles to anyone, not even to those closest to you— whose companionship can you seek, if not your own flesh that's taking shape into another life? sino pa ba ang mas makakaintindi sa 'yo kundi ang sarili mong laman at dugo? yeah in practice that may not be true LOL kaya nga ipinaabort pa rin ni Sunshine eh xD kahit anong "romantic" ng notion na susuportahan ka ng anak mo anuman ang pangarap mo, that's practically impossible when its very existence is what could hinder you from reaching them lol. pero ayun nga, it's the difficulty of the situation and our human vulnerabilities that add nuance to these discussions.—some pro-choice people (and i know they mean well naman) like to claim that abortion is ok because it's just getting rid of some soulless clumps of tissue anyway. and i guess that's scientifically true... but if fetuses are rly just soulless clumps of tissue then why are we so afraid of pregnancy at all...? why do we want to do abortions as early as possible...? I MEAN LIKE, it's silly to keep dismissing the possibility of actual growing life when discussing these things. and the fact that Sunshine Did Not Do That makes this movie good and relevant and real and special and a must-must-must-must watch. i love this movie <33 i hope more people get to see it

in a world where girls are called disgrasyada for carrying the consequences of what boys get to laugh of, where religion teaches you guilt before it teaches you choice, Sunshine makes you sit in that reality.this film should hurt and make you uncomfortable because it’s real. this is what is happening to us women and children. imagine ah the first thing she did when she found out na buntis siya is bumisita sa simbahan para mag sorry. we are raised in a country to fear God more than to trust our own body. it just feels like we are destined to bleed. this film didn’t try to redeem anyone. it didn’t even ask for forgiveness. it just told the truth and maybe that’s the bravest thing it could doSunshine you are so loved by me!!!! best film i’ve watched so far that is just so raw & vulnerable. i teared up watching this, especially the part na tinabihan siya ng ate nya :,)

“Drown out the noise. You’re Sunshine.” i know that everyone already said it, but this is one of the best filipino films this year! sobrang tapang and opens a lot of conversations about abortion, healthcare, sex education, lahat na! sobrang galing ni Maris, di ko siya nakita as Maris Racal in this film ramdam ko na siya talaga si Sunshine. it was a performance of a lifetime and her best film to date. this film depicts kung gaano nagpagiiwanan and close-minded yung mga pinoy with topics about abortion lalo na at taliwas ito sa religion natin, it also shows how unfair our healthcare and justice system is. the fact na halos walang kakampi karamihan nang mga nakaka-experience nang unwanted pregnancy, sobrang nakaka-lungkot na kahit mga hospital hindi ka matutulungan dahil hindi legal ang abortion sa bansa. i hope that more filipinos watch this and be open on why abortion has to be legal in the philippines. sobrang ganda talaga, wala na akong masabi!

mula palang sa pagbili ng pregnancy test, hanggang sa paglalahad ni sunshine na ayaw niyang maging ina, kapansin-pansin ang paulit-ulit na pagsumbat sa kanyang pagiging bata. ipinagdidiinan na hindi pa raw niya kayang mag-isip para sa sarili.habang nanonood, hindi ko maiwasang mapaisip: ano kaya ang gagawin ko kung ang nasa posisyon ni sunshine ay isang babaeng malapit sa akin? at ano naman kaya ang magiging trato ng mga taong malapit sa akin kung ako naman ang nasa posisyon ni sunshine? sa ngayon, siguro hindi ko pa alam ang mga sagot diyan. pero nakakatakot isipin na ang problemang 'to ay napakalapit sa akin, at alam kong kahit minsan sa buong buhay ko, makakakilala ako ng isang babaeng nasa katulad na sitwasyon ni sunshine na magigipit sa isang sistemang lugi na lugi sila.malinaw na ipinakita ng pelikula kung gaano kaatrasado ang usaping reproductive rights sa ating bansa. sa halip na matuunan ang mga kasong ganito at mabigyan ng suporta, kinakailangan pa ng mga babae na maghanap ng mga alternatibong mas delikado para sa kanilang sarili at sa kanilang dinadala.ang ganda ng pelikulang ito dahil wala nang ibang makapag-unawa at makapagkuwento nito nang buong-buo kundi isang babae lang din.hayyyy.., maris racal, i am your #1 defender. direk tonete, i am your #1 truther. at salamat Papa God for Piolo Pascual! #needthat

The first movie for 2025 that i'm giving my precious 5 stars. And although I would never change my stance on abortion, I always believe that my personal beliefs should never discredit or deny an excellent film-the credit where credit is due. Antoinette Jadaone's best film to date since Never Not Love You. The performance by Maris Racal is a career-defining one, she is so damn good, she can even give Natalie Portman a run for her money. Her subtleties in her emotions are so raw, her transformation into a gymnast is so believable and displayed such bravura, for a moment there she became the character, she was Sunshine—a flawed character that warrants empathy and compassion instead of judgment. So deserving of my 230 pesos. If I could watch this again on the big screen I would.

i was crying silently sa last few minutes of the film and the moment i woke up this morning for sunshine. habang nakikipag simpatya bilang manonood ay mabigat na, pano pa kaya ang mga babaeng nakakaranas mismo ng ganitong bangungotill prolly write my entire thoughts sa journal ko pero– i just wannna commend annika co for understanding the status of women living in this country. si annika yung type ng batang paglaki nya, makikita mong nakikibaka sa lansangan– to jennica garcia for being such a good actor. ramdam ko yung sakit sa mata nya every time lumalabas sya. – to maris racal for bringing sunshine to life. i know embodying the role was never easy, but thank you for being brave to represent oppressed women in our country. salamat din sa pagbibigay ng boses para sa mga kababaihang biktima ng kaharasan at ng relgious pressure ng bansang to. – to direk tonet for making this film. for choosing to tackle this topic despite the country being anti abortion. maraming salamat sa pagmulat ng mata namin sa iba't-ibang anggulo. dare i say the best 275 pesos i ever spent in my whole life.salamat sunshine, gets ko na.

Hindi lang basta coming-of-age film ang Sunshine. Isa itong kwentong maraming pinanghahawakang realidad, at inilalagay ka sa posisyon ng isang babaeng lumalaban para sa katawan niya, kinabukasan niya, at boses niya.Ang husay ng pagkakalahad ng Sunshine sa mabibigat na isyu tulad ng abortion, Catholic guilt, patriyarka, kahirapan, kakulangan sa public healthcare, reproductive health, teenage pregnancy, at kababaihan sa sports—pero ni minsan, hindi siya naging pilit o nangaral. Ramdam mong may tiwala siya sa manonood. Si Sunshine ang pumili para sa sarili niya, pero ikaw, binibigyan ka ng espasyong pag-isipan 'yon sa sarili mong paraan.Malinaw kung ano ang tinutumbok ng pelikula, at 'yon ang isa sa pinakamalakas nitong punto. Alam niya kung anong gusto niyang sabihin, pero hindi ka niya dinidiktahan kung paano mo ito tatanggapin. Binibigyan ka ng sapat na puwang para makaramdam, magtanong, at magnilay. Sa panahon ngayon na maraming pelikula ang kailangang sumigaw para marinig, ang Sunshine ay bumulong lang—pero 'yung bulong, dala-dala mo pa rin hanggang paglabas ng sinehan.

Sunshine offers something refreshing and different in Philippine cinema—and honestly, we need more stories like this. It’s bold, necessary, and deserves to be talked about. Kailangan natin ng mga kwentong totoo—‘yung nagpapakita ng realidad ng pamumuhay sa bansa natin.Under the direction of Antoinette Jadaone, Sunshine goes beyond being just a story about sports or dreams. It’s a story about womanhood in the Philippines—isang bansang deeply rooted sa religion, conservatism, at kung saan ang mga usaping tulad ng abortion ay nananatiling taboo. But the film’s message resonates far beyond our borders. It reflects the reality of so many women around the world. The film speaks so much truth about the lived experiences of countless women, and saludo talaga ako sa tapang ng mga gumawa nito. In these times, it takes guts to tell a story like this.Sunshine, as a character, represents those who dare to dream, and more importantly, those who dare to choose for themselves. The film is a powerful reminder that you have the right to carve your own path. Lalo na sa isang bansa na madalas i-demonize ang mga choices ng kababaihan, ng LGBTQ+ community, o kahit sinong pumipili para sa sarili nila.The entire film is gripping, emotional, and tense in the best way. Sa bawat eksena, may bigat, may puso, may katotohanan. I genuinely believe Sunshine will be remembered as a modern classic in Philippine cinema. Isa itong pelikulang hindi lang dapat panoorin, kundi pag-usapan.Maris Racal gave the performance of a lifetime. And bilib ako sa tapang mo, Direk Tonet. Salamat sa kwento. Gets ko na.

An important story, that highlights a very important reality in the country. I don’t think I completely agree with giving physical form to the child, but I understand the choice. I do think the boyfriend was too much of a caricature, and the narrative would have benefitted from a little nuance, to add more texture and reality. loved the underlying web of support from most of the women on screen, probably the best part of the whole film.

I can honestly say na lumalim yung understanding and empathy ko, especially towards young Filipino women. Sobrang galing ni Maris Racal, ramdam na ramdam from the screen lahat ng emotions na dala dala ni Sunshine. First time ko lang din mapanuod si Jennica Garcia and omg napakahusay !!! Siya ata paborito ko dito sa movie heheh very touching and nakakaiyak sobra yung relationship nilang mag ate. I watched this with my younger sister which made it more memorable, and natutuwa ako na naging malalim and maganda yung kwentuhan namin pagkatapos manuod.

Direk tonet and the rest of the Sunshine crew are so brave for tackling such a sensitive yet prevalent issue in this patriarchal and catholic society. I liked how they showed both sides of the debate, sparking conflict in me as well as a viewer. And even though I am a catholic who grew up in an all-girls school, I found myself saying “gets ko si Sunshine”, kasi ‘yun yung realidad. Not everyone has access to the same resources, nor the privilege to live comfortably. Dito ko rin natutunan na wala akong karapatang manghusga.Maris Racal, tangina napakahusay mo!!! She portrayed Sunshine’s desperation, anxiety, and grit in such a raw manner that it was so beautiful. Fan na fan mo rin ako Jennica Garcia! I think everyone should see this film at least once in their lifetime. It shows the reality of Manila and forces you to face the truths of young Filipino women. Dahil din dito ay mas nahikayat akong pag-usapan ang aborsyon, at sana ganun din ang mangyari sa lahat ng manonood nito. Kasi dapat talaga siyang pag-usapan! A very beautiful and thought-provoking film! Salamat sa sining, direk tonet at maris racal! This is what filmmaking is all about!

Ilang minuto pa lang sa panonood, malinaw na agad sa akin ang mensahe ng pelikula. Hindi gusto ni Sunshine na ipagpatuloy ang isang bagay na hindi niya piniling simulan, at nauunawaan ko siya.Nauunawaan kita Sunshine. Gayundin ang ibang kababaihang nasa parehong katayuan mo. Hindi madaling maging babae, lalo na sa Pilipinas kung saan walang batas na magbibigay-karapatan sa ating awtonomiya sa katawan at reproduktibong kalusugan. Sa madaling salita, walang batas para sa ligal at ligtas na aborsyon.Katulad ni Sunshine, may tapang, puso, at paninindigan ang pelikula. At hindi ito magiging posible kung hindi dahil sa maingat na direksiyon ni Direk Tonet at mahusay na pagganap ni Maris Racal. Sa loob ng mahigit isang oras, inilagay ko ang posisyon ko kay Sunshine. Bawat emosyon at sakit na naramdaman ni Sunshine ay tila parang naramdaman ko rin. Totoo nga, na mas iba ang karanasan sa panonood sa sinehan. Dahil doon, makikita mong iisa ang reaksiyon ng bawat tao sa bawat eksena. Mayroong kolektibong karanasan. At para sa akin, isa itong tagumpay na layunin ng pelikula. Maaaring hindi kami pare-pareho ng paninindigan, pero iisa ang aming nararamdaman habang sinusundan ang kuwento ni Sunshine.At sana, marami pa ang maabot ng pelikulang ito. Sana, marami pa ang maging bukas ang kanilang kaisipan sa ganitong kahalagang naratibo. Sana, maging tulay ang pelikulang ito upang magkaroon ng diskurso mula sa mga nakaupo. Dahil ang kuwento ni Sunshine ay tunay na nangyayari, si Sunshine ay isang tunay na tao.

— gets na gets kita sunshine (rant bc i need to take out sum shit that people my age cannot understand +medj spoilers)although I’ve always supported pro-choice, i still grew up in an environment and society of toxic, judgemental, religious people na sobrang diri sa idea ng topics na pinapakita ng movie nato… i have to admit that i am not perfect and have either stayed silent or have been partially agreeing w/ them to stay out of judgement,,,, that’s the issue here. Maraming tao na nagsasabi lang ng,,, “Bat ba hindi kayo nag-iisip?” or “Sinisira nyo lang future nyo”  I’m not here to normalize teenage pregnancy at all pero nakakakalungkot talaga how other people view the WOMEN in the situation. Ang dali dali nyo manghusga ng ating mga kapwa babae dhil di sila nagiintay for marriage, or minamadali nila ung “paglandi”, but it’s never on the guy. Its normal for us humans to feel lust and think about sexuality but I do not want to glorify it okay,, Sunshine as a person is not perfect, shes human. And so are all the other sunshines in the world. I have debated about the topic of teenage pregnancy a few times now and all i wish for is a better system in our country, and more support for the girls who have no choice, wether from strangers, family, loved ones, non-governmental organizations, or governmental ones,, even just that is rare haha. Abortion is not murder, it’s saving your life; and aswell as your child’s life from being put into an environment that isn’t meant for them. Adoption after labor isn't always the right choice. Imagine if u actually gave birth to it and put it up for adoption that ends the baby up in a worse household noh!!?!?!? If a girl isn’t ready to give birth, and has an independent choice, there shouldn’t be people to stop her at that point. One thing i dislike hearing is people bringing religious “morality” into the topic. It’s honestly super disrespectful, don't want to elaborate it anymore.Everything else aside, well no,, i just wanted to finally say how beautiful and educational this film was, the message was loud, raw, and clear, and is such an eye-opener to people who are unfamiliar with the topic; to see the authenticity of what teenage victims in the philippines go through, we see two perspectives, (Arianna) a little girl in a toxic household r’ed by her uncle, (Sunshine) and a young adult going through pregnancy, not being able to bare seeing another girl torturing her body— both suffering through the judgements of their fellow filipinos. This shows that we can never truly understand what somebody is going through unless we experience it in our own hands. But i wont forget about Annika Co in this movie ofc. Her part of being here shows na nde masama turuan ang mga kabataan tungkol sa mga gantong sensitibo na topic, and that Sunshine was never alone in her journey, Annika’s character was there to guide Sunshine on her journey, even though they had hardships with their relationship together, in the conclusion, the kid understood how Sunshine felt, and supported her throughout the end and that is more than enough.Basta i love u sunshine  this was not just a review of the movie, but also my personal rant feeling the reality beyond this fictional movie. Absolute cinemahay kingina tlg ni miggy and bubot !! I do not glorify teenage pregnancy/abortion but we should not disregard our rights as women to be able to make our own decisions for our future
PERIOD (pun intended)

no one tells you how alone it feels. to carry something you didnt ask for. to suffer in silence because your pain is inconvenient, because your choices are not yours. sunshine didnt just show that. it made me remember it. it made me feel it again.i watched it twice. and both times, it hurt in the same places. but it also touched something soft in me.a reminder im not the only one whos ever felt this way. her name was sunshine. but nothing about her story was light. and maybe thats the point—women are expected to shine, even when everything inside is collapsing. she made bad choices. yes. but what choices do we really have, when the world makes decisions for our bodies before we even know how they work? what choice does a girl have when the world punishes her for not being ready, and punishes her again for trying to survive it? when the system has failed us already when they have decided that bearing a baby is a demand and not a choice?and i felt seen. in all the things i was too scared to say out loud. the hiding. the pain you cant tell your mother about. the googling. the not knowing where to get pills, or how to afford them. the fear of your own body, and the shame of not understanding it. putangina. ang hirap maging babae. lalo na sa bansang pilit kang pinatatahimik.and still—there was warmth. there was sunshine. because somehow, this film made me feel less alone. because stories like this remind us that we are not alone. that our pain is not isolated. that someone out there is watching too, and feeling seen. that is what sunshine gave me. a relieving and painful kind of light. that not everything has to be healed, sometimes it just has to be shared.

Gutsy. Had a few elements that were pretty clunky but the razor-edge, frayed rawness sold the everyday dream of a coming-of-age Filipina coming of age in a country where the very same notion is downright dangerous. Maris Racal might just be the finest young actress amongst her contemporaries.

Kakampi mo ako.I think what felt most important to me about this film is that the sensitivities considered in writing this story ensured that reality was still being shown. It showed respect for the people direk was able to interview, and it showed disdain for the culture we perpetuate in the guise of religion and culture.It calls for the audience to see the effects of the choices they ask of others. It calls for empathy for the victims and what they have to go through and give up — their dreams, their childhood, their life. And it calls for disgust for the old ways of thinking, and possibly our skewed views on morality.And in these hard times, how proper support from the people around you can allow you to make decisions for yourself and not because of what others will think. Something that most people do not readily have in our society.Every moment of this film has emphasized a deep-rooted societal problem that was asking to be seen. And kudos to direk Tonet for doing so beautifully.

Cried four times lol.While I don’t think this movie is going to convert any pinoy pro-lifers, I also don’t think that’s the movie’s purpose anyway. This movie is so pinoy, or at least in the Manila sense. The city noise, the sweltering heat, all radiating in the background of Sunshine’s journey to get an abortion. I wouldn’t say the movie’s perfect—I have some issues with the use of Sunshine’s motivations as a student athlete being a little flat—but the movie resonates in the parts where it matters.

Although Sunshine (2024) advanced the conversation about abortion and body autonomy, one treatment of the film sets the conversation back.Don't get me wrong tho', it effectively presented difficult conversations within an already difficult subject. It doesn't just talk about abortion in the moral sense, but also its nuances—such as abuse and inaccessibility of healthcare, including both financial and policymaking aspects that rob women of the right to appropriate medical procedures.It also gave face to the concept of guilt through the personification of the unborn, embodied by the characters of the unnamed child and Ariana.But that very personification is where exactly the issue starts.The argument for the pro-choice position is the fact that life does not start at conception, but upon delivery. To personify unborn fetuses strengthens the narrative that abortion is murder. "Murderer," as the unnamed child called Sunshine the moment abortion crossed her mind upon knowing that she's pregnant.But how much does this set the conversation back? Not a lot, really.The film did not fail in doing its job. By tackling abortion itself, it already succeeded in sparking conversations such as this one. And that's already a huge step in advancing women's right to accessible healthcare.Let's just hope that we'll get to see more "woke indie films" like Sunshine (2024). Art, after all, is not solely for its own sake.

i am sunshine, i was once sunshine. the dreams i thought i wouldn't reach because of one incident made everyday a living hell for me. the pain i had to endure alone every night, playing the waiting game, taking in all the harsh words everyone would say. this film just brings back the pain i suffered through but it also encapsulated how the people around me supported and stayed with me through it. may this film be a comfort to the other sunshines out there. this is the reality that needs to be depicted, it might receive criticisms but this film captures the whole of the essence of being a woman. i cried throughout the movie, i know how bad the pain is. gets kita sunshine, gets na gets kita.
