gets ko naSo many still don’t understand, but it’s enough that some do.This film is brave—fearlessly made, carefully thought out, and clearly crafted from the heart.When I watched it, all I wanted to do was hold Sunshine—hold every Sunshine out there who I know is carrying the weight of this harsh, terrifying society.I still can’t get over the fact that this was shown in Philippine cinemas because, finally, it got the visibility it truly deserves. This is the kind of film the world should see. When I finished watching it, I already knew the state and how our society would portray abortion and how it was always deemed evil and inhumane but after seeing this film, I felt a sense of relief that finally, a film about women, about abortion, about its effects, not just mentally but physically, and how sometimes, we really just have to understand, for who are we to judge someone who really is just fighting to live through and view women in a way that they should be, respected.Even the supporting characters—especially Jennica Garcia—were brilliant. I felt her love for her sister so deeply. Even when Sunshine thought the world had turned its back on her, her sister’s presence was a constant reminder that someone was still there, always beside her, fully aware of the struggles she faced—struggles made heavier because she’s a woman.Also a huge role that was portrayed by Rhed Bustamante. Just, wow. It was a story meant to be told and written. It isn't just fiction it's currently happening today and that's why it should be a story that needed to be shed light on. It was tragic, painful to look at but it was real, all of it, and that's what makes it a story worth telling.And Maris Racal—what a phenomenal actress. Her cries pierce right through you. Her frustration, her courage, her strength as a woman—all of it shines through. In Sunshine, I saw her desperation, her bravery, her womanhood, and her relentless grasp on her dreams, refusing to let them slip away.Maris and Direk Tonet knew exactly what they wanted to tell their audience, and I’m so glad they did it with such courage. They gave voice to women like Sunshine—women who are still too afraid to scream their truths.I hope this film becomes a beacon for people like Sunshine, the way she brings life to every twirl of her ribbon and every movement of her body to the rhythm. There are so many like her still hidden in the shadows of fear and guilt. And yes, we all know that in the Philippines, some mindsets are hard to change—but does it have to stop there? Will we allow people like Sunshine to remain caged by a judgmental society?Maybe for now, it’s hard. But because of this film, women like Sunshine can finally catch a glimpse of hope.:’)

manila cradles both the victories people chase and the dreams they leave behind. i'm so glad there's a film that sheds light on the struggles of both those who choose motherhood and those who don’t. i'm not a stranger to these experiences— i’ve been surrounded by women all my life. their struggles, their dilemmas, and their perseverance have deeply shaped who i am. films like this are so so important. godspeed to all filipino actors and directors— everyone in film!!maris is stellar and she's only starting. my god, i kid you not i wanted to stand up and clap.

malalim. tagos sa puso. masakit.sa SUNSHINE ko napagtanto na sapat na ang “gets ko na” sa nakararaming tanong sa mundo. wala na sanang kasamang opinyon o salita, nawa’y turuan natin ang sarili na bigyan sila ng kahit simpleng pagtango sa kung ano man ang maging desisyon nila. dahil bago sila dumating sa puntong iyon, alam na nila kung ano ang dapat gawin, wala na ang kung ano mang sumbat.dahil si SUNSHINE ay hindi lamang basta babae, o ang magulo at maingay na daan sa avenida, kabilang na ang quiapo na minsan ay naging hingian ng sagot—dahil sya ay ang sarili niyang desisyon, hindi natin o kung sino pa man.sa huli ko lang din nareliaze na si annika ay ang anak niyang in-abort, with her saying “gets ko na.” sobrang tagos. sobrang sakit.sa huli ko lang din narealize na si anika pala yung in-abort nyang child
Start of my love for Philippine cinema this 2025.

Honestly, 3.5 stars for the movie overall, but here's extra 0.5 star for the super random cameo that was also somehow super on the nose. It's such a good bit that amuses me to no end. I'd rate the movie higher if not for a plot device that felt completely unnecessary and at times distracting. Take it away, and it won't even change anything about the movie. Every time they employed this plot device, it was just so unnecessary and distracting. The movie also squeezed in too many "unwanted pregnancy" tropes that it risked being too bloated story-wise. Think of an "unwanted pregancy" trope, it's there. They stop short of it being too bloated at the expense of the story (and you have to give it to Antoinette Jadaone for this balancing act), though I still spent a good chunk of the movie wondering how many more tropes were coming. Still the movie is brave, and is made so much better for its bravery. It does not shy away from the realities faced by so many women in this country when it comes to maternal health. It tackled head-on the heavily religious overtones that tends to dominate the conversations around this topic. It shows the ironic juxtaposition of abortion pills being sold next to religious artifacts. But most importantly, it does not get preachy. It does not feel like it is patronizing the audience about what should be in each scene that squeezes your heart, it just shows it. But also Jennica Garcia steals the show in every scene is in. Maris Racal deserves the accolades she's getting for carrying the movie so steadily as its lead and with everything asked of her for the character. But Jennica Garcia just commands every scene even she doesn't say a word. And every scene these two have together was really gold-medal worthy.
powerful and rawmaris and the entire team did an incredible job
gets ko na

sana marami pa ang makanood nito. tunay nga na ang sining ang sumasalamin sa buhay ng mga tao. eto ang pelikulang kailangan natin ngayon: totoo, mahalaga, may puso, at kailangan pag-usapan. gusto ko lang talaga icommend si maris. tangina, powerhouse performance, sobrang husay. dalang dala nya ang emosyon, karakter, at kwento ng bawat babae—matanda man o bata—na naghahanap ng solusyon sa bansa o komunidad na taliwas dito. yung jeepney scene? grabe. sabi nga nila, masarap maglabas ng nararamdaman tuwing nasa byahe tayo. at saan ba bumabyahe ang mga pangkaraniwang pilipino? sa jeep.ganda ng cinematography. kuhang kuha ang essence ng maynila. bawat eksena ng pelikula ay may laman at kontrobisyon sa karakter at flow ng istorya. sa dinami-dami ng pelikulang pilipino na napanood ko, iisipin ko na napagusapan na lahat ng paksa na maaaring ipakita sa midya. pero, totoong taboo pa rin ang usaping aborsyon dito sa atin dahil tayo ay “religious country”. sana ay maging daan ang pelikulang ito upang mas maging bukas tayong mga pilipino sa pinagdadaanan ng mga kababaihan, at bigyan sila ng karapatan na magdesisyon para sa kanilang sarili at kapakanan. sobrang daming kababaihan ang nakaranas ng naranasan ng karakter ni rhed. kailangan pa ba na mag-agaw buhay para magkaroon ng panibagong pag-asa sa buhay?sobra rin ako naging emosyonal sa last scene ni maris at annika. para sa akin, eto (at ang scene ni maris at jennica) ang nagpakita ng mensahe ng pelikula: pag-unawa. gets ko na is such a short, simple, yet heavy statement for someone who feels hopeless, directionless, and who is going through something that will dictate her whole future. kudos sayo, mom tonet at sa buong produksyon ng pelikula. mabuhay ang pilipinong sining!

if this shares anything with films from ph cinema's golden age, it is a strong thesis statement about manila. a lot has changed since we have moved from one marcos to another, but the power sunshine holds is to choose the one thing that has endured -- belief.driven by ambition, comforted but oppressed by religion, and deceived by folk medicine, sunshine's situation is a product of the convictions of those around her. fact and fiction are difficult to distinguish from her perspective. whether the effectivity of unregulated medication or the potential of an unborn child, a pregnant woman has to deal with the gradient of reality that is muddled by a conservative environment. importantly, sunshine is not a product of circumstance, but an active agent in negotiating her place amid all of it. i have my gripes with the main plot device of her possible unborn children, but i also feel open to interpretations that explain them. this is going to be an important filipino film and its artistry is probably secondary to how it might change views.

“hindi sapat na ang babae ay maging ina lamang; dapat din siyang maging aktibong bahagi ng pagbabago ng lipunan.”Lualhati Bautistaas a huge believer in “only make art if you have something to say,” jadaone really has something to say. this movie is probably one of the most important filipino films ever made. the sad truth is, it does not exaggerate any details, this is simply the reality of our patriarchal society.but the film’s strength lies not only in its message but also in how it perfectly captures its setting.the movie itself is something that the majority of filipino filmmakers should study, a lino brocka-esque portrayal of the grit of manila: the familiar filipino home interiors, the choice of clothes, the 300 pesos motels, the guilt-tripping sermon from conservative boomers, the religious imagery. every detail, even the smalles rings true and is authentically filipino. this is something that elevates it far above many other modern filipino films.also,  ABORTION IS HEALTHCARE!!!

“gets ko na.”This film clearly shows that it’s usually women who suffer the most and face judgment when it comes to issues like this, especially in countries where it is considered taboo. It also shows the serious and deadly consequences of unsafe abortions in places where legal and safe options are not available na sana gets niyo rin.

sana naman ma-gets na—or at least mag-start na ng usapan sa topic na to—ng taumbayan kung bakit sobrang mahalaga ang abortion. it’s not a black and white issue kung saan mali na agad siya kasi labag siya sa batas ng diyos. i really loved how the movie was directed; kuhang-kuha talaga yung emosyon ng mga characters pati na rin yung sobrang pagkagulo ng manila. i loved how maris portrayed sunshine. sobrang raw and authentic ng pag-act niya lalo na yung kaba niyang tatanggalin na siya sa roster na nagdulot ng pagkadesperada niyang makaalis sa sitwasyong iyon para makamit yung mga pangarap niya. to all the sunshines out there, i see you. gets ko kayo, at sana maging tulay ang sunshine sa pagsimula ng diskusyon sa topic ng abortion para tuluyan ninyong makamit ang inyong mga pangarap.

The best Filipino film of the year so far. Perhaps also the best locally made sports drama in recent memory. No glitz and glamor and just plainly focused on the realities and internal struggles of athletes. The vision and the photography of the film is on point. Pinoy na pinoy ang atake, lalo na 'yung mga shots sa Quiapo at Avenida. Hindi rin 'to natakot talakayin ang issues ng teenage pregnancy, abortion, toxic religiosity, incest, matinding kahirapan at kabulukan ng sistema ng health care sa bansa.The best part of the film? Maris Racal! Grabe! Give her a role, enough time, and she can do anything! That performance towards the end shows how she worked hard to emulate a rhythmic gymnast, to perform the craft assigned to her. Obviously, the most dedicated, if not the best, actress of this generation. 'Di masyadong sikat, walang masyadong top billing pero wala kang masasabi pagdating sa galing at puso sa bawat role na binibigay sa kanya.

the most relevant filipino film this 2025!everything about this film felt raw, honest, and real. from the acting to the cinematography, every scene felt intentional. the desperation, fear, and guilt in that one jeepney scene really sums up the struggle, shame, and mistreatment that many young women have to face due to the carelessness of men. this film is also proof on how growing up in a country with predominantly very catholic christian views affects the way that we feel about certain choices that we make; kahit na kinakailangan talaga nating gawin. kaya bago bumili si Sunshine ng kailangan niyang bilhin sa quiapo, humingi muna siya ng patawad kay Lord. overall, a film that caters to many young women—like Sunshine, who just wants to reach the dream she has been working on her whole life in spite of systemic barriers and cultural expectations imposed by a country that values religious beliefs over a woman’s right to autonomy. gets ko na, Sunshine.

from her wardrobe colors down to each and every vital experience that sunshine went through, this film bled womanhood. hindi lang tungkol sa sensitibong tema na tinatalakay; tungkol mismo sa choice. choice na magpatuloy, choice na sumuporta, choice na magalit. ng mga karakter at maging ng manonood. una pa lang, nasabi kong extension ng identity ni sunshine ‘yung bata. her unborn child. hindi nito hangad mangumbinsi. hangad nitong magpaunawa. sana sa pamamagitan ng mga ekstensibong diskusyon, mapukaw tayong umaksyon tungkol…
good for her!

Gets ba bakit ang hirap hirap maging babae sa mundong to? Like men get to enjoy the pleasures of life without a single care kasi una, wala silang iniintindihing consequences. Hindi naman sila mabubuntis, hindi naman nila kailangan pagdaanan ang grueling 9 months ng pagdadalang tao at dahil don, hindi rin nila kailangang isuko or isantabi ang mga opportunities in life. They can go and live their normal lives as usual. Tapos pangalawa, kapag babae ang nabuntis, lahat ng sisi, kahihiyan, at pressure sa kanya agad. Hindi nila mararamdaman yung guilt, yung takot, yung burden kasi hindi naman sila shinashame ng lipunan gaya ng pagshame sa kababaihan.ewan puro galit at sakit naramdaman ko sa film na to bukod sa walang proper healthcare for women at napakalalang religious influences sa pilipinas, parang awang awa ako saming mga kababaihan na para bang hindi talaga magegets ng mga lalaki yung danas at hirap magiging babae sa lipunang to.

i didn’t know na the simple “gets ko na” line will have me almost crying sa sinehan. oa na kung oa pero GETS NA GETS KO. it lands because the whole film builds up to it, this idea that women are constantly being misunderstood, questioned, doubted. and then one woman looks at another, sees her pain, and simply says, “gets ko na.” that’s the most powerful kind of solidarity. not saving someone. not preaching to them. just understanding them. the female relationships were the heart of it. hindi romantic love ang source of salvation dito. women helping women, women understanding women, yun ang lifeline ni sunshine. and that, to me, is what makes the movie not just brave, but also beautiful.one of the boldest things sunshine did was not moralize. a lesser film might’ve gone down the typical route— punishing the character for her sins, forcing her into regret, or ending with her back in the cycle of poverty because she “deserved” it. sunshine rejects that. it gives her space to want more, unapologetically. that is, in itself, revolutionary kasi sanay tayong makita ang kababaihan na laging martyr, laging nagpapaubaya, laging umiiyak sa ending habang umaandar ang jeep, but here? we get a girl who simply chooses her self. and that should never have to be a radical act but in our context, it is. because we glorify mothers, “ilaw ng tahanan,” “walang katulad ang pagmamahal ng ina”, pero the moment a woman says that she's not ready for the role, she’s shamed. our culture wants motherhood without giving women the right to choose it.

and when a system of laws, religion, and society plays repression towards women at its core, they are left optionless but to reach the edges—even the roughest ones. this is starkly and assertively depicted in sunshine as it alludes to the fact that although customs and policies are purposed to save, they may also be they very waters that drown us.and that sequence with the pastor? very nuanced. so good. goes to show how the patriarchy and the church always find ways, direct or indirect, to monopolize women's choices and liberty. in one way or another, we are sunshine.

ok ito na ang review ko na hindi naman ganun ka-relevant (???) CHARpero kailangan ko lang ‘to ilabas before anything else: maris racal is THE doja cat of the philippines, controversial-wise. bakit? GIRL… kasi kahit anong gawin ni maris na “cancellable”, hindi talaga siya ma-cancel because she’s just THAT good. GETS BA!!! pruweba lang ‘to na ang cancel culture ay hindi totoo… chrue?OK ITO NA TALAGA. this is it.mula sa pinanood ko, hindi lang basta-bastang pelikula ang sunshine. given na ‘yung magandang konsepto, storyline, casting, at setting ng pelikula pero gusto ko lang mas i-highlight ‘yung fact na kahit ba sobrang taboo ng “abortion” topic sa pilipinas, direk tonet did what NEEDS to be done and i mean, talk about IT. sa malawak na masang pilipino, kailangan nilang maintindihan na hindi pwedeng tanggapin na lamang ng bawat babaeng maagang nabuntis na dadalhin nila ito hanggang sa mabuhay ang sanggol. hindi. kasi may mas malawak pang diskusyon labas sa pagbubuntis at ito ang kapalpakan ng sistemang kinagisnan ng karamihan.kung maglalaan ng oras ang administrasyon sa pag-aaral hinggil sa kahalagahan ng abortion sa pilipinas, mas gagaan ang buhay ng bawat pilipinang maagang nabuntis. gaya ni sunshine, hindi na nila kailangan pang dumaan sa peligrosong proseso upang ipalaglag ang pagdadalang-tao nila dahil aksisable, at ligal na ito. pero sa lagay ng bansa natin ngayon, mukhang wala pa tayo sa kalingkingan ng pagsasabatas nito dahil tila mangmang ang mga mambabatas na iniluklok sa pwesto. malayo pa ang tatahakin ng bawat pilipino sa lipunang patuloy na binubura ang mga progresibo pero ang mga pelikula gaya ng sunshine, ay isa lamang sa maraming paraan upang manghamig, magmulat, at pakilusin ang masang patuloy na inaapi laban sa mapanamantalang sistema na kinalakihan natin.suportahan natin ang mga lokal na pelikula. suportahan natin ang larangan ng sining. suportahan natin ang sariling atin.#MakeAbortionLegal #AbortionIsNotMurder
Life changing & still speechless

It’s been a while since I last watched a movie alone. I actually asked my partner first if it was okay to watch Sunshine without him—he’s not really into Filipino films, and I totally respect that. But something about this movie pulled me in.And I’m glad I watched it. Sunshine shook me. It’s not just a film—it’s a mirror of what’s really happening around us. It hit hard, especially thinking about those who’ve gone through abuse—women, children, even the ones who never had the courage to speak up.Sure, there were a few funny scenes—maybe to ease the weight of the story—but the truth behind it stays. It’s heavy, it’s real, and it’s heartbreaking.We can’t just look away anymore. These kids and young women who’ve lived through this kind of nightmare… they need to be seen, heard, and protected. Because maybe—we are their last hope. And that means something.
galing tangina

This film truly moved me—it powerfully portrays the harsh reality of the Philippines’ current stance on abortion. The line “gets ko na” struck me deeply; it’s both empowering and eye-opening. Every woman in the country should see this, as it sheds light on the difficult experiences many go through. The story is raw, relevant and it is worth talking about. It’s a bold feminist film that reminds us we all sunshine in our own unique ways and we continue to wait for sunshine. Every woman has the right to make decisions about her body and her future. Thank you so much, Direk Tonet, for creating this important piece.

Ang husay!!!That was my first thought after the credits rolled. Every cast member acted so well, but Maris really carried it. Nothing felt performed. She was just there, fully present in every scene. Manila looked exactly how we know it. Crowded, humid, alive, and heavy.Sceeenplay wise, it was honest and not trying hard. A lot of those lines I’ve heard in real conversations. It just shows you what it’s like to be a woman in this country with no access to reproductive rights and safe and legal abortion. I hope Sunshine helps start more open and honest conversations. Reproductive health is still treated like something dirty in the PH. Women suffer quietly, and most people pretend not to see.The story is simple, but the path it takes is so clear. From beginning to end, it doesn’t stray. I was honestly scared it would compromise somewhere along the way, but it didn’t. It stayed brave.Antoinette Jadaone, you are so brave!!! Seriously. It takes guts to make something like this here. Thank you for telling this story, and for telling it without fear.
So much better on second viewing.

Sunshine sa Kuko ng MaynilaKasama ng mga pelikulang may “maynila” sa titulo na kamakailan ko lang napanood, bukod sa pagpupunit ng bandila ng konserbatibong paniniwala na nagmula sa kristiyanismo, pinapakita din ng Sunshine ang siyudad ng Maynila sa gabi—kung saan imbes na pag-asa, sumpa ang pangunahing kaluluwa na hinihinga’t tinitiis ng mga mamamayan. Sa labas ng simbahan makikita ang mga illegal na medesinang pampalaglag na nagsisilbi bilang pagasa para sa maraming kababaihan marahil ang institusyon sa harapan ng mga tindahang ito, ang simbahan, ang may kapangyarihan kahit na sabihing progresibo na ang mga paniniwala ng tao. Sa isang eksena, si Sunshine ay nagbuwis buhay sa isang masikip na motel sa Avenida, dala dala ang boteng pampalaglag, nagdudugo, nanghihingalo palabas habang patuloy ang pagtakbo ng LRT, at nagising nalang sa ospital, puno ng mga babaeng tinitiis ang hindi makataong pampublikong pasilidad.Halos 500 teenager ang nagiging ina araw araw. Kung legal lamang ang pagpapalaglag, ang mga numerong ito’y mababawasan. Isa sa may pinaka mabigat na istorya ay ang karakter ni Rhed Bustamante na si Menggay, isang 13 taong gulang na binuntis ng kaniyang tito. Kaniyang sinusundan si Sunshine at ibang mga babae, upang humingi ng pampalaglag. Nililibot niya ang Maynila na may tiyang di nararapat para sa isang dalaga. Tulad ni Sunshine, si Menggay ay pinadala rin sa ospital. Ngunit di natin siyang nakitang gumising. Ang pelikula ni Jadaone ay paniguradong titignan ng mga iskolar bilang “classic” makalipas ang ilang taon, tulad ng Manila by Night at Maynila Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag. Isa sa mga susi ng pagtatagumpay ng storyang ito ay naiintindihan nito ang mga karakter na kinekwento bilang mga tao at hindi lamang teksto. Madaling tapusin ang mga pelikulang may realismo sa trahedya ngunit hindi pinili ni Jadaone ang direksyong iyon. Ang titulong “Sunshine” ay sumisimbolo rin sa diwa ng Pilipino—madalas masiyahin at nakakahanap pa rin ng ilaw sa madidilim na eskenita, matatatag (o resilient). Dahil tayo’y kilala sa ganitong paraan, madali tayong abusuhin ng ating gobyerno. Labag raw sa batas ng diyos ang pagpapalaglag ng bata ngunit sa ganitong pagiisip, sa pagproprotekta ng mga hindi pa naisisilang, pinapatay ang ating mga kababaihan. Ngunit isa sa mga ipinakita sa pelikulang ito ay ang mga babae na nakikiramay kay Sunshine, kahit man ito’y makulit na bata, o kapatid na nagsilbing nanay, o kahit mga babae sa post maternal ward na nakakaintindi ng sakit na nadarama ng karakter ni Maris Racal at ang mga Sunshine sa Pilipinas. Mahaba pa ang magiging lakbay patungo sa bansang kayang tumanggap na isang karapatan ng babae ang awtonomiya ng kaniyang katawan, ngunit sa pelikulang ito, at sa pagdami ng mga manonood, nagkakaroon ng espayo upang magbukas ang mga usaping tinuturing “taboo”.
tight hugs, for all of the sunshines out there.

This is the kind of film I want to see.I had huge expectations for this movie before I came to the theater to watch it, and it did not at all disappoint. It didn’t, in any way, fall short of anything I hoped for. From the direction to the casting, sobrang ganda… and I wish I were exaggerating.Una, Antoinette Jadaone, what a director you are. Throughout the movie, the words “Ang galing” kept escaping my mouth. The camera angles were beautiful, the timing of the sound production was marvelous, the screenplay was solid—everything was on point. Sunshine satisfied my standards for aesthetics when it comes to film.Pangalawa, Maris. Hands down—sobrang talentadong babae talaga. Setting her issue aside, she’s a versatile actress. She embodied Sunshine so well that I felt myself completely absorbed in the story. Dagdag pa riyan si Jennica Garcia, another golden star. I knew her through Saving Grace, and doon pa lang, sobrang namangha na ako sa kakayahan niya. I need to see her in more films. Halos lahat naman kung tutuusin—they have done a tremendous job with their performances. Everything felt so real.Pangatlo, the script? Hello? Ang natural. It wasn’t like her other directed movie, Uninvited, na puro mura. This time, it was profanity with purpose. (haha) The lines were written and delivered so well that it made me stop and think how observing plays such a vital role in every profession. Lalo na rito. Kaya tagos sa puso, kasi totoo. Nangyayari ‘to.At panghuli, the hidden message. In every movie, I like to believe that there’s at least a little advocacy screaming through every minute. In this case, it’s the consideration of legalizing abortion in the Philippines. Maraming mga hindi kayang bumuhay ng anak, mga hindi kayang sustentahan ang isang tao, at mga taong sinamantala lamang. Even with these reasons, is it still not right to consider abortion? One might counter, “Pwede mo namang ipaalaga sa kamag-anak o sa mga magulang.” But the truth is: life is much more complex than that. It is so much more complicated because there are cases like this in real life, where the only family they have is their siblings... Some only have themselves.…Hays, basta abstinence talaga dapat guys!I love everything about this movie. I love how it depicts the reality some pregnant teenagers go through—even those who have dreams. I believe I have more to say, but I’d like to reflect on that myself. Just keep a bit of Sunshine all to me.That's how deeply it hit me.

late na review kasi putangina ang tagal nitong nasa isip ko pagkatapos naming panoorin.ngayon lang ulit ako nakakita ng ganito ka-grounded at ka-totoong portrayal ng totoong maynila sa contemporary philippine cinema. madalas kasi sa mapapanood mo ngayon ay kung hindi pinapaganda, nagiging palamuti lang o para bang wala lang talagang papel yung maynilang ginagalawan ng mga karakter ng pelikula.pero dito sa maynila ni tonet jadaone, kita, at rinig mo lahat. siguro isa pang dahilan kung bakit malakas tama sa'kin nito kasi ito yung mga naririnig ko araw-araw: yung napakaingay na tunog ng lrt, yung mga jeep na sasabog na sa lakas ng tugtog (kahit music taste ko naman yung mga kanta xD), at yung samu't-saring mga usapan ng mga taong kagaya mo na naglalakad sa maynila.sobrang ingat din ng pagkaka-handle sa isyu ng abortion at women's healthcare in general. walang pananaw na nilagay sa "bad light," pero may reyalidad na ipinakita at ipinaintindi, ang reyalidad ng mga babaeng katulad ni sunshine. ang ganda rin na hindi lang reaktib si sunshine sa mga nangyayari sa kanya, meron siyang sariling pangarap, meron siyang sariling desisyon, at meron siyang gagawin sa mga problema niya kahit na para bang lahat ng nakapalibot sa kanya ay pursigidong kontrolin ang buhay niya o diktahan ito nang naaayon sa kagustuhan nila.maganda yung pelikula, oo, pero para sa'kin, mas may bigat ang kahalagahan nito: sobrang laki ng magiging (at nagiging) papel nito upang magpatuloy ang diskurso sa isyu ng women's rights, abortion, at women's bodily autonomy sa lahat ng lebel ng lipunan. hindi man ito ang puno't-dulo ng usapin, masasabi kong isa ito sa mga may kakayahang magtulak ng lipunan natin sa tamang landas. salamat, direk tonet at salamat, sunshine. sana magets na nilang lahat.

award winning movie of maris racal, after watching the film and the interviews—ang daming realizations.dito mo masasabing eto ang realidad ng pilipinas, gaano kapoor ang healthcare system, may iilang scenes na walang linya ngunit ingay lang ng paligid ang maririnig mo. lahat ng emosyon nalalabas talaga bawat luha, sigaw, mura ramdam mo kay sunshine.its not just about of gymnast with a dream, its a dream of a young girl talaga. its not just about her dream or career. its about public health, teenage pregnancy, catholic guilt, lack of sex education at choices ng mga kababaihan.sobrang relevant, ang tapang, its raw. susuportahan ang pelikulang pilipino, mabuhay ang mga pilipino.

Sunshine.Akala mo pabebe title. Pero nope.Pinasabog ako emotionally. Walang pasintabi.At this point, masasabi ko na isa ito sa mga pinakamagandang pelikulang Pilipinong napanood ko. Walang pilit na patawa. Walang palamig. May saysay, may sipa, at may kirot na hindi mo pwedeng balewalain. May mga eksenang uncomfortable pero kailangan.Kasi minsan, ang totoong kwento, hindi masarap panoorin.Pero dapat.The storytelling?Putcha. Tahimik pero mabangis. Hindi ito yung tipo ng pelikula na sasabihin sa’yo kung ano ang tama o mali. Ipapakita lang niya tapos bahala ka sa internal crisis mo after. May bits na parang sinaksak ka sa puso pero may ngiti ka pa rin sa labi. Kasi ganon katalino ang pagkakasulat. Simple lang ang galaw ng camera, pero lahat ng eksena may laman. Lahat ng katahimikan, may sigaw.Maris Racal bilang Sunshine?Grabe. Ang natural. Parang hindi umaarte, pero ramdam mo bawat pikit, bawat buntong-hininga, bawat patak ng luha.And for the rest of the cast?Jennica, Meryll, Elijah, Annika, Rhed. Kung may acting Olympics, podium lahat ‘to.And the themes?Feminism na hindi lecture. Commentary na hindi sermon. May mga eksenang tatahimik ka after. Yung tipong mapapaisip ka: “Shit. Ako ba ‘yung pinatatamaan?” Oo, bes. Tayong lahat. Kasi lahat tayo may ambag sa double standards na tinotolerate natin araw-araw.Hindi ito ‘yung tipong pelikulang minadali. Sunshine is crafted, not just created.Hindi lang siya ginawa para may mapanood. Sunshine is a film that meant something and moved with purpose.Hindi siya sumisigaw ng “tignan mo ako.” Pero hindi mo rin siya kayang i-ignore. It sits with you. Stays with you. Makes you ask things you usually avoid.At sa ending, walang fireworks. Walang dramatic breakdown, walang moral lesson na pilit. Pero andun yung bigat. Yung linaw. Yung paninindigan.Sunshine made a choice: tahimik, matatag, at alam niyang hindi lahat makakaintindi. Pero hindi rin niya kailangang ipaliwanag. Katawan niya ’yon. Buhay niya ’yon.At sa pagpili niya, may kirot, oo. Pero may ginhawa rin. May lungkot, pero may pag-asa. Kasi for once, isang babaeng Pilipina ang pinayagang pumili para sa sarili niya, at hindi siya pinarusahan.Hindi siya ginawang trahedya.Ginawa siyang posibilidad.At sana mas dumami pa ang ganitong kwento, yung mga kwentong hindi sinusukat sa sakripisyo kundi sa kalayaan. Yung mga babaeng hindi inaasahang sumunod, kundi tinuturuang magtanong ng: “Ano ba talaga ang gusto ko? At handa ba akong ipaglaban ito?”Because at the end of the day, whether it’s about your career, your body, or your future, ikaw dapat ang may final say. Hindi ang mundo. Hindi ang ingay. Hindi ang kahon na kung saan gusto nilang ipagsiksikan ka.Kung saan ka masaya, kung saan ka buo, doon ka tama.

to live in a society where your most personal decisions are controlled by external forces and outdated structures… it’s exhausting.after watching the film today, i found myself deep in thought as i left the cinema. it was so real and raw. like, genuinely, an eye-opener. the film just beautifully, but also painfully, shows how interconnected everything is. your sex education, or lack thereof, impacts your healthcare system access, your personal moral compass, and of course, your dreams and your passion. it really hit home how incredibly hard it is to be a woman especially here in the philippines, with all our deeply ingrained religious beliefs, particularly around topics like abortion. it’s just so disheartening to hear all the harsh opinions and these strong pushes for anti-abortion laws, especially when they come from people who aren't personally dealing with those difficult, life-altering situations. it’s so easy for some to just state an anti-abortion stance, but the reality for a woman wrestling with such a complex decision is so much more nuanced and personal.you hear it all the time: choosing to terminate a pregnancy is selfish. but then i genuinely wonder, isn't it also selfish to bring a child into the world if you're not fully ready, or if you're uncertain about the future that motherhood brings? in a country that can be so conservative, we really, really need a broader, more compassionate discussion. we need to figure out how to support women and their choices, whatever they may be. not all women want to be mothers. not all women want to be impregnated. even i, personally, don't want to be a mother. and that's okay. it’s time we should be open to talking about these topics, really opening up our minds, and stop letting our religious beliefs completely go into our way of empathy and understanding. this movie just amplified that for me. ang galing galing mo, maris.

an anecdote that nobody asked for: i vividly remember my sixth grade homeroom class, sinabihan kami ng adviser namin na mali magpalaglag, kasi “hindi mo matatama ang isang pagkakamali sa paggawa ng isa pang pagkakamali”. it’s been engrained in our heads and taught to us that abortion is wrong. i didn’t even have the time back then to question it kasi ‘yun yung sinasabi ng lahat ng adults around me, and eto na yung tinuturo sa atin even at a young age. having a film like Sunshine is so important, it sparks a conversation that we couldn’t have before because it was such a taboo topic.separate na character ang maynila sa pelikulang ‘to. ramdam ko kasama ko rin si sunshine na naglalakad pa-quiapo also te sobrang affected talaga ako sa scenes with maris and jennica like GRABE LANG… the scene sa taxi when sunshine was leaning on her big sister, wala pa silang sinasabi tumutulo na luha ko. pati nung tinabihan ni jennica si maris sa kama, the sisterly bond was something i didn’t see coming kuhang kuha talaga ako watched this in cinemas with my tita, who’s like a mother to me. it meant a lot that i got to experience it with her :)

Ang pinakanagustuhan ko sa Sunshine ay yung tapat na kwinento ang karanasan ng mga kababaihan, lalo na ng mga batang babae, sa bulok na healthcare dito sa Pilipinas na hindi tayo binibigyan ng kalayaan para makapili. Hindi ito paligoy-ligoy, at ang galing ni Maris sa kanyang ginampanan na papel bilang bida - na mas lalo ko pang naappreciate dahil sa pagparticipate nya sa pagkausap ng mga babaeng nakaranas nito sa realidad.Sana marami pang makanood nito. Sana, balang araw, may kalayaan na ang mga Sunshine sa Pilipinas para makapili at maalagaan ng sistemang may pakialam.

although i already knew what the premise of the movie was, sobrang emotional pa rin nung dating nung intro sakin. it opened with Sunshine performing her gymnastics routine almost flawlessly tapos maya-maya, it was immediately revealed that she was pregnant. knowing all this beforehand didn't lessen the impact of the intro scene for me - my heart broke for her all the same. living in an extremely conservative country with an extremely poor healthcare system is a nightmare especially for people like Sunshine. where the only choices are to carry on with the pregnancy or risk going through an unsafe abortion - she will get judged either way.another thing that i liked was the kid's character. she can be interpreted in many ways - some say she is Sunshine's what if but i interpreted her as Sunshine's conscience. in the early parts of the movie, she was discouraging Sunshine from going through with her plan but eventually came at peace with Sunshine's decisions by the end of the movie. for me, she was also a manifestation of Catholic guilt - something that most of us carry since we grew up in a religious country. the things she says to Sunshine is exactly the kind of thoughts you would think of when deciding on something that is against the principles you grew up with.surely, this movie will become something that starts a discussion on the sensitive topics it tackled - para sa mga taong nagdadawang-isip pa sa pagiging pro-choice, sa mga taong sinsubukang intindihin yung mga pro-choice, at para sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine.i just hope that people with more conservative views can watch this para naman maintindihan nila yung point ng mga nasa kabilang side ng diskursong ito.

“Saan ka pupunta?”—Di ko alam.“Mahirap ’yan. Tumatakbo at hindi alam kung saan ang pupuntahan.”These words pierce through the screen because they echo the confusion and helplessness felt by so many young women who were never taught what to do, only what not to become.The film refuses to sensationalize and instead, it exposes how a girl’s so-called mistake (often rooted not in her choices but in a partner’s negligence or acts of abuse) can lead to an avalanche of lost dreams, happiness, and possibility. Sunshine becomes every girl who was failed by sex education, every young woman silenced by stigma, and every teenager blamed instead of held.Running beneath the narrative is a critique of the Philippine healthcare system. Sunshine does not receive proper maternal support. She is not offered structured care, options, or safe counseling. Instead, she moves through her pregnancy in silence guided only by whispered advice, black market pills, and the cold gaze of people. Clinics do not offer refuge, hospitals feel clinical in the worst way. Rushed. Underfunded. Emotionally vacant. Healthcare here is not healing but a trauma repackaged as procedure.What I find striking is how the film threads the idea of stigma into the structure itself. It’s the system. How fear, silence, and judgment strip away any chance for recovery, much less dignity. And this is where Sunshine dares to challenge its viewers. The existence of this movie forces a confrontation. Sunshine doesn’t preach, but it demands to be seen. It tells the story of a girl who chose herself. In a world that expected her to stop, she kept going, and that choice changed everything.“Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?”—Gets ko na.

“Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?”That's how she basically ended that chapter. She’s aware sa ginawa niya, hindi niya kailangan pagsabihan pa siya na yung mga ginawa niya was wrong, illegal, or malaking kasalanan etc. And she doesn’t even deny that in the film. There were enough reasons laid out throughout the film validates her choice, and you see the life that she leads. The hallucination of her own child is her own manifestation of the guilt that haunts her — which tells you she still has hesitations and ramdam niya yung kahihiyan ng mga desisyon niya. You can mourn all you want about the potential of these unborn fetuses that “could’ve” changed our world. Pero paano naman yung mga Sunshine na buhay at may pangarap? What if they’re the ones capable of changing the world? May mga pangarap naman din sila diba?Not everyone may agree with her decision — but that doesn’t mean she doesn’t deserve to reach those dreams.

I'm never too late to watch a great film, and Sunshine is exactly that. The storyline is easy to follow, but what truly captured me from the beginning was the character of Sunshine, played by Maris. She brings a natural charm that immediately connects with the audience, and I was genuinely impressed by the depth and nuance of her performance.What makes Sunshine even compelling is its brave exploration of abortion, a topic that’s still heavily stigmatized in the Philippines. The script tackles a lot of issues that share deep commentary about our social reality. It's a social realism film with metaphysical personification of guilt and morality as I would call it. No matter what your political stance is, you can't deny how the script threaded with care and empathy towards women and women's health.I'm glad they went for an ambiguous ending because if not, it would've been too preachy and they would alienate or estrange a large group of people, but instead its rhetoric opened up an important topic to debate on. I actually agree that it's one of the most important Filipino films of modern times and it's Jadaone's strongest work yet.

Para sa isang lipunan kung saan nalilimitihan pa rin ang karapatan ng kababaihan, dadako at dadako ang mga ito sa 'illegal' na paraan para mabawasan ang pasan. How couldnt they?Sa loob ng pelikulang 'Sunshine,' binubuksan nito ang mahirap at hindi napaguusapang diskurso ukol sa karapatan ng kababaihan ayon sa kanilang katawan, aborsyon, guilt, morals, pati na rin ang Sexual abuse/harassment partikular sa mga kabataan o menor de edad. At sa kabilang banda naman, napoportray dito yung bond na nabubuo ng mga kababaihan sa loob ng pyudal na lipunan. Ilang beses akong naiyak habang nanonood, especially nung scene na ni Maris na nagtake siya ng pampalaglag. Ang bigat panoorin nito actually, kasi what do you mean na para mabawi ko yung buhay na mayroon ako before, kailangan kong pumunta ng Quiapo para bumili ng pampalaglag at pagdaanan yung sakit para lang duguin ako ulit? Sunod pa ay yung dinala si Rhed sa hospital dahil binuntis siya ng tito niya. 13 lang siya. Ang mga ganitong klaseng halimbawa ay pinapakita kung gaano ka-devastating yung fact na walang tulong ang narereceive ng mga kababaihan with this kind of situation. Meron naman siguro, pero mahirap at hindi lahat ay may kakayahang makakuha nitong "tulong" na ito dahil halos lahat ay kailangan ng pera.Nakaka-mind fuck yung situation ni Rhed (kahit short amount of time lang sha ron s film) kasi sa lipunan natin ngayon, ang daming batang babae ang nabubuntis, at bawat taon, pababa nang pababa ang edad ng mga ito. Ngunit, sino ba ang bumubuntis sakanila?Ang abortion ay hindi isang paraan upang mag-promote ng sarap sa sex sa mga kabataan;And with films like this, maganda yung na-aacknowledge na may ganitong klaseng pangyayari sa lipunan. Pero kagaya ng iba pang pelikula that tackles issues like this ay tulad ng 'Uninvited,' bakit hanggang acknowledge lang?Sa role ni Maris bilang Sunshine, pinapakita nito ang journey niya sa loob ng mundong nangguguiltrip and self-devoted Christians, matatanda, etc etc (at napepersonify itong guilt na to through the character of Bata (played by annika)), nakita niya na may mga batang nabubuntis, nakita niya na may judgement agad yung mga tao sa tulad niya, nakita niya na hindi madaling nakakatanggap at nakakahingi ng tulong yung mga nasa sitwasyon niya—pero even after all these, walang self-reflection or closure yung film or yung character ni Sunshine mismo (since first-hand niyang nawitness and naexperience lahat) sa lahat ng issue na naipakita. Parang "bahala ka na kung ano gusto mo isipin, basta eto yung pinapakita namin." Solid 6-7/10.

It's a rather decent take on the current status of the Philippine status quo on women's health and the healthcare system in general. Rather a hit and miss for me with the kids being a figure of speech so to speak and that the little kid's dream is also Sunshine's dream being the same but should have been clear that both won't be able to meet as per the dialogues. Story-wise, everything somehow fell into place in such a way that all the things that could have been possible in terms of occurrences akin to a deus ex machina of sorts, giving the sense that everything was too good to be true - still, point stands; it's a great film to talk about and amazingly delivers points that we should discuss more of a society, especially when it concerns the lives of women, children, and the difficulties of being a woman in a third world country.<<Objectively, story continuity could have been better which could have convinced me of giving it a higher score.>>

Sunshine is a bold and compelling story about when passion collides with unforeseen circumstances. Delivering a powerful performance, Maris Racal gives light to Sunshine, a bright and hopeful teen gymnast whose Olympic dreams come crashing down after an unplanned pregnancy. While the film is beautiful aesthetically, it’s also dark and grim as it not only deals with a controversial subject matter, but is also an accurate reflection of Philippine culture and society.I love stories that involve moral dillemas — stories that make the character choose between two conflicting moral values. This is the case for Sunshine, whose choice is either to abort her baby to reach her Olympic dream, a goal she’s dreamt of in years; or keep the baby as this is deemed the morally right thing to do. Set in the Philippine context, one of the most religious countries in the world, that is one of the hardest dilemmas to have, and I thought the film gave justice to what Maris’ character had to go through.Maris deserves her props for this as well. She was an acting powerhouse, delivering and making the audience feel everything she was going through right out of the screen. It seemed like she trained legitimately for all the stunts, too. All these efforts made the film much more impactful and grounded.Visually, this is what I imagined the City of Manila is like on film. The city, while beautiful to look at, lying beneath it feels like a sense of grime and moral corruption, which blended well with the film’s theme.But aside from a couple of narrative choices made, I really liked this film. Sunshine, while beautiful, is also a haunting reminder of the everyday struggle of the common Filipino. A Filipino who has goals and dreams but is blindsided by forces beyond their control but chooses to push through. It’s an empowering film that I think will leave its mark for years to come.

Every choice in cinematography, production, writing, etc. feels all so delicately planned together to build itself into a single cohesive message on the state of reproductive health in the Philippines. Even just the choice of Sunshine being a gymnast- a sport that is known to affect women's menstrual cycles, which explains why Sunshine didn't consider pregnancy in the first place- proves the care and attention direk Tonet placed on every aspect of the film.The ending however, did leave me to wish more in terms of understanding the aftermath of Sunshine's abortion. Filipino society's marites culture and religious evangelism no less is bound to have an effect on Sunshine's life and that was something I wished to see her persevere through post-abortion...but I do also respect the need to end Sunshine's story on a more hopeful note, as that message of sheer hope and optimism is probably more important than portraying an already familiar reality.

Gets ko na. Ang galing galing magsulat ni Antoinette Jadaone. Naalala ko ‘yung “Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable.” I was so disturbed by the reality faced by women. Maraming Sunshine at maraming Menggay sa mundo, hanga ako na isinulat ito ni Jadaone para masampal sa masa ang mga nararanasan nila. Mahirap maging babae, paano pa kaya kapag naging nanay pa? Mabuti at firm si Sunshine na ayaw niya talaga maging ina because I was rooting for her…

For Every Woman (Para sa bawat Babae) It’s hard to fully grasp what women go through in our society, what more if you’re living in a country like the Philippines, where there aren’t enough laws to protect women’s rights. This movie is a wake-up call, an eye-opener, a voice for the voiceless women. It sheds light on major issues we often sweep under the rug like, sexual assault, teenage pregnancy, public healthcare, poverty, child abuse, and most especially, abortion. These are real, painful realities in the Philippines and we need to talk about them. We need tangible solutions. We need action from our government.As for the cast, whoever handled the casting, hats off. Every single actor in this film delivered. No weak links. Maris Racal completely embodied Sunshine. It wasn’t Maris I saw on screen, it was Sunshine. I know she’s getting a lot of praise for her impeccable, flawless acting here, and she absolutely deserves it.But let me also talk about Annika Co and Jennica Garcia. Annika was incredible in this film. From funny to irritating to heartbreaking, she nailed every single scene. She held her own alongside veteran actors, and that’s not easy dude. And Jennica Garcia? Her eyes, that “mata-mata acting” . In one confrontation scene where she barely had lines, her eyes told the whole story, you could feel out of the screen that she’d do anything for Sunshine. She’s the older sister we all deserve.And the rest of the cast, Elijah Canlas, Xyriel Manabat, Meryll Soriano, Ar-Yuh-Nuh (JM), Rhed Bustamante and the others...damn, perfection! They ate and left no crumbs, mothered!!!This film serves rawness. It’s honest (the Quiapo, to searching from Reddit, X, FB) . It almost feels like a documentary film type. From the gritty shots of Manila’s streets to the realness of the lines, these are the same things we hear in actual situations like this. The script cuts deep. The weight of each line… it’s crushing, full of heavy emotions. Major kudos to Direk Antoinette Jadaone for creating films that reflect the harsh realities of life in the Philippines, especially the realities that women face, the never-ending battle against a society that dictates what a woman should do with her body, the shame, the guilt, and the silence they’re forced to carry. I hope more films like this are made, films like Pamilya Ordinaryo, Birdshot, and now, this. This film deserves AWARDS. I’m also amazed by the cinematography, the color grading, the symbolism of the two children, the sound (especially the NATSOT from Manila, ang lala beh, it really adds so much depth to every scene). This movie will make you laugh, cry, and feel pain. But above all, it stirs the mind and hits the heart, also it carries a message that matters. Message that needs to be heard, seen, and acted upon.The story arc is solidddd. The ending? Not abrupt, not lacking, it was just right. Perfectly right! To every Sunshine out there “gets na namin kayo.” Compassion shouldn’t depend on religion, gender, or social status. These aren’t just stories. This is real life. And we need bold, brave storytellers to bring these realities to light. Highly recommended. Another title could be "HALA PASALAMAT KA"

Sunshine tells a simple yet powerful story of women’s struggles—navigating sexual abuse, the lack of knowledge and guidance around relationships, and the absence of accessible, safe medical resources. What makes the film striking is its subtle handling of sensitive issues. Rather than aggressively challenging religious beliefs about life and birth, it approaches them with quiet respect and nuance. One of the most impactful aspects of the film is how it portrays the internal conflict of Sunshine, the mother. Instead of…

first of all, maris racal ate. you could never make me hate her, ever. she brings so much nuance and truth to this role. one of the most compelling actresses of this generation, hands down. you just feel everything she feels, no effort.also, annicka’s performance really surprised me. the contrast from her mini miss u days to this role? ang layo. she fully disappeared into the character (literally). and jennica garcia, wow. her portrayal of the older sister felt so grounded and real, like someone you actually know. there’s comfort in the way she carries herself. gusto mo na lang yakapin ka niya at sabihan ka ng, “kaya mo ‘yan.”there’s something about the way the film is made that feels like a quiet throwback. may brocka feels pero hindi pilit. very grounded in truth. the quiapo scene especially hit hard. ganun talaga ang sitwasyon dun. like direk tonet said, quiapo is one big irony. magsisimba ka with so much faith, then paglabas mo, you’re faced with desperation and survival. it's painful how real that is.the film doesn't try to be loud, and i think that’s what makes it more powerful. it reflects the harshness of our society, especially for women who are constantly judged for the choices they make. sunshine isn’t just timely, it’s necessary.in a country that prides itself in morality but refuses to give women full control over their own bodies, this film hits different. it makes you ask, sino ba talaga ang may karapatang pumili?sunshine is not just a character. she’s a reality too many are still afraid to look at. and this time, gets ko na.

ang tapang. mahal ko na walang pagdududa kay sunshine. sa oras na nalaman niyang buntis sya, alam nya na ang gusto nyang gawin. hindi sya nagdalawang isip kung dapat o hindi niya ba dapat gawin. buo ang desisyon nya. hindi siya nahihiya. ayaw nya maging nanay.nililihis nito ang conflict ng pelikula. hindi si sunshine ang problema. ang problema ay ang kawalan ng karapatan nya sa pagpili, kawalan nya ng ahensya sa sariling katawan. dahil sa gobyernong hindi kayang tugunan ang karapatan ng mga kababaihan, sa relihiyong dumidikta sa pasya ng mga tagasunod, at sa lipunang mapanghusga.mahal ko ang kababaihan ng pelikula. si sunshine, si mary grace, si geleen, si coach eden, si thea, si dra. helena, si manang na nangtitinda ng pamparegla sa quiapo, si ateng receptionist sa motel. malayo-layo pa para sabihing nakuha ng mga lalaki (miggy at bobot) ang parusang karapat-dapat sa kanila, pero pipiliin kong isipin na kumatok din iyon sa pintuan nila.mahal ko ang bata at si ariana. mahal kong "nabuhay" sila mula kay sunshine at mary grace. mahal kong nabuhay sina sunshine at mary grace mula sa kanila.mahal ko rin si direk tonet. thank you papa god, at may direk tonet jadaone.

this film had me holding back tears on the jeepney ride home.direk tonet’s vision and storytelling are so brave and well-crafted – and maris brought it all to life. “Babae siya, hindi bayani. At hindi niya kailangang maging isa para maging totoo.”Sunshine is not here to baby you. It assumes you can handle the discomfort—because you should. Quiet, raw, and unapologetic. Hindi ito comfort film. Hindi rin ito film na may malinis na aral sa dulo. Sa halip, isa itong tahimik pero galit na sigaw sa bansang patuloy na tinuturing ang kababaihan bilang incubator, atleta, o anak—pero hindi bilang ganap na tao. It’s not even a loud film. Antoinette didn’t spoon-feed, and that’s exactly why it hurts.She frames Maris not as a victim, but as a girl with agency. Sa kamay ng ibang director, baka naging sermon to. Pero sakanya, naging tanong. At ang sagot: hindi mo kailangan sumagot.PS:This film turned into a full-blown debate night with my boyfriend. Loved it! Solid talk! Ang dami namin insights. Lol

You know, I was a child of unwanted pregnancy too. So are my siblings. Like Sunshine, my mom had dreams. Like Sunshine, my mom was striving for better living. Like Miggy, my father was the more financially capable. Like Miggy, my father was useless about it [pregnancy]. Though, my mother couldn't do anything. She still had me— and my ate; and my younger 2 siblings. I wish she had a choice, or even knew that there are options more than just acceptance. Maybe, she could have lived her dreams. It hurts me that I lived on and carried on in my father's care (and even my dad lived unbothered); meanwhile, my mother still suffers in poverty. She is always dead worried about us, and about how she can even carry herself at the age of 40.I hope this film helps people realize Sunshine humanizes all Filipino women who endure such a heavy living— heavy dreams, heavy hearts, and heavy standards. I hope Sunshine becomes the gateway to opening discussions which let women choose and live, especially against how we had been dictated. I hope every Sunshine is given their flowers, and given the warmest hugs. Sunshine, oh Sunshine.

Ang tapang mo Direk Antoinette!! Hard topic to tackle but I LOVE how the reality and rawness of it was portrayed in the movie. Being a woman in a culture shaped by Catholic values often means silencing your own needs to conform and that reality was portrayed so powerfully. But what I loved most is how the story pushes back against that. I loved how Sunshine embraced her truth and only her unique relationship with God. ANG TAPANG MO, SUNSHINE! "Drown out the noise!"I watched this film just hours before I turned twenty (teenage graduate). After a year of waiting for it to be released here in the Philippines, I can say—it was absolutely worth it.What makes it so powerful is its courage to open the conversation about abortion and reproductive health in a deeply religious country like ours. It doesn't hold back. As a society, we need to be more open to the realities women face, and ask ourselves what we can do collectively, especially what the government can and should do. "Mahirap maging babae, lalo na dito sa Pinas".The film is raw and relevant. Sunshine is real. Her character struck a chord, and I saw glimpses of my past classmates and friends in the struggles of Maris Racal and Rhed Bustamante’s roles. The film tackles poor awareness and lack of access to health facilities, while also confronting religious beliefs and cultural norms head-on.It really centers on abortion—not to promote it, but to open the conversation, especially for conservative audiences. It is still a taboo and personally, I hold a progressive stand on abortion, and seeing it presented this way felt affirming.I also loved the use of symbolism—from the “Gift of God” jeepney that Sunshine rides on her way to Quiapo, to her choosing not to enter the church even while seeking God’s guidance. Those subtle moments say so much.I admire how it ends with the strong message that women own their bodies and have the right to choose and decide—whether or not it goes against religious or cultural expectations.This film is more than a story, it’s a tool. A voice. A reflection of many who share the same experiences as Sunshine. And I truly hope the government will soon shed light on this issue and give women access to safe and free abortion procedures.

This is the reality, our painful reality—honest, hindi pretentious, totoong totoo lang. Sa buong cast and production, salamat sa tapang at commitment sa kuwento ni Sunshine.Salamat sa husay. Salamat sa pagiging totoo.

First time ko bumili ng movie ticket na mag-isa akong manonood. I’m glad this was the film I chose to watch for that kind of first time because this film felt like a personal conversation.Alam ng mga taong close sa akin how I dislike children, at kung paanong ayoko mag-anak. It’s not that I hate children; it’s just that what I see in them are the responsibilities and the lifetime commitment. I see them more as a burden than a blessing. I can’t be a parent with that kind of perspective—at least, not now or in the near future. My greatest fear has always been unexpected pregnancy and this film materialized the why behind that fear. I bawled my eyes out in a lot of scenes because this film felt validating and liberating. It made me feel seen and understood as a woman. Paglabas ko ng sinehan, kahit mugto mga mata ko, I felt free. Ang gaan-gaan ng loob ko. Siguro dahil sa thought na finally someone putted it out there. Sobrang husay ni Maris; she represented and embodied the struggles of a woman through her character, Sunshine. And to Direk Tonet, thank you for sparking conversations about this. It was bold and powerful. You will always have my respect and admiration.
Thank you, Papa God

i’ll try and process the movie first for a full review pero god. so effective. so moving. i haven’t been this deeply affected and moved by a movie in a while.OKAY PROCESSED, and my dad says it best: they [the direction and the story] make a lot of good choices. as a woman i can’t help but agree with him: direk jadaone takes up all the right angles and approaches in making a film about abortion and safe sex, and when i say right i don’t just mean morally, i also mean rhetorically or symbolically. it’s more pro-life than pro-lifers, in that through the little girl’s presence and role in the movie, it emphasizes that life is more than just birth: it is care, and that care lies in the emotional or mental capacity to do so. i take off a half-star because i feel there could be only a bit more scenes bringing home that point, but in any case the film is deeply moving — and deeply caring for the filipino woman. i love this film to death.

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is an absolute cinematic gut-punch. Sunshine, the titular character played by Maris Racal, is on her way to Olympic glory, her dreams already in the bag. It takes a missed period and a couple of pink lines to veer her off-course. And just like that, she crashes headlong into a society that’s dead set on denying women their bodily autonomy. Racal’s performance is where the film’s soul resides. She embodies Sunshine with a physicality and emotional depth that’s fully felt from start to finish. Her sobs are painful to watch, but she’s given some respite she can hold onto: the comradeship among women. Jennica Garcia’s Geleen, Sunshine’s older sister, is a particular standout.Fittingly, Jadaone is not soft around the edges, and the film is unflinching in its message. Yet Sunshine never feels preachy or didactic. Because, to be fair, there’s really no neat, easy, and one-size-fits-all resolution for women like Sunshine. But ultimately, it does pull back the curtain and invites you into a conversation, rather than passing judgment.

sabi ng coach ni Sunshine, “yung iniisip mo, ilang araw lang yan. weeks, or months. pero ito, ang tagal na nito sayo.” pertaining to her dream of representing her country in the olympics. not knowing na yung problema ni Sunshine will long outlive her dream, and will likely stay with her for the rest of her life. hindi humingi si Sunshine ng opinyon sa mga tao sa paligid niya. bago pa niya sabihin sa iba, alam na niya yung desisyon niya. she didn’t need anyone to ‘talk her out of it’, she only asked for their understanding. yun lang naman talaga hinihiling ng mga babaeng katulad ni Sunshine. hindi naman nila sinasabing gawin mo, gusto lang nilang maintindihan mo kung bakit nila ‘to ginagawa. kasi wala naman silang choice, at hindi sila binibigyan ng choice ng bansang ‘to, at ng mga outdated beliefs nito. nakakalungkot isipin kung ilang babae na ang dumaan sa paghihirap at sakit na pinagdaanan din ni Sunshine dahil lang kinicriminalize ng batas at simbahan ang abortion, kaya ito nagiging unsafe. at mas lalong nakakalungkot isipin kung ilang babae na rin yung nakaranas ng paghihirap na pinagdadaanan ng mga nanay, kahit hindi naman nila ‘to ginusto. ewan wala na ‘ko masabi basta naiyak ako sa kwento ni Sunshine at sobrang nag eempathize ako sakanya kasi nakikita ko sakanya yung kaibigan ko. Sunshine represents all the women who dream big and are unapologetically true to themselves. we need more films like this in ph cinema!!!!!!!

that shot of sunshine and her sister in the taxi? inject that shit in my VEINSthis was so beautifully lit, the night scenes were so captivating. probably my favorite scenes aesthetically because it sets the mood of an isolating society for women but a mix with the light of hope. the addition of the “future” children was pretty clever and adds a witty touch of when people say what if your aborted child becomes this!!! it’s truly a women-centric film that we barely had a few seconds without the titular sunshine. i love the grit mixed with wittiness— which i think are the quintessential qualities of filipino films. maybe im greedy but i wish we could’ve gotten more of how sunshine overcame the pregnancy and not just a “girl who is going to be okay” scene. if they were gonna represent the struggles of women, possibly be the face of a movement, and be “gritty,” they should’ve went all the way. it just felt incomplete and leaves an unsatisfying feeling that we are still stuck (which is true but i wanted more!!).

might just have been the film that took me the longest to process. it’s real, it gets too personal, and it finally acknowledges what most deny kasi nga taboo.gaya nga ng sinasabi ng karamihan, sunshine exists as a mirror. walang paligoy-ligoy, walang unnecessary plots or twists—literal na sinasamahan lang natin ang isang babae na magkusang kumapit sa patalim, sa kamatayan para lang matupad ang kanyang pinapangarap.mahirap siyang i-digest in a sense that kahit alam naman na natin kung ano mga mangyayari, hinding-hindi tayo magiging si sunshine. seeing her go through hell (that is this god-forsaken country), you could never really know gaano kabigat ang dinadala niya.compassion lang talaga para sa mga tulad ni sunshine. 2025 na, dapat batid natin we are sexual people, we make stupid decisions, and things such as this do happen. punyeta naman oh, walang taong perfect!! ang dali lang manghusga pero sana naman maisip din natin ang kakulangan ng sistema at lipunan. bakit hinayaan itong mangyari? at kung nangyati na, bakit parang naging kasalanan pa ang tumulong?nawa’y magets ng lahat si sunshine dahil hindi naman siya complicated in the first place. ginagawa lang nating komplikado dahil namulat tayo sa mundong ito condemned to discuss and be educated in such topics. tamang pag-intindi lang talaga kasi dapat may choice, hindi lahat kaya at dapat maging nanay. hindi rin natin kailangan i-impose na kesyo nangyari na, yun na dapat. hindi lang tayo pumapatay ng mga pangarap, sumisira tayo ng buhay kapalit lang ng isa. kaya, ang ending? wala ring pagbabago. same shit, same issues dito sa pinas.

No coz wtf is up with it trying to be like Challengers in the exhibition scene?I don’t think it’s worth the hype that it’s getting, but it doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s not a good movie. It doesn’t have a resolution nor does the message really sticks it landing. It is however, simply a story told that is based on the bits and pieces of reality that we can only conceive. It’s a conversation starter, but its certainly does not explore much of the topic that its centered on. So much so that the film doesn’t really let you grow to care about the Protagonist’s support system, thus their presence, their wisdom and their comfort, falls flat in terms of having and relevance to you. There are moments wherein I enjoyed the humor, but you can only do so much with curse words in dialogues that it starts to sound like Daryl Yap’s films, the only difference here is that it handled a topic that’s taboo and has managed to deliver its point across, however at the expense of being safe enough to be told, but less poignant and thought provoking to be considered as something to be discussed in depth. I think it did its job though, to tell a story.

Ang galing ni Maris! She mothered that role. No pun intended.I'm not really fond of Filipino films as they always fail to peek my interest when it comes to filmmaking. However, if the movie talks about social and political issues like it has in SUNSHINE, I can tune and lock in.SUNSHINE is straightforward to its message. It's about dealing with abortion in a country where not only is illegal but also discriminated hardly. A sensitive topic portrayed with a really good script by Jadaone. What a complete package in terms of writing. The story is justified.Even though I may have found the climactic moments not explosive enough, I'm sure the average Filipino conservative does. Personally, I am pro-abortion and I believe women have the rights to their own bodies. I'm glad the movie went in the direction I wanted. As someone who has seen a lot of abortion films in Holywood, this is the first Filipino. And I just applaud everyone in this project for the risk and making a statement through SUNSHINE. For that, it's already a big win for independent Filipino cinema as theaters flock and raise the demand. Because at the end of the day, a movie is not only good if it's good, but also if it sparks conversation. Hundreds of essays and reviews are out there for this film. It makes the whole movie going experience worth it even more.#Sunshine 4/5

Hindi nagmintis ang “Sunshine,” sa direksyon ni Antoinette Jadaone, sa pagsuong sa panganib na kaakibat ng paggiit ng kababaihan sa kanilang autonomiya sa sariling katawan at kalayaan mula sa pananamantala. Batid ng pelikula na ang karapatan sa aborsyon ang tanging daan ng bidang si Sunshine Francisco tungo sa kanyang pangarap na makalundag sa Olympics.Ngunit sa paglalarawan sa paghihirap ni Sunshine bilang isang abstraksiyong siya lamang ang humaharap, naisantabi ang pagkakataong maging paanyaya ang pelikula upang bulatlatin ang panlipunang estruktura sa likod ng kanyang pagdurusa.Hindi rin tuluyang tumagos palabas ng sinehan ang tindig na itinanghal nito para sa kababaihan. Sa kabila ng panawagang boykot bilang pagtutol sa henosidyo ng Israel sa Gaza, lumahok ang pelikula sa Berlin International Film Festival 2025 at indirektang nakisangkot sa panlulupig ng kababaihan kapalit ng Kanluraning balidasyon.Sa tulak ng lokal na suporta, na-extend ang pagpapalabas ng “Sunshine” sa mga sinehan—patunay na posible ang tagumpay ng pelikula nang hindi kinakalakal ang sarili sa mga institusyong may kamay sa karahasan.Basahin ang buong rebyu dito.

[will edit later, for now this is my initial thoughts]Gets kita, Sunshine!Abortion is not just a decision—it's a process. It's never easy. We saw how sunshine depicted guilt, anxiety, and contemplation throughout the film, which mirrors many women's lived experiences. The more we don't talk about this kind of topic and deny women's bodily autonomy, the more women to seek unsafe alternatives—like hilot at pamaparegla sa quiapo—which can lead to death and complications. "Baka next president yang dinadala mo pero ipapalaglag mo lang" pano magiging next president ang isang baby kung yung nanay nya walang mapakain sa kanya at walang pera para mapaaral sya? Pro-life lang kayo kapag nasa tyan ng nanay, pero wala na kayong pake after that. Sunshine is just one of many women who also have a dreams for themselves. If giving birth is for you, good for you and it's a valid choice. But for some, it was never an option because they have big dream to fulfill and personal stories as to why they want to make that decision. I love it when Dir. Toñet Jadaone creates characters who are goal-driven and ambitious— Christine(Alone/Together), Vilma(Beauty in a bottle), and now Sunshine. Throughout the film, it felt like Sunshine already had a decision and she's firm with it. She's going to do it regardless of what will happen. I hope in the future, there will be legal medical practices that provides safe abortions, because there's an urgent need for them.

Mahal kita, Sunshine. I did not stop crying until we arrived home. Bukod sa ang bigat ng pelikula at damang-dama ko ang bawat eksena, I also couldn’t stop thinking about my Sunshine. My Sunshine, a friend, who also had the same experience few months before our college graduation. Para akong ibinalik sa mga oras na iyon. ‘Di ko mapigilang mag-isip kung nagawa ko bang maging katulad ni Geleen. Kung nakapag-offer ba ako ng enough understanding at compassion kagaya ni Geleen. Surface-level lang pala ang alam ko sa struggles niya noon, dahil hanggang doon lang naman ang kaya kong malaman at maintindihan even as a gay guy and a feminist. There is so much more struggles to abortion than just making a decision— it inevitably comes with guilt, shame, and fear to which the film portrayed effectively.One thing is for sure, ang hirap na nga maging babae— mas lalo pa sa Pilipinas. Poverty, bulok na public health system, lack of access to reproductive rights— all were tackled with so much bravery, honesty, and rawness. Ang husay ng lahat ng bumuo ng pelikulang ito, on and off cam. Thank you Direk Jada One at Maris na haggard. Thank you Papa God sa buhay nila eme.Catch the film. Isama niyo ang tito’t tita niyong relihiyoso dahil dalwa lang iyan, either kukumbulsyunin sila sa sama ng loob o magbabago ang pananaw nila. Either way, Thank you Papa God eme. Dahil tama si Jennica sa pagpag episode sa AWKP na minsan iyong panghihimasok ng ibang tao sa ganitong usapin isn’t always coming from a place of concern and genuine care rather from a place of self-righteousness and it’s high time we silence these regressive and harmful voices.Time!

"Gets ko na." It’s so hard being a woman. This film? A masterpiece. It powerfully shows how deeply abortion needs to be addressed in the Philippines. “Mawawalan ako ng lisensya, Miss.” That line hit so hard—because this is real. This happens. And it’s not about protection. It’s about control. Fuck the system. Fuck the doctors who speak so loudly about God but stay silent about compassion.To anyone out there who feels like Sunshine—or has ever felt like her—you’re not alone. “naiintindihan mo na ba ako””gets ko na.”raw, simple, poignant, brave is how i would describe this film. its a film that has something to say and my god they delivered it so well. its direct to the point, its bold, its in your face, it shows you the reality of what the women in this country go through when it comes to reproductive health. nakakaiyak, nakakalungkot isipin na our women has to depend on unsafe abortion just because the men violated their body — mary grace’s tito raped her and miggy not pulling out when he said he will — and just because abortion is illegal.i don’t think my mind has fully processed the film in a way that my thoughts are still all over the place and dont know where to start even if 2 hours has passed since i watched the movie. there are so many key moments in the movie and i want to talk abt it all, but let me stick to at least 3. one, sunshine and geleen’s (jennica) relationship, specifically yung part na tinabihan niya si sunshine sa kama para sabihin na sinusuportahan niya si sunshine sa kung ano mang desisyon niya, CRIED HARDDDD!!! kasi ramdam mo na conflicted siya in terms of abortion pero si sunshine ang priority niya at kung ano magpapasaya at magpapalaya kay sunshine iyon ang lagi niyang pipiliin. im glad that sunshine has an ate like her, i wish i had one too and i’m hoping to be a good of an ate like geleen. two, the whole sequence between mary grace and sunshine, it was sooo heartbreaking and so shattering to think na ito ang reyalidad ng napakaraming kabataan hindi lang sa pilipinas kundi sa buong mundo. our children deserves better. lastly, when sunshine finally perfected her routine, she looks so free, so happy, so contented, you just know she already made her decision. it was such a beautiful scene, its just her and her routine and the kid — her kid — watching her and finally understanding her. sobrang nakakaiyak. “gets ko na” such a simple statement but made me cry so hard wow. gets na gets talaga. great performances all around din talaga especially to maris racal grabe napakagaling, literal na wala talaga ako ibang masabi kundi sobrang sobrang galing wow. jennica garcia na hindi rin talaga maipagkakaila ang galing, ang onti lang ng scenes niya pero lahat may impact. and siyempre who would forget rhed bustamante na napakagaling din. sound design and cinematography are on point din talaga, i especially love those parts when sunshine drowns out the noise. writing this made me realize that the whole film, the ones who made the most impact are women. oh women, i hope one day the world will be kinder to us. i think i have said enought but i really hope that this film would be a way for people to be more open minded when it comes to the discussion of abortion and sana itong pelikulang ito ay maging daan rin para mas lalong maraming pang tao ang sumama sa laban na gawing legal ang safe abortion practices sa bansa. and to direk tonet thank you for sharing us your craft and for meticulously creating this film. you delivered its message very well! kudos to you direk and to everyone involved!

HELL YEAHHHHHHH!!! PEAK PINOY INDIE FILM IS BACK AGAIN! THANK YOU, ANTOINETTE JADAONEP.S. : This fricking movie made me realize that being informed is one thing, but seeing and feeling the experience is another.

Fear and self-interest. The two powerful drives of men according to Napoleon.But Sunshine is a woman— a gymnast, one of the few sports considered most feminine—one of those burning out athletes who lives by flexibility, by bending yourself in all possible corners to become this perfect beautiful being. So yes, maybe she was driven by fear and love for gymnastics, but why not?Her panic walks bending through eskinitas, the close ups on Maris’ expressive eyes unyielding despite the fear, and the overwhelming passionate Filipino noise shiver through the gritty scene of Manila and it feeds us, the audience, a rhythmic choreography of the most tender experience of a woman. Manila succumbs her, a fragile thin young girl on the verge of losing it all. And I fucking loved and consumed it.I love it too much I felt the giddiness through the tips of my fingers when the first scene at Quiapo entered, Sunshine in panic crying inside the jeep, and the first thing I thought was, “putangina si Julio ng Maynila sa Kuko ng Liwanag.”Yes maybe Sunshine enjoyed doing it with Miggy, and maybe seen the near death process of getting rid of it through Mary Grace, felt the catholic guilt, and that maybe her drive to success is to disregard what could be (motherhood) but still, ultimately still, tender is the flesh of a woman who wants to be in life. Like Julio (my shayla), tender is the flesh that holds all possibilities in life. The difference is, the tragedy of Brocka’s Julio is the absence of grounded support systems. Sunshine became her own because of the people and the women in her life who understood and grieved with her.Ito ang kasagutan sa katanungang paano naging kapantay Lino Brocka, Ishmael, Mario O’Hara si Dir. Tonet Jadaone; pusong pilipino ang lente. Sining ang pangangalampag.

hangga't criminalized ang abortion sa pilipinas, patuloy na mapipilitan ang mga babaeng piliin ang delikadong paraan ng pagsasagawa nito. kahit pa labag ito sa batas, mangyayari't mangyayari pa rin. hindi ba ironic na sa quiapo—kung saan mayroong simbahang dinadasalan ng maraming tao, kung saan nakatayo ang isa sa mga institusyong unang nagtatatag ng pag-unawa natin sa aborsyon at iba pang "sensitibong" usapin—doon din makahahanap ng mga pampalaglag? mapalad si sunshine at mary grace dahil mayroong doc helena. ngunit para sa maraming mga babae sa pilipinas, hindi palaging ganoon ang kanilang sinasapit.mahusay ang pagkakasulat sa relasyon ng mga babae sa pelikula—sila ang naging sentro nito para sa akin. mula sa coach na naniwala sa kakayanan ni sunshine sa loob ng siyam na taon, sa ate niyang nangakong lagi niya itong kakampi, kay thea na sinamahan siya sa dulo sa kabila ng fallout nila noong una, si annika na pangarap ang pangarap niya, si mary grace na tinulungan at hindi iniwan ni sunshine hanggang masigurado niyang ligtas ito, si doc helena na nagligtas ng buhay ni mary grace nang walang kapalit at mismong nagsagawa ng aborsyon para kay sunshine, hanggang sa receptionist na agad-agad inalala ang kapakanan niya at siya pang nagbayad ng pamasahe. sa bansa nating karaniwang malupit ang pagturing sa mga kababaihan, maaasahan mong sa huli, babae pa rin ang palaging magiging sandigan ng kapwa niya babae.
