long ass word dump bc wow. it’s been a long time since i’ve felt so much for a film. hindi ko alam paano simulan, pero grabe kabog ng puso ko the entire time.the frustration of knowing that this happens in real life. that every girl, in a sense, was once sunshine. isang batang babaeng puno ng potensyal, mga pangarap, at may mga plano para sa sarili. isang batang babaeng takot na takot at walang magawa kundi tumungo sa online spaces (twitter, reddit, google, tiktok, etc.) para humanap ng paraan para makawala sa sitwasyong hindi niya inakalang mangyayari sakanya; saklap pa na isang lalaking walang kwenta ang naglagay sakanya sa posisyon na iyon.actually, isang buong bansa (with its strictly religious ideals, nonsensical government, and fucked up healthcare system) ang naglagay sakanya sa posisyon na iyon. from the beginning until the end of the movie sobrang emphasized nito. from the small comments (yung pharmacist) to the loud barking of unsolicited remarks (yung doktora na sinabihan pa si sunshine na magpasalamat kay Lord na hindi nalaglag yung bata, grabe rage bait 10000).pero makikita mo parin na grabe talaga ang chokehold ng religion sa ating mga pinoy. the way sunshine’s first instinct was to go to church and pray that it all goes away? prays that He takes the baby? an ironic reality.the film encapsulates manila and its complexities, completely. walang sugarcoat. manila up close? horrid. konti nalang parang maaamoy mo na yung baho sa may avenida at quiapo in the movie… but somehow, antionette jadaone makes it beautiful. the scene of maris contemplating and hesitating inside her room in avenida inn? the darkness that is only lit up by the train rushing by? cinematography at its finest. ultimo yung background noice, to a T. prayers and church bells, clinking bottles, vendors yelling, random cursing— it was so authentic i genuinely felt like i was in manila. the representation of a lot of things in the movie were also beautiful. the “bata” (which i assume is younger sunshine) was my favorite. telling the older sunshine that abortion was wrong at the start, then hugging her at the end whispering “gets ko na.” after the older sunshine performs her piece ??? HEART CRUSHED. TEARS WERE SHED!!!! although may questions ako left unanswered, hindi ako unsatisfied. this film opened my eyes to so much more. i truly loved this film. tangina buong cast walang tapon. ang gagaling. hats off to maris!!!!!! Ang pangarap mo ay ang pangarap ko.Nirerepresenta ng pelikula na ito ang malaking sikreto ng isang babaeng nakaranas ng ganitong sitwasyon. Pinag-usapan sa pelikula na ito ang katahimikan, takot, kasabikan, pagdadalawang-isip, pag-iisa, ang konsensya, ang buhay, ang kamatayan--- isinambit sa pelikula ang hindi maibanggit-banggit ng mga kababaihang nakaranas ng aborsyon, at ngayon sila ay narinig, nagkaroon ng boses at patuloy lang sa pagpapatuloy.Some people don't understand the role of Annika and Aryana(?). Some think it's just a cell (you will forget about it). But for someone who carried it, even for a short time, you know it's there--- the heartbeat, the suffocation. You find yourself dreaming of their face, of their future. But they will never be engraved in your soul. You just know that, for a brief moment, something existed inside you. And still, it doesn’t change your decision--- what you know is the right thing to do for yourself.Mahal na mahal kita, Sunshine at sa lahat ng Sunshine

i absolutely love how nuanced this is. how it took into consideration filipino contexts in discussing such a sensitive topic. i love the cinematography, absolutely stunning. captured the vibe of living in the busy and harmful streets of manila.discussed this with my gf but i find the heavy incorporation of religion in this quite integral to the story. while westerners may be able to discuss about abortion more openly, filipinos whose lives revolve around religion, are not at all the same. we were taught at an early age that religion is the absolute law, and we must follow every rule made in the name of religion. and so, the guilt sunshine carries throughout the film is heavier than ever, because not only was she dealing with the judgment of others, she was also dealing with the judgment of God, “The Father.” And, surprisingly enough, I find the presence of the child important. At first, she bothered me a bit, how she accused shine of being a murderer, stopped shine from her attempts at abortion. She’s the superego, the guilt that follows shine everywhere. But also, she’s a part of sunshine, hence her line “Pangarap ko ang pangarap niya.” (non verbatim) and so, she too, wishes to see sunshine succeed. Her running to sunshine after her final performance and saying “gets ko na” was her way of easing shine’s guilt. After all, as people love to give life to everyone’s unborn child, then I guess this once, I too, shall make use of that. Viewing sunshine’s life through the eyes of her “unborn child” must have been painful, yet every child I know has questioned (at least once) how good of a life their mother would’ve had, had they never been born. And just like every living child, the kid too, understood how much gymnastics meant to shine. And she was willing to trade the loss of her life for sunshine’s happiness, because she will always be a part of sunshine.

late review, but the tears that i have shed were an overwhelming amount — tears for the women who felt so alone, with a cruel world that seems to surround them from all sides, forcing to navigate these hardships on their own while combating bigotry, misogyny, and prejudice in modern society. yung scene kung saan humingi ng tulong si rhed bustamante kay sunshine hanggang sa hospital, iyak ako nang iyak, na parang naghilamos ako. konting-konti lang yung nakakagets pero karamihan hindi, kasi nasa bansa tayo na traditionalist, maka-diyos (thus sunshine’s plea for forgiveness, that familiar catholic guilt), at mapili pa sa morality. kaya kahit anong galaw mo bilang isang babae, feeling mo ang daming mata nakatutok sayo, ang bilis nila manghusga at sila pa yung gumagawa ng mga desisyon mo, binubuo pa yung buhay mo kahit hindi mo pa nga naaabot o nakakabuo ng pangarap mo. mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas, and the film portrays the harsh reality so honestly. “drown out the noise” a line that rises above judgement, criticism, and societal pressure. sana mapaunlad ang sistema natin sa healthcare at para sa kababaihan, at sana mas marami sa atin ang maka-gets.

Sunshine affected me deeply. The film explored women’s autonomy with so much honesty, and the characters’ struggles and victories felt incredibly real. I loved how it showed the layered challenges that come with unwanted pregnancies and the emotional, physical, and social weight women carry. The story treated its themes with grace and intelligence, and I truly believe it deserves a wide audience.One of the most powerful elements came from Sunshine’s relationship with her sister. Watching the difficulty of her sister’s life, especially the reality of raising a child, shaped her own decision. It felt like she saw her future in that picture, a future filled with sacrifices and dreams placed on hold. That glimpse alone said so much about choice, survival, and the pressure placed on women.The film also opened an entire landscape of conversations. Misogyny, women’s choices, abortion, body autonomy, laws, healthcare, and the quiet burdens carried by women in this country. These are everyday truths, yet they rarely reach the screen with this level of sincerity. I crave more stories with this courage, stories that explore mature themes with depth and curiosity. This film touched many important ideas and left me eager for even richer layers. Symbolism filled the entire narrative, and I loved how each detail carried emotional weight. I could spend an entire afternoon unpacking everything.One scene stays with me the most. The motel sequence. The stillness, the rumble of the train, her actions, and the aftermath created a breathtaking moment. That scene captured the danger of doing something unfamiliar to one’s body and the immense pressure created by law and religion. It felt intense, raw, and beautifully crafted.And the presence of the kid as her guilty conscience completed the emotional arc in such a striking way. It felt like a final haunting reminder of everything she carried.

What I love the most of this film is the face-on paradoxes that unfortunately reflects the reality. You see a doctor, who is supposed to save lives regardless, ignore a teenager because she took pills. You see the main character fully knowing the consequences of her actions but most people around her thinks she should do this or that. And you see pro-life always insisting that the aborted children could be someone great, but never giving a glance to those…

this is a film that shows several harsh realities that many young women face every day. it tackles sensitive yet crucial issues such as unplanned pregnancy, illegal abortion, sexual assault committed by a family member, the heavy influence of religion on decision-making, and how one snap can completely shatter a young person’s future. these themes are not exaggerated; they are painful and real. “Mahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas.”the film drop a reality line about women especially here in the philippines. this resonates the lived experiences of countless young women who grew up navigating a society that often blames them first before offering help.the movie also embodied the noises—the noise of judgment from society, the noise of broken dreams, and the noise coming from people who desperately need help but have nowhere to turn. it speaks out that the loudest sound isn’t the chaos of Manila’s streets, but the silent cries of countless helpless women. the film exposes the flaws in our cultural, social, and institutional systems, making it easy to see where we are lacking the most.the scene showing the overcrowded OB department in a public hospital was somehow alarming. it’s chaotic, understaffed, and overcrowded—yet this reflects reality. it reveals how instead of creating long-term solutions, government tend to simply acknowledge the issue or, worse, disregard it. the systems remain weak and unresponsive.beyond all of these social issues, the film also shows how dreams can easily collapse under the weight of societal pressure. this makes the film more than just a film—it becomes a moviefied reflection of the everyday struggles of filipino youth, especially young women who are forced to grow up too fast.overall, the movie sunshine is a wake-up call. it’s a call for empathy, understanding, and meaningful change.

Hindi ako magaling sa pag kritiko ng mga bagay-bagay, lalo na sa mga pelikula. Pero sinusubukan ko. Ang pelikulang "Sunshine" idinirekta ni Antoinette Jadaone sobrang danas at isyu sa bansang Pilipinas. Ang ganda ng set sa manila, ang raw, rinig at ramdam mo ang init, sikip, usok, baho, at gulo. Noong tatapatin pa lang niya yung nakabuntis sa kanya itong salita agad ang pumasok sa isip kong sasabihin ng lalaki e,"Sigurado ka bang sa akin 'yan?" Ito talaga ang una mong maririnig sa isang lalaki kapag sinabi ng isang babae na "buntis ako". Walang hiyang linya 'yan imbes na pagsuporta kay Sunshine pagdududa ang ibibigay para ikaila yung responsibilidad, lalaki nga. hahahahaha, sorry kung may pagka discriminate sa parteng ito pero iyan ang reyalidad. Sunod naman yung batang si Anika, noong una hindi ko gets bakit bigla siyang susulpot at mawawala. Para sa akin para siyang inner child ni Sunshine kung susuriin yung pelikula sa bandang dulo nang tinuloy ni Sunshine na gamitin yung nabiling gamot sa Ale sa quiapo, basta fast-forward sa tricycle, makikita na yung legs ni Anika ay may dugo rin which is sign na ganon ang epekto ng nabili niyang gamot o pag abort, hindi ko ma explain pero gets na yan, at kung paano huminga si Sunshine ganoon din siya noong isinusugod na siya sa hospital. Tapos parang noong una hindi pa gets ni Anika yung mga desisyon ni Sunshine sa kagustuhang magpa abort pero yung sa huli nakita niya kung paano mahal at gusto ni Sunshine yung pangrap niya kaya I love the part na sinabi niya na "gets ko na" ika niya nga. Tapos if you think yung pagintindi ay hindi nanggaling sa iba kundi sa sarili niya diba????? So, ito na nga dahil binanggit ko na ang quiapo, gusto ko rin yung scene na matapos niyang malaman na buntis siya dumiretso agad siya sa simbahan para mag dasal. why? kasi may guilt siya part niya sana gets niyo ako, staka super religious o predominant catholic itong bansa natin, sana gets hahahaha...tapos diba yung binilhan ni Sunshine ng pangpa abort parang katabi o malapit sa simbahan parang na pinipilit ng relihiyon at batas ang mga babae sa isang krisis, ngunit ang parehong lugar din ang kanilang takbuhan para maghanap ng bawal na solusyon. Sobrang konserbatibong bansa. At sunod ulit yung pag bili niya ng illegal na pangpa abort, no choice e, walang health care sa mga katulad niyang may ganoong problem. diba? ang lala ng sistema, walang program na pwedeng lapitan right away. Kasi ano ang unang nangyayari o ginagawa ng mga tao pag ang isang babae ay buntis, ang gagawin ng ibang tao manghusga ngunit hindi naman handang magbigay ng practical na tulong. Kaya ang katuwang lang ng babae ay sino? Sarili, dignidad, at pangrap. Kaya, gets ko si Sunshine sa mga desisyon niya, it's a relief for her kung gagawin niya yung illegal. At huli, sobrang galing ni Maris Racal, hanga ako, dalang-dala niya talaga yung bigat ng karakter. Mata-mata acting at yung pag perform niya galing. Huli na talaga, gustong-gusto ko ang mura ng batang si Anika, galing! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

The performances of the entire cast is truly memorable and that scene from Maris and Jennica will be an important one that would heal so many hearts. gets na gets kita, sunshine. this film shows how every women struggles due to pregnancy; and how abortion is only the solution they'd think of— to save their dream, for them to have a better future for themselves.i'm just so amazed how every scene on this movie portrays how filipinos act towards women who gets pregnant at the very young age— and how religious people have always something to say on that. putangina rin kasi napakita rito kung paano na 'yong lalaki, kayang makatakas sa responsibilidad pero 'yong babae, buhat-buhat lahat ng bigat at problema na mayroon sa mundo. it's just so frustrating yet painful to watch, and i despise that this scenario can happen to everyone in real life.if a woman doesn't want a child, then so be it.

Sunshine itu film yang keliatannya lembut, tapi makin lama ditonton makin kerasa nyentil. Ceritanya ngikutin seorang remaja yang harus menghadapi tekanan dari lingkungan, keluarga, sampai norma sosial yang bikin hidupnya seolah bukan miliknya sendiri. Film ini juga pake simbol dan momen hening buat nunjukkin betapa sempitnya ruang gerak yang dia punya.Yang aku suka, filmnya nggak pernah maksa penonton buat mikir searah. Banyak hal dibiarkan ambigu, tapi justru itu yang bikin interpretasinya hidup. Kita diajak ngikutin proses dia ngambil kembali kendali atas tubuh dan masa depannya, pelan-pelan, tanpa drama berlebihan. Aku merasa ada satu titik di mana semuanya terasa klik. Bukan karena dijelasin, tapi karena apa ya bisa pahamlah gitu dari caranya bersikap dan bertindak.Akhirnya juga bukan yang gimana-gimana, tapi ya kerasa personal dan melegakan. Intinya sih, ini sebuah film tentang betapa susahnya perempuan punya pilihan di tempat yang konservatif, dan gimana tetap bisa berdiri di atas kaki sendiri meski nggak ada yang dukung.

Where do I even begin? It’s heart wrecking to realise that still there’s a country with total ban on “Abortion” irrespective of the way got the girl pregnant (even rape) or the condition of the pregnant woman.It’s cruelty!Scenes were so raw depicting the hard to digest reality. Unimaginable curse of being a child bearing gender in this stupid stupid world. How much inequality have we imposed on them in different ways and names.Where she just keeps hitting her stomach with bare hand hoping it’d kill the baby or the approach of bringing in surrealism (or mythology) to show the unborn kids’ connection and interactions with their yet to give birth Mom had made it much more harder for us to come over it. Hypothetically speaking, “If I ever get a girl child I’d call her Sunshine” Coming from rural India, I guess without much realisation I had recently developed a more liking towards Asian cinemas. It makes me feel more connected and more personal. Not just with the main characters but each and every moving and non-moving, told and untold, shown and hidden subjects in every single frame.
slayyy

What is worse than living in a country that has outdated laws/systems/infrastructure? Having no one to share your suffering with.Sunshine only gained clarity when she felt supported by her older sister - that at the end of the day, she gets to have control and the final say to whatever her decision is. Giving agency to the people whose decisions will only affect them anyway sounds so simple since you can apply it to almost anything, but once abortion is mentioned, suddenly some people want to control the decisions of other people.Religion is obviously at the forefront of this topic. People forget that their religion is based on faith, not objective truth. It is still crazy to me that we live in an age where you could educate yourself, yet some of us still blindly choose to follow a random book that was written by a random person thousands of years ago.Kudos to Jadaone and team for making this important and (unfortunately) still relevant film.

All I can say is that this film is undeniably brave—brave enough to tackle a timely and controversial issue within a country shaped by religious beliefs, societal judgment, and limited access to healthcare. For Sunshine, the act of making a decision carries extraordinary weight, as she becomes fully aware of the consequences that she will have to faceI appreciate that the filmmakers not only showed how Sunshine arrived at her decision, but also place emphasis on why she makes it. The narrative thoughtfully explores the influences, pressures, and circumstances that frame her choices, allowing the audience to understand her on a deeper level.The film effectively captures the bleak realities and unfiltered rawness of Manila, which it is easy for me to say “gets ko na”—to agree with certain moments and empathize with Sunshine’s actions, precisely because the film enables us to feel the gravity of her experiences.This work is a feat for Filipino cinema. I hope more Filipino filmmakers continue to produce films that spark meaningful conversation and illuminate social realities capable of influencing society. Kudos to the cast, director, producers, and entire crew for this compelling piece of storytelling.

The cinematography, the composition, the colours, and the character were all absolutely stunning. This was obviously handled with so much care and love, as it should be, you can tell that the director has a clear vision of exactly what she wants the film to feel and look like which was executed flawlessly. I will never know what it’s like to be a woman with child but this film made me feel all the conflicted, complicated, and crushing emotions of what it’s like to make that oh so difficult decision. Yes it’s incredibly sad yet she has to make the choice that’s best for her even though it literally breaks every inch of her soul. It accurately portrays Filipino society’s perception around abortion and how religion and gender roles play an integral part in the whole ordeal when it absolutely should not. It should be between the woman and her doctor alone, the outsiders opinion only makes this life altering decision so much harder than it already is. It’s so wonderfully nuanced and so so beautiful, thank you for keeping Filipino cinema alive Sunshine. I also loved that her kid had a rainbow shirt on which comes after a sunshine.

Hindi lang tungkol sa kung ano ang pinipili mo, kundi kung bakit mo kailangang pumili.The film reminds us that while we argue about what's right and wrong, may mga taong bitbit ang bigat ng mundong hindi natin kailanman mararamdaman. And those people have to make decisions that sometimes are not acceptable to norms or beliefs. But Maris Racal delivers a story of a girl na hindi humihingi ng sympathy kundi karapatan. Karapatan na mamili. Karapatan na magpatuloy. Karapatan na mangarap. For me, it's not just a simple talk tungkol sa abortion; it’s about access, fairness, and acknowledging na hindi tayo pare-pareho ng laban.We don’t have to personally want what Sunshine wants. Pero we must understand why she has to fight for it. Kung bakit may mga oportunidad na dapat bukas para sa lahat kahit na hindi natin ito kailangan. Kung hindi mo gets kung bakit may kailangang pumili, maybe you are privileged enough na hindi mo pa kailangan mamili.And that’s exactly why we must always choose compassion.

“Pangarap ko din mga pangarap mo, Sunshine”This movie was so beautifully written, directed and acted. Grabe, hands down kay maris kasi ramdam na ramdam mo yung emosyon niya and struggle throughout the whole movie. This literally depicts women around the philippines—-no matter what economic class they may be— when it comes to teenage pregnancy. Whether or not we care to admit it, no teenage pregnancy is planned and the toll that has on a developing woman will never ever ne experienced by ANY man. So miggy, pakyu.Pero grabe, you can feel the internal battle Sunshine was going through and I think that every single woman who has a dream, a goal in life perhaps, if situated the same, would go through the same lengths. Maybe not through all of that extent, but this is such an eye opening movie to those who still feel like abortion in the philippines is taboo. You would literally rather have all these women dying instead of getting and giving them the right medical treatment? These are children, btw. Yes, they did adult things but bear in mind that there is no such thing as a consenting child in the eyes of the law.Oh Antoinette Jadona, the woman that you are. Thanks for showing us a movie that says na we can choose ourselves. We can decide our future and no amount of guilt trip—whether it be from the church or from any ball-lacking man—can stop us from persuing that.

It’s always “labag yan sa batas ng Diyos” but never “naiintindihan mo ba ako?” This film carefully define failures of this country. Ang ironic lang for me na kalat sa labas ng Quiapo ang bentahan ng mga gamot pampalaglag, habang ang sistema natin ay patuloy na tutol sa ganitong paraan. Goosebumps when my friends and I noticed the sign sa jeep saying “Gift of God”, we came up with only one assumption of what that sign is trying to tell the viewers. Simply, babies are a blessing. And that’s what they’ll always say whenever abortion comes up in a conversation.The symbolism of the Kid who has been following Sunshine all throughout the film. My first assumption was— she was the conscience of the latter. Obviously, lumalabas siya every time na may gagawin si Sunshine sa pagbubuntis niya. Siya ang constant reminder na lahat nang gagawin niya ay mali. Second, it was Sunshine’s younger version. Trying to tell her something. Pero bandang dulo ng film it was revealed na it was the baby. I would like to believe na malaki ang naging parte niya sa naging desisyon ni Sunshine. Because Sunshine was the happiest when she’s doing what she love. Walang karapatan ang kahit sino man sa magiging desisyon ng babae para sa katawan niya.Super dami kong pang gustong sabihin sa film na ‘to kasi super pleased ako sa mga details and symbolisms. Right, decision din to watch it with my friends hahaha. Ayun lang! Maris Racal is a really really remarkable artist. And also, Direk Antoinette Jadaone always timely and relevant ng mga films. Super galing!

wow, maris… kakaiba ka. read smth on twitter that said, maris may have her faults but you can’t deny that she is a really great actress… And i agree wholeheartedly. i watched this with my dad, not knowing what the plot is (i was never spoiled either). kala ko tungkol sa gymnastics lang pero ito ung mga topic na hindi talaga pinag-uusapan, lalong-lalo na sa pamilya. i’m glad that he got to see women’s pov when it comes to these topics cos where else would he ever hear about them? this is what the purpose of movies are. ung talagang gagawa ka ng plataporma para sa lahat ng manonood na makita ung pananaw ng mga tao sa lipunan, lalong-lalo na ung mga hindi naman talaga pinakikinggan at pinaniniwalaan. nakita ko rin ung kahit na kala ng mga tao wala lang ung mga nagtitinda sa gilid, pero isang malaking tulong na un sa iba. sobrang ganda ng pagkakagawa ng pelikulang ito. ganda ng cinematography, screenplay, tsaka ng mismong kuwento. talagang hindi kulang eh. walang kulang, walang sobra. direct to the point. hindi ko alam ano pa hindi maiintindihan ng ibang tao rito. empathy talaga kailangan natin sa mundong ‘to.

i have so many thoughts about this movie so i might just make edits. also i only got to watch it now kasi kakarelease lang sa netflix first i just wanted to applaud the use of background noises. i think im so used to movies relying on ‘noise cancellation’ that the background sounds were so instantly noticeable for me, and i understood it as something integral to the plot na ‘sunshine’s story is just one sound among many’, and thinking about how noisy these public spaces are (quiapo, avenida) parang ang liit tignan ng buhay ni sunshine tuloy. and it’s so real that society tends to overlook the lives of these women where they’re commonly diminished into statistics or cautionary talesi can even argue that in some instances, like sunshine praying outside the quiapo church or secretly talking to the pamparegla seller, is a ‘background noise’ in itself. naingayan ako sa mga scenes na yun to the point where the dialogue was just blending with the background noise. it really says a lot about how these stories are just among us, and it’s so devastating to think that something as serious as this matter (something hindering of one’s ambitions and with the capacity of changing the direction of one’s life) blends so well with noise we consider every-day and mundanesecond, this movie really touched my pathos  given my positionality as a woman. the scrolling on reddit, silently looking for online communities or help..ugh i understood the frustration of being a woman in a catholic country so well. i obviously have never been pregnant, but when im at the BIOLOGICAL age for it, ang scary to think na we don’t have that option at all, na our bodily autonomies are immediately disregarded by others just because of personal beliefs. ang daming instances when i was watching na iniisip ko nalang ‘what if that were me?’ SYEMPRE WAG NAMAN SANA PERO that’s the point diba? for the movie to put us in the shoes of sunshine and make us FEEL that we don’t want to be in her shoes. that way we’ll think of challenging the system that we currently have but i really love how despite the circumstances, sunshine was still adamant about being true to her autonomy and GANUN talaga dapat. i heard the ending was supposed to be different, but im so glad they changed it to this

got surpised when the film ended, a “hala tapos na?” na-bitin moment. but maybe it felt that way because there’s no complete ending to the struggle of sunshine. whether she chose herself or her kid, habang buhay niyang dadalhin ito because people will shame her regardless.i hope the world becomes a little bit kinder to women like sunshine.
good intention but extremely bad execution

this wouldve been a 1.5 if it weren’t for the importance of this movie and its effectiveness regardless of cinematic quality. idc if characters make bad/weird decisions, just make it have a glimpse of logical reasoning (which includes logical illogicality) i would support it. an absurd amount of suspension of belief is required for this movie which doesn’t make sense to me in a movie where most of the situations are so grounded in reality anyway. It tries to do too much for its own good. The sequence of events make no sense, relationships with people have no emotional weight aside from Sunshine and her sister, ang gulo. The whole Ariana thing suddenly having a That’s so Raven moment. Giving a stranger you just met 5 minutes ago 1K. Calling your unborn kid with no name “bata”. Wait Sunshine can see others’ unborn children too? Just sloppy rough writing overall. If there rest of the movie were like the last 10 minutes (the confrontation with the dad is the highlight of this movie for me) maybe this would’ve been great!EDIT: okay so nagka That’s so Raven moment sya kasi nafeel nya sa katawan ng nanay nya ok gets ko na

some bits I especially liked: - sunshine praying just outside the church, feeling unworthy to enter for what she's about to do- her sister helping her stretch her shoulders, trying to motivate her by saying "SEA games" "olympics" and so on, accidentally doing what is opposite her intention and instead adding a burden to sunshine's shoulders. - the focus on rape-incest cases. it happens so much in our country but its been kept under wraps for way too long. im glad a film that has gained this much traction helped put it, and the many ways that it's the mothers and maternal figures that facilitate such violations of their own children has been put to light. i felt conflicted watching what is supposed to be these imaginary consciousnesses of unborn children running about and acting as, what i initially thought to be, a device for invoking guilt in these young and unwilling kids and anger in its audience. but perhaps they were an avenue for the world to understand that while they have a future too, so does sunshine. so does the thirteen year old. what are these pastors and doctors planning for /their/ future? anyways im glad the movie stuck by its pro-abortion stances and did not pull back any punches. women's and children's healthcare has been on a serious decline in this country. its high time we see changes that put women as priority not some hypothetical individual.

gets ko nakuhang-kuha ng pelikulang ‘to ang puso at kaluluwa ko. it is not like typical tear-jerker indie films out there pero yung mga linyahan ng characters at yung buong mensahe ng pelikula, talagang makatotohanan at tagos kung tagos.ang sakit sa damdamin na ito talaga ang reality ng maraming kababaihan at kabataan dito sa Pilipinas at nakakapoot isipin na hanggang ngayon, wala pa rin silang sapat na proteksyon para sa ganitong sitwasyon, kaya sobrang nakakaputangina lang talaga ng mga lalaking puro sarap lang ang nasa isip pero walang puso at paninindigan, pati na rin ng gobyerno at ng mga relihiyong tumutuligsa sa sex education at safe abortion. isang malaking pakyu para sa inyong lahat! hands down din kay miss maris racal. hinding-hindi maipagkakaila na magaling talaga siyang artista. makikita mo talaga sa kanya yung passion at dedication niya sa pag-arte sa pelikulang ‘to, lalo na sa part na nagsumikap talaga siyang matutuhan ang gymnastics para maisabuhay ang character ni Sunshine.anyway, ayoko nang pahabain ‘to.... para sa mga Sunshine at Mary Grace, at sa lahat ng mga babaeng nakararanas ng iba pang kalupitan ng tunay na mundo, hindi kayo nag-iisa dahil kasama niyo ako sa laban niyo. hindi natin sila bati, pangit silang lahat! at para naman sa mga Miggy at Tito Bobot, pakyu! sana mabaog kayong lahat.

many people misunderstood this film once it came out on streaming. it's not about romanticizing abortion, it's about being given a choice and respecting it. Sunshine gave us a look into what a pregnancy scare entails for a girl in the Philippines---the accessibility of options, the healthcare system, the spiritual nuances, and everything else in between. the writing is so beautiful and raw. i thought the metaphor was so on the nose but the tie-up was so satisfying that i didnt even mind it. the hype is justified (and possibly underrated).thank you, Sunshine, for opening up a much-needed conversation about teen pregnancy and abortion in the country.
this really captures the everyday struggles, fears, and impossible choices faced by so many women/girls here in the ph. the harsh reality of living in a country where abortion remains inaccessible.

I had the chance to watch this at JAFF 2025. The plot twist is simple, but the message is powerful. The film highlights issues of sexual harassment and sexual violence involving minors. At JAFF, the director shared a little about how sexual issues are still considered taboo in the Philippines, and how the film also touches on the topic of abortion.Listening to the director speak at JAFF about the impact of this film, several discussions regarding cases of sexual harassment and violence in the Philippines have begun to open up, even if only slightly. According to him, this film has helped pave the way for filmmakers there to create similar works, which are still relatively rare.

Gets kita Sunshine, gets ka namin.Grabe, napakahusay. I didn’t expect how emotional this film would make me feel — to the point that it got me all teary-eyed. "Sunshine" is one of those films that stirs something inside: It makes you see, it makes you feel, it makes you realize, and it makes you understand.Itong "Sunshine" ay hindi lang basta-bastang pelikula gaya ng iba, dahil sa malalim at mabigat nitong mensahe. Sunshine, the girl with big dreams who got pregnant too early. Mary Grace, a child neglected by her own Mother, and was raped and impregnated by her Uncle — these characters aren’t purely fictional; they reflect real-life problems that many have faced. Iilan lamang ang sitwasyon nina Sunshine at Mary Grace sa maraming dahilan kung bakit sang-ayon ako sa Abortion o Pro-choice.Abortion isn’t murder; it’s healthcare — this is a strong and profound message in the film. "Sunshine" is a film that goes beyond entertainment; it also functions as an eye-opener. I hope na mas marami pa ang manood ng movie na ‘to. Para ma-realize nila kung gaano kahalaga na i-legalize ang aborsyon sa bansa. Kasi, sa totoo lang, napakaraming problema na puwedeng ma-solve kapag na-legalize na ang aborsyon (e.g., poverty, suicide cases, unemployment, uneducated people, etc.).Ang solid talaga nito, pati ‘yung mga bwisit na chismosa at religious people na nagpapaka-saint kuhang-kuha. But joke aside, nakakainis talaga ‘yung mga nagmamagaling na ‘yan, ta’s gagamitin pa ang Bible para i-justify ang pagiging ignorante nila. Like please, can’t they learn to set aside their religious beliefs and think about what truly matters?! They disagree, solely because the bible says it’s a sin. But what about those who have (and will) suffer? All they care about is that the baby gets delivered, but what comes after that? They don’t care. They really know how to be a pain in the ass.

mahal na mahal kita Sunshine!!! bigla kong na-gets yung sinabi ng mama ko na tumatak talaga sa’kin. she once told me, during a fight, na sana hindi niya na lang ako binuhay. i know it’s an inappropriate thing to say to your child, pero now i kinda understand where it came from.hindi ko siya kayang i-hate. alam ko na she was once a “Sunshine” too na punong-puno ng pangarap, at nawala ang lahat ng ’yon nung nabuntis siya sa’kin. maybe we can use the quote “rejection is redirection,” pero masakit isipin na she could’ve done better. i can’t blame her for having the what-ifs of her past. hindi niya kasalanan na she grew up in a conservative, religious country. systemic talaga ang lahat. alam ko na mahal na mahala ako ng nanay ko pero hindi ko rin siya masisi kung may regret pa rin siya about the dreams she never got to chase.this movie helped me understand her side a bit more, and somehow, it helped me forgive her for saying that thing.sana maging legal na ang abortion sa Pilipinas. at sana mas maraming kababaihan ang maging katulad ni Sunshine na patuloy na pipiliin ang sarili at pangarap.

aside from being a tad bit short for my liking, i have no notes. this movie perfectly encapsulated the reality most women experience. women are deprived of choices when it comes to this because of the possibility of being persecuted. and I'm glad Sunshine made a decision solely for herself and her dreams. women should never be scared nor be subjected to subjugation by beliefs such as religion for a decision made for herself. i will always support women who knows what they want and what they don't. until it's your life, you have no right to decide. standing ovation for Maris for being so natural. she nailed this role. and shout out to Ms. Antonette for this masterpiece. PS: Pro-choice also means being Pro-life. Argue with the wall.

Gets kita.Wala pang kalahating oras nang ipakita ang eksena kung saan humingi ng tawad si Sunshine sa harap ng simbahan—Tagos. Ramdam agad ang emosyon at ang mensahe. Sabay na nakakalungkot at nakakagalit kung iyong iisipin na sa bawat tagpi ng eksena ay ipinapamukha ng pelikulang ito ang tunay na representasyon at kalagayan ng mga kababaihin patungkol sa aborsyon at 'reproductive health' sa Pilpinas: mahirap at nakakasuka. Importante ang bawat sulok ng pelikulang ito lalung lalo na ang pananalamin sa estado at kasuluksulukan ng Quiapo. Sa bawat busina at usok ng mga jeep, sa bawat ingay ng mga tao, sa bawat lakad ng mga kababaihan na may sabay na bitbit na pangarap at problema, hinding hindi maikukumpara kung gaano kasalimuot ang kanilang mga nararanasan. Kaya kung napanood mo ito at hindi ka pa sumasang-ayon, naway isipin mo ang mahabaging desisyon na bitbit ni Sunshine (hindi man ito aayon sa kultura at relihiyon ng ating bansa), sapagkat ito ay mahalagang proposal na dapat isaalang-alang ng nakararami.

First of all, hands down kay Maris. Knowing na inaral niya talaga yung gymnastics, grabe yung dedication. Kudos din to Direk Antoinette—this film shows how women are so easily labeled, judged, and stereotyped by society. Malaking isyu pa rin talaga ang aborsyon sa Pilipinas.This film shows kung paano napipilitan ang mga babae bumili ng illegal abortion pills kahit alam nilang delikado, dahil banned pa rin ang abortion sa’tin. Hindi lang naman ‘to tungkol kay Sunshine na may pangarap, para…

This movie unveiled how every unexpected pregnancy burdens solely the women. The men who always attempt to get away with their responsibility after learning the byproduct of their act. More significantly, the relevance of the depiction of the child on how the story and the plot progresses gives an emphasis on the acceptance of the sentiment of not wanting to conceive a child. How Maris' character dedicated most of her life doing something she loves: gymnastics, which can be taken away from considering her pregnancy--- she literally did everything and sacrificed everything to reach her dreams. The movie has conveyed the weight of abortion and how motherhood is a choice which is not tailored for all women.

Pero mas lalong mahirap maging babae sa bansang walang maayos na sistemang pangkalusugan, sa at isang bansang korap ang gobyerno, PINOY PRIDE PILIPINAS!It’s so easy to judge women for their decisions, lalo na sa isang “Catholic country”, where they claim to “value life”. But a woman’s life is ALSO A FUCKING LIFE. Hindi ko alam kung bakit ang hirap nitong intindihin para sa iba.This movie doesn’t just show the reality of unplanned pregnancy, it exposes why good quality and ACCESSIBLE healthcare is crucial and why fucking abortion needs to be legalized. It makes you realize how a corrupt, underfunded healthcare system, shaped by decades of neglect, ends up deciding the choices and safety of women. A country with no real healthcare access, outdated religious stigma, and a government that would rather shame women than help them traps women into choices they never truly want, and pushes them to resort to illegal and unsafe ways just to be able na mapalaglag na lang yung bata para makapagpatuloy sa kanilang buhay. Pinakita din nito na HINDI madali para sa isang babae na magpalaglag ng bata, lalo na kung ikaw ay isa lang ring bata.PUTANGINANG FLOOD CONTROL PROJECT YAN.PUTANGINANG BANSA TO.

The movie was very good. A bleak, reality-grounded conversation-starter on women’s reproductive rights in a conservative, third-world country like the Philippines. Maris and Jennica’s performances made the movie. Both the kids’ acting could’ve been better but not a dealbreaker at all. I hope this movie nudges Filipino public opinion to, at the very least, question their deep-seated perceptions on abortion. After all, it is in the dominant will of the public that reforms in policies occur. (Also, my first ever Letterboxd entry! Glad I started with this.)

“Naiintindihan mo bako?”“Gets ko na.”Gets ko na/naiintindihan ko are the words na lagi kong sinasabi sa mama ko but in so many different situations, the child and sunshine’s similarity to us is that, laging nabibring up sa usapan naming mag-ina yung mga what ifs ko for her as her daughter, what she could’ve been if she chose herself years ago. Hindi ko naiintindihan, are the words na lagi kong sagot kada ang response niya sakin ay “kasi ikaw ang buhay ko”, kasi ang kapalit nun sakin ay yung mga responsibilidad na maging mas matalino, mas magaling, na hindi option ang pumalpak, especially when it comes to decisions.Sabi ko, hindi ko naiintindihan kasi sayang. Lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, lahat ng mga narating ko ngayon, dapat siya na yun, o mas higit pa kung nilakasan niya lang loob niya. Ika nga, in this world we can’t always get all that we want, kaya sa kabila ng bawa’t hindi ko maintindihan, siya ring may katapat na naiintindihan ko. Gets ko na, hindi pala na sayang, dahil siya din naman ang lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, dahil dun palang sa pinili niya ako para maging anak niya, kahit pa na may kapalit iyong mga responsibilidad hindi lang para sakin kundi para din sa kaniya, dun palang sa araw na yun, isang matapang na pagpasya din ang ginawa niya para piliin na kaming dalawa ang magkakampi sa bawat laban na haharapin namin. Gets ko na, na hindi lang sakin to mahirap, na masyado ring mahirap itong mundong ito para sa kaniya, kaya’t ano pa’t para dumagdag pa ako sa mga kalaban niya.I feel like most daughters shares this same sentiments and dreams for their mothers of wanting them to choose themselves even if it means not having the chance to be born in this world, and that’s what makes me love this movie. It comforted me to have the perception of making that dream come true for my own mom. It showed the depth of the understanding between the mother and their child especially their daughters. Just when we thought it’s already deep, it could get more deeper.Gets ko na. Sabi ng anak ni sunshine sa kaniya, whom I still and highly believe na kakampi niya (bukod sa ate niya) on every step of her way dahil lahat ng pangarap na meron sila, lahat ng bawat sumunod na tagumpay ay para padin sa kanilang dalawa.

My debut here on letterboxd inkigayo (chareng) and I wanted it to be about Sunshine because this is my movie of the YEAR! As a man na lumaki sa very conservative and religious na family, I’ve always been socially aware. I am pro abortion but I never really know kung gaano kalalim yung pinaglalaban natin, well atleast not until I saw this film.Bilang lalaki na manonood, I can only empathize & be compassionate towards sunshine because I feel like nobody can understand her better than women themselves. Highlight ng film for me is yung scene ni Maris sa motel, besides feeling a sense of dread, it also fills me with anger dahil babae pa din talaga ang sasalo sa lahat ng hirap. Anong ginawa ng nakabuntis? binigyan lang ng pera si sunshine, that’s it. Si sunshine yung naghirap, nasaktan, at napahiya. Kaya ang galing ng pelikula kasi nakuha niya gaano pa rin ka pabor ang mundo sa mga kalalakihan.Ang ganda ng casting, sobrang buhay nila na pwede ko lang silang makita sa labas ng bahay namin. Favorite performance ko ay si Maris at Jennica, hayop sa galing! (Grabe yung iyak ko sa kwarto scene nila) Ganda ng cinematography, editing, at music. Sa AWKP ko lang nakilala si Direk Tonet and I was NOT familiar with her game! Basta ang ganda at mabuhay pa ang mga gantong klaseng pelikula

not every woman wants to be a mother.so, so, soooo refreshing to see an ambitious woman choose her own dreams over society’s forced motherhood. sabi nga ni bata (or Annika), “pangarap ko ang pangarap niya.” i really hope this film opens up better laws for reproductive and maternal health. sobrang nakakairita lang talaga na kung sino pa yung mga OB-GYN, sila pa yung mga taong madiin sa pananampalataya. motherhood is already troubling in itself, teenage pregnancy faced with a hateful doctor? that’s fucking worse.this is an incredible film that gave space for abortion and illegal abortions to be discussed in the philippines. it’ll definitely leave a bad taste in conservative filipinos’ mouths, but that’s the point. teenage mothers live their lives in discomfort everyday, so showing their realities and humanizing them is more than enough to make people realize that their own personhood should always come first before an embryo. hugs with consent to every girl or woman who’s going through a similar struggle. nawa’y mahanap niyo ang lakas na kinakailangan ninyo para malagpasan ang mga problema niyo. i just hope you all remember that what’s best for you, will also be what’s best for the child. and if what’s best is not having the child, then that’s the painful reality and you shouldn’t be ashamed for putting your wellbeing first. in the end, the best sign of motherhood is to never enter it in the first place. you can’t pour love into another cup if your own cup is empty. so, forge your own path and dance to your own beat—you will always be the master of your own ship. kudos, sunshine! congratulations on your gold.

Worth the year long wait, brilliant film and really cements Antoinette Jadaone as an Auteur of Philippine Cinema. I think what I found so strikingly sad about this is that, fourteen years removed from the Philippines (more than half of my life!); I try to tread carefully when I talk about Manila, the people and their struggles. I don't think that my incredibly sheltered memory of the place would hold as much cultural weight than that of a local, and yet fourteen years later Manila is still...Manila. And if I am brought to tears by this, I wonder about the grief carried by generations of young women failed by a dated system. In all her films, what Jadaone ultimately wants, or rather demands for her female protagonists, is Space. Space to exist safely and choose freely.To break women out of crowded public maternity wards with shared beds, obsolete facilities, abject doctors (with their religious biases), and to bring them into the clearing of their dreams, the main-stage gymnasium, the Olympics.
mahirap talaga umiyak pag may kasama

“Ayoko maging nanay. Hindi ko ipapanganak ‘to dahil hindi ako ready maging nanay.” / English: I don’t want to be a mother. I won’t give birth to this child because I’m not ready to become a mother.Abortion is illegal in the Philippines, heck even being pro-choice here is looked down upon. Yet, motherhood is an expected life trajectory for many Filipino women, that is if you marry at the “right age” and have more than 1 child at the “right time”. So what choice do women have if they are pregnant under different circumstances? For a country that claims to be collectivist (pakikipagkapwa tao mindset ang dapat pinapairal, etc.), how can this principle become a universal behavior for most when its own government continues to throw its own citizens under the bus? Every dire problem that needs to be addressed can be traced back to how fucked Filipinos are by their government. Whatever rhetoric the Spaniards spread about Filipinos being “lazy” is still used today by the rich and powerful, their basis why the Philippines continues to be poor. Galit na galit ako sa nagtitinda ng mga pekeng “gamot” para sa pagpapalaglag ng bata, the review she showed Sunshine that it was effective could possibly be fake, pero narealize ko na nagbebenta sila ng pekeng solusyon para sa maka ahon sa buhay (not justification of this behavior). This government continues to fail people in every aspect of life, you’d realize why the crime is so high. But is it such a crime to not want a baby? (It is not).How can Filipinos truly care for the children (whether born or unborn) when elected officials undermine reproductive health in this country, primarily women’s health. The Reproductive Health Law faced a long legislative battle just to get passed, and it still took two years for the law to be fully accessible for the public. When your prospects are so thin, people will do anything to get what they want, even if it costs their life. That is a hard pill to swallow for a lot of Filipinos. At the end of the day, Filipinos are treated as just mere statistics in politics.

Sunshine (2024) looks soft, warm, almost gentle on the surface. the colors cradle you, the scenes feel tender, and at first, you think it is comforting. but beneath all of that warmth carries a weight that is impossible to ignore. it is about abortion in the Philippines, where it is illegal, and labeled as “blasphemous,” “disgraceful,” and judged above the lives it affects. the film does not shy away from showing how cruel reality can be. people, even doctors, prioritize morality over humanity, ignoring the pain, the fear, and the uncertainty of the woman at the center. it shows a woman whose future and potential clash with society’s judgment.the unknown girl who follows Sunshine feels like a younger version of herself. she is the part of Sunshine that believes abortion is wrong, the part that cannot yet grasp the weight of a life lived on someone else’s terms. and yet, by the end, she mutters, “gets ko na.” she sees that Sunshine’s life is not a simple question of right and wrong. she feels the burden Sunshine carries, the life she cannot give without losing herself. she recognizes how much was left for Sunshine to live, how much potential to burn bright, and how pregnancy would have dimmed it. she senses the life that should have belonged to Sunshine alone.the realization does not absolve, it recognizes the choices forced upon someone who should have been free to live her life on her own terms. that recognition shatters you more than any argument, any moral lesson ever could.watching this film, you feel everything at once. the warmth of the colors, the softness of the scenes, the love in small gestures, and then the ache, the rage, the grief that lingers because the world can be cruel, unfair, unfeeling. Sunshine is about life that is too heavy for the judgment of others. it is about the potential snuffed out when morality is chosen over empathy. it is about understanding, even when the world cannot. it is gentle, devastating, and necessary. it will stay with you long after the credits roll.Sunshine is soft to watch, hard to forget, and brutally honest about the ways society fails those who need understanding the most.it will make you feel what it is to live, to choose, to survive, and to understand when understanding is all that remains.

“Gets mo na ba?” “Gets ko na,” Well ako hindi ko masyadong gets.An avid fan of Dir. Jadaone’s works, so I was so excited for this one considering all the positive reviews and attention it got all over social media. However, seeing it now, I believe this is one of her weakest works yet.Okay maganda AT FIRST, and I love Maris Racal’s acting, as well as Jennica Garcia’s and the kids’. I’ll give you that. But this also felt all over the place and inconsistent. From the first 10 minutes alone, I could get the premise of the film and I was curious to see where they would take it dahil magandang storyline nga naman ito. Pero jusko, simpleng storyline na nga lang, andaming nangyayari at andaming dagdag masyado na characters at subplot…especially for a film entitled “Sunshine.” It just comes off unnecessary.Mapapasabi ka nalang, yun na yon?

Sobrang nakakaiyak and worth it to watch. Gets ko na, Sunshine. Also, tangina ni Miggy at kuhang kuha niya inis ko kasi karamihan ng lalaki talaga hindi pinapanugatan mga anak nila tapos parang wala lang, tuloy lang ang buhay. Palibhasa kasi, hindi sila yung manganganak at hindi mawawalan ng pangarap.

Though it’s a Filipino film, the issues it brings up feel very close to home for my country—we’re part of the same Southeast Asian family, after all. The story is poignant and deeply relatable, especially the short subplot about Mary. I couldn’t stop thinking about all the other “Marys” out there who are sexually abused by their own relatives, trapped in a vicious cycle with no real options. Let alone healing the trauma—they don’t even know where to begin.And then there’s Sunshine. True to her name, she becomes the light in the darkness, taking responsibility for what happened even though she never wanted to become a mother yet.

“kasalanan sa mata ng diyos”is abortion a sin? people will answer this differently because morality in the philippines is rarely personal. it is inherited by religion, tradition, and the weight of everyone watching. for many, the word “abortion” automatically activates the label of sin, as if life were a simple moral equation and suffering didn’t count as part of the formula. for others, it is a decision carved out of fear, pressure, and survival, made in the middle of circumstances that no outsider fully understands. kung ginahasa ka, kasalanan pa rin ba ang pagpapalaglag sa bata? if your answer is yes, then your moral compass is calibrated more by dogma than empathy, and your worldview is as rigid as the doctrine you inherited without questioning.conservatism in the philippines is not subtle. it is soaked into daily life, in families, in pulpits, reinforced by laws that pretend neutrality but are shaped by centuries of religious influence. sa bansa natin, halos lahat ng desisyon ng babae ay may kasamang mata ng lipunan na handang humusga, tama? abortion becomes more than a medical choice; it becomes a cultural crime, a symbol that people weaponize even when they know nothing about the life behind the decision. the environment itself—manila’s density, poverty, inequality, survivalism—creates conditions where choices are never purely “moral.” what do you expect from a city where half the population is just trying to get through the day?when you strip away the labels, the question of sin becomes less religious and more philosophical. sin implies intent, malice, or moral wrongdoing. abortion, for many, is none of these. if you’d ask me i’d say that, it is not an act of cruelty. it is a response to reality, a calculated survival decision shaped by pressure that most people never experience. kung hindi mo kailanman naramdaman ang desperasyon ng isang taong walang mapuntahan, anong karapatan mong magsabing mali ang pinili niya? reducing abortion to “sin” ignores everything: economic instability, trauma, lack of support systems, inaccessible healthcare, fear of judgment, and the sheer brutality of living in a country that demands endurance but offers nothing in return.the real discussion is not about moral purity but about environment. what context shaped the choice? what access to resources existed? what physical, emotional, and social risks will the woman face? people prefer judgment over understanding because judgment feels easier. introspection requires effort, and compassion requires complexity—two things society often avoids.if morality is measured by harm done, abortion may not be a sin at all. it may be a reflection of a society that fails its people so deeply that they must make decisions the world refuses to understand. sa totoo lang, mas madali para sa lipunan na manisi kaysa kumilala ng sistematikong pagkukulang. we condemn individuals because it distracts us from confronting the bigger failure—the environment that gave them no safe path.the real sin might not be in the act of abortion but in the society that makes someone carry the weight alone. a society that romanticizes suffering, worships conformity, and punishes anyone who chooses survival over tradition. a society that has the audacity to moralize while refusing to provide support, empathy, or alternatives.

"Do you understand me?""I get it"Jadaone's Sunshine portrays the raw, harrowing, and excruciating journey of a young gymnast who found out that she is pregnant, just months before Olympics qualifiers. The emotional turmoil that sends her into a downward spiral ghastly encapsulates the prevalent issue of teenage and accidental pregnancies in the Philippines and how public's notions that are grounded from bigotry, conservatism, and outdated values can negatively imbue the minds of these helpless women.The fragments of Sunshine's psyche of children also deepened the already thematically layered piece where it now provides the protagonist a whole new outlook whether she should carry on with the pregnancy or terminate it. What I really love about it is the film stays grounded to its footing and steadily focuses on putting the audience in Sunshine's lens. The last act with the kid is a top-notch and probably the most heartwarming scene in the whole film.Maris Racal's impeccable performance also puts the cherry on top where the in-depth introspect of a young woman that is going down the rabbit hole won't be solidified without her. Overall, Sunshine may just bring a new sunshine in the modern era of Philippine cinema.

This movie really captured the whole idea of “what if my parents chased their dreams instead of having me?” The film shows how teenage pregnancy and child sexual abuse really happen not just because of irresponsible boyfriends who don’t use protection, but also because it can come from anyone and i mean ANYONE. your own dad, uncle, cousin, friend, or partner.Its eye-opening how teen pregnancy has become so normalized in the phillipines of ages 13 to 18. And to my mom who had dreams too, until she found out she was pregnant with me, she was torn a real 50/50 on whether to keep me or not. She chose to keep me and eventually married my dad.Sometimes I can’t help wondering what her life could’ve been if she pursued her own dreams. Honestly, I’d want her to be happy, even if that meant I wouldn’t exist. The movie’s meaning and message really hit me deeply.

'Naiintindihan mo na ba 'ko?''Gets ko na. Gets ko na.'Ang tagal kong naghintay para mapanood ’to sa Netflix and FINALLY nandito na. And grabe, hindi ako prepared sa binigay ni Maris dito. Sobrang pulido. Sobrang raw. Sobrang “ay oo, ganito talaga buhay ng babae—lalo na kung babae ka sa Pinas.”Sa wakas, may pelikulang hindi takot maging totoo. At bilang bansa na predominantly Catholic (sigh), alam mo na agad na taboo ’to. Ang hirap maging pro-choice sa isang lugar na agad kang hinuhusgahan bago ka pa marinig.Kaya huge deal talaga na may pelikulang gaya nito na nag-oopen ng usapan. At pinaka-tumatatak sa akin ’yung paalala na ang babae… tao. Hindi lang “may dinadala.” Hindi lang vessel. Tao.Na may nararamdaman, may konsensya.Na may sariling isip at puso.Na may takot at pangarap.At hindi biro ’yung bigat ng bawat desisyong kailangan niyang pasanin mag-isa.Tapos Manila as the backdrop??? YES.Hindi siya ginawang poster aesthetic! Totoong Maynila talaga: mainit, masikip, magulo, pero buhay. Like literal na buhay. Mga mukha ng taong araw-araw lumalaban sa sistema na hindi naman talaga pumapanig sa kanila.And the film doesn’t say “Maawa ka.” Hindi.Ang sinasabi niya is: “Makinig ka naman kahit minsan.”Kaya oo.Isang malaking oo.Gets ko na, Sunshine.(At medyo hindi ko kinaya emotionally kasi DAMI KO PANG NASASABI pero grabe, kudos talaga!)

Sunshine is a feat for Philippine cinema. It tackles a topic most are scared to produce and it was written WELL. Yes, without the poverty porn or political porn most films of ours subtexts. There are characters that are REAL. Not written to tell unjustly-unrelated issues but to support the story itself. And so, characters that are in poverty aren’t written to convey another message, rather to stand with what the film is about in the first place. This film is easily the one of the best written films of all time in our history. Not only does it tell a beautiful picture of a character undergoing such a life-turning “accident” but how it tells it psychologically, and powerfully. It never let go of what it portrays nor does it settle for a scene that would bring in viewers, it’s written SO realistically that you’d forget it’s a movie. A quick one to point out is Sunshine texting her bestfriend, at the time she needs support the most, even if she’s disappointed for losing contact with her, she still texts out of fear, and that’s something i’m sure plenty of people have done. Those text messages are so real, raw and incredibly well-written too. The whole story is an absolute masterclass of writing a film straightforwardly without losing the essence of what it is. It’s a display of perfect world-building, from the story of her boyfriend, the realistic response from him to the story of the tindera, who without building a relationship, completely makes sense of the film. Even built a subtext of a no nonsense coach that adds to fear, support, motive and regret of the main character.I can tell you all about the beautiful writing but this would be too long. Let’s get to the cinematography. Well, it’s good. Definitely better than most films, it’s quite obvious that certain camera works and shots aren’t just to finish the scene but is chosen to look good while portraying a scene nicely. There’s a lot of cues that whispers visually, like how she prays with bars infront of her, evoking the feeling of our character not FEELING or BEING welcome inside the church. Shot-selections like those sre essential and quite reliable to make a scene impactful so i’m incredibly proud they excerted better effort to make this film the best it could possibly be. Wouldn’t say it’s a strong suit, but this fil is definitely visually well-made.I’ve always seen Maris Racal as a great actress before this, now she’s PHENOMENAL one and is one of the best in the industry right now. The talent to portray talent and skill alone, is something most actors/actresses not only have the chance to audition for BUT absolutely nails from the first to the last second of the film. There’s a Piolo Pascual jumpscare here, Elijah Canlas KILLS it AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN.Sunshine is great, it’s amazingly told through emotions and a bit of a psychologically present engagement to allow interpretations of viewers be as wide as it can.

gets ko lahat ng sunshinesunshine understands that womanhood is lived inside systems that are unfavored to women — a society that polices women’s bodies and their rights, while men disappear just as easily as guilt and conscience stay.abortion is a form of love. it’s a right that should never have required this much endurance. kaya sa last scene, when annika said “gets na kita” after sunshine’s last routine, it felt like self-forgiveness, and a release of fear and guilt forced upon her by a world that never shared the burden. only then does sunshine allows her body to move without apology.

Sunshine is one of those rare Filipino films that refuses to look away. Instead of sugarcoating or romanticizing the world its characters inhabit, it confronts the audience with the uncomfortable truths we collectively sidestep—the toxic mindsets we inherit, the social issues we normalize, and the moral rigidity we mistake for virtue.What makes the film remarkable is its honesty. It acknowledges how deeply ingrained complacency is in our culture, how we often witness injustice, misogyny, or dysfunction and simply shrug, labeling it as “ganun talaga.” Sunshine exposes that mentality for what it is: a quiet violence that enables suffering. The film does not preach; it simply presents the weight of these realities with clarity and emotional intelligence, letting the audience feel the consequences of silence and inaction.Its commentary on anti-abortion attitudes is especially bold for Philippine cinema. Rather than reducing the debate to dogma or melodrama, the film shows how anti-abortion rhetoric becomes a peril for women; not just physically, but emotionally, socially, and economically. It reveals how denying reproductive autonomy restricts their futures, limits their ambitions, and punishes them for choices men are rarely held accountable for. Sunshine portrays this with nuance: the internal conflict, the fear of judgment, the systemic lack of support, and the complete absence of safe options. The film understands that this isn’t just a “moral issue”—it’s a structural one, tied to poverty, misogyny, and societal expectations about what women owe to the world.Ultimately, Sunshine is more than a movie; it’s a critique of the culture that raised us. It forces us to ask why we maintain harmful traditions, why morality is weaponized against women, and why we accept inequality as a norm. Its power lies in its refusal to let the audience remain comfortable, and in reminding us that the first step toward progress is learning to confront what we’ve been taught to ignore.

Films like this make me realize how great the potential of the PH film industry is when it comes to storytelling, creativity, and taking risks. Sunshine proves exactly that. Ang tapang ng pelikulang ‘to, not just in the execution, but sa choice of subject matter. Makamasa, madaling kapitan, and at the same time, a real eye-opener. From start to finish, ramdam mo yung puso at bigat ng kuwento, and yet ang linis ng pagkakadala.Maris Racal shines in a way that’s both raw and controlled; she gives a performance that stays with you long after the credits roll. Jennica Garcia is equally powerful, grabe yung presence niya, every scene hits (we all need a family member like her!!). Together, they carry the emotional core of the film so well na hindi mo mapigilang maapektuhan like ALL I CAN SAY IS I REALLY LOVE WOMEN SM.But above all, very important yung conversation na binubuksan ng Sunshine. Abortion is a difficult, nuanced topic—one that should be openly discussed not just within families, but within our society and government. And I firmly believe na choosing yourself first, your success, your safety, your future matters just as much. AND, women should be able to decide for themselves: their body, their rules. This isn't a simple issue, and the film treats it with the depth and humanity it deserves.Sunshine is indeed a courageous and a necessary film that everyone should watch!!

More didactic than her previous films, but this is still a great “social issues” drama (albeit one with some magical realist touches), with a moving central performance. In terms of “abortion movies,” it really does a great job of making its case. For a teenage gymnast, carrying a baby to term really does completely remove that path as a possibility for her life—that dream just gets immediately destroyed, in a way that (obviously) won’t happen for the baby’s father, and it’s why it’s so essential to this film’s success that Jadaone so skillfully captures the tactile and practical *reality* of Sunshine’s body in the gymnastic scenes: that body, with its graceful and athletic movements, that she has spent her entire life molding for this sole purpose of Olympic gold, and it will go away, permanently, if she doesn’t have an abortion. I also think Jadaone does a good job of avoiding deck-stacking. Yes, the pro-life nurse who castigates Sunshine is portrayed as a witch, but the saleswoman who gives her the abortifacients is also shown to be a greedy haggler herself. And while the two male figures pressuring her to have the baby (her boyfriend and her boyfriend’s father) both make specious and insincere cases, it is again to Jadaone’s credit that she cast two dynamic male performers for these roles (Elijah Canlas and Pio Pascual—whom I didn’t recognize in a straight-up “Dad” role, after decades playing the heart-throb!)…this is one of those reviews where in the process of writing it I’ve realized I liked the movie a lot more than I thought I did while the credits were rolling. Jadaone, she’ll do that to you!

One of the biggest factors holding back the Philippines from being as progressive as our neighboring countries like China and Japan is our deep entanglement with religion—Christianity, in particular. As much as faith shapes our culture, it also becomes a hindrance to national progress when religious beliefs are imposed on matters that should prioritize the welfare and rights of all citizens. Imagine how much better our society could be if we allowed personal freedoms and evidence-based policies to guide our decisions, instead of insisting on religious doctrine as the standard for everyone.The movie portrayed this reality so powerfully. It addressed so many issues in one narrative—how women are often the ones who suffer the most under a misogynistic system, how men can easily walk away from responsibilities while women cannot, and how horrifying it is that young girls, even minors, can be raped and then forced to bear a child. These are the consequences of a society that refuses to give women full autonomy over their own bodies.I truly hope more people come to realize the importance of allowing women to make decisions for themselves by legalizing abortion. Every woman deserves the right to choose what happens to her own body.Despite the heaviness of the story, I’m glad that Sunshine still managed to pursue the dream she longed for, proving that resilience can still bloom even in the harshest circumstances.

I may be on the unpopular side of this: I want to love this so badly but for some reason, I can't help to mull-on & pinpoint some details lacked for me and thought it needed more revising story-wise. I am not hating on this. In fact, I actually like several parts of the movie. I think it's fair to say (and undeniably so) that this is an important and a refreshing story on what's the take of abortion & body autonomy here in the Philippines and I do appreciate this movie for that. (I added the half star plus because it still is an important movie)I want to love this movie (but only like it) because I thought it obviously have such a great potential to be "a great movie" on most aspects. What holds me back is the writing, story-wise.It started really strong and direct to the point which I really liked. By the next part, we'd see a little girl who follows Sunshine. At first it seems to me that it could be her inner child or her unborn future child so it confused me a bit (most especially on the part where Sunshine was rushed to the hospital, we'd see a blood on her crotch area as well). This device they used provided a bit of comic relief in the movie which I thought is cute and actually can be an effective way to delve deeper sentimentally because its so personal. However, I came to learn (through online reading) that she is indeed her unborn future child (bc of Ariana disappearing). To be honest, I couldn't finalize my thoughts on this whether I like it or not because with that in mind, the mix message does confuse some a bit on whether or not it's a "pro-life" but I guess that could also be the point that it is complicated. Afterall, Sunshine did kept coming back to the church scenes and this can represent a lot of women who faces/d the same situation. I just thought the movie might have to clarify in telling that message.I also much prefer her being Sunshine's inner child (which could be a "tangible" reminder on what the whole movie is all about, Sunshine taking control of her own life and the dream of being a national athlete ever since she's a child). But the line "Gets ko na" have such a great impact on people because of its "casualness" but its the words that has a really heavy weight on it that I thought is effective to pull people's heartstrings in. Another aspect of the movie that kinda lacked for me which is, I think a big part of it: I want to see how much Sunshine wants it by seeing her own training to be a gymnast. What does she do every day as a training athlete? How does she balance everything in her life-- being a sister/aunt/student/friend/a woman in general while also being a training athlete? What do you to do train as a gymnast? How heavy does it weigh on her that she's truly doing every thing she can to be in olympics and be a great gymnast, what does it look like? I wished she saw that a bit (even just in a montage) before or during the moment she found out she got pregnant. I want to see her really work hard and see how much blood, sweat, and tears and really feel and see that "goddamn it i want this so bad" and not just tell it. I guess what I want to say is that I want more training scenes too because I am also interested in watching gymnasts do their thing haha.I also thought that by the 3/4 part of the movie where we do meet Ariana is kinda took a different turn for the movie. I am not sure if it is necessary that we meet another kid (Ariana, not Mary Grace) and that maybe without that, they could still end up getting the same storyline/result (though don't get me wrong, I did like Ariana, i think she's fab). It also didn't do much impact on Sunshine's decision but rather it does prove how fucked up it is that this happen in reality and how shitty it is again that we don't have much (legal and safe, known) access to women's sexual and reproductive health services, let alone being a woman/person who's forced into something they aren't ready to be/never wanted be in the first place.More so, the visuals and cinematography, can't deny that it is beautiful, that's a given. Acting is amazing, no notes no doubt.A little predictable on emphasizing on the Manila landscape and scenery although it is still beautiful to look at (especially considering to people haven't been to Manila/Philippines, at least they'd get the gist of it even though its not all picturesque all the time). I especially appreciate the movie getting in deep and showing the grim & messy ways of taking different methods of abortion. I thought its very important to see how harrowing and fucking hard/harsh/unfair/dangerous it is that women have to/had no choice to do experiences like these. I only wished that they showed the method of when Sunshine made an appointment for that Doctor Helena because maybe it could also show that abortion could also have safe and harmless way that would make people feel less wary and scared of it and maybe even talk about it.With all that, in conclusion I think I do like this movie. It is an important movie to exists especially at our modern times, it's long overdue that we finally talk about this here in our country. I hope we keep talking about it because it is necessary for us we want to keep fighting for women's rights. I don't love it but I do like it and I appreciate it for what it did.

i liked the narrative and character of Sunshine. a well-performing gymnast who carried it all alone, refusing to give up her passion over being a childbearer. but there's something more to see, something to observe about — the country's system is rotten. beggars crossing your struggles only to be fed. the extreme language of Filipino people to express rage. busy and wasted streets to feel unsafe yet realistically implied. hospitals rejecting patients instead of living out the work ethic of saving lives. being a bad influence for expressing what you really feel. religion as a coping mechanism. plans of abortion kept clandestinely to hide against the law. and the most of it all, choosing to smile as a way to focus on doing what you love. additionally, showcasing Sunshine's child manifestation was wild. it was her conscience at the same time — guilt tripping the heck out of her.curses to the legal system. curses to insensitive and lustful men.curses to irresponsible parents.ang gwapo ni Piolo Pascual.
