this is what the filipino people need to see more often. it might be obscure for some, but it is timely and important. teenage mothers are often judged for carrying a child; whether they keep it or not, judgement will still eye on them. the guilt of their conscience will still haunt and hunt them. but we never get to see their point of view, we only see them for the mistakes they have done. where is that energy when it comes to boys who choose to abandon the outcome of their bad decisions? nowhere. i love how this film doesn’t just show us the story of a teenage girl who got pregnant while chasing her dreams—it is a story of all the girls and women who are forced to carry a baggage they never asked for. we saw their hardships and struggles. it also shows us how flawed our system is and how hypocritical some religious people are. this should be a wake up call. the little girl (annika) doesn’t just represent sunshine’s unborn child—she also represents us. we only see abortion and choosing oneself as something wrong and sinful because we are too blinded by what was merely taught to us. we never get to see or feel what others feel. and once we do, we will understand them. that is when we will realize. let’s be more like the little girl, let’s try to understand more.i also love that they chose manila as the setting of this film. it might not be important but i think it is. manila is messy, scary, and it will kill you. but once you overcome it, you’ll see its beauty.lastly, sorry pero super bothered talaga ko sa part na nasa lope de vega na sila tapos ang layo pa ng hospital na pinuntahan nila e mas malapit naman ang metro, san lazaro, or jose reyes.  bothered lang ako pero gets ko naman kung bakit, so wala na lang yon, di siya mahalaga. hahaha

Source: www.reeladvice.net/2025/12/sunshine-2024-movie-review.htmlAntoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine has been one of our most anticipated local releases of the year and it does not disappoint. Emotionally charged and socially resonant, the film tackles teen pregnancy and the realities of limited reproductive rights in the Philippines with honesty and empathy. While it may not offer clear-cut moral answers, Sunshine succeeds in revealing the real and painful stakes of becoming a young mother tackling equally both sides of the moral coin.National gymnast Sunshine (Maris Racal) has always dreamed of competing in the Olympics. With qualifiers fast approaching, she pushes her body to its limits until she suddenly faints during training. What she assumes is exhaustion from her intense regimen and strict diet turns out to be something far more life-altering: she is pregnant. At only 19 and with her lifelong dream on the line, Sunshine faces a bitter decision: keep the child and lose her final chance at the Olympics, or pursue an illegal abortion and grapple with the moral and emotional fallout.As expected, Sunshine doesn’t shy away from tough conversations. Its central dilemma is painfully relatable, regardless of where you stand on the right to choose in a predominantly Catholic country. Maris Racal is a revelation, delivering a nuanced and deeply human performance as a young athlete forced to confront consequences that will shape the rest of her life. And while we won’t spoil where the story ultimately lands, the film takes a definitive stance without betraying the complexity of its subject matter. It was a balancing act handled with notable care.What elevates Sunshine further is how vividly it captures the societal pressures and chaotic realities of Philippine society when it comes to the right to choose. The judgment, the ironies, the lack of support systems, everything feels painfully authentic and grounded. Where the film stumbles slightly is in its more fantastical elements. Though the intent behind these sequences is clear, they often feel out of place and not fully integrated into the narrative, appearing more convenient than cohesive. Still, Sunshine is a compelling and important watch and not only for Maris Racal’s standout performance but for its bold and compassionate exploration of an issue that remains deeply relevant in modern Philippine society. It’s a film that provokes and ultimately shines.

Gets na gets kita, Sunshine. Nakakapanlumong isipin na bilang isang babae, ultimo katawan mo, hindi mo masasabing may full autonomy ka to do whatever you want with it and with your life. Kapag naman gusto mong kumawala sa idinidikta sayo ng relihiyon at ng konserbatibo nating lipunan, parang hindi tama na hindi ka kainin ng konsensya mo; dapat pa yatang lumuhod ka sa harapan nila kahit para sa ikabubuti mo naman ang magiging desisyon mo—parang mali pa sa mata nila na unahin mo ang sarili mo. Kailanman ay hindi magiging pro-women ang kahit anumang sistema dito sa Pilipinas kung patuloy na babahiran ng relihiyon ang mga batas na ipinapatupad. Dahil dito, imbes na bumuo tayo ng isang lipunan kung saan walang babae ang kinakailangang dumaan sa butas ng karayom para magkaroon ng access sa isang serbisyo na DAPAT ay parte ng healthcare system natin, we continue to condition women into shaming themselves. Walang Sunshine, o kahit sinumang babae, ang dapat na isakripisyo ang kanyang mga pangarap.

this feels very similar to brocka in that it portrays manila as a city full of hardship and loneliness that can leave you so disillusioned and alienated; and where hope and humanity exist on the fringes of it. it's a working-class story with working-class sentiments that fully takes on its own identity because jadaone is able to portray such familar elements in a way that feel completely isolating; the interiors of jeepneys, tricycles, shabby motels, clinics — everything feels so alien. which, i guess, offers many people unfamiliar with what these woman go through a much-needed perspective on the importance of dignity and bodily autonomy and how violent, horrible men try to take that away from many women.i think it's also worth noting that religion and patriarchy play such a prominent role here in oppression; jadaone laser-focused on placing religious beliefs and preconceived notions about abortion in the spotlight, all the more affected by teenage pregnancy and how religion has kind of shaped the way many filipinos treat abortion as something so taboo and inhuman that they completely forget how it affects the mother. and it's brought to life by a really incredible maris racal; shaped by all the adversity — the kind of performance that requires you to bare your soul to the audience, to beg them to see the humanity behind the people suffering from religious oppression, and why access to abortion services — even in a heavily catholic country — is of utmost importance.

“Gets ko.”This is the first time na medyo mag-essay ako here because just… wow. Usually, when I watch films, madaldal ako with side comments here and there. Pero habang nanonood ako ng Sunshine, tahimik lang ako. Walang imik. Kasi it didn’t feel like I was watching a script come to life, it felt like I was actually watching Sunshine. Not Sunshine as the protagonist of a movie or a character that Maris plays, but Sunshine as a real person—her, as someone like me. A young girl struggling with the kind of belief system that we have in our country. Bilang babae, nakakatakot na malagay sa sitwasyon na mapapahamak lahat ng pinaghirapan mo, lahat ng pinagtrabahuhan mo buong buhay mo, lahat ng mga pangarap mo. Lahat tayo may karapatan mamili ng kapalaran natin. Kaya gets ko, Sunshine. Gets na gets ko. Hindi dapat tayo inihahalintulad sa demonyo o pinipilit na humingi ng kapatawaran sa kahit sino dahil lang gumawa tayo ng isang desisyon na para sa sarili natin. Hindi para sa pamilya o sa kaibigan, para sa atin.Would I say na the Philippines is ready for these kinds of films? I don’t know, pero parati akong naniniwala na hindi kailangang maging handa ang isang tao o bagay sa lahat ng oras. I think a more important question is: do we need these kinds of films? Then my answer would be yes. We do.

At hindi ka maaapektuhan kung magdedesisyon ang isang tao na gawin yon.Fuck people with this kind of mindset.Imagine, nasa pedestrian lane ka, tapos tatanungin ka kung magpapakamatay ka? Tanga ka ba?Bibili ka lang ng pregnancy test, tapos ijjudge ka at sasabihing, “Mga kabataan ngayon hindi na marunong magpigil.” People just can’t shut their mouths.Fuck the government.Putangina nakakalungkot, everytime na may Pilipino na magkakasakit, una nilang iisipin ay wala silang pera, paano ang gagastusin, at kung anong ipangbabayad nila sa ospital, imbes na isipin ang kalusugan at mangyayari sa kanila. Nakakalungkot pero totoo, and I’ve been a witness of that, yung dalawahan sa higaan at yung konting check up na sobrang mahal, na dapat naman ay libre. Sobra na, bakit ganito? Bakit ang tingin nyo sa babae e parang laruan? Pwedeng basta iwanan, itapon, o palitan kapag nagamit na? Bakit tingin ng mga lalaki e sex lang ang pinakamagandang bagay sa relasyon na maiooffer ng isang babae? Putangina, tite lang ba nagpapatakbo sa isip nyo?Thank you sa scene na hinampas ni Sunshine yung bote ng beer yung lalaki, super deserve nya yon.Fuck society for thinking all we’re made for is to procreate and care for our husbands.There’s more to life than men. Literal. Ito yung gusto kong sabihin everytime na may family gathering tapos unang tatanungin sa’kin, “May boyfriend ka na?” Putangina. Nakakapagod. Ito lang ba yung concerning na bagay sa buhay ko? Lalaki? Haha. Pano kung tanungin nyo kamusta yung pag-aaral ko? Ano yung mga bagay na ginagawa ko lately? Ano yung mga lugar na napuntahan ko? Kamusta ako? Wala ba? Lalaki lang ba talaga? “Hindi ako nahihiya, ayoko maging nanay”This was the part where I literally cried, salamat, at least at some point narealize ko, may boses tayo, may karapatan tayong magdesisyon para sa sarili natin, may karapatan tayong piliin kung ano yung tama at mas makakapagpasaya satin.Gets ko na, salamat Sunshine.

Women in the Philippines continue to grapple with deeply rooted issues such as teenage pregnancy which is made even more complex by the country’s predominantly Catholic identity. The moral codes and expectations instilled in us from childhood often determine whether society views abortion as a sinful act or a necessary choice, and this cultural tension becomes the silent force shaping many young women’s lives.In the film, Maris Racal embodies this struggle with striking emotional clarity. She carries the weight of a decision that no young woman should have to make alone: the impossible choice between holding on to her dream of becoming an Olympian or confronting the life-altering reality of an unexpected pregnancy. Her performance is powerful not because it dramatizes the dilemma, but because it mirrors the experiences of countless Filipinas whose voices are often dismissed or shamed into silence.What elevates the film is how it frames her situation not as a moral failure, but as a human story: one shaped by fear, hope, societal pressure, and the search for agency. Through Racal’s nuanced portrayal, the narrative exposes the cultural contradictions we live with: a society that celebrates the achievements of young women yet imposes rigid expectations on their bodies and choices. The film invites the audience to move beyond judgment and recognize the quiet courage required to stand at the crossroads of identity, aspiration, and responsibility.In grounding a personal crisis within the broader context of Philippine social norms, the film becomes more than a character study; it becomes a commentary on how we, as a society, often fail to extend empathy to young women navigating impossible circumstances. And in that sense, Maris does not just act the role; she embodies a truth many are too uncomfortable to confront.

The grittiness and colours of the streets of Manila were the most apt backdrop for the emotions and Filipino sensibilities brought about by ingrained patriarchal conservatism. I especially adore films that take me back to familiar spaces, and Sunshine did not only tell a brave story but was also a visually rich piece of work.That night scene with the running LRT reflected on the motel window was, to me, textbook cinematography at its finest.

ABORTION IS KILLING!! THEN JERK OFF AND DON'T FUCK WOMEN!!What makes Sunshine haunt me is how real it feels — not just as a story of a gymnast’s dream, but as a raw, painful portrait of what it means to be young, afraid, and fighting when everything seems stacked against you. The moment the truth sinks in — that this girl, brimming with hope and ambition, is now carrying a life she never asked for — the world she built starts cracking. Maris Racal gives a performance that doesn’t feel like acting — even when she’s silent, you feel every tremor of fear, every doubt, every moment she prays for a different ending. The film doesn’t paint shades of grey — it throws you into a world where choices are dangerous, and every door seems closed.And the way the city closes in around her — tight alleys, cold clinics, judgmental stares, desperation disguised as quiet — Sunshine doesn’t just tell a story. It burrows underneath your skin and refuses to leave. This film isn’t easy or comfortable, but it’s needed — for the stories it refuses to sanitize, for the voices it pulls from the shadows, and for the courage it asks from us to look. If you think you know pain, you might not until you watch Sunshine.

stream-of-consciousness review (i’ll edit it later): her younger self got mad at her for losing her friend (which i presume was rhed’s baby) cause her younger self’s view on abortion was that it’s morally wrong. the scene where she made peace with her younger self felt like the magic piece that ties this excellent film together. i love how introspective and culturally true this film is. although scene-setting would have made it better like showing sunshine’s house from the outside, where she lives - more sceneries that show her life.the actress playing her sister gave the best performance in this film. the subtle moves, the eyes, the persona. the abortion topic, of course, is a daring one to talk about for a film by a filipino to be watched by filipinos. abortion is completely illegal and prohibited here, with penalties for those who perform or obtain one. the film successfully tackled a sensitive subject in good taste. i also saw the religious lady doctor character as a commentary on the non existent secularism in the country. that lady confronted with the sister was satisfying to watch.

Finally had a chance to watch this, i was meant to watch this when it was showing at the cinemas but so busy until recently saw news that it was gonna come out on Netflix so i was elated. Haha.I like it so much, i love the cast in this film, and i love seeing this kind of quality in Filipino movies which is super rare these days. The story is about a young woman who has a dream that she pursued her whole life and suddenly she becomes pregnant which risks this dream, and now she has to weigh everything carefully because either which choice she pick will be life-changing. The whole movie revolves around that and we get to be introduced to the characters and the environment around her that is essential and will influence the choice she will make. Here we get to see a real picture even though the story is fictional, as filipinos you could almost grasp the realness out of this film and say, this is the REALITY but we don't have to embrace it, WE HAVE TO CHANGE IT. As a man, I always believed that i am no position to speak about what women should and shouldn't do about their bodies, but will absolutely support the concept of abortion. When we speak about abortion in a country that is like the Philippines, that is so centered on religion, abortion becomes a taboo, illegal and unethical. We also see these professionals, government leaders that support this kind of ideology that abortion is bad blah blah blah. This film is a great commentary and an eye opener to what young women and women in general what they go through, and that abortion should become an option for all women in our society. I will just make it clear that i think this film is not pro abortion or anti life, without directly stating it, the film focuses on making better decisions, the importance of protection, sex is more common than we think which is ironic in the Philippines that is so religious but that’s ok, this country just needs proper education and thats it. PS. If you are going to argue with me about me being ok about abortion or use of protection, I’m going to tell you this, how dare you bring a life in this world, in this country that cant do anything about poverty, cant do anything about corrupt politicians, cant vote right, doesn't have an accessible healthcare and on top of that, if you’re a man, stfu, and if you’re a woman, who is not ready, physically, mentally and financially, Ari and that young girl doesn’t deserve to live like that, on the streets or getting abused. But if you are, financially stable, mentally stable and physically stable with a nice and healthy environment to grow a living thing then go fucking crazy.

In spite of her past controversies, Maris Racal's performance in this film is the very reason why she remains in the spotlight. Her acting as Sunshine is spectacular. The story requires someone who is capable of letting the viewers feel the heaviness of her pain, the agony, and the hope of standing up for yourself and for what you want, and she made us feel all of that. And though I may not completely agree with everything that's pointed out here, I really admire Jadaone's attempt and bravery at addressing such a taboo topic, not just in the Philippines but the rest of the world. Being prayerful and always going to church do not give us the right to see ourselves as being more morally upright than others. When you put all of that aside, Sunshine is just a teenager who regretfully made a mistake and who made a decision for herself, stood up for what she wanted, and spared the child from the resentment of a mom from being robbed of her own dreams, and of leading her to what could possibly be a miserable life.She knows she could be ridiculed for that decision, but she lived according to her own terms anyway. And we know that in the end, she is happy, and that's all that matters.
You’d know toxic pinoy kasama mo if they were rooting against Sunshine the whole time.

ang hirap maging babae parang pasan mo ang mundo.ilang minuto pa lang sa pelikula, ramdam mo na kaagad, pinakita na ni direk tonet. una, yung kawalan ng akses sa impormasyong pangkalusugan. karamihan ng babae, katulad ni sunshine, umaasa lang sa sabi-sabi. libo-libong babae ang kumakapit sa peligro ng pagpapalaglag: ilegal na gamot, hilot, o pribadong clinic.pangalawa, babae rin ang makatutulong sa kapwa babae ngunit babae rin ang pwedeng magtulak sayo sa kapahamakan. parehong biktima at minsan instrumento ng isang macho-pyudal na lipunan. maraming eksena ang nagpapakita ng pagtutulungan: si aling nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, buena mano kahit gabi na, may tawad pa dahil alam niyang gipit ka. si ate sa motel, kahit anong sungit, kukuha pa rin ng tulong dahil duguan ka. pero sa kabila ng tulong, nariyan ang mga babaeng nakakulong pa rin sa lumang paniniwala: si doktorang victim-blamer at relihiyosa, yung nanay na nagpapadala sa lalaki niyang kapatid kapalit ng kaligtasan ng kanyang babaeng anak. sa lipunang matagal nang pinagsasamantalahan ang kababaihan, nakakalungkot isipin na nasanay na tayo sa ganitong galaw.maganda ang sunshine, pero higit pa doon, kailangan itong mapanood ng bawat babae—bata man, teenager, o nakatatanda. dito pa lang makikita na may kailangang baguhin sa sistema; hindi tayo dapat masanay sa ganitong kalagayan.sunshine, pangalan mo pa lang, alam mong isa itong pelikula na magpapaalala na lilipas din ang pagpasan ng mundo. para sa lahat ng babae, sabi nga ni sunshine, "laban lang tayo. kapit lang tayo." sa dulo, malinaw ang mensahe: hindi babae ang dapat magbago, kundi ang sistemang matagal nang mali ang takbo.

Ang hirap maging babaeng puno ng pangarap. The film Sunshine (2024) resonated with me because it honestly depicts how unforgiving reality can be. It shows how quickly people judge young women, often before they even have a chance to breathe or ask for help. The film also makes painfully clear how the lack of reproductive rights pushes women toward risky, sometimes dangerous choices. You can almost feel Sunshine being boxed in on all sides, not because she did anything wrong, but because society refuses to give her real options.Women in the Philippines face judgment, limited choices, and immense pressure around pregnancy. And the film makes a point I strongly agree with: no government or religious institution should dictate what a woman does with her body. Those decisions belong to the person living that reality, not to people watching from a distance.Sunshine made the right choice. Sobrang taboo sa Pilipinas ang usapang abortion, pero at least the child didn’t grow up feeling guilty or resenting their mother for what might have happened if they hadn’t been born. It’s better for a child to know they were truly wanted, rather than feeling like the product of someone else’s dilemma. Constantly being told they’re a blessing can’t replace the sense of being genuinely chosen.Sana ma-gets ng lahat si Sunshine.

SOBRA SOBRANG GANDA NG PELIKULA NI DIREK TONETsa sobrang ganda i had to watched it 2 times. hindi ko alam ma fefeel ko after kong unang panuodin ito, sobrang lungkot at bigat dahil alam kong hindi lang ito basta pelikula kundi realidad ng bawat babae, bawat tao, at bawat batang muntik makita ang mundo.i love the jeepney scene, It was a really heavy scene, I think it was me interpreting na iniisip na ni sunshine na 'bakit??, bakit saakin pa? baka hindi na ako makasama sa olympics na ito- bakit?' maybe there was this question of confusion na kahit siya hindi niya masagot.. na kahit saan siya dalhin ni kuya manong at ibaba dala dala parin niya talaga ito (yung bata)I loved how this film not only focuses on abortion rights, but also shows many of the real problems in the Philippines.Napakita talaga kung gaano ka–fucked up ang sistema ng mga hospital dito—kulang sa pasilidad, nagsisiksikan, at ang daming pwedeng mamatay dahil sa ganitong sistema. Sobrang nakakagalit isipin na sa hospital ka pa dapat may chance mabuhay, pero doon ka pa pwedeng bawian.It also shows the messed-up beliefs of people who think it’s “easy” to raise a child. Yung mga nagsasabing “takot mo sa una lang ‘yan” at “biyaya ‘yan ng Panginoon.” I’m not against their beliefs—they’re entitled to them—but I find it toxic. Paano mo kayang sabihin sa isang tao na “biyaya” ito kung galing sa karumaldumal at walang kamalay-malay na kasalanan ng ibang tao? Paano mo sasabihing tanggapin niya na lang ito?I think not everything can be called a blessing. And I don’t think it’s fair to say “binigay ito ng Diyos” kahit mali ang pinanggalingan. When I watched it for the second time, ang dami ko talagang na-notice. Naging malaking tanong sa’kin kung *paano* at *saan* narealize ni Sunshine ang lahat.At first, akala ko si Annika (yung batang babae) was her inner child someone who guides her, the version of herself who dreamed of becoming an Olympian but never got the chance.Yung part sa ilalim ng tulay, nung lumabas na si Ariana — doon ko talaga na-connect. I think Sunshine realized it too. Habang hinahanap niya si Sunshine, hindi siya mapakali. Naging question ko rin talaga kung paano kilala ni Sunshine si Ariana if kakakita niya lang dito? Diba??!And what Ariana said made sense. May part sa movie na sinabi niya na ayaw niyang bumalik sa bahay dahil wala namang may pakialam sa kanya. sabi ni Sunshine doon “Hindi, naguguluhan lang siya.” i think she was referring to marygrace.The conversation between Ariana and Annika (the little girl) really altered my brain.The way they pictured the life they could’ve had in a world they will never get to be part of sobrang bigat..And that line, “Pangarap ko kung anong pangarap ni Sunshine,” grabe.sobrang naiyak ako sa part ng ate niya at si sunshine, grave sobrang galing talaga ni direk tonet. tinanggap at inintindi niya ito ng buong buo mabuhay talaga ang pelikulang ito.Lastly! finally!(ang sobrang daming yap)the last part, yung “gets ko na.” Those words explained everything.It felt like Sunshine was saying,“I hope naiintindihan mo kung bakit ko ‘to ginagawa.”And i know that’s exactly how she felt.Maybe the girl can’t have the world.But no—actually, she did.Because she gave Sunshine the world she always wanted, even if she couldn’t have it herself. "Pangarap ko kung anong pangarap niya"That “gets ko na” part really hit me.Sobrang bigat. And right after that line,there was a cut showing Sunshine in this moment of relief and it says so much kahit na walang description kahit walang explanation.i love this film na gustong kong yakapin si sunshine at hawakan ang kamay niya at sabihing "hindi mo ito kasalanan"

i have a lot to say about this movie but if i were to describe it in one sentence, it would be: ang hirap maging babae, at mas mahirap maging babae sa pilipinas. i can tell that this story is well-written. it is my first time watching a filipino movie so realistic and women-focused. this movie depicted the struggles of being a woman—not just sexually, but in all aspects. women are expected to be perfect—capable of carrying the weight, not expected to make any mistakes despite everything hateful is being thrown at us. we are expected to meet and be the standard even if it is out of our capabilities. dahil? babae tayo. at kung ‘di man natin maabot ‘yon, isa tayong kahihiyan. dahil nga, mga babae tayo. kalaban natin ang relihiyon, gobyerno, at bansa na mapang-husga. ika nga ni coach, drown out the noise. but that is not the case. even if you force yourself to be apathetic, you’ll still hear the the voices of the people. mga kabataan nga naman ngayon, hindi na makapag-pigilbawal ‘yan sa batas ng Diyoshindi ko ma-a-admit kaibigan mo dahil illegal ‘yonkung buntis ka, i’ll have to kick you out of my rosteranother thing i loved about this movie is that it was shot in manila and covereed many social issues—making it even more relatable to us filipino. especially when it comes to poverty, dito talaga natin masasabi na mahirap maging mahirap. the film showed the reality of life for those without privilege—struggling to find a tricycle, not having enough money for basic needs, and doing everything we can just to earn a little. even parents are driven to the point of selling their own children.some men, on the other hand, can run away from everything. nakabuntis? kasalanan pa rin natin ‘yang mga babae! kesyo hindi tayo nananamit nang maayos, kesyo tayo raw ang may mali kahit sila naman ang tumakbo sa responsibilidad. here, i saw how cowardly some men can be—afraid to take responsibility for their wrongdoings, and always ready to cling to anyone who will shield them from consequences.lastly, i love how the kids represented their inner child—sunshine’s bata symbolizing her dream of becoming an olympian, while menggay’s bata represented the lgbtq community and her longing to get revenge on those who wronged her. each represented their dreams, no matter how impossible they seemed in their circumstances. each represented their dreams, clinging to whatever little piece of themselves the world hasn’t taken away.

Whenever Sunshine waves around her colorful ribbon while flowing and gliding through the mat, it's not just a flawless routine at stake. It's the little bit of life growing inside her.Maris Racal anxiously walks through the streets and markets of Quiapo, looking for a way out in the form of illegal drugs hidden beside statues of Mama Mary. Sunshine knows what she wants —to be on the Olympic stage, but the world around her from the kid who knocked her up, to the saleslady who's "helping" her, to her sister who also got pregnant, may have different opinions.Sunshine stops by the church, pleading for clarity but also possibly for forgiveness and absolution. But a ghost in the form a kid that calls her a "murderer" haunts her the most, popping in and out like a conscience. She was nervously waiting to see what Sunshine would finally decide, and so was I.Pelikulang Pinoy

Sunshine saying “hindi pa ako ready maging nanay” really hit me. No woman should ever be forced into something she isn’t ready for. And yes I agree with abortion. Every woman has the right to choose what happens to her own body and her own life. No man, or anyone else, gets to decide that for us. And to the men who can’t even take responsibility for being a father? Yeah… fck you.

"gets ko na"that line literally sent me into the abyss. going into the film, i was so confused about the little girl following sunshine. i thought she was sunshine’s inner child, like a guide through the mess, reminding her who she was and what she actually wanted. but when they introduced ariana, the kid that “bata” playmate during that night, everything started clicking.then the incident happened. mary grace (rhed bustamante) tried to get an abortion, and her baby died. when we saw ariana recognize mary grace, and then later, at the hospital, the nurse announced the baby didn’t make it… ariana just disappeared. that’s when it hit me: ariana and bata was supposed to represent the baby, their baby. it felt ironic at first because you’re torn between “should i feel bad?” and “should i feel sad about the literal premise of the film?” but then bata said to sunshine, “gets ko na,” and the whole film just punched my soul.maris racal is easily one of the best actresses of this generation, and sunshine proves that. the film is raw, very indie pinoy cinema vibes, and it works. it also doesn’t shy away from the heavy stuff, like how brutal the philippines can be when judging teenage pregnancy and abortion. the shame, the gossip, the pressure to “keep it,” the lack of safe spaces… the film shows how hard it is for girls to make choices about their own bodies when everyone feels entitled to comment.i just kinda wish they explored sunshine being a public athlete more, like the public eye, the rumors, the judgment she’d face online and her community as the time goes by. the ending showing her making it to the sea games was nice, but i feel like addressing the backlash and the pressure could’ve made the story even stronger.overall: great film. beautiful, painful, and honest. i love you, sunshine.

I have a lot of feelings to share about this beautiful and heartbreaking film. Truly a big eye-opener to many Filipinos.Women carry a biological physical pain we are given the moment we are born. Period, childbirth, postpartum, etc. But we also carry the pain this world and men cause. The pain men should be held accountable for. Emotional labour, cultural and religious expectations, rape, pregnancy, forms of abuse, etc. It's like our suffering is pre-written, pre-approved, and expected. And yet the world still has all the audacity to treat us as if we're lesser, fragile, dramatic, overreacting. I think I will never be able to understand the logic of a world that demands strength from women and then punishes us for being strong.Like Sunshine and Menggay, a lot of women out there don't have choices. A lot of women are already deprived of basic rights before they even learn to speak. But then again, society still keeps finding new ways to take more from them.The hypocrisy of the Filipinos in this film is also insane but couldn’t be more well depicted. (It’s actually so much worse in real life.) Filipinos will praise God with one hand and strip women of autonomy with the other. Anti-abortion because “God said so,” but silent about abuse, poverty, rape cases, or the girls forced into motherhood long before they even have the chance to understand themselves. They defend unborn children better than they defend the living women who have to endure the burden of carrying them. Because if they don’t, you will judge them. You will shame them. How is that love? How is that morality? Abortion is criminalized, but sexual abuse cases get dismissed.It’s exhausting. It’s enraging.To all of the Sunshines out there, gets na gets ko kayong lahat. The world keeps underestimating and shaming us, but here we are, still standing, still surviving.To end this, I want to share that one monologue in Fleabag that came back to me after watching this film and inspired my entire review:"Women are born with pain built in. It's our physical destiny—period pains, sore boobs, childbirth. We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives. Men don't. They have to seek it out. They invent all these gods and demons so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own. And then they create wars so they can feel things and touch each other and when there aren't any wars they can play rugby. We have it all going on in here, inside. We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years, and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens? The menopause comes. The fucking menopause comes and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world. Yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you're free. No longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts. You're just a person."

hindi ko alam kung ilan at paano ko i-rate tong film na to, kasi tangina. una sa lahat, tangina ng mga lalake. pangalawa, ang fucked up talaga ng opinion ng mga pinoy kapag tungkol sa abortion to the point na nakacenter nalang siya kay God, when in fact, kung sino pa yung pala simba sila pa ang mas lason kung mag-isip. may karapatan ang babae kung ano ang gustong gawin nila sa katawan nila. kahit pa sabihin na, oo, nagseggs sila kaya automatic na alam nila kung ano ang mabubuo, pero hindi yun sapat para sabihin mong masama ang abortion. gaya ng scene na sinabi ni miggy na huwag na gumamit ng condom kasi sa labas niya ipuputok, pero anong nangyare?gaya ng nasa pelikula, yung nabuntis ng tito niya. kung masama sa mata ng Diyos ang paglaglag, paano pa kaya ang kasalanan nung tito niya? nagdebate kami noon about sa abortion, ang sabi ko gagawin ko kasi sarili ko ang iniisip ko, na hindi ko kaya at hindi ako ready. pero anong sabi saakin? selfish daw ako kasi hindi ko inisip ang bata kahit pa galing grape cases yan.nagaaral ako ng nursing, at base sa mga pinagaralan ko, habang nasa loob pa yan ng sinapupunan, hindi yan bata. fetus yan. hindi naman puso ang unang nabubuo, kundi ang utak. hindi ko maintindihan kung bakit ang hirap maging babae sa bansang to. wala kayong pake sa mga corrupt na politicians kasi may binibigay na pera sainyo, e kung sa tutuusin galing din naman sa tax natin yon. pero sa abortion na wala naman kayo noong may nangyayare sakanila, kung makapag salita para bang kayo ang mag-bubuntis, mag-hihirap, at mag-papaanak.

the film moves slowly, almost cautiously, letting you sit with people who are trying to hold their lives together even when everything around them keeps slipping sideways. nothing is exaggerated; it all feels painfully ordinary in the way real lives are. the characters are not shouting for answers, they are just trying to make sense of the days piling up. there is this constant push and pull between wanting to break free and accepting that the world has edges you cannot always escape.no big revelation, no sudden salvation. just a slow unraveling-that honesty hits harder than any dramatic twist could. thank you

It was true when they said that this was a brave film. To be one of the first films in pinoy cinema to explore a pro-choice and an unwanted pregnancy narrative is indeed brave, especially when you know the Philippines’ socio-political and religious climate around topics regarding sex, female desires, pregnancy, bodily autonomy, and parenthood.There were unfortunately some parts of the film that felt like they didn’t work.I’m not sure but Sunshine’s decision to abort felt too quick. And her dream to be an Olympian felt underexplored and more of her coach’s. We’re told rather than shown that it was hers.The inclusion of Annika Co whose character can be interpreted as Sunshine’s subconscious/ego or unborn child or whatnot sometimes felt irritating to watch (sorry not sorry). But I guess to reach more towards a predominantly Filipino audience and to highlight Sunshine still being a (teen) child who’s forced to confront the consequences of her choices by a child: worked? I don’t know. Not to mention that it felt a little silly to include two other characters, where one was another pregnant teen girl, that lowkey felt like their stories were being shoved down to the audience’s throats. And in the end, felt shallow. I just think that I hoped they showed more of the technicalities of her being an athlete. Rhythmic gymnastics is considered an elite sport. And when you consider it in the Philippine context – the film didn’t really show what was at stake of being an athlete in this sport. The film’s strong aspects are definitely on the score, cinematography (particularly to highlight the corners of Manila as this chaotic, packed, and cruel city), and of course: Maris’ performance as Sunshine. There were scenes that hit hard and heavy. The irony of abortion drugs sold and found in the street outside a church. The motel scene to show Sunshine’s quiet desperation. Her final rehearsal for her routine before her “gets ko na” scene with Annika (where I cried unfort bcz luteal phase duh).The film does show you a glimpse of the unforgiving reality of what many Filipino women go through everyday: teenage pregnancy, overcrowded and underfunded public hospitals, and the lack of comprehensive sexuality education about sexuality and sexual and reproductive health. It lacked, sure. But I guess, for pinoy cinema to start tackling difficult topics such as this: it’s a start.

a well-crafted filipino movie made by a woman for women. napakagaling ni maris (OH MY GOD TALAGA) napaka oscar worthy ng performance niya. so happy to see xy and rhed too! ang galing ng buong casts! production design team deserves so much flowers too!ramdam na ramdam sa Sunshine gaano kahirap maging babae sa isang patriyarkal na lipunan. ramdam na ramdam din ang korupsyon ng gobyerno: kalagayan ng mahihirap & bulok na healthcare system ng pilipinas. sobrang daming issues ang natackle on this movie (and i believe they were not surface level at all). nakakalungkot at nakakagalit ang realizations 'to the point na maiiyak ka talaga (i Can vouch. lmao)."Naiintindihan mo ba ako?" "Gets ko na."i interpreted the child as her inner conscience kasi pinakita how societal standards (ex: religion na sobrang evident sa movie) affected her decision-making. thats why gustong gusto ko yung linya na yan, kasi sunshine felt na everything was already settled for her and all noises were finally shut out. mas mahalaga parin talaga ang mga pangarap niya para sa kanya.this movie begs the watchers to Be More Understanding. ganun lang kasimple. intindi na hindi lahat ay pare-pareho; at for sunshine & menggay's cases, intindi na hindi lahat ay handang maging ina. unawa lang sa sitwasyon ng iba. tunay naman na abortion is not for all, pero may iba parin na Kailangan ito. why restrict the choices of others diba? legalizing accessible and safe abortion helps girls like sunshine and menggay. no one deserves to be go through those levels of pain. direk tonet's best work yet imo!!!! sunshine is indeed a movie that can move you + can change one's thoughts about abortion. altho i believe sobrang long way to go pa natin. malayo pa tayo sa pinaglalaban natin, ngunit walang imposible. :)

“naiintindihan mo ba ako?”oo, gets ko na.”this film is raw, relevant and worth seeing. it goes to show that it’s not about changing one’s political belief, but about having radical kindness. the film doesn’t intend you in changing sides, but it teaches you to be more understanding of people’s choices. i’ve known sunshines in my life - a co-worker, a co-worker’s sister, close friends, and old classmates back home. and it’s just sad just how much they were under scrutiny for, for something they should have total control over. it infuriates me even further to realize that back home, abortions are not accessible, and are illegal even. oftentimes the women are frowned upon because of our country’s conservative and religious culture, they face shame and judgement first before they can even get to decide of their own autonomy. meanwhile, the men that are responsible can get to walk away from all scrutiny just because it’s not theirs to hold and carry. to all the sunshines that we know, get to know and may not know yet, they deserve to talk about these things openly, not in secret, not in shame. sunshine reminds us that we definitely have a long way to go. yet a little empathy can go a long way.

I want to start this by saying what an incredible film this is. Not only does it highlight the pressing inadequacy of women's healthcare in the Philippines but importantly, it educates its audience on women’s decisions on their bodies and the urgent need for reproductive rights. I don't remember where I first heard of it, but the idea has always stayed with me: for every abortion, miscarriage, or infertility, if a women desires to be a mother, it will come to her at the right time—in one form or another.And I think this film beautifully echoes hints of that belief.The part where Sunshine asks the little girl, "Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?" And the child replies, "Gets ko na," feels like a simple, but so profound of an exchange of words. It feels like a hand that's gently soothing a wound she's been carrying all this time. A wound that asked to be seen with the nuances that came with it, not the fantasies the society chooses to blind themselves with.Another thing that stood out to me abt this film is how it challenges the viewers to confront the expectations forced onto women simply for existing. Not with judgement, but with a silence that understands what it means to be human.I just love that this film respects women's choices. It doesn't force a message or a narrative that motherhood is the only path to walk through once it enters in a woman's life. Instead, it says that your life, dreams, and timing are all yours regardless of what everyone thinks nor says abt it.Because to be a mother means to be ready mentally, physically, and financially. Love alone isn't enough to carry a life, just a majority of its suffering.

I loved it to bits. The Philippines has always been against abortions due to its religious nature, so I love that this is the kind of film that will spark conversations about the said controversial yet necessary topic. I for one can never fully give my stance since I am religious but also because I am not a woman. I've always believed that the woman is the one that should decide on what to do with an unwanted pregnancy. So, to see pros and cons of wanting to abort a child as well as choosing to go through abortion was quite engaging and I understand things more now. To see the horrors of using illegal ways of abortion was eye-opening, in all honesty. The film did a fantastic job of showcasing these issues, as the message was loud, clear and perfect. I'd say that my only issue with this film is that I wish the story was more fleshed out in a way. Also, it was blatantly obvious that the mysterious (and annoying, mind you) little girl was Sunshine's supposed daughter. I would've honestly preferred it if it wasn't made obvious.

First Letterboxd essay — I had an itch to scratch so bad with this one. Also medyo late, crammer kasi year-end na :) Right off the bat, I knew how reviews of this film would look like. At hindi naman nagkamali. This film is highly praised, receiving remarks such as masterpiece, brave, and a stepping stone.Yet to my surprise, a few share the same sentiments I had, thoughts that were brewing in me while watching Sunshine. Kaya rin ang hirap buuin ng review na ito (bukod sa hindi naman talaga ako nag-eessay sa plataporma na ito), kasi ayoko maging echo lamang.Anyways, just for the sake of sharing kahit onti:(1) I agree that the supposed personified child is, safe to say, contradictory. Kahit may explanation si Direk Jadaone, it still felt conflicting and made the film unsure of itself.(2) The introduction of some characters felt out of place. In some aspect parang chess yan, character placement and arcs matter, so the player must be aware of their moves.(3) The slap in the face commentary on religion felt overdone. Sayang ang parts and points na pwede pang mahimay.Oh diba, dami niyang sinasabi. But in all honesty, I really felt the need to essay the hell out of this review. Mahalaga sa akin ang usapang SRH at syempre mahalaga rin sa akin na maging diskurso ito.And dahil diyan, here’s a point I feel no one else has raised. Personally, it felt like under-researched ang pelikula. Bakit? Mababaw pa ang na-capture nitong realidad ng abortion at ang hirap na nadadanas ng kababaihan sa kalusugan. These are things you would know agad with one simple search on Reddit. Gets ba? (Lol) And to think na mas layered and complex pa dapat ito sa sitwasyon ni Sunshine, as a student-athlete with financial instability. Sayang lang, ano? Syempre may good points din ang Sunshine sa pananaw ko. Visually, it did its thing. Acting, no doubt, great talents, especially Maris and Jennica. The fact that I watched this with my parents and that they were genuinely interested and concerned about the film is a good point.Sa dulo naman, baka expectations ko rin ang rason kaya ko ito naisip. From here on, sana hindi laging hanggang unang bato lang. Here’s to hoping na makahakbang at makausad na tayo.

How would she even know? lol aside from that, we could’ve explored more of why this sport is so important to her instead of adding a subplot (that 13 yr old girl case) that makes her situation feel less serious.her feelings and reasons are all valid but that subplot makes her look careless and kinda dumb lol so it’s hard to root for her tbh also, her imaginary child looks cute, healthy, and fun to talk with... why would she think of aborting her if that’s what her imaginary child is going to look like growing up?????? the imaginary child should reflect the life she can’t give or the pressure she feels or at least something burdensome that is so much worse, not some fantasy lolz. gets na niya, hinayaan niya, tinaggap nalang niya ang fate niya kahit imaginary siya.

I’ll be honest, underwhelming siya for me. Siguro tumaas lang expectations ko dahil sa dami ng reviews na nakita ko sa social media (na hindi ko binasa para iwas spoiler) at syempre dahil sa haba ng theatrical run niya. What I genuinely liked were the performances. They hired competent actors, and it shows. And since marami na rin akong napanood na Jadaone films, andun pa rin ’yun trademark angst niya—and I love that for her.Ang hindi ko kinaya ay ’yun imaginary children. Siguro kasi sobrang dami ko nang nakitang ganitong atake sa short films at full-length lalo na kapag tungkol sa abortion kaya hindi na bago sa paningin ko. I get kung bakit siya ginamit as a plot device to feel “innovative,” especially with a message that wants to tell the masses na okay lang piliin ang sarili at magpa-abort. Importanteng mensahe ’yun.Kaso… hindi ako nadala emotionally. May mga babae akong kakilala na nagpa-abort at grabe ’yun pinagdaanan nila. Compared sa mga kwentong narinig ko, ang nipis lang ng emotional experience ni Sunshine sa film. Kaya siguro nainis ako sa imaginary children na atake. The feeling itself of learning you're pregnant tapos mag-decide to get an abortion already carries so many complex emotions. Hindi mo na kailangan idikit pa ’yun mga bata to prove a point.Hindi ko rin nagustuhan na parang ang babaw ng pagkakahandle sa kwento nung batang na-rape ng tito niya. Pakiramdam ko ibang pelikula dapat ’yun—isang pelikula na mas malalim at mas handang i-tackle ’yun bigat ng topic.Feeling ko kung lalaki ka, baka mas "oks" itong film para sayo. Pero bilang babae… parang kulang pa. Hay. Miss ko ’yun docu days ni Jadaone. Can we bring her back? Charot.

I’m very grateful at this film’s attempt to keep the narrative always in favor of pro-choice.For a recent narrative on a young woman’s choice about her pregnancy, this film plays a lot of modern elements well. Social media is used several times throughout the start of the film, but none of it is cliché or abhorrent. Each social media is used in a very relatable way, which kind of shocked me but it was a feature of the film I really appreciated. Sunshine’s panic is so realistic and grounding too, the performance is amazing. In terms of tonal shifting, the film does a really great job at keeping it’s theme and message intense and suffocating, much like Sunshine’s need to make a decision. It should ALWAYS be the woman’s choice!!

ive been waiting for this to come out on netflix and it is honestly such a GREAT commentary on anti-abortion laws in the philippines and in religious/third world countries as a whole. it truly is a privilege to have the right to our own bodies.the writing of this movie was quite interesting and i believe the children held so much significance to the development and the decision making of the main lead. i believe they are the make-believe consciousness of the “thing” (lets stop calling them babies PLEASE) inside the main lead and the 13yo girl, and i LOVED being so confused and then realising this later on. “drown out the noise” something we need to tell ourselves more often than not. we shouldn’t listen to outside opinions of what to do with ourselves and our own bodies. it is the happiest way to live and love life.i hold this movie very close to my heart and living in a country where abortion is legal is a HUGE privilege and i look forward to the days where religious doctrine dont run the government and put its citizens in a chokehold. religious or not, DON’T tell ANYONE what to do with their bodies, we are all in different circumstances and have wants/dreams/aspirations we’d like to pursue for our own happiness and that’s not selfish.

my best friend sent a message in the group chat saying “guys please don’t ever get pregnant” fresh after watching this. i laughed in my mind thinking how is that even gonna happen. but here i am sobbing like a child and wishing that nobody ever gets pregnant against their will. what a demented, horrifying, and pathetic world we live in. this film plunged my heart deep into my guts from the very beginning. it’s already hard being a girl and then you have systems in place that form a fist around your throat. this was so well made that none of it looked fake. i mean it’s so funny to see the juxtaposition of the church and the “pamparegla” vendors that are still there today. maybe it’s more sad really but that is the reality. i don’t know i guess it is so hard to explain the horrors of being a woman. men get to conveniently be selfish as part of their nature but putting yourself first as a girl needs an apology from god. men regard laws only when they can deny women any autonomy, but break them with ease for their own disgusting desires and freely laugh about it with their friends. i am so glad this film ended the way it did but i am also very sad and angry that girls who meet the same fate have to suffer maybe even worse than this. and that’s when i know god is not a woman.

Society claims to protect the “unborn child,” yet the conversation often leaves out the women whose bodies, health, and futures are directly involved. It feels unsettling to watch how easily society dismisses the experiences of women, as if their lives become secondary the moment they become pregnant. I can’t ignore how deeply this connects to the patriarchal norms I’ve grown up seeing. From subtle expectations to outright judgment, there is a long history of controlling women’s bodies and decisions. The shame placed on those who consider or seek abortion is not just personal; it is cultural and religious, embedded in systems that teach us to shame and question women’s choices instead of supporting them. This made us more aware of how easily society turns compassion into condemnation when it comes to reproductive health.P'wede ba pag walang matres, 'wag na bumoses?

hindi ko alam kung anong mas mabigat habang pinapanood ko Sunshine — yung katahimikan ng mga babaeng walang mapagsabihan, o yung ingay ng mundong ang bilis humusga pero ang bagal tumulong. Jadaone films always stab softly, pero ito? Parang dahan-dahang hinihiwa yung dibdib, layer by layer, para ipakita yung takot, pangarap, at kahihiyang matagal nang nakatago sa ilalim ng “ok lang ako.”this is the kind of film na hindi mo papanoorin para gumaan ang loob mo, papanoorin mo siya para maalala kung gaano kabigat mabuhay bilang babae sa bansang ayaw umamin na may mali sa sistemang sinasamba nito. Sunshine doesn’t preach. it just stands there, raw and trembling, asking the kind of questions we’re trained to avoid:Paano ka pipili kung lahat ng choice mo ay kasalanan sa mata ng iba?Paano ka lalaban kung mismong katawan mo ang pinaparusahan?Maris Racal is devastating in ways na hindi loud pero lumalalim. hindi siya yung tipikal na dramatic heroine — she’s simply a girl suspended between a dream and a reality that keeps shrinking her choices. her silence says more than any monologue could. every frame feels like a confession: hesitant, trembling, pero totoo.and what struck me most wasn’t the gymnastics, or even the central issue of abortion. it was the ache between who we want to become and what our circumstances force us to be. nakakapagod maging babae sa Pilipinas — laging may moral lesson, laging monitored, laging may takot na isang maling galaw lang, tapos na ang lahat. parang ang liit liit ng mundo mo kahit ang laki laki ng pangarap mo.Sunshine doesn’t romanticize any of this. walang sermon, walang cinematic gloss. just a raw, unfiltered look at how dreams bruise under a society na mas mabilis manghusga kaysa umintindi. the film’s imperfections — the loose ends, the uneven metaphors, the sometimes rushed stakes — oddly work in its favor. because real life isn’t clean. hindi linear ang trauma. hindi laging malinaw ang choice. and maybe that’s the point: that we’re all navigating a world built not on empathy, but on fear and control.in the end, Sunshine feels less like a movie and more like a mirror — one that forces you to sit with the darkness until you finally admit na masakit talaga ang liwanag. it’s an eye-opener not because it shocks, but because it whispers truths we’ve mastered the art of ignoring.a film worth watching, not because it entertains, but because it confronts. because it nudges you to look beyond the screen and into the world we built… and ask, Bakit ganito?And more importantly — hanggang kailan?

Ang hirap maging babae.Sunshine touched on some of the most sensitive and difficult struggle of being a woman... especially in the Philippines. One of which is the inaccessibility to women-friendly environments, may it be in your household, in public, at the hospital, at school. And when I say women-friendly, it's the support for the emotional and mental consequences, and physical choices for oneself. We suffer consequences that are beyond our own control but when we decide how to deal with it, our surroundings tend to vilify us for our choices. But Sunshine shows us that we are in charge of our own choices however we like it. We know our bodies, our dreams, our capacities the best. Salamat Sunshine at nagwagi pa rin tayo sa pagtatapos ng pelikula.

abortion is a topic i usually avoid because it’s morally, socially, and emotionally heavy. what i loved about this film is how it didn’t shy away from that weight, showing how complicated it really is especially in a conservative, Catholic society like ours where abortion is still illegal and pregnant teens are often judged and shamed. i liked how they showed that harsh reality here. and i also really liked Maris Racal’s performance, i think she brought so much depth and vulnerability to her role.i’m a Christian, so of course i have my own beliefs. but honestly, i don’t think life is always black and white. i do believe every woman should have a say over her own body. we shouldn't force someone into a choice they aren't ready for. if she isn't ready to be a mother, she may not be able to provide the care a child deserves. sometimes, the bravest and kindest choice a woman can make is the one who chooses the best for herself, who considers her life and circumstances. at the end of the day, it's not our body, not our life, not our consequences so we shouldn't judge. we're called to love, to show mercy, and to respect the dignity and choice of others. after all... autonomy is a lifeline.

"A woman’s body is not a vessel only to bend for a man’s morals nor a canvas for a man’s shame."Imagine a young woman who is chasing her dreams, but being struck down by laws made by patriarchal society which restricts and shames her for taking decisions for her own body. We failed our women! Antoinette jadaone’s SUNSHINE is powerful , poignant, beautiful, and yet heartbreaking which showcases the crisis of young age pregnancy, the taboo and the shame comes with it, hypocrisy of society and being resilient and standing up for yourself and for your dreams over anyone. It’s not a fairytale, but a hard hitting truth. There is no ending to this cycle of shame for women who are bred in this macho-feudal society, how religion and social taboos remain a bottleneck than a savior. But the movie overcomes those things so bravely and leads a courageous path to tell women to take their rights in their own hands. I really loved the idea of her imaginative child being with her all the time, giving her strength, and emotional support and that final moment between those two is tear jerking. What most people think it was a sad ending, but actually it was not, it was an inspiring ending which reaffirms that every woman should have the right to make a decision for herself. Abortion is actually less cruel than bringing a baby in this hell hole and making its life shitty, when its parents are not capable of taking care of it mentally, physically, financially and emotionally. You are not only ruining one life, but multiple lives.2025 Movies Ranked

Biktima lang din talaga si Sunshine ng circumstances.Sunshine is just one of the many girls in the society who still get solely blamed for the acts that should also be blamed on the boys. This movie is not just your typical feminist film; it speaks of depth, especially on the challenges of women and the dilemma they face. Isa pa sa nagustuhan ko sa film na to is yung pinadama niya yung hopelessness ni Sunshine. Di naman sa ayaw ko ng movies na binibigyan ng pag-asa ang main character sa huli, pero this served something different and it worked. It's when she was forced to choose between two things, and ended up choosing what's best for her, even if it meant—basta. May empathy ka pa din kay Sunshine kahit labag sa iyong kalooban ang kanyang gagawin (as a Filipino Catholic).Sobrang ironic lang din ng title, which I admire. this film is a deeply realistic exploration of what it means to be a woman in the philippines—a country where patriarchy, tradition, religion, and economic pressure converge in ways that make womanhood both exhausting and precarious. Importantly, the film is not a pro-life statement, nor does it romanticize suffering or prescribe motherhood as a moral imperative. instead, it shows that the choices women face are complex, constrained, and often invisible to those who hold power.it also addresses the ways women navigate survival under these pressures. it shows that women are often responsible for both care work and emotional labor without recognition or support. the everyday reality of harassment, unsafe streets, economic vulnerability, and social judgment creates conditions in which reproductive choice becomes a deeply personal but politically fraught decision. the film does not moralize these choices; it presents them with nuance, empathy, and a refusal to simplify the stakes into a pro-life narrative.at higit sa lahat, thank you, sunshine, sa pagpukpok ng bote sa tito.

This is a blistering, gut-punching film that doesn’t just ask difficult questions about bodily autonomy and Olympic dreams; it screams them into the humid, chaotic reality of Manila. It’s a brave, essential piece of cinema that confronts the devastating consequences of living in a country where a woman’s control over her own body is perpetually under threat. The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking and utterly visceral—it’s relentless, trapping us inside Sunshine’s suffocating anxiety. Jadaone uses the oppressive visual texture of Quiapo’s crowded, sweltering streets—a perfect, gritty backdrop—to symbolize the labyrinthine journey of a young woman navigating impossible choices in a system designed to fail her.A massive and well-deserved standing ovation goes to the central performances. Maris Racal is devastating as the titular gymnast, embodying the crushing physical and emotional burden with every strained muscle and every desperate, silent plea. Her performance is a masterclass in controlled despair, capturing the agony of a lifetime of sacrifice being threatened in an instant. She is perfectly complemented by Annika Co’s mesmerizing, eerie, and unrelenting presence as the Kid—an unsettling narrative device that functions as both Sunshine’s internal critic and her desperate conscience. But let’s be real: the film’s rawest emotional hook comes from the shocking failure and apathy of the men around her. Their irresponsibility and sheer lack of accountability form a central, infuriating symbol of the patriarchal society that traps Sunshine.Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Every day feels like a battle against a society na paulit-ulit kang nilalagay sa kahon, insisting that your worth begins and ends with motherhood. Fuck the stigma na finoforce ang mga kababaihan into roles they never agreed to—parang automatic default na lang na dapat tahimik, dapat magtiis, dapat magpakamartir. Walang puwang para sa sariling pangarap, sariling katawan, sariling desisyon.Kaya sana mas umingay at mas mapag-usapan ang Reproductive Rights—hindi lang as a “women’s issue” but as a basic human right. This is about giving women the freedom to choose, the safety to seek care without judgment, and the dignity to exist without being shamed or controlled. Hanggang hindi natin tinatalakay nang seryoso ang mga ito, paulit-ulit lang tayo sa cycle ng stigma, trauma, at kawalan ng choices.Being a woman here shouldn't feel like a punishment. It shouldn't demand silence in exchange for survival. And yet, dito sa Pilipinas, ganun pa rin ang realidad—and that’s exactly why conversations like this matter.Putangina, Miggy/Miguel na naman!

DIREK TONET! YOU DID IT AGAIN!first of all, this should be more relevant than it is. being pro choice and growing up somehow religious, I know what other people think of abortion. especially yung mga sagradong katoliko. and that scene where sunshine went to church and immediately begged for forgiveness showcased EXACTLY THAT. (religious guilt!!!) it perfectly captures how the film isn’t just telling a story, but also reflecting a very real internal conflict na ang daming pinoy women who quietly deals with—yung clash between what you personally believe is right for your body and what your religion tells you is a sin. ang bigat pakinggan at panoorin."buntis lang ako, 'di to nakakahawa"kahit sa kapwa babae natin di mapipigilan yung judgement eh. kasi ganun yung pagpapalaki satin which is honestly fucked up. and that line hits SO hard because it’s a commentary on how society treats pregnancy like a moral failure instead of a situation that needs support, empathy, and actual options. the film shows how even other women, who should’ve been supporting you, end up policing each other because yun yung environment na kinalakihan natin. tangina diba?!!?also the irony of buying abortion pills at a church and you can't get a room at a motel ALONE?? the system makes it impossible for women to make decisions about their own bodies, pero at the same time they judge you for every workaround you try to do. also for young girls who get raped and still, THEY have to deal with the consequences. it exposes how the philippines forces women into shame, secrecy, and inconvenience—and then they act shocked when women feel unsafe or unsupported. it’s painfully real, and so, so on point.overall, i love this movie because it's honest in a way that most local films are too scared to be. some women don't have a choice, and it's important that WE DO HAVE A CHOICE. LET WOMEN HAVE THEIR DREAMS!!!

it’s beautiful. it’s brave. it’s heavy. it’s painful.it’s hard to be a woman. even harder to be a woman in the philippines.one of our professors once told us that our laws are deeply embedded into our culture. that’s why there’s no abortion in the philippines… because of our strong religious beliefs. if you choose abortion as your option, you’re immediately seen as a murderer, a sinner, by our legal system and, of course, by god’s law. the same religious beliefs hiding under the skirt of a patriarchal culture, doing nothing but scaring women away from their own choices.sana, ngayon, gets n’yo na. gets na ng marami.that this kind of decision has never, ever been easy.and i hope that now, we finally push for comprehensive sex education, free check-ups and contraceptives as reproductive health rights, and the legalization of abortion in the philippines, so no woman ever has to resort to unsafe methods while carrying the guilt and the danger all on her own.there are so many deep-rooted problems tied to abortion that we need to confront and tear down. only then can we truly set women free.

first of all, gusto ko rin ng isang ate geleen hands down to maris' restrained but deeply affecting performance. ramdam mo 'yong bawat pag-aalinlangan at takot—every moment where the world presses a little too hard on a young girl who only wanted to chase her dream.what makes the film even more powerful is its raw, unflinching portrayal of philippine society. the story exposes how reproductive rights in the country are entangled with religion, shame, and systemic neglect. it shows how a woman's body becomes a public issue the moment it no longer fits moral expectations, and how access to safe, affordable healthcare quickly turns into a privilege instead of a right. ultimately, sunshine champions a woman's right to her body, her choices, and her future—even in a society that constantly takes those away.

Nakalimutan ko maglagay ng mga bagay na gusto ko sa Sunshine. Habang pinapanood ko ang Sunshine, naisip ko na ganon talaga kainit, kalagkit, kausok ang Manila (3 months pa lang ako dito). Ganon ako kasweaty gaya ni Sunshine everytime naglalakad sya sa mga kalsada ng Manila. Napakahirap mabuhay sa lugar na to, at tiyak mas mahirap bumuhay ng tao rito. Ang galing mo talaga Maris!May lima akong ate, at gets ko kung gaano kahirap maging babae. At nakita ko sa kanila kung gano kahalaga magkaroon ng autonomy; at sana yon ang reality ng lahat ng kababaihan didto satin. Ang ganda ng mga pelikula gaya ng Sunshine, kasi napag-uusapan natin ang mga bagay na dapat noon pa man ay napag-uusapan na. Ang aborsyon ay karapatan ng kababaihan. Ang pagccriminalize dito ay nakakaendanger lang sa buhay ng mga babae. Thanks direk!Napaisip din ako kanina pagkatapos kong mapanood ang Sunshine, na sana in the future ay malegalize na talaga ang aborsyon, and if ito ay malelegalize man ay sana magkaroon din ako ng opportunities to train. Yon lang!

What stayed with me long after the credits rolled is how Sunshine understands the quiet corners of being young. The ones filled with fear you don’t even have language for yet, and the hope you still hold anyway. The film doesn’t chase shock value; instead, it trusts stillness, letting the soft ache of its characters speak for themselves.And then there’s that storyline about the 13-year-old girl, pregnant because of her own uncle. OH GOD. That shattered me. It’s horrifying, devastating, and the film doesn’t sanitize the truth of it. It shows how violence like that hides inside families, how children are left carrying consequences for sins that were never theirs. I felt so much grief and anger for that kid; it’s the kind of scene that makes you sit there and go quiet because it hurts in a very real way. The film’s exploration of choice, shame, and the pressure to “grow up correctly” hits even harder because of moments like that. It never lectures. It simply shows how heavy it is to carry circumstances shaped by adults who should’ve protected you. Maris Racal delivers an immaculate kind of devastation in this role. There’s a sharpness to every look she gives, a trembling truth in every word, that feels painfully real. She breaks open the character’s longing, lets the fear spill out raw, and turns her strength into something that rises slowly from the wreckage. It’s a performance that destroys you and stays spotless in its honesty.Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers. Soft, bruising, furious when it needs to be, and quietly bright in all the places that matter.

A challenging plot to bring to the screen and a harsh and sad reality for many women. The strong hold religion has over the Philippines is especially frustrating. The hospital scene where you would expect empathy from the doctor pissed me off. The pastor and Miggy especially bothered me — Miggy because he’s a little shit and the pastor because his reaction reminded me of my father. Other people can get away with abortion because they have the money so they can just go freely with their lives, but for younger women like Sunshine and Ariana, it’s life or death. Ariana’s situation is especially heavy, something I’ve heard about from people I know. This film is going to bother me for a while.

Sunshine (2024) serves as a powerful and eye-opening film, especially for us Filipinos. As someone working in the healthcare field, I believe the movie highlights an important truth: abortion should not be treated as a taboo subject or inherently immoral. Whether we acknowledge it or not, there are women who do not wish to become pregnant or are not ready to become mothers. Criminalizing abortion does not stop it from happening; it merely drives women toward unsafe procedures that place their lives at greater risk.If one personally identifies as pro-life, then one has the choice not to pursue abortion. However, holding that belief does not grant anyone the authority to dictate or restrict what women can do with their own bodies, especially when they do not contribute to the wellbeing of the child these women may be forced to bear. The health, autonomy, and safety of women must remain our priority. It is time to end the stigma surrounding reproductive choices and to uphold the separation of religion and state in policymaking.

Ang pelikulang Sunshine ay hindi lang simpleng kwento ng isang babae—isa itong salamin sa maraming isyung matagal nang umiikot sa Pilipinas pero pilit pa ring isinasantabi. Nagawa ng pelikula ito na ilahad ang mga sakit ng sistemang kinabibilangan natin: mula sa pakikibaka ng kababaihan sa kanilang sariling katawan hanggang sa nakakalungkot na estado ng ating healthcare system.Isa sa pinakamalinaw na ipinupukol ng pelikula ay ang isyu ng aborsyon. Ipinapakita ng pelikula kung gaano kahirap ang desisyong hinaharap ng mga kababaihan—lalo na sa bansang halos bawal pag-usapan ang reproductive rights. Nakakahalit dahil hanggang ngayon, marami pa ring kababaihan ang hindi ganap na malaya sa sarili nilang katawan dahil sa malalim na kapit ng konserbatismong relihiyoso. Sa halip na suportahan, hinuhusgahan sila. Sa halip na pakinggan, pinapatahimik. At gaya ng ipinapakita sa pelikula, napipilitang harapin ng mga babae ang mga sitwasyong hindi nila pinili, wala man lang ligtas o legal na option para makaligtas..Kasunod nito, mariing binabangga ng pelikula ang realidad ng ating healthcare system. Hindi na bago ang nakikitang eksena sa ospital: siksikan, kulang sa gamit, at kapos sa espasyo. Dalawa, minsan tatlong ina sa iisang kama—hindi dahil gusto nila, kundi dahil wala talagang mapaglagyan. Ito ang reyalidad na hinaharap ng ordinaryong Pilipino araw-araw, habang ang mga pulitikong may kapangyarihan ay kayang lumipad paabroad para magpagamot sa mas kumpletong pasilidad.Sa kabuuan, nagsilbing boses ang Sunshine para sa mga isyung matagal nang dinidinig ngunit hindi pinakikinggan. Maris Racal did her best one on this. Kudos!

This movie was fun to watch in terms of its setting. I have been to the gym Sunshine was training in and also the Rizal Sports Complex because I have trained there before in 2015!Argh, teenage pregnancy in the Philippines stems from the lack of sex education and advocacy for contraceptives and abortion. The fact that we are a mostly Catholic-dominated country or population that strongly adheres to tradition makes it harder for pregnant teenagers to find support. They are made to feel ashamed and helpless because even the law says that abortion is illegal, meaning that they do not have a choice but to deliver the child. Sunshine's passion was found in gymnastics, something that she couldn't let go of. She knew that if she were to become a mother (which she isn't ready for, as she explicitly states during her conversation with Miguel and his father), she would have to surrender everything she has worked hard for. Her sister's situatio, who was a former gymnast as well, basically shows that Sunshine's life would eventually become just like hers if she were to proceed with the pregnancy. The doctor was so annoying because that's exactly how the older generation sounds like when stating their opinions about religion, abortion, and chilbirth.I also liked the fact that they tackled topics like sex, autonomy, rape, and incest. These are very real in the Philippines and the situation with Ariana and his sister (?) greatly displayed how messed up it is. These children have no choice or power over their elders and what makes it sad is that those who should be protecting them are the ones putting them in danger and ruining their lives.I read somewhere that the little girl that followed Sunshine was her unborn child. I also thought of this throughout the movie and it even made more sense when the little girl said "Gets ko na" after Sunshine practiced her piece with a passionate smile and aura that could be felt by the audience.I love that Sunshine chose herself and her dreams over being a mother. A child born into this world who would eventually live in substandard conditions just because people say they should be born won't truly experience a life that should be lived.

Ganda. A harrowing, claustrophobic, yet essential sprint across Manila streets. The craft here really shines, at just 90 or so minutes the film feels tightly-paced and confidently crafted through Jadaone's masterful direction, yet it still swings wide over several discussions and thoughts over its major theme in an arguably short amount of time. Mind you there's an element here that I'm not the biggest fan of-- I think the film could have actually eliminated it altogether as it feels inelegant especially against the overt realism of the rest of the film. But otherwise it's easy to overlook this compared to how wise the rest of the film is. It culminates in a truly lovely finale that uses simplicity to great, moving effect, especially when juxtaposed to how much noise and haste the rest of the film's heavy atmosphere is. Gets ko na why "Gets ko na" became an easily recognisable, even arguably iconic line from this film.Besides the stellar direction, the rest of the departments here really shine. The camera and production design really stand out here, painting a crowded and cramped world. The performances are simply captivating. Maris Racal truly carries this hefty narrative, but Annika Co really exudes such natural confidence that steals the scene whenever she appears. Ultimately, this really feels like important cinema from simply one of the best Filipino filmmakers out there.

Sobrang tapang ng pelikulang 'to. Sobrang tapang ni direk tonet. Sobrang tapang ni Sunshine. Sobrang tapang ng mga kababaihang nagpapatuloy, lumalaban sa mga hamon ng lipunan. Dinala ako ng pelikulang 'to sa kung anong klaseng lipunan ang kailangang harapin ng mga kababaihan araw-araw — lahat ng husga, dikta, at pangungurakot. Wala sa kahit anong batas or salita ng diyos ang makatutulong sa mga taong kagaya ni Sunshine, kung 'di ang maayos na health care system, maayos at tapat na gobyerno, at isang mapagpalayang lipunan — malaya sa kahit anong dikta at husga ng mga taong hindi kailanma'y namroblema sa kanilang kaligtasan kapag maglalakad mag-isa sa madilim na kalsada, sa kanilang kasuotan at pananamit, sa kung anong pananaw ng iba sa kanilang katawan, sa kakayahan makapag-luwal ng anak, sa mga tingin at pagnanasa ng mga mabababang-uri, at sa mga marami pang bagay. Napakaraming aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine ang paulit-ulit sinasampal sa atin para lang magising sa realidad ang bulok na lipunang 'to. Isa na rito ang pagbibigay sa mga kababaihan ang kalayaang mamili, kalayaang magdesisyon, at kalayaang mangarap, kasama ang proteksyon para sa mga batang katulad ni Mary Grace.Ilang kababaihan at bata pa ba ang kinakailangang maranasan ang hirap nina Sunshine at Mary Grace bago mamulat at umusad ang lipunang sakop pa rin ng makalumang pananaw — mga pananaw na hindi nila alam ay unti-unting ginigilitan at pinapatay ang karapatan, kalayaan, at kakayahan ng mga kababaihan. Ang mga taong tulad nina Bobot, nanay ni Mary Grace, at Miggy ang tunay na lumalabag sa sa utos ng diyos, ang tunay na gumagawa ng krimen, at ang tunay sa nagpapabulok pa sa inuuod na sistema para sa mga kababaihan at bata, hindi ang mga taong tulad ni Sunshine na pinanghahawakan ang karapatan nilang mangarap at magkaroon ng desisyon para sa kanilang sariling katawan. Tangina gaano ba kahirap isipin yon?Napakaganda ng cinematography. Lahat ng baho, usok, lagkit, at sikip ng Maynila; lahat ng mga matang mapanghusga, mga taong makasarili, mga komentong nananakal, at bigat na dala-dala araw-araw ng mga babae at bata, lahat ito ipinakita.
