This film really reminded me that sometimes even the most seemingly trivial decisions—like whether to use a condom or not by relying on the excuse of pulling out—can have huge effects on one’s life. It also shows how having no access to proper medical care for abortion (since it is illegal) is so unfair, especially for children who were taken advantage of, which leads them to use unsafe methods that put their lives at risk. I really applaud Sunshine’s determination to chase her dreams and stay strong in the face of her friends ignoring her and her boyfriend not wanting to take responsibility for their child. Aside from her, I also applaud her family for staying by her side regardless of what her decision may be. I applaud this film for showing the hardships of being a woman—specifically, a woman in the Philippines—surrounded by noise, distractions, and judgment.
not the pastor kid

"Naiintindihan mo na?""Gets ko na."Whenever somebody asks me why I support abortion, I will ask them to watch this film—especially now that it is widely accessible through Netflix. The ability to choose for a woman's own welfare and decide for the future of a child is a fundamental right, it should never be a debate. Bodily autonomy is a human right. We can use religious morals as a basis to weigh the decision but NEVER force it on somebody and leverage that same bullshit to guilt-trip them. Safe-sex should be promoted not shushed by religious parties; accessible care for abortion should be a must We shouldn't demonize doctors and women who want that for themselves. Like the line, "Flush out the noise", these unneeded external noises should never be heard in the first place, all throughout the film it catches up to Sunshine. Hangang, hanga, ako sa'yo Sunshine. Dreams should never be impeded because of a mistake, she's still a teen who's transitioning to adulthood. She should be allowed to live her life not being worried about a child she never wanted in the first place. And to all the women out there, who's met with arguably stronger hostility, I hope that laws, people, the Philippines becomes more friendly to you. It should be like that. I never doubted Maris Racal's ability to act, and all I can say is they found jackpot by casting her as Sunshine and casting Annika as the little girl that appears all throughout the film. P.S. that Uncle deserved so much more than breaking a bottle on their head.
this is really good. and that’s exactly WHY abortion should be legal! huge step for the philippine cinema, bravo!

A disturbingly realistic film that tackles on the disadvantages of living in a country that criminalizes abortion—discouraging women’s bodily autonomy and integrity, huge risks on women’s reproductive health, and so on.It is a dark cinematic film that does not only impress one with its amazing visuals and role portrayal from the cast lineup, but also leaves you pondering on the bold message it screams throughout.

Maris Racal is ready for leading roles, and Sunshine gives her everything to work with. It helps that a stellar ensemble of women round out the supporting roles too, with Annika Co haunting her like an undeniable reality. Its plot, certainly a conversation-starter, doesn't all the way succeed with all its creative choices, but it's welcome forward motion for showing that women's choices command respect even if it doesn't fit the ones you decide for yourself. Another thing everyone should agree on is that Antoinette Jadaone has her finger on the pulse of what Filipinos, and the cinephile-going population of the country, need to discuss.

“usapang bata to!””bakit? bata rin naman ako!”a striking detail that struck me the most is the contrast between the very first time we watch sunshine step onto the mat and the last time she ever does. at first, you hear this deep and intense noise of her drowning the music, her choach’s instructions, and even the sound of her own breathing. and the noise only goes louder and harsher each time we see her practice her routine while she quietly endures the devastating ordeal of attempting to terminate her pregnancy. what started off as a sound to describe her pressure and desperation to reach her olympic dreams, now becomes the sound of her fear, her secrecy, and her grief. this says so much about what it means to be a woman in the philippines: how suffering must be hidden, how autonomy becomes something to apologize for, and how you’re expected to quietly tend to your own wounds you never asked to carry.and sunshine carries her decision with guilt, so much that she looks at the unnamed young girl like she’s staring at every version of her future that never got the chance to choose. but she dreams. she dreams so much. and she dreams for more. and she stands firm, because what’s so wrong about wanting a life that belongs to her? what’s so wrong about refusing to be swallowed by sacrifice? what’s so wrong about refusing to become another woman she didn’t want to be?“gets ko na.”so as we see the last time she practices on the mat, we finally hear the sound of the music, not the deep sound of pressure of fear, but a rhythm that finally belongs to her. the gymnasium is dark, she’s alone and she’s pale, but this is the brightest she has ever looked in the past hour i’ve watched the film. she moves with a softness that feels earnest, like this is the first time her body isn’t performing to impress or survive, only to exist. she dances gracefully, probably the most she ever has, and it’s a moment that shows us that she has unapologetically reclaimed something no one ever thought she deserved: the right to choose herself. and for the first time, she is no longer a girl she’s afraid to be—she is a woman who has already decided.i hope more people watch sunshine (2024) not to criticize women with early and unintended pregnancies, but to meet them with grace and empathy for their fears, their confusion, and their fight to claim what should have always been theirs in the first place—their autonomy, dignity, and right to have access to healthcare without being made to beg for it.patuloy nating pahalagahan ang kalusugan, karapatan, at mga kwento ng kababaihan minus half star kasi parang kaya pa natin i-improve yung dialogues, direk?? HAHAHAHAH also sino ba agent ni elijah canlas bakit parang kalhati na ng roles nya may nabubuntis sha

Philippine cinema is not dead and Sunshine is a living proof of it. this film has so much emotional depth and thought-provoking scenes that captures perfectly what it feels like to be a woman living in a patriarchal society- in a country where hypocrisy runs rampant and making decisions for yourself is often frowned upon. why is it that women are the ones always blamed, shackled and punished for choices they make- choices driven by the need to prioritize their health and safety in situations they did not fully create? Antoinette Jadaone's best film yet so far, and i'd say it because of its boldness, for addressing an elephant, a taboo topic that most of us are not ready to talk about, but eventually we must. it's already hard enough that we don't have proper access to healthcare, even worse to be scrutinized by society simply for choosing yourself.

”Ay nako! Talaga naman ang mga kabataan ngayon hindi na makapagpigil.”Throughout Sunshine, there are several adult figures that do not listen to Sunshine, blinded by either their convictions or Filipino societal norms. They push Sunshine on what she must do: pray, seek forgiveness, give the baby a life, be a mom, and pray. In the adults’ eyes, Sunshine is not a nineteen-year-old Filipina in Manila going to school and practice. To the adults, Sunshine is already a mom.On Saturday, the Filipino noontime show It’s Showtime invited parents with 7 or more children for their game Laro, Laro, Pick. A majority of the contestants were women, and two of the mothers interviewed, Elsa and Rosalie, had 15 and 8 children respectively. Elsa, the 63-year-old woman with 12 living children and 3 deceased children recited the ages of her 12 children from the oldest, 46, to the youngest, 24. The gap between the older ones is 1-2 years apart, while the younger ones are about 2-3 years apart. Elsa confesses how difficult life is for her and her children, spouting how without God she would not be as strong as she is today, living off 300 pesos everyday. When Vice Ganda asked Elsa why she has so many children, Elsa plainly said, “Ehhh di ako marunong mag family planning eh,” inciting some laughter in the audience. Elsa even revealed that the father was absent and had a different family, leaving the Filipina mother and her 12 living children to figure out how to live.The second woman, Rosalie, with 8 children echoed the same sentiments as Elsa. She sells sampaguita every day with no days off at the age of 60 something; her children married and had their children early; the highest level of schooling one of her children attained was high school, but never graduated; her children sell sampaguita with no days off; and she has 19 grandchildren to look after in a home with no roof above their heads.What Sunshine, Elsa, and Rosalie have in common is how the patriarchy confines them to suffocating religious ideals, a corrupt and conservative government, and poor healthcare. What Sunshine does not have in common with the two women is the ignorance in family planning. Sunshine is no one's mother! It should never be a reason to have 7 or more children at an early age, with no means of support financially and emotionally, because it is "God's gift," or because they simply want to experience having children. The favorite catchphrase, "Kase malakas ako, kaya ko to" can only thrive for so long with honesty until oppressors abuse the Filipina determination. Access to sexual education MUST be a right, not a privilege nor a taboo subject. Children do not decide when they want to be born, so there should be conscious efforts to assess if the environment people live in can secure their children's/childrens' future(s), especially in a country like the Philippines. Unfortunately, there are connections to poverty and the lack of interest and access to proper education. There is also the inability for Filipinos in poverty to seek other options, or have the real agency to pursue aspirations. While there is such thing as being irresponsible, Filipino women are a laughingstock in conversations surrounding teen pregnancy and reproductive rights—when realistically—they should have the choice to protect themselves, but are instead ruthlessly flayed off by the very system that commands kindness.[Minor spoilers ahead]Annika Co manifests herself as (what I think) Sunshine's Catholic guilt. We first meet Annika after Sunshine prays outside of Quiapo Church and is about to light a cigarette. Annika appears whenever Sunshine does something that will affect the fetus, and often berates Sunshine for being "bad." At first, I was hesitant towards the idea of Annika representing Sunshine's potential child, because it can mistakenly support the pro-life argument of murder (which Annika actually yells at Sunshine), until Annika says, "ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya." SOBRANG bigat yung line na yan! In a sense, Sunshine and Annika are the same person. Sunshine should be able to pursue her dreams successfully the same way Annika, along with other living and future children, should feel secure enough to be ambitious. The message further builds itself with Ariana, Annika's friend and the 13-year-old girl's potential child. Ariana wants to be the first gay president, but how can they do that in an environment with a r*pist, a neglectful grandmother, and a KID whose choice was stolen?If mothers like Elsa and Rosalie can somehow "get away" with no family planning, how can Sunshine and the 13-year-old girl survive in a Catholic Philippines? The Reproductive Health Law was passed in December 2012, and efforts to educate the masses and distribute contraceptives have improved, yet there is still a high percentage of unintended pregnancies, AIDS rates, and JUSKO PO—ISSUES WITH BUDGETING (source 1),(source 2) !!!!!! The Philippines will never progress as a nation if objectivity is blocked by the grip the church and the state have on one another, which ultimately and consistently harms Filipinas who give their best yesterday, today, and tomorrow.I am certain that Sunshine is not the first film to be unapologetically bold and loud for the Filipina, but it is certainly the first to make rounds among the casual movie-goers and the general Filipino. It is not a perfect film and such flawed instances are where:- the narrative of Sunshine being an Olympic-level athlete clashes with the lack of popularity shown outside of practice- the cinematography is poetic without a doubt, but the scenes of Sunshine messaging her Coach, Miggy, and Thea isn't synchronized with Sunshine typing on the phone/isn't even her actually texting. If you're going to place emphasis on the quietest scenes, I believe that something as minor as texting should be clean (this was the same quip I had with the controller scene in Anora like c'mon now....)- the cinematography can be too poetic. for example, the shot of Sunshine looking out of her hotel window with the Metro Manila noise juxtaposing her quiet turmoil contributes to Sunshine purposely not drowning out the noise (or the failure to?), but I found it unnecessary because right after she woke up in pain. the juxtaposition felt like it was purely for aesthetics- the Jojo Rabbit esque character of Annika and Ariana was VERY risky (re: pro-life arguments)- maybe it's just me but the film gives you some breathers with comedic aspects in things like "no bad words" and Annika proceeding to say "putangina" which I found myself like "damn girl ! ! !" though it makes me wonder if those who do not share the same ideals as me laughed at it the same way the audience laughed at Elsa in Laro Laro Pick. In a not long-winding way, and assuming negatively, if tonal shifts struck the audience as a serious matter and not a reactionary narrative.- the last 3 paragraphs of this review regarding how art can effectively stand by its purposeAng hirap maging isang Sunshine sa Pilipinas, at hindi pinaguusapan kahit eto ang reality ng karamihan ng babae at batang babae. Women can dream for themselves. Women can learn to protect for themselves if there are resources available by sources that make themselves available. Women are strong, but you cannot glorify them to always be strong at the expense of exploitation. Sunshine is many of the first steps in Philippine cinema that can continue the conversation. I hope the film incites action in Filipinos to call out the current and future administration, who, under the guise of a devotee to a forgiving religion, perpetuates being uncritical and whose laziness is a disservice to the Filipino people. And most importantly, may Filipinos denounce the administration's vigor in committing violence against them, and reclaim the autonomy all Filipinos are born with.

I know this movie feels heavy and complicated the first time you watch it. It’s about a girl who is struggling against the world and against herself. She loses her way, and she could lose her dreams if she doesn’t stand up to the world.From this movie, I learned one important thing in life, everyone has their own problems, different kinds of problems. But the important thing is what you choose to do when you’re going through something difficult and nobody is there to help you. Even when you feel alone, useless, or hopeless, don’t give up. You can still reach what you want and chase your dreams. Just keep going and keep fighting.As a man, I feel sorry for Sunshine, but believe me, there are many good men in this world better than selfish and stupid men and I learned from this movie how to be a better man. Use protection when you’re doing something intimate, and if you don’t, make sure you can take responsibility for your actions. Live wisely and don’t make rushed decisions. Every choice you make shapes your future. We may not regret our actions in the moment, but we regret them later.And for other men, I want to say this if you have a girlfriend, make sure she’s happy with you. Don’t be rude to her, and don’t ruin her life because of your desires. As a man, I promise myself that I'll be better. I’ll treat women with respect, and I'll never raise my hand when we have problems or arguments.

kababaihan nga ba ang kanilang pinoprotektahan, o ang sariling takot na mawalan ng kontrol sa buhay ng kababaihan?sobrang ironic lang na ang simbahan at ang kanilang pananampalataya ang itinuturing na pinakamalaking hadlang sa pag-legalize ng abortion sa ating bansa. pero sa mismong labas ng kanilang pintuan, makikita mismo ang serbisyong pilit nilang ipinagbabawal. minsan katabi pa nga ng mga santong sinasamba nila.kung ganoon katibay ang kanilang pagtutol, bakit hindi nila mapigil ang realidad na nasa harap nila?dahil sa hindi pagtanggap sa aborsyon, maraming kababaihan ang napipilitang gumamit ng hindi ligtas na pamamaraan, na naglalagay sa kanila sa kapahamakan.kung ang ipinaglalaban ng kanilang moralidad ay “proteksyon ng buhay,” bakit parang hindi kasama sa buhay na iyon ang mismong babaeng nagbubuntis? bakit ang potensyal na buhay ang pinapahalagahan, pero ang buhay na humihinga, nagdurusa, at nalalagay sa panganib ay tila pangalawa lamang—o minsan, hindi man lang isinasama sa usapan?hindi kayang resolbahin ng moral absolutism ang totoong problema. ang kababaihan ang nagbabayad ng presyo—hindi ang simbahan, hindi ang mga pulitiko, at hindi ang mga taong nagtatakda ng mga patakaran na kailanman ay hindi nila mararanasan sa sarili nilang katawan.ang karapatan sa sariling katawan ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban sa husgado ng relihiyon o pulitika. ito ay desisyon na dapat ibalik sa taong may katawan, may buhay, at may tunay na pinansyal, emosyonal, at pisikal na pasanin.

worth watching fr! i love all the subtle scenes — like sa jeep na may “gift of god” sa harap, the super makadiyos billboards, every convo with annika and her gay friend (ariana), and yung scenes na kahit nasa crowd siya, you still notice her. alam mo yun, kahit sobrang simple at halos walang make-up, she still shines. And the cinematography is a solid 10 out of 10.this movie shows how cruel the system is for women in general. with a patriarchal society and a conservative country, talagang “jackpot” maging babae. it also highlights how badly we need proper sex education and why decriminalizing abortion should be pushed hard!gigil ako dun sa hayop na bobot, yung unang doctora na super pabida, at siyempre special mention kay miggy at sa pastor niyang tatay.overall, this movie hit me in a way na kahit hindi ako in sunshine’s situation, ramdam ko pa rin. as a woman, it just made me realize again how much we deal with. it’s not just a good movie it’s the type na kahit okay ka naman, pero pag may sad song, bigla kang nagrereflect. that’s exactly the energy it gave me. kudos to the director, and of course maris, who always gives justice to every character.

This is truly one of the best Filipino films this year. It takes courage to empower abortion and women’s rights in a country that has been conservative and patriarchal for the longest time. I really really loved how the film doesn’t shy away from unraveling the realities of a Filipino woman. The crowded and unorganized public hospitals, the irony of churches and black markets, and the innate nature of self-righteous men trying to dictate a woman’s life. There should be more movies like this marketed to the mainstream media. Looking forward to Maris’ future projects, galing niya as always!

i want to say a lot of things about this movie pero ang hirap niya i-form into words. pero una sa lahat, i love this film. umpisa palang, ang bigat na sa feeling manuod. siguro kasi i’ve been to those places? na it felt too real. lahat ng sulok na dinaanan ni sunshine at mga lugar na tinakbuhan niya, parang nandon lang din ako. i know some will say na maling desisyon yung mga ginawa ni sunshine pero ano na bang pwede niyang gawin? sa bansang walang maayos at ligtas na healthcare para sa mga kababaihan, saan pa siya lalapit? kahit nung dinala siya sa ospital dahil sa epekto nung pampalaglag, hinusgahan pa siya. ganyan ang estado ng healthcare ng mga kababaihan dito sa bansang to. i love the “what should have been her daughter” na character na sinusundan si sunshine sa bawat sulok ng maynila. alam natin sa umpisa palang na ayaw ni sunshine maging nanay at gagawa siya ng paraan para magpalaglag. pero hindi parin mawawala yung parang “guilt” na meron ang isang babae lalo na’t lumaki tayo sa katolikong bansa. kita rin ito dun sa pagpunta ni sunshine sa simbahan tuwing dumadaan siya sa quiapo. mahirap siguro hindi isipin ang mga “what ifs” pero kung hindi handa ang isang babae maging nanay, hindi siya handa. dapat ganun lang kadali. i also like how they added the side story of mary grace. kasi totoo naman. ano ang gagawin ng isang babae (at sa lagay ni mary grace na 13 palang) kapag ni-r*pe siya ng tito niya? hindi kailanman magiging handa maging ina ang labintatlong gulang na bata lalo na’t bunga ito ng abuse sa bahay. also ang galing ni maris! sobrang husay niya sa pelikulang ito. kahit yung mga mata-mata acting lang, damang dama ko. you can say anything you want about maris pero no one can say anything bad when it comes to her as an actress. ang dami ko pang naiisip and i think i need days to reflect and form my thoughts pero ang masasabi ko ay we needed a movie like this sa pinas. kailangan talaga marinig ang mga kwento gaya ni sunshine (at ni mary grace).

“Gets ko na.”In a country like the Philippines, where everyone has an opinion on your body except you, this film hits a nerve that’s been aching for a long time. The way the film shows her struggle, the shame, the fear, the judgment, the dreams she’s forced to postpone, feels like a mirror held up to countless Filipina girls who had to grow up too fast. You can feel how her choices are never just hers; they’re tied to religion, family, and the weight of “dapat” at “bawal.”But what makes Sunshine beautiful is how it refuses to punish her for wanting more. For wanting herself.When she finally chooses her dreams, finally chooses herself and it doesn’t feel selfish. It feels like survival. Like finally stepping out of a shadow she never asked to stand under.This is a reminder that a woman’s future shouldn’t be treated like a sin.And that the sun doesn’t ask permission to shine… it just does.The best Filipino Film of 2025.

Ayokong maging nanay! Ano bang pakielam nyo?!Followed by her Ate's support is what every young woman's response to people trying to dictate what to do with her body. not when she's not ready, not whenever. In this world, we need an ate like her, Dok Helena, and ate pharmacist who completely shows support no matter what her decisions, does not have malicious mindset and judgmental tendencies. Sunshine reflects the reality all young women face, the struggles of being a woman in a religious third world country and it is so brave to create this kind of film, so kudos to Direk Antonette Jadaone, Maris Racal, and to everyone behind this. Sunshine's bravery for fighting for what she wants, her exercising her rights, and her choices are what young women of today should follow. It is important to see how women who plan to abort or did abort are NOT completely cruel nor sinners, as they also have a conscience and dilemma as they go through every consideration. Her conscience, being represented by "bata," goes to show how she considered having her, but of course it all just boils down to her body, her choices, and her future. And the rights to have access in safe abortions does NOT only applies to rape victims but all WOMEN. ABORTION IS HEALTH CARE. AND ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE IS HUMAN RIGHTS. Sunshine showed how hard it is to receive health care in the philippines; that we resort to what is accessible even if it meant danger for herself. This is sad but this is reality. We need more films like this!!!

do i love this movie because i relate to it the most or because it is beautifully written and perfectly carved for this generation? either way, hands down to everyone who took part in this film. a solid watch. people often says that our society has become "pro women"—from the laws created to protect and empower us to the countless celebrations of women’s lives. pero, matatawag mo bang pro women ang isang lipunan kung babae lang ang naipapako sa tuwing nagbubunga ang isang bagay na hindi lang sya ang gumawa? sunshine had to go through everything—buying the pregnancy test kits on her own, enduring the crippling anxiety while waiting for the result, desperately seeking help in terminating a pregnancy she wasn’t ready for, and then facing judgment from almost everyone around her. and ano yung na-experience ng boyfriend nya? napagalitan, siguro, pero he had the fucking audacity to chill while the girl he knocked up had gone through all phases of desperation and grief. and he thought one conversation with her, plus his dad, and he really thought that would fix everything? bffr. this is our society. despite the progressive movements, women are still seen as an object that can be controlled, blamed, and burdened with responsibilities others refuse to share.i am proud of sunshine for choosing herself.

Sunshine candidly showed a tough, honest look at teenage pregnancy and abortion without sugarcoating. So raw and empathetic that it almost feels like eavesdropping on someone’s real-life crisis. Quietly powerful.

Not much to be "gained" from watching this movie even though the topic is considered taboo in the PH. Watching it reminded of "Anora" but with much less nuance and entertainment. Felt like a wasted opportunity to have Maris Racal be the lead but without a real plot to actually steer. Was it a censorship issue?? I don't understand why they would choose such a topic and not really have a stance on it. Maybe the creators themselves are also confused as to being pro-choice or pro-life, as are most Filipinos due to their religious beliefs (I'm assuming). I'm just saying, if you didn't want to get "too" political by having a clearer opinion in the film, then it's probably best to take more time and do more research about the topic, or just make another kind of movie.

it's no surprise to me that a lot of filipinos will misunderstand the whole point and premise of this movie. ang pagb-buntis ng maaga ay madalas nakikita lamang bilang topic ng chismis ng marami kaya di na ko nagulat na madami ang di nakakaintindi sa istorya ni sunshine. i love the inclusion of mary grace in the story, it's a bleak reminder that the women who want and need to get abortions aren't always the stereotyped madonna who's into casual sex,(granted women shouldn't have to fit into a "perfect victim" image just to be granted bodily autonomy) but they are also minors who were victims of rape from family members. mary grace's story adds so much to how deeply the film tackles the conversation around abortion as well as making it known to the audience that abortion is not a black and white subject. additionally, it also does a good job in portraying the role of men in these women's lives as well as how little guilt they shoulder from something they also took part in. sobrang little ng guilt at remorse na nararamdaman nila miggy at yung tito ni mary grace. the fact that miggy was only able to help and apologize to sunshine when his father was involved was so putangina. if male audacity had a poster child it would be him. never fucking trust a man (period) who says his "pull out" game is strong, especially if that motherfucker is named miggy and talks like he consumes red pill content on the daily.

sunshine confronts a difficult truth — choices that seal themselves shut the moment they’re made, sanctified by a faith that bends only toward the patriarch, leaving everyone else to kneel under its weight.it holds one of the most unsettling narratives i’ve seen this year, not because it reaches for emotional peaks, but because its horror rests in its reality. you watch knowing this isn’t fiction for many; it’s a reflection of someone’s everyday struggle. and you feel helpess watching a dramatization of a pain others still carry, while the very people meant to help choose to look away. film is always political, always bound to the world it mirrors. and sunshine reminds us that.I first saw this sometime in august but never got the chance to log it.

what hit me the most was how the film shows society’s pressure without ever yelling at you. the judgement, the shame, the rules you’re supposed to follow — it’s all there, always in the background, shaping every choice she makes. but then there are these tiny moments of kindness, little glimmers of hope, and it’s those moments that make the sadness bearableyou really feel her pain, her confusion, her stubborn spark to survive and keep dreaming, even when everything seems against her. and the story doesn’t give you easy answers — it just lets you sit with the reality of what it’s like to be a girl in a world that doesn’t make it easypero na-realize ko na the girl who follows sunshine and calls her “murderer” is not a real person. she represents the harsh judgment sunshine feels from others and the guilt she carries inside herself. the girl is basically the voice of society telling sunshine she did something wrong, even when the situation is more complicated. she’s also sunshine’s own fear and self-blame turned into a person. in short, the girl is the symbol of the guilt and pressure that keep haunting sunshineyung nasa jeep scene fav ko kasi pinakita na how overwhelmed sunshine is without her having to say a word. while she’s sitting in the jeep, everything around her feels loud, messy, and fast—parang tuloy-tuloy yung mundo habang siya, nakastuck. when she starts crying quietly, it shows how much she’s been holding in for so long

“pangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, sunshine”UGHHHHH ugly crying right now bc it’s all too real. tangina. ang ganda. kuhang kuha ang lagay ng maynila—ang madidilim na eskinita, run-down motels, yung lagkit, yung dumi, at yung mga pangarap na hindi man lang makapigtas sa kanilang kamalayan. i started this movie with my mom and my sister and i kept on going wt my furious commentary; bakit ko pa daw pinapanood kung nakakatakot? nakakatakot kasi totoo. kung magiging babae, bakit sa pilipinas pa? sa bawat sulok may mga umaalingawngaw na tigang, ang pagtangkklik sayo kasi ika nga “horny” sila, pag-ostracize at pag-iskandalo, yung preachy tangents nila para lang itemper ang karamdaman mo, the misogny, the commodification, the devastating __ of it all. yung paglagay ng bag sa harap kasi baka manakawan, yung pagtago ng pampalaglag sa mga imahen ni mama mary, at yung desperasyon (mula sa labas ng simbahan kasi ikaw ay naging “makasalanan) sa musmos at awa ng diyos. sa kinaingay at sulasok ng siyudad, nariyan ang mga pusong may kinakapitang mga pangarap; at kung kailan andyan na ang pinakaninanais mo, wala ka nga palang karapatan sa iyong katawan. mas alam pa ng mga doktor at gagong hindi mo kilala ang gagawin sa sinapupunan mo. ‘yan si sunshine. at ‘yan rin kamigrowing up in a devout catholic household in a predominantly catholic-practicing country, mahirap ang maging progressive. there are days na makikipagdebate ako sa parents ko at matatapos sa mga dabog at pagkulong sa mga kwarto. bilang pro-choice, bilang babae, at bilang isang tao, wala talagang ikakukumpara yung mental process of choosing between your dream and something that wasn’t even in your control (kasi nga sabi hindi ipuputok sa loob)—this movie has it all: the catholic guilt, yung mga minuto ng katahimikang naaaning dahil sa kakaisip, yung lito at pagkamatigas sa iyong desisyon. i’d like to imagine sunshine lived the ribbon kasi nakokontrol niya ito: na sa bawat pitik ng kamay sumusunod ang ribbon na kahit anong gawin ay maganda tignan at delikadesa mahulog, kahit anong buhol, kaya pa ring mahulas, kahit anong gulo sa galaw, maganda pa ring ang kinalalabasan. GRABE. sunshine, with her ribbon, was able to be free on the mat. now, clad in her shimmering pink and purple bedazzled spandex, she walks out with the brightest smile in her force and, like the ribbon she’s been acquainted with since childhood, is finally able to take control of her own life. Putangina, hanggang ngayon, ang daming lalaking nag-aakalang may karapatan silang magpasya para sa katawan ng babae. What stays with you long after Sunshine ends is how the film treats every moment as something pulled straight from real Filipino girlhood. You see it in the small, mundane ways Sunshine tries to keep herself together like the way she tightens her jaw during training to hide the panic creeping up her spine, how she forces a neutral expression when adults around her throw judgment disguised as concern and the humiliation of realizing everyone expects her to handle a crisis she never chose.Girls grow up by being punished for becoming women. Sunshine is still a teenager, but the moment her pregnancy becomes known, people start talking to her like she owes them maturity, penance, and accountability she was never taught to carry.When Pastor Jaime steps in, offering moral pressure, you can feel the room closing in on her again. Everyone wants her to be a mother. Everyone thinks they have the right to her future. Despite all that pressure, Sunshine’s refusal hits like a rupture in a system built to control her.

[ system log : 001 ]user : haziah | age : 23status : active // processingI liked Sunshine because it speaks volumes about the lack of real sex education among teenagers—how so many are left to navigate consequences without ever being given proper knowledge, guidance, or protection. It shows how quickly people are forced into rigid sides—pro-choice or pro-life—without being allowed the space to exist as confused, scared, and human first. I didn’t like it only because Maris Racal’s acting was phenomenal—raw, restrained, and painfully real—but because the film chose to center understanding instead of judgment. It didn’t sensationalize the situation; it made you sit with it.I liked it because it treated the experience as what it truly is: a life-altering moment that cannot be simplified into slogans, morals, or online arguments. It showed how heavy one decision can feel when the world is already crashing down on you. I liked it because it refuses to make the audience comfortable. It doesn’t beg for sympathy, it doesn’t chase approval, and it doesn’t try to make itself digestible for everyone.And most of all, I liked it because it never tells you what the “right” answer is. It simply lays everything bare and lets you face it on your own. It allows you to choose what to feel, what to believe, and what to carry after the credits roll.Some people say it lacked something—especially in its length—that it should’ve been longer, that it ended too soon. But I don’t agree. I think it had to end exactly where it did. Because some stories aren’t meant to be over-explained. Some experiences don’t offer neat closures. The ending didn’t feel incomplete to me—it felt honest.

"naiintindihan mo ba ako?"Sunshine, at its core, is a film that aims to make the people who watch truly understand. hopefully to also change minds but for that to happen, dapat maintindihan muna kung bakit. and in the spectrum of making films that want to make people listen, Sunshine sits perfectly in the middle. hindi masyadong dinikta yung mensahe to the point that it may be a bit too "preachy" kahit walang substance, pero hindi rin nasobrahan sa spectacle at drama at kinulang sa tapang to the point that the message gets blurred. this was a very well executed show and not tell, and show it did.plus everyone was just soooo good. ang husay ng pag arte ng lahat. maris, jennica, annika???? ang husay. no acting to take you out of the scene, no lines to remind you that you're watching a film aiming to be a commercial success (which is a pinoy movie disease, the infamous hugot line syndrome)simple lang. the story was straightforward. it knew what it wanted to tell and it delivered. the topic was handled with care without shying away from the heaviness of it. visually stunning, i love seeing manila filmed as it is and have it be a setting that adds to the storytelling. technically admirable, without losing the heart to tell the story. ms tonet jadaone you've won me over once again. balik nanaman ako sa good side mo po ms jadaone po. please don't stop making pinoy movies tnx po

Women are born with pain built-in. It's our physical destiny: period pains, sore boobs, childbirth, you know. We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives; men don’t. They have to seek it out. They invent all these gods and demons and things, just so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own. And then they create wars, so they can feel things and touch each other. And when there aren’t any wars, they can play rugby. We have it all going on in here inside. We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens? The menopause comes. The fucking menopause comes, and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world. And yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you’re free, no longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts. You’re just a person.
Alam kong ang pelikulang ito ay more than just about dreams, pero sinulat ito sa mga dreamers na gusto mag succeed. Kaya gets kita, Sunshine

This movie would have been a 5/5 for me if not for the scene with Rhed Bustamante, which weakens its claim of being genuinely “pro-choice.” Some devout viewers might frame abortion as acceptable only in cases like rape or other extreme circumstances. Abortion is a woman’s right because she has full authority over her own body. Women are autonomous humans. Reproductive rights should not depend on how tragic the story is. Abortion should not be portrayed as acceptable only for rape survivors or under certain conditions, but as a fundamental expression of bodily autonomy for all women, regardless of their reasons.

apaka hirap maging babae.sunshine did the right thing. she wasn’t being selfish; she was being honest. she knew, deep within herself, that she wasn’t ready to be a mother, and because of that self-awareness, she understood that ending the pregnancy was the most responsible choice she could make.i genuinely love this film. it exposes the harsh reality of living in a country dominated by catholic doctrine—where the people around us can be relentlessly cruel, judgmental, and unforgiving. the film tackles abortion with remarkable depth, showing how society instinctively treats it as a sin, a crime, even a form of murder—without ever pausing to consider the woman’s circumstances, pain, or autonomy.sana mapanood ‘to ng lahat, para maintindihan nila na hindi masama ang pagpapalaglag. people forget that there are reasons—real, painful, and valid reasons—why someone would choose it.the storyline of the thirteen-year-old child, impregnated by her uncle, shattered me. it happens in real life. children—literal children—forced to carry pregnancies at the cost of their own safety and future. it’s heartbreaking that instead of being allowed to end the pregnancy for their well-being, many are forced to keep it simply because abortion is illegal. the kid didn’t even know she was pregnant—she only realized when her stomach started to swell. that level of innocence being burdened with trauma feels monstrous.i truly hope our country stops clinging to extreme conservatism and learns to be more open-minded—to understand that these things do happen outside the walls of their moral fantasies. legalize abortion. educate children about sex. there is nothing lewd or obscene about knowledge—malisyoso lang ang mga utak ng mga ayaw magturo.at tangina si miggy. walang kuwenta.

loveee the solidarity of women in the film. especially jeannica's character (sunshine's sister) what stood out to me abt “Sunshine” is how it handles abortion without turning it into shock value or moral debate. the film treats it the way real life does, quietly, privately, and w a kind of heaviness that doesn’t need big explanations. it shows how a situation like this doesn’t happen in a vacuum; it’s shaped by family, religion, money, expectations, fear, and the silence surrounding women’s choices, seeing how, in the film, women were denied healthcare even in life or death situations bc of the values and systems upheld in this country.motherhood demands so much, money, energy, time, and an immeasurable amount of emotional labor. once u step into it, there's no turning back. that's why becoming a mother should never be forced, it's not something anyone should bepushed into. it's not easy to be one.being a mother is a beautiful, yet deeply complex role. it should be intentional, it should be a choice.at the same time, every person brought into this world deserves to be born out of intention, love, and readiness. if someone doesn't want to become a mother, that's OKAY. it's only fair, both to her, and to the life she could've been expected to bring into the world.the movie doesn’t try to justify anything or convince u what is right. instead, it shows the reality of how young people end up dealing w choices they were never prepared for. it’s not dramatic, not preachy, just painfully honest. the long pauses, the still shots, the way conversations trail off… it all reflects how hard it is to say something out loud when yk u’ll be judged before u’re understood.it’s thoughtful, grounded, and uncomfortable in a necessary way. a reminder that behind every headline or opinion is someone trying to figure out how to move forward when every option hurts.

Lahat ay politikal kapag babae ka. Napakahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Catholic country na nga tangina puro korap pa. Puno ng diskriminasyon sa lahat ng kilos natin na para bang apakalinis din ng mga kamay ng nanghuhusga. :) Sa ilalim ng lahat ng pangarap sa Maynila ay ang hindi mawala-walang kahirapan ng mga tao rito. Sa bawat kayod ng kamay at kalyong nabubuo dahil sa pagod, sa bawat patak ng pawis sa ilalim ng mainit na araw, at sa patuloy na pagtrabaho ng lahat para lamang sa kabuhayan — ito ang realidad ng Pilipinas. Hindi lang ito pelikula, ito ang katotoohanan. Ang realidad. Ang kamulatan ng masa na hanggang ngayon ay naghihirap para lang makawala sa hirap.Ramdam na ramdam bawat emosyon. Tangina ang husay e. Galit, inis, desperasyon — lahat 'yon kitang-kita. Maris’ acting is what makes this movie work. Ang galing din ng cast, undeniably a great performance from all of them.Kaya gets ko na. Putanginang buhay 'to. Pero patuloy pa rin para sa pangarap. Para sa sarili. Be the sunshine that will always come after every rain.

"naiintindihan mo ba ako?""gets ko na."See Greatest Filipino Films Of All TimeSee Jom’s Greatest Films Of All TimeOnce in a while, movies like this will remind us how great Philippine Cinema could be with proper production and marketing.Let's be honest, there are many films like Sunshine out there, produced and marketed independently. The talent of our Filipino directors, writers, and actors is flourishing; it just needs the right hand managing them. Studios surrounding Sunshine took a huge gamble promoting and marketing this movie, because they know how good it is. And it's that fcking good!Sunshine beautifully captures Sunshine, our protagonist, as she battles her way out of an unwanted pregnancy set in the cold city of Manila. This journey was documented with captivating visuals of Sunshine in the gym, in Quiapo, in a motel, etc. On top of this, this is unlike any other dialogue in mainstream Pinoy. The dialogue often has witty layers, purposeful intentions, and emotional punches.Maris Racal delivered a career-defining performance. This is not the same Maris Racal we often see in teleseryes or some other romcom movie. Her performance is an incredible take on such a complex and relatable character.I could nitpick some off details here and there which really bugged me, but I won't talk about it here as I believe that further magnifying this movie's success is what we should do.Sunshine represents every woman, every female, every girl, every lady of any shape or form. It brings up socially relevant topics and issues worthy of discussion. I am most impressed by its bravery to speak all about these, coming from a conservative country. Sunshine, the protagonist, showed bravery in confronting the stigma and the conservative norms. Sunshine, the movie, showed the bravery of promoting and marketing this despite the stigma and the conservative norms.

Antoinette Jadaone's "Sunshine" is anchored by a stellar lead performance from Maris Racal and a neo-realist perspective on the lack of reproductive rights in the Philippines. The film follows a rhythmic gymnast who dreams of participating in the Olympics, only to find out that she is pregnant. The film explores the difficulties of finding the right medical care for abortion. Racal's performance is impressive, and she is solidly supported by Annika Co, Jennica Garcia, and Meryll Soriano. Jadaone is able to capture the dirt and grime of Manila's urban areas, as well as the outdated beliefs in the country.Reproductive rights for all!

Kapag nabuntis ka, disgrasyada.Kapag nagpalaglag, mamamatay tao. Not the type to do long reviews for a film, but I love Sunshine so much. Biggest fear na ata ang maging teenage mom ka dito sa Pilipinas; hindi dahil may nakakahiya, kundi dahil doon na lang irereduce ng lahat ng tao ang buong pagkatao mo. Kung tutuusin, mas cinocondemn pa nga nang iba ‘yung pagpapa-abort kesa sa pagnanakaw o pag-ddrugs na makakalimutan na makalipas ilang araw at babansagang “normal” lang. Sa bawat sulok ng Pilipinas, there would always be a Sunshine or a Mary Grace na aping-api na nga ng patriyarkiya, ilulugmok pa ng mga maka-relihiyon. Just shows how difficult it is to be a woman, especially a woman living in the country of so-called saints. Lysm Direk Tonet, Sunshine truly embodied the hell is a teenage girl spirit— raw, bold, and unapologetically ambitious.

The movie did not contain any surprise elements whatsoever — rather, it depicted the realities that Filipino women endure, especially when it comes to pregnancy and abortion. Seeing individuals like Sunshine and Mary Grace deal with the outcomes they did not choose is devastating. It's awful that they had to put their own lives in danger to reclaim their lives. In addition, I detest the notion that women are blamed and criticized while the majority of males who participated in the incident roam free from the consequences. It's horrible how obviously apparent the double standards are. Most of us are aware of the worst-case situations if abortion isn't legalized, and this film accurately depicts the gravity of the situation. If watching this doesn't change your mind about being anti-abortion, I don't know what will. Not everyone is ready to be a mother. Not everyone is capable of being a mother. Is protecting your child's future and safety truly a sin? I truly hope that this movie will continue to inspire empathy and provide better facilities for safe and regulated practices in the country. Let's do better, Philippines.

“Gets ko na.”Ang dami kong gustong sabihin na feeling ko, hindi ko kayang masulat in a movie review. Literal na daramdamin mo lang yung pelikula and your emotions will be enough for people to understand.Gets na gets ko si Sunshine—from thinking you’re an adult yet feeling like a child; an ambitious girl to a woman on a tightrope; from being alone and criticized by society as a whole to finding your space, your people, your support system despite what people have to say… and ultimately choosing your own peace and happiness—something that is deemed a privilege for women. Hindi naging madali ang pinagdaanan ni Sunshine at ng milyong-milyong babae sa Pilipinas, sa mundo. May mga babaeng katulad niya na hindi sinasadyang mabuntis, may mga babae namang katulad ni Menggay na posibleng ginahasa at pinagsamantalahan. Hindi ko masikmura kung gaano karaming babae ang dumadaan sa ganitong hirap araw-araw at nakakaramdam na wala na silang mapanghahawakan pa. At dadagdag pa sa pasakit ang ang mga lalaki, ang simbahan, gobyerno at mga sarado ang isip sa ganitong sitwasyon. Why is it that women have to suffer the consequences alone, with the whole world—heaven and hell—blaming them for what happened. A world that continues to place heavy pressure on a woman’s shoulders yet crucify them the moment they make a mistake. Society needs to be more forgiving to women who are trying their best to make and take up space without making them sacrifice their whole life and identity. Every woman is a Sunshine of their own, and I hope that they realize that their happiness, their life, their voices and choices matter.

SAGOT SA PELIKULANG “SUNSHINE”: HINDI GUGUSTUHIN NG BATA ANG MAMATAY SA ABORSYON KONTRA SA PINAKITA SA PELIKULA----------------------------Paalala: Ito ay dati naming Facebook post na muli naming inilabas dahil nasa Netflix na ang pelikulang "Sunshine." Para sa nagnanais na malaman kung sino ang "unlikely guide" sa caption, basahin ang post dito. ----------------------------Matapos maibalita ang pelikulang “Sunshine” ni Maris Racal, inaasahan ko na ang pagsuporta nito sa aborsyon o ang pagkitil sa anak na nasa sinapupunan ng kanyang ina. Ngunit, ang hindi ko inasahan ay ang huling parte ng pelikula. Hindi ko pinanood ang pelikulang ito ngunit nagbase ako sa buod nito upang malaman kung ano ang naganap [1].Si Sunshine (Maris Racal) ay naghahanda na sumali sa “gymnastics team” para sa Olympics ngunit nalaman niya na buntis pala siya. Dahil dito, pumunta siya sa Quiapo upang bumili ng pampalaglag. Matapos ng eksenang ito ay makikita na sinusundan siya ng isang batang babae. Iyon pala, ang babaeng ito, na nasa larawan sa post na ito, ay isang “imaginary friend” ni Sunshine. Hindi ko na babanggitin ang gitna ng buod ng kwento ngunit sa huling parte ng pelikula, makikita na si Sunshine ay naghahanda para sa Olympics. Nagpakita muli ang “imaginary friend” na batang babae kay Sunshine. Tinanong ni Sunshine kung nauunawaan ba ng batang babae ang desisyon niya. Matapos nito, pinakita ng batang babae na tinatanggap niya at niyakap niya na may luha sa mata si Sunshine. Ang “plot twist” dito ay ang “imaginary friend” na ito ay ang anak ni Sunshine na namatay dahil sa aborsyon. Sa imahinasyon ni Sunshine, tinanggap ng kanyang anak ang desisyon ni Sunshine na patayin siya sa sinapupunan. Tila ba tinuturo ng pelikulang ito, hindi lang na dapat gawing ligal ang pagpili ng tao na patayin ang anak sa sinapupunan ng ina, kundi gugustuhin ng isang bata na mamatay na lamang sa aborsyon kaysa ang mabuhay dahil sa benepisyo na matatanggap ng nanay kung pinatay na lang ang kanyang anak. Nakakalungkot dahil sobrang sama ng moralidad na ipinapalaganap ng pelikulang ito. Dahil dito, nais ko lang ipakita kung ano ang sinabi ng mga taong nakaligtas sa tangkang aborsyon. Hindi sa lahat ng pagkakataon ay namamatay ang mga anak na pinapalaglag. Dahil dito, mahalaga na makita ang kanilang perspektibo sa usapin ng aborsyon matapos silang makaligtas dito. Sabi ni Linda Swayn na nakaligtas sa aborsyon ngunit nagkaroon ng problema sa kanyang bungo dahil sa bawal na gamot na ginamit sa pampalaglag,"The greatest gift I have received is life. God has given me the greatest gift of life [2]."Ito naman ang mababasa sa buhay ni Charlie Rousseau, isang tagapagsalita sa radyo sa Canada, na nakaligtas ng aborsyon na nagdulot upang mabuhay siyang putol ang braso at dalawang binti,“She wants to continue with her dream to work and live remotely, and see the world [3]."Makikita naman natin na lagi nanaginip ng masama si Kimberly na maaaring parte ng kanyang masamang alaala sa tangkang pagpatay sa kanya,“For as long as I can remember, I would have a recurring nightmare. I could feel it coming, as if someone was coming to kill me... Somehow I knew it was going to kill me! It was terrifying! When I was 15 years old, I woke from the nightmare screaming and crying [4]."Ngayon, huwag muna natin isipin ang aborsyon kundi ang bagong silang na sanggol. Tama ba na patayin sila para hindi maapektuhan ang pangarap ng kanyang nanay? Sa tingin ba natin, sasabihin ng sanggol na tama ang desisyon ng kanyang ina na patayin siya? Malamang ay hindi. Ito rin ang ating rason sa pagtanggol sa buhay ng lahat, lalo na ng mga bata na walang kakayahan ipagtanggol ang kanilang sarili. Galing mismo sa boses ng mga nakaligtas ng aborsyon na alam nila kung gaano ito kasama at gaano kaganda ang buhay. Walang bata ang gugustuhin na sila ay patayin. Itigil na sana nila ang kasinungalingang ipinapalaganap sa pelikulang ito.

Bring back more filipino movies like this, gets ko sunshineSunshine really hits the mark in portraying toxic filipino culture (since we’re a largely catholic country, abortion is looked as “sinful” and “immoral”) and Filipino women struggles. We don’t even have access to safe abortion, even if the baby is born off of violence since it’s illegal. And it STILL is. Why is the concern of safety regarded for the unborn baby,, not the woman carrying it? Why are we shaming women for not wanting to keep it even if they didn’t ask for it? Kakainis. No more words other than thank you to Antoinette Jadaone for making a movie that tackles the pro-life/pro-choice conflict so well and shows awareness respectfully. Nailed it so hard. It’s uncomfortable to watch, but I can’t imagine the reality of living it.The movie leaving us with the question, are these beliefs that can be challenged more important to uphold than the safety of our Filipino women? How many more women must suffer until it gets through their thick skull that these beliefs and the anti-abortion law actively does more harm than good?Extra: I reco you read Nutribun review of this movie after you’ve watched it, explains it much better than me and i agreed with SO many points.

Abortion has been a pressing issue in a predominantly Christianised nation like the Philippines. Albeit some of the points raised are quite incisive, what Sunshine lacks is an original insight on how we ought to discuss “abortion” that Hinugot sa Langit (poverty & morality) and Bendor (folk & speculative realism) have not articulated yet. Maris Racal and Jennica Garcia are two of this generation’s finest actresses, in my opinion.

this isn’t really a film about mistakes. well, at least for me. it’s a film about the quiet burdens women carry—those moments when the world expects you to stay composed while everything inside you is breaking apart. what stayed with me wasn’t the plot itself, but the feeling of watching a girl stand at the edge of her dreams while life keeps pulling her in directions she never asked for.there is a particular kind of loneliness here that Filipinas know too well: the pressure to be strong, the fear of being judged, the lack of safe spaces to fall apart... The film captures that ache, the way society can be quick to moralize but slow to understand.For me, it felt like looking at a reflection of a system we’ve all quietly learned to navigate: the whispers, the shame, the institutions that pretend to help but rarely do. Yet in those heavy moments, you still see a girl trying to choose herself, even when the world insists she shouldn’t.it’s messy, raw, and painfully familiar… and that’s why it felt less like watching a film and more like remembering something you wish you could forget.

just had to rewatch once more. ito, seryoso na at skl ko lang din this anecdote of mine. i remember being a transferee in sixth grade when i was suddenly forced into an intra-school debate tournament. one of the motions i had was about the legalization of abortion and i was placed in the opposing team. i vividly remember kung paano ako naging mulat sa topic na ‘to and i thought to myself, “oo nga, ‘no? bakit nga ba bawal?” i honestly had a hard time countering the government side’s points, so i just ended up focusing on my own arguments (without saying any rebuttals) instead — buti leader of the opp. lang ako no’n, lol. our debate teacher, or the madam chair, was very strict about not using the church as a basis when making an argument. but all i could think of then was the bible, i couldn’t think of any other countering argument na pwede kong maibato.and so, if a small-scale school debate tournament prohibits using the church as an argument, why can’t we demand the same from our government? bakit patuloy na iginigiit ang impluwensya ng simbahan sa batas if we supposedly live in a secular state?sunshine and all filipino (women) do not deserve this bullshit. free and accessible (reproductive) healthcare for filipinos!on the side note, this film is incredibly well-made and fearless. salamat, direk tonet and to everyone involved. give maris racal her flowers juseyo! i’m sooo glad i finally got to watch this kasi i missed the local screening months ago. i really hope na maging mulat ang bawat manonood kung bakit napaka-timely at mahalaga ang mga pelikulang tulad nito.

Sunshine offers a quiet yet affecting exploration of teenage pregnancy and abortion—two issues deeply intertwined with the social and economic realities of our country. What makes the film striking is its simplicity: it doesn’t rely on heavy dramatics, but instead allows its heartfelt moments and grounded storytelling to speak for themselves.I particularly appreciated how the film subtly incorporated supernatural elements. Rather than distracting from the story, these touches added depth and symbolism, making the film feel both intimate and introspective. It’s a creative choice that gives Sunshine a unique emotional texture.As someone who grew up Catholic, I’ve never taken a firm stance on abortion; I’ve mostly remained indifferent or unsure. But this film pushed me to reflect on the bigger picture. It gently raises a painful yet necessary question: Why bring a child into a country that struggles to provide a dignified, nurturing environment for its people? Without forcing a specific viewpoint, Sunshine invites viewers to confront the harsh realities that many young Filipinos face—stories that are often ignored or oversimplified.Overall, Sunshine succeeds not just as a piece of cinema, but as a conversation starter. It lingers with you, urging you to think about compassion, choice, and the societal conditions that shape both. It’s a simple film, but one with a resonance that’s hard to forget.

Mga uri ng tao na hinihiling kong masunog sa impyerno:1. Mga lalaki sa mundo2. Overly religious people3. PRO-LIFERS.WOMEN'S RIGHTS SHOULDN’T BE SOMETHING TO BE DEBATED!“Hindi pa ako ready maging nanay” is already a valid reason for abortion. It’s her choice, not a moral issue for everyone to judge. Nakakalungkot noong ipinakita sa movie na ito kung gaano kalala ang situation sa public hospitals—kulang sa resources, walang safe at stigma-free options, mayroon pa ngang nanganganak na lang sa sahig dahil sa kakulangan sa mga tao at kagamitan. Kaya hindi nakapagtataka na for many women, the “safest” choice ends up being underground options, kahit sobrang risky. Mas ironic pa, kasi nasa paligid lang ng simbahan ang mga nagbebenta ng pamparegla, hilot, at kung anu-ano, tapos ang narrative ng church: “kung natukso ka, talo ka.” Kaya understandable that the “tukso” becomes sometimes the only lifeline for someone desperate. Women bear the brunt of the hypocrisy. That’s literally the only way a woman could access it. Hindi ko alam kung bakit kapag babae ka, ang daming bawal sa’yo. Pero hindi ka naman bibigyan ng reliable options. Napaka eye-opening nito sa atin, lalo na’t ipinakita sa atin na wala tayong karapatan husgahan ang batang ina kasi hindi natin alam ang pinagdadaanan nila. Rape victim man o hindi, a woman should always have the right to decide for herself—her body is never up for debate.

Okay siya. Gets ko 'yung punto. Hindi na-romanticize ang unplanned pregnancy. Alam nating lahat na tangina ni Miggy. Very backwards ang point of view ng character ni Piolo as a pastor. “Drown out the noise. You are Sunshine.”it’s heartbreaking how many young women are going through this right now. abortion in the Philippines is not only illegal, but also so deeply stigmatized that many are forced to carry this burden alone, sometimes risking their own lives through unsafe procedures. the film portrays this reality with such quiet honesty that it sticks with you. the symbolism throughout was also so striking, like the “Gift of God” sign in the jeepney Sunshine rode, or her so-called imaginary friend who could represent her unborn child or her inner child.it was honestly so satisfying watching her stand up for herself against miggy and his father, who’s a pastor. then of course, her breaking the bottle on tito bobot’s head? deserved. every mf like him deserves that.the final sequence felt incredibly freeing as well. it was like she was finally free, almost like a release of everything she had been carrying — fear, shame, pressure, expectation. her imaginary friend disappearing can be interpreted that she did push through with the abortion (which parallels the 13 y/o kid and ariana), or as her finally finding peace with whatever choice she made. hopefully, this film gives conservatives some perspective on the immense weight placed on women in these situations, and they’ll finally be able to say, “Gets ko na.” not everyone has the means to raise a child, especially when society is quick to judge. and even if you do have the means, you might simply not be ready because you might still have dreams you want to chase. it’s really tough, and that’s why kindness matters so much.at the end of the day, we shouldn’t be the ones deciding what women should do with their bodies. and yeah, practice safe sex!!

'Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya.Ang hirap maging babae sa bansang 'to.Gusto ko lang sabihin na napakagaling ng mga gumanap sa mga karakter sa pelikulang 'to, hindi ako usually umiiyak sa mga pinapanood ko, pero dito, nagawa ko. Para sa'kin, purong-puro 'yung mga scenes, naipakita talaga 'yung reyalidad ng buhay pagdating sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine, mga pangyayari na katulad ng sa kanya. Pati 'yung sitwasyon na nangyayari sa mga public hospitals, 'yung mga facilities na binabayaran natin gamit ang tax natin, ay hindi nila magawang maayos. May mga doktor pang kung umasta ay hindi sila propesyonal at napaka-condescending. It is the reality of life here in the Philippines. Napansin ko rin that hatred for abortion is rooted from patriarchy and religion, napakahirap maging babae kapag ito ang mga kalaban mo, 'no? Sa babae ang sisi, sa babae ang lahat ng kasalanan habang ang mga lalaki ay may tinatawag na "free pass." Sabi pa nga nila, "Ba't ka kasi bumubukaka," o kaya naman, "Kung sino-sino na lang kasi ang kinakalantari mo." Those things are the representation of the mindset of those who deem themselves as religious, but for me, they are just a bunch of hypocrites. Men can even be erased from the picture, and women will continue being condemned. Fuck people with double standards. Our society is so hypocrite that 'yung mga tinatawag na "pamparegla" ay natatagpuan malapit sa labas ng simbahan. Gaano sila kamapanghusga sa mga babaeng may karapatan sa kanilang sariling katawan, ipinapakita 'yan sa paniniwala nilang biased at outdated. It is sad to think na kailangan pa ng mga kababaihan na mag-lean towards these illegal means just to afford being free, when in the first place, it is their right to have a legal, safer, and non-demoralizing way to abort when it means taking care of their body, preventing the unborn from having a miserable life, and just letting women have their right to bodily autonomy. It just shows na napaka-patriarchal ng batas, sumabay pa 'yang pagiging misogynistic ng lipunang ginagalawan natin. These force women into motherhood and to have a life they do not want, and guess what happens after that? The cycle continues. Sa mga katulad ni Sunshine, at sa mga kababaihan, I'm proud of you. Sana'y buhay pa ako kapag nawala na 'yang ganyang kabobohang mindset na laganap ngayon.

I hesitated to write a review that delves into the realities women in our country face, because I’m not the person who should be speaking for them.But SUNSHINE is a deeply powerful film.It would’ve been easy for a story like this to sink into pure despair from beginning to end. Yet somehow, the film manages to confront its darkest truths while still carving out a sliver of hope. The performances are extraordinary—raw, fearless, and honest—but they make the film difficult to watch in the best possible way. It exposes how our country refuses to grow, medicine needed for the operation coming from black markets, how it continues to force women into roles far smaller than what they’re capable of, and how it avoids addressing issues that desperately need to be talked about. Women deserve choice. They deserve agency. They deserve that right without question.This film places you in the shoes of a woman who believes her life has been shattered by one reckless decision made by someone she trusted—and then shows, unflinchingly, how our society treats victims.Hopefully, the success of this film reignites the conversation around the importance of being pro-choice and pushes us toward building a better, more humane system.All we hope for is a little sunshine to finally break through.

thank you antonette jadone for that ending. maris racal, brilliant performance. yeah, i cried. the plights and reality of Filipino women. a country where the government prioritizes their reputation and relationship with the church over the welfare of their people, over the welfare of their female citizens. the church constantly used as justification for conservative law decisions for women’s health and well-being. the shame and guilt brought on by Filipino society on women who choose, choose for themselves, for their dreams. why, why should we shame them? why should we rob them of safe procedures for abortion? what case do we even make for victims of rape? why, should we dictate that they should push through with the pregnancy? so here’s to brave Filipino women out there, i’m so sorry that this country could not support you and would rather even shame you. i wish you well, i hope you were able to chase your dreams and turn them into reality just like sunshine did.

Nothing beats reality when it is transformed into art. The uncomfortable and unsettling feeling is present throughout the film, demanding to be felt by the audience—as it should be. We need to face this reality. Check on our siblings, sons, and daughters. Isang mahigpit na yakap para sa lahat ng mga kababaihan.

this film doesn't just tell a story; it exposes a system. for that reason, it stands as one of the most important films ever made in the philippines. honestly, it deserves far more attention, discussion, and recognition. include it in school curriculums too if possible.you don't need tearful monologues, or dramatic breakdowns (not that there's anything wrong with them) to understand the full weight of sunshine's situation. the film uses restraint as its sharpest tool. the dim, muted visuals; the overwhelming noise of her environment; the way the camera locks her in the centre of the frame.. always boxed in, always between lines.. all emphasise how trapped she is by the social and religious stigma, and by a society that refuses to recognise abortion as a woman's right. the blurred backgrounds aren't just aesthetic; they reinforce her disconnection from the world around her. she doesn't have the luxury to care about anything beyond her immediate reality: herself, her dreams, and the looming consequences of every decision she faces.and that is the tragedy, sunshine is a young woman with ambition, yet she navigates a world that is unforgiving. she is asked to seek god's forgiveness for attempting to abort the baby, yet if god is understanding, wouldn't he understand that she is not ready, and that she acted out of necessity? with abortion vilified and access almost impossible, the film illustrates how society corners, isolates, and silences young mothers.. not with loud condemnation, but with quiet, crushing inevitability. it is a devastating portrait of how systemic and cultural forces conspire to limit women's autonomy, and a reminder of the human cost of denying choice.one of the most striking elements of the film, for me, is its gendered power dynamic. every character, without exception, imposes his own beliefs onto sunshine. urging her to keep the baby, citing legality, morality, or personal conviction. their "advice" is never about her well-being, it's about controlling her choices. the absence of a single moment where a man asks what she wants is not accidental, it reflects a broader social structure where women's autonomy is secondary to male authority.the women in the film, however, present a more nuanced spectrum. some internalise patriarchal norms and unintentionally reinforce them, but many others recognise sunshine's struggle immediately. they empathise not because they have the answers, but because they understand the emotional, economic, and social burden that falls disproportionately on women. their solidarity is quiet but powerful. a direct contrast to the coercive, dismissive tone of the male characters. the film ultimately critiques how systems built and upheld by men deny women agency, especially around reproductive choices. in a society where institutional and cultural norms consistently silence women, the film shows that women often became each other's only source of validation, understanding, and empowerment. no scene is waster. nothing is filler. every character is intentionally placed, each one shaping or limiting sunshine's decisions in ways that feel painfully real.

Yes! This is the type of films the Philippines should make more! Finally a movie with substance, relevance, and courage to tell a story despite cultural taboo. This is required and essential.I thought an hour and a half wouldn’t be enough to dig deeper into the journey of Sunshine but it was actually just enough to see all of it. Although, there were unnecessary choices made in the film that I disliked and that I wish were done differently and I wish saw more of Sunshine’s character in the lowest of lows or maybe I’m just greedy. However,Maris Racal is a revelation. And for the Philippines to have such a film like this one that speaks to so many women, even men, in the country. I hope this is a step forward for the country to move progressively and this be a force for politicians to pass that bill. Because after all, films are made to speak out, protest, and to implement change. Lastly, Sunshine is such a huge step towards good filmmaking in the Philippines. We need more films that speak of truth and of society. Stories that need to be heard and not rely too much on fake romance. Though Sunshine isn’t perfect as a film itself, the courage and the amount of truth revealed in an hour and a half are enough to have the voices of so many women be heard. TO THE PHILIPPINES: YES TO ABORTION!

Alas tres na ng madaling araw pero I have to get this out kahit medj unorgnized pa ang thoughts ko.!! MAY CONTAIN SPOILER !!GRABE. GRABE. GRABE. MARIS RACAL I WAS NOT FAMILIAR WITH YOUR GAME!Ang kwento, ang cinematography, ang emosyon!!! Sobrang raw and realistic from the familiar “jeje” song playing sa jeep pagsakay ni Sunshine, to the 13 yr old na nakaranas ng pang aabuso mula sa kanyang tito (talamak ang kaso ng incest sa pinas, thank u direk for highlighting that). Sa sobrang realistic pati ang inis ko kuhang kuha ng conservative doctor. Literally had to pause and say “Putangina” pag sabing “Baka yan pala ang magiging future presidente ng Pilipinas or ang makakagamot sa AIDS.”Ang pelikulang ito ay napakatapang. It had the guts to shine a spotlight on a longstanding issue sa bansa na lagi na lang inooverlook. It dare call out and address what Filipinos considered as taboo. And as someone who had a debate with her mom over dinner about abortion, this film is so special to me. “Hindi ka ba kinikilabutan?” were my moms’ exact words but I cannot blame her. Being a country deeply rooted in Christianity, where morals and teachings of the church are deeply ingrained in you ever since you were young, it is actually hard to speak freely about this things without the catholic guilt creeping up on you. Kaya ang laki rin ng significance ng pagdasal muna ni Sunshine before nya gawin. To ask the lord for forgiveness.Plus it doesn’t shy away from showing the state of the country’s public healthcare system. Nakakaputangina lang. Putangina ng gobyerno. Putangina ng sistema kung saan kailangan maging life-threatening situation ang pagpapalaglag. Banning abortion does not end it, it only makes it unsafe for women since it causes them to resort to underground means. And what an irony that one of those means can be found tucked under the shadows of the church (mga ale na nagbebenta ng pamparegla, u carry so much hope for these women). The very church that condemns it and shuns women who will even consider it. This film is a big step in understanding women’s bodily autonomy. Mas mahalaga pa rin ang buhay ng nagdadalang-tao. Lastly, Annika (the child symbolizing Sunshine’s future child) saying “Gets ko na” at the end is so so dear huhu. Bata pa ang bata para magkabata. She has her whole life ahead of her and god forbid a woman chooses herself and her dreams. Gets ko na, Sunshine. Gets ko na.

this film is so close to my heart and i don't think there's a word in any dictionary that can explain how much value i put in this movie. sunshine is the representation of many young girls in the philippines and the cultural violence that filipino women have to face every single day. manila is home, but what home turns away its daughters? what home is so noisy that it becomes hard to hear the plea for change? it's hard to drown out the noise when manila is nothing but the howl of traffic and trains grinding along rusty tracks. it's hard to drown out the noise when every corner of the city carries the weight of other people's opinions about you. it's hard to drown out the noise when people love nothing more than the echo of their own voices. it's hard to drown out the noise when the government chooses to not help. it's hard to drown out the noise when the hospitals meant to care for you are bursting in the seams. it's hard to drown out the noise when you're a woman in manila. besides, why are we expected to keep drowning out the noise? why can't the noise just stop. i am tired of seeing women seek help from the narrow and noisy streets of quiapo to get unsafe abortion simply because there's no other choice available to them. women should be able to walk into a hospital and feel protected in their own decisions, in their own bodies, without a doctor insisting they “thank God” for something that has broken them. sunshine, i dream the same dreams you have. gets na gets kita

drown out the noise.kung iisipin, malaya ba maging isang babae?mapagpalaya ba ang manirahan sa ganitong klase ng bansa bilang isang babae? kailan darating yung panahon na hindi na kinakailangang kumilos ng babae sa isang lugar kung saan malayang malaya siyang husgahan dahil sa kaniyang mga desisyon? tuwing kailan mo masasabing malaya ka sa sarili mong bansa; kung nakakulong ka pa rin sa gate ng simbahan, sa ingay ng dyip at tren sa kalsada, sa konsensya mo, sa sarili mo? paano mo aasahang gumalaw ang isang babaeng hindi lang isa o dalawang tao ang "masasagasaan" sa pagtindig sa kaniyang nga karapatan bilang babae—kundi isang buong relehiyon at batas ang haharapin mo na dapat sana ay nangunguna sa pagbibigay sekuridad at protekta sayo. malinaw sa pelikulang ito ang mga problemang nagpahirap kay sunshine, pero higit na mas malinaw ang mga dahilan kung bakit mas lalo itong nahirapan. hindi sana kinakailangang mag-alala ni sunshine sa mga posibilidad na maaaring may maging sagabal sa natatangi nitong pangarap. dito ipinakita na kahit nakatira si sunshine sa lugar kung saan madilim, madumi, maingay, at dikit-dikit ang mga marurupok na bahay ay mayroon pa rin itong isang ate—isang babae, na lagi't lagi niyang ipapaalala na may kakampi pa rin siya sa hinagpis ng buhay. dito ipinakita kung paanong sa kabila ng mga taong maaari mong lapitan sa gitna ng problema ay mapipilitan ka na lamang maglakad nang mabilis at balisa sa quiapo sa takot na may makakita sayo, o di kaya'y mag check in sa isang motel sa pag-asang sa madilim na kwarto ring iyon matatapos lahat ng problema mo. para sa akin, sapat na ang mga eksena sa simbahan at mga rebulto sa harap ng mga pampareglang itinitinda patago upang malinaw na maihatid ang mensaheng nais maparating ng pelikula; na isang malaking sagabal ang mga aspetong isa tayong bansa na karamihan ay mga katoliko, at lahat ng pilipino'y mga hipokritong deboto, at mas may pakielam pa ang mga ito sa mga desisyon ng mga babae para sa kaniyang sarili, kaysa sa kani-kanilang mga buhay. ang pahayag na hindi handa si sunshine maging isang ina ang siyang dapat na tumapos sa lahat ng mga opinyong wala namang maitutulong sa kaniya. ganoon lang sana kasimple ang lahat. pero higit sa mga eksenang nakaangkla sa ating pagiging katoliko ay ang mga doktor, mga propesyonal na edukado, sa pelikula kung saan mas narinig ko pa silang nanghusga kay sunshine kaysa sa sarili nitong konsensya. paano ka nga naman hihiling na sana'y gawin nang legal ang aborsyon sa bansa, kung yung mismong mga pribilehiyo at edukado na mismo ang nagbibigay rason sayo upang mas lalong matakot at panghinaan ng loob? sa mundo na kagaya ng kay sunshine, sino nga ba ang maaari nitong kapitan? hindi ba't mapipilitan ka na lamang tahakin ang landas ng mga naging desisyon ni sunshine? nakakagalit isipin na sa pagtagal ng panahon ay mas lalo lamang dumadami ang mga kaso ng mga babaeng gumagawa ng sariling diskarte para mailaglag ang kanilang mga dinadala; na higit pa sa nagbibigay kapahamakan sa kanila. napakagaling ng eksena niya sa motel; naghihikahos sa pag-asa na mamamatay din yung reyalidad na nagdadalang-tao siya. mistula ko ring personal na nararamdaman yung pisikal na sakit na nagpapadugo sa kaniya. pero tumulo talaga ang mga luha ko nang napagtanto ko yung papel ng karakter dito ni rhed bustamante. hindi matatawaran yung dating ng kuwento niya, dahil nirerepresenta niya ang bawat batang babae na dumanas ng karahasan sa sarili nitong tahanan, mula sa sarili nitong kadugo. sa bawat katagang pagsambit ni coach na "drown out the noise." ay ang reyalidad na hindi lahat ay katulad ni sunshine—sa bawat pitik ng mga kamay at lambot ng kaniyang katawan ay may kakayahan itong lunurin ang isip sa katahimikan. hindi lahat ng dumanas sa teenage pregnancy ay may kakayahang isarado ang isip sa bawat panghuhusga at pagsabi ng mga tao na, mali iyan, kasalanan iyan, malay pa natin at balang araw ang laman na gusto mong ipalaglag ay ang magiging presidente ng pilipinas. higit sa katotohanang dapat ay nasa lalake ang lahat ng sisi, malaking parte rin ang simbahan, gobyerno, at ang mga taong nakapaligid sayo, kung bakit hindi mo magawan ng desisyon ang sarili mong katawan at kinabukasan. pangarap ko rin ang lahat ng pangarap ng mga sunshine.
