This is tough to watch as a woman. I was already crying halfway through the film. I usually comment on the techniques used by the production but I honestly don't feel like it with this film because the story and the themes tackled carries so much weight. I just hope this film could shine a light to everybody, especially the PH Government. The topic shown, specifically, is more than cultural, it is systemic. It is not just a medical issue or a mere moral dilemma in our belief systems considering that it significantly affects all Filipino women. The more we shy away from these issues, the more we increase mortality rates, creating dysfunctional families and dysfunctional communities as a whole, it also contributes to the poverty problem that has prevailed since forever. Safe abortion is a necessity, especially in this godforsaken country.

Hands down, wala akong masabi sa palabas na ‘to. This film reveals everything about the Philippines that we don’t often talk about. Many Filipinos have no choice kasi illegal ang abortion dito, and young women are forced into situations THEY NEVER REALLY WANTED. It shows the harsh reality of how society constantly pressures women into motherhood, ignoring their dreams, their health, and their right to make decisions about their own bodies. The film doesn’t sugarcoat the pain physical, emotional, and mental—that comes with being trapped in a system that refuses to acknowledge their autonomy.What hits the hardest is how normalized this struggle has become, and how many are suffering in silence. Especially the story of rhed bustamante’s character. Grabe. 13 years old nag cacarry na ng baby  a child carrying a child. This is a message to all the people to talk more openly about abortion, to stop victim-blaming, and to hold those useless shitty ass irresponsible men accountable. It’s more than a movie—it’s a wake-up call, a plea for empathy, and a DEMAND for change. Sobrang gets kita, sunshine.

SUCH AN IMPORTANT FILM!!!!During these times, we genuinely need more films like this. First, not only does it touch on the struggles of a young woman faced with an unwanted pregnancy. It also shows how easy it is for the men to rid themselves of the responsibility. Miggy DID NOT give a fuck about Sunshine. He wanted her to deal with it herself; he wasn't even going to give her money if she didn't threaten him. It was his fault that she got pregnant, and yet she has to suffer the consequences of their unprotected sex, which he insisted upon. Second, it is very important how this film shows that early/childhood pregnancies are not just because of young people's 'kapabayaan.' More often than not, young girls' pregnancies are results of sexual assault and rape by predators. I cried when I saw Mary Grace, even more when we were told she's just 13. JUST 13!!!!! She wasn't "wreckless," she wasn't out there having sex with anyone; she was raped by her own uncle. And she's just expected to mother the child born out of such a horrific thing done to her?Third, it shows you just how important legalizing abortion is. It's already happening out there. People are selling abortive pills or concoctions. People are doing basement abortions, in unsafe conditions, without licensed doctors. It's happening and it's dangerous. Sunshine was hospitalized. Mary Grace almost died. If abortion was legal, none of this would've happened. These girls would've been safe and cared for.Again, what an important film! It also shows how abysmal the healthcare system is in the Philippines. Overcrowded hospitals, little to no financial support, etc.On top of that, phenomenal performances all around. Maris Racal was great. Jennica Garcia was, as usual, brilliant. Rhed Bustamante, you will always be a star.This might be the longest entry in my letterboxd rn. I'll end it with: COMPREHENSIVE SEX EDUCATION NOW!! LEGALIZE ABORTION!!!

One thing I like about Sunshine is its brazen risk to center the story on a 19-year old who's made consequentially irresponsible choices. It's a gambit that can easily be -- and, judging by discussions surrounding this movie, has already been -- misconstrued as a lesson on the importance of hammering down our society's puritanical views on sex and reproductive health to set teenage girls straight. That, somehow, Sunshine is a lesson in, as the elders say, "opening your legs for just about anybody"; that she did not listen to the adage is an absolute failing on her part, and its consequences fall rightfully on her shoulders. But here's the tricky bit: Sunshine could very well have been about a mother who could no longer give birth to another, and it would have still been met with the same logic-defying resistance that still places the blame squarely on the woman. Minor gripes include a finicky plot device that, at times, feels jarring and slightly questionable in terms of messaging. But it all feels egregious to say because the urgency of its existence really dwarfs over whatever minor flaws it may have. It also helps that Sunshine carried is so deftly by Maris Racal's and Jennica Garcia's career-defining performances, and a score by Rico Blanco that knows how to restrain and reintroduce itself in all the right moments.Sunshine cracks open a conversation on an obstinately immovable subject, and unflinchingly exposes the grim reality on how our women and girls move about our society, bearing the problems that we could easily find solutions to but which our religious guilt and intolerance constantly shame us into denying.

gets na gets na yung hype for Sunshine, naiyak akothis film really opened up a lot of heavy conversations regarding controversial topics that, up to this day, are still very hard to be tackled in our country where most minds are still enveloped by conservative ideologies that have been long influenced by religious policies.the message is straightforward and clear. it showed us the reality of women alike that had to endure the consequences of the patriarchal oppression and the dominance of Catholicism in the country, which is something that the rightists would undoubtedly refuse to accept because they'd still believe their presumed "norms" are what they think what's "best" for everyone and in the country — which is so out of touch from reality and it's very frustrating.however, i just had a bit of a problem with the film's inclusion of imaginary children; which i think somehow holds it back from letting the main message have its full weight. i get that they were used as some kind of a metaphor or a device for the plot, but something with it troubles me for reasons i can't quite best explain yet.but all in all, i really commend the bold attempts they did for this film. still a solid gem for Philippine contemporary cinema that's deserving to be watched by so many

the premise alone is enough for me to give it a full rating. to come up with a movie about one of the most taboo topics in this predominantly catholic country—given how conservative almost everyone is about it, how it’s actively vilified and condemned, how those who seek it are treated as no better than murderers, and how women are left to fend for themselves and look for alternative ways, whether through an underground clinic, safe or unsafe, or a seller’s comforting words when you don’t even know if the medicine will work—is a huge feat. it has been long overdue, but this is already a big step for everyone. abortion is, and will always be, healthcare.film-wise though, i absolutely LOVE the color grading. i usually hate SOME filipino movies (omg i’m sorryyyy) because the coloring pisses me off (like ik we can do better). idk how to pinpoint what gives me the ick but,,, yeah. sunshine’s though was nice. and it was a delight to see bits of manila’s vibe. always shady, dirty, BUT well, that’s our country and i loved the actual showcase of it. there were some symbolism and stills of how ironic some scenes can be too!! nice touch :) from the pills next to the statues to the jeepney signs. the plot is predictable for me (re: what those kids are), but not in a bad way. it just shows that it’s working, and i feel seen. a lot of women will feel seen. not saying we went through the exact same thing, but generally, the gist of thinking your life is over, or will be if it does happen, because we don’t have a choice in the first place, and are expected to just live with it, is familiar. the amount of mental gymnastics people will spew about “the future of the children,” how they could be “the next inventor of a cure,” while never considering the mother, who has her own ambitions, who has to give birth, raise the child, and provide the system and support for their hypothesis to even happen… it’s all broken-record arguments. these are the usual lines they’ll say, and some of their reactions (doctors, friends, “partners”) really DO HAPPEN irl and it’s proof that the film is heavily based from real experiences, and well researched enough about the actual process people will go through (and went through) for this. here’s to shed light, to inform, and hopefully, to make people more open, thoughtful, and willing to give women the autonomy they deserve.mic drop

ok… two things: ang ganda at ang tapangang ganda kasi kuhang kuha yung manila as in!!! yung opm rap sa jeep, yung kabusyhan ng quiapo, yung juxtaposition na sa tabi ng simbahan mo pa makikita mga nagbebenta ng abortion pills, yung vibe ng recto (tangina heavy on this)accordingly, kuhang kuha din nito yung Pilipino — kung paano tayo nasshape ng religious ideals, kung paano pineperceive ng karamihan yung mga babaeng gustong magpa-abort, even kung ano yung tingin natin sa teenage pregnancykaya ang tapang ng movie na to for delving into sunshine's inner struggles - bilang isang teenage Filipina na working class, na nagkaroon ng unexpected pregnancy, na nakatira sa isang bansa na hindi accessible ang reproductive healthcare at sobrang religious lang ng mga tao (intersectionality af) oo, first choice niya talagang ipa-abort ang bata, pero makikita na hindi to naging madali for her - eto ang crux ng movie. pinakita nito na hindi madali ang daan sa abortion - sa kalooban ng babae at sa mga methods na available sa kanya (esp sa bansa natin). pinakita ng Sunshine kung gaano ka-ingrained sa kababaihan na makaramdam ng guilt kapag cinoconsider nilang magpa-abort. HINDI SIYA MADALI, lalo na if may iba pang circumstances na kailangan tignan. sana magets ng mga close-minded people yung point pag pinanood nila.kung iisipin, buhay ng isang babae in real life ang buhay ni sunshine sa pelikula. pero kahit nakikita natin si sunshine sa ordinaryong Pilipina, napakahirap pa rin ng conversation surrounding abortion. kaya ang tapang talaga ng movie for inviting discussion on this topic.hindi ko nagets at first pero i appreciate how the kid represented her unborn child. ang ganda nung "yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya" nakakaiyak...ang galing galing galing ni maris racal!!!!!gets ko na :)

if there is light, kahit konting-konti lang, we chase it—because sometimes that’s the only thing left for women to hold.sunshine (2025) is the kind of film na hindi ka pinapa-wow sa effects or spectacle. instead, it sits beside you quietly, like a friend na alam lahat ng pagod mo kahit hindi mo sinabi. it’s woman-centered in the most unsettling, honest way—walang sugarcoating, walang mythologizing, just the raw truth of being a girl in a country that asks you to endure more than it ever protects.the film strips away the usual softness associated with its title. sunshine isn’t light; she’s a girl trying to survive a world that keeps dimming her. and when the story touches the issue of abortion not being legalized in the Philippines, it doesn’t sensationalize it—pinapakita lang niya ‘yung totoo: na in this country, women are expected to carry consequences alone. that reproductive rights become moral battles instead of health and safety; na the system treats our pain like an inconvenience, our choices like crimes.‘yung internal struggle ni Sunshine—‘yung fear, guilt, confusion, desperation—hindi dahil “mahina siya,” but because society makes women feel cornered by circumstances we never chose. and the film doesn’t villainize her for thinking about her future; it villainizes the world that forces her to justify wanting one.and then there’s Miggy.Miggy is… familiar. not evil, not abusive, just painfully typical. he represents the kind of boyfriend most girls in the philippines know too well—the one who “cares,” but only until it requires accountability. the boy who says “I’m here for you” pero umiilag sa big conversations. the boy who loves you but doesn’t understand the weight you carry because he’s never had to carry anything like it.Miggy is the embodiment of how boys in this country are raised: may freedom without consequence, may opinion without knowledge, may presence without responsibility. his reactions, his avoidance, even his attempts to comfort—they feel real because they’re exactly what so many girls have lived through. boys who think support is just saying “kaya natin ’to” while leaving the actual pain to us.sunshine 2025 becomes a commentary on how women are taught to be accountable for everything—including mistakes that weren’t only theirs—while men are taught to be forgiven for everything. the movie doesn’t hate Miggy; it exposes him. it shows the casualness of male privilege, the way it slips into daily life unnoticed but heavy—always heavy—on our side.and that’s what makes the film hit: it’s not loud, not preachy, not dramatic. it just shows the truth—and the truth is already loud enough.sunshine isn’t a story about brightness; it’s a story about women trying to navigate a world that refuses to make space for their choices, their fears, their bodies, their futures. it’s a film that says:the pain wasn’t yours alone, but somehow, you were the only one expected to carry it.and long after the credits, you’re left with that hurt—the kind that reminds you why we keep fighting for a world where women don’t have to beg for the right to their own lives.

"Gets ko na."to be honest i don't know what to say, i just love this film so bad!!! i just want to hug all the women who have been suffering for a very long time.this film actually made me think of that college chit-chat from my class last semester that i remember when we were talking about bioethics and the law here in the philippines, my professor told us "alam kong marami sainyo dito ang pro-choice pero as part ng medical healthworkers, we need to be pro-life kasi we need to be rational and to save lives, kasi that's what we'rs here for: what we're aiming to do as part of our jobs." and at that time i was so devastated and upset at the same time, like i don't know what to feel at that moment. syempre as pro-choice i believe in the "your body your choice" but hearing that makes me feel like "hanggang dito ba naman sa healthcare, may pakielam pa rin kayo sa gusto namin gawin? can't you just support us with less risk of dying?" again, i added this to my 2025 favorite top 10 films. tangina ng mga lalake at abante babae!

Ang hirap mangarap sa pilipinas, at mas lalong mahirap maging babaeng nangangarap sa pilipinas. Here, our dreams can be taken away in just one snap. The hardship every woman face in this country was shown in this movie — everything in every angle. From the lack of support from the government, the inequalities women face, how fucked up the mentalities of most of the Filipinos, struggles in the face of poverty, to the fragility of our dreams. "Libre lang mangarap" they say, but it's not really free when you live in this country. It costs you your dignity, and even your life.---- I just know na I chose Humanities and Social Sciences to broaden up my understanding, perspective, and empathy like how this movie exposed and depicted our reality. We all need exposure to learn, since parang hindi sapat yung everyday witnessed struggles nating mga Pilipino, let this movie open your eyes on how f-ed up our system in this country really is. don't say bad wordsedit: gawa project muna bago essay para dito pero I got a lot of things to say for this movie, I actually have watched half of the movie like days before I finished it as a whole you knowww busy woman, daming ginagawa, daming abala sa buhay...from the moment that the bata showed up in the movie, i already know that that's supposed to be the bata inside her womb, point blank period... dami daw di kasi nakagets nung existence ni bata sa movie pero i get it dun palang sa malaman ko kung ano yung premise ng showalam mo it's a battle between dreams or faith, may mga point na napapaisip ako bakit gusto kong maipanganak yung bata, though i believe that every woman has the right to decide for themselves, siguro kasi we already have met the child eh, siguro nagkaroon na ako ng perspective of how the child would think or live kaya i want her to be a real thingcan i just say that it has the perfect casts?? kahit yung mga ekstra o mga nasa isang scene lang, sobrang galing nilang lahat...the script is a chefkiss by the way, it never missed a mark in making me feel more hooked about the characters at dito lang ako talaga nakakita ng napakaraming batang nagmumura (ayokong nakakarinig ng mura mula sa mga bata kaya i hate those parts pero I STILL LOVE THOSE PARTS ALSOOO I DON'T KNOW it makes the movie more realistic and blatant)the only thing for me is that nakulangan lang ako ng konti kay elijah sa acting, i can't really pinpoint it pero nandun na yun konti nalang talaga, di ko siya mafeel nang buo as a character unlike kay sunshine, sa bata, saka kay ariana basta everyone else in the castbut overall, this is such a great movie about battling guilt and passion... naiintindihan mo na ba ako? gets... gets ko na.

Sunshine (2024) is the most needed Filipino film of our generation and the generations to come. Beyond the excellent storytelling and technicalities, the message it conveys in a predominantly Catholic & conservative country is a long-overdue revelation of the reality of women.The film opens conversations for the uncomfortable truth of human nature. This is not just Sunshine's story. This is also the story of every woman and every young girl who face the challenges of being silenced and whose rights are being dictated and stepped on by our society.Maris perfectly portrayed Sunshine as a woman who knows what she wants and realizes the power that she and every other woman should have.The rest of the cast realistically depicted the Filipino society that reflects their morals on the teachings of Christianity. Moreover, the two "imaginary" characters brought life to the film by displaying the faces behind the masked moralities our society tells us.As a child of unwanted birth and as an adoptee, I know deep in my heart how much I advocate for abortion. I will always side with what is just and right; the ability of women to have access to reproductive health and the power of women to make decisions for their own life.Maraming salamat sa tapang at galing mo, Direk Tonet.

I watched this film with my very religious family. I didn't say a word the whole duration of the film— yet every few minutes, without fail, at least one of my family members would nag me about teenage pregnancy and promiscuity. I heard countless demeaning phrases like "kita mo yan? alam mo na ha, pag ikaw" and "san ka pupulutin kung di namin sinasabi sayo 'to?". I'm 15, they don't even let me watch movies with sex scenes on the family tv. (but obviously i still do watch movies beyond my age rating) The overbearing nature of religion is truly a problem in the philippines; and among our people, the vast majority of our country is made up of catholics, and it seems like the state is sometimes one with the church because of that fact. I commend this movie for being a step in the right direction. It's showing the true nature of these things to our often ignorant and close-minded society. I know it's still a long way to a progressive philippines, but atleast i know there are still measures being made to ensure that we will get there. Someday, somehow.

Authentic depiction of how the female reproductive health is viewed and discussed in the Philippines. It is terrifying and undeniably demeaning that many, if not all, do not have access to these basic rights and thus continue to endanger the lives of many women out there. It is more infuriating to know that this also includes children as young as 13. Though this inclusion in the film may seem minor, it actually emphasizes that not being able to be given a choice to our own body steals our futures away.I also liked the nuances and subtle details that made this film feel more humane and relatable, including the motto etched on the Jeepney Sunshine rode when she found out she was pregnant, which was “GIFT OF GOD.” Hands down, Maris Rascal nailed this role. Those facial expressions? Period. Bonus na rin appearance ni Piolo Pascual.I could yap about this film but for the sake of my fingers typing this review, I’ll leave this as it is for now.All in all, this one is a great watch.

Nadama ko sa pelikula na mag-isa si Sunshine sa kanyang tinatahak ngunit nadama ko din na may iilang sumoporta sa kanya at ito ay mga kapwa kababaihan.Ito ang mga babae sa istorya na tumatak para sa akin: Sa eksena kung saan tinanggihan ng isang lalaking doctor i-attend ang batang nag pahilot sa takot na mawalan siya ng lisensiya at isang babaeng doctor ang nag lakas loob na tulungan ang bata. Ito ay realidad na ang batas sa bansang ito ay nakaka apekto sa pag lilingkod kapwa. Ang ate ni Sunshine na inintindi at sinuportohan hindi lamang ang desisyon kundi ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Malaking aspeto ang pagkakaroon ng kapamilya na hindi ka i-guiguilt trip o susumbatan ka sa nagawa mo, bagkus nag tiwala siya na alam ni Sunshine kung ano ang makakabuti para sa sarili niya. Ang imaginary child na nag boses na gets niya ang alab sa puso na makamit ang pangarap ni Sunshine. Sa tanong na who will protect women? Ang sagot ay tayo. Tayong kapwa kababaihan ang palaging tumutulong sa isa't isa dahil alam natin ang bigat ng mundong pasan pasan natin. Sa bansang hindi prayoridad ang kalusugan ng kababaihan, napakita ng pelikulang ito ang realidad ng isang babae kakapit sa kung anong meron sa paligid niya na paraan para mag palaglag dahil pinag kakait sa atin ang accessible healthcare. Ang pelikulang ito ay para sa lahat ng kababaihan na tahimik lumalaban sa ingay ng paligid na palaging may kuda sa kung anong daan ang dapat nating tahakin.

Grabe napaiyak naman ako nito. Although I have personal reservations about Maris Racal due to past issues, her performance in this film was undeniably amazing. Sunshine is a definite eye-opener regarding religion, stigma, and the taboo surrounding abortion matters here in the Philippines.I genuinely feel for all the women represented by the characters of Sunshine and Rhed. They may have different names, but they share a rough, unfair path: being stigmatized and pressured to conform to religious and misogynistic beliefs about motherhood. They are forced into the role of nurturing a child, often without considering their own agency.I particularly noticed the scene when Miggy and his father confronted Sunshine about her situation. They never once asked her what she wanted. Their "plans" were simply laid out for her to accept without a word, effectively depriving her of choice. This lack of genuine care is what hurts. Furthermore, the film shows how these women are forced to go through dangerous and unhygienic lengths just to pursue their personal dreams, highlighting how their rights as human beings are limited solely because of their CHOICE.I appreciate this film immensely, and it should be talked about more. The tragic reality of Rhed’s character, a 13-year-old victim raped and impregnated by her own uncle, is a situation faced by many. Yet, victims like her are still discriminated against for wanting an abortion. The movie effectively represents this toxicity, such as the scene where the OB-GYN cruelly orders a literally pale and blue Sunshine to "repent" while she is struggling in a hospital bed.This film is beautifully made. I sincerely hope that someday, people will truly receive the message: Every woman should have a choice. Depriving them of that fundamental choice does NOT make one a saint.

Watched this before sa sinehan and with the netflix release, had the chance to watch it again alone and at home (can repeat scenes too).It's as good as I remember. It challenges the foundation of this county's backwards and outdated beliefs — the very fact that we are willing, as a nation, to limit what an individual, specifically, a woman's decisions with what she wants do to her own body even if it means them harm just to hold up centuries-old ideals, because what, we want to feel righteous and good people? This kind of shit is barbaric and has no place in the current state of the world. The ending was very powerful. The gymnasium scene where sunshine could be herself: free from the shackles of the patriarchy, is something that brought tears to my eyes. However, I feel like final final scene was unnecessary, it could have ended with the "gets ko na" scene.Jesus, Pilipinas. Do fucking better. Protect your citizens. Protect women.

Gets ko si Sunshine.This film really captures me the most. As a woman who grew up in a most conservative country and a religious family, I feel the comfort of the movie. I know that tackling this kind of topic would raise brows to the people especially the one who’s spirituality believes that a women shouldn’t undergo abortion even if she really didn’t want to bear the child. Actually, it’s even funnier that this country preach that abortion should ban but the truth is there is a lack of education about sex, abortion, and contraceptives. Additionally, it’s so hypocrisy and misogynistic that people really blame woman for getting pregnant but NOT THE MAN?! In fact, they are the ones who put babies inside the woman’s womb. I really learned so many lessons in the movie which open my mind to the struggles of a woman. It’s disappointing that people keep preaching what’s right or wrong but THEY NEVER HELP AND UNDERSTAND THESE WOMEN. The movie open my mind that abortion SHOULD BE LEGALIZE. Abortion ISN’T a sin, murder, nor crime. IT’S A HEALTH CARE. It’s NOT selfish. It’s okay.But it is just sad that the Philippines is not yet ready to understand and tackle this kind of topic. I get Sunshine. The guilt-tripping, shame, and misogyny are tackled in a best possible way to give the viewers assurance and comfort. Also, it gives reminder that Filipinos should really open their minds and change their mindset. Women didn’t deserve the shame, the hate, and mostly the expectations that have been throwing to them just because THEY ARE WOMEN. For fucking sake. WOMEN NEED SUPPORT NOT A FUCKING JUDGEMENT FROM THE PEOPLE WHO’S CLAIMING TO BE A SPIRITUALLY ACTIVE BUT CANNOT OPEN THEIR MINDS AND THINK RIGHT.I hope and wish that the government legalize abortion. It is not a shameful thing to do. It is not killing. It is a self-care — A HEALTH CARE. People should know and understand that.Overall, I really love the movie and it will have a special place in my heart. I hope, Filipino directors would produce many movies like this to promote woman and to educate people that abortion is a health care.

I have so much to say about this movie. Grabe. The story, the cinematography, the acting—everything, just wow. This movie is so impactful, and it felt surreal as it is totally happening in this country right now. Kuhang kuha yung reyalidad sa bawat buhay ng mga Pilipino, sa mga babaeng pinagkaitan ng sariling desisyon sa kanilang sariling mga katawan. As a person who agrees about legalising abortion in this country/pro choice, the religious people who tried to convince Shine and even made her feel guilty about aborting her baby triggered me so much. Dahil lamang sa relihiyosong paniniwala, o konsensya? I get it, it is a sin and it is evil thing to do. But what's more evil is that producing an unwanted child out of guilt into this world. Sunshine wasn't ready to be a mother, she still has dreams to follow, and she has the right to make a decision for her own life, own good, and own satisfaction. Miggy didn't even felt responsible for that child. He only got scared of his pastor father who is also a manipulative religious man. Smh. Men will be a horndog and disappear, yet it's their sperm that made that baby.  Yes, raw sex is pleasuring. But the thought or risk of producing a child habang hindi ka pa handa maging magulang ay dapat lamang na mas nangingibabaw sa kagustuhan mong masatisfy sexually. I hope people are aware of the consequences of their action before doing something because it's a big responsibility.I love this movie so much. Grabe kuhang kuha lahat, mga kaganapan sa maynila, mga black market, mga bawat sulok o tindahan sa quiapo, mga taong hindi nauubusan ng pag asa mabuhay sa kabila ng kahirapan ng buhay, mga batang kalye na nangangarap, at ang mga kinabukasan na naghihintay para sa kanila.I had goosebumps about Annika's representation in the movie. I thought she was the younger Sunshine  I just realized that she's the child that shine could've had. Now I know why she always appears around her, and make her feel guilty, and understood her in the end.I love this movie so much! I hope this will be an eye opener to those imbecile peeps lol, and ofc the government. Abortion should be legal, especially if it'll be processed by the law too. Irresponsible people should not be punished by forcing them to keep the child. Because only the child will suffer throughout their lives. There are for sure a lot of an unwanted pregnancies situation, not only by not using condom but could be also by a failed contraceptives, or lack of knowledge about the reproductive system. Restricting abortion doesn't really promote responsibility—it just punished people for circumstances that are often beyond their control, and women will always be left with no choice but to abort an unwanted child in a harmful way.

kudos kay dir. jadaone kasi bihira lang ‘yung ganitong ingay sa filipino cinema, buti na lang walang twitter mga matatanda baka ma-cancel pa ‘yan siya lolanyway, kahit baliktarin mo man ang mundo, walang mawawala sa lalaki when he engages in coitus—kahit pa makabuntis ito. and, the film gave us this statement as it is. moreover, it exactly depicts how our society reacts when a woman participtes in sexual intercourse: bawal, nakakahiya, nakakawala ng dignidad. that our society reinforces this same tired belief: kapag babae ang nagkamali, pangalan at pangarap niya ang nakataya.nakakairita kasi napakatotoo, “mag-iingat ka,” “isipin mo lagi ‘yung future mo—‘yung pamilya mo,” “tandaan mo na ‘yang virginity mo ang pinakamagandang maireregalo mo sa asawa mo,” mga katagang palagi mo maririnig kapag babae ka pero ni isang beses hindi ibubulong sa isang lalaki. nakakainis kasi hindi siya exaggerated, it’s not melodramatic, it’s reality. the silent judgment, the unsolicited advice of people, and the casual sexism na parang background noise ng buhay ng babae. it makes the audience uncomfortable, distressed, and painfully aware of how familiar everything is.ang ganda lang kasi it’s not about regret, rather it’s reclamation. it gives you this dichotomy between burden and freedom, as well as give you the raw and aching truth na nakakagalit, nakakaiyak, nakakaputangina kasi bakit hanggang ngayon ganito pa rin?ay, putangina rin ng mga lalaki, putangina ng mga hindi naniniwala na virginity is a social construct that’s used as a tool for the patriarchy to label a woman’s dignity, putangina ng mga hindi hinahayaang magkaroon ng bodily autonomy ang mga babae. legalize abortion at sorry papa god sa bad wordssana gets

From the very beginning, the film doesn’t sugarcoat anything. It throws you straight into the raw, unfiltered reality of the city. You feel the noise, the chaos, the sense of being overwhelmed, like you’re standing right in the middle of it all.Pero beyond the city’s noise, Sunshine digs into something heavier. It shows the weight of Sunshine’s struggle, the clash between personal pain, religious expectations, and society’s harsh judgment. The movie doesn’t shy away from the reality na hanggang ngayon, ang hirap mag-access ng abortion services sa Pilipinas dahil illegal pa rin ito. It captures how isolating it is to face a problem this heavy, and how hard it is to seek help in a system that refuses to understand.Overall, I like it.

A young aspiring teenage Filipino gymnast who everyone looks up to has been selected in the National team to participate in Olympics. Her nightmare begins when she finds out she is pregnant. Her boyfriend wants her to abort. Her best friend disowns her. She hallucinates a small girl chasing her around trying to make her feel guilty. Desperate to pursue her gymnastics career, she buys a product from the local black market. She rents a room in a shady inn, inserts the product and ends up bleeding profusely. She wakes up in an anti abortion clinic to learn that the fetus is still alive. ‘Sunshine’ plays out like a horror movie as the characters try to come to terms with their reality. The tension, fear and desperation is palpable. Sunshine’s journey from numb helplessness to a woman who wants to pursue her dreams is truly remarkable.Abortion is illegal in the Philippines under all circumstances, including rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. Black markets of abortifacients thrive near places of worship and street side shops. Hospitals refuse admission and doctors perform secret illegal procedures. Antoinette Jadone’s writing and direction is raw and brutal. The narrative is neither preachy nor claims to know a solution to a complex problem that leaves women without agency. It simply critiques the situation and demands that viewers confront it along with women who are left helpless in front of politics and religion. Maris Racal pours her heart into the titular character and you would feel nothing but compassion and empathy for Sunshine Francisco.

There’s always a thin, trembling line between a patriarchal society and the relentless social construct that insists women still can’t decide for themselves—least of all when it comes to their own bodies. And even if we try to drown out the noise, this film refuses to stay quiet. It hits too hard. It shows the very realities women go through in today’s world.What makes it even bolder is its willingness to be raw, relevant, and unapologetically confrontational in a country where abortion remains illegal. It doesn’t tiptoe. It doesn’t soften its edges. Instead, it stares straight into the contradictions of a culture that claims to protect life while silencing the ones who live it.

this is someone’s life right now. put yourself in their place.you can understand sunshine even if you’re not pregnant. even if you’re not a gymnast. even if you’re not joining the olympics. she’s a woman filled with rage, ambition, and dreams. in a place that reeks from layers of sweat, the stench of alcohol, noise, spit, and smoke—under the blazing sun and along filthy streets, sunshine keeps shining. she can carry herself even when only a few stand behind her. it’s hard to be a woman. it’s hard to live on your own. it’s hard to bear problems you never wanted in the first place. it’s hard to live comfortably when you don’t have the privilege to attain that right away. but if no one reaches for her hand, she’ll take her own. because her story isn’t about waiting for someone else to save her—it’s about uncovering the strength that has always been inside her.

jadaone never fails to deliver a movie that starts strong but falls flat and chokes on the message it’s attempting to tell, whatever that may be. every story she writes is abysmal and surface level and almost always advocates for shallow feminism, hanggang doon nalang ba tayo? spouting for women’s rights without actually understanding the nuance of what you’re actually advocating for?maliban sa poverty porn na kinatutuwaan ipakita palagi ni jadaone, from fan girl to sunshine, she also likes showcasing sexual assault as a plot device, only this time it wasn’t shown to us explicitly—wow, how she’s advanced in her writing noh? (sarcasm meant)while i appreciate the gritty and emotional moments of the film especially when the focus is entirely on the movie’s protagonist who it’s named after (maris carried this entire film along with the supporting cast’s acting) it’s overshadowed by it’s dogshit abysmal surface level performative writing, its inclusion of imaginary children that is either a representation of the characters and their inner child or their unborn children which confuses and irritates me as they’re shown way too much, the on the nose messaging of conservatism in the philippines, the lack of detail on how important sunshine’s dream actually is because it focuses on another separate character that rids sunshine a chunk of her story and conflict, and the abstract, hollow message they’re trying to advocate for.genuinely, can we take the pen away from this grown ass woman? not only does she exploit the masa to serve her story but women as well, nakakabastos sa totoo lang, not very feminist and not very for the masa also—add to the fact that jadaone probably thinks that her audience is stupid and can’t read in between the lines for how she chooses to write the story. more actions, less words sana, more time spent in the writer’s room, less color-grading and filming quiapo’s slums for your poverty porn sana.i could say more but i’d have to give half a star at least for the cast’s amazing performances, they carried this film, and they deserve the recognition especially maris racal. also nagulat ako andito pala si piolo pascual haha.

"Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya"it's such a brave move for anyone to take this on considering how against our country is in making abortion safe and legal ! sunshine is a beautiful film that depicts the reality of being a woman in this country. the philippines is not ready for this and it shows

Pero Quiapo… a place where you’ll find even the tiniest bit of hope, a place where even an ounce of solution can be found, a place where help exists, even if only through a few people.i also loved how fuckass men were portrayed in this movie. walang kwentang jowa, walang kwentang kapatid, walang kwentang tatay, walang kwentang tito, walang kwentang doktor. Tangina ang may kwentang lalaki lang ata rito is yung tricycle driver eh. Tangina ng mga lalaking ganyan. Patriarchy at its finest! Also, fuck women who let themselves be abused by this power. Yes, I’m talking about YOU nanay ni Mary Grace.as it progressed, onti-onti kong nararamdaman yung emotional sincerity ng film. yung dilemmas of decisions ni sunshine and yung heartbreaking truth about Mary Grace’s pregnancy. 13 years old pa lang siya? Yes, 13 years old pa lang siya. The movie refuses to romanticize their situation. instead, it leans into the uncomfortable truths of being a young woman in a society that praises discipline, resilience, and sacrifice yet offers little support when life derails. Director Jadaone shapes the film with a raw, documentary-like honesty: tight shots of silent breakdowns, stripped-down scenes with no dramatic score, and a narrative that mirrors the suffocating pressure placed on young Filipinas navigating taboo choices.Lastly, ang nagustuhan ko talaga sa film na to is the fact na the film didn’t fail to show and acknowledge the other women surrounding sunshine. women who, though not always in the spotlight, embody the many forms of pressure, expectation, and silent resilience that shape the world she moves in. they all carry their own versions of sacrifice: women praised for being disciplined, nurturing, and endlessly strong, yet rarely offered the same support they tirelessly give. like seriously? the maternity ward scene broke my heart so much  seeing allthe women sharing the same beds also shows how fucked up our healthcare system really is. Tayo-tayo lang rin nagtutulungan. Tayo lang ang sumusuporta sa isa’t isa. Tayo lang mga babae. Kudos to that tindera. Ironic lang na sa harap pa talaga ng mga rebulto ni santo niño nagtinda ng pampalaglag  these kinds of religious beliefs shouldn’t really hinder us from doing what’s right and best for ourselves. and in showing these women’s quiet struggles, the film expands its emotional weight, reminding us that the story isn’t just about one girl’s burden but about an entire generation of women expected to endure everything while being thanked for it in silence. kulang pa tayo sa pansin, sa pagmamahal, at sa suporta. i hope that someday, all of us can finally feel how to live as a woman and be loved as a woman.

Kudos to Direk Tonet, Maris Racal, and the whole team responsible for creating this film, thank you for being brave and casting a light on our nation’s issues often overlooked in fear of the cultural taboo it carries. I would have rated it 5 stars, but the choice to represent Sunshine’s internal conflict with herself through a hallucinated child character doesn’t sit right with me. Jadaone’s direction results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the film’s emotional center. What was perhaps intended as a bold attempt at cinematic expression to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. It’s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the film’s pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old “when does life begin?” debate—a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesn’t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, frames it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. Though, I will still give my flowers to this movie. It helped brought upon a conversation in our country long overdue and for that I am grateful. I hope it inspires other filmmakers to be bold in the face of a country that chooses to be blind to issues that continue to grow with no solutions in sight.

oh. my. god. this film is so powerful. so raw and extremely relevant. this is a film ph cinema has long been missing. it is harsh in tackling the realities of womanhood and most importantly, the taboo case of abortion in this ph society. no filipino mainstream film has ever been this confrontational about the philippine’s criminalization of abortion. the religious trauma, the guilt that piles, the heavy duty of motherhood that is immediately expected of a woman. i stand by my notion that pregnancy must never be romanticized, for it is a big responsibility to carry and such a heavy toll on a woman’s life.such a beautiful movie, from its core to its composition. the framing of each shot is so good and so honest in showcasing manila as it is—chaotic and alive. the message this film delivers is something so poignant; despite the struggles, despite getting thrown into one trial after the other, you must reach your goals, you must be defiant. like sunshine, as a young woman, you must.

people often judge teenage pregnancy as the result of “giving in to temptation,” but this film shows the other side—not all teenage pregnancies are wanted or chosen. what i love about the film is how powerful it is; it resonates deeply with viewers and delivers a clear message consistently from start to finish.maraming sunshine sa lipunan—na biglaan, takot, at walang lakas ng loob na harapin ang pagiging ina—pero hindi ito usapin na masama ng tao si sunshine kaagad nang dahil lamang sa hindi pa siya handa. a moment of temptation is not enough reason to demand she accept her situation, as forcing a woman into parenthood before she is ready is a far greater mistake.i hope this film opens more eyes and highlights the need to strengthen reproductive rights in our country, recognizing that abortion is a right for all women. men who cause pregnancies rarely face the same scrutiny or shame; women, on the other hand, bear society’s judgment alone.abortion is not always chosen for pleasure—often it is the result of abuse or exploitation.it is heartbreaking that in the philippines, a case of violence against women is reported every 57 minutes. globally, over 30% of women—more than 737 million—experience abuse from partners or non-partners. many feel trapped, unable to leave because they are pregnant and have no right to terminate.in february 2024, save the children urged stronger reproductive rights in the philippines, noting that 35% of filipino girls under 15 became pregnant from 2021 to 2022—clear victims of abuse and exploitation. this is a critical issue that the government must address.women have the right to control their own bodies and make their own choices—regardless of religion, culture, or social pressure. they are often the most vulnerable and left behind in such situations.thank you to sunshine for her courage in standing up for herself and pursuing her dreams, and thank you to the film for portraying these realities.as i read somewhere, “marami ang hindi mapapatawad si sunshine dahil sa ginawa niya, pero sapat naman nang napatawad ni sunshine ang sarili niya.”

hurt to watch, but also necessary. we definitely need more easily-accessible movies that stir up discourse on important issues like this. by easily accessible i obviously mean the price and the length of the runtime they had in cinemas, but also the straightforwardness of the story with just one metaphorical element, the little girl. knowing filipino audiences it’s almost better not to hide in metaphors or hard-to-get undertones, else they misinterpret because this country needs so much more improvement in media literacy, comprehension, and just plain empathy for others who have different beliefs. not to say a lot of filipinos are stupid… that stupidity is also, unfortunately, engineered by the system we’ve been stuck in since forever. but anyway. solid movie for sure!

super tagal ko inantay yang film na yan promise, matagal na dapat ilalabas talaga yan kaso nagkaroon ng issue si maris. okay ito ha... para sa akin, yung likeliness ng isang tao towards a movie depends on how they perceive it. kaya kung ako ang tatanungin, the fact na they were brave enough to dive into that taboo topic palang, it alr made the movie good. sobrang realistic, sobrang authentic, at sobrang maka-tao.nakakalungkot isipin na kailangan pang pagdaanan ng mga kababaihan yung dangers ng isang bagay na dapat assisted na and legal with healthcare. hindi ko maintindihan bakit ang desisyon ay nakasalalay sa mga taong wala namang karapatang bumoses. sa gitna ng film, sabi ko sa friend ko @beh kung nasa ibang bansa lang, tapos na yan agad no?" wahahaha kung ibang bansa lang ang setting, hindi na nila kailangang mag-agaw buhay pa dahil lang pinili nila yung sarili nila. sobrang fucked up dito sa pilipinas jusk!!!ang emotional ko slight dun sa patapos na na part, yung indication nang pagpili niya sa pangarap niya. hindi niya kinailangang patayin yung pangarap niya, kasi kung gagawin niya yun parang namatay na lang din naman talaga siya. naiisip ko yung mga babae na walang choice. naisip ko yung future ng mga kababaihan na naglaho na lang bigla para gampanan yung role na hindi naman nila ginusto.alam kong responsibilidad nila ang pag prpractice ng safe sex. wala akong tinotolerate. ang akin lang, hayaan sana ng mundo na magdesisyon ang isang tao para sa sarili niya. nang walang hadlang, at nang hindi na kailangan pang dumaan sa kapahamakan.IN CONCLUSION POTANGINANG MGA LALAKE YAN! masaya ako para kay Sunshine.

even the extra characters did well to the point na sobrang natural ng pagkakadeliver ng lines and they way they act. upon reading reviews, ang lungkot isipin na kahirapan na talaga ang naging simbolismo ng pilipinas. when they said “very pinoy”; ofc it’ll start off with “maynila” then hindi na naaalis sa huli ang hirap, kalat, ingay, gulo, korapsyon, hypocrisy, etc. this film is really well produced. it’s something na worth panoorin, esp sa mga hindi naiintindihan ang aborsyon. and realistic din yung fact na hindi gaano natackle yung lalaki haha, sa babae talaga lagi salo yung blame and judgement. putangina diba. sobrang importante ng role ni Annika here. in the end when she threw the line and assured Sunshine “gets ko na”, i see it as innocence, influence, open mindedness, and realist—growth. she’s young—innocent, and her judgement might be due to influence of others, then there’s open mindedness kung san hindi siya nagstay sa same mindset nung naka encounter na siya ng same situation kay Sunshine, but different reasons behind—Ariana’s friend. And then there’s being realist at the end na it’s just okay dahil…hindi natin alam ang pinagdadaanan ng bawat isa. kudos.

lahat ng tao ay may sariling ingay na tinatahak. sa pelikula, hindi lang ito ingay ng traffic o tambutso. ito yung ingay ng moralidad, ng tsismis, ng relihiyong mabilis magturo pero mabagal magmahal. ito yung ingay ng mga taong hindi naman mabubuhay sa katawan mo pero sila ang pinakamalakas magdikta kung ano ang dapat mong maramdaman, gawin, at piliin. at sa lahat ng ito, isang nineteen-year-old girl ang pasan ang mundo—a girl who should’ve been allowed to dream freely, pero sinasakal na ng lipunang takot sa kababaihang may sariling isip.isang bagay na ramdam mo agad sa pelikula: magkakampi ang mga babae. halos lahat ng karakter ay babae, at karamihan sa kanila may dalang munting piraso ng simpatya. isang kolektibong danas. isang unspoken sisterhood built on the multiple burdens that women carry: being caregivers, dreamers, breadwinners, shock absorbers of society’s cruelty. pero hindi rin romantisado ang pelikula—may mga babaeng kakampi, at may mga babaeng hindi. katulad ng doktor na ultraconservative, na nagpapaalala sa atin ng painful truth: hindi lahat ng babae ay mapagpalaya, at hindi lahat ng babae ay kakampi sa kapwa babae. minsan, ang mismong sistemang umaapi ay umiiral din sa mga babaeng natutong ipasa-pasa ang sakit.pinaka-mahalaga sa lahat: hindi totoong pagiging makasarili ang pagdedesisyon ng babae para sa sarili niyang katawan. kung may isang “gets ko na” moment ang sunshine, ito ‘yon. kung sarili lang niya ang iniisip niya, wala sana tayong ganitong pelikula. wala sana tayong ganitong lalim. pero ang totoo, bawat desisyon niya ay puno ng takot, pagmamahal, at pag-asa—lahat ng bagay na kinalimutan ng lipunan kapag babae ang may kailangan pumili.dito rin pumapasok ang simbolismo ng batang babae—ang unborn child, ang personified conscience. ariana is 13 y/o's own past self, her own fear, her own what-if. lahat ng interaction nila ay nangyayari “sa loob,” sa pinakatahimik na sulok ng isip ng babaeng hinahati ng daigdig. at nung ending, it’s for herself. the hug is acceptance. ang yakap na iyon ay tahimik na paglaya.pero kahit sa mundong pilit nagpapatahimik sa kababaihan, may irony na hindi kayang itago ang pelikula: sa isang konserbatibong lipunan, ang nagbebenta ng religious figures ay siya ring nagbebenta ng abortion pill. ang ob ay bigot. ang bahay ay hindi laging ligtas. ang simbahan ay humuhusga. at ang babae? wala man lang tunay na espasyo para huminga. bakit ang mga lalaki, may opsyon? bakit ang kababaihan, pilit pinapapili pero hindi ginagawaran ng tunay na choice?dito nagiging mas malakas si sunshine. hindi siya martyr. hindi siya sainted victim. she doesn’t just endure—she decides. she chooses herself kahit alam niyang bawat galaw niya may kasamang kurot ng panibagong judgment. she’s not fearless, but she moves anyway. at minsan, iyon na ang pinaka-matapang na pwedeng gawin ng babae sa bansang sobrang hilig kontrolin ang katawan at kinabukasan niya. dedma sa ingay. dedma sa prejudice. kung may pangarap ka, hawakan mo, kahit pa buong mundo pa ang naka abang na magkamali ka. ang sabi ni direk jadaone, ang pagbubuntis ay magbabago sa katawan ni sunshine, sa career niya, sa buong trajectory niya bilang atleta. at totoo—para kay sunshine, ang pregnancy ay literal career suicide. at dito umaalingawngaw ang tanong na gusto talagang ipukpok ng pelikula: bakit ba laging kababaihan ang kinakailangang magsakripisyo ng pangarap? bakit ang freedom ng babae ay laging conditional?kaya oo—decriminalize abortion. kasi ang autonomy ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban, dapat innate. ang katawan ng babae ay hindi battleground para sa moralidad ng iba.in the end, sunshine reminds you that sometimes the bravest thing a girl can do is to choose herself, quietly, consistently, even when the world says she shouldn’t.

‘yong pangarap ko, kung ano'ng pangarap niya. ⋆˚࿔Especially in the Philippines, society is stacked against women. From secretive clinic visits to hushed conversations with unsympathetic adults— with Sunshine’s journey, you can feel the judgement of a society that constantly polices women’s bodies and their choices. Patriarchy is relentless : they leave it up to the women to pick up the pieces that the men shattered— "Bahala ka na diyan, just get rid of it". Maris Racal’s performance was exquisite, ramdam mo yung pagod, sakit, and overwhelming suffocation that Sunshine faces as she navigates through making a choice that is supposed to be hers and hers alone. Every flip, every landing, every stretch was a step towards her dreams— the stage, the recognition, the life she has ever envisioned for so long. Sunshine’s journey is not just about survival; it’s about the courage to continue dreaming in a world determined to limit her. Gymnastics wasn’t more than a sport, it was her identity, her sanctuary, the place that gave her hope to keep believing. At the end, pinili niya pangarap niya, despite the fear, the sadness, and the guilt, her decision was a refusal to let anyone dictate her future, to let her stop that dream.

First of all, I know that this movie premiered at the 49th Toronto International Film Festival in 2024 and arrived in Philippine cinemas 4 months ago. And now that it finally dropped on Netflix… I hope I’m not too late to say it finally: This movie is powerful Antoinette Jadaone delivers one of her most fearless films yet with ‘’ — a coming-of-age sports drama that hits with quiet power and emotional honesty.Maris Racal plays the titular character, a young gymnast on the road to the Olympics. Her world revolves around discipline, repetition, and the dream of making it to the competition she’s trained her whole life for. But when she discovers she’s pregnant, her perfectly controlled world cracks open.What I loved about the film is how it never sensationalizes her situation. Sunshine’s fear is treated with quiet realism. The movie acknowledges how complicated teenage pregnancy is, especially in a society where abortion, reproductive rights, and bodily autonomy remain heavily stigmatized and often misunderstood.These themes are controversial. And yes, the movie will divide people. But ‘’ refuses to look away from the truth:         .    ,  .Maris is phenomenal here. She carries the entire emotional weight of the story with a performance that feels painfully real. She rarely breaks down on screen, but you think her internal collapse in the smallest expressions — the breath she holds, the way she avoids eye contact, the way she pushes her dream forward while everything else is falling apart.         .The supporting cast — particularly Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Rhed Bustamante, and Xyriel Manabat — also elevate the film, each representing a different kind of pressure or support Sunshine faces. And yeah, some male characters in the movie definitely got what they deserved. Jadaone’s direction is quiet, patient, and uncomfortably close — exactly how it should be. The movie lets us follow Sunshine’s anxiety and feel the suffocating pressure she’s under.One of the film’s boldest artistic choices is the recurring appearance of a mysterious girl who seems to follow Sunshine. At first it’s confusing, then a bit eerie, then surprisingly emotional. I won’t spoil anything, but when the film finally reveals who she represents… . It’s symbolic, heartbreaking, and adds a deeper emotional layer to Sunshine’s arc.Beyond the gymnastics, beyond the controversy, Sunshine is really about choice — and how young women often aren’t given the space to empower themselves to make their own choices.The movie conveys important messages: your body is your own; silence can mask the deepest struggles; the pressure to be perfect is harmful; pursuing dreams matters, but so is ensuring one's survival; kindness fosters safety, while judgment breeds fear; and young women need safe spaces. The movie doesn’t push a specific viewpoint — it drives for humanity.Overall, ‘’ is brave, heartbreaking, and painfully relevant. It does not shout — it whispers truths that hit even harder. Indeed, it’s a film that mirrors reality for many young women today, and one that our society needs to see, even if the conversations it starts are uncomfortable.With that being said, I’m going to give this movie…9/10! Where Filipino films trend to historic dramas and at times big explosive bursts of emotion, Sunshine reflects the good and the ugly of Filipino society in the modern times. It is within the same type as the classics like Maynila sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, but where it could've easily just copied that same old formula of poverty, crime, and the ugliness that lies beneath the city, the film chooses to explore controversial topics at its heart and anchors it toward really good character dynamics, not to mention where other films center around a male character from the rural side or from the slums, we instead focus on a lady who is faced with a great moral dilemma (in the Filipino perspective, you'll get it) when her dreams are on the verge of being stripped away from her. While watching, I sometimes forget that it is a Filipino film (not to sound derogatory or self-hating btw) because it strays away from tired old cliches other Filipino films do, and while the blueprints of those tropes are present, they are presented in a light that feels more subdued than its usual contemporaries. Also, I do love how the film does respect the audience in choosing not to explain certain things, letting us fill in the gaps.It's a great watch, in my opinion. And I feel that this film should be at the helm of some sort of renaissance for Philippine cinema, where we aren't afraid to speak out and be bold while also making great art out of it.

GANDA WTHit cuts deep, revealing the brutal realities of being a woman in a society na hanggang ngayon ay kinakadena pa rin ng patriarchy; mahirap maging babae, lalo na sa pilipinas, at ramdam mo ‘yan sa bawat eksena. its raw honesty, feminist gaze, and unflinching portrayal expose how our culture endlessly polices women’s bodies, choices, and dreams, lalo na when the world expects them to sacrifice habang ang iba ay malayang nakakalakad palayo. by the end, the film leaves you holding both galit and pag-asa, reminding us that kahit ilang bagyo pa, women will still rise — mabagal man, pero matatag, like sunshine breaking through the darkest clouds.

Maganda ang Sunshine, napakita ang pagiging taboo ng abortion, teen pregnancy, at kung gaano kakonti ang kontrol ng babae sa sarili nilang katawan sa Pilipinas.Sobrang totoo ng pag-arte ni Maris Racal, kaya ramdam mo lahat ng pinagdadaanan ni Sunshine. Medyo bitin lang sa pagpapakita kung gaano siya kagaling bilang atleta, at may ilang plot, lalo na yung parallel story ng isang buntis na biktima ng pang-aabuso, na kahit malakas, medyo rushed at overwhelming.Pero kahit ganun, malakas pa rin ang dating ng pelikula sa social issues at sa pagpapakita ng totoong buhay sa Maynila.

gets ko na.literal na gets ko na yung hype. lowkey regretting that i didn’t watch this sa sinehan because it’s good af.sobrang ganda ng pagkakatackle ng social issues na hindi demeaning LIKE gets ba. i like how hindi siya namimilit na maawa ka kay sunshine, but rather you’d get in that process or feeling by yourself. dahil hindi siya nakakaawa, mas nakakaawa yung mga mapanghusgang tao sa paligid niya, yung mundong ginagalawan niya. and i’m so glad she stood up for herself, especially during the scene with piolo (also, super random??) sobrang gusto ko yung color grading, cinematography, and pacing ng kwento. pakiramdam ko kasama ko si sunshine. basta, hindi pilit even yung structure. maganda. kuhang kuha ako.in terms of acting, napakahusay ni maris racal. yung tipong kahit walang linya, tagos na tagos yung emotions niya. i also love how they incorporated the kids (lalo na si ariana) sa kwento. mas napalalim and nagbigay ng kakaibang perspective na at first glance may seem and sound cliche but sa tingin ko maganda siyang addition. siguro some ick lang, sobrang halata nung double ni maris lalo na sa intro part and sa gymnastics scenes. and idk but some scenes ay hindi tugma sa lines or sa bibig nung actors. i hope everyone can watch this film. it’s one of those films na you shouldn’t miss. mabuhay ang pelikulang pilipino !

It’s a great movie. It dives well into the reality of some women and the heavy choices they have to make. A little spoiler: I really like how they were able to let us see the experiences of women, including young girls, who are abused and forced to take on a weighty responsibility just because choosing themselves is wrong in some people’s eyes, even if they didn’t want what’s happening to them in the first place. Some experience it as the consequences of their actions, but this movie also gives up a glimpse of those who are oppressed and have nowhere to go. We also see the current situations of places like hospitals. It’s a good way to raise awareness about the issue being tackled in this movie. Very eye-opening and inspiring.

this film stayed with me. raw, quiet, tapang na hindi sumisigaw pero tumatagos.unang-una: Maris Racal. hindi lang nag-portray — she became Sunshine. yung pagod, yung takot, yung pagka-desperate pero umaasa pa rin… ramdam mo hanggang buto. this is the face of so many young women na araw-araw lumalaban in a country that tells them what to be, what to do, and what to carry.ang ganda ng pagkakahuli sa Manila — yung sikip, yung init, yung ingay, pati yung bigat na hindi mo maipaliwanag. hindi siya romanticized; totoo lang. yung Quiapo scenes? sobrang accurate na parang naamoy mo na yung alinsangan at dasal at pag-asa ng mga taong dumadaan dito para humanap ng solusyon sa problema na hindi sila binibigyan ng choice.and that’s the heart of the film: choice. or the lack of it. bilang kababaihan, ang hirap pag-usapan ng reproductive rights dito sa Pilipinas kasi every conversation is haunted by guilt, religion, and judgment. pero Sunshine manages to hold that tension — yung guilt, yung fear, yung what-if — without punishing the woman at the center of it.this isn’t just a film — it’s a mirror. it asks questions na hindi madali, and refuses to hold your hand para bigyan ka ng sagot. it lets you sit with discomfort. it lets you ask yourself: kung hindi ikaw ang nasa sitwasyon, bakit ikaw ang magdedesisyon?

What will you do if your dream is at stake because of one mistake?Sunshine delivers a powerful message about reproductive rights and the need for access to safe and legal abortion.The film shows the current state of healthcare in the Philippines and how this basic necessity has become inaccessible, especially to those living below the poverty line.I like how the film does not romanticize the societal issue of unwanted pregnancy. Instead, it highlights how stigma deeply affects women’s decision-making about their own bodies. It shows how the main character struggles with an internal conflict and debates with her own conscience.While the film clearly presents why abortion should be legalized and recognized as part of healthcare in the Philippines, it also portrays how religion and health often clash. It is true that our country is still in the process of accepting that abortion is a right that should be available to all women.Some might argue that safe sex is the only way to avoid these situations, but we cannot ignore the fact that many women experience sexual abuse, rape, or non-consensual ejaculation during intercourse.Sunshine is not just a film that explains why safe abortion should be legalized; it calls our attention to consider the issue without guilt-tripping women through religion or societal pressure.Women should have the freedom to decide what to do with their own bodies. Marriage or co-parenting should not be treated as a band-aid solution to a lifelong responsibility. These solutions do not apply to everyone, especially to those who do not have the means to support a child.I know we all have different perspectives on this issue, but thinking long-term about the future of our children depends on how ready we truly are to take on this responsibility.

Hindi talaga ako binibigo ni direk Jadaone kapag usapang isyu, pakikipagsapalaran, at boses ng kababaihan. Kuhang-kuha rin ang realidad ng Maynila (bigla kong naalala ang Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag [1975]).Mabuhay ka direk Jadaone!

Love how the film depicts the harsh reality of what women have to go through just to be able to decide for themselves and their BODIES!! This movie really goes to show how making abortion illegal makes it so much harder and dangerous for women. It does not sanctify the value of life since in the first place the life of the woman is endangered. Moreover, I love how Manila gets depicted in this light, it shows the good and bad that comes with the city. It is bad for obvious reasons, the normalized chaos that is happening around it, how every night Sunshine is there, a mayhem ensues. However, I appreciate how Manila became a sanctuary place for her, where we can see how despite the chaos that happens every night, there are bits of humanity that saves her. The girl dun sa hotel, yung tricycle driver, and the 13-year-old girl that she met.Furthermore, I would like to commend the addition of having childrens act as her conscience or the "what if child of hers". It's a great addition because we can see how in the beginning of the film the girl was literally shouting "murderer" over and over again because in her perspective, her mother is harming her. But in the end when she said "gets ko na", it became a cathartic scene as it finally hits us that it isn't about being irresponsible and selfish ---- rather it is something more than that. The whole line of the girl saying to her friend Ariana that her dream is the same as Sunshine's is a great addition because I think it rings true with reality. As every now and then, when a child hears about the dreams of their parents and how they had to stop it to take care of their children, especially when it comes to Mothers, the child often feels bad and just wished that thier Mom was able to live out their dream first.Lastly, I love the relationship of sunshine and her older sister, the fact that never once pinagalitan o diniktahan ng ate nya sa kung paano nya haharapin yung sitwasyon niya goes to show how much she trusts and love Sunshine. I also love the contrast that all throughout the film there were different sides of the story whether labelling her as a "murderer" o miggy telling her to do what you got to do that once you reached the end scene when her sister just told her "kahit ano maging desisyon mo kampi lang ako sayo" made it soo impactful. Kase in the end yun lang naman ang kailangan niyang marinig, we have seen her face through that circumstance alone with nothing but her conscience, that the moment na sinabi sa kanya yun, it became a relief to her as well as allowed her to finally tell someone or at least cried it out to them na natatakot din siya kase nga bata din siyaa and hindi pa siya ready maging nanay. All in all, the film was a 10 out of 10, and I appreciate how the film wasn't all in the face about what you should believe in and what you shouldn't. It just presents Sunshine's story and her decision which should be acknowledged because hindi dapat humantong sa isang sitwasyon na mas uunahin pa ng isang doktor ang kaniyang lisensya kesa sa buhay ng isang tao dahil lang "nagpalaglag" siya. If you really value life in its essence then we should also acknowledge the life of the person carrying the baby so bakit niyo papabayaan lang na mamatay yung batang 13-year-old???????? so in conclusion:TANGINAA NG MGA LALAKETANGINA MO MIGGYTANGINA NUNG DOKTORATANGINA NUNG LALAKING DOKTORTANGINA NUNG TITO TANGNIA NUNG WALANG KWENTANG NANAY (?) - di nya deserve matawag na nanay

Holy shit, this film had me in tears. Not only is it extremely well made, the cinematography and the characters were so raw that it had me stressing over them. I have never rooted for anyone so much to get rid of that damn baby. The movie also shows the darkest sides of the healthcare system in the Philippines, religion, and most of all, fucking men. It is unfortunate that us Filipina women have it the fucking worst. Not only are we in a third world country where it is illegal to abort, but we are guilt tripped over and over again by society to not choose ourselves. We are literal machines for them to procreate and forget ourselves in the process. We are not human to them.Right from the get-go it is shown how unprepared (who I assumed is 20) 20 year old Sunshine is. Even when she is cleaning up her sister’s child, she raises her hand as if to scare the child, when the child clearly does not understand this gesture. The men in this film are shown to be no help at all, may it be sibling, the boyfriend, the men in the streets, every. single. man. The concept of birthing a child will never be their problem, it will never even cross their minds. I love how realistic the scenes were when all the pregnant were all together, aiding each other and comforting each other; that is the harsh truth— men will never know the connection us women have with one another. Even if they are strangers.Rhed (Mary Grace) is the exact reason why abortion should be legalized in the Philippines. Young women subject themselves to improper medical procedures because that’s all they have access to (and hardly)— they do not know the severity of what their bodies will go through. In the first place, sex education is still frowned upon in the Philippines. God, I really hate, HATE how religion proves time and time again that they are the main reason why we cannot progress as a society. This film is beautifully filmed, I loved every bit of it. My heart sank deeper whenever she struggles, but the weight lifts whenever she chooses herself. Ladies, please choose yourself, above everyone else.

There is beauty in raising a child, and beauty in chasing a dream. Women shouldn’t have to trade one for the other. This film shines light on this truth—understanding that every woman deserves the freedom to choose what’s right for her, and the autonomy to decide the path her life will take.Such a beautiful and inspiring watch. I hope more people watch it, and allow its message to open hearts, challenge norms, and spark understanding for women like Sunshine.

Holds so much meaning about womanhood during different stages of life, especially for those living in a country in which unplanned pregnancy is a death sentence. The backwards system that gets perpetuated by bigots like a couple of doctors that Sunshine meets is heavily stacked against women, but the movie shows us how having a choice can save our lives. There's surrealism in the movie too but it's very much deeply rooted in reality. Many girls are Sunshine or Mary Grace.

'Yung pangarap ko, kung ano ang pangarap niya. Isang mahigpit na yakap para sa mga sunshine diyan:) at fuck you sa mga Miggy at Bobot diyan. Putangina niyong mga lalake, mga walang dulot. Gets na gets ko—and I hope many more people will get it, too. This film struck a deep chord with me. Nearly every scene felt like it could happen in real life—and in many cases, it truly does.Abortion is treated like a sin in this godforsaken conservative and dominantly Catholic country. Many people disagree, but it really doesn’t matter whether you agree or not. In the end, the decision should be up to the woman who’s pregnant. We shouldn’t have an opinion—just understanding is enough. After all, it's her body, her life, her future, her choice. That's why I'll always firmly believe that abortion should be legal and safe. There are women—and even girls—who are far too young, forced into pregnancy, still unstable, still trying to build their own lives, and completely unprepared to raise a child while chasing their dreams. Abortion is healthcare, and access to it is a basic reproductive right.This film captures that reality so loudly. It’s loud with the streets of Manila, with people’s judgment, with hypocrisy. You can hear it all so clearly—the way society pushes women toward unreliable and dangerous methods like pamparegla in Quiapo or hilot, simply because abortion is condemned and proper reproductive healthcare is lacking. It’s so fucked up and heartbreaking. Tangina, ang hirap-hirap maging babae sa bansang ’to—sa mundong ’to.'Yung scene na walang filter na ipinakita ang estado ng public hospitals—mga serbisyong galing sa buwis ng tao pero hindi nila kayang ayusin—sobrang sakit panoorin. Sobrang bulok ng sistema natin. And there’s probably something even worse behind it—we are so fucked.So when Sunshine finally went through with the abortion, I felt relieved. For a moment, I was scared she might keep the baby. Bringing a child into the world when you’re not ready—and being forced to give up your own dreams because of it—is one of the most cruel things you can do to yourself and to that child. And that’s exactly why choice matters.Gets ko na.

Ang ganda!Isa sa mga kagandahan ng Sunshine ay ang pagiging tapat nito sa katotohanan. Pinakikita ang katotohanan kung anong meron sa Maynila; masikip, maingay, maputik, at maalikabok. Pamilyar.Pamilyar ang ingay.Pamilyar ang tsismisan.Pamilyar ang katolisismo.Pamilyar ang sikip at mahabang pila sa pampublikong ospital.Pamilyar ang sistemang mabagal at madalas walang pakialam.Pamilyar—dahil ipinanganak at lumaki rin ako sa pinakasiksik na bahagi ng Maynila.Pero bilang lalaki, iba ang mundo na ginagalawan ko. Sa gitna ng pelikula, naisip ko: hindi ako pamilyar kung paano ba talaga maging isang babae.Hindi pamilyar ang takot.'Yung takot na hindi ko kailanman mararanasan, pero ramdam ko habang pinapanood si Sunshine.Para sa akin, Sunshine works because it feels lived-in.Alam mong ganito talaga ang Pilipinas. Bansang puno ng pangarap, pero puno rin ng hadlang.At sa gitna ng lahat, nando'n si Sunshine: takot at desperado, pero matapang.Hindi melodrama ang dating. Hindi rin lecture.Mas parang paalala: hindi dapat ganito kabigat ang mundo para sa mga kababaihan.

Maris Racal is Sunshine; and Sunshine is womanhood incarnate. Through Sunshine’s story, the film becomes a quiet yet devastating reflection of how our society—and deeply, its systems—continue to fail women. One of the film’s most harrowing moments is the scene where Sunshine rescues Mary Grace after she nearly dies from a self-induced abortion. It is not just a moment of personal crisis; it is a painful exposure of how inaccessible, judgmental, and unsafe our healthcare system remains for women…

Gets.I was gonna leave it there but I have thoughts so full steam ahead—Manila is a staple in almost every Filipino film, being the capital and all, but rather than the large city itself— Sunshine specifically captures the essence of Quiapo so well. The bustling markets, the overcrowd and kids begging for alms, and religion is embedded everywhere— whether it be its churches, the posters within the buildings, street stalls selling rebultos and rosaries, or the people themselves. I don't usually care for the setting of the story but I always think it's smart when it actually helps drive the narrative forward, so I find this neat little aspect of the film amusing (also, while we're at it, props to whoever the prod designer is wow). I watched this at 3AM during a vigil so I had all the time to read other reviews and can I just say, while I understand how it could be viewed as such— I don't think this film was didactic or propaganda. I love films that open conversations and Sunshine opened a lot, but more than the conversations it opened, I love how the center of it has always been women. The heart of Sunshine is Sunshine herself, and Maris Racal definitely gave the performance of a lifetime in this one. The fact that she filmed this the same time as Can't Buy Me Love is insane, talk about range.Also, props to Direk Tonet 'cause I have only watched this film a day before, but it is so dear to my heart. Pangarap ko ang pangarap mo, Sunshine <333PS.Also, whoever decided to cast Piolo Pascual and Elijah Canlas sa father and son deserves a raise.

grabe. SUNSHINE absolutely wrecked me in the best way possible. hindi ko in-expect na ganito katapang, ganito ka-personal, at ganito ka-Pinoy yung atake. ang tapang talaga ng pelikulang ‘to not loud, not preachy, just brutally honest.from the first few minutes pa lang, ramdam mo agad yung bigat na dala ng story. the way the film paints the reality of women in the Philippines… sobrang tumatagos. ang galing ng pacing, ang ganda ng visuals, and the emotions?? solid.what I love most is how real it feels. walang sobra, walang kulang just a story na kailangan talaga mapakinggan. sana mas marami pang ganitong pelikula na hindi natatakot mag-open ng conversations we rarely talk about pero sobrang kailangan.and honestly… I have my own sunshine and gets ko sila :)) kaya siguro mas tumama lahat. when you’ve lived even a tiny part of it, ang sakit niya panoorin in the best way.and that public hospital scene? grabe. damang-dama mo yung pagiging mahirap imagine mga bagong panganak na magkakasama sa iisang malaking ward, siksikan, pagod, walang choice. ang bigat niya panoorin kasi alam mong totoo.

Drown out the noise.The double meaning behind this line in the film holds so much meaning. Both in the sense that Sunshine needs to drown out the noise to chase her goal and that she needs to drown out the noises that judge and try to influence her decision regarding her pregnancy. This film reveals the very ugly truth about abortion: that criminalizing it will not make it go away, but only make it more dangerous for women like Sunshine to go through it.

everything moving, heartbreaking, and gut wrenching has already been said about this film so i’ll add my favorite short sequence that left me breathless:sunshine’s attempt at self-induced abortion was at this tiny raggedy inn room; a rule of thirds composition using the windows to divide the shot, sunshine in the rightmost basked in green light, which feels cold and lonely, away from the leftmost corner of the room lit in warm orange light emitting from a small lamp. she’s boxed and contained and helpless, it’s just her carrying the weight of her own problems and decisions. as she slowly carries out the procedure of the abortion, the train rolls by—loud and deafening—like the heavy guilt and grief setting in. she can’t drown out the noise, she’s drowning in the noise of her troubled thoughts.(not great at writing and describing things sry but yeah the inn scenes were the start of my ugly sobbing throughout the movie)
