Two can tango, but only one makes it out of the dancefloor.The hard truth of women and children being the ones to bear the consequences. May this film be an eye opener. The underlying issues on mental health, socioeconomic burden, and lack of education are directly implied in this film. To bravely put it out on Philippine media is a start of a more aware perspective. The cinematography and script are well combined and well thought of. The metaphors hit the spot and Maris' performance not only represented a lot of young girls out there, but also those who are mentally struggling. Seeing someone doing everything alone and bear the burden of something that isn't normative is heartbreaking. Children must not be guilt tripped into doing things just to survive. Proper education and guidance is what we always hope and pray for. May this film pave the way to a more open and safe space for all that are struggling.

“Gets ko na. Gets ko na.”it feels incredibly realistic... so real that it’s as if Sunshine herself is my best friend, opening up to me and sharing her deepest thoughts. you can truly feel every line she delivers; each word carries weight, sincerity, and emotion.the film truly stands out in the way it portrays raw, human moments. sunshine’s character is written with such honesty that her struggles and triumphs feel personal.hands down to you, direk tonet  your vision and heart made this film shine in the most genuine way.

beautiful, just absolutely beautiful this has got to be one of the best filo movies i have ever watched, like EVER. i honestly cannot find the words right now but i have never felt so affected, like i was the one experiencing it. from sunshine drowning out the noise, to her practicing the last time (we see) before the olympics. all of this was just so beautiful, i felt her struggles and everything that happened to her.this movie made me tear up atleast 3 times. it was just so sad seeing the reality, and thinking that someone might be experiencing this - that this IS someones life. its sad, really to think about just how many women have to suffer and give up their lives, their DREAMS just because of this stupid anti abortion law. and its crazy how so much women have to go through suck risky procedures just to get rid of a baby. its not helping either that the philippines is a catholic/ christian heavy country. meaning that in their eyes, abortion is evil and murder. we see this in the film, and the film executed and protrayed it perfectly. we see how sunshine is slowly becomes confuse because why should sunshine apologize? if god is so forgiving, couldnt he forgive her for fighting for her dream? i am catholic but people who think that god wouldnt forgive women for aborting their children confuse me. also, i forgot to mention that we also see how sunshine prays before doing anything bad, just shows that she has some catholic guilt/ conscience.sunshine didnt even want a baby, was it her fault miguel didnt pull out? why should she be pressured to give birth when she never wanted it? think about it, why should women pay for mens incompetence? its crazy how so much men think that just because women carry the baby means that they have to carry all the burdens and troubles too, like hello? ure also a part of this too LOL. speaking of men, FUCK that bobot guy  sunshine was so right for what she did to him and i will forever defend her for that. but, lets not forget that this is the reality of some women. its just gross and inhumane. FUCK YOU BOBOT!! now lets talk about the people who supported sunshine along the way, starting with her sister. Honestly, with how close they were i was really surprised that sunshine never told her. all of their scenes were just so heart warming and it really just felt so comforting. i feel like she was someone that sunshine really needed at the time and yknow those words probably meant so much to sunshine. i got a little teary eyed during that scene cuz it was just so next, the doctora. notice how it was a woman who risked her lisence and did everything to save the pregnant girl? yeah, thats what i call girlhood  but yeah, i was just so happy that someone, an actual stranger, reached out a helping hand. even though she had very little screentime, i really enjoyed her character and it really just showed that there are still some good people out there.moving on, we have the pregnant girl. her hug with sunshine absolutely made me cry. idk, maybe seeing someone going through the same things as her just brought some comfort like atleast theyre both in this together. her almost dying made me feel something, it was either goosebumps or just deadass misery.. i guess a HM would be the coach. (no i am not mentioning the kid cry about it )overall, this was such a beautiful movie. i felt everything and it just captured the life of a filipina so well. just shows how much one person could be going through and how much a woman has to do to simply get rid of her baby. def watch this if you have time!!

this was so realistic. and also so realistic in showing how fucked up the system in our country really is.people say things like "paano kung 'yan yung maging susunod na president?", "paano kung 'yan yung makahanap ng cure sa ganito gan'yan?" when talking about a fetus that might be aborted, when those questions should honestly be applied more about kids who were forced to live a messed up system that was also because of adults, just like yung kay mary grace. her case happens a lot in real life. many children as young as 13 are forced to be pregnant and become mothers. like imagine, a 13 year old?? that's a kid. anddd hindi ko rin talaga magegets (and never will, honestly) yung mga tao na hindi pro-choice who doesn't care if pregnancy happened because of rape. tangina niyo. another thing, dahil nga illegal pa ang abortion in the philippines, a lot of kababaihan would resort to "pangpa-regla" and other unsafe procedures para lang makapag-abort. if the healthcare system truly cares about the people, why prioritize the "life" of a fetus, imbis na sa taong buhay and humihinga na? bakit kailangan pa silang maghirap? and i like annika's character here also symbolizing sunshine's guilt. kahit na parang desidido na talaga si sunshine noong una pa na she wouldn't keep the baby, there still lingers a feeling of guilt inside her, yunv parehong religious and personal guilt. and yung sa last part, her saying na "gets ko na"... ay, putangina, i love it.i really hope this movie would serve as an eye opener sa bansang 'to rsgarding abortion, and i also hope that people become more open-minded. sana maging legal na ang abortion. hay, tangina kayo

Gets ko na si Sunshine.Sometimes I fail to remember how Philippines such as other countries, do not have the same privilege as first world countries do. Imagine the first thing someone says to you after you almost die from trying to have an abortion “Say sorry to God, be thankful He is forgiving. Be thankful that your child is still here.” Women shouldn’t have to feel guilt or religious pressure to have a baby they didn’t want. It should always be their choice, their right to their own body. I hope one day that the Philippines legalises abortion, it’s healthcare after all.I’m just so glad she didn’t let go of her dreams.

If your moral values believe that no child should be aborted, sana kasama rin sa values nyo na walang babaeng deserved na mahirapan dahil sa unwanted pregnancy. Women needs to have choice, if we always shame women na nabuntis, bakit hindi natin ibaling sa mga nakabuntis ang sisi? Sa buong panonood ko, nainis ako kay Elijah Canlas, sa nanay ni xyril, kay Piolo Pascual, dun sa nagtitinda ng pampalaglag, dun sa doctor na ayaw mag-admit ng batang naghihingalo dahil gumawa daw ng ilegal (mind you, narape yan kaya sya buntis), at sa ospital na hindi kayang i-cater ang pangangalaga sa mga kababaihan. Sana imbes na ijudge si sunshine sa choices nya, sana namulat tayong lahat na we should be free of our choices. Na hindi tayo selfish dahil lang ayaw natin ng anak. And that we are entitled to be taken care of kahit ano pang desisyon natin when it comes to our pregnancy. Sobrang lupit ng mundo natin, na patuloy na nagtataas ng kilay kapag tungkol sa SOGIE pero wala ring ginagawang hakbang kapag nagkakaroon ng unwanted pregnancy ang mga kababaihan. grabe gets niyo ba ko?! tangina nadejavu ako sa love in the big city. yung emotions ko and most importantly yung perspective ko sa ganitong 'talk' still hindi nabago. sobrang raw ng film to the point na tanging tunog ng train, jeep, traysikel, mga alingawngaw ng tao yung bumubuo sa lahat pero sobrang bigat, kasi ito yung reyalidad na hindi matanggap ng karamihan. Mahal na mahal kita direct Antoinette, dati hindi ko masyadong na r recognize yung director and staff team itself. pero simula nung natuklasan ko yung mga films mo— nagkaron ako ng pake sa mga detalye na kumukumpleto sa kung anong nakikita ko.dafawk— pero anggaling talagang umacting ni Maris, imagine sobrang raw ng film and no ost songs or so whatever pero dalang dala niya yung emotion. Also, sobrang creative sa part ng character ni Annika, sobrang hirap himayin at ilarawan ng ganitong konteksto sa pelikula, pero yung sa ganitong way, mas nakalinaw siya. Oo ako naiintindihan ko yung ganitong side of talk, pero kung i c consider to na eye opener— yes walang tapon. Sobrang ganda ng detalye sa point na walang tapong sasabihin ng maraming manonood— "gets ko na"

“Gets ko na, gets ko na.”Sobrang tumatak sakin yung line na yun.Sunshine is the kind of film that hits quietly but deeply. It shows how hard it is for women in the Philippines to ask for help, and how scary it can be, pero kahit ganun, it reminds us na may karapatan pa rin tayong mangarap.I also liked how it showed the reality of our Olympians here. You can give everything, train like crazy, be so talented, pero minsan hirap ka pa rin mabuhay. Ang bigat pero ang totoo.Sunshine’s character feels real and strong. Hindi perfect, pero may tapang pumili ng sarili niyang future. Even when she had an easier option, pinili pa rin niya yung pangarap niya. I respect that so much.Sana mas maraming babae ang makapili ng sarili nilang path, dreams, and life.

waited so long na maging available on digital 'yung movie na 'to and needless to say it was worth the wait because wtf ilang beses ako naiyak from the depiction pa lang ng daily life sa pinas, the customs and norms we have, to the imaginary children representing the "could-have-beens", and also in a way, the girls' own guilt following them with every decision they try to make for a common situation that girls—especially the young ones—suffer through here sa bansa na 'to (not just the pregnancy itself but also the internal battles that come with religious guilt and having dreams beyond what other people would call as "a gift from God").na-bother lang ako sa texting scenes because ang random ng pag-type sa keyboard, but hindi mo na talaga maiisip 'yon at present sa sobrang daming na-tackle for such a short film. and yet it was done so beautifully. the pacing was SO GOOD and i couldn't help but fall in love with the cinematography, the WRITING, the ACTINGGG because of how natural the lines were delivered. kudos kay direk at pang top 4 films na ata 'to !!two takeaways for me dito: there's really no hate like christian love and seeing female solidarity in films will always make me cry. (pwede na 'to i-add sa films about girlhood bcs it would be my fav on the list).

Thank you for this film, kudos Direk Tonet! <3

!!!!!!!!! review: tbf

Not everyone will agree with her choices, nor understand them. But since when is it anyone else’s business what a woman chooses to do with her own body?!The raw, unflinching exposition of a city filled with contradictions—similarly displaying the distinct patriarchal society overshadowed by the hold that Catholicism has over the views and laws held by the Philippines. It is beautifully shot and the story is even more beautifully represented through the acting. Sunshine’s story is one related to by many women and brings to light so many issues that women are facing. Her story is one of light amongst the dark; befitting her name
